description: Microsoft Exchange 2013 is one of the most popular commercially supported email and collaboration platforms in the world. This course helps systems administrators to quickly come up to speed on deploying and supporting each of the various services provided in Exchange. In addition to the real world skills, this course also covers each of the exam objectives required for the Microsoft 70-341 exam which counts toward the MCP and MCSE certifications.
name: Microsoft Exchange 2013 - 70-341
subtitle: Core Solutions of Microsoft Exchange Server 2013

episodes.description: Microsoft Exchange 2013 is one of the most popular commercially supports email and collaboration platforms in the world. This course helps systems administrators to quickly come up to speed on deploying and supporting each of the various services provided in Exchange. In addition to the real world skills, this course also covers each of the exam objectives required for the Microsoft 70-341 exam which counts toward the MCP and MCSE certifications.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.186
[SOUND] In this series, we're gonna be

2
00:00:05.186 --> 00:00:11.646
taking a look at Microsoft Exchange 2013.

3
00:00:11.646 --> 00:00:14.872
We've had a lot of request from viewers
out there from people implementing their

4
00:00:14.872 --> 00:00:17.400
own email systems and
they're choosing Microsoft Exchange.

5
00:00:17.400 --> 00:00:18.410
They want some help to be able to do that.

6
00:00:18.410 --> 00:00:20.640
So that's what this series
is kinda built around.

7
00:00:20.640 --> 00:00:25.030
Now we're using the exam objectives for
the 70-341 exam to

8
00:00:25.030 --> 00:00:28.410
build this episode series, just to
make sure we cover all that content.

9
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:31.140
Because it really is a great way
to get introduced to the product,

10
00:00:31.140 --> 00:00:34.140
as well as to get it implemented
quickly and reliably.

11
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:38.140
Now that means that we're gonna cover a
lot of great stuff to get you exam ready,

12
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:40.690
but from a practical sense
what are we gonna cover?

13
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:44.910
Well, in this series we're going to take a
look at how to select the right edition of

14
00:00:44.910 --> 00:00:49.050
Microsoft Exchange, how to get Exchange
installed and have the right amount of

15
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:53.060
servers for your environment, get that
network design properly put in place.

16
00:00:53.060 --> 00:00:56.944
How to implement mailbox services, which
is probably the most important part of

17
00:00:56.944 --> 00:00:58.890
an email server is to
be able to send email.

18
00:00:58.890 --> 00:01:01.140
But also take a look
at the calendaring and

19
00:01:01.140 --> 00:01:03.460
other functionality that's
built inside of Exchange.

20
00:01:03.460 --> 00:01:06.660
There is a ton of power under
the hood of Exchange that makes it

21
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:08.560
far more than an email server.

22
00:01:08.560 --> 00:01:10.660
And we're gonna take a look
at all of that, right.

23
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:12.790
Let's take a look at the exam
objectives to get a look at some of

24
00:01:12.790 --> 00:01:14.080
the things we're gonna cover.

25
00:01:14.080 --> 00:01:17.690
I said we were gonna build this
around the 70-341 exam and

26
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:20.610
you'll see that it breaks
things up into four categories.

27
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.380
Installing and
configuring the mailbox role, right.

28
00:01:23.380 --> 00:01:24.880
That's the email portion, right.

29
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:26.610
Getting email set up.

30
00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:29.246
Installing and
configuring the client access role.

31
00:01:29.246 --> 00:01:35.770
That's getting POP3, IMAP4, the Outlook
Web App, getting those things configured,

32
00:01:35.770 --> 00:01:39.140
as well as the full Microsoft Outlook
client and some of the advanced

33
00:01:39.140 --> 00:01:43.950
functionality we get with it, seeing how
to get those implemented and put in place.

34
00:01:43.950 --> 00:01:46.751
Then we're going to move into
installing and configuring transport.

35
00:01:46.751 --> 00:01:50.277
Now, by transport we mean what
happens to our email while it moves

36
00:01:50.277 --> 00:01:51.440
across the network.

37
00:01:51.440 --> 00:01:55.879
And that might sound pretty boring, but
this is where we do things like anti-spam,

38
00:01:55.879 --> 00:01:56.700
anti-virus.

39
00:01:56.700 --> 00:01:58.270
We can do compliance or

40
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:02.370
regulatory compliance type rules where you
do email retention or redirecting email.

41
00:02:02.370 --> 00:02:05.470
There's a lot of stuff you can do
to email while it's in transit.

42
00:02:05.470 --> 00:02:07.590
It might be really complex things or
really simple,

43
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:11.250
like sticking a footer on the bottom
that says, this is a private email,

44
00:02:11.250 --> 00:02:13.500
please do not disclose it,
or something of that nature.

45
00:02:13.500 --> 00:02:14.880
There's a lot we can do there.

46
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:17.880
We'll see how to manage our
message queues, and so on.

47
00:02:17.880 --> 00:02:21.120
And then we've got designing and
managing an Exchange infrastructure.

48
00:02:21.120 --> 00:02:24.560
When you start to build this out,
you'll find that small environments

49
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:27.320
have very different needs
from large environments.

50
00:02:27.320 --> 00:02:30.940
If you just have one Exchange
administrator and 20 mailboxes,

51
00:02:30.940 --> 00:02:33.900
you can have a really straightforward and
simple Exchange deployment.

52
00:02:33.900 --> 00:02:35.910
But if you have 50,000 users and

53
00:02:35.910 --> 00:02:40.080
ten Exchange administrators, well, now
things get a lot more complex and so we'll

54
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:44.040
look at some of the functionality that's
built into Exchange that supports that.

55
00:02:44.040 --> 00:02:44.970
So, all in all,

56
00:02:44.970 --> 00:02:47.980
it's gonna be a really good series
covering all the information you need.

57
00:02:47.980 --> 00:02:49.400
If you wanna get certified, great.

58
00:02:49.400 --> 00:02:51.240
We're gonna cover all the objectives.

59
00:02:51.240 --> 00:02:54.412
If you're not interested in getting
certified, that's fine too.

60
00:02:54.412 --> 00:02:56.980
We're gonna show you what you
need to know about Exchange to

61
00:02:56.980 --> 00:02:59.750
get it deployed in your environment,
and to be able to take

62
00:02:59.750 --> 00:03:02.990
advantage of the really cool features
that are new in Exchange 2013.

63
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:06.960
So, if that sounds interesting to you,
then you're in the right place.

64
00:03:06.960 --> 00:03:10.456
Stay tuned, we've got
Microsoft Exchange 2013 coming up next.

65
00:03:10.456 --> 00:03:17.249
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to Microsoft Exchange 2013. He discusses the differences between the Standard and Enterprise editions of Exchange, and wraps up by discussing how Exchange licensing is handled.
episodes.title: Introduction to Exchange 2013
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.055 --> 00:00:10.259
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.259 --> 00:00:12.960
All right good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:12.960 --> 00:00:16.270
And welcome back for
another episode of ITProTV, I'm your host,

4
00:00:16.270 --> 00:00:20.280
Don Pezet, here today with an episode for
Microsoft Exchange 2013.

5
00:00:20.280 --> 00:00:22.970
And I'm excited to kick this series off.

6
00:00:22.970 --> 00:00:26.420
Exchange is a very popular
e-mail server program.

7
00:00:26.420 --> 00:00:29.190
A lot of companies and enterprises run it.

8
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:31.750
There's a ton of ways to
get involved with it, and

9
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:34.170
in this episode I just want
to spend some time kind

10
00:00:34.170 --> 00:00:38.970
of describing what Exchange is and
how we go about purchasing it.

11
00:00:38.970 --> 00:00:42.300
Cuz unfortunately it has gotten
a little bit confusing these days.

12
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:46.480
So there's a lot of companies that use
email, I shouldn't say a lot of companies,

13
00:00:46.480 --> 00:00:48.980
pretty much every company
uses email these days.

14
00:00:48.980 --> 00:00:52.750
It might be completely private and
internal, it might be public and

15
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:53.870
connectivity to the Internet.

16
00:00:53.870 --> 00:00:55.760
That's the most common, right.

17
00:00:55.760 --> 00:01:00.080
But we need email, and one of the best
email solutions that's out there

18
00:01:00.080 --> 00:01:03.840
is Microsoft Exchange, and
it's not sure because of the email side.

19
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:05.640
There's plenty of email
servers that are out there,

20
00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:08.800
you could fire up a Linux server
with Sendmail, and there you go,

21
00:01:08.800 --> 00:01:11.140
you got an email server and
it didn't cost you a dime.

22
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:13.670
So why would I pay for Microsoft Exchange?

23
00:01:13.670 --> 00:01:16.760
Why would I implement that,
over some of these other solutions?

24
00:01:16.760 --> 00:01:20.590
And the answer is, the collaboration
services that come along with it.

25
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:24.390
Exchange is a lot more
than just a mail server.

26
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:27.860
For example, it gives you shared group
calendars and individual calendaring.

27
00:01:27.860 --> 00:01:30.130
You can do tasks, like to-do lists.

28
00:01:30.130 --> 00:01:34.020
You can do unified messaging, where your
voicemail goes right into Exchange and

29
00:01:34.020 --> 00:01:35.060
is managed there.

30
00:01:35.060 --> 00:01:36.510
You can do public folders for

31
00:01:36.510 --> 00:01:41.100
shared content and files,
Exchange can do a lot of things.

32
00:01:41.100 --> 00:01:43.560
It's a very powerful collaboration suite.

33
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:46.640
In fact Microsoft sometimes
calls it collaboration suite.

34
00:01:46.640 --> 00:01:50.020
They don't say email server ,cuz
it does so much more than email.

35
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:53.850
And those are all reasons why we might
chose to implement Microsoft exchange,

36
00:01:53.850 --> 00:01:57.080
as opposed to going with some of the other
services that are out there, all right?

37
00:01:57.080 --> 00:01:59.500
So, let's say you're at a company, and

38
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:01.510
you're evaluating whether
you want Microsoft Exchange.

39
00:02:01.510 --> 00:02:04.770
You say, all right, I think we're
going to do an email server and

40
00:02:04.770 --> 00:02:06.570
we're looking at going this
Exchange route, right?

41
00:02:06.570 --> 00:02:10.220
So, there's some of the reasons that I
just mentioned a moment ago that you might

42
00:02:10.220 --> 00:02:11.170
want to choose Exchange for.

43
00:02:11.170 --> 00:02:12.750
There's other reasons too.

44
00:02:12.750 --> 00:02:14.890
For example,
it's really easy to administer.

45
00:02:14.890 --> 00:02:17.090
Exchange has a nice
graphical user interface.

46
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:18.010
It's all web based.

47
00:02:18.010 --> 00:02:19.960
You browse to a web page,
you can configure the server,

48
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:22.070
you do everything that
you need right there.

49
00:02:22.070 --> 00:02:23.040
It's pretty straight forward.

50
00:02:23.040 --> 00:02:25.350
And you'll see through out this series,
that configuring,

51
00:02:25.350 --> 00:02:26.670
it's really not that hard.

52
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:29.820
You do need to know where things are,
and that's a bit of a challenge, right.

53
00:02:29.820 --> 00:02:32.200
Or understand the terminology
that Microsoft uses.

54
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:33.470
But once you get past that,

55
00:02:33.470 --> 00:02:36.210
actually performing the activities
is not difficult at all.

56
00:02:36.210 --> 00:02:38.900
And it's It's actually a pretty
great system to work with.

57
00:02:38.900 --> 00:02:40.670
It's also extremely scalable.

58
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:43.220
Exchange can run and
support five mailboxes if you want.

59
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:44.690
All right?
I just have five mailboxes,

60
00:02:44.690 --> 00:02:46.010
I'm running it from my home.

61
00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:48.750
But that might be a little overkill there,
but you could do it.

62
00:02:48.750 --> 00:02:53.930
Or my company has 500,000 employees and
I need mailboxes for all of them.

63
00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:55.250
Exchange can do that.

64
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:57.450
It can run in very small,
very large environments, and

65
00:02:57.450 --> 00:03:00.840
you can even host it online through
Microsoft's Azure if you want.

66
00:03:00.840 --> 00:03:03.810
Right, so there's a few different
solutions that are out there.

67
00:03:03.810 --> 00:03:06.420
One of the first decisions you
have to make with Exchange,

68
00:03:06.420 --> 00:03:10.635
is whether you're gonna go with
the standard or enterprise edition.

69
00:03:10.635 --> 00:03:13.705
So when you buy Microsoft Exchange,
there's a few things we have to think

70
00:03:13.705 --> 00:03:16.365
about, and
one of those is the features that we want.

71
00:03:16.365 --> 00:03:18.535
The features are divided up
a couple of different ways,

72
00:03:18.535 --> 00:03:20.495
and that's part of where
the confusion comes from.

73
00:03:20.495 --> 00:03:24.525
The other thing we have to decide,
is whether we want just one server, or

74
00:03:24.525 --> 00:03:26.465
if we want more than one server.

75
00:03:26.465 --> 00:03:29.770
If you just have five mailboxes,
you can run one exchange server.

76
00:03:29.770 --> 00:03:30.810
You can have one server.

77
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:31.680
It can be a virtual machine.

78
00:03:31.680 --> 00:03:32.930
It doesn't have to be a physical machine.

79
00:03:32.930 --> 00:03:34.440
And it can run exchange.

80
00:03:34.440 --> 00:03:35.990
It can provide all your e-mail services.

81
00:03:35.990 --> 00:03:39.620
Calendaring, public folders,
all that good stuff, right on one box.

82
00:03:39.620 --> 00:03:41.100
But if you've got a large company.

83
00:03:41.100 --> 00:03:42.960
If you've got thousands of employees,

84
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:45.620
that one box is gonna get
killed pretty fast, right?

85
00:03:45.620 --> 00:03:49.380
It's gonna need storage to
support all those mailboxes.

86
00:03:49.380 --> 00:03:51.850
It's gonna need CPU to move email in and
out.

87
00:03:51.850 --> 00:03:54.540
It's gonna need RAM to process
all the mail requests.

88
00:03:54.540 --> 00:03:57.485
And it's gonna need network bandwidth,
to be able to move files and

89
00:03:57.485 --> 00:03:58.825
things back and forth.

90
00:03:58.825 --> 00:04:00.895
That's a lot for one server to do.

91
00:04:00.895 --> 00:04:04.395
So in enterprise environments,
we actually break Exchange up and

92
00:04:04.395 --> 00:04:06.095
spread it across several servers.

93
00:04:06.095 --> 00:04:09.765
I think the largest environment I've
worked in had about 30 exchange servers,

94
00:04:09.765 --> 00:04:12.375
all divided up performing
different functions, and

95
00:04:12.375 --> 00:04:15.295
that was just because of
the size of that organization.

96
00:04:15.295 --> 00:04:17.900
Or if you're organization
is just geographically big.

97
00:04:17.900 --> 00:04:20.320
Maybe you've got some employees
in the United States, and

98
00:04:20.320 --> 00:04:22.130
some employees in England.

99
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:24.860
Well, you don't want the employees
in England to have to jump

100
00:04:24.860 --> 00:04:27.000
all the way over to the U.S.
to access their mailbox.

101
00:04:27.000 --> 00:04:29.780
It would be nice if we had an Exchange
server over there in England, and

102
00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:31.320
an Exchange server over here in the U.S,.

103
00:04:31.320 --> 00:04:33.840
And now people can access
the server that's closest to them.

104
00:04:33.840 --> 00:04:35.750
Exchange lets you do that, right?

105
00:04:35.750 --> 00:04:38.520
We do have to think about how many
copies of Exchange we need to buy, and

106
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:40.090
how many servers we want.

107
00:04:40.090 --> 00:04:42.980
But when you go to buy it, the first
decision you have to make is whether we

108
00:04:42.980 --> 00:04:45.570
want Standard or Enterprise right.

109
00:04:45.570 --> 00:04:48.430
Now with the standard addition you get

110
00:04:48.430 --> 00:04:52.200
all the core functionality you
need from Microsoft Exchange.

111
00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:54.280
With the enterprise addition
you get some extra stuff.

112
00:04:54.280 --> 00:04:56.130
And let me show you.
I've got Microsoft's page pulled

113
00:04:56.130 --> 00:04:56.920
up right here.

114
00:04:56.920 --> 00:05:00.540
This is the page that discusses
the Exchange 2013 licensing.

115
00:05:00.540 --> 00:05:02.320
And you'll see right here at the top,

116
00:05:02.320 --> 00:05:04.960
its got a little note about Standard and
Enterprise.

117
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:09.510
Well there's actually only one difference
between Standard and Enterprise, and

118
00:05:09.510 --> 00:05:12.500
that's how many mailbox
databases you can have.

119
00:05:12.500 --> 00:05:18.250
If you're a single company, and
you've got say less than 50,000 users,

120
00:05:18.250 --> 00:05:21.600
you can probably get away with
just having one mailbox database.

121
00:05:21.600 --> 00:05:24.450
But if you want to divide your
mailbox databases up, and

122
00:05:24.450 --> 00:05:28.120
have some mailboxes in England some
in the U.S. and some in Australia.

123
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:30.820
Or you've got more than one company,
and you want the different

124
00:05:30.820 --> 00:05:34.730
business units to have their own database,
well then you're going to need more.

125
00:05:34.730 --> 00:05:39.710
And the Standard addition can only
support up to five mailbox databases.

126
00:05:39.710 --> 00:05:43.040
So, if I just need five mailbox databases,
standard addition,

127
00:05:43.040 --> 00:05:44.440
it'll do what I need and that's that.

128
00:05:45.940 --> 00:05:48.180
Right.
Then there's the enterprise edition.

129
00:05:48.180 --> 00:05:51.620
And the Enterprise edition,
if you bought Exchange 2013 on a DVD,

130
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:56.690
out of the box it supports
up to 50 mailbox databases.

131
00:05:56.690 --> 00:05:59.000
But if you've installed
all the Windows updates,

132
00:05:59.000 --> 00:06:03.600
when they released service pack one,
it bumped it up to 100 mailbox databases.

133
00:06:03.600 --> 00:06:06.910
So you could divide up all your email
into all these different databases.

134
00:06:06.910 --> 00:06:08.900
Now I, why would I want to do that?

135
00:06:08.900 --> 00:06:11.590
Well, I gave you guys
the example of a geolocation.

136
00:06:11.590 --> 00:06:14.140
Putting people's email closer to them.

137
00:06:14.140 --> 00:06:15.790
That makes access to their mailbox faster.

138
00:06:15.790 --> 00:06:17.030
That's something you might want, right?

139
00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:19.160
That's one reason you might divide it up.

140
00:06:19.160 --> 00:06:22.300
Another reason you might divide
it up is backup and recovery.

141
00:06:22.300 --> 00:06:25.760
Right?
If I have 50 thousand mailboxes and

142
00:06:25.760 --> 00:06:27.190
they're all in one database, and

143
00:06:27.190 --> 00:06:32.480
that database fails, all of my
users can't access their mailbox.

144
00:06:32.480 --> 00:06:36.287
But if I divided that up into
five mailbox databases, right?

145
00:06:36.287 --> 00:06:40.030
Ten thousand users in each of those five
databases, and one of them fails, well,

146
00:06:40.030 --> 00:06:41.680
the other four are still up and going.

147
00:06:41.680 --> 00:06:44.100
And I can even transition
mailboxes over to the other one,

148
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:45.450
to get them up and going too.

149
00:06:45.450 --> 00:06:48.410
It creates a more resilient,
more redundant environment.

150
00:06:48.410 --> 00:06:51.940
And so
Enterprise will come in handy there.

151
00:06:51.940 --> 00:06:54.770
Now we're gonna cover in
another episode the different

152
00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:57.400
roles that Exchange can
take when you install it.

153
00:06:57.400 --> 00:07:00.170
And when you install Exchange, there's
two main roles we need to worry about.

154
00:07:00.170 --> 00:07:03.770
There's a client access server and
a mailbox server.

155
00:07:03.770 --> 00:07:05.630
The mailbox server, that's the one
that holds the database, and

156
00:07:05.630 --> 00:07:06.890
that's where these limits come in.

157
00:07:06.890 --> 00:07:11.440
So the Atandard mailbox server
can hold up to five mailboxes.

158
00:07:11.440 --> 00:07:14.290
The Enterprise mailbox
server can hold up to 100.

159
00:07:14.290 --> 00:07:16.770
But a client access server,

160
00:07:16.770 --> 00:07:18.950
that's the server where your
end users actual connect.

161
00:07:18.950 --> 00:07:20.890
It's where they use POP3 or IMAP.

162
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:23.110
It's where they use OWA.

163
00:07:23.110 --> 00:07:25.900
They're using the Outlook Web App
to access their mailbox.

164
00:07:25.900 --> 00:07:28.080
They go through that client access server.

165
00:07:28.080 --> 00:07:30.110
And if you've got a dedicated
client access server,

166
00:07:30.110 --> 00:07:31.850
it doesn't have any mailboxes.

167
00:07:31.850 --> 00:07:34.530
If it doesn't have any mailboxes It
doesn't matter which one you get, so

168
00:07:34.530 --> 00:07:37.350
you might as well save money and
get the Standard edition.

169
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:40.290
So this really only applies
to our mailbox servers.

170
00:07:40.290 --> 00:07:44.086
And that's really, honestly and truly
the only difference between Standard and

171
00:07:44.086 --> 00:07:44.754
Enterprise.

172
00:07:44.754 --> 00:07:47.535
So if you've got less than
five mailbox databases,

173
00:07:47.535 --> 00:07:49.630
don't waste any money on Enterprise.

174
00:07:49.630 --> 00:07:51.952
You don't get any extra features.

175
00:07:51.952 --> 00:07:54.099
That wasn't always the case.

176
00:07:54.099 --> 00:07:55.591
In older versions of Exchange,

177
00:07:55.591 --> 00:07:58.860
it used to be if you wanted clustering
you had to go to Enterprise.

178
00:07:58.860 --> 00:07:59.982
Or if you wanted this feature or

179
00:07:59.982 --> 00:08:02.845
that feature there were things where you
had to jump up to Enterprise, right?

180
00:08:02.845 --> 00:08:04.550
Extra memory access and things like that.

181
00:08:04.550 --> 00:08:05.620
That's all gone.

182
00:08:05.620 --> 00:08:07.620
Now they're identical except for
the mailbox databases.

183
00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:13.780
The differences are now tied to what's
called a client access license.

184
00:08:13.780 --> 00:08:16.570
With Exchange you have to pay for
the server software.

185
00:08:16.570 --> 00:08:18.980
So I have to buy a copy of Exchange 2013.

186
00:08:18.980 --> 00:08:22.520
But then, for
every user that connects to the server,

187
00:08:22.520 --> 00:08:25.140
I can have a client access license or
a CAL.

188
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:29.250
And the CAL comes in two forms,
a Standard CAL and an Enterprise CAL, and

189
00:08:29.250 --> 00:08:32.230
there's a lot of differences between them,
all right?

190
00:08:32.230 --> 00:08:34.968
Now the Enterprise CAL
is more of an add-on.

191
00:08:34.968 --> 00:08:38.810
So at a minimum,
you need a Standard CAL for

192
00:08:38.810 --> 00:08:41.190
every single user that's
gonna have a mailbox.

193
00:08:41.190 --> 00:08:45.470
So if I have 50,000 users, at a minimum
I'm gonna need 50,000 Standard CALs,

194
00:08:45.470 --> 00:08:47.600
all right?

195
00:08:47.600 --> 00:08:52.180
Then if I want some of the advanced
functionality, I can pick and

196
00:08:52.180 --> 00:08:53.800
choose with my Ennterprise CALs.

197
00:08:53.800 --> 00:08:56.020
And I can say, I got 50,000 users, but

198
00:08:56.020 --> 00:09:00.220
there's only 5,000 of my users
that need this one feature.

199
00:09:00.220 --> 00:09:04.420
I'll just buy Enterprise CALs for
those 5,000 users and that's it.

200
00:09:04.420 --> 00:09:07.520
And so,
those users will have both a standard and

201
00:09:07.520 --> 00:09:09.690
an Enterprise CAL to add together.

202
00:09:09.690 --> 00:09:12.830
So when we look at this licensing page,
it starts off real simple.

203
00:09:12.830 --> 00:09:15.130
Here's the difference between Standard and
Enterprise.

204
00:09:15.130 --> 00:09:16.700
Then it gets real complex.

205
00:09:16.700 --> 00:09:20.350
When it jumps into the client CALs or
the client access licences, right?

206
00:09:20.350 --> 00:09:24.460
Now it starts to list all these different
features that come with the Standard CAL

207
00:09:24.460 --> 00:09:27.440
and that come with a Standard
plus Enterprise CAL.

208
00:09:27.440 --> 00:09:30.010
Notice how it doesn't just say
Enterprise CAL by itself, right?

209
00:09:30.010 --> 00:09:32.240
You have to have both a Standard and

210
00:09:32.240 --> 00:09:34.920
an Enterprise combined to
get the Enterprise features.

211
00:09:36.260 --> 00:09:40.190
So the first set here is we look at things
like email, calendar, contacts, and

212
00:09:40.190 --> 00:09:41.130
tasks, right?

213
00:09:41.130 --> 00:09:41.930
They both have that.

214
00:09:41.930 --> 00:09:45.051
If I just need basic email functionality,
these are identical.

215
00:09:45.051 --> 00:09:50.199
If we want Outlook Web App, it we want
advanced Outlook functionality, if we want

216
00:09:50.199 --> 00:09:55.590
site mailboxes, role based access control,
those are in Standard and Enterprise.

217
00:09:55.590 --> 00:09:57.466
You don't need an Enterprise account for
those,

218
00:09:57.466 --> 00:09:59.261
they just come as part of Standard,
all right?

219
00:09:59.261 --> 00:10:02.680
But then as we scroll down you'll start
to notice sorta the differences creep up.

220
00:10:02.680 --> 00:10:07.130
We'll see things like journaling,
unified messaging and so on.

221
00:10:07.130 --> 00:10:10.070
These are part of the Enterprise CAL,
right?

222
00:10:10.070 --> 00:10:13.130
I mentioned unified messaging let's
talk about that for a second.

223
00:10:13.130 --> 00:10:17.080
If you have a voice over IP system, most
people have a voice over IP system that is

224
00:10:17.080 --> 00:10:21.270
completely separate from their email,
two separate things.

225
00:10:21.270 --> 00:10:24.650
But, remember how I called
Exchange a collaboration suite?

226
00:10:24.650 --> 00:10:26.510
It's designed to help people communicate,
right?

227
00:10:26.510 --> 00:10:28.030
We wanna put these pieces together and

228
00:10:28.030 --> 00:10:32.110
help people communicate through
whatever means, not just email.

229
00:10:32.110 --> 00:10:35.610
So with the full collaboration suite,
we can send email,

230
00:10:35.610 --> 00:10:40.130
we can do a voice over IP call,
we can do a meeting, right?

231
00:10:40.130 --> 00:10:42.780
A screen share type meeting or
a video meeting, and

232
00:10:42.780 --> 00:10:45.380
we can do interaction with voicemail.

233
00:10:45.380 --> 00:10:47.530
All through Microsoft Outlook.

234
00:10:47.530 --> 00:10:49.358
It's done with unified messaging.

235
00:10:49.358 --> 00:10:52.030
Unified messaging lets you
connect your exchange environment

236
00:10:52.030 --> 00:10:53.840
with your voice over IP environment.

237
00:10:53.840 --> 00:10:57.410
So now when that voicemail comes in,
you get it right there in your inbox.

238
00:10:57.410 --> 00:11:01.930
And when you schedule a meeting inside of
Outlook, it can set a conference number

239
00:11:01.930 --> 00:11:04.330
through your voice over IP system and
it can tie it all together.

240
00:11:04.330 --> 00:11:07.380
And when you click on that
contact to call somebody,

241
00:11:07.380 --> 00:11:10.350
it can actually dial right from
inside of Outlook and place the call.

242
00:11:10.350 --> 00:11:11.970
It's really neat stuff.

243
00:11:11.970 --> 00:11:13.690
But not all our users need that.

244
00:11:13.690 --> 00:11:16.730
You might have some mailboxes
that are just service mailboxes.

245
00:11:16.730 --> 00:11:18.070
They don't actually have
employees tied to them.

246
00:11:18.070 --> 00:11:19.280
They don't need a phone.

247
00:11:19.280 --> 00:11:22.700
So for those, what you would do is
you would say, for those mailboxes,

248
00:11:22.700 --> 00:11:25.650
just the regular mailboxes,
I would stick with the Standard license.

249
00:11:25.650 --> 00:11:30.630
But then for anybody who had a VOIP
extension, I would get them a Standard and

250
00:11:30.630 --> 00:11:34.680
an Enterprise CAL, and that's what would
give them the ability to use that unified

251
00:11:34.680 --> 00:11:36.290
messaging piece, all right?

252
00:11:36.290 --> 00:11:38.990
So you have to think about this,
cuz it is expensive, right?

253
00:11:38.990 --> 00:11:40.420
This is adding to the cost,

254
00:11:40.420 --> 00:11:44.228
it over doubles the cost of that user when
you bump them up to an Enterprise CAL.

255
00:11:44.228 --> 00:11:47.840
So you've gotta look down here and
say, do I need these features?

256
00:11:47.840 --> 00:11:49.530
Do I need In-Place Archive?

257
00:11:49.530 --> 00:11:50.890
Do I need In-Place Hold?

258
00:11:50.890 --> 00:11:52.720
Do I need some of these advanced features?

259
00:11:52.720 --> 00:11:55.703
All right, well I don't want to spend
a ton of time diving into these,

260
00:11:55.703 --> 00:11:58.043
cuz we're gonna see them
all throughout this series.

261
00:11:58.043 --> 00:12:00.840
But let me just hit a couple
of highlights here, right?

262
00:12:00.840 --> 00:12:04.550
The number one reason that you go for an
Enterprise account is unified messaging.

263
00:12:04.550 --> 00:12:06.563
Unified messaging is
a big part of that and so

264
00:12:06.563 --> 00:12:09.467
that's why I singled that one out first,
all right?

265
00:12:09.467 --> 00:12:12.794
There's a few other things,
though, like journaling, okay?

266
00:12:12.794 --> 00:12:16.130
Journaling, notice here I've got
this journaling per database.

267
00:12:16.130 --> 00:12:20.924
What journaling is is basically keeping
a record of users emails, all right?

268
00:12:20.924 --> 00:12:24.067
Here in the United States right now
there's a little bit of controversy over

269
00:12:24.067 --> 00:12:26.819
a certain politician who maintained
their own mailbox database,

270
00:12:26.819 --> 00:12:30.600
their own mailbox server, outside of
what the government normally provided.

271
00:12:30.600 --> 00:12:31.640
And so now,

272
00:12:31.640 --> 00:12:35.880
there's not a reliable record of
the emails that were sent by that person.

273
00:12:35.880 --> 00:12:40.020
Well, if you have regulatory compliance,
if you have rules to dictate,

274
00:12:40.020 --> 00:12:42.935
you've got to save emails,
how do you keep a record of that?

275
00:12:42.935 --> 00:12:46.550
Journaling, in the Standard
edition of Exchange,

276
00:12:46.550 --> 00:12:48.420
we can do journaling per database, so

277
00:12:48.420 --> 00:12:53.110
you can say, journal everyone in this
database or no one in this database.

278
00:12:53.110 --> 00:12:56.330
But if we go to an Enterprise CAL,
we can pick out individual people.

279
00:12:56.330 --> 00:12:57.520
So we can say, hey,

280
00:12:57.520 --> 00:13:02.360
the CEO of our company, we wanna
retain their email for five years.

281
00:13:02.360 --> 00:13:06.260
But the mailroom clerk,
we wanna retain their email for 30 days.

282
00:13:06.260 --> 00:13:07.730
You can get very, very specific.

283
00:13:07.730 --> 00:13:09.750
You can set these granular policies.

284
00:13:09.750 --> 00:13:13.090
So if you need journaling and
retention policies like that,

285
00:13:13.090 --> 00:13:17.190
that are really granular,
you'll need to go to an Enterprise CAL.

286
00:13:17.190 --> 00:13:19.140
Also, we've got things
like retention policies,

287
00:13:19.140 --> 00:13:23.100
which ties into the journaling, right,
how long we retain those messages, and

288
00:13:23.100 --> 00:13:25.110
even setting which messages get retained.

289
00:13:25.110 --> 00:13:27.570
Now I'm not talking about per user,
I'm talking about per message.

290
00:13:27.570 --> 00:13:31.860
I might say, any message that has this
keyword in it needs to be saved for

291
00:13:31.860 --> 00:13:32.499
seven years.

292
00:13:34.290 --> 00:13:35.580
We've got In-Place Archive.

293
00:13:35.580 --> 00:13:37.680
Now archive is a big deal.

294
00:13:37.680 --> 00:13:38.880
If you've run Outlook.

295
00:13:38.880 --> 00:13:41.530
I mean, I remember running
Outlook back in the 90s.

296
00:13:41.530 --> 00:13:44.940
When you ran Microsoft Outlook your
mailbox was all being backed up

297
00:13:44.940 --> 00:13:47.650
to a PST file, right,
this PST file on your hard drive.

298
00:13:47.650 --> 00:13:51.800
As it grew and grew and grew,
Outlook got slower and slower and slower.

299
00:13:51.800 --> 00:13:53.690
And so people would archive.

300
00:13:53.690 --> 00:13:55.900
And when you would archive it,
it would take your email and

301
00:13:55.900 --> 00:13:58.880
it would take it out of the mailbox and
put it in a secondary file.

302
00:13:58.880 --> 00:14:00.870
And it would say, all right we're
gonna stick it over here and

303
00:14:00.870 --> 00:14:02.970
make your mailbox smaller,
make it faster, right?

304
00:14:02.970 --> 00:14:04.450
And it did, that worked.

305
00:14:04.450 --> 00:14:08.120
But here was the problem,
when people's email was on the server,

306
00:14:08.120 --> 00:14:10.530
their server was being backed up, right?

307
00:14:10.530 --> 00:14:12.850
And if the server failed,
we could always restore it.

308
00:14:12.850 --> 00:14:14.930
The server admins would back that up.

309
00:14:14.930 --> 00:14:17.880
But their laptop or their desktop
might not be getting backed up.

310
00:14:17.880 --> 00:14:21.640
And when Outlook did an archive,
it would archive right to their laptop or

311
00:14:21.640 --> 00:14:23.780
right to their desktop, and
it wouldn't get backed up anymore,

312
00:14:23.780 --> 00:14:26.030
and people were losing email left and
right.

313
00:14:26.030 --> 00:14:27.330
You can do a Google
search on the Internet,

314
00:14:27.330 --> 00:14:31.150
you'll find tons of people saying,
I lost my archive, Outlook sucks.

315
00:14:31.150 --> 00:14:32.620
A lot of people complained about that.

316
00:14:32.620 --> 00:14:35.565
And it's just because you're not
storing that archive safely.

317
00:14:35.565 --> 00:14:38.110
In-Place Archive solves that.

318
00:14:38.110 --> 00:14:40.820
It says, we're gonna allow people to
archive their mailboxes to make them

319
00:14:40.820 --> 00:14:43.450
smaller, but instead of storing
it on their laptop or desktop,

320
00:14:43.450 --> 00:14:46.010
we're gonna store it
right here on the server.

321
00:14:46.010 --> 00:14:48.470
Now, it might be in a different
place on the server.

322
00:14:48.470 --> 00:14:53.960
We might have 15,000 RPM SCSI drives
that are handling our mailbox database,

323
00:14:53.960 --> 00:14:58.760
and we might have,
just 5400 RPM SADA drives,

324
00:14:58.760 --> 00:15:01.220
really cheap hard drives,
sitting over here for the archive.

325
00:15:01.220 --> 00:15:02.380
So it's slower storage.

326
00:15:02.380 --> 00:15:06.070
It's cheaper storage, but that's where the
archive sits when we back that up, right?

327
00:15:06.070 --> 00:15:08.620
When we know that it's on Raid 5 or
Raid 10 or Razor, or whatever,

328
00:15:08.620 --> 00:15:10.410
that's got that protection in place.

329
00:15:10.410 --> 00:15:15.300
So now the server admins can protect
all of your mail, your main mailbox and

330
00:15:15.300 --> 00:15:17.600
your archive, not just the main mailbox.

331
00:15:17.600 --> 00:15:21.560
That's a solution that comes
with the Enterprise CAL.

332
00:15:21.560 --> 00:15:23.880
We've got other things like In-Place Hold.

333
00:15:23.880 --> 00:15:26.510
In Exchange, by default,
if you delete somebody's mailbox,

334
00:15:26.510 --> 00:15:28.340
it'll hold onto it for 30 days.

335
00:15:28.340 --> 00:15:30.740
And then after 30 days it gets rid
of the mailbox, that's the default.

336
00:15:30.740 --> 00:15:32.285
You can manipulate that time.

337
00:15:32.285 --> 00:15:36.698
In Exchange 2013 with an Enterprise CAL,
you can define an In-Place Hold to say

338
00:15:36.698 --> 00:15:40.117
when we delete an individual message,
that we wanna to hold it for

339
00:15:40.117 --> 00:15:43.620
a certain period of time and
the end user can't clear it out.

340
00:15:43.620 --> 00:15:45.547
And we can even say that for
a whole mailbox if we want, or

341
00:15:45.547 --> 00:15:47.930
a whole mailbox database, so
you can get really powerful with that.

342
00:15:49.812 --> 00:15:52.406
All right, so
those are some of the bigger differences.

343
00:15:52.406 --> 00:15:53.295
There's other ones,

344
00:15:53.295 --> 00:15:56.259
they list a bunch of them like all
the rights management features and so on.

345
00:15:56.259 --> 00:15:59.102
If you want those,
you gotta go to an enterprise account.

346
00:15:59.102 --> 00:16:03.248
But if you don't need those, if you're
just looking for email, calendar, tasks,

347
00:16:03.248 --> 00:16:06.380
right, public folders,
you could do that with a standard CAL.

348
00:16:06.380 --> 00:16:09.910
And at a minimum,
you're going to need one standard CAL for

349
00:16:09.910 --> 00:16:14.060
each user mailbox on the server.

350
00:16:14.060 --> 00:16:16.090
So for everybody that's
gonna be connecting to it.

351
00:16:16.090 --> 00:16:16.620
All right.

352
00:16:16.620 --> 00:16:19.250
Now Exchange does kind of work
on an honor system, and so

353
00:16:19.250 --> 00:16:22.730
it's up to you to track those numbers and
then if Microsoft ever audits you,

354
00:16:22.730 --> 00:16:25.280
then you've got to show that you've
purchased the right amount of CALs.

355
00:16:25.280 --> 00:16:27.400
It doesn't really enforce
it with an iron fist, so

356
00:16:27.400 --> 00:16:29.240
they're not gonna harp on
you too much about it.

357
00:16:29.240 --> 00:16:33.250
But you will get a little warning if
you've applied Enterprise features to more

358
00:16:33.250 --> 00:16:36.010
users than you have Enterprise CALs,
you'll get a warning about that.

359
00:16:36.010 --> 00:16:38.200
It'll let you know that you
don't have enough CALs.

360
00:16:38.200 --> 00:16:38.950
All right.

361
00:16:38.950 --> 00:16:41.630
So, when purchasing Exchange,
our first decision is,

362
00:16:41.630 --> 00:16:44.100
do we go with Standard, or Enterprise?

363
00:16:44.100 --> 00:16:47.020
And that comes strictly down to how
many mailbox databases we have.

364
00:16:47.020 --> 00:16:49.360
And it only applies to
the mailbox servers.

365
00:16:49.360 --> 00:16:51.900
So, for our client access servers,
for our Edge servers,

366
00:16:51.900 --> 00:16:54.800
those you always do Standard,
there's no point in doing Enterprise.

367
00:16:54.800 --> 00:16:56.380
But on your mailbox server,

368
00:16:56.380 --> 00:16:59.299
if you need more then five mailbox
databases, you go Enterprise.

369
00:17:00.370 --> 00:17:03.020
And then you pick your Cals.

370
00:17:03.020 --> 00:17:06.780
All of your users need a standard CAL, and
then for those advanced features I just

371
00:17:06.780 --> 00:17:10.600
talked about a moment ago, like unified
messaging, advanced journaling and so on.

372
00:17:10.600 --> 00:17:15.171
If you need those, you buy an Enterprise
CAL for each user that's gonna need those

373
00:17:15.171 --> 00:17:19.031
in addition to their standard CAL,
right, they definitely add on.

374
00:17:19.031 --> 00:17:19.920
All right.

375
00:17:19.920 --> 00:17:22.080
So those are some of
the decisions we need to make.

376
00:17:22.080 --> 00:17:23.800
There is one other really big decision.

377
00:17:24.820 --> 00:17:28.240
Should I even be installing
Exchange in the first place, right?

378
00:17:28.240 --> 00:17:29.540
And I know it sounds kinda funny.

379
00:17:29.540 --> 00:17:31.490
And I'm a server admin.

380
00:17:31.490 --> 00:17:32.570
I've done it for years.

381
00:17:32.570 --> 00:17:36.330
And this is one of those decisions that
you think might put you out of a job.

382
00:17:36.330 --> 00:17:37.370
It really doesn't,

383
00:17:37.370 --> 00:17:41.100
which is [LAUGH] what if I choose to
just throw it in the Cloud instead?

384
00:17:41.100 --> 00:17:42.430
I could host Exchange.

385
00:17:42.430 --> 00:17:43.880
I know how.
I can bring up the servers.

386
00:17:43.880 --> 00:17:44.863
I can install the software.

387
00:17:44.863 --> 00:17:46.890
I can get an Exchange
environment going on right now.

388
00:17:46.890 --> 00:17:48.680
But, I'm busy.

389
00:17:48.680 --> 00:17:50.080
I don't have a lot of time on my hands.

390
00:17:50.080 --> 00:17:51.670
I'm doing shows like this one.

391
00:17:51.670 --> 00:17:53.660
So, what happens if that server fails?

392
00:17:53.660 --> 00:17:55.340
What happens if a new
employee gets hired and

393
00:17:55.340 --> 00:17:57.200
I don't have time to create their mailbox?

394
00:17:57.200 --> 00:18:00.730
Well, wouldn't it be nice if we
just let somebody else handle it?

395
00:18:00.730 --> 00:18:01.330
And you can do that.

396
00:18:01.330 --> 00:18:04.280
So, Microsoft has online.

397
00:18:04.280 --> 00:18:06.620
You can do it where it's hosted Exchange.

398
00:18:06.620 --> 00:18:08.340
Now there's two ways to deploy it, right.

399
00:18:08.340 --> 00:18:10.880
There's one way,
which is where you just use Azure VMs.

400
00:18:10.880 --> 00:18:13.320
So you bring up these virtual machines and
Microsoft Azure,

401
00:18:13.320 --> 00:18:15.360
or Amazon web services or whoever.

402
00:18:15.360 --> 00:18:16.880
And you deploy Exchange in there.

403
00:18:16.880 --> 00:18:17.930
Now you're still managing that.

404
00:18:17.930 --> 00:18:21.090
The only difference there is you kinda
outsourced your hardware, not the support,

405
00:18:21.090 --> 00:18:21.930
you're still supporting it.

406
00:18:23.180 --> 00:18:26.770
But an even better route is
to go with Exchange Online.

407
00:18:26.770 --> 00:18:29.140
Let me bring up their webpage right here.

408
00:18:29.140 --> 00:18:33.520
Microsoft Exchange Online is where
they handle everything for you.

409
00:18:33.520 --> 00:18:35.020
They take care of the servers.

410
00:18:35.020 --> 00:18:36.360
They take care of the provisioning.

411
00:18:36.360 --> 00:18:38.560
They take care of whether you have
a standard CAL or an Enterprise CAL.

412
00:18:38.560 --> 00:18:39.720
They take care of all of that.

413
00:18:39.720 --> 00:18:42.070
And they just charge
you a per-mailbox fee.

414
00:18:42.070 --> 00:18:44.960
And you log into the website,
you access your email, and

415
00:18:44.960 --> 00:18:48.150
you don't even have to worry about
how many hard drives you have or

416
00:18:48.150 --> 00:18:49.830
whether you have air-conditioning units.

417
00:18:49.830 --> 00:18:52.870
Whether the servers are being backed up,
whether there's a UPS attached,

418
00:18:52.870 --> 00:18:54.610
you don't have to worry about any of that.

419
00:18:54.610 --> 00:18:56.230
Microsoft takes care of it for you.

420
00:18:56.230 --> 00:18:58.870
And you don't have to worry about
how to get Exchange installed or

421
00:18:58.870 --> 00:19:00.470
how to troubleshoot it.

422
00:19:00.470 --> 00:19:04.710
Microsoft has their staff of who
are arguably are the best Exchange

423
00:19:04.710 --> 00:19:07.480
administrators on the planet because
they're the ones who write the software.

424
00:19:07.480 --> 00:19:09.230
They're the ones who support it.

425
00:19:09.230 --> 00:19:12.250
If you're a small business,
I encourage you to do this.

426
00:19:12.250 --> 00:19:14.494
It's not worth it to try and
maintain your own Exchange environment.

427
00:19:14.494 --> 00:19:17.210
It becomes pretty challenging, right?

428
00:19:17.210 --> 00:19:21.350
But, if you've got sensitive data,
private data, data that you

429
00:19:21.350 --> 00:19:25.420
can't allow somebody else to host,
you don't want to host that on Microsoft.

430
00:19:25.420 --> 00:19:26.480
You wanna make sure you run it yourself,

431
00:19:26.480 --> 00:19:28.950
that way you have complete
control of those servers.

432
00:19:28.950 --> 00:19:31.190
You know where your data is at all times,
right.

433
00:19:31.190 --> 00:19:32.430
That's important.

434
00:19:32.430 --> 00:19:33.670
But, it is an option.

435
00:19:33.670 --> 00:19:37.480
You'll see it's $4 per user,
per month for a standard license.

436
00:19:37.480 --> 00:19:38.230
Now that is standard.

437
00:19:38.230 --> 00:19:39.920
See how they've got compare plans?

438
00:19:39.920 --> 00:19:42.950
And you can go into the plans and
start to look at what's available.

439
00:19:42.950 --> 00:19:45.900
And you'll see $4 versus $8.

440
00:19:45.900 --> 00:19:48.090
Why twice as much for the online plan 2?

441
00:19:48.090 --> 00:19:50.260
That's the Enterprise CAL, right?

442
00:19:50.260 --> 00:19:53.043
These are users that have a standard and
an Enterprise CAL, and so

443
00:19:53.043 --> 00:19:56.295
as you start to scroll down, we'll
pass on chatting with Microsoft today.

444
00:19:56.295 --> 00:20:00.074
But as I scroll down, I'll see
the differences here in place hold,

445
00:20:00.074 --> 00:20:05.160
unlimited storage, hosted voicemail,
data loss protection or prevention.

446
00:20:05.160 --> 00:20:08.930
Those are the Enterprise CAL features,
right?

447
00:20:08.930 --> 00:20:11.240
Data loss prevention,
I didn't talk about that one.

448
00:20:11.240 --> 00:20:12.790
This is not like backups.

449
00:20:12.790 --> 00:20:16.960
This is data retention for
regulatory compliance, I did mention that.

450
00:20:16.960 --> 00:20:18.530
I just didn't call it DLP.

451
00:20:18.530 --> 00:20:22.630
So if I need to retain email for
seven years, DLP will let me do that.

452
00:20:22.630 --> 00:20:25.431
Even if the user completely deletes it,
empties the recycle bin,

453
00:20:25.431 --> 00:20:26.790
they think it's gone?

454
00:20:26.790 --> 00:20:29.000
DLP still saves that copy so
I've got it, right.

455
00:20:29.000 --> 00:20:30.592
So I maintained my compliance.

456
00:20:30.592 --> 00:20:34.380
So this is a great option for
small businesses if you've got,

457
00:20:34.380 --> 00:20:36.310
let's say you have ten mailboxes.

458
00:20:36.310 --> 00:20:38.152
You can pay Microsoft $40 a month.

459
00:20:38.152 --> 00:20:40.364
Your ten mailboxes get hosted right there,

460
00:20:40.364 --> 00:20:44.390
you get a full world-class Exchange
server environment, for $40 a month.

461
00:20:44.390 --> 00:20:48.210
That's a great solution, and that's what I
always encourage small businesses to do.

462
00:20:48.210 --> 00:20:50.950
But if you're a medium or
large business, there is an economy of

463
00:20:50.950 --> 00:20:53.559
scale here where you might be
able to do it cheaper yourself.

464
00:20:53.559 --> 00:20:55.599
But at a minimum, you get more control,

465
00:20:55.599 --> 00:20:58.188
if you wanna control all
the aspects of the system.

466
00:20:58.188 --> 00:20:59.950
Here you don't, right?

467
00:20:59.950 --> 00:21:03.070
Your mailboxes are being hosted
on servers with other customers.

468
00:21:03.070 --> 00:21:05.660
You don't see it, it's all hidden
from you, but that's the truth of it.

469
00:21:05.660 --> 00:21:08.581
Behind the scene, you're being hosted
on servers with other customers, and

470
00:21:08.581 --> 00:21:10.510
you don't know who those customers are.

471
00:21:10.510 --> 00:21:13.250
And so there's a risk that you
take when you use a Cloud service.

472
00:21:13.250 --> 00:21:15.240
For most people that's fine,
it's an acceptable risk.

473
00:21:15.240 --> 00:21:19.970
We do it with ITPro TV, ours is hosted
through Microsoft, and it works great.

474
00:21:19.970 --> 00:21:21.490
But you can host your own, too.

475
00:21:21.490 --> 00:21:22.950
So that's another decision.

476
00:21:22.950 --> 00:21:25.130
They call that a make or buy analysis.

477
00:21:25.130 --> 00:21:26.640
Your project managers, your CIO,

478
00:21:26.640 --> 00:21:29.940
they'll know what that is,
where do I make the solution myself?

479
00:21:29.940 --> 00:21:32.340
Build my own Exchange servers up,
or do I buy?

480
00:21:32.340 --> 00:21:34.442
Do I just let somebody else do it for me?

481
00:21:34.442 --> 00:21:36.954
And doing this online,
it works out really well.

482
00:21:36.954 --> 00:21:42.134
I'm showing you here Exchange online,
but there's also Office 365, which

483
00:21:42.134 --> 00:21:48.260
packages Exchange, but also gives you full
Office Suite and SharePoint connectivity.

484
00:21:48.260 --> 00:21:52.290
That's a neat new feature in Exchange 2013
is you got a really good tight integration

485
00:21:52.290 --> 00:21:53.420
with SharePoint.

486
00:21:53.420 --> 00:21:55.420
You know, let me talk about
that real quick for a second.

487
00:21:55.420 --> 00:21:57.150
Let me see if I can pull this page up.

488
00:21:58.280 --> 00:22:01.225
If you're looking at going into Exchange
is another decision you have to make,

489
00:22:01.225 --> 00:22:04.280
which is,
do I want to go with Exchange 2013?

490
00:22:04.280 --> 00:22:09.050
Exchange 2010 is still supported and
it's more popular, right?

491
00:22:09.050 --> 00:22:11.090
Exchange 2013's only been out a few years.

492
00:22:11.090 --> 00:22:13.380
It's not as widely deployed as 2010.

493
00:22:13.380 --> 00:22:15.870
Maybe I wanna go ahead and
deploy 2010 instead, right?

494
00:22:15.870 --> 00:22:17.830
Why would I jump straight to 2013?

495
00:22:17.830 --> 00:22:20.540
Well, [LAUGH] I'll give you
the best argument right there.

496
00:22:20.540 --> 00:22:22.440
The best reason to jump to 2013 is so

497
00:22:22.440 --> 00:22:25.910
that you don't have to upgrade
to 2013 later on, right?

498
00:22:25.910 --> 00:22:28.570
If you're doing a brand
new Exchange install,

499
00:22:28.570 --> 00:22:30.670
always start with
the latest one if you can.

500
00:22:30.670 --> 00:22:34.481
Because otherwise, two years from now,
you're gonna have to do an upgrade, and

501
00:22:34.481 --> 00:22:37.650
it's gonna be costly,
time-consuming, and risky, right?

502
00:22:37.650 --> 00:22:40.270
Any time you do an upgrade,
there's a risk something could go wrong.

503
00:22:40.270 --> 00:22:42.110
Best to avoid that if you can, right?

504
00:22:42.110 --> 00:22:43.930
So always deploy the latest one.

505
00:22:43.930 --> 00:22:46.590
But if your environment's
already running Exchange 2010,

506
00:22:46.590 --> 00:22:48.290
you can stay on Exchange 2010.

507
00:22:48.290 --> 00:22:49.380
Microsoft still supports it.

508
00:22:49.380 --> 00:22:52.600
I know you're thinking 2010,
that's five years old.

509
00:22:52.600 --> 00:22:53.470
Well, it is.

510
00:22:53.470 --> 00:22:55.170
But Microsoft has wide support for it.

511
00:22:55.170 --> 00:22:57.010
They're really good about
supporting that for a long time.

512
00:22:57.010 --> 00:23:00.280
We'll probably see Exchange
2010 supported well into 2017.

513
00:23:00.280 --> 00:23:02.080
It'll probably go for a while.

514
00:23:02.080 --> 00:23:05.430
But Microsoft has this nice little chart
where they kinda show you what you would

515
00:23:05.430 --> 00:23:09.740
lose if you were to go with one of
the older versions of Exchange.

516
00:23:09.740 --> 00:23:12.950
So for example, you'll see things
like administration has changed.

517
00:23:14.080 --> 00:23:15.540
In previous versions of Exchange,

518
00:23:15.540 --> 00:23:19.510
we managed it by using
the Enterprise Management Console.

519
00:23:19.510 --> 00:23:21.800
And that Console was an MMC.

520
00:23:21.800 --> 00:23:24.160
It was software that ran right on
your client, and it was a pain.

521
00:23:24.160 --> 00:23:25.540
It was really slow.

522
00:23:25.540 --> 00:23:28.220
And if you were on a new computer,
you had to install it.

523
00:23:28.220 --> 00:23:31.178
In Exchange 2013,
we have a web management interface.

524
00:23:31.178 --> 00:23:32.440
You just browse this webpage and
you manage it.

525
00:23:32.440 --> 00:23:35.670
You don't need to install anything on your
client and that makes life a lot easier.

526
00:23:35.670 --> 00:23:38.295
That's something you
gain by going to 2013.

527
00:23:38.295 --> 00:23:42.051
Some of the other things that you gain,
well, you'll notice like over at 2010,

528
00:23:42.051 --> 00:23:44.503
there's a lot of these
features 2010 already has,

529
00:23:44.503 --> 00:23:47.950
like role-based administration,
Cloud integration if you want.

530
00:23:47.950 --> 00:23:51.190
You don't necessarily have to go
with that, managed availability.

531
00:23:51.190 --> 00:23:53.880
But we'll start to see some of the bigger
differences down here with the new

532
00:23:53.880 --> 00:23:57.370
things that have been introduced,
like support for Apps.

533
00:23:57.370 --> 00:24:00.989
Third party applications are allowed to
integrate with the Outlook web app at

534
00:24:00.989 --> 00:24:01.552
2013.

535
00:24:01.552 --> 00:24:03.340
They weren't able to do that in 2010.

536
00:24:03.340 --> 00:24:06.980
And that means third party companies
are writing some really cool integrations.

537
00:24:06.980 --> 00:24:12.630
I saw some Salesforce.com demos,
and even Microsoft CRM demos,

538
00:24:12.630 --> 00:24:16.720
where you'd go into Outlook and
a phone call would come in.

539
00:24:16.720 --> 00:24:20.710
You're in OWA, and the contact record for
that person calling in would pop up and

540
00:24:20.710 --> 00:24:23.180
you'd see their information so
you'd know who it was that was calling and

541
00:24:23.180 --> 00:24:24.300
have all that data.

542
00:24:24.300 --> 00:24:25.850
It's great for salespeople, right?

543
00:24:25.850 --> 00:24:29.350
That kind of functionality is stuff
that you gain by going with 2013.

544
00:24:29.350 --> 00:24:32.640
Other things, SharePoint Integration,
I mentioned that one right,

545
00:24:32.640 --> 00:24:35.370
really tight
SharePoint Integration with 2013.

546
00:24:35.370 --> 00:24:39.988
DLP, that data loss prevention,
which is the enhanced records management.

547
00:24:39.988 --> 00:24:43.866
Being able to keep that data and maintain
our compliance, that's new in 2013.

548
00:24:43.866 --> 00:24:46.819
And you'll see a few other things
that have just been improved,

549
00:24:46.819 --> 00:24:50.440
like improved E-Discovery,
where we can search for mailboxes.

550
00:24:50.440 --> 00:24:54.700
These are all newer things in 2013 that,
if you want those features,

551
00:24:54.700 --> 00:24:55.900
you want to jump to 2013.

552
00:24:55.900 --> 00:24:56.820
That's the one that you want.

553
00:24:56.820 --> 00:24:57.444
All right.

554
00:24:57.444 --> 00:25:01.490
But just all that aside,
just from my own personal experience,

555
00:25:01.490 --> 00:25:04.750
you usually don't want to deploy an older
version of Exchange if you can avoid it.

556
00:25:04.750 --> 00:25:07.100
If you can always go with the newest one,
you want to go with the newest one,

557
00:25:07.100 --> 00:25:10.140
because that'll save you
an upgrade down the road.

558
00:25:10.140 --> 00:25:12.450
I've done literally hundreds
of Exchange upgrades.

559
00:25:12.450 --> 00:25:16.317
And I'll tell you, if I could have avoided
them, I would have, every one of them.

560
00:25:16.317 --> 00:25:17.940
So [LAUGH] that's kinda how it is.

561
00:25:17.940 --> 00:25:21.910
And newer upgrades aren't as painful
as the old ones used to be, but

562
00:25:21.910 --> 00:25:24.980
it's still something you'd
rather avoid if you can.

563
00:25:24.980 --> 00:25:27.620
Well, I think I've kind of gone
on long enough on this one,

564
00:25:27.620 --> 00:25:31.610
but in this episode we got
a chance to see what Exchange is.

565
00:25:31.610 --> 00:25:34.930
We talked about the licensing as far as
Standard versus Enterprise licensing.

566
00:25:34.930 --> 00:25:38.036
We talked about the client access
licensing as far as the Standard and

567
00:25:38.036 --> 00:25:39.430
the Enterprise CAL there.

568
00:25:39.430 --> 00:25:41.940
We took a look at the online
offering from Microsoft,

569
00:25:41.940 --> 00:25:44.350
if we wanna do a hosted
Exchange environment.

570
00:25:44.350 --> 00:25:47.710
And lastly, we just talked about
the different versions of Exchange and

571
00:25:47.710 --> 00:25:49.140
which one we wanna go with.

572
00:25:49.140 --> 00:25:53.110
So, hope that opens up your eyes there
as far as where we're going on that.

573
00:25:53.110 --> 00:25:55.440
We're a little light on the technical
details this episode though, aren't we?

574
00:25:55.440 --> 00:25:58.614
So I'm really looking forward to our next
couple of episodes where we dive into our

575
00:25:58.614 --> 00:26:01.651
Exchange architecture, our framework,
and then we start to get our Exchange

576
00:26:01.651 --> 00:26:03.460
environment installed and
build from there.

577
00:26:03.460 --> 00:26:05.300
So definitely stay tuned for that.

578
00:26:05.300 --> 00:26:07.740
But, for this episode,
that's a good place to wrap it up.

579
00:26:07.740 --> 00:26:09.240
So I hope you guys enjoyed it.

580
00:26:09.240 --> 00:26:11.351
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pizet.

581
00:26:11.351 --> 00:26:12.984
And I'll see you next time.

582
00:26:12.984 --> 00:26:18.860
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses the server roles available in Exchange 2013. He begins by discussing the roles found in Exchange 2010 and earlier, and then wraps up by explaining the mail flow in Exchange 2013 along with how each role interacts.
episodes.title: Exchange Server Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.288
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.288 --> 00:00:12.668
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:12.668 --> 00:00:15.175
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.175 --> 00:00:18.812
I'm your host Don Pezet back
again with another episode of

5
00:00:18.812 --> 00:00:20.850
Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.850 --> 00:00:25.860
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at the Exchange Server roles that

7
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:27.300
we can deploy Exchange in.

8
00:00:27.300 --> 00:00:31.490
When you install Exchange there's actually
a number of different pieces inside of it.

9
00:00:31.490 --> 00:00:34.985
And if you're a small business you can
just install it all on the same server,

10
00:00:34.985 --> 00:00:36.785
just have all the roles
right there in one place.

11
00:00:36.785 --> 00:00:39.600
You have one big super Exchange Server,
that works fine.

12
00:00:39.600 --> 00:00:42.050
And for small businesses
that's the recommendation.

13
00:00:42.050 --> 00:00:45.530
But for medium and large business,
as you start growing,

14
00:00:45.530 --> 00:00:49.540
when you have several thousand or
tens of thousands of mailboxes,

15
00:00:49.540 --> 00:00:51.800
there's no single server that's
gonna be able to hold up to that.

16
00:00:51.800 --> 00:00:54.210
Not to mention just the fact that
there's a single point of failure.

17
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.460
What if that single server fails?

18
00:00:56.460 --> 00:00:57.920
Now you're out of luck.

19
00:00:57.920 --> 00:01:02.030
So if we want redundancy, if we want
scale, if we wanna be able to grow to

20
00:01:02.030 --> 00:01:05.610
support our user base, we're gonna
have to deploy more than one server.

21
00:01:05.610 --> 00:01:09.640
And when you deploy more than one server,
you're breaking up the pieces of Exchange

22
00:01:09.640 --> 00:01:12.330
and spreading them out across
multiple pieces of hardware.

23
00:01:12.330 --> 00:01:14.700
So we need to understand
what those pieces are.

24
00:01:14.700 --> 00:01:19.470
Now for those of you that are taking
the exam, they expect you to know the new

25
00:01:19.470 --> 00:01:23.880
roles in Exchange 2013 as well as
the previous ones from 2010 and earlier.

26
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:25.400
So I'm gonna cover both of them.

27
00:01:25.400 --> 00:01:29.190
But even for those of you that aren't
taking the exam, it's good data to have

28
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:33.250
because if you have an existing Exchange
environment and you're upgrading,

29
00:01:33.250 --> 00:01:36.360
you need to know what happens to those
roles, how you build around that.

30
00:01:36.360 --> 00:01:39.350
Or you'll find a lot of technical
data out there on the Internet,

31
00:01:39.350 --> 00:01:43.060
if you start Googling for help, where
people are referring to the old roles.

32
00:01:43.060 --> 00:01:45.980
And so we need to make sure we
understand those different pieces,

33
00:01:45.980 --> 00:01:48.150
what each piece does.

34
00:01:48.150 --> 00:01:51.740
So let's start with the old way and
then we'll move to the new way.

35
00:01:51.740 --> 00:01:56.185
In Exchange 2010 there were actually
five different roles inside of

36
00:01:56.185 --> 00:01:59.150
Microsoft Exchange, and each one was
responsible for a different piece.

37
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:00.520
So let me kind of show you how these work.

38
00:02:00.520 --> 00:02:03.580
I've got a little diagram that I
whipped up here to show kinda just

39
00:02:03.580 --> 00:02:06.860
a generic company and
what they would expect to see.

40
00:02:06.860 --> 00:02:07.915
Now we've got the Internet,

41
00:02:07.915 --> 00:02:11.850
that's the real world that's out there
that everybody uses and connects to.

42
00:02:11.850 --> 00:02:16.490
But then in our company, we probably
have two networks, like a DMZ and a LAN.

43
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:18.070
The LAN, that's our local area network.

44
00:02:18.070 --> 00:02:21.170
That's our private network that
we don't want anybody to touch.

45
00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:26.250
Our DMZ, that stands for demilitarized
zone, that's our network that's public.

46
00:02:26.250 --> 00:02:27.870
That's where our web servers go,

47
00:02:27.870 --> 00:02:30.580
where we want the Internet
to be able to connect to it.

48
00:02:30.580 --> 00:02:33.010
If somebody on the Internet
is gonna send us email,

49
00:02:33.010 --> 00:02:35.360
it's gotta get into our company somehow.

50
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:38.900
So we could have them come straight
into the LAN, but that's pretty risky.

51
00:02:38.900 --> 00:02:41.440
So it's better off to have
them come through a DMZ.

52
00:02:42.570 --> 00:02:45.670
And then from the DMZ,
it then passes in through the LAN.

53
00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:50.360
Now in Microsoft Exchange, we can
set it up to be able to handle that,

54
00:02:50.360 --> 00:02:52.760
thanks to a couple of different roles.

55
00:02:52.760 --> 00:02:54.960
The first role I want to talk about,
though, is the most important one.

56
00:02:54.960 --> 00:02:56.830
It's this guy way over here.

57
00:02:56.830 --> 00:02:58.690
That's the Mailbox server.

58
00:02:58.690 --> 00:03:02.800
The Mailbox server is the server
responsible for, well, mailboxes.

59
00:03:02.800 --> 00:03:04.760
This is where our
mailboxes are gonna reside.

60
00:03:04.760 --> 00:03:09.030
It's really a very fancy
Microsoft SQL database server.

61
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:12.190
Microsoft's Exchange,
at the end of the day, is storing your

62
00:03:12.190 --> 00:03:15.830
email in a database that's very similar to
the database that's used in Microsoft SQL.

63
00:03:16.890 --> 00:03:22.940
But it's very highly tuned and very highly
customized to work as an email server.

64
00:03:22.940 --> 00:03:23.900
So it's not SQL,

65
00:03:23.900 --> 00:03:28.000
you can't put your own data in there
like that, it is just an email database.

66
00:03:28.000 --> 00:03:30.840
And it's been changed quite
a bit to make it different

67
00:03:30.840 --> 00:03:33.220
from your other database
solutions that are out there.

68
00:03:33.220 --> 00:03:37.720
So that Mailbox server, that's one
that's gonna need a lot of storage.

69
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:38.910
That's where your email is.

70
00:03:38.910 --> 00:03:42.730
So if you've got millions of emails,
they've gotta be stored somewhere.

71
00:03:42.730 --> 00:03:44.220
The Mailbox server acts as that database.

72
00:03:45.310 --> 00:03:46.910
Now your end users,

73
00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:51.370
when they wanna access the Mailbox server,
they're not gonna connect directly to it.

74
00:03:51.370 --> 00:03:53.050
Well, there are some
scenarios where they do, but

75
00:03:53.050 --> 00:03:55.090
most of the time they're not
gonna connect directly to it.

76
00:03:55.090 --> 00:03:58.210
They're gonna do something
like using Outlook web app and

77
00:03:58.210 --> 00:04:00.060
browse to a web page to log in.

78
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:03.900
Or they'll fire up a POP3 or
IMAP4 client to connect in.

79
00:04:03.900 --> 00:04:08.840
And when they connect in through those
ways, well, we can have that on the same

80
00:04:08.840 --> 00:04:13.290
physical server or we can break it off
into what's called a Client Access server.

81
00:04:13.290 --> 00:04:16.840
The Client Access server is that
point of contact for your end users.

82
00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:18.890
When your end users want
to access their email,

83
00:04:18.890 --> 00:04:20.720
they access the Client Access server.

84
00:04:20.720 --> 00:04:22.900
It in turn accesses the Mailbox server.

85
00:04:24.880 --> 00:04:27.960
We may also have
a Unified Messaging server.

86
00:04:27.960 --> 00:04:32.300
If we've got Exchange tied into our voice
over IP system to handle voicemail,

87
00:04:32.300 --> 00:04:36.640
scheduling conferences, doing quick
contact dials, things like that, well,

88
00:04:36.640 --> 00:04:40.010
we can deploy a Unified Messaging server,
and that'll tie that together too.

89
00:04:41.240 --> 00:04:44.070
And then lastly we've got
the Hub Transport server.

90
00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:48.740
The Hub Transport server is the one
responsible for moving email around.

91
00:04:48.740 --> 00:04:52.250
It's the one that runs SMTP,
the simple mail transport protocol.

92
00:04:52.250 --> 00:04:56.417
So all incoming and outgoing email in
your organization is gonna pass through

93
00:04:56.417 --> 00:04:57.900
the Hub Transport server.

94
00:04:57.900 --> 00:04:59.290
It's gonna move right through there.

95
00:04:59.290 --> 00:05:03.850
So it's a great place to deploy
things like spam and virus filtering,

96
00:05:03.850 --> 00:05:07.600
email policy rules, things that add legal
disclaimers at the bottom of emails.

97
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:10.730
You can deploy them there cuz all
of your email is gonna pass through

98
00:05:10.730 --> 00:05:12.360
that Hub Transport server.

99
00:05:12.360 --> 00:05:13.660
So that's its role.

100
00:05:14.790 --> 00:05:20.190
Now I could have one physical server
that's running all four of these roles,

101
00:05:20.190 --> 00:05:21.430
and in a small business that works fine.

102
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:23.420
You can deploy them all right there.

103
00:05:23.420 --> 00:05:25.850
Or I could have four servers
that are running these, or

104
00:05:25.850 --> 00:05:27.320
I could have ten servers.

105
00:05:27.320 --> 00:05:29.550
I might have three
Client Access servers and

106
00:05:29.550 --> 00:05:33.220
two Mailbox servers, one
Unified Messaging and two Hub Transport.

107
00:05:33.220 --> 00:05:34.230
You can mix it up.

108
00:05:34.230 --> 00:05:36.110
I'm not sure that adds up to ten,
I wasn't keeping track.

109
00:05:36.110 --> 00:05:37.735
So maybe I went over ten, I don't know.

110
00:05:37.735 --> 00:05:41.300
[LAUGH] But you can have multiple
servers based on your need.

111
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:43.720
And your need might be for
redundancy as far as failure.

112
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:44.902
It might just be for scale.

113
00:05:44.902 --> 00:05:48.973
You've got so many users that one Client
Access server can't do it, so you deploy

114
00:05:48.973 --> 00:05:52.470
three or five or fifty to support
the amount of users that you've got.

115
00:05:53.470 --> 00:05:57.040
This is a very modular deployment that
gives you that ability to expand.

116
00:05:58.200 --> 00:06:01.072
Now what, oh, sorry, I left out one role.

117
00:06:01.072 --> 00:06:02.558
There's this one guy
sitting way over here.

118
00:06:02.558 --> 00:06:04.210
Now why did I leave him out?

119
00:06:04.210 --> 00:06:04.760
He's special.

120
00:06:05.790 --> 00:06:06.780
These other roles,

121
00:06:06.780 --> 00:06:10.380
remember how I said you could have one
server that was running all four roles?

122
00:06:10.380 --> 00:06:12.630
You can, but there's a fifth role.

123
00:06:12.630 --> 00:06:16.100
And that fifth role,
the Edge Transport server, he's different.

124
00:06:16.100 --> 00:06:17.900
He has to be by himself.

125
00:06:17.900 --> 00:06:20.960
He can't run on a server that's
a Mailbox server or Client Access or

126
00:06:20.960 --> 00:06:22.210
Hub Transport or Unified Messaging.

127
00:06:22.210 --> 00:06:24.410
He has to be all by himself
out there in the DMZ.

128
00:06:25.760 --> 00:06:30.460
And that's because this is the server
that's designed to be ultra secure,

129
00:06:30.460 --> 00:06:34.460
that's really, really protected and
isolated from your network.

130
00:06:34.460 --> 00:06:36.650
These guys over here,
all four of these roles,

131
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:39.680
have to have direct connectivity
to your Active Directory.

132
00:06:39.680 --> 00:06:41.340
They've got to be able to
pull up your user list.

133
00:06:41.340 --> 00:06:43.030
They've got be able to authenticate users.

134
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:45.060
They've got to be able
to do a lot of stuff.

135
00:06:45.060 --> 00:06:49.070
Well, if somebody from the outside world
were to hack into one of these servers,

136
00:06:49.070 --> 00:06:51.550
they would then have access
to your internal network,

137
00:06:51.550 --> 00:06:55.040
to your domain controllers, to things that
you don't want them to have access to.

138
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:56.990
So Microsoft created a special
version of Exchange.

139
00:06:56.990 --> 00:06:59.170
It's called the Edge Transport Server and

140
00:06:59.170 --> 00:07:02.100
it doesn't need to be connected
to the Active Directory.

141
00:07:02.100 --> 00:07:06.230
It can run as a standalone entity and
if somebody hacks into it, big deal.

142
00:07:06.230 --> 00:07:09.470
They just have access to that server and
that's it.

143
00:07:09.470 --> 00:07:12.020
But it's got very,
very limited functionality.

144
00:07:12.020 --> 00:07:13.850
We're gonna cover it in
some later episodes so

145
00:07:13.850 --> 00:07:15.460
you get a chance to see how it works.

146
00:07:15.460 --> 00:07:17.695
But it's a great place
to run antivirus and

147
00:07:17.695 --> 00:07:22.750
anti-spam cuz it filters things out
before they even get into your network.

148
00:07:22.750 --> 00:07:25.160
Now I'll tell you, of the roles,
this is one of the least popular.

149
00:07:25.160 --> 00:07:28.820
Not a lot of people run an Edge Transport
server, and you might ask yourself why,

150
00:07:28.820 --> 00:07:31.180
if this makes it more secure,
why wouldn't I want it?

151
00:07:31.180 --> 00:07:36.190
And the reason is a lot of people already
have something that provides this role.

152
00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:42.580
So for example, us, for ITProTV, we have
a Barracuda anti-spam and virus firewall.

153
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:46.480
It's an appliance, and it does exactly
what that Edge Transport server does.

154
00:07:46.480 --> 00:07:51.650
It sits in our DMZ, email flows into it,
gets filtered before it even comes in, and

155
00:07:51.650 --> 00:07:54.420
then the Barracuda is allowed
to talk to our internal systems.

156
00:07:54.420 --> 00:07:56.870
It performs this role,
the role of an Edge Transport server.

157
00:07:56.870 --> 00:07:59.238
You don't have to use
Microsoft's Edge Transport.

158
00:07:59.238 --> 00:08:01.780
You can use any provider
out there that you want.

159
00:08:01.780 --> 00:08:04.753
But if you don't have one,
you can use Microsoft's.

160
00:08:04.753 --> 00:08:08.436
And now it's supported by the same people
that are running your operating system as

161
00:08:08.436 --> 00:08:12.310
well as your internal mail servers, so
it creates a more consistent environment.

162
00:08:12.310 --> 00:08:14.620
So it's up to you whether you
wanna go that route or not, but

163
00:08:14.620 --> 00:08:16.350
it is purely optional.

164
00:08:16.350 --> 00:08:17.890
Some of these roles are optional, right.

165
00:08:17.890 --> 00:08:21.560
The Unified Messaging, if you don't have a
Voice over IP system that you want to tie

166
00:08:21.560 --> 00:08:24.780
into, you don't need this role,
you leave it out, you just chuck it and

167
00:08:24.780 --> 00:08:25.835
that's the end of it.

168
00:08:25.835 --> 00:08:26.490
Right?

169
00:08:26.490 --> 00:08:29.860
But these three roles,
Hub Transport, Client Access, and

170
00:08:29.860 --> 00:08:33.264
Mailbox, you have to have
those in Exchange 2010.

171
00:08:34.730 --> 00:08:37.510
Now, when email comes
into your organization,

172
00:08:37.510 --> 00:08:40.850
if you have all the roles,
it looks something like this.

173
00:08:40.850 --> 00:08:43.040
You mail comes into
the Edge Transport Server,

174
00:08:43.040 --> 00:08:45.390
it then jumps over to
a Hub Transport Server.

175
00:08:45.390 --> 00:08:48.490
So bridging that gap between the DMZ and
the Hub.

176
00:08:48.490 --> 00:08:51.710
Now, neat thing about this,
I shouldn't have drawn arrow this way.

177
00:08:51.710 --> 00:08:55.390
This arrow really should be pointing
the other direction because

178
00:08:55.390 --> 00:09:00.590
the Edge Transport Server is not allowed
to talk to your Local Area Network.

179
00:09:00.590 --> 00:09:02.670
It's not.
It cannot talk to your LAN.

180
00:09:02.670 --> 00:09:08.488
Instead, your Hub Transport Server has to
reach out to it and pull the email back.

181
00:09:08.488 --> 00:09:12.180
And that way, if somebody hacks into this
box, they can't initiate connections in.

182
00:09:12.180 --> 00:09:14.790
The connections have to be
initiated from the inside out.

183
00:09:14.790 --> 00:09:16.350
It makes them more secure.

184
00:09:16.350 --> 00:09:19.740
So your email comes into the Edge
Transport, your Hub Transport Server goes

185
00:09:19.740 --> 00:09:24.110
and picks it up, and now it gets it and
sends it to the Mailbox Server.

186
00:09:24.110 --> 00:09:26.240
Your end users connect to
the Client Access Server and

187
00:09:26.240 --> 00:09:27.920
the Client Access Server
connects the Mailbox Server.

188
00:09:27.920 --> 00:09:29.500
And that's how they get their email.

189
00:09:29.500 --> 00:09:32.170
Or your voice over IP system
connects that Mailbox Server

190
00:09:32.170 --> 00:09:33.950
through the Unified Messaging Server.

191
00:09:33.950 --> 00:09:37.910
All these pieces kind of integrate
together, and if these four are all

192
00:09:37.910 --> 00:09:40.950
running on the same hardware,
that's all just happening in software.

193
00:09:40.950 --> 00:09:42.800
But, if these are running on
separate physical servers,

194
00:09:42.800 --> 00:09:46.770
they just communicate via the network, and
it's nothing too terribly special, right?

195
00:09:46.770 --> 00:09:49.660
We can build redundancy into this
by adding multiple servers, and

196
00:09:49.660 --> 00:09:51.430
you get a really powerful
exchange environment built up.

197
00:09:52.600 --> 00:09:57.310
However, Microsoft did some studies, and
they found some really interesting things.

198
00:09:57.310 --> 00:10:02.640
They found, for example, that very
few people used Unified Messaging.

199
00:10:02.640 --> 00:10:06.070
And that when they did, the functions
that Unified Messaging Server

200
00:10:06.070 --> 00:10:09.680
role was providing, were actually
being performed by their other system.

201
00:10:09.680 --> 00:10:12.910
So, like if you have
a Cisco Unified Communication Server,

202
00:10:12.910 --> 00:10:16.330
it does the bulk of what
the Unified Messaging Server role did.

203
00:10:16.330 --> 00:10:19.130
So at the end of the day,
the Unified Messaging Server was

204
00:10:19.130 --> 00:10:22.310
really just acting like a proxy at that
point, the Cisco stuff did all the work.

205
00:10:22.310 --> 00:10:26.040
Or you might have a Via or
Microcom, Microtel,

206
00:10:26.040 --> 00:10:29.660
one of those guys, and
their systems do a lot of that work and

207
00:10:29.660 --> 00:10:31.510
we don't necessarily need
the Unified Messaging Server to do it.

208
00:10:31.510 --> 00:10:32.470
All right.

209
00:10:32.470 --> 00:10:35.720
So, Microsoft found that was
the case in a lot of environments.

210
00:10:35.720 --> 00:10:38.790
This same thing went for
the Edge Transport Server.

211
00:10:38.790 --> 00:10:39.840
A lot of people weren't using it.

212
00:10:39.840 --> 00:10:43.410
They had a third party system that was
doing it and they were sticking with that.

213
00:10:43.410 --> 00:10:47.870
They also found that most people
were deploying Hub Transport Servers

214
00:10:47.870 --> 00:10:48.430
incorrectly.

215
00:10:48.430 --> 00:10:50.021
They were using them the wrong way and

216
00:10:50.021 --> 00:10:52.800
deploying them in a way
that wasn't secure.

217
00:10:52.800 --> 00:10:54.920
And so in Exchange 2013, Microsoft said,

218
00:10:54.920 --> 00:10:57.270
you know what,
we really need to revisit this.

219
00:10:57.270 --> 00:11:00.370
We need to tweak things to be a little
more efficient, to be a little more

220
00:11:00.370 --> 00:11:03.890
intuitive, and to make sense with
the way people are using our products.

221
00:11:03.890 --> 00:11:10.340
So in Exchange 2010, we had five roles,
in Exchange 2013, we only have three.

222
00:11:10.340 --> 00:11:13.260
There's just three roles and
that's it, alright.

223
00:11:13.260 --> 00:11:17.040
So in Exchange 2013,
the Unified Messaging role is gone, and

224
00:11:17.040 --> 00:11:19.160
the Hub Transport role is gone.

225
00:11:19.160 --> 00:11:23.386
Now if you rely on those, which the Hub
Transport you definitely do, dont panic.

226
00:11:23.386 --> 00:11:25.640
It's not that they're gone as in
the functionality is all gone,

227
00:11:25.640 --> 00:11:28.590
its just that they've been
eliminated as roles and

228
00:11:28.590 --> 00:11:31.350
now Microsoft dictates how they
work inside of the system.

229
00:11:31.350 --> 00:11:33.040
They work in a much more intuitive manner.

230
00:11:33.040 --> 00:11:35.210
So let's talk about how this works.

231
00:11:35.210 --> 00:11:38.410
First off,
if you install Exchange 2013 from DVD,

232
00:11:38.410 --> 00:11:43.730
you only have two roles,
Client Access and Mailbox.

233
00:11:43.730 --> 00:11:45.410
And that's it, right?

234
00:11:45.410 --> 00:11:47.140
Edge Transport, Microsoft left it out.

235
00:11:47.140 --> 00:11:50.250
Microsoft said, you know a lot of people
are using third party stuff, well,

236
00:11:50.250 --> 00:11:52.160
we'll just let them stick with
their third-party stuff and

237
00:11:52.160 --> 00:11:54.240
we'll eliminate the Edge Transport role.

238
00:11:54.240 --> 00:11:57.230
So they eliminated it,
originally in 2013, and there was so

239
