00:11:57.230 --> 00:11:59.990
much feedback from the community,
people saying, no we really want that.

240
00:11:59.990 --> 00:12:01.890
Yeah, yeah,
we're running a third-party system but

241
00:12:01.890 --> 00:12:04.890
we wanna migrate to the Edge Transport
role, we just haven't done it yet.

242
00:12:04.890 --> 00:12:07.370
And so in Exchange 2013 Service Pack 1,

243
00:12:07.370 --> 00:12:12.210
Microsoft reintroduced the Edge Transport
role, so that's back again.

244
00:12:12.210 --> 00:12:14.790
Be careful with that if you're
Googling for help on the Internet,

245
00:12:14.790 --> 00:12:17.780
you'll see a lot of people say there's
only two roles in Exchange 2013.

246
00:12:17.780 --> 00:12:21.100
But on the exam,
the exam is based on Service Pack 1,

247
00:12:21.100 --> 00:12:24.870
there's three roles in Exchange 2013,
so be aware of that, right?

248
00:12:24.870 --> 00:12:25.680
Now you may not use it.

249
00:12:25.680 --> 00:12:28.230
You can always just choose not
to use the Edge Transport role.

250
00:12:28.230 --> 00:12:31.710
But at a minimum you're gonna have these
two guys, Client Access Server and

251
00:12:31.710 --> 00:12:32.630
Mailbox Server.

252
00:12:32.630 --> 00:12:34.330
You've got to have them, right.

253
00:12:34.330 --> 00:12:36.710
The Mailbox Server is
where your email resides.

254
00:12:36.710 --> 00:12:37.685
It's gotta be stored somewhere.

255
00:12:37.685 --> 00:12:38.455
You have to have that.

256
00:12:38.455 --> 00:12:41.125
And the Client Access Server,
that's what your clients connect to.

257
00:12:41.125 --> 00:12:42.845
They've gotta have a way
to get to the email.

258
00:12:42.845 --> 00:12:43.795
You have to have that.

259
00:12:43.795 --> 00:12:45.685
Those are the two roles you have to have.

260
00:12:45.685 --> 00:12:48.625
You could deploy them on
the same physical server.

261
00:12:48.625 --> 00:12:49.515
It'll let you do that.

262
00:12:49.515 --> 00:12:50.135
Right.

263
00:12:50.135 --> 00:12:52.105
Or you could split them
up into two servers.

264
00:12:52.105 --> 00:12:53.225
You could have 20 servers.

265
00:12:53.225 --> 00:12:54.575
You could have more than one of each role.

266
00:12:54.575 --> 00:12:55.680
That works great.

267
00:12:55.680 --> 00:12:56.370
All right.

268
00:12:56.370 --> 00:13:00.650
So when email comes in,
it comes into the Edge Transport role,

269
00:13:00.650 --> 00:13:04.550
the Edge Transport sends it to
the Client Access Server, now.

270
00:13:04.550 --> 00:13:07.550
And the Client Access Server
distributes it to the Mailbox Server.

271
00:13:07.550 --> 00:13:10.340
Mail flows a little bit different
because we don't have that Hub Transport

272
00:13:10.340 --> 00:13:11.280
role anymore.

273
00:13:11.280 --> 00:13:11.800
All right?

274
00:13:11.800 --> 00:13:13.890
And we don't have
the Unified Messaging role.

275
00:13:13.890 --> 00:13:15.580
Well, what happened to those guys?

276
00:13:15.580 --> 00:13:17.930
What happened to
the Unified Messaging role?

277
00:13:17.930 --> 00:13:22.330
Well, because most people
were using it as a proxy,

278
00:13:22.330 --> 00:13:24.810
basically, Microsoft did exactly that.

279
00:13:24.810 --> 00:13:29.580
They reduced it to become more of just
a proxy and it runs as just a service now.

280
00:13:29.580 --> 00:13:31.710
It's not a role,
it's not something we have to install.

281
00:13:31.710 --> 00:13:35.270
It's a service that's installed
automatically on your Mailbox Server.

282
00:13:35.270 --> 00:13:37.350
So your Mailbox Server is
actually running that proxy.

283
00:13:37.350 --> 00:13:40.810
And if you have a third party voice over
IP system that supports Exchange 2013,

284
00:13:40.810 --> 00:13:42.990
you can point it right to there.

285
00:13:42.990 --> 00:13:44.050
All right.

286
00:13:44.050 --> 00:13:46.650
If you don't have a third
party voice over IP system and

287
00:13:46.650 --> 00:13:50.340
you want one, well, what about all
the functionality that's gone?

288
00:13:50.340 --> 00:13:54.020
Well that's now part of Microsoft's
link or Skype for Business.

289
00:13:54.020 --> 00:13:57.570
So it's all been kind of rolled into that
new system and you can deploy that and

290
00:13:57.570 --> 00:13:58.338
it takes care of it.

291
00:13:58.338 --> 00:13:59.660
So they just kind of shifted that out and

292
00:13:59.660 --> 00:14:02.540
they said not enough people are using
it to keep it as part of Exchange.

293
00:14:02.540 --> 00:14:04.890
Now it's a separate product.

294
00:14:04.890 --> 00:14:09.290
On the Hub Transport side,
well, that one is still there.

295
00:14:09.290 --> 00:14:11.880
The Hub Transport role is
technically still there.

296
00:14:11.880 --> 00:14:15.850
But what happened is,
they broke it into three services.

297
00:14:15.850 --> 00:14:19.875
Instead of being a dedicated role that you
can install on a dedicated server, if you

298
00:14:19.875 --> 00:14:24.305
wanted, now it's three services that work
together that are already implemented.

299
00:14:24.305 --> 00:14:26.885
And this gives us the most
efficient implementation and

300
00:14:26.885 --> 00:14:30.435
the most reliable one and it insures that
it's always being deployed correctly, so

301
00:14:30.435 --> 00:14:32.650
we don't have to worry about the role
anymore it's basically gone.

302
00:14:32.650 --> 00:14:33.380
All right.

303
00:14:33.380 --> 00:14:34.530
Now the three services.

304
00:14:34.530 --> 00:14:37.270
Let me just kind of run over those and
how they work.

305
00:14:37.270 --> 00:14:39.430
The first one is kind of important.

306
00:14:39.430 --> 00:14:42.445
It's called
the Front-end Transport service.

307
00:14:42.445 --> 00:14:44.370
The Front-end Transport service?

308
00:14:44.370 --> 00:14:45.990
That's basically our SMTP server.

309
00:14:45.990 --> 00:14:48.160
Right.
This is where our incoming mail is gonna

310
00:14:48.160 --> 00:14:50.780
come in to and
where our outgoing mail goes out to.

311
00:14:50.780 --> 00:14:55.320
So, when email comes in and goes to an
Edge Transport Server, if we have one, or

312
00:14:55.320 --> 00:14:59.460
just comes in bypassing it, if we don't,
it's gonna come to a Client Access Server.

313
00:14:59.460 --> 00:15:02.410
And it's the Front-end Transport
service that's running right

314
00:15:02.410 --> 00:15:06.100
here on the Client Access Server,
that's what's gonna receive that email.

315
00:15:06.100 --> 00:15:08.390
Now, interesting fact here.

316
00:15:08.390 --> 00:15:11.102
It receives the email but
it does not queue it.

317
00:15:11.102 --> 00:15:15.520
The Front-end Transport service does not
hold your email, not even for a second.

318
00:15:15.520 --> 00:15:17.030
It doesn't write it to the hard drive.

319
00:15:17.030 --> 00:15:21.530
It receives it in RAM,
applies any transport rules that it has.

320
00:15:21.530 --> 00:15:24.710
We might do email, spam and
virus filtering or

321
00:15:24.710 --> 00:15:27.590
compliance journaling, whatever it is.

322
00:15:27.590 --> 00:15:30.810
It does that and
then it sends the email on,

323
00:15:30.810 --> 00:15:32.550
to be able to go back
to that Mailbox Server.

324
00:15:33.770 --> 00:15:36.750
Now back in the Mailbox Server we actually
have two services that are running there.

325
00:15:36.750 --> 00:15:39.630
That was the Front-end Transport service.

326
00:15:39.630 --> 00:15:41.720
Then we've got our Hub Transport service.

327
00:15:41.720 --> 00:15:43.290
Now that sounds familiar, right?

328
00:15:43.290 --> 00:15:46.240
The Hub Transport role,
here's the Hub Transport service.

329
00:15:46.240 --> 00:15:50.090
The Hub Transport service is what
manages your queues, your incoming and

330
00:15:50.090 --> 00:15:51.116
outgoing mail queue.

331
00:15:51.116 --> 00:15:53.916
When an e-mail comes in, it actually
gets written to the hard drive and

332
00:15:53.916 --> 00:15:55.222
it sits there on the hard drive for

333
00:15:55.222 --> 00:15:58.084
a second while it figures out where
to send it, that's your mail queue.

334
00:15:58.084 --> 00:16:02.087
Outgoing e-mail is the same way, it drops
into a queue and it sits there in that

335
00:16:02.087 --> 00:16:05.680
folder until we can contact
the destination server and send it along.

336
00:16:05.680 --> 00:16:10.465
So the hub transport service is that
series of cues and it's gonna store those

337
00:16:10.465 --> 00:16:14.306
emails and it's doing that right
here on the mailbox server.

338
00:16:14.306 --> 00:16:18.019
And then lastly, we've got our
mailbox transport service and

339
00:16:18.019 --> 00:16:20.963
the mailbox transport
service is responsible for

340
00:16:20.963 --> 00:16:25.039
moving emails between the hub
transport service and the mailboxes.

341
00:16:25.039 --> 00:16:27.859
So those cues that are sitting here,
that's what's shifting in between.

342
00:16:27.859 --> 00:16:32.133
When you write an email in Outlook,
if I write an email and I hit send,

343
00:16:32.133 --> 00:16:37.315
the first thing it does is it copies it to
my outbound mailbox or my outbound folder.

344
00:16:37.315 --> 00:16:39.471
So you've got this outbound folder.

345
00:16:39.471 --> 00:16:42.980
And then once it sends,
then it moves it to sent items.

346
00:16:42.980 --> 00:16:46.113
When it's in that outbound folder, that's
when it's trying to communicate that

347
00:16:46.113 --> 00:16:48.181
mailbox transport service to
be able to send it along.

348
00:16:48.181 --> 00:16:51.510
And once it communicates,
then it moves it to sent items.

349
00:16:51.510 --> 00:16:55.920
So I can have an email stuck in outbound,
if it's just pending and

350
00:16:55.920 --> 00:16:57.490
can't communicate with the server.

351
00:16:57.490 --> 00:16:59.630
So that's it communicating
with this other service.

352
00:16:59.630 --> 00:17:03.509
So hub transport's been divided into three
services and those services have been

353
00:17:03.509 --> 00:17:07.572
spread across the client access server, so
we don't have to worry about it anymore.

354
00:17:07.572 --> 00:17:09.986
But that's kinda gone,
it's gone by the wayside.

355
00:17:09.986 --> 00:17:11.925
Those are roles we don't
have to worry about.

356
00:17:11.925 --> 00:17:15.744
So at the end of the day, there's really
two main roles we have to worry about.

357
00:17:15.744 --> 00:17:19.615
Client access server and mailbox server
and they can run in the same box or

358
00:17:19.615 --> 00:17:20.820
we can split them up and

359
00:17:20.820 --> 00:17:25.089
rum them on separate boxes and we can run
more than one of each based on our scale.

360
00:17:25.089 --> 00:17:27.990
As your database gets larger,
it takes longer to backup.

361
00:17:27.990 --> 00:17:30.387
It takes more memory to cache and
index, so

362
00:17:30.387 --> 00:17:32.925
we might want more than
one physical server.

363
00:17:32.925 --> 00:17:34.720
We can have more than one mailbox server.

364
00:17:34.720 --> 00:17:36.730
We might wanna have mailbox
servers in multiple geographic

365
00:17:36.730 --> 00:17:38.060
locations, you can do that.

366
00:17:38.060 --> 00:17:39.431
You just have more than one.

367
00:17:39.431 --> 00:17:41.043
Same thing with client access.

368
00:17:41.043 --> 00:17:43.284
Client access is all about CPU and RAM.

369
00:17:43.284 --> 00:17:46.782
If I have so many users, that server's
getting overloaded and I can just add more

370
00:17:46.782 --> 00:17:49.928
and I can load balance across them and
we'll see that in later episodes.

371
00:17:49.928 --> 00:17:53.063
We're gonna have an entire series
of episodes that are based just on

372
00:17:53.063 --> 00:17:56.151
the mailbox server role and
just on the client access server role.

373
00:17:56.151 --> 00:17:59.104
And then there's that third row we don't
wanna forget about, the edge transport.

374
00:17:59.104 --> 00:18:03.589
If you want that secure kind of gateway
in between you and the internet,

375
00:18:03.589 --> 00:18:06.603
the edge transport role
is designed to do that.

376
00:18:06.603 --> 00:18:11.030
It's a very limited version of Exchange,
it's not allowed to talk to your LAN.

377
00:18:11.030 --> 00:18:14.464
Servers on the inside of your
network have to reach out to

378
00:18:14.464 --> 00:18:17.836
it to pull data back in and
so that makes it very secure.

379
00:18:17.836 --> 00:18:22.074
And if somebody were the break into it,
they cant get to your internal network.

380
00:18:22.074 --> 00:18:24.067
Keeps things nice and safe.

381
00:18:24.067 --> 00:18:26.378
So that's kind of what
that is designed for.

382
00:18:26.378 --> 00:18:29.847
So when you're getting ready to install
Exchange, if you're doing a brand new

383
00:18:29.847 --> 00:18:33.392
deployment for your environment, these
are the things you have to think about.

384
00:18:33.392 --> 00:18:36.946
Do I want one server that's gonna
run both client access and mailbox?

385
00:18:36.946 --> 00:18:38.512
Or do I want to do two servers?

386
00:18:38.512 --> 00:18:39.453
Or do I want to do five servers?

387
00:18:39.453 --> 00:18:40.068
Or ten servers?

388
00:18:40.068 --> 00:18:41.763
What's my load going to be like?

389
00:18:41.763 --> 00:18:45.115
Well, if you go on to Microsoft's TechNet
website they have various pages on

390
00:18:45.115 --> 00:18:47.603
there to kind of help you to
do your scaling and planning.

391
00:18:47.603 --> 00:18:52.043
But at the end of the day,
my rule of thumb for your average user,

392
00:18:52.043 --> 00:18:56.170
I try and keep mailbox servers
to 1,500 users or less.

393
00:18:56.170 --> 00:19:00.484
When you start getting over 1,500 users,
it's just a lot of seek time on that

394
00:19:00.484 --> 00:19:03.125
database and
most file systems can't handle it.

395
00:19:03.125 --> 00:19:05.923
But you don't always have average users.

396
00:19:05.923 --> 00:19:09.037
Sometimes you have power users that
have 10 gig mailboxes, sometimes

397
00:19:09.037 --> 00:19:12.772
you have really light users that only have
100 meg mailboxes that are really small.

398
00:19:12.772 --> 00:19:16.710
So that really influences how many
people a single server can handle.

399
00:19:16.710 --> 00:19:18.144
And on client access servers,

400
00:19:18.144 --> 00:19:21.520
it really comes down to how many
simultaneous users you have connected.

401
00:19:21.520 --> 00:19:24.051
Each user's gonna occupy
a little bit of CPU and

402
00:19:24.051 --> 00:19:26.082
a little bit of memory on your system.

403
00:19:26.082 --> 00:19:27.592
If they're doing Outlook Web App,

404
00:19:27.592 --> 00:19:30.273
then they're actually gonna
occupy a little bit more memory.

405
00:19:30.273 --> 00:19:33.524
You'll find your average users
consuming somewhere between 40 and

406
00:19:33.524 --> 00:19:35.021
50K of memory on that system.

407
00:19:35.021 --> 00:19:36.633
So if you have thousands of users,

408
00:19:36.633 --> 00:19:39.479
you can start to see where that's
gonna run out pretty fast.

409
00:19:39.479 --> 00:19:43.279
So TechNet has some scaling tools,
you can punch in your amount of users and

410
00:19:43.279 --> 00:19:47.396
it'll help you to scale that out, but
it's really easy to scale out on your own.

411
00:19:47.396 --> 00:19:49.394
I usually deploy these
as virtual machines.

412
00:19:49.394 --> 00:19:51.751
So if I see a client access
server getting overwhelmed,

413
00:19:51.751 --> 00:19:54.523
I can just spin up another client
access server and go from there.

414
00:19:54.523 --> 00:19:56.611
So really easy to do that.

415
00:19:56.611 --> 00:20:01.250
Do be aware that we need to make sure
we're running either Exchange Standard or

416
00:20:01.250 --> 00:20:02.673
Exchange Enterprise.

417
00:20:02.673 --> 00:20:05.418
And if you remember from an earlier
episode, the difference there,

418
00:20:05.418 --> 00:20:08.130
Exchange Enterprise can handle up
to a hundred mailbox databases.

419
00:20:08.130 --> 00:20:11.323
Exchange Standard can only handle
up to five mailbox databases.

420
00:20:11.323 --> 00:20:15.349
Well, if I'm running my client access and
mailbox on the same server and

421
00:20:15.349 --> 00:20:19.853
I've got more than five mailbox databases,
then I need an Enterprise edition.

422
00:20:19.853 --> 00:20:22.465
But if I split these off,
my mailbox server may or

423
00:20:22.465 --> 00:20:26.609
may not need Enterprise based on the
mailbox databases, but my client access

424
00:20:26.609 --> 00:20:30.838
server will always be standard edition
unless I just feel like wasting money.

425
00:20:30.838 --> 00:20:34.041
The client access server
does not hold the email.

426
00:20:34.041 --> 00:20:35.597
It has no mailbox databases.

427
00:20:35.597 --> 00:20:38.918
It's doing Outlook Web App, POP3, IMAP4.

428
00:20:38.918 --> 00:20:41.216
It's doing the offline address book.

429
00:20:41.216 --> 00:20:46.313
It's doing the mobile device management,
communicating to mobile devices.

430
00:20:46.313 --> 00:20:50.570
It's doing all of those functions and it's
running that front-end transport service,

431
00:20:50.570 --> 00:20:52.036
which doesn't queue emails.

432
00:20:52.036 --> 00:20:54.742
So literally, no email is stored
on the client access server.

433
00:20:54.742 --> 00:20:58.140
I don't need to pay for an Enterprise
license to get more mailbox databases on

434
00:20:58.140 --> 00:20:59.617
a server that doesn't have any.

435
00:20:59.617 --> 00:21:04.167
So even if I was a trillion dollar
multinational company that had hundreds of

436
00:21:04.167 --> 00:21:08.861
thousands of users, I would still only
do Enterprise on my mailbox servers and

437
00:21:08.861 --> 00:21:10.369
not on my client access.

438
00:21:10.369 --> 00:21:12.819
So definitely be aware of
that as you plan for this.

439
00:21:12.819 --> 00:21:16.089
But you'll probably have more than one
client access server before the end of

440
00:21:16.089 --> 00:21:18.461
the day,
you'll probably load balance across those.

441
00:21:18.461 --> 00:21:19.281
And then that way,

442
00:21:19.281 --> 00:21:22.420
you can quickly add new servers as you
need to scale your environment up.

443
00:21:22.420 --> 00:21:25.438
That's an important thing to do.

444
00:21:25.438 --> 00:21:26.924
So be aware of that.

445
00:21:26.924 --> 00:21:29.780
On the edge transport side,
you might need redundancy there also.

446
00:21:29.780 --> 00:21:31.625
This is how the internet
is connecting to you.

447
00:21:31.625 --> 00:21:34.178
It's probably where your MX
records are gonna point to,

448
00:21:34.178 --> 00:21:37.117
your mail exchange records, so
people know where to send email.

449
00:21:37.117 --> 00:21:39.799
And if your one server goes down,
you stop receiving email.

450
00:21:39.799 --> 00:21:44.185
So you might need 2 of these or 3 or 20,
you can setup a whole array, if you want.

451
00:21:44.185 --> 00:21:46.460
[LAUGH] Yes,
it gets kinda crazy after a while.

452
00:21:46.460 --> 00:21:48.152
But you can deploy as many as you want and

453
00:21:48.152 --> 00:21:50.105
these just need to be
standard edition also.

454
00:21:50.105 --> 00:21:53.681
No sense doing enterprise,
because they don't store email.

455
00:21:53.681 --> 00:21:55.504
They're receiving it and
forwarding it along.

456
00:21:55.504 --> 00:21:58.263
There is actually a queue here
on the transport server while

457
00:21:58.263 --> 00:21:59.427
it's scanning emails.

458
00:21:59.427 --> 00:22:04.002
But if we were to lose those, it's just
a small portion of time that you lose.

459
00:22:04.002 --> 00:22:06.207
So we don't normally worry
too much about that.

460
00:22:06.207 --> 00:22:09.567
You don't normally backup edge transport
servers, just because the email's so

461
00:22:09.567 --> 00:22:10.108
transient.

462
00:22:10.108 --> 00:22:12.245
It's just passing through
while it gets scanned.

463
00:22:12.245 --> 00:22:16.203
And if you're not scanning it,
then it just passes through really fast.

464
00:22:16.203 --> 00:22:19.710
The email's only on there for
a fraction of a second.

465
00:22:19.710 --> 00:22:24.307
So those are the roles inside of Exchange
2013 that we need to be aware of.

466
00:22:24.307 --> 00:22:28.126
I wanted to cover this in depth,
because when you're installing Exchange,

467
00:22:28.126 --> 00:22:31.488
one of the first things it asks you
is what role do you wanna install?

468
00:22:31.488 --> 00:22:35.586
Do you want it to be client access or
do you want it to be a mailbox database?

469
00:22:35.586 --> 00:22:37.165
Do you want it to be edge transport?

470
00:22:37.165 --> 00:22:38.569
You got to pick.

471
00:22:38.569 --> 00:22:41.263
And so we need to understand those
roles and how they fit together.

472
00:22:41.263 --> 00:22:45.985
In 2013, it is still the same that
edge transport has to be by itself

473
00:22:45.985 --> 00:22:50.882
versus client access and mailbox that
can be combined or can be separate.

474
00:22:50.882 --> 00:22:52.995
Well, that's about it as far
as what I've got on the roles.

475
00:22:52.995 --> 00:22:56.758
So in this episode, we got a change
to see the Exchange 2010 roles and

476
00:22:56.758 --> 00:23:00.663
how they used to work and the Exchange
2013 roles and how they work now.

477
00:23:00.663 --> 00:23:04.076
And that's important stuff to know
when we're doing the install.

478
00:23:04.076 --> 00:23:05.643
Well, this is a good point
to wrap this one up.

479
00:23:05.643 --> 00:23:07.095
So, I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

480
00:23:07.095 --> 00:23:10.578
Stay tuned, because we've got more
Exchange 2013 coming down the line.

481
00:23:10.578 --> 00:23:14.537
But signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll you next time.

482
00:23:14.537 --> 00:23:20.490
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses the steps necessary to prepare your Active Directory prior to installing Exchange 2013. He also discusses some of the different administrative roles that may need to be involved in getting prepared for an Exchange deployment.
episodes.title: Preparing the Active Directory
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.194 --> 00:00:11.015
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.015 --> 00:00:11.980
All right.

3
00:00:11.980 --> 00:00:13.600
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

4
00:00:13.600 --> 00:00:15.810
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.810 --> 00:00:20.830
I'm your host, Don Pezet Back again
with another episode of Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.830 --> 00:00:25.050
Now in this episode, we're gonna take a
look at preparing our Active Directory for

7
00:00:25.050 --> 00:00:26.480
our Exchange install.

8
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:29.150
And if you've been watching out episodes,
I think we're on episode number three now.

9
00:00:29.150 --> 00:00:31.550
You're probably thinking boy,
this is a great series Don.

10
00:00:31.550 --> 00:00:33.181
But you haven't actually
done any work yet.

11
00:00:33.181 --> 00:00:36.625
[LAUGH] And so, this will be the first
episode we do some real work as far as

12
00:00:36.625 --> 00:00:39.230
getting Exchange deployed
in our environment.

13
00:00:39.230 --> 00:00:41.530
And the funny part,
it's not even to work with Exchange.

14
00:00:41.530 --> 00:00:43.070
It's to work with the Active Directory.

15
00:00:43.070 --> 00:00:45.010
Now why do we have to do that?

16
00:00:45.010 --> 00:00:48.040
Well, Microsoft Exchange
does some really neat stuff.

17
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:53.710
One of the cool things that it does is
that it stores its entire configuration

18
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:55.300
in the active directory, and

19
00:00:55.300 --> 00:00:57.750
that's pretty awesome because your
active directory replicates, right?

20
00:00:57.750 --> 00:00:59.580
So you've probably got
multiple domain controllers.

21
00:00:59.580 --> 00:01:02.290
I say probably, I hope you have
multiple domain controllers.

22
00:01:02.290 --> 00:01:05.700
So that Active Directory partition is
being replicated between all those

23
00:01:05.700 --> 00:01:06.980
different systems.

24
00:01:06.980 --> 00:01:11.290
And that means if you lose your Exchange
Server, you can actually restore it,

25
00:01:11.290 --> 00:01:15.080
bring it up really quickly because
it can reload the config right from

26
00:01:15.080 --> 00:01:16.110
the Active Directory.

27
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:18.930
And then you just have to restore your
mailbox data and you're in business.

28
00:01:18.930 --> 00:01:22.230
Active Directory restores
are lightning fast because of that.

29
00:01:22.230 --> 00:01:23.980
So definitely, a cool thing to have.

30
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:27.210
Also, all of your user data.

31
00:01:28.210 --> 00:01:31.120
So, for example, like what email
addresses I have attached to me, or

32
00:01:31.120 --> 00:01:32.370
what groups I'm in.

33
00:01:32.370 --> 00:01:34.610
That's all stored in
the active directory also.

34
00:01:34.610 --> 00:01:36.330
That makes for quick look ups and

35
00:01:36.330 --> 00:01:39.715
a database that's already being
replicated across my environment.

36
00:01:39.715 --> 00:01:41.715
So Exchange builds on that.

37
00:01:41.715 --> 00:01:45.495
You cannot deploy Microsoft Exchange
without having an Active Directory first.

38
00:01:45.495 --> 00:01:47.815
You've gotta have
an Active Directory to run Exchange.

39
00:01:47.815 --> 00:01:49.785
There is no standalone mode.

40
00:01:49.785 --> 00:01:52.305
But the Active Directory out of the box,

41
00:01:52.305 --> 00:01:55.715
if I just install Windows Server 2012,
promote it to a domain controller, and

42
00:01:55.715 --> 00:02:00.200
build up a forest, it actually
doesn't have the Exchange attributes.

43
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:01.960
So when we install Exchange,

44
00:02:01.960 --> 00:02:06.300
it's expecting a lot of stuff to be
in the AD that just isn't there yet.

45
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:09.150
So before we can install
our first Exchange server,

46
00:02:09.150 --> 00:02:11.320
we've gotta prepare the AD, all right?

47
00:02:11.320 --> 00:02:15.440
Now, what I'm about to show you is
really the same if you're doing

48
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:20.560
your very first Exchange server or if
you're upgrading from a previous version.

49
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:22.400
If it's your very first exchange server,

50
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:26.100
you're active directory has no
exchange records whatsoever.

51
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:29.580
So we need to prepare the AD
to have those records.

52
00:02:29.580 --> 00:02:31.610
If you're running exchange 2010 or
exchange 2007,

53
00:02:31.610 --> 00:02:33.560
or one of the earlier versions,

54
00:02:33.560 --> 00:02:38.160
your Active Directory does have Active
Directory record, or Exchange records.

55
00:02:38.160 --> 00:02:41.930
But they're the old records and
Exchange 2013 added some new ones, so

56
00:02:41.930 --> 00:02:44.100
we have to prepare the AD
to add the new ones, right.

57
00:02:44.100 --> 00:02:46.580
So either way we've gotta
run through this process.

58
00:02:46.580 --> 00:02:50.690
But the key thing to remember here
is that this absolutely must be done

59
00:02:50.690 --> 00:02:54.560
before you install the first
Exchange 2013 server, all right.

60
00:02:54.560 --> 00:02:57.350
So let's run over some of
the prerequisites before we even

61
00:02:57.350 --> 00:03:00.220
really get started because there's
a few things we need to do.

62
00:03:00.220 --> 00:03:04.720
First off, our Active Directory
has a forest functional level.

63
00:03:04.720 --> 00:03:09.930
And that forest functional level needs to
be set to Windows Server 2003 or higher.

64
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.240
So, if you're still running in
Windows 2000 mode in your forest or

65
00:03:13.240 --> 00:03:16.410
if you're back in mixed mode,
one of those really old modes.

66
00:03:16.410 --> 00:03:17.990
You can't run a Exchange 2013.

67
00:03:17.990 --> 00:03:19.750
So you need to be in 2003 or higher.

68
00:03:19.750 --> 00:03:23.395
Fortunately, 2003 has been out for what?

69
00:03:23.395 --> 00:03:24.960
12, 13 years now?

70
00:03:24.960 --> 00:03:26.410
It's really old.

71
00:03:26.410 --> 00:03:28.430
It should be safe to go to that.

72
00:03:28.430 --> 00:03:32.280
But that means that if you're
going to deploy Exchange 2013,

73
00:03:32.280 --> 00:03:35.480
all of your Windows 2000 domain
controllers have to be gone.

74
00:03:35.480 --> 00:03:36.510
They've got to be gone.

75
00:03:36.510 --> 00:03:39.100
You've got to be on 2003 and
higher, right?

76
00:03:39.100 --> 00:03:40.400
The other thing is,

77
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:43.690
we're gonna need some permissions
to be able to do this deployment.

78
00:03:43.690 --> 00:03:45.330
We need to modify the Active Directory.

79
00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:48.590
And when you modify the Active Directory,
there's different partitions inside of

80
00:03:48.590 --> 00:03:50.910
there and you need different
permissions to do stuff.

81
00:03:50.910 --> 00:03:55.630
We need to prepare our domain as well
as prepare our schema, all right?

82
00:03:55.630 --> 00:03:57.630
Now, you might not be
familiar with the schema so

83
00:03:57.630 --> 00:03:59.310
let me just cover this real quickly.

84
00:03:59.310 --> 00:04:01.120
Inside of Active Directory,
we have objects.

85
00:04:01.120 --> 00:04:04.490
Objects like user accounts,
groups, computer accounts.

86
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:07.370
And each of those objects
has things that describe it.

87
00:04:07.370 --> 00:04:10.330
So like if you pull up my user account,
there's things that describe me.

88
00:04:10.330 --> 00:04:11.130
Let me show you here.

89
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:11.950
So I'll take this.

90
00:04:11.950 --> 00:04:13.010
This is a domain controller.

91
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:14.040
It doesn't have Exchange.

92
00:04:14.040 --> 00:04:15.700
It hasn't been prepared.

93
00:04:15.700 --> 00:04:17.768
And if I go into
Active Directory > Users and

94
00:04:17.768 --> 00:04:20.860
Computers
>> So let me just jump in there.

95
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:22.370
I'll find my user object.

96
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:24.500
So I'm gonna browse in here and
I'll find Don Pezet.

97
00:04:24.500 --> 00:04:25.210
I'm in here somewhere.

98
00:04:25.210 --> 00:04:26.220
There I am.

99
00:04:26.220 --> 00:04:27.980
So here's my user object.

100
00:04:27.980 --> 00:04:32.060
And my user object has what
are called attributes attached to it.

101
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:34.810
First name, last name,
display name, description.

102
00:04:34.810 --> 00:04:36.180
These are attributes.

103
00:04:36.180 --> 00:04:39.760
Now how does Active Directory
know to gather this information?

104
00:04:39.760 --> 00:04:42.680
Well in the background there's
a thing called a schema and

105
00:04:42.680 --> 00:04:45.860
the schema says a user object
should have a first name,

106
00:04:45.860 --> 00:04:49.500
a user object should have a last name,
a user object should have an account.

107
00:04:49.500 --> 00:04:51.470
Versus when I pull up a group.

108
00:04:51.470 --> 00:04:54.160
The schema says well a group
doesn't have a first name,

109
00:04:54.160 --> 00:04:55.829
a group doesn't have a last name.

110
00:04:55.829 --> 00:04:59.505
A group has a description, an email,
but not a first and last name.

111
00:04:59.505 --> 00:05:01.340
It's the scheme that defines that.

112
00:05:01.340 --> 00:05:03.220
So the Exchange schema says,

113
00:05:03.220 --> 00:05:07.535
oh by the way, not only should a user
have a first name and a last name, but

114
00:05:07.535 --> 00:05:11.565
they should also have an email address or
multiple email addresses.

115
00:05:11.565 --> 00:05:13.175
They should have a mailbox server.

116
00:05:13.175 --> 00:05:14.725
They should have this and that and

117
00:05:14.725 --> 00:05:18.385
all these other attributes that
pertain to email and collaboration.

118
00:05:18.385 --> 00:05:19.225
All right?

119
00:05:19.225 --> 00:05:21.725
So that all has to get
added to the schema.

120
00:05:21.725 --> 00:05:23.655
Now by default, we don't see the schema.

121
00:05:23.655 --> 00:05:24.615
It's hidden in the background.

122
00:05:24.615 --> 00:05:25.185
We don't touch it.

123
00:05:25.185 --> 00:05:28.830
Microsoft actually goes to some
length to make sure we never see it.

124
00:05:28.830 --> 00:05:32.710
The main reason is, once you modify
the schema you can't undo it.

125
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:34.410
You can't take this back.

126
00:05:34.410 --> 00:05:37.950
Once you've prepared your Active Directory
for Exchange, it's prepared forever.

127
00:05:37.950 --> 00:05:40.060
Even if you uninstall
your exchange servers and

128
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:42.752
get rid of them, your Active Directory
is still prepared for it.

129
00:05:42.752 --> 00:05:45.555
All right, and
that's a limitation of the schema.

130
00:05:45.555 --> 00:05:49.965
When you add something to the schema you
can disable it but you can't delete it.

131
00:05:49.965 --> 00:05:51.155
It's there permanently.

132
00:05:51.155 --> 00:05:53.985
So you really need to make sure this is
something you want to do before you get in

133
00:05:53.985 --> 00:05:55.625
there and prepare it.

134
00:05:55.625 --> 00:06:00.375
So, some of the other things I need to
know here, because this is something that

135
00:06:00.375 --> 00:06:03.760
can't be reversed,
we need to jump through a few hoops.

136
00:06:03.760 --> 00:06:07.430
First off, in your active directory forest
you'll have what's called a schema master.

137
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:09.600
The schema master is the one server,

138
00:06:09.600 --> 00:06:13.680
it's just one, one domain controller
that's responsible for the schema.

139
00:06:13.680 --> 00:06:16.700
Every other server has a read
only copy of the schema, so

140
00:06:16.700 --> 00:06:19.570
only one server's allowed
to modify the schema.

141
00:06:19.570 --> 00:06:24.610
And only users in the schema admins
group are allowed to modify it.

142
00:06:24.610 --> 00:06:27.750
And guess who's in the schema
admins group by default?

143
00:06:27.750 --> 00:06:28.360
No one.

144
00:06:28.360 --> 00:06:29.140
It's empty.

145
00:06:29.140 --> 00:06:31.830
Nobody can modify the schema by default.

146
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:36.350
So if I want to modify the schema,
I've got to put myself into the schema

147
00:06:36.350 --> 00:06:41.410
admins group, and
I've gotta connect to the schema master.

148
00:06:41.410 --> 00:06:44.210
And make that change, and
actually prep the AD.

149
00:06:44.210 --> 00:06:47.680
So I need to do a little bit of homework
before I actually get in here and

150
00:06:47.680 --> 00:06:48.620
start to do my work.

151
00:06:48.620 --> 00:06:50.570
Right?
So let me show you guys that homework,

152
00:06:50.570 --> 00:06:51.590
how we can kind of figure this out.

153
00:06:51.590 --> 00:06:54.790
So here on my system the first thing
I wanna check, cuz I'm already in

154
00:06:54.790 --> 00:06:57.780
Active Directory Users and Computers, I
want to check my forest functional level.

155
00:06:57.780 --> 00:07:00.320
I'm gonna pick my domain.

156
00:07:00.320 --> 00:07:04.463
And I'm gonna right click on that and
choose Raise Domain Functional Level and

157
00:07:04.463 --> 00:07:06.156
I'm gonna take a look at here and

158
00:07:06.156 --> 00:07:09.183
it's gonna give me my domain
functional level, right.

159
00:07:09.183 --> 00:07:12.920
So I can see my domain has a functional
level of Windows Server 2012 R2.

160
00:07:12.920 --> 00:07:16.050
I'm looking for that to be 2003 or higher.

161
00:07:16.050 --> 00:07:18.070
And that's my domain functional level.

162
00:07:18.070 --> 00:07:21.650
I also have a forest functional level and
we can see that in another tool.

163
00:07:21.650 --> 00:07:25.250
If I go up to here to my tools and
into Active Directory Domains and

164
00:07:25.250 --> 00:07:30.640
Trusts, right in here, if I right-click
on Active Directory Domains and

165
00:07:30.640 --> 00:07:33.400
Trusts you'll see
Raise Forest Functional Level.

166
00:07:33.400 --> 00:07:36.030
And you can click on that and
you'll see I'm at Windows server 2012.

167
00:07:36.030 --> 00:07:38.110
I'm looking for 2003 or higher.

168
00:07:38.110 --> 00:07:39.230
Right, and I can move that.

169
00:07:39.230 --> 00:07:40.700
Now, be careful if you need to move yours.

170
00:07:40.700 --> 00:07:43.230
If yours is 2000,
you only have to go to 2003.

171
00:07:43.230 --> 00:07:45.148
You don't have to go all the way to 2012.

172
00:07:45.148 --> 00:07:48.930
All right, now, you might ask yourself,
why wouldn't I go to the latest?

173
00:07:48.930 --> 00:07:49.860
Two reasons.

174
00:07:49.860 --> 00:07:51.940
Reason number one, you can't go back.

175
00:07:51.940 --> 00:07:55.256
Once you go forward,
you can't go back again, all right.

176
00:07:55.256 --> 00:07:58.210
So only move as far
forward as you have to go.

177
00:07:58.210 --> 00:08:00.471
Never move all the way
if you don't have to.

178
00:08:00.471 --> 00:08:04.711
And the reason there is, if you jump
to 2012, you can no longer have

179
00:08:04.711 --> 00:08:09.550
Windows Server 2003,
Windows Server 2008 domain controllers.

180
00:08:09.550 --> 00:08:12.500
You can still have Windows Server
2008 member servers, but

181
00:08:12.500 --> 00:08:13.810
not domain controllers.

182
00:08:13.810 --> 00:08:15.900
So you're limiting the domain
controllers that you can have.

183
00:08:15.900 --> 00:08:17.330
Now that might be a good thing.

184
00:08:17.330 --> 00:08:18.090
Might be a bad thing right?

185
00:08:18.090 --> 00:08:19.020
You might not want that.

186
00:08:19.020 --> 00:08:20.680
So only goes as far as you need.

187
00:08:20.680 --> 00:08:25.730
And for Exchange 2013, Windows Server 2003
mode that's as far as you need to go.

188
00:08:25.730 --> 00:08:26.270
All right.

189
00:08:26.270 --> 00:08:27.300
So make sure you're there.

190
00:08:27.300 --> 00:08:30.190
I can see my domain level and
my forest function level are the same.

191
00:08:32.115 --> 00:08:33.605
All right, the next thing.

192
00:08:33.605 --> 00:08:36.735
I need to put myself in
the schema admin's group.

193
00:08:36.735 --> 00:08:38.355
Now I don't need to stay in there forever.

194
00:08:38.355 --> 00:08:40.075
I just need to be in there
while I make this change, and

195
00:08:40.075 --> 00:08:41.455
then I can take myself
out of the group again.

196
00:08:41.455 --> 00:08:42.425
And that's a good idea.

197
00:08:42.425 --> 00:08:43.975
Don't leave yourself in the group.

198
00:08:43.975 --> 00:08:47.255
Because if you accidentally make a change
to the schema, which is pretty hard to do.

199
00:08:47.255 --> 00:08:49.255
But if you do, you can't undo it.

200
00:08:49.255 --> 00:08:50.025
The way you undo it.

201
00:08:50.025 --> 00:08:51.180
This is fun.

202
00:08:51.180 --> 00:08:54.200
You shut down all your domain controllers
and you restore them all from backup.

203
00:08:54.200 --> 00:08:55.110
It's a good time, right?

204
00:08:55.110 --> 00:08:57.090
You don't want to do that even if
you only have one domain controller,

205
00:08:57.090 --> 00:08:58.290
you don't want to do that, right?

206
00:08:58.290 --> 00:09:00.920
So, take yourself out of
that group when you're done.

207
00:09:00.920 --> 00:09:04.180
So I'm gonna go back to my
Active Directory Users and Computers, And

208
00:09:04.180 --> 00:09:08.770
I'll go under users here and
I'm gonna find the Schema Admins Group.

209
00:09:08.770 --> 00:09:10.030
It's buried in here somewhere.

210
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:11.680
Here it is, Schema Admins.

211
00:09:11.680 --> 00:09:12.430
All right.

212
00:09:12.430 --> 00:09:13.770
And I'm gonna put myself in there.

213
00:09:13.770 --> 00:09:18.545
So I'll go under Members and
I'm gonna add in donpezet.

214
00:09:19.700 --> 00:09:22.830
And there we go, now I'm a Schema Admin.

215
00:09:22.830 --> 00:09:26.752
Quick work of caution here, remember when
you modify a user's group membership,

216
00:09:26.752 --> 00:09:30.058
it doesn't actually take effect until
they log out and log back in, so

217
00:09:30.058 --> 00:09:33.887
I just put myself in the Schema Admin's
group, but I'm not really in there yet.

218
00:09:33.887 --> 00:09:37.280
Until I log out and log back in,
just remember that.

219
00:09:37.280 --> 00:09:40.880
Now there is another thing we have to do,
preparing the Schema is one piece.

220
00:09:40.880 --> 00:09:42.820
I also need to prepare my domain.

221
00:09:42.820 --> 00:09:45.160
There's certain service accounts,

222
00:09:45.160 --> 00:09:49.250
certain users, as well as certain
groups that Exchange expects to exist.

223
00:09:49.250 --> 00:09:51.190
And it can create those for us.

224
00:09:51.190 --> 00:09:54.800
But in order to do that,
I need to be a domain admin,

225
00:09:54.800 --> 00:09:57.040
of the domain that I'm gonna prepare.

226
00:09:57.040 --> 00:09:59.390
So I need to make myself
a domain admin for that domain.

227
00:09:59.390 --> 00:10:02.490
Now you might just be
an Exchange administrator,

228
00:10:02.490 --> 00:10:04.790
and there's a separate
active directory group.

229
00:10:04.790 --> 00:10:06.370
So you might have to reach
over to them and say, hey,

230
00:10:06.370 --> 00:10:09.490
I need you guys to run this command for me
because you're the domain admins, right?

231
00:10:09.490 --> 00:10:11.160
So this might not all be you doing it.

232
00:10:11.160 --> 00:10:15.390
In a large environment, you might have an
Exchange team, an active directory team,

233
00:10:15.390 --> 00:10:17.180
a network team, all kinda divided up.

234
00:10:17.180 --> 00:10:19.150
So you might have to delegate
this out to somebody else.

235
00:10:19.150 --> 00:10:20.130
Just be aware of that.

236
00:10:21.640 --> 00:10:23.980
All right, now I do get a choice here.

237
00:10:23.980 --> 00:10:27.180
If I'm just prepping one domain,
I can make myself a domain admin for

238
00:10:27.180 --> 00:10:28.440
that domain and that's it.

239
00:10:28.440 --> 00:10:32.080
But if I wanna prep all
of my domains at once,

240
00:10:32.080 --> 00:10:35.560
I can put myself in
the Enterprise admins group.

241
00:10:35.560 --> 00:10:36.620
In the Enterprise admins group,

242
00:10:36.620 --> 00:10:40.260
that's like making me a domain admin for
all of my domains.

243
00:10:40.260 --> 00:10:43.404
Now, if you're just an Exchange admin
then you're probably not gonna have that

244
00:10:43.404 --> 00:10:45.903
permission, but if you're
a smaller environment you may, and

245

00:17:56.520 --> 00:18:00.100

00:19:04.560 --> 00:19:08.400

00:19:08.400 --> 00:19:10.940
Now there's some things that

00:19:10.940 --> 00:19:14.885
You really do need to have the .NET
Framework version 4.5.2 installed.

00:19:14.885 --> 00:19:16.892

00:19:16.892 --> 00:19:19.020
If you haven't done your Windows updates,

00:19:19.020 --> 00:19:22.110
So make sure you've got
the .NET Framework in place and

you also need the Windows Management
Framework Version 4.0, which if you're

00:19:31.580 --> 00:19:34.880

00:19:40.335 --> 00:19:44.229

00:19:44.229 --> 00:19:45.090

It's looking, am I running Windows

00:20:01.280 --> 00:20:05.010
So you've got to make sure your service

00:20:05.010 --> 00:20:07.350
After it checks that then it's going

00:20:07.350 --> 00:20:09.060

00:20:09.060 --> 00:20:11.710
It's preparing my organization and

00:20:11.710 --> 00:20:13.124

00:20:13.124 --> 00:20:18.760
The .NET framework, .NET Framework 4.5 is

00:20:18.760 --> 00:20:22.450

00:20:43.100 --> 00:20:46.830

00:20:46.830 --> 00:20:49.070

00:20:51.060 --> 00:20:54.000
All right, so we need to have that

00:20:54.000 --> 00:20:56.190
So those are some of the things

00:20:59.590 --> 00:21:03.330

I need to prepare my domain.

471
00:21:48.380 --> 00:21:50.250
And preparing the domain goes much faster.

472
00:21:50.250 --> 00:21:53.140
Because all it's doing is creating
some users in groups, and that's it.

473
00:21:53.140 --> 00:21:57.020
It actually creates one or two OUs in
your active directory and that's it.

474
00:21:57.020 --> 00:22:00.380
So while this is running, if I go back to
my active directory, users and computers.

475
00:22:01.420 --> 00:22:05.000
And I take a look at it, you can see my
folders here as I look down the side.

476
00:22:05.000 --> 00:22:07.960
We've got things like, well actually
one of them has already appeared,

477
00:22:07.960 --> 00:22:09.780
Microsoft Exchange security groups.

478
00:22:09.780 --> 00:22:12.550
That wasn't there a few moments ago,
it just got created

479
00:22:12.550 --> 00:22:15.690
because my AD is being prepared
right now in the background, right.

480
00:22:15.690 --> 00:22:19.460
So it's creating that and we'll see that
it does that for this domain that I'm in,

481
00:22:19.460 --> 00:22:21.910
but not the other domains
in my organization.

482
00:22:21.910 --> 00:22:25.700
So I need to get those prepared, and
that'll be my next step is preparing them.

483
00:22:25.700 --> 00:22:27.210
But it also creates a few user accounts,

484
00:22:27.210 --> 00:22:30.310
we'll start to see some other things pop
up, we'll verify all that in a minute.

485
00:22:30.310 --> 00:22:33.520
All right, looks like this one's done.

486
00:22:33.520 --> 00:22:34.750
My Schema has now been extended.

487
00:22:35.950 --> 00:22:36.890
How do I know it worked?

488
00:22:36.890 --> 00:22:38.580
Well, I can go and verify that.

489
00:22:38.580 --> 00:22:41.550
I've got my handy dandy Schema tool
that we've built up at the beginning

490
00:22:41.550 --> 00:22:42.900
of the episode.

491
00:22:42.900 --> 00:22:47.380
And if I go back into this and
I'm just gonna browse in here and

492
00:22:47.380 --> 00:22:49.840
find the User Class.

493
00:22:51.240 --> 00:22:52.680
Which was down here at the bottom.

494
00:22:53.750 --> 00:22:57.060
So here's my User Class and
all the attributes tied to my user.

495
00:22:57.060 --> 00:23:00.900
I'm gonna scroll down and
what I should see, here it is.

496
00:23:00.900 --> 00:23:02.955
Remember from the beginning
of the episode,

497
00:23:02.955 --> 00:23:05.660
there were three MS Exchange attributes.

498
00:23:05.660 --> 00:23:10.650
Now I start right here and
if I scroll down, let me just scroll and

499
00:23:10.650 --> 00:23:15.480
scroll and scroll, there's a few,
there's a few Exchange attributes here.

500
00:23:15.480 --> 00:23:19.220
Good gosh there's probably, well, there's
got to be at least 100 of them right?

501
00:23:19.220 --> 00:23:22.310
These are all Exchange attributes
that have been added in the Schema.

502
00:23:22.310 --> 00:23:25.800
I'm still scrolling, there we go,
there's the end of it right there.

503
00:23:25.800 --> 00:23:29.970
And so we can see that's a huge
amount of attributes that it added.

504
00:23:29.970 --> 00:23:32.360
Those are all attributes that
we can never get rid of.

505
00:23:32.360 --> 00:23:32.960
They're permanent.

506
00:23:32.960 --> 00:23:34.960
They're a part of the Schema now, right?

507
00:23:34.960 --> 00:23:37.280
If I store data in there,
it's going to stay there.

508
00:23:37.280 --> 00:23:39.410
I can disable the attributes but

509
00:23:39.410 --> 00:23:42.930
they're still gonna reside in
the four Schema forever right.

510
00:23:42.930 --> 00:23:44.010
So those stay there.

511
00:23:44.010 --> 00:23:48.851
That's what preparing the AD did,
it created all of those.

512
00:23:48.851 --> 00:23:52.427
Now if I only have one domain,
I could actually stop right there,

513
00:23:52.427 --> 00:23:56.250
it did prepare my domain too
because I'm in that domain.

514
00:23:56.250 --> 00:24:00.300
But if I have more than one domain
I gotta prepare my other domains.

515
00:24:00.300 --> 00:24:03.557
And I can do them one at a time or
I can do them all at once.

516
00:24:03.557 --> 00:24:06.429
If I want to do them one at a time, I'm
just gonna bring up this command line that

517
00:24:06.429 --> 00:24:09.430
I ran a moment ago and
I'm gonna modify it a little bit.

518
00:24:09.430 --> 00:24:11.440
If I want to do them one at a time,

519
00:24:11.440 --> 00:24:16.120
I can get rid of this organization since
that's already created, I don't need that.

520
00:24:16.120 --> 00:24:20.890
And I can get PrepareAD and
change that to PrepareDomain, so

521
00:24:20.890 --> 00:24:22.630
now it's just preparing
a particular domain.

522
00:24:23.660 --> 00:24:27.830
And I can then specify the domain
that I want to prepare.

523
00:24:27.830 --> 00:24:32.500
So mine is lab.itprov.tv,
that's the domain I wanna prepare.

524
00:24:32.500 --> 00:24:34.240
And then I accept the licensing terms.

525
00:24:34.240 --> 00:24:36.300
So that's gonna get that
one domain prepared.

526
00:24:37.390 --> 00:24:41.610
I need to be a domain admin for that
domain in order for this command to work.

527
00:24:41.610 --> 00:24:43.190
And you can run this on
any domain controller.

528
00:24:43.190 --> 00:24:44.950
This doesn't have to be run
on the Schema Admin anymore.

529
00:24:46.050 --> 00:24:48.130
All right.
So if you're a really big company,

530
00:24:48.130 --> 00:24:52.800
you might have a Schema team and then a
regular AD team, so the Schema team might

531
00:24:52.800 --> 00:24:57.270
run the PrepareAD, and then the regular
server admin team runs the PrepareDomain.

532
00:24:58.350 --> 00:25:01.780
But if you're an Enterprise admin like
I am, you can make it even easier,

533
00:25:01.780 --> 00:25:10.890
because you can change this to
say PrepareAllDomains, alright.

534
00:25:10.890 --> 00:25:13.320
When we say prepare all domains,
it says get them all.

535
00:25:13.320 --> 00:25:14.630
Just knock them all out at once.

536
00:25:14.630 --> 00:25:16.993
One big command,
you do need to be an Enterprise admin for

537
00:25:16.993 --> 00:25:19.220
this because it's got to
run across all the domains.

538
00:25:19.220 --> 00:25:23.260
And so that's going to reach out and
knock them out.

539
00:25:23.260 --> 00:25:24.320
That's going to run pretty quick.

540
00:25:24.320 --> 00:25:26.950
Just creating some users some
groups setting some permissions.

541
00:25:26.950 --> 00:25:27.720
Nothing too fancy.

542
00:25:27.720 --> 00:25:30.500
But, while it's running let
me just mention something.

543
00:25:30.500 --> 00:25:32.530
Let's say you get hired somewhere.

544
00:25:32.530 --> 00:25:35.950
And you can see those Exchange
attributes in the active directory but

545
00:25:35.950 --> 00:25:40.510
you don't know if it's 2010 or 2013 or
2007, you don't know, all right.

546
00:25:40.510 --> 00:25:44.350
It doesn't hurt to run these commands
a second time or a third time or

547
00:25:44.350 --> 00:25:45.630
a fourth time or a fifth time.

548
00:25:45.630 --> 00:25:47.950
If the attributes already exist,
it just skips over them.

549
00:25:47.950 --> 00:25:50.740
If the users and the groups already exist,
it skips over them.

550
00:25:50.740 --> 00:25:53.270
But anything that's missing,
it'll put in there.

551
00:25:53.270 --> 00:25:56.130
So if you're not sure whether
you're running the latest ones,

552
00:25:56.130 --> 00:25:57.660
it doesn't hurt to go ahead and
redo the prep.

553
00:25:57.660 --> 00:26:00.450
You can rerun it, it'll churn right
through, and it'll get them updated.

554
00:26:00.450 --> 00:26:02.290
So, when in doubt, just run them again.

555
00:26:03.390 --> 00:26:06.693
Alright so at the end of the day there are
really two commands that I ran here right?

556
00:26:06.693 --> 00:26:11.670
Setup/PrepareAD and
setup/preparealldomains.

557
00:26:11.670 --> 00:26:12.580
Those two.

558
00:26:12.580 --> 00:26:16.670
Prepare AD, they got my Schema ready and
that had to be run on the Schema Admin.

559
00:26:16.670 --> 00:26:19.950
Prepare all domains, that got all my
domains ready and that could be run on any

560
00:26:19.950 --> 00:26:23.120
domain controller I just need to
make sure I have the permissions.

561
00:26:23.120 --> 00:26:27.290
When that's done,
I've now got all my attributes in the AD,

562
00:26:27.290 --> 00:26:31.350
and I've got my various other accounts
created in the active director it self.

563
00:26:31.350 --> 00:26:32.830
So if I go to active director users and

564
00:26:32.830 --> 00:26:37.910
computers, now we expect to see
if you didnt see it before,

565
00:26:37.910 --> 00:26:41.300
now you'll see that Microsoft exchange
security groups and all the groups that

566
00:26:41.300 --> 00:26:46.790
are inside of there under users, you'll
see the Exchange online application.

567
00:26:46.790 --> 00:26:48.980
That's allowing our hooks to Azure.

568
00:26:48.980 --> 00:26:50.230
So it'll have that.

569
00:26:50.230 --> 00:26:52.120
So you'll see a few
other things like that.

570
00:26:52.120 --> 00:26:53.890
As well as some hidden objects,

571
00:26:53.890 --> 00:26:56.840
that only turn up when you go
into like your advanced views.

572
00:26:56.840 --> 00:26:58.350
When you start to turn these on,
you can dig and

573
00:26:58.350 --> 00:27:00.360
then you'll see some more
things buried in here.

574
00:27:00.360 --> 00:27:04.150
Like these Microsoft Exchange system
objects that are hidden by default.

575
00:27:04.150 --> 00:27:07.900
And that's where you can jump in and start
see your monitoring mailboxes and so on.

576
00:27:07.900 --> 00:27:10.490
All of that was created
by preparing the AD.

577
00:27:10.490 --> 00:27:14.490
When this is done,
now we can install Exchange.

578
00:27:14.490 --> 00:27:16.700
If we try to install Exchange
before preparing it,

579
00:27:16.700 --> 00:27:18.190
it would fail, it wouldn't work.

580
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:20.960
Alright so
you've got to prepare your AD first.

581
00:27:20.960 --> 00:27:24.480
Now the newer installers that come with
Exchange 2013 will actually try and

582
00:27:24.480 --> 00:27:26.340
prepare the AD for you.

583
00:27:26.340 --> 00:27:28.070
But you need to be in
the Schema Admins group.

584
00:27:28.070 --> 00:27:31.240
You need to be in the Enterprise Admins
group in order for it to run.

585
00:27:31.240 --> 00:27:34.350
If your environment has divided roles,
that's not gonna work,

586
00:27:34.350 --> 00:27:36.890
and you've gotta run it step by step
like I just did in this episode.

587
00:27:36.890 --> 00:27:38.120
So keep that in mind as you deploy it.

588
00:27:39.370 --> 00:27:41.290
All right,
well that takes care of preparing the AD.

589
00:27:41.290 --> 00:27:44.050
Our next step is to
actually install Exchange.

590
00:27:44.050 --> 00:27:46.710
I'm a little short on time for
this episode so we'll save that for

591
00:27:46.710 --> 00:27:48.660
the next one and we'll wrap up right here.

592
00:27:48.660 --> 00:27:53.400
So in this segment we got a chance to see
getting our Active Directory, our Schema,

593
00:27:53.400 --> 00:27:56.780
getting all of that ready to
deploy Exchange the first time.

594
00:27:56.780 --> 00:27:58.380
Real important steps.

595
00:27:58.380 --> 00:27:59.580
All right, well we'll go ahead and
wrap it up here.

596
00:27:59.580 --> 00:28:01.480
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

597
00:28:01.480 --> 00:28:05.684
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

598
00:28:05.684 --> 00:28:10.397
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates installing Exchange 2013 on a Windows Server 2012 R2 system. He discusses the prerequisites and then walks the viewers through a Mailbox and Client Access server install.
episodes.title: Installing Exchange Server 2013
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.059 --> 00:00:13.539
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.539 --> 00:00:15.230
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.230 --> 00:00:20.340
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Exchange 2013.

5
00:00:20.340 --> 00:00:24.950
In this segment, we're gonna take the
plunge and get Exchange 2013 installed.

6
00:00:24.950 --> 00:00:28.140
We've talked about it in our previous
episodes, all the prep work we have to

7
00:00:28.140 --> 00:00:31.820
do to get ready to install,
now we're ready to pull the trigger.

8
00:00:31.820 --> 00:00:35.000
The installation's pretty straightforward,
but it does ask us a few questions that we

9
00:00:35.000 --> 00:00:39.410
need to be aware of and kinda understand
the repercussions of our decisions, right?

10
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:42.640
So, first off let's just tackle
a couple of prerequisites we need to

11
00:00:42.640 --> 00:00:44.750
meet before we're able to do the install.

12
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:47.250
If you're installing Exchange 2013,

13
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:50.160
first off,
your active directory has to be prepared.

14
00:00:50.160 --> 00:00:53.880
Your schema and your AD have to
be ready to receive Exchange.

15
00:00:53.880 --> 00:00:57.780
So if you haven't already, jump back and
watch our episode on preparing the AD.

16
00:00:57.780 --> 00:01:02.900
Assuming that's done, the server
you're going to install on needs to be

17
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:08.980
Windows Server 2008 with Service Pack 1 or
higher, or Windows Server 2012, all right?

18
00:01:08.980 --> 00:01:10.920
Those are the two supported
operating systems and

19
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:12.470
obviously Microsoft's recommendation.

20
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:14.640
They want you to run it
on Windows Server 2012.

21
00:01:14.640 --> 00:01:18.760
So the server I'm going to
install on is Windows 2012 R2.

22
00:01:18.760 --> 00:01:20.960
You can do it in 2008 if
that's what you've got or

23
00:01:20.960 --> 00:01:21.980
that's what you need to support.

24
00:01:21.980 --> 00:01:23.950
It's up to you how you wanna go about it.

25
00:01:23.950 --> 00:01:24.600
All right,

26
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:28.040
after that there's couple little pieces
of software that we need all right.

27
00:01:28.040 --> 00:01:34.010
You need to have the .NET
framework version 4.5.2 installed.

28
00:01:34.010 --> 00:01:38.690
Now in Windows Server 2012 and Windows
Server 2008 it's not installed by default.

29
00:01:38.690 --> 00:01:42.010
In Server 2008, you can go to Microsoft's
website, and you can download it.

30
00:01:42.010 --> 00:01:44.120
In 2012,
it's actually a feature you can turn on.

31
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:46.430
Let me show you where to
find that on the server.

32
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:47.860
So here I'm on my server.

33
00:01:47.860 --> 00:01:49.710
My server's just called LAB-EXCHSERV01.

34
00:01:49.710 --> 00:01:50.895
It's not actually running.

35
00:01:50.895 --> 00:01:52.145
Exchange yet.

36
00:01:52.145 --> 00:01:54.765
And if I go up here to manage and
add roles and

37
00:01:54.765 --> 00:01:57.025
features, we can move through this wizard.

38
00:01:57.025 --> 00:01:58.535
Now, I don't want to add any roles.

39
00:01:58.535 --> 00:02:01.265
I just want to mess with my features, so
I'm just gonna hit next over and over and

40
00:02:01.265 --> 00:02:04.975
over again until I get to my features
screen, and right here at the top of

41
00:02:04.975 --> 00:02:08.720
features you'll see dot net framework
4.5 you need to install it and

42
00:02:08.720 --> 00:02:12.479
then, you need to do your
Windows updates to get to 4.5.2.

43
00:02:12.479 --> 00:02:13.250
All right.

44
00:02:13.250 --> 00:02:15.240
That's the minimum version.

45
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:17.730
You also need
the Windows Management Framework 4.0.

46
00:02:17.730 --> 00:02:22.430
If you're running Server 2012 R2, you've
already got it, it's part of the system.

47
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:26.220
If you're running Windows Server 2012,
just do your Windows updates.

48
00:02:26.220 --> 00:02:29.010
But if you're running Windows Server 2008,
you're gonna have to go and download it.

49
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:31.880
So, you can go and download it
right from Microsoft's website.

50
00:02:31.880 --> 00:02:33.520
I'll post the links in the show notes.

51
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:36.420
In Server 2008 you have to
download .NET Framework 452 and

52
00:02:36.420 --> 00:02:39.450
you have to download
the Windows Framework 4.0.

53
00:02:39.450 --> 00:02:44.350
You also need the Unified Communications
Framework even if you're not

54
00:02:44.350 --> 00:02:47.700
gonna use the Unified Communications stuff
that service is installed by default and

55
00:02:47.700 --> 00:02:49.470
you've gotta have it installed.

56
00:02:49.470 --> 00:02:51.260
None of the versions of
server come with that.

57
00:02:51.260 --> 00:02:53.422
You're always gonna have to go and
download that one.

58
00:02:53.422 --> 00:02:56.660
All right, now if you're missing any of
these components, when you do the install

59
00:02:56.660 --> 00:03:00.210
it'll check, it'll see they're missing and
it'll give you the links to download them.

60
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:04.990
But what I do, I might install a few
more exchange servers then most people.

61
00:03:04.990 --> 00:03:08.170
But If you find yourself installing a lot,
what I like to do is,

62
00:03:08.170 --> 00:03:11.820
I create a little file
where I store these things,

63
00:03:11.820 --> 00:03:17.000
where I have the .net
framework 4.5.2 right there.

64
00:03:17.000 --> 00:03:20.360
I've got my
Windows Management Framework 4.0 and

65
00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:23.140
I've got the Unified Communications
Framework right there.

66
00:03:23.140 --> 00:03:26.110
So, I just keep them handy, and when
I'm building up a new exchange server,

67
00:03:26.110 --> 00:03:27.260
I can just install those.

68
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:30.300
Now, in 2012,
you don't need the 452 installer, and

69
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:31.860
you don't need the management framework.

70
00:03:31.860 --> 00:03:35.240
You just need the unified communications
but on 2008 you'd need all three.

71
00:03:35.240 --> 00:03:36.800
So you just install those, and you run.

72
00:03:38.490 --> 00:03:40.330
Now when we do the install,

73
00:03:40.330 --> 00:03:45.720
you're gonna have to pick between whether
you're doing a edge transport server,

74
00:03:45.720 --> 00:03:51.870
a client access server, or a mailbox
server or maybe you're doing all three.

75
00:03:51.870 --> 00:03:53.330
Well, there's some services,

76
00:03:53.330 --> 00:03:57.260
some roles that need to be
installed ahead of time, and.

77
00:03:57.260 --> 00:04:00.610
If you go to Microsoft's website, they
give you the list, it's a massive list of

78
00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:03.530
all sorts of different roles and
so it's hard to keep track of.

79
00:04:03.530 --> 00:04:05.970
And this is another one that I
usually keep in a handy file, and

80
00:04:05.970 --> 00:04:09.380
you'll see mine right here,
PowerShell install.

81
00:04:09.380 --> 00:04:13.160
When you install Exchange, there's
certain roles and features you need and

82
00:04:13.160 --> 00:04:15.540
the installer will actually add them for
you.

83
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:18.700
But the problem is it's gonna make
you reboot during the install and

84
00:04:18.700 --> 00:04:20.750
then you kinda gotta continue and
it's really annoying so

85
00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:22.410
it's something I like to do ahead of time.

86
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:24.860
Ahead of time I like to go ahead and
install these roles.

87
00:04:24.860 --> 00:04:28.820
And so I've just kind of created
this power shell script that I run

88
00:04:28.820 --> 00:04:33.470
that has all the different roles and
features I need to have installed.

89
00:04:33.470 --> 00:04:37.340
If it's a client access server or a mail
box server, there's actually quite a few.

90
00:04:37.340 --> 00:04:39.820
This list,
let me turn on word wrap here so

91
00:04:39.820 --> 00:04:41.750
you guys kind of get the full experience.

92
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:42.650
There we go.

93
00:04:42.650 --> 00:04:45.220
It's a lot of different things,
it's hard to keep track of.

94
00:04:45.220 --> 00:04:48.900
And I'll post this with the show notes too
so you guys can have it, just remember,

95
00:04:48.900 --> 00:04:51.300

00:11:07.160 --> 00:11:10.320

00:15:11.010 --> 00:15:12.710
And that's probably
what's going on with me.

324
00:15:12.710 --> 00:15:13.950
So I'm gonna go back here.

325
00:15:13.950 --> 00:15:15.880
And it's not telling me to reboot or
anything,

326
00:15:15.880 --> 00:15:17.800
and I probably don't even need to reboot.

327
00:15:17.800 --> 00:15:21.190
I should just be able to log out and log
back in to refresh my group membership,

328
00:15:21.190 --> 00:15:22.220
and that should take care of that.

329
00:15:22.220 --> 00:15:25.190
So I'll sign out, and
then I'll sign back in.

330
00:15:25.190 --> 00:15:30.040
Just remember, any time you change
Group membership in Active Directory.

331
00:15:30.040 --> 00:15:32.850
You do need to log out and
log back in for them to take effect.

332
00:15:32.850 --> 00:15:34.550
That is more then likely my issue.

333
00:15:35.730 --> 00:15:38.270
So I'll do that, and
I'll just relaunch the installer and

334
00:15:38.270 --> 00:15:39.310
we'll let it do it's check again.

335
00:15:40.405 --> 00:15:41.785
So, I'm just going to fire that back up.

336
00:15:42.985 --> 00:15:44.395
I'm not going to connect to the Internet.

337
00:15:44.395 --> 00:15:45.945
We'll go a little faster this time.

338
00:15:45.945 --> 00:15:48.965
The cached file should already be there,
so that should go quicker.

339
00:15:48.965 --> 00:15:50.225
And then at this point we should pass.

340
00:15:50.225 --> 00:15:53.785
We've got our unified communications
installed and we should be ready to rock.

341
00:15:53.785 --> 00:15:55.015
All right.

342
00:15:55.015 --> 00:15:57.825
Now, I'm going to do
a mailbox server here.

343
00:15:57.825 --> 00:16:00.275
I also want to do a client access server.

344
00:16:00.275 --> 00:16:02.470
I can do the installs at the same time.

345
00:16:02.470 --> 00:16:05.220
So, I could jump over to another server,
like this one.

346
00:16:05.220 --> 00:16:09.700
And if I want to get it set up, well,
first off, I'm gonna log out and

347
00:16:09.700 --> 00:16:13.150
log back on just to be on
the safe side on this one.

348
00:16:13.150 --> 00:16:14.940
But I can start this
install at the same time.

349
00:16:14.940 --> 00:16:17.210
You can be setting up more
than one Exchange Server.

350
00:16:17.210 --> 00:16:20.280
You don't have to wait for one to
finish before you can start the other.

351
00:16:20.280 --> 00:16:23.230
So I'm gonna start up
the install on this guy too, and

352
00:16:23.230 --> 00:16:24.990
we'll get them both up and running.

353
00:16:24.990 --> 00:16:27.860
The only difference is on this one I'm
gonna choose Client Access Server instead

354
00:16:27.860 --> 00:16:30.900
of Mailbox so
that I can get that set up on this one.

355
00:16:30.900 --> 00:16:33.650
And I did already install
the Unified Communication Manager here so

356
00:16:33.650 --> 00:16:34.820
I shouldn't have to worry about that.

357
00:16:34.820 --> 00:16:38.940
All right, so my Mailbox Server is just
gonna churn along there and do its

358
00:16:38.940 --> 00:16:41.980
readiness checks and, sure enough, I'm
seeing a little bit of a different screen.

359
00:16:41.980 --> 00:16:44.130
Now, instead of a list of
errors that I need to correct,

360
00:16:44.130 --> 00:16:47.550
I see Prerequisite analysis 100% install.

361
00:16:47.550 --> 00:16:49.170
I'm good, I've cleared all my errors.

362
00:16:49.170 --> 00:16:50.640
I can start the install.

363
00:16:50.640 --> 00:16:53.730
Now, the installation takes a long time.

364
00:16:53.730 --> 00:16:56.600
It can take like an hour to run,
so I'm gonna let that one churn.

365
00:16:56.600 --> 00:16:59.120
I'm gonna move back over
to my client access server.

366
00:16:59.120 --> 00:17:01.140
This is the one where I want to
install a client access role, and

367
00:17:01.140 --> 00:17:03.030
I'm gonna start it up also.

368
00:17:03.030 --> 00:17:05.720
So I'll go ahead and
move forward with that same installation.

369
00:17:05.720 --> 00:17:07.770
It's gonna do its pre-requisite check.

370
00:17:07.770 --> 00:17:11.300
And then once it's done, it will be
all clear and I can do my install.

371
00:17:11.300 --> 00:17:13.452
So I should see that just flip to 100% and
be done.

372
00:17:13.452 --> 00:17:18.310
All right, now I imagine, much like
myself, you guys probably don't wanna sit

373
00:17:18.310 --> 00:17:21.580
here and watch this little blue bar
slowly creep across the screen.

374
00:17:21.580 --> 00:17:26.110
So, I'm gonna do a TV timeout and jump
ahead into the future after the install is

375
00:17:26.110 --> 00:17:29.490
done, and then we'll verify that Exchange
is up and running and functional.

376
00:17:29.490 --> 00:17:31.010
So, let's take a break.

377
00:17:31.010 --> 00:17:31.990
We'll be right back after this.

378
00:17:31.990 --> 00:17:36.110
All right, so after about an hour
of churning along on that install,

379
00:17:36.110 --> 00:17:37.030
the install is done.

380
00:17:37.030 --> 00:17:40.010
The system reboots, and
now we're up and running.

381
00:17:40.010 --> 00:17:42.670
So the last thing we need to do
is to verify that Exchange is

382
00:17:42.670 --> 00:17:43.910
installed and happy.

383
00:17:43.910 --> 00:17:47.090
And there's really just two simple ways
that we can test this before we dive

384
00:17:47.090 --> 00:17:48.930
into any crazy configuration.

385
00:17:48.930 --> 00:17:52.180
The first thing,
is to check the services on your computer.

386
00:17:52.180 --> 00:17:55.340
When Exchange installed,
whether you pick client access or mailbox,

387
00:17:55.340 --> 00:17:57.900
it installs different services,
they should be up and running.

388
00:17:57.900 --> 00:18:02.230
So I'm gonna take my server here, and I'll
just jump under my Server Manager, and

389
00:18:02.230 --> 00:18:05.080
I'll go to Tools and Services.

390
00:18:05.080 --> 00:18:09.260
And in my Services screen, I should start
to see some Microsoft Exchange services.

391
00:18:09.260 --> 00:18:12.820
And so if I kinda drill down a bit here,
we'll find them in the list.

392
00:18:12.820 --> 00:18:18.040
So here I see the Active Directory
topology, diagnostics, IMAP 4 and POP 3.

393
00:18:18.040 --> 00:18:20.060
That's because this is
a client access server.

394
00:18:20.060 --> 00:18:21.880
Your mailbox server won't have those.

395
00:18:21.880 --> 00:18:25.900
And so I see each of those, there's that
unified messaging connector and so on.

396
00:18:25.900 --> 00:18:28.690
I start to see the different
things that were installed.

397
00:18:28.690 --> 00:18:31.750
There's front end transport,
I mentioned those in another episode.

398
00:18:31.750 --> 00:18:35.680
So I see them, and I see that some of
them are running, some of them aren't.

399
00:18:35.680 --> 00:18:38.310
I notice that IMAP 4 and
POP 3 are disabled by default.

400
00:18:38.310 --> 00:18:41.990
They're set to manually start, so
I don't expect to see those running.

401
00:18:41.990 --> 00:18:43.670
But all these ones that say Automatic,

402
00:18:43.670 --> 00:18:45.840
those are the ones that we
wanna see up and running.

403
00:18:45.840 --> 00:18:48.800
And that let's us know that this server,
at a minimum, at least,

404
00:18:48.800 --> 00:18:49.900
thinks it's an Exchange Server.

405
00:18:51.350 --> 00:18:52.990
How do we know it's actually working?

406
00:18:52.990 --> 00:18:55.320
Well, we can jump into
our management console.

407
00:18:55.320 --> 00:18:58.240
Now in previous versions of exchange
we had the actual exchange management

408
00:18:58.240 --> 00:19:01.750
console, a software program that we ran,
and it was nightmarishly slow, and

409
00:19:01.750 --> 00:19:02.770
I always hated it.

410
00:19:02.770 --> 00:19:06.340
Well, now we have our web interface for
management.

411
00:19:06.340 --> 00:19:08.590
So we can jump over to any
client in our network.

412
00:19:08.590 --> 00:19:12.280
I'll take this Windows 7 machine, and
we can browse to our management console.

413
00:19:12.280 --> 00:19:15.900
So I'm gonna fire this up, I'm gonna
ignore my Windows updates there, and

414
00:19:15.900 --> 00:19:18.230
I will browse to one of my servers.

415
00:19:18.230 --> 00:19:20.440
Now, I need to browse to
a client access server.

416
00:19:20.440 --> 00:19:23.650
The management panel's actually not
installed on a mailbox server, so

417
00:19:23.650 --> 00:19:26.940
I can't just browse to that.

418
00:19:26.940 --> 00:19:31.110
So I'll browse to https:// and
then I'll pick a client access server.

419
00:19:31.110 --> 00:19:32.900
And you know, now that I think about it,

420
00:19:32.900 --> 00:19:35.650
I can't remember which one
was my client access server.

421
00:19:35.650 --> 00:19:37.520
Let's see, it's server number two.

422
00:19:37.520 --> 00:19:43.440
So I'm gonna browse to server number two,
/ecp.

423
00:19:43.440 --> 00:19:47.970
All right, now, in previous versions of
Exchange like Exchange 2010, ECP stood for

424
00:19:47.970 --> 00:19:49.690
the Exchange Control Panel.

425
00:19:49.690 --> 00:19:53.340
And it used to be just for regular
users to be able to get in there and

426
00:19:53.340 --> 00:19:56.300
manage themselves, and then for
administrators you had some basic queue

427
00:19:56.300 --> 00:19:58.720
management you could do in there,
and that was it.

428
00:19:58.720 --> 00:20:02.970
In Exchange 2013, the ECP is now
a full featured management suite for

429
00:20:02.970 --> 00:20:04.500
the entire Exchange environment.

430
00:20:04.500 --> 00:20:07.140
It replaces the old Exchange
management console.

431
00:20:07.140 --> 00:20:08.500
So we don't need that software anymore,

432
00:20:08.500 --> 00:20:11.100
now we just have a webpage
that we browse to.

433
00:20:11.100 --> 00:20:14.680
Now, by default when you install it's
gonna do a self signed certificate, so

434
00:20:14.680 --> 00:20:16.960
expect to get a certificate
warning like this.

435
00:20:16.960 --> 00:20:18.460
We can swap that certificate out later.

436
00:20:18.460 --> 00:20:20.260
We'll see that in another episode.

437
00:20:20.260 --> 00:20:22.610
But for right now I'm gonna
continue onto the website,

438
00:20:22.610 --> 00:20:26.210
even though it's not recommended, and it's
gonna browse to it and give me the site.

439
00:20:26.210 --> 00:20:29.430
Now, if I'm browsing to a mailbox server

440
00:20:29.430 --> 00:20:34.070
I'll probably get some kind of 500
error or 404, saying page not found,

441
00:20:34.070 --> 00:20:37.510
and that's because the mailbox server
doesn't have the exchange control panel.

442
00:20:37.510 --> 00:20:40.850
But when I go to a client access
server I should see this.

443
00:20:40.850 --> 00:20:45.450
I'm in the Exchange Admin Center, and
I can log in with my admin account.

444
00:20:45.450 --> 00:20:47.700
So I'm gonna log in with that.

445
00:20:47.700 --> 00:20:50.500
And in the example here,
it gives you domain/username.

446
00:20:50.500 --> 00:20:52.160
That's the old net bios name.

447
00:20:52.160 --> 00:20:56.220
You can user the newer, fully qualified
domain name format if you want it,

448
00:20:56.220 --> 00:20:57.380
it's up to you.

449
00:20:57.380 --> 00:20:58.780
And I can get logged in.

450
00:20:58.780 --> 00:21:03.050
Now, just the fact that I even saw this
screen is letting me know that my client

451
00:21:03.050 --> 00:21:05.180
access server's web interface is working.

452
00:21:05.180 --> 00:21:06.930
So I've already verified part of it.

453
00:21:06.930 --> 00:21:09.930
But what I really want to do is get in and
see my organization, and

454
00:21:09.930 --> 00:21:12.430
see the servers inside
of that organization.

455
00:21:12.430 --> 00:21:16.230
So, when I get logged in here, it's going
to start to show here's some recipients,

456
00:21:16.230 --> 00:21:18.000
I've got one mailbox for me.

457
00:21:18.000 --> 00:21:19.780
I get a mailbox, it's exciting.

458
00:21:19.780 --> 00:21:22.470
And I can start to work with my groups and
resources, and so on.

459
00:21:22.470 --> 00:21:23.780
So I start to see that.

460
00:21:23.780 --> 00:21:24.730
But over here on the left,

461
00:21:24.730 --> 00:21:28.110
what I really want to see is
right down here under servers.

462
00:21:28.110 --> 00:21:31.860
I can jump down to servers, and I'll see
all the servers in my organization and

463
00:21:31.860 --> 00:21:34.940
I expect to see Lab Exchange server 01 and
02.

464
00:21:34.940 --> 00:21:38.780
There's my mailbox and
client access servers that I brought up.

465
00:21:38.780 --> 00:21:41.640
If I was running both roles on
the same server it would say mailbox,

466
00:21:41.640 --> 00:21:43.560
client access server, you have both.

467
00:21:43.560 --> 00:21:46.960
But in this case I see my separate server,
so they're up and running.

468
00:21:46.960 --> 00:21:51.180
And from here I can go and verify other
things like the databases, right?

469
00:21:51.180 --> 00:21:53.360
So here's my Mailbox Database
on Exchange Server 01.

470
00:21:53.360 --> 00:21:56.910
We could also look at other
things like Virtual Directories,

471
00:21:56.910 --> 00:21:59.420
which will be things
like the Outlook Web App.

472
00:21:59.420 --> 00:22:02.390
So I can find those in here, or
the Exchange control panel, and

473
00:22:02.390 --> 00:22:06.570
see how the Exchange control panel is
running on server 02, not server 01.

474
00:22:06.570 --> 00:22:09.600
Right, the mailbox database is
not included in any of those.

475
00:22:09.600 --> 00:22:12.930
So right here I can verify that,
looking at the active directory,

476
00:22:12.930 --> 00:22:13.794
looking at the servers,

477
00:22:13.794 --> 00:22:17.650
I'm seeing all the information,
my Exchange organization is up.

478
00:22:17.650 --> 00:22:20.050
Now it's up to me to go and
configure it and

479
00:22:20.050 --> 00:22:21.870
customize it to meet
the needs of my organization.

480
00:22:21.870 --> 00:22:23.980
And that's where things start
to get different, right?

481
00:22:23.980 --> 00:22:27.510
The installed steps that I just did,
everybody's gonna do those.

482
00:22:27.510 --> 00:22:30.360
But what you configure from here on out,
is gonna be based on

483
00:22:30.360 --> 00:22:33.260
a series of decisions built around
your company, and what your needs are.

484
00:22:33.260 --> 00:22:35.100
So things do start to get
a little bit different.

485
00:22:35.100 --> 00:22:39.550
But from right here we can start to
see that basic view of our system,

486
00:22:39.550 --> 00:22:43.817
what we're gonna be working with, how we
make sure that we are up and running and

487
00:22:43.817 --> 00:22:47.530
happy, and that we've now got Exchange
installed and we're ready to work with it.

488
00:22:47.530 --> 00:22:49.800
Now if you've worked with Office 365 or

489
00:22:49.800 --> 00:22:52.950
Azure Hosted Exchange,
this might look familiar.

490
00:22:52.950 --> 00:22:56.340
Because this is the same management
tool that you use in Azure.

491
00:22:56.340 --> 00:22:57.680
So if you learn how to
do this in Exchange,

492
00:22:57.680 --> 00:22:59.510
you know how to do it in Azure also.

493
00:22:59.510 --> 00:23:01.990
Or Office 365.
Or if you learned it in Office 365,

494
00:23:01.990 --> 00:23:03.170
you know how to do it here.

495
00:23:03.170 --> 00:23:06.990
Microsoft made it the same to make it easy
to transition from one to the other, or

496
00:23:06.990 --> 00:23:08.410
run both in tandem.

497
00:23:08.410 --> 00:23:09.710
You can have them connected.

498
00:23:09.710 --> 00:23:12.180
It's really neat to have those
solutions that are out there.

499
