00:23:12.180 --> 00:23:15.530
But at this point,
Exchange is installed, it's up,

500
00:23:15.530 --> 00:23:18.220
it's running, now we got an email server.

501
00:23:18.220 --> 00:23:19.690
Done that easy.

502
00:23:19.690 --> 00:23:21.950
Now, I do wanna remind you that
it happened pretty fast here, but

503
00:23:21.950 --> 00:23:25.840
in real-life land, I'm not joking when I
say that install can take about an hour.

504
00:23:25.840 --> 00:23:28.730
It takes a long time to get all
the different things set up,

505
00:23:28.730 --> 00:23:30.840
to provision the database space,
and all that.

506
00:23:30.840 --> 00:23:32.340
It takes a while.

507
00:23:32.340 --> 00:23:34.370
The better your hardware,
the faster it'll happen.

508
00:23:34.370 --> 00:23:40.270
But I'm on a quad-core Intel
i7 with a SSD storage here,

509
00:23:40.270 --> 00:23:41.810
and it takes my system about an hour.

510
00:23:41.810 --> 00:23:43.980
So, it does take a long
time to do the install.

511
00:23:43.980 --> 00:23:46.622
Just be prepared for that, and
don't be surprised when that happens.

512
00:23:46.622 --> 00:23:52.030
All right, well, in this episode we got
a chance to see installing Exchange,

513
00:23:52.030 --> 00:23:54.390
we did a client access server and
a mailbox server.

514
00:23:54.390 --> 00:23:55.860
We didn't do edge transport,

515
00:23:55.860 --> 00:23:58.540
I'm gonna cover that in
a special episode down the road.

516
00:23:58.540 --> 00:24:01.670
But we gotta chance to see how to get
our organization up and running, and

517
00:24:01.670 --> 00:24:05.090
get a fully featured exchange
organization in place.

518
00:24:05.090 --> 00:24:06.160
Definitely stay tuned, though.

519
00:24:06.160 --> 00:24:08.720
On all of our other episodes,
we're gonna see how we can tweak this and

520
00:24:08.720 --> 00:24:10.800
customize it and
really get it to work for us.

521
00:24:10.800 --> 00:24:13.090
But as far as getting a basic
install done, that's it.

522
00:24:13.090 --> 00:24:16.360
All right, well, this is a pretty
good spot for us to wrap this one up.

523
00:24:16.360 --> 00:24:17.780
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

524
00:24:17.780 --> 00:24:21.387
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

525
00:24:21.387 --> 00:24:27.220
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Don introduces the viewers to the Exchange 2013 mailbox database. He discusses the files that makeup a mailbox database and walks us through how to create our own databases.
episodes.title: Mailbox Databases
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.532
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.532 --> 00:00:13.215
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

3
00:00:13.215 --> 00:00:15.111
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.111 --> 00:00:20.410
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Exchange 2013.

5
00:00:20.410 --> 00:00:23.390
Today's episode is pretty important,
because we're going to be taking a look

6
00:00:23.390 --> 00:00:26.680
at the mailbox database role,
or the mailbox role.

7
00:00:26.680 --> 00:00:31.090
When we set up Exchange, one of the key
functions of it is to be an email server,

8
00:00:31.090 --> 00:00:33.550
and we've got to store
that email somewhere.

9
00:00:33.550 --> 00:00:37.340
So one of the critical roles we have in
Exchange 2013, is called the mail box

10
00:00:37.340 --> 00:00:41.130
server role, and that's the server
that holds all your email.

11
00:00:41.130 --> 00:00:42.000
So let's take a look at that.

12
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:44.800
We're gonna see where the email get
stored, how it kind of moves around, and

13
00:00:44.800 --> 00:00:48.355
some of the considerations we have
to have with that information.

14
00:00:48.355 --> 00:00:49.985
Now I got on my machine right here,

15
00:00:49.985 --> 00:00:52.895
just a base install exchange,
I haven't tweaked it much.

16
00:00:52.895 --> 00:00:53.995
I have two servers.

17
00:00:53.995 --> 00:00:58.805
I've got a mail box server, and
I've got a Client Access Server,

18
00:00:58.805 --> 00:01:00.295
so two separate systems.

19
00:01:00.295 --> 00:01:02.235
You could run them together if you wanted.

20
00:01:02.235 --> 00:01:05.600
I've chosen to run them separate,
and we normally do that for scale.

21
00:01:05.600 --> 00:01:08.640
But when you bring up your
first mailbox server,

22
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:11.900
one of the things it does is
it creates a mailbox database.

23
00:01:11.900 --> 00:01:13.630
And if you're a small organization,

24
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:16.350
then default mailbox database
might be fine for you.

25
00:01:16.350 --> 00:01:19.390
But most people are gonna find
that they do have to tweak it and

26
00:01:19.390 --> 00:01:20.980
change it a little bit.

27
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:23.420
Now if I browse here,
I'm in my Exchange admin center, and

28
00:01:23.420 --> 00:01:26.980
I'm just gonna go down to Servers, and
I'll see my servers that are right here.

29
00:01:26.980 --> 00:01:30.730
And you can see that Lab Exchange Server
1 is my mailbox server, and

30
00:01:30.730 --> 00:01:33.130
then I've got a client access one, also.

31
00:01:33.130 --> 00:01:35.850
Well, if I go over here to Databases,

32
00:01:35.850 --> 00:01:38.840
I'm gonna see a list of
the mailbox databases that I have.

33
00:01:38.840 --> 00:01:40.040
And I've got this one right here.

34
00:01:40.040 --> 00:01:41.975
It's got a nice, easy to remember name.

35
00:01:41.975 --> 00:01:44.120
[LAUGH] If you go with the default.

36
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:45.800
You're going to have a name like this.

37
00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:47.370
Mailbox Database 2013076320, right?

38
00:01:47.370 --> 00:01:50.330
It probably won't match that, right?

39
00:01:50.330 --> 00:01:53.060
But it'll be something similar.

40
00:01:53.060 --> 00:01:56.250
This is the default mailbox database.

41
00:01:56.250 --> 00:01:58.680
If you create your own mailbox database,
you can call it whatever you want, but

42
00:01:58.680 --> 00:01:59.900
the default gets this name.

43
00:01:59.900 --> 00:02:02.140
Now, why the weird name?

44
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:06.080
Well, what we'll see in some later
episodes is that if you wanna do high

45
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:09.930
availability, if you wanna maintain
multiple copies of that database for

46
00:02:09.930 --> 00:02:11.350
redundancy sake,

47
00:02:11.350 --> 00:02:15.500
your mailbox database has to have
a unique name across your entire forest.

48
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:18.100
And so that's why it sticks all
these numbers at the end of it.

49
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:19.680
That's why it's not just mailbox database,

50
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:25.400
it's Mailbox database 2013076320
to try and create that uniqueness.

51
00:02:25.400 --> 00:02:26.240
All right.
So

52
00:02:26.240 --> 00:02:28.280
expect to see a kind of
a weird name like that.

53
00:02:28.280 --> 00:02:30.220
But that's why it has that name.

54
00:02:30.220 --> 00:02:32.640
Now this just looks like
a single entry right here.

55
00:02:32.640 --> 00:02:34.530
I see I've got a mailbox database.

56
00:02:34.530 --> 00:02:37.290
And if I click on it,
I can see some basic information.

57
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:39.620
I can see the servers
that it's running on.

58
00:02:39.620 --> 00:02:42.270
And notice that I can
have more than one copy.

59
00:02:42.270 --> 00:02:46.890
By default your mailbox data base runs
on one server and your users, you'll

60
00:02:46.890 --> 00:02:50.240
create mailboxes for them, and they'll
be in this mailbox data base right here.

61
00:02:50.240 --> 00:02:51.920
It's the default.

62
00:02:51.920 --> 00:02:55.150
Well, what happens if this mail
box data base goes offline?

63
00:02:55.150 --> 00:02:56.550
We cant get to our email, right?

64
00:02:56.550 --> 00:03:00.620
We're not necessarily losing email,
because remember email comes in

65
00:03:00.620 --> 00:03:05.360
through your client access servers, so
the email comes in there and gets stuck.

66
00:03:05.360 --> 00:03:08.940
It kind of gets stuck while it waits
to make it to your mailbox server.

67
00:03:08.940 --> 00:03:12.040
If your hub transport role is at least
running, it will at least get to that.

68
00:03:12.040 --> 00:03:13.730
I shouldn't say role,
it isn't a role anymore.

69
00:03:13.730 --> 00:03:15.210
Your hub transport service.

70
00:03:15.210 --> 00:03:17.680
If that's running,
it'll actually get queued there and

71
00:03:17.680 --> 00:03:20.730
wait even if your
Mailbox Database is offline.

72
00:03:20.730 --> 00:03:22.980
But if your entire
infrastructure is offline,

73
00:03:22.980 --> 00:03:25.160
then you do kinda start to
lose email at that point.

74
00:03:25.160 --> 00:03:30.225
But here, I can see my Mailbox Database Is
up, incoming email can flow into it.

75
00:03:30.225 --> 00:03:33.035
My users can check their email,
and they can access it, right.

76
00:03:33.035 --> 00:03:36.965
I know it's up and healthy because I
see right here, status mounted, right?

77
00:03:36.965 --> 00:03:39.875
That status of mounted, you're
usually gonna see one of two things,

78
00:03:39.875 --> 00:03:41.195
mounted or unmounted.

79
00:03:41.195 --> 00:03:45.110
Mounted means it's online,
it's active and you can look inside it.

80
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:49.440
Unmounted means the files exist, but
you can't access them right now.

81
00:03:49.440 --> 00:03:51.350
It's kind of like the data
base is turned off.

82
00:03:51.350 --> 00:03:53.410
We might unmount the data
base to do maintenance on it,

83
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:56.800
and we'll talk about that a little
bit later in the episode, but for

84
00:03:56.800 --> 00:03:59.950
the most part we expect to see it's
mounted and up and running, all right?

85
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:02.280
Now, I don't have any
copies of this data base.

86
00:04:02.280 --> 00:04:03.480
I just have my one copy.

87
00:04:03.480 --> 00:04:04.310
If I had more than one,

88
00:04:04.310 --> 00:04:08.230
I'd see more than one server name right
here, letting me know I had a copy.

89
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:10.480
We're talk about availability
more in other episodes, but

90
00:04:10.480 --> 00:04:12.060
just to mention it here real quick.

91
00:04:12.060 --> 00:04:16.540
There's two great ways to make your
databases redundant in Exchange.

92
00:04:16.540 --> 00:04:18.430
One way is do a database copy, right?

93
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:21.340
A database copy is basically
a full clone of your

94
00:04:21.340 --> 00:04:24.110
mailbox database that's
stored on a separate server.

95
00:04:24.110 --> 00:04:27.230
The cool thing about that is the server,
it could be right next to the server,

96
00:04:27.230 --> 00:04:29.890
it could be in another building, it could
be in another city, it could be in another

97
00:04:29.890 --> 00:04:33.420
country, but it's an identical
copy of your mailbox database.

98
00:04:33.420 --> 00:04:37.730
So if this mailbox database server fails,
I can redirect everybody to the other one,

99
00:04:37.730 --> 00:04:40.220
and they'll have access
to their information.

100
00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:41.830
And that redirect can
happen automatically.

101
00:04:41.830 --> 00:04:43.550
The end users might not even notice that.

102
00:04:43.550 --> 00:04:46.590
If they're using like the Outlook client,
it'll fail over and jump right over to

103
00:04:46.590 --> 00:04:50.260
the other system, and in business,
they don't even know the failure happened.

104
00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:53.330
It might be a little slower, depending
how far away that other server is, but

105
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:54.920
otherwise it's seamless to them.

106
00:04:54.920 --> 00:04:56.700
So, that's a really cool
way to handle that, and

107
00:04:56.700 --> 00:04:58.720
that's just called a database copy.

108
00:04:58.720 --> 00:04:59.980
There is another option.

109
00:04:59.980 --> 00:05:03.020
You'll see up here,
database availability groups.

110
00:05:03.020 --> 00:05:07.840
A database availability group,
Is where we take the mailbox database, and

111
00:05:07.840 --> 00:05:11.710
we store it on a Microsoft Windows
failover cluster.

112
00:05:11.710 --> 00:05:15.810
If you have a failover cluster set up,
multiple servers with shared storage,

113
00:05:15.810 --> 00:05:18.720
your database can be part
of that shared storage, and

114
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:21.230
it can flip between
multiple physical systems.

115
00:05:21.230 --> 00:05:25.140
That gives you a lot of redundancy,
but it requires a lot of hardware.

116
00:05:25.140 --> 00:05:27.800
If you're in an Enterprise environment
you've probably got the hardware for

117
00:05:27.800 --> 00:05:30.370
that or at least the budget for
that and you can do it.

118
00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:34.050
But if you're in a small or medium
business, clusters get to be expensive, so

119
00:05:34.050 --> 00:05:35.790
you might not have that
infrastructure in place, or

120
00:05:35.790 --> 00:05:38.160
you might not just want to
deal with the complexity.

121
00:05:38.160 --> 00:05:40.300
And those database
copies are a lot easier.

122
00:05:40.300 --> 00:05:42.330
So those are two solutions for
making it redundant, and

123
00:05:42.330 --> 00:05:44.580
that's what we kind of see
here when we look at these.

124
00:05:44.580 --> 00:05:46.830
I can see I've got a bad
copy count of zero.

125
00:05:46.830 --> 00:05:49.470
I don't have any copies, so
none of them can be bad.

126
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:50.770
I'll have a zero there.

127
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:51.490
All right.

128
00:05:51.490 --> 00:05:54.270
Now, I didn't make this mailbox database.

129
00:05:54.270 --> 00:05:55.800
Exchange made it for me.

130
00:05:55.800 --> 00:05:57.430
But I can make my own if I want.

131
00:05:57.430 --> 00:05:58.660
You got a little plus sign up here.

132
00:05:58.660 --> 00:06:01.740
You can hit it and you can start
to create more mailbox databases.

133
00:06:01.740 --> 00:06:05.870
Now why would I want to have
more than one mailbox database?

134
00:06:05.870 --> 00:06:09.560
The reason is, we can actually put some
different settings on there that dictate

135
00:06:09.560 --> 00:06:14.580
restrictions, limits, behaviors that apply
to users in one database versus another.

136
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:19.100
When you create a new user mailbox,
you can pick the database that it goes to.

137
00:06:19.100 --> 00:06:22.440
So I might have one database setup for
my executives, and

138
00:06:22.440 --> 00:06:25.370
the executives are allowed to have
mailboxes with unlimited size.

139
00:06:25.370 --> 00:06:27.490
They can have as much emails as they want.

140
00:06:27.490 --> 00:06:30.920
But I have another mailbox that I use for
my contractors, and

141
00:06:30.920 --> 00:06:34.810
I hold my contractors to 1 gig
of mail in each mailbox right.

142
00:06:34.810 --> 00:06:36.020
I have a limit on them.

143
00:06:36.020 --> 00:06:39.400
So we can impose these pretty easily,
through mailbox databases.

144
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:41.820
I might also do this for
performance issues.

145
00:06:41.820 --> 00:06:44.831
I might want to split my
mailboxes up 50/50, so

146
00:06:44.831 --> 00:06:48.790
that some are 1 ray to ray and
the others are on another ray to ray.

147
00:06:48.790 --> 00:06:50.640
It's all one physical server.

148
00:06:50.640 --> 00:06:55.050
But I have multiple that I'm bouncing
across to help eliminate disk contention.

149
00:06:55.050 --> 00:06:57.120
These mailbox databases,
they're databases.

150
00:06:57.120 --> 00:07:01.160
You do a lot of reads off of there and
you do get disk contention, where multiple

151
00:07:01.160 --> 00:07:04.210
users are trying to access data at
the same time, and they have to queue up.

152
00:07:04.210 --> 00:07:05.460
They have to form a line.

153
00:07:05.460 --> 00:07:07.460
So you might have to
wait to get to your data,

154
00:07:07.460 --> 00:07:11.360
while somebody is getting their data
first, and we don't want that to happen.

155
00:07:11.360 --> 00:07:14.540
Dividing our mailbox databases
up can help with that.

156
00:07:14.540 --> 00:07:17.000
Now, in the standard
version of Exchange 2013,

157
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:19.990
I can create up to five
mailbox databases per server.

158
00:07:21.240 --> 00:07:24.840
If I need more than five,
I've got to go to the Enterprise edition.

159
00:07:24.840 --> 00:07:26.090
With service pack one,

160
00:07:26.090 --> 00:07:29.370
you can have up to 100 mailbox
databases on the Enterprise edition.

161
00:07:29.370 --> 00:07:30.250
But I'm gonna create one.

162
00:07:30.250 --> 00:07:33.100
Maybe I want to separate
all my salespeople.

163
00:07:33.100 --> 00:07:37.210
I want my salespeople to be in a separate
mailbox database for various reasons.

164
00:07:37.210 --> 00:07:40.020
So I'm gonna create a database
here called Sales, and

165
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:42.950
I can choose what server it resides on.

166
00:07:42.950 --> 00:07:45.990
Now, I've only got one mailbox server,
so it's not a big deal for me.

167
00:07:45.990 --> 00:07:48.590
But if I had more than one mailbox server,
I could browse.

168
00:07:48.590 --> 00:07:50.610
And pick the one where
it's gonna reside on.

169
00:07:50.610 --> 00:07:51.560
I'll just pick the one that I've got.

170
00:07:53.140 --> 00:07:53.840
All right.

171
00:07:53.840 --> 00:07:55.980
And then we've got our database path.

172
00:07:55.980 --> 00:07:59.084
This is where the database files
are actually gonna be stored.

173
00:07:59.084 --> 00:08:00.822
And it's telling me about two things.

174
00:08:00.822 --> 00:08:04.574
This first one is the database itself,
and so

175
00:08:04.574 --> 00:08:09.412
I'll see this long path here
that it's laying out for me,

176
00:08:09.412 --> 00:08:13.083
and at the very end, I'll see Sales.edb.

177
00:08:13.083 --> 00:08:15.486
That edb, that stands for
Exchange Database,

178
00:08:15.486 --> 00:08:17.950
that's the mailbox database file.

179
00:08:17.950 --> 00:08:20.380
So, if I were to browse on
the hard drive and find that file,

180
00:08:20.380 --> 00:08:22.499
that's where my email is
actually being stored.

181
00:08:23.630 --> 00:08:27.960
Then it has a log folder path and
if I look at the end of that one.

182
00:08:27.960 --> 00:08:32.060
If I kinda scroll over it doesn't
have a file name at all and

183
00:08:32.060 --> 00:08:35.420
that's because what it's referring
to are called transaction logs.

184
00:08:36.430 --> 00:08:38.755
And you're not gonna
have 1 transaction log,

185
00:08:38.755 --> 00:08:42.781
you're gonna have many transaction logs,
at a minimum you're gonna have 11.

186
00:08:42.781 --> 00:08:45.941
You'll probably have 100, 1,000.

187
00:08:45.941 --> 00:08:48.247
You can have a ton of
transaction log files, and

188
00:08:48.247 --> 00:08:50.940
I'll explain what those
do here in a few minutes.

189
00:08:50.940 --> 00:08:53.580
But that's why it's just a path,
it doesn't let us pick the file name.

190
00:08:53.580 --> 00:08:57.640
It's just saying this is the folder where
we're gonna store those transaction logs.

191
00:08:57.640 --> 00:08:59.700
And then I've got the option
to mount the database,

192
00:08:59.700 --> 00:09:01.940
which is what's actually
gonna bring it online.

193
00:09:01.940 --> 00:09:05.650
So when I hit Save,
It's gonna create that sales database and

194
00:09:05.650 --> 00:09:07.370
it's gonna bring it online.

195
00:09:07.370 --> 00:09:10.570
Now, it's empty, it doesn't have any
mailboxes in there, but from now on,

196
00:09:10.570 --> 00:09:15.870
when I create mailboxes, I can choose to
put them in the sales mailbox database or

197
00:09:15.870 --> 00:09:18.110
I could take existing mailboxes and
I can move them.

198
00:09:18.110 --> 00:09:21.780
You can do a mailbox move request, and
that'll move the mailboxes over to this

199
00:09:21.780 --> 00:09:24.900
one, so I can move them back and forth,
and you can do it while people are online.

200
00:09:24.900 --> 00:09:26.100
It's actually pretty slick.

201
00:09:26.100 --> 00:09:29.750
When you move a mailbox,
it's copying their mailbox, but

202
00:09:29.750 --> 00:09:34.380
leaving the original, and it gets them
both in full synchronization, and

203
00:09:34.380 --> 00:09:36.815
then it just removes the old one.

204
00:09:36.815 --> 00:09:41.150
So you've got a full copy of the mailbox
at all times, and the Outlook client,

205
00:09:41.150 --> 00:09:44.870
Outlook Web access, all the various
other ways of getting into your mail,

206
00:09:44.870 --> 00:09:47.300
are aware of that and
will jump to the other server.

207
00:09:47.300 --> 00:09:49.020
The end users don't even
know that that happens.

208
00:09:49.020 --> 00:09:49.870
It's pretty neat stuff.

209
00:09:52.250 --> 00:09:55.010
All right, so I just added the mailbox
database, and you'll see I got a little

210
00:09:55.010 --> 00:09:59.050
warning here that says I need to restart
the Microsoft Exchange Information Store

211
00:09:59.050 --> 00:10:02.040
service on that server after
adding a new mailbox database so

212
00:10:02.040 --> 00:10:03.160
that it can recognize it.

213
00:10:03.160 --> 00:10:04.810
I'm gonna go ahead and say okay to that.

214
00:10:04.810 --> 00:10:08.230
So I've got my database, it's up and
it's showing as mounted.

215
00:10:08.230 --> 00:10:12.640
Now how is it mounted, but it told
me I needed to restart the service?

216
00:10:12.640 --> 00:10:14.980
Why do I need to restart the service?

217
00:10:14.980 --> 00:10:17.651
Well it's actually mounted,
it's online and it's working right now.

218
00:10:17.651 --> 00:10:21.469
I don't have to restart the service,
but there's certain things like

219
00:10:21.469 --> 00:10:25.923
database indexes that get build when you
restart the service, and so at my earliest

220
00:10:25.923 --> 00:10:29.631
convenience I need to go and
restart that service when I get a chance.

221
00:10:29.631 --> 00:10:34.216
Now if I restart that service every
mailbox database that's on that

222
00:10:34.216 --> 00:10:38.239
server is going to get unmounted and
then re-mounted, and

223
00:10:38.239 --> 00:10:41.391
that's gonna cause a service interruption.

224
00:10:41.391 --> 00:10:44.591
If I have copies of the database or
if I'm in a database availability group,

225
00:10:44.591 --> 00:10:47.041
it's no big deal, but
if I've only got one copy like I do,

226
00:10:47.041 --> 00:10:48.991
that is gonna create
a service interruption.

227
00:10:48.991 --> 00:10:53.057
So I don't wanna do it right now if users
are in the system, I wanna wait and

228
00:10:53.057 --> 00:10:55.560
do it later when users
aren't in the system.

229
00:10:55.560 --> 00:10:58.620
All right, but now I've got my
different mailbox databases.

230
00:10:58.620 --> 00:11:01.920
Now I have to be careful,
because my mailbox database,

231
00:11:01.920 --> 00:11:04.640
I didn't give it a crazy
name like the default.

232
00:11:04.640 --> 00:11:07.910
The default has those extra numbers
attached to the end of it to make it

233
00:11:07.910 --> 00:11:09.170
unique, mine doesn't.

234
00:11:09.170 --> 00:11:11.740
So if I'm gonna be doing
database copies and

235
00:11:11.740 --> 00:11:14.630
database availability groups,
I need to make sure from now on,

236
00:11:14.630 --> 00:11:18.360
on all of my mailbox servers,
I don't use the name Sales again.

237
00:11:18.360 --> 00:11:21.270
So we want it to be a little bit specific
with that name and make sure that we don't

238
00:11:21.270 --> 00:11:24.379
get duplicates, and
that's throughout the whole organization.

239
00:11:26.670 --> 00:11:28.450
Once I've got a mailbox database created,

240
00:11:28.450 --> 00:11:31.920
it's actually built several
files to store that database in.

241
00:11:31.920 --> 00:11:33.440
Let's take a look at those files.

242
00:11:33.440 --> 00:11:36.530
I'm gonna switch over to that server,
which is that guy right here,

243
00:11:36.530 --> 00:11:38.960
and i'm just gonna browse
on the hard drive, and

244
00:11:38.960 --> 00:11:41.530
we'll browse into where all
those files are stored.

245
00:11:43.800 --> 00:11:50.950
They're buried away in
C:/programfiles/Microsoft/exchangeserver/-

246
00:11:50.950 --> 00:11:56.000
version15, that's Exchange 2013, /mailbox.

247
00:11:57.130 --> 00:12:00.560
In there you're going to see folders for
your mailbox databases.

248
00:12:00.560 --> 00:12:05.630
So I can see mailbox database 2013076320,
rolls right off the tongue,

249
00:12:05.630 --> 00:12:07.625
and I'll see the database sales.

250
00:12:07.625 --> 00:12:11.100
So I see those databases right there,
and if I browse into it,

251
00:12:11.100 --> 00:12:13.920
like I'll take my sales database,
I see a lot of files.

252
00:12:15.340 --> 00:12:17.730
All of these files are important.

253
00:12:17.730 --> 00:12:19.830
If you delete one of these
files you will regret it.?

254
00:12:19.830 --> 00:12:21.880
[LAUGH] All of these are important files.

255
00:12:21.880 --> 00:12:23.540
They each serve a purpose.

256
00:12:23.540 --> 00:12:27.450
The most important one is this
guy right here, Sales.edb.

257
00:12:27.450 --> 00:12:29.820
That's my Exchange database,
that's really important to me.

258
00:12:29.820 --> 00:12:35.170
I don't have any mailboxes in here, but
notice that it's already 253 megs in size.

259
00:12:35.170 --> 00:12:37.527
That's because it's got some
default information and

260
00:12:37.527 --> 00:12:41.390
some basic size applied to it, some empty
space so that it doesn't have to grow.

261
00:12:41.390 --> 00:12:42.370
As I throw more and

262
00:12:42.370 --> 00:12:46.020
more data in there, it'll grow to reflect
the amount of data that's in there.

263
00:12:48.280 --> 00:12:50.260
Some of the other files
that are important,

264
00:12:50.260 --> 00:12:52.370
remember those log files that I mentioned?

265
00:12:52.370 --> 00:12:57.160
Well, we can see one of them right here,
E01.log, And

266
00:12:57.160 --> 00:12:58.680
I'm not seeing my file extensions.

267
00:12:58.680 --> 00:13:00.425
Let me turn on my file extensions,
there we go.

268
00:13:00.425 --> 00:13:04.980
E01.log, that is what's
called a transaction log.

269
00:13:04.980 --> 00:13:07.800
Now let me explain transaction logs
really quickly, it's important and

270
00:13:07.800 --> 00:13:10.320
you need to know it for the exam, but
you need to know it for real life too.

271
00:13:11.370 --> 00:13:16.070
When you get a new email, that email comes
in and it needs to go to the database, so

272
00:13:16.070 --> 00:13:19.020
we gotta write the data to the database.

273
00:13:19.020 --> 00:13:22.840
Well, let's say the email has an
attachment and it's 1 meg in size, and so

274
00:13:22.840 --> 00:13:26.260
it starts to write that one meg
attachment into the database.

275
00:13:26.260 --> 00:13:28.700
It gets halfway through and
you lose power.

276
00:13:29.980 --> 00:13:32.020
Power goes out, the server shuts down.

277
00:13:32.020 --> 00:13:34.630
Well, power comes back,
you boot the server up.

278
00:13:34.630 --> 00:13:35.992
What happened?
Well,

279
00:13:35.992 --> 00:13:40.820
only half of that attachment was written
to the database, so it's now corrupted.

280
00:13:40.820 --> 00:13:43.270
You've got corrupt data in your database,
so

281
00:13:43.270 --> 00:13:45.700
now when someone goes to access that
attachment, they get a corrupt file.

282
00:13:45.700 --> 00:13:47.900
It's damaged, and worse,

283
00:13:47.900 --> 00:13:50.470
the file might be damaged in a way
that Exchange can't even access it.

284
00:13:50.470 --> 00:13:53.950
Now you've got dead data filling up your
database, and it just sits there, and

285
00:13:53.950 --> 00:13:55.630
you can't do anything about it.

286
00:13:55.630 --> 00:13:56.880
That would be bad.

287
00:13:56.880 --> 00:13:59.980
So transaction logs are designed
to help insulate us from that.

288
00:13:59.980 --> 00:14:02.780
The way transactions logs work is
when data comes in to be written to

289
00:14:02.780 --> 00:14:03.810
the database,

290
00:14:03.810 --> 00:14:07.170
you don't write to the database,
you write to the transaction logs.

291
00:14:07.170 --> 00:14:11.410
So that one meg attachment gets to written
to a transaction log file first, and

292
00:14:11.410 --> 00:14:15.970
only when the data is 100%
written to the transaction log,

293
00:14:15.970 --> 00:14:18.450
is it then written to the actual database.

294
00:14:18.450 --> 00:14:21.360
And the reason it does it that way is,
now when it's writing to the database,

295
00:14:21.360 --> 00:14:23.770
let's say it's halfway through and
the power goes out?

296
00:14:23.770 --> 00:14:26.370
Well, when you boot that
server back up it says, oh,

297
00:14:26.370 --> 00:14:29.900
I was halfway through, when we look at the
transactional file, there's all the data.

298
00:14:29.900 --> 00:14:33.690
Let me just start it over again, and
it copies it back in, it does a rollback.

299
00:14:33.690 --> 00:14:38.000
It undoes the partial write, and then
a roll forward to reapply that data in and

300
00:14:38.000 --> 00:14:40.290
you get it back in the database.

301
00:14:40.290 --> 00:14:44.430
And so it ensures that things like
power outages or unexpected database

302
00:14:44.430 --> 00:14:48.870
dismounts or whatever don't result
in corrupted data in the database.

303
00:14:48.870 --> 00:14:52.440
Now, transaction logs only affect writes,
when we write data.

304
00:14:52.440 --> 00:14:54.660
When you read data,
you read it right out of the database,

305
00:14:54.660 --> 00:14:57.160
cuz you're not gonna corrupt
the database by reading it.

306
00:14:57.160 --> 00:14:59.630
Those happen right out of the EDB file,
but

307
00:14:59.630 --> 00:15:03.920
when you're doing a write operation, your
writes always go to the transactions logs.

308
00:15:03.920 --> 00:15:10.260
Now, the transaction log file, on mine you
can see this E01.log, it's just one file.

309
00:15:10.260 --> 00:15:11.681
It won't be one file for long.

310
00:15:11.681 --> 00:15:14.601
Notice that the file is 1 meg in size,
right?

311
00:15:14.601 --> 00:15:15.961
1,024 kilobytes.

312
00:15:15.961 --> 00:15:20.961
Well, it's one meg, what if I have
more than one meg of changes?

313
00:15:20.961 --> 00:15:25.223
If I have more than one meg of changes
it's going to create a second file, E02,

314
00:15:25.223 --> 00:15:28.044
E03 and so on, and
what it's actually gonna do is,

315
00:15:28.044 --> 00:15:30.761
you'll see it's already
done it right down here.

316
00:15:30.761 --> 00:15:36.253
E01, 0000001 and then E01 00000002

317
00:15:36.253 --> 00:15:40.320
It's created two log files right here.

318
00:15:40.320 --> 00:15:44.270
So the first one filled up,
I had one meg of changes here, and so

319
00:15:44.270 --> 00:15:46.000
then it created a second file.

320
00:15:46.000 --> 00:15:47.000
Now, what is that E01?

321
00:15:47.000 --> 00:15:52.550
E01 just means that this is
the second database on my server.

322
00:15:52.550 --> 00:15:55.126
Remember, I already had a database server,
I mean a database.

323
00:15:55.126 --> 00:15:57.293
I had the mailbox database.

324
00:15:57.293 --> 00:15:59.084
Let me just jump back to it here.

325
00:15:59.084 --> 00:16:02.292
This guy right here, this was my
first database, mailbox database.

326
00:16:02.292 --> 00:16:04.752
So sales is technically my second one.

327
00:16:04.752 --> 00:16:09.981
The mailbox database, this guy,
was E00, this one is E01.

328
00:16:09.981 --> 00:16:13.602
So inside of sales, that's why
everything starts with E01, right?

329
00:16:13.602 --> 00:16:17.563
So if I were to put all of these
databases in the same folder,

330
00:16:17.563 --> 00:16:23.842
they'd be able to tell each other apart,
because E00, E01, E02, and so on, right?

331
00:16:23.842 --> 00:16:28.604
If I go backup a folder here, and
go into that mailbox database 2013 folder,

332
00:16:28.604 --> 00:16:30.645
see how they all start with E00?

333
00:16:30.645 --> 00:16:32.990
It was the first database, right?

334
00:16:32.990 --> 00:16:36.159
And, it's the first, but they start
numbering with 0, it's computers,

335
00:16:36.159 --> 00:16:38.132
they're annoying, so
[LAUGH] we've got that.

336
00:16:38.132 --> 00:16:42.820
All right, but here inside of our
sales database, We've got E01.log.

337
00:16:42.820 --> 00:16:46.170
That's defining what our
transaction log list is, right?

338
00:16:46.170 --> 00:16:47.490
How many logs we have.

339
00:16:47.490 --> 00:16:51.960
And then down here, I can see E01
all the way through 1, and then 2.

340
00:16:51.960 --> 00:16:56.250
And it's just gonna keep counting up,
3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and higher.

341
00:16:56.250 --> 00:16:57.860
And it actually does hexadecimal.

342
00:16:57.860 --> 00:17:02.480
So it'll do 0 through 9, and then
A through F, and then start over again,

343
00:17:02.480 --> 00:17:03.910
0 through 9, A through F.

344
00:17:03.910 --> 00:17:06.180
And so you can have tens of thousands,

345
00:17:06.180 --> 00:17:08.100
hundreds of thousands of
transaction log files.

346
00:17:08.100 --> 00:17:11.290
As you're writing data to that database,
those are gonna grow and grow and

347
00:17:11.290 --> 00:17:13.650
grow, and they're always 1 meg in size.

348
00:17:13.650 --> 00:17:16.350
It breaks up into 1 megabyte chunks,
all right.

349
00:17:16.350 --> 00:17:21.265
Now, when you write to a transaction log,
when your data is 100%

350
00:17:21.265 --> 00:17:24.505
written to the transaction log,
it's ready to be written to the database.

351
00:17:24.505 --> 00:17:26.575
So then it writes it to the database.

352
00:17:26.575 --> 00:17:29.835
How does it know what data's
been written to the database and

353
00:17:29.835 --> 00:17:32.095
what data's still in the transaction logs?

354
00:17:32.095 --> 00:17:33.790
Well, it doesn't.

355
00:17:33.790 --> 00:17:34.740
It doesn't know.

356
00:17:34.740 --> 00:17:38.340
So it has to keep track of that somehow,
and it has a separate file for that.

357
00:17:38.340 --> 00:17:41.520
You'll notice up here,
I've got a filed called ES1.chk.

358
00:17:41.520 --> 00:17:43.540
That's my checkpoint file.

359
00:17:43.540 --> 00:17:48.930
The checkpoint is defining points in
time when everything was in sync,

360
00:17:48.930 --> 00:17:51.570
when everything in the transaction
log was written to the database.

361
00:17:51.570 --> 00:17:54.490
And so we can use that
checkpoint file to figure out

362
00:17:54.490 --> 00:17:57.120
what was written to the database and
what wasn't.

363
00:17:57.120 --> 00:18:01.360
So when there's a power outage,
we can boot our system back up,

364
00:18:01.360 --> 00:18:06.150
it looks at the checkpoint, and says okay,
what was written 100% and what wasn't?

365
00:18:06.150 --> 00:18:10.490
Anything that wasn't written 100%, let's
roll that back, let's undo that, okay?

366
00:18:10.490 --> 00:18:14.220
And then everything that was written
100% is done, it's fine, and

367
00:18:14.220 --> 00:18:17.850
now we start rolling forward any other
transactions that are still in tact,

368
00:18:17.850 --> 00:18:19.800
anything that we actually have
the full set of data for and

369
00:18:19.800 --> 00:18:23.490
it will start reapplying them, and
it does all this automatically.

370
00:18:23.490 --> 00:18:25.110
We don't have to worry about it.

371
00:18:25.110 --> 00:18:28.430
Well, there is actually one little
bit we have to worry about.

372
00:18:28.430 --> 00:18:32.170
As you make changes, the changes
are being written to the log files,

373
00:18:32.170 --> 00:18:34.150
and then they're being
written to the database.

374
00:18:34.150 --> 00:18:36.230
That means you're using double storage.

375
00:18:36.230 --> 00:18:37.386
If you get a five meg attachment,

376
00:18:37.386 --> 00:18:39.453
the attachment is written to
the transaction log file, and

377
00:18:39.453 --> 00:18:42.452
then it's written to the database, too,
now it's a 10 mega attachment, right?

378
00:18:42.452 --> 00:18:43.920
It took twice the space.

379
00:18:43.920 --> 00:18:48.040
So these transaction logs,
they grow and they grow and they grow.

380
00:18:48.040 --> 00:18:49.670
Eventually, you need to flush them out.

381
00:18:49.670 --> 00:18:52.615
You flush the transaction logs, and
the way you do it is by running a backup.

382
00:18:52.615 --> 00:18:53.210
When you run a backup,

383
00:18:53.210 --> 00:18:58.740
when you run a full backup of an exchange
server, it flushes the transaction logs.

384
00:18:58.740 --> 00:19:02.440
Or if you run a differential backup,
it flushes the transaction logs.

385
00:19:02.440 --> 00:19:04.590
I'm sorry, not differential,
let me try to get this straight.

386
00:19:04.590 --> 00:19:06.870
I wanna make sure you guys
have the right information.

387
00:19:06.870 --> 00:19:10.750
If you run an incremental backup,
it flushes the transaction logs.

388
00:19:10.750 --> 00:19:14.080
If you run a differential,
it leaves the transaction logs,

389
00:19:14.080 --> 00:19:18.950
because each differential contains all
the changes since the last full backup,

390
00:19:18.950 --> 00:19:20.520
regardless of how many differentials.

391
00:19:20.520 --> 00:19:23.140
And it achieves that by
leaving the logs alone.

392
00:19:23.140 --> 00:19:26.252
So if you run a full backup or
an incremental backup,

393
00:19:26.252 --> 00:19:30.190
it'll flush those transactions,
as long as you empty them out.

394
00:19:30.190 --> 00:19:33.120
If you don't do that, if you're running
Exchange and you're not backing

395
00:19:33.120 --> 00:19:36.370
up your server regularly, maybe you're
backup software starts malfunctioning and

396
00:19:36.370 --> 00:19:39.680
it's not running, or maybe you use some
third party software that's not Exchange

397
00:19:39.680 --> 00:19:42.870
aware, then you're transaction auxiliary
are gonna grow and grow and grow and

398
00:19:42.870 --> 00:19:44.398
grow, until they fill the hard drive.

399
00:19:44.398 --> 00:19:47.660
And your server's gonna get slower and
slower and slower and

400
00:19:47.660 --> 00:19:50.800
slower, cuz it's constantly having to
check those log files to see if there's

401
00:19:50.800 --> 00:19:52.820
changes that haven't been
written to the data base yet.

402
00:19:52.820 --> 00:19:54.720
So it really starts to kill performance,
so

403
00:19:54.720 --> 00:19:57.260
you gotta keep an eye on
those transaction log files.

404
00:19:57.260 --> 00:20:01.910
Now, this is all default behavior,
we want this behavior, but

405
00:20:01.910 --> 00:20:03.750
you can disable the transaction log files.

406
00:20:03.750 --> 00:20:05.940
There's something called circular logging.

407
00:20:05.940 --> 00:20:08.770
With circular logging,
it just makes, I think it's five or

408
00:20:08.770 --> 00:20:11.830
ten transaction log files and
that's it, it stops there.

409
00:20:11.830 --> 00:20:15.690
And then, when it writes new data,
it just overwrites the oldest data.

410
00:20:15.690 --> 00:20:19.670
So, it's just operating within
a small set of transaction log files.

411
00:20:19.670 --> 00:20:23.214
That's okay, but it's not the greatest
solution in the world and

412
00:20:23.214 --> 00:20:24.298
let me tell you why.

413
00:20:24.298 --> 00:20:28.725
When we do circular logging, if I have
a failure, if I have a database failure,

414
00:20:28.725 --> 00:20:31.895
I go back and I get my last full backup,
and I restore it and

415
00:20:31.895 --> 00:20:33.702
I'm back in business, right?

416
00:20:33.702 --> 00:20:36.325
Let's say I backup my Exchange
server every night at midnight.

417
00:20:36.325 --> 00:20:38.368
So every night at midnight, I back it up.

418
00:20:38.368 --> 00:20:42.670
And here I am at 3 PM in the afternoon,
and my server fails.

419
00:20:42.670 --> 00:20:44.100
And I'm like, great, it failed.

420
00:20:44.100 --> 00:20:46.550
Well, I've got a full backup,
let me just go and restore that.

421
00:20:46.550 --> 00:20:50.210
The problem is the full backup,
if it ran at midnight and now it's 3 PM,

422
00:20:50.210 --> 00:20:53.420
that full backup is 15 hours old.

423
00:20:53.420 --> 00:20:58.370
I lost 15 hours of email, 15 hours of
email just gone, incoming, outgoing,

424
00:20:58.370 --> 00:21:00.320
anything that happened the last 15 hours,
gone.

425
00:21:00.320 --> 00:21:01.660
Is that okay?

426
00:21:01.660 --> 00:21:03.450
In your business it might be, right?

427
00:21:03.450 --> 00:21:05.670
In your business,
email might not be critical.

428
00:21:05.670 --> 00:21:07.950
And so losing 15 hours of email,
that might not be a big deal.

429
00:21:07.950 --> 00:21:09.200
You don't worry about it.

430
00:21:09.200 --> 00:21:11.270
Turn on circular logging, do full backups.

431
00:21:11.270 --> 00:21:13.040
Works great, right?

432
00:21:13.040 --> 00:21:17.030
But, wouldn't it be nice if you
could get those 15 hours back?

433
00:21:17.030 --> 00:21:19.030
Well, sometimes you can.

434
00:21:19.030 --> 00:21:20.850
If I had a full backup
that ran at midnight,

435
00:21:20.850 --> 00:21:25.970
and then I've got transaction logs
that have run all day long for

436
00:21:25.970 --> 00:21:31.540
those 15 hours, it's possible that
I could restore my full backup,

437
00:21:31.540 --> 00:21:36.690
and then import those transaction logs and
get right back to the point of failure.

438
00:21:36.690 --> 00:21:38.660
And now I don't lose any email.

439
00:21:38.660 --> 00:21:39.950
Isn't that better?

440
00:21:39.950 --> 00:21:41.500
Absolutely, it's better, right?

441
00:21:41.500 --> 00:21:45.110
So, those transaction logs can really be
a great safety net to help you recover

442
00:21:45.110 --> 00:21:47.160
right to a point of failure, all right?

443
00:21:47.160 --> 00:21:50.150
So, you don't want to just
disable them out of hand.

444
00:21:50.150 --> 00:21:53.150
They do serve a purpose,
especially at times of failure,

445
00:21:53.150 --> 00:21:54.260
they're really handy to have.

446
00:21:54.260 --> 00:21:55.350
You just need to maintain them.

447
00:21:55.350 --> 00:21:56.770
It's part of running an Exchange server.

448
00:21:56.770 --> 00:21:57.270
It's really important.

449
00:21:58.910 --> 00:22:02.240
All right, there are a few other log
files in here, and in fact, I've

450
00:22:02.240 --> 00:22:05.270
talked long enough that we've actually
generated a third log file here, right?

451
00:22:05.270 --> 00:22:09.010
So just the server sitting here running
has generated enough to create a new log

452
00:22:09.010 --> 00:22:10.550
file while I was talking.

453
00:22:10.550 --> 00:22:14.320
Some of the other files that we've got
in here, notice all these JRS files.

454
00:22:14.320 --> 00:22:19.110
There's ten JRS files,
1 through 9, and then an A.

455
00:22:19.110 --> 00:22:20.160
What are those?

456
00:22:20.160 --> 00:22:23.280
Well, these are reserve files.

457
00:22:23.280 --> 00:22:25.650
What happens if your hard drive fills up?

458
00:22:25.650 --> 00:22:27.120
If your hard drive fills up and

459
00:22:27.120 --> 00:22:31.610
you've got email coming in,
it can't write it to the database, can it?

460
00:22:31.610 --> 00:22:35.260
It can't write it to the transaction logs,
the file system is full.

461
00:22:35.260 --> 00:22:36.620
You're losing them.

462
00:22:36.620 --> 00:22:38.710
So what these reserve files do
is they reserve some space.

463
00:22:38.710 --> 00:22:41.250
I'm reserving 10 megs of space.

464
00:22:41.250 --> 00:22:45.950
And if my hard drive ever fills up,
Exchange will dismount the database.

465
00:22:45.950 --> 00:22:46.980
It will take the database offline.

466
00:22:46.980 --> 00:22:48.762
That will stop incoming email.

467
00:22:48.762 --> 00:22:52.100
And, it'll write anything
in the current queues,

468
00:22:52.100 --> 00:22:55.530
right here to these ten files,
this reserved space that it's set aside.

469
00:22:55.530 --> 00:22:56.630
So that's what these are.

470
00:22:56.630 --> 00:22:58.580
These are actually empty,
they're empty files.

471
00:22:58.580 --> 00:23:00.020
There's nothing in them.

472
00:23:00.020 --> 00:23:03.605
They're just holding ten megs of
space on my hard drive, right?

473
00:23:03.605 --> 00:23:09.270
It's ten files at 1,024 kilobytes each,
so those are our reserve space.

474
00:23:09.270 --> 00:23:11.350
There's only one other file in
here that we need to worry.

475
00:23:11.350 --> 00:23:16.920
It's this guy down here at the bottom,
tmp.edb, and that's a temporary database.

476
00:23:16.920 --> 00:23:20.610
Any temporary data that Exchange works
with, like when it's doing mailbox move

477
00:23:20.610 --> 00:23:24.410
requests and stuff, there's temporary
data, it'll get thrown right in there.

478
00:23:24.410 --> 00:23:26.750
That database gets flushed regularly and

479
00:23:26.750 --> 00:23:30.050
it's pretty unusual to see it bigger
than one or two megs in size.

480
00:23:30.050 --> 00:23:31.545
It doesn't normally get very big at all.

481
00:23:31.545 --> 00:23:35.283
You'll see mine's 1.2 megs in size or
something like that.

482
00:23:35.283 --> 00:23:36.444
So, it's usually pretty small.

483
00:23:36.444 --> 00:23:37.980
It's just temporary data.

484
00:23:37.980 --> 00:23:41.910
But all of these files were created
when I created that database.

485
00:23:41.910 --> 00:23:45.910
And now, as I work with the server,
it's using all this in the background and

486
00:23:45.910 --> 00:23:47.980
I don't really have to worry
about it all that much.

487
00:23:49.110 --> 00:23:51.760
If I go and look at the other
mailbox database, same thing, right?

488
00:23:51.760 --> 00:23:52.584
It's got log files.

489
00:23:52.584 --> 00:23:55.995
It actually has more log files than my
other one, because it's been running

490
00:23:55.995 --> 00:23:59.567
longer, and it's actually got user
mailboxes in it But I'll see that database

491
00:23:59.567 --> 00:24:03.780
file, it's got it's own temp file, I'll
see its checkpoints, it's reserve files.

492
00:24:03.780 --> 00:24:07.335
Same basic structure, you expect to see
this for all of your mailbox database,

493
00:24:07.335 --> 00:24:07.876
all right?

494
00:24:07.876 --> 00:24:10.667
So that's the basic structure and
the key takeaway here that I want you guys

495
00:24:10.667 --> 00:24:12.840
to remember are these transaction logs,
right?

496
00:24:12.840 --> 00:24:17.220
The transaction logs are what you write to
first before you write to the database.

497
00:24:17.220 --> 00:24:19.300
And that gives you that
database integrity.

498
00:24:19.300 --> 00:24:23.220
Now if I jump back to my Exchange
Management screen, back here in the admin

499
00:24:23.220 --> 00:24:28.370
center, I could take my sales database and
if I edit the sales database,

500
00:24:28.370 --> 00:24:31.380
I'll see some various settings
on there that I can tweak.

501
00:24:31.380 --> 00:24:32.320
And some of it,

502
00:24:32.320 --> 00:24:35.880
like here on the general page, there's not
a whole heck of a lot that I can modify.

503
00:24:35.880 --> 00:24:37.270
I can modify the name.

504
00:24:37.270 --> 00:24:42.160
So I could give it one of those unique
names if I wanted to like the big

505
00:24:42.160 --> 00:24:44.210
long name that we saw on the other one.

506
00:24:44.210 --> 00:24:46.471
I could go crazy, or
I could just leave it be, right?

507
00:24:46.471 --> 00:24:47.080
So you can modify that.

508
00:24:47.080 --> 00:24:48.700
But most of this is just information.

509
00:24:48.700 --> 00:24:50.610
When was the last full backup?

510
00:24:50.610 --> 00:24:52.730
When was the last incremental backup,
right?

511
00:24:52.730 --> 00:24:53.930
What's its current status?

512
00:24:53.930 --> 00:24:55.150
What servers that mounted to?

513
00:24:55.150 --> 00:24:55.710
And so on.

514
00:24:55.710 --> 00:24:56.670
Just basic information.

515
00:24:57.900 --> 00:24:58.980
Most of this you can't change.

516
00:24:58.980 --> 00:25:00.760
It's just giving you that data.

517
00:25:00.760 --> 00:25:04.690
Under maintenance, here we actually can
tweak a few things and the one that I want

518
00:25:04.690 --> 00:25:08.150
to point out is right here at the bottom,
Enable Circular Logging.

519
00:25:08.150 --> 00:25:12.080
If I don't want transaction log files,
here's where I can fix that.

520
00:25:12.080 --> 00:25:14.980
I can check that, and that's gonna
turn off transaction log files.

521
00:25:14.980 --> 00:25:19.010
You still have transaction 1000 it's
going to start overriding them.

522
00:25:19.010 --> 00:25:21.210
So new data will override the old.

523
00:25:21.210 --> 00:25:22.997
You won't have hundreds or thousands.

524
00:25:22.997 --> 00:25:25.610
You'll have five or
I can't remember if it's five or ten,

525
00:25:25.610 --> 00:25:29.078
it's a real small amount of transaction
log files and that's it, all right?

526
00:25:29.078 --> 00:25:31.938
There's other things you can tweak like
whether you want to allow background

527
00:25:31.938 --> 00:25:32.820
maintenance.

528
00:25:32.820 --> 00:25:36.700
It's constantly defragmenting and trying
to compact the database in the background.

529
00:25:36.700 --> 00:25:38.120
And you can turn that off if you want.

530
00:25:38.120 --> 00:25:42.360
You can set a schedule for it, for
when those maintenance routines run.

531
00:25:42.360 --> 00:25:44.200
Set it for off-peak hours.

532
00:25:44.200 --> 00:25:47.230
You can set whether the databases
mounted at startup.

533
00:25:47.230 --> 00:25:49.470
Maybe you don't want it to mount
automatically, you mount it yourself.

534
00:25:49.470 --> 00:25:51.570
There's not a lot of reason for that.

535
00:25:51.570 --> 00:25:52.740
Then there's this guy.

536
00:25:52.740 --> 00:25:55.600
This database can be
overwritten by a restore.

537
00:25:55.600 --> 00:25:58.030
We'll see this in the episode
where we do back-ups and restores.

538
00:25:58.030 --> 00:26:00.690
In order to restore over a database,
you need to turn this option on.

539
00:26:00.690 --> 00:26:03.510
It's off by default, and
that's a protection mechanism.

540
00:26:03.510 --> 00:26:06.930
It's to save you from accidentally
overriding your database,

541
00:26:06.930 --> 00:26:09.880
because you might want to recover
those transaction log files.

542
00:26:09.880 --> 00:26:13.883
And when you do a restore, it wipes
the transaction log files by default.

543
00:26:13.883 --> 00:26:15.009
We want to be able to get those.

544
00:26:15.009 --> 00:26:17.588
So those are all important.

545
00:26:17.588 --> 00:26:19.335
I mentioned at the beginning
of the episode we can set

546
00:26:19.335 --> 00:26:20.380
limits on a mailbox database.

547
00:26:20.380 --> 00:26:22.270
We'll see that right here
under the limits section.

548
00:26:22.270 --> 00:26:26.950
I can say I only want users to
have a certain amount of space.

549
00:26:26.950 --> 00:26:28.580
This is my sales mailbox database.

550
00:26:28.580 --> 00:26:32.900
So I want salespeople to have a,
we'll say a 4 gig mailbox.

551
00:26:32.900 --> 00:26:35.040
And so I can come in here,
and I can set limits, right?

552
00:26:35.040 --> 00:26:41.120
I can say issue them a warning
when they get to 3.5 GB, right?

553
00:26:41.120 --> 00:26:43.770
At 3.5 I'm gonna warn them.

554
00:26:43.770 --> 00:26:50.080
And then, at 3.7 I'm gonna stop
them from being able to send email.

555
00:26:50.080 --> 00:26:52.640
They're not gonna be able
to send email anymore.

556
00:26:52.640 --> 00:26:57.180
They can still receive but they can't
send until they clean up their mail box.

557
00:26:57.180 --> 00:26:58.410
And then I can come in here and

558
00:26:58.410 --> 00:27:02.540
I can say when they hit 4 GB, I'm going
to stop them from sending and receiving.

559
00:27:02.540 --> 00:27:04.100
That's it, there mailbox is full.

560
00:27:04.100 --> 00:27:06.020
They won't be able to receive any data.

561
00:27:06.020 --> 00:27:10.150
Now, that's not a terribly popular
option because if email is critical for

562
00:27:10.150 --> 00:27:12.570
your company, you want people
to be able to send and receive.

563
00:27:12.570 --> 00:27:15.220
So a lot of times I'll come in here and
just set these to Unlimited.

564
00:27:16.350 --> 00:27:19.210
So I'm never gonna stop them
from sending and receiving, but

565
00:27:19.210 --> 00:27:21.310
I am gonna issue them a warning.

566
00:27:21.310 --> 00:27:22.940
And it'll annoy the heck out of them,
right?

567
00:27:22.940 --> 00:27:24.367
Once a day,
they'll get this warning message.

568
00:27:24.367 --> 00:27:27.270
During our maintenance window is when
it generates these warning messages.

569
00:27:27.270 --> 00:27:31.250
So if the maintenance window is midnight
to 3, somewhere in between midnight and

570
00:27:31.250 --> 00:27:33.380
3 AM, they'll get this warning
message that will say,

571
00:27:33.380 --> 00:27:36.350
your mailbox is over its limit or
your mailbox is approaching its limit.

572
00:27:36.350 --> 00:27:38.310
And they'll get that every single day.

573
00:27:38.310 --> 00:27:40.170
They could choose to ignore or
they could clean it up.

574
00:27:41.860 --> 00:27:44.800
We also specify retention
information right here so I want

575
00:27:44.800 --> 00:27:49.450
to keep deleted items for 14 days, I want
to keep deleted mailboxes for 30 days.

576
00:27:49.450 --> 00:27:52.640
I can tweak that if I want,
or I can leave it like this.

577
00:27:52.640 --> 00:27:55.420
Maybe I want it to be shorter or longer.

578
00:27:55.420 --> 00:27:58.883
Keeping deleted items, if a user throws
an item in the recycle bin and they empty

579
00:27:58.883 --> 00:28:02.449
the recycle bin, we actually retain it for
14 more days, and they can recover it

580
00:28:02.449 --> 00:28:05.832
right through Outlook if they want, or
we can recover it as administrators.

581
00:28:05.832 --> 00:28:08.862
We might wanna bump that up to something
larger to be able to maintain that.

582
00:28:08.862 --> 00:28:10.770
You'll see it will go up till 24,000 days.

583
00:28:10.770 --> 00:28:12.560
That's a long time.

584
00:28:12.560 --> 00:28:16.070
That's probably longer than
any of our careers will be so

585
00:28:16.070 --> 00:28:17.710
that will get us covered.

586
00:28:17.710 --> 00:28:20.440
Another neat option down here
is on the deleted mail boxes.

587
00:28:20.440 --> 00:28:22.640
You can say I wanna hold
any deleted mailbox for

588
00:28:22.640 --> 00:28:25.740
30 days, but then you can turn
on this other option that says

589
00:28:25.740 --> 00:28:30.220
even if it's been more than 30 days, keep
the mailbox if a backup hasn't been run.

590
00:28:30.220 --> 00:28:33.280
And that way we can ensure that a copy
of this mailbox is still in a backup

591
00:28:33.280 --> 00:28:37.200
somewhere, so that's a neat little
option to be able to turn on.

592
00:28:37.200 --> 00:28:38.620
And here's that warning message interval.

593
00:28:38.620 --> 00:28:40.450
You'll see it's set to midnight here.

594
00:28:40.450 --> 00:28:42.100
We can set when those messages go out.

595
00:28:43.950 --> 00:28:45.370
And then last we've got
our client settings.

596
00:28:45.370 --> 00:28:47.340
I'm going to talk about this
in the address book episode.

597
00:28:47.340 --> 00:28:50.720
We can define what offline address book
our end users are going to make use of.

598
00:28:50.720 --> 00:28:52.410
I'm just going to leave that be for
right now.

599
00:28:53.482 --> 00:28:56.020
All right, so those are all different
things that we can tweak in our

600
00:28:56.020 --> 00:28:58.800
mailbox databases and get them set up.

601
00:28:58.800 --> 00:29:01.080
Now I kinda talked a long time on that.

602
00:29:01.080 --> 00:29:02.640
We covered some really important stuff.

603
00:29:02.640 --> 00:29:05.490
I have more I wanna talk about
on mailbox databases though,

604
00:29:05.490 --> 00:29:07.930
especially when it comes
to file system tuning.

605
00:29:07.930 --> 00:29:11.380
There's some stuff we can do on our server
to make it perform at its peak, and

606
00:29:11.380 --> 00:29:12.250
it's really important.

607
00:29:12.250 --> 00:29:14.810
So I wanna make sure I tackle that and
I take my time with it.

608
00:29:14.810 --> 00:29:16.380
So let's do a part two to this episode.

609
00:29:16.380 --> 00:29:19.630
We covered mailbox databases here,
the basics, getting one created and

610
00:29:19.630 --> 00:29:20.930
the basic settings.

611
00:29:20.930 --> 00:29:23.730
But I wanna do some more on tweaking and
performance, so definitely stay tuned for

612
00:29:23.730 --> 00:29:26.360
that, but for now, we'll go ahead and
wrap this episode up.

613
00:29:26.360 --> 00:29:28.250
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this one.

614
00:29:28.250 --> 00:29:31.141
Stay tuned for part two,
it's definitely coming up next.

615
00:29:31.141 --> 00:29:34.587
But for now, signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet, and

616
00:29:34.587 --> 00:29:35.843
I'll see you next time.

617
00:29:35.843 --> 00:29:41.740
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues discussing mailbox databases. He begins by demonstrating how to move mailbox databases to alternate locations. He then discusses tuning the file system to ensure that the database operates at optimal efficiency.
episodes.title: Mailbox Databases Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.069 --> 00:00:11.922
All right.

3
00:00:11.922 --> 00:00:14.310
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening, and welcome back.

4
00:00:14.310 --> 00:00:17.349
To another episode of ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.349 --> 00:00:20.020
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:24.390
In this episode, we're actually picking
up where our last episode left off.

7
00:00:24.390 --> 00:00:27.880
We started our mailbox databases and
well I just talked too much.

8
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:28.770
So, in this episode,

9
00:00:28.770 --> 00:00:32.590
we're going to continue on with
part two of mailbox databases.

10
00:00:32.590 --> 00:00:35.830
We got a chance to see in the last
episode how to create a database and

11
00:00:35.830 --> 00:00:37.520
all the files that are kind
of involved in it.

12
00:00:37.520 --> 00:00:39.880
I talked a little bit about
transaction logs and databases and

13
00:00:39.880 --> 00:00:41.170
all that good stuff.

14
00:00:41.170 --> 00:00:45.610
In this episode, I wanna talk about
tuning those databases for performance.

15
00:00:45.610 --> 00:00:49.710
Now, by default, Exchange is taking
care of indexing the data, and

16
00:00:49.710 --> 00:00:51.040
defragmenting the database.

17
00:00:51.040 --> 00:00:53.280
So that stuff we really
don't have to worry about.

18
00:00:53.280 --> 00:00:57.190
But what we do have to worry
about is disk contention.

19
00:00:57.190 --> 00:01:03.250
When you create databases, by default it's
gonna throw them into C:/Program Files,

20
00:01:03.250 --> 00:01:05.990
it's gonna throw them
right on your C:/ drive.

21
00:01:05.990 --> 00:01:09.150
And that means, at a minimum,
if you just have one mailbox database,

22
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:13.520
at a minimum, it's gonna be contending for
disk access with your operating system.

23
00:01:13.520 --> 00:01:17.030
So the database and your operating
system both fighting to read and

24
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:18.050
write to the same hard drive.

25
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:21.330
If you have more than
one mailbox database,

26
00:01:21.330 --> 00:01:25.230
they are contending against each other for
access to that file system.

27
00:01:25.230 --> 00:01:28.440
So we're probably going to
want to spread our data out.

28
00:01:28.440 --> 00:01:32.060
We're gonna move our databases
off to separate hard drives, so

29
00:01:32.060 --> 00:01:34.750
they can have exclusive
access to those drives.

30
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:37.730
All right now, when I talk about
discontention, what am I talking about?

31
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:39.540
Well when we have a hard drive,

32
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:43.570
a hard drive, it's got a spinning disk
inside of it or it might be SSD, right?

33
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:44.960
It might be solid state.

34
00:01:44.960 --> 00:01:49.060
But, either way, you've got to go through
a controller to then access the data.

35
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:51.880
On a solid state drive,
the controller can only handle so

36
00:01:51.880 --> 00:01:53.700
many operations at one time.

37
00:01:53.700 --> 00:01:57.730
So you end up with a queue where people
are waiting in line to access the drive.

38
00:01:57.730 --> 00:02:00.170
It's much worse on spinning disks.

39
00:02:00.170 --> 00:02:03.420
On a spinning disk, there's this
mechanical head that moves back and

40
00:02:03.420 --> 00:02:05.230
forth on the disk to read data.

41
00:02:05.230 --> 00:02:09.160
That mechanical head can only
be in one place at a time.

42
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:15.140
So a mechanical spinning disk can
only handle one operation at a time.

43
00:02:15.140 --> 00:02:16.900
And that creates a big queue.

44
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:20.110
SSD can do a lot more and it does a lot
faster, that's definitely better.

45
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:24.680
So again we might shift our data over
to those types of disks that do it.

46
00:02:24.680 --> 00:02:29.110
In addition to that we're probably worried
about redundancy because hard drives fail

47
00:02:29.110 --> 00:02:30.540
all the time.

48
00:02:30.540 --> 00:02:33.570
It's a rare hard drive these days that
will last you more than three years.

49
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:37.430
So knowing that disk failure is eminent,
we need a plan for that.

50
00:02:37.430 --> 00:02:41.360
So we're typically going to put our
databases on top of RAID arrays.

51
00:02:41.360 --> 00:02:44.330
Well RAID,
the redundant array of independent disks,

52
00:02:44.330 --> 00:02:46.550
that can give you resiliency
several different ways.

53
00:02:46.550 --> 00:02:48.910
And we need to understand how
they each affect the database.

54
00:02:48.910 --> 00:02:52.530
So I wanna spend a minute to kinda go
through the different RAID technologies.

55
00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:55.320
And how they affect Microsoft Exchange.

56
00:02:55.320 --> 00:02:59.290
Because we all probably, by this point you
guys probably already know RAID 0, RAID 1,

57
00:02:59.290 --> 00:03:01.120
RAID 5, you know, they're not new.

58
00:03:01.120 --> 00:03:03.180
But, how they affect
Exchange is important.

59
00:03:04.200 --> 00:03:06.480
And when we talk about
how it affects Exchange,

60
00:03:06.480 --> 00:03:09.930
we have to remember that there's
two pieces of our mailbox database.

61
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.890
There's the database itself, and
there's the transaction log files.

62
00:03:13.890 --> 00:03:17.790
The database, we are reading
from the database constantly.

63
00:03:17.790 --> 00:03:19.890
Everybody checking their email,
going in there.

64
00:03:19.890 --> 00:03:22.890
We read from that database all the time.

65
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:25.270
So read operations are really important.

66
00:03:25.270 --> 00:03:28.280
We write to the database also,
but not as often.

67
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:31.270
In fact,
end users never write to the database.

68
00:03:31.270 --> 00:03:34.380
End users all write to
the transaction log files.

69
00:03:34.380 --> 00:03:37.920
And then it's the system that writes
from the transaction log files into

70
00:03:37.920 --> 00:03:38.800
the database.

71
00:03:38.800 --> 00:03:42.020
So it's really just one person
writing to the database.

72
00:03:42.020 --> 00:03:45.250
Whereas you might have thousands of
people reading from the database.

73
00:03:45.250 --> 00:03:48.610
Only one person, the Exchange service,
is writing to the database itself.

74
00:03:48.610 --> 00:03:51.330
So the reads and
writes are a little weird.

75
00:03:51.330 --> 00:03:54.090
Your transaction logs
are very write heavy.

76
00:03:54.090 --> 00:03:56.410
Your database is very read heavy.

77
00:03:56.410 --> 00:03:59.040
And so
the file systems need to be different.

78
00:03:59.040 --> 00:04:00.180
You can put the database and

79
00:04:00.180 --> 00:04:02.710
the transaction log files in
the same folder if you want.

80
00:04:02.710 --> 00:04:03.590
In fact, that's the default.

81
00:04:03.590 --> 00:04:05.920
Right here,
I'll take this Exchange server.

82
00:04:05.920 --> 00:04:06.990
And here's an Exchange server.

83
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:08.900
I did a default install on it.

84
00:04:08.900 --> 00:04:13.637
And right here in
C:\ProgramFiles\Microsoft\ExchangeServer\-

85
00:04:13.637 --> 00:04:19.420
V15\Mailbox we can see the Mailbox
Database and here's all the files.

86
00:04:19.420 --> 00:04:23.700
And I've got, I'll find it here,
the E00, let's see here we go,

87
00:04:23.700 --> 00:04:30.100
here is Mailbox Database
201376320 whatever .edb.

88
00:04:30.100 --> 00:04:31.470
That's the exchange database.

89
00:04:31.470 --> 00:04:33.740
That's going to be really read heavy.

90
00:04:33.740 --> 00:04:36.160
Then see all these transaction log files?

91
00:04:36.160 --> 00:04:38.260
Those transaction log files
are going to be very write heavy and

92
00:04:38.260 --> 00:04:40.060
they're right here in the same place.

93
00:04:40.060 --> 00:04:44.630
So now, when users are trying to read from
the drive and other people are trying to

94
00:04:44.630 --> 00:04:48.320
write to the transaction log files,
they're fighting for access to that disk.

95
00:04:48.320 --> 00:04:49.410
This isn't great.

96
00:04:49.410 --> 00:04:52.670
For a small environment, maybe even a
medium environment that might be okay, but

97
00:04:52.670 --> 00:04:56.610
when you start getting into the thousands
of mailboxes, or tens of thousands,

98
00:04:56.610 --> 00:04:59.710
hundreds of thousands of mailboxes,
this will kill your server.

99
00:04:59.710 --> 00:05:01.450
Disperformance will be your big problem.

100
00:05:01.450 --> 00:05:02.630
So, we need a better solution.

101
00:05:03.780 --> 00:05:07.680
At a minimum, it's recommended
to split your database and

102
00:05:07.680 --> 00:05:10.680
transaction log files onto
separate hard drives, all right?

103
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:14.340
If my databases are on one set of hard
drives, and my transaction log files

104
00:05:14.340 --> 00:05:17.590
are on a different set,
my reads are happening on set 1,

105
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:21.230
my writes are happening on set 2,
things are spread out.

106
00:05:21.230 --> 00:05:23.030
We get better disk access.

107
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:25.990
If I go a step further and
separate my mailbox databases themselves,

108
00:05:25.990 --> 00:05:28.450
each mailbox database getting
its own set of hard drives.

109
00:05:28.450 --> 00:05:31.220
That's even better for
reducing contention, but

110
00:05:31.220 --> 00:05:33.710
you guys are probably
starting to see dollar signs.

111
00:05:33.710 --> 00:05:34.750
It gets more and more expensive.

112
00:05:34.750 --> 00:05:36.320
You gotta buy this extra hardware, but

113
00:05:36.320 --> 00:05:38.930
if performance is your concern,
you gotta do it.

114
00:05:38.930 --> 00:05:42.410
You've gotta make sure you've got the
available through put to be able to read

115
00:05:42.410 --> 00:05:44.420
and write the data to your system.

116
00:05:44.420 --> 00:05:46.750
The other thing to remember
is if we have a failure,

117
00:05:47.880 --> 00:05:50.230
we can always restore
our last full backup.

118
00:05:50.230 --> 00:05:51.500
And that'll restore this guy right here.

119
00:05:51.500 --> 00:05:53.400
That'll restore the database, but

120
00:05:53.400 --> 00:05:58.390
I lose any email that happened since
that full backup was taken, right?

121
00:05:58.390 --> 00:06:02.890
But if I can recover my transaction logs,
I can get right to the point of failure.

122
00:06:02.890 --> 00:06:06.810
Well, if I just lost my database, and the
transactions logs are on the same drive as

123
00:06:06.810 --> 00:06:09.510
the database,
I probably lost them too, didn't I?

124
00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:11.040
So there's not really
a point in keeping them,

125
00:06:11.040 --> 00:06:12.970
might as well turn on circular logging.

126
00:06:12.970 --> 00:06:16.030
But if I put my transaction logs
on separate hard drives, and

127
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:19.030
I lose the array that has the database.

128
00:06:19.030 --> 00:06:22.120
I can restore a full
backup of my database.

129
00:06:22.120 --> 00:06:25.270
And then I can salvage the transaction
logs that are still right here on

130
00:06:25.270 --> 00:06:26.690
a separate set of hard drives.

131
00:06:26.690 --> 00:06:29.470
Bring those over, and I can reapply

132
00:06:29.470 --> 00:06:32.470
those changes to the database to bring
it right to the point of failure.

133
00:06:32.470 --> 00:06:35.100
I don't lose any email,
and that's a great thing.

134
00:06:35.100 --> 00:06:37.510
So, separating these files out.

135
00:06:37.510 --> 00:06:40.030
When I installed this,
well, here I'll show you.

136
00:06:40.030 --> 00:06:44.690
If we go back into our Exchange admin
center, we can go down to servers and

137
00:06:44.690 --> 00:06:46.060
databases.

138
00:06:46.060 --> 00:06:48.130
When you add in a database,

139
00:06:48.130 --> 00:06:52.330
it actually gives you the chance right
here to specify alternate paths.

140
00:06:52.330 --> 00:06:54.750
We can put these in different places.

141
00:06:54.750 --> 00:06:57.840
The problem is a lot of us don't think
about it when you create the database.

142
00:06:57.840 --> 00:06:59.580
Think about it after the fact.

143
00:06:59.580 --> 00:07:02.110
So you go to create the database, and

144
00:07:02.110 --> 00:07:06.300
then a year later, two years later things
have grown, it starts getting slow, and

145
00:07:06.300 --> 00:07:08.930
you go, boy I really wish I
would have separated those out.

146
00:07:08.930 --> 00:07:11.590
Well, you can move them after the fact.

147
00:07:11.590 --> 00:07:13.130
You can't do it through the GUI.

148
00:07:13.130 --> 00:07:17.765
So if I were to take my sales database
here and edit that and go in the path.

149
00:07:17.765 --> 00:07:18.755
See how it's grayed out?

150
00:07:18.755 --> 00:07:19.745
It won't let me change that.

151
00:07:19.745 --> 00:07:22.065
Even if I unmount the database
I can't change that.

152
00:07:22.065 --> 00:07:23.505
It's kinda stuck where it is.

153
00:07:23.505 --> 00:07:28.305
But we can drop to the Powershell and
we can move that database somewhere else.

154
00:07:28.305 --> 00:07:32.635
So if I take this server for
example, let me go here into my

155
00:07:32.635 --> 00:07:36.395
computer management utility, I've got
a couple of hard drives in this server.

156
00:07:36.395 --> 00:07:38.260
So I can start to make use of those.

157
00:07:38.260 --> 00:07:40.920
So I can jump in here and
go down to my disk management.

158
00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:44.470
And you'll see I have a C: drive,
that's where my operating system is.

159
00:07:44.470 --> 00:07:46.980
But then I've got these extra
hard drives sitting down here.

160
00:07:46.980 --> 00:07:49.430
I've got a 20 gig E: drive, and

161
00:07:49.430 --> 00:07:54.715
a looks like a 128 gig F: drive that
I'm not really using for anything.

162
00:07:54.715 --> 00:07:57.506
So I can take these and
I can move my other data to them.

163
00:07:57.506 --> 00:07:59.384
So I can take that E: drive,

164
00:07:59.384 --> 00:08:03.546
for example, and I might call
that my transaction logs drive.

165
00:08:03.546 --> 00:08:06.486
So I'm gonna start putting my
transaction logs on the E drive.

166
00:08:06.486 --> 00:08:10.907
And then I can take my F drive and
I could make that my database drives, or

167
00:08:10.907 --> 00:08:13.430
I could call this my Mailbox Databases.

168
00:08:14.830 --> 00:08:16.210
All right, so I'm just kinda naming them.

169
00:08:16.210 --> 00:08:16.970
You don't have to name them.

170
00:08:16.970 --> 00:08:18.530
I'm just doing it so
I can keep it straight.

171
00:08:18.530 --> 00:08:21.570
So I've got an E drive and an F drive, and
that's where I wanna start storing those,

172
00:08:21.570 --> 00:08:26.680
separating these out, trying to
remove some of that disk contention.

173
00:08:26.680 --> 00:08:31.242
All right, so then I can jump down
into my PowerShell and I'll fire.

174
00:08:31.242 --> 00:08:33.220
Wait, this is important.

175
00:08:33.220 --> 00:08:36.170
I need to use some Exchange
commandlets and the regular PowerShell

176
00:08:36.170 --> 00:08:39.070
doesn't have them, so I need to make
sure I run the Exchange PowerShell.

177
00:08:39.070 --> 00:08:41.430
So let me just jump here
to my start screen and

178
00:08:41.430 --> 00:08:43.820
I'll fire up
the Exchange Management Shell.

179
00:08:43.820 --> 00:08:47.255
Remember the Exchange Management Shell is
just like the regular PowerShell except

180
00:08:47.255 --> 00:08:50.150
that it's got all the Exchange
commandlets added to it.

181
00:08:50.150 --> 00:08:51.620
I'm doing it here on the server.

182
00:08:51.620 --> 00:08:54.001
I could have done like
a PSremote from a client and

183
00:08:54.001 --> 00:08:57.153
connected up the same way that I
have the commandlets there too.

184
00:08:57.153 --> 00:09:01.857
So this will get me in here and
then I'll bump that font size up a bit so

185
00:09:01.857 --> 00:09:04.511
we'll be able to see what I'm doing.

186
00:09:04.511 --> 00:09:07.970
Since that's not necessarily
super legible like it is.

187
00:09:07.970 --> 00:09:09.641
And [SOUND] there we go.

188
00:09:09.641 --> 00:09:15.013
All right, so what we're looking at here
is just the Exchange Management Shell and

189
00:09:15.013 --> 00:09:17.250
I wanna move that Sales database.

190
00:09:17.250 --> 00:09:19.960
Well, I'm gonna make a couple
of folders here real quick.

191
00:09:19.960 --> 00:09:24.880
I'm gonna make E:\TL, that's where I'm
gonna be putting my transaction logs.

192
00:09:24.880 --> 00:09:29.700
And then I'm gonna make F:\DB, that's
where I'm gonna be putting my databases.

193
00:09:29.700 --> 00:09:32.370
And now I can start to
move these guys around.

194
00:09:32.370 --> 00:09:36.840
And the command for
that is the Move-DatabasePath.

195
00:09:36.840 --> 00:09:39.600
But the problem with that command,
Move-DatabasePath,

196
00:09:39.600 --> 00:09:42.290
I have to know the name of
the database and all that.

197
00:09:42.290 --> 00:09:47.495
So when I do this, I almost always
start with just Get-MailboxDatabase,

198
00:09:47.495 --> 00:09:49.855
and that's gonna give me a list
of all my mailbox databases.

199
00:09:49.855 --> 00:09:53.355
It will give you a list for the whole
organization, so you'll see everything.

200
00:09:53.355 --> 00:09:56.575
And I can see there's that default
database that was created, and

201
00:09:56.575 --> 00:09:59.555
there's the Sales database that I made,
and that's the one that I wanna move.

202
00:09:59.555 --> 00:10:01.705
I'm gonna move that one around.

203
00:10:01.705 --> 00:10:05.859
So now I can come in and
I can say, Move-DatabasePath, and

204
00:10:05.859 --> 00:10:09.160
I can specify the identity,
which is sales.

205
00:10:09.160 --> 00:10:11.810
It's my sales database
that I'm gonna be moving.

206
00:10:11.810 --> 00:10:13.560
And then I can tell it what
I'm gonna be moving around.

207
00:10:13.560 --> 00:10:18.480
I'm gonna say my EdbFilePath, and
I'll specify where I want that to go.

208
00:10:18.480 --> 00:10:23.741
Well, I want that to
go to F:\DB\Sales.edb.

209
00:10:23.741 --> 00:10:26.230
That's where I want that one to end up,
so I'm gonna move it there.

210
00:10:27.490 --> 00:10:36.800
Then I can say -LogFolderPath and I can
specify where I want this one to go to.

211
00:10:36.800 --> 00:10:39.660
Now my log folder path I want it
to be a different set of drives.

212
00:10:39.660 --> 00:10:44.930
And so this one I'm gonna
move to E:\TL\ and then you

213
00:10:44.930 --> 00:10:48.440
can give it a subfolder or you can just
throw it right into there if I wanted.

214
00:10:48.440 --> 00:10:50.500
I probably should have
created a sales folder, and

215
00:10:50.500 --> 00:10:51.840
I don't remember if it'll create it for
me.

216
00:10:51.840 --> 00:10:53.270
So we'll find out right here.

217
00:10:53.270 --> 00:10:56.470
So I'm just gonna create a folder
called Sales to stick it in there.

218
00:10:56.470 --> 00:11:00.250
So now I'm telling it I
want to move the database.

219
00:11:00.250 --> 00:11:03.630
And when I run that, it's going to
reach in there and it's gonna move it.

220
00:11:03.630 --> 00:11:05.420
So there it goes, moving that database.

221
00:11:05.420 --> 00:11:08.500
It's telling me that am I
sure that I want to do it?

222
00:11:08.500 --> 00:11:11.820
So I'll go ahead and say yes to that,
and there it goes, moving that over.

223
00:11:11.820 --> 00:11:14.640
It's telling me, To perform the operation
it must be temporarily dismounted.

224
00:11:14.640 --> 00:11:16.397
It's going to kick my users out, so

225
00:11:16.397 --> 00:11:19.330
this is definitely
an after-hours type operation.

226
00:11:19.330 --> 00:11:22.120
We don't want people in the database and
then we kick them out.

227
00:11:22.120 --> 00:11:23.770
They'll see it as Outlook going offline,

228
00:11:23.770 --> 00:11:25.570
and then when the move is
done it'll come back online.

229
00:11:25.570 --> 00:11:27.990
But the move could take a while,
couldn't it?

230
00:11:27.990 --> 00:11:30.010
If you've got a mailbox database
that's a terabyte in size,

231
00:11:30.010 --> 00:11:31.730
it's gonna take a while to copy.

232
00:11:31.730 --> 00:11:33.220
So we definitely wanna plan around that.

233
00:11:33.220 --> 00:11:35.400
I'm gonna go ahead and say yes to do it.

234
00:11:35.400 --> 00:11:37.810
And there it goes.
It's gonna dismount the database,

235
00:11:37.810 --> 00:11:40.410
it's gonna copy the files
to the new location, and

236
00:11:40.410 --> 00:11:43.080
it's gonna remount the database and
bring back it online.

237
00:11:43.080 --> 00:11:44.735
And now my database and

238
00:11:44.735 --> 00:11:47.940
my transaction log files will be spread
out on these separate hard drives.

239
00:11:47.940 --> 00:11:53.300
And that was all done with the
Move-DatabasePath PowerShell commandlet.

240
00:11:53.300 --> 00:11:57.360
Now it doesn't take too terribly
long to do it for a small database.

241
00:11:57.360 --> 00:11:59.110
Now pay attention to
the time it's taking mine.

242
00:11:59.110 --> 00:12:01.370
Now my disk IO is kind
of constrained here.

243
00:12:01.370 --> 00:12:05.616
I actually only have one hard drive, so
you'll see a little contention there, but

244
00:12:05.616 --> 00:12:09.331
my mailbox database, it was only,
I think it was like 250MB in size.

245
00:12:09.331 --> 00:12:11.040
It was very, very small.

246
00:12:11.040 --> 00:12:14.790
So imagine if it's a terabyte or
even 50 gigabytes,

247
00:12:14.790 --> 00:12:16.480
it's going to take longer than that.

248
00:12:16.480 --> 00:12:20.900
So it could take an hour, it could take
hours your mail system might be offline.

249
00:12:20.900 --> 00:12:22.938
You're not losing email during this time.

250
00:12:22.938 --> 00:12:24.710
Your mail queues are still running, so

251
00:12:24.710 --> 00:12:27.710
any incoming email is just getting
stuck in the queue and sitting there.

252
00:12:27.710 --> 00:12:32.030
