So you're not losing email, but it's gonna
have to take time to kinda rearrange.

253
00:12:32.030 --> 00:12:33.930
And then when the database
comes back online,

254
00:12:33.930 --> 00:12:36.820
which mine just did,
all the email in the queue gets delivered.

255
00:12:36.820 --> 00:12:38.080
So I don't lose email.

256
00:12:38.080 --> 00:12:39.530
Just users can't get into their email.

257
00:12:41.300 --> 00:12:44.190
All right, when it's done,
now my database should be moved.

258
00:12:44.190 --> 00:12:46.910
If I go back to my
Exchange Management Center.

259
00:12:46.910 --> 00:12:49.970
And I'll take Sales here,
and I'm gonna edit it.

260
00:12:49.970 --> 00:12:56.520
When I go into its settings,
it shows that new path, F:\DB\Sales.edb.

261
00:12:56.520 --> 00:12:59.560
So that data moved and
I can go verify that on the server too

262
00:12:59.560 --> 00:13:01.570
if I browse around on the hard
drive of this server.

263
00:13:03.110 --> 00:13:07.020
Let me just jump over to my F drive, and

264
00:13:07.020 --> 00:13:11.590
there's that DB folder and
there's Sales.edb, it's about 250MB.

265
00:13:11.590 --> 00:13:16.510
And if I go to my E drive,
there's the TL folder I made and

266
00:13:16.510 --> 00:13:19.920
the Sales folder, and
there's the transaction logs for it.

267
00:13:19.920 --> 00:13:22.850
And notice it didn't flush my
transaction logs, it just moved them.

268
00:13:22.850 --> 00:13:24.565
Moved them to the new location and
off it went.

269
00:13:25.735 --> 00:13:26.805
Now I say it moved.

270
00:13:26.805 --> 00:13:28.925
It actually does a copy operation so

271
00:13:28.925 --> 00:13:31.905
that if something goes wrong it can
always just fail back to the source.

272
00:13:31.905 --> 00:13:34.955
And it's only when the copy is done
that it removes the original, so

273
00:13:34.955 --> 00:13:38.465
it's not a true move,
it's a copy and then delete.

274
00:13:39.505 --> 00:13:41.375
But there we go,
we've moved off to separate drives.

275
00:13:41.375 --> 00:13:43.325
Now I've alleviated some
of my disk contention.

276
00:13:44.520 --> 00:13:45.860
That is a key thing.

277
00:13:45.860 --> 00:13:47.270
When you're setting up
an Exchange Server for

278
00:13:47.270 --> 00:13:51.210
a large organization, you're typically
gonna want four sets of drives.

279
00:13:51.210 --> 00:13:53.520
You want a set of drives for
the operating system.

280
00:13:53.520 --> 00:13:55.980
You want a set of drives for
your page file.

281
00:13:55.980 --> 00:13:58.410
You want a set of drives for
your transaction logs.

282
00:13:58.410 --> 00:14:01.470
And you want a set of drives for
your mailbox database.

283
00:14:01.470 --> 00:14:03.260
Four sets of drives.

284
00:14:03.260 --> 00:14:07.490
Now I say sets because you don't
want just one hard drive for each.

285
00:14:07.490 --> 00:14:08.670
You want them to be RAID arrays.

286
00:14:08.670 --> 00:14:10.420
You want them to be redundant or
optimized, so

287
00:14:10.420 --> 00:14:12.670
there's some additional
considerations there.

288
00:14:12.670 --> 00:14:15.780
The other thing is,
don't think about partitions.

289
00:14:15.780 --> 00:14:17.680
Just put partitions out of your mind.

290
00:14:17.680 --> 00:14:19.280
Some people say all right,
I'll take a drive and

291
00:14:19.280 --> 00:14:21.190
I'll divide it into four partitions.

292
00:14:21.190 --> 00:14:23.780
The problem there is it's still one drive,
right?

293
00:14:23.780 --> 00:14:26.810
That's basically what I've done here in
my lab is I've got this one partition.

294
00:14:26.810 --> 00:14:30.770
So when I'm writing to
partition 1 versus partition 2,

295
00:14:30.770 --> 00:14:33.910
I'm still using the same hardware and
I still get the same contention.

296
00:14:33.910 --> 00:14:36.890
So partitions really don't help
you at all in Exchange land.

297
00:14:36.890 --> 00:14:38.470
It's just kind of a waste of time.

298
00:14:38.470 --> 00:14:40.190
So I'm really talking about
separate physical disks.

299
00:14:41.670 --> 00:14:44.090
All right, now in my case I threw
these to separate physical disks.

300
00:14:44.090 --> 00:14:46.340
Now I'm optimized and I'm done, right?

301
00:14:46.340 --> 00:14:48.270
Well, I can do better.

302
00:14:48.270 --> 00:14:51.390
Just throwing it on a single
disk gives us two problems.

303
00:14:51.390 --> 00:14:53.810
One, you've got a single set of
hardware working for you, so

304
00:14:53.810 --> 00:14:55.950
you have limited throughput.

305
00:14:55.950 --> 00:14:58.470
The other one is you've got
single points of failure.

306
00:14:58.470 --> 00:14:59.980
If my E drive fails,

307
00:14:59.980 --> 00:15:03.380
I just lost my transaction logs,
my database goes offline.

308
00:15:03.380 --> 00:15:08.130
If my F drive fails, I just lost my
database, database goes offline.

309
00:15:08.130 --> 00:15:11.090
If my C drive fails, I just lost my
operating system, database goes offline.

310
00:15:11.090 --> 00:15:13.900
So any one of those failing will
bring my whole system down.

311
00:15:13.900 --> 00:15:15.410
I need redundancy.

312
00:15:15.410 --> 00:15:18.960
The problem is redundancy normally
comes at a cost of performance.

313
00:15:18.960 --> 00:15:22.790
So we have to find a balance
between performance and redundancy,

314
00:15:22.790 --> 00:15:25.670
and that's what RAID lets us
do is we get that choice.

315
00:15:25.670 --> 00:15:29.680
So let's take a look at some
options as far as using RAID.

316
00:15:29.680 --> 00:15:32.500
There's really four main types of
RAID that we worry about today.

317
00:15:32.500 --> 00:15:35.480
RAID 0, 1, 5 and 10.

318
00:15:35.480 --> 00:15:40.120
RAID 0 is all about performance.

319
00:15:40.120 --> 00:15:42.960
If you want the fastest
mailbox database or

320
00:15:42.960 --> 00:15:46.340
the fastest transaction logs,
RAID 0 is your winner.

321
00:15:46.340 --> 00:15:48.420
This is gonna get you
the best performance.

322
00:15:48.420 --> 00:15:52.860
When you do RAID 0, when you write
data to the drive, it's striped,

323
00:15:52.860 --> 00:15:54.690
it's spread across multiple drives.

324
00:15:54.690 --> 00:15:56.260
So in this example I've got three drives.

325
00:15:56.260 --> 00:16:00.043
And so when it takes data, it writes
it and breaks it up into chunks, and

326
00:16:00.043 --> 00:16:04.220
I get chunk one here, two here, three
here, spread across the three drives.

327
00:16:04.220 --> 00:16:06.741
And then when it gets to chunk
number four, it jumps right back.

328
00:16:06.741 --> 00:16:09.550
And now we're on Drive 1 gets Block 4.

329
00:16:09.550 --> 00:16:10.910
Drive 2 gets Block 5.

330
00:16:10.910 --> 00:16:13.070
Drive 3 gets Block 6, and so on.

331
00:16:13.070 --> 00:16:15.210
It's spreading it across the drives.

332
00:16:15.210 --> 00:16:19.610
That means when I write, I've got three
pieces of hardware doing the write.

333
00:16:19.610 --> 00:16:22.090
I can write three times as fast.

334
00:16:22.090 --> 00:16:24.350
And when I read, I've got three
pieces of hardware doing the read.

335
00:16:24.350 --> 00:16:26.050
I can read three times as fast.

336
00:16:26.050 --> 00:16:28.030
So RAID 0 is all about speed.

337
00:16:28.030 --> 00:16:30.620
If I have three drives,
I'm three times as fast.

338
00:16:30.620 --> 00:16:32.050
If I have five drives, I'm five times.

339
00:16:32.050 --> 00:16:34.550
If I have ten drives,
I'm ten times as fast.

340
00:16:34.550 --> 00:16:39.330
So the more hard drives the better
when it comes to RAID 0, all right.

341
00:16:39.330 --> 00:16:40.830
Here's the problem.

342
00:16:40.830 --> 00:16:45.180
If any one of these disks fail,
all of my data is gone.

343
00:16:45.180 --> 00:16:45.800
Right?

344
00:16:45.800 --> 00:16:48.730
Because, like here in my example I've
got three drives, if I lose one drive,

345
00:16:48.730 --> 00:16:50.350
I just lost a third of my data.

346
00:16:50.350 --> 00:16:53.400
If I lose a third of my database,
what am I left with?

347
00:16:53.400 --> 00:16:54.480
A corrupt database.

348
00:16:54.480 --> 00:16:55.000
Right?

349
00:16:55.000 --> 00:16:57.350
So, I don't get any redundancy.

350
00:16:57.350 --> 00:16:59.710
If I'm just looking for
performance, this is it.

351
00:16:59.710 --> 00:17:01.840
Now, some of you guys have probably
put this out of your mind now,

352
00:17:01.840 --> 00:17:04.130
saying well I'm never going to do RAID 0,
let me throw that out.

353
00:17:04.130 --> 00:17:05.300
Don't do that.

354
00:17:05.300 --> 00:17:10.220
Because what if you're running something
like where you have database copies?

355
00:17:10.220 --> 00:17:12.130
All right?
Yes, I'm running RAID 0.

356
00:17:12.130 --> 00:17:15.060
But, I've got a copy of
the database on another server.

357
00:17:15.060 --> 00:17:17.950
So if I have a failure here,
I just flip over to the copy.

358
00:17:17.950 --> 00:17:20.390
In the meantime, I get great performance.

359
00:17:20.390 --> 00:17:22.210
I might not have a failure for
three years.

360
00:17:22.210 --> 00:17:26.160
So for three years, I get screaming
performance and when a failure happens,

361
00:17:26.160 --> 00:17:29.800
I just failover to the other node
versus building redundancy and

362
00:17:29.800 --> 00:17:32.830
now I get less performance for those three
years when everything was running fine.

363
00:17:32.830 --> 00:17:34.890
Right?
So Raid 0.

364
00:17:34.890 --> 00:17:35.760
Don't just throw that out.

365
00:17:35.760 --> 00:17:36.760
Don't discount it.

366
00:17:36.760 --> 00:17:38.100
It's very practical.

367
00:17:38.100 --> 00:17:39.210
It's very fast.

368
00:17:39.210 --> 00:17:42.790
It will give you the best performance,
the more drives the better.

369
00:17:42.790 --> 00:17:46.370
Raid 0 works great for pretty much
everything, operating system, database,

370
00:17:46.370 --> 00:17:50.340
transaction logs, page file,
it optimizes reads, it optimizes rights,

371
00:17:50.340 --> 00:17:51.690
it's great for everything.

372
00:17:51.690 --> 00:17:55.190
It's just not redundant and so
a lot of people don't use it.

373
00:17:55.190 --> 00:17:59.608
If we want redundancy, our first
option is RAID 1, RAID 1 is mirroring.

374
00:17:59.608 --> 00:18:05.210
With RAID 1, you write to one disk and
it clones it to another disk.

375
00:18:05.210 --> 00:18:09.059
So here you'll see where I've written
the one disk block 1, block 2, block 3 and

376
00:18:09.059 --> 00:18:11.650
then those blocks just get
cloned over to my other disk.

377
00:18:11.650 --> 00:18:13.610
Block 1, block 2, block 3.

378
00:18:13.610 --> 00:18:17.080
If the first disk fails, I got a second
disk and all my data is there.

379
00:18:17.080 --> 00:18:18.080
It's great.

380
00:18:18.080 --> 00:18:19.020
Right?

381
00:18:19.020 --> 00:18:21.220
Well, here's the thing about RAID 1,

382
00:18:21.220 --> 00:18:25.202
rather mirrors, it doesn't really
help you as far as performance.

383
00:18:25.202 --> 00:18:27.630
When I write my data,
what do I have to do?

384
00:18:27.630 --> 00:18:29.880
I have it write it twice, right?

385
00:18:29.880 --> 00:18:32.080
I write to one disk and
I have write to the other one.

386
00:18:32.080 --> 00:18:34.180
It kind of hurts a little bit, right?

387
00:18:34.180 --> 00:18:35.680
But usually your RAID
controller does that.

388
00:18:35.680 --> 00:18:37.680
It's on your hardware, so
you don't even notice it.

389
00:18:37.680 --> 00:18:41.555
So when you write to your disk, it's the
same as if you were writing to one disk.

390
00:18:41.555 --> 00:18:45.270
And when you read from it, same thing,
you're reading from one disk.

391
00:18:45.270 --> 00:18:47.320
So you're really don't
get any improvements.

392
00:18:47.320 --> 00:18:52.530
RAID 0 was all about performance,
RAID 1 is all about redundancy.

393
00:18:52.530 --> 00:18:54.500
If I'm just looking to get redundancy,
I can get RAID 1.

394
00:18:54.500 --> 00:18:56.852
It will not change my performance at all.

395
00:18:56.852 --> 00:18:57.450
My performance,

396
00:18:57.450 --> 00:19:00.590
my system will be the same, assuming
I have a hardware RAID controller.

397
00:19:00.590 --> 00:19:01.930
If you have a software RAID,

398
00:19:01.930 --> 00:19:04.900
if you're just doing software
RAID instead of hardware, don't.

399
00:19:04.900 --> 00:19:08.670
It sounds funny when we say that,
but software RAID is designed for

400
00:19:08.670 --> 00:19:09.620
workstations.

401
00:19:09.620 --> 00:19:12.750
On a server,
software RAID kills your throughput.

402
00:19:12.750 --> 00:19:15.600
When you're writing to the disk,
the CPU has to get involved.

403
00:19:15.600 --> 00:19:17.830
So now you're moving
storage through your CPU.

404
00:19:17.830 --> 00:19:19.050
It's terrible for performance.

405
00:19:19.050 --> 00:19:20.020
Don't do it on a server.

406
00:19:20.020 --> 00:19:21.500
Software RAID is a bad idea.

407
00:19:21.500 --> 00:19:24.350
But hardware RAID,
you don't even notice it.

408
00:19:24.350 --> 00:19:25.580
It all happens in hardware.

409
00:19:25.580 --> 00:19:28.630
It moves right through the disk,
great solution.

410
00:19:28.630 --> 00:19:29.240
All right.
So,

411
00:19:29.240 --> 00:19:32.610
RAID 1 doesn't necessary seem
like the greatest thing, right?

412
00:19:32.610 --> 00:19:34.920
Well, there are sometimes
where it's useful.

413
00:19:34.920 --> 00:19:39.040
It's useful when you only
have one person writing.

414
00:19:39.040 --> 00:19:41.680
So, when are times that we
only have one person writing?

415
00:19:41.680 --> 00:19:43.640
Well, there's things like our page file.

416
00:19:43.640 --> 00:19:44.960
Who writes the page file?

417
00:19:44.960 --> 00:19:46.610
Your operating system.

418
00:19:46.610 --> 00:19:49.080
No software is allowed to
directly touch the page file.

419
00:19:49.080 --> 00:19:51.110
It all has to go through
the operating system, and

420
00:19:51.110 --> 00:19:53.800
then the OS writes to the page file.

421
00:19:53.800 --> 00:19:56.940
So is the OS ever trying to write to more
than one place in the page file at a time?

422
00:19:56.940 --> 00:19:57.670
No.

423
00:19:57.670 --> 00:19:59.510
It does it all in serial.

424
00:19:59.510 --> 00:20:03.830
So, when you have something like that,
RAID 1 is really handy.

425
00:20:03.830 --> 00:20:08.640
So I'll oftentimes use RAID 1 for the
drives where I store my operating system,

426
00:20:08.640 --> 00:20:11.850
and the drives where I store my page file,
and a lot of times I'll use it for

427
00:20:11.850 --> 00:20:14.670
the files where I store my
transactions logs also.

428
00:20:14.670 --> 00:20:19.170
Transaction logs can be write-heavy,
but it's just one

429
00:20:19.170 --> 00:20:22.610
service that's writing to it, so you don't
get a lot of write contention for it.

430
00:20:22.610 --> 00:20:24.060
And so it works great for those.

431
00:20:24.060 --> 00:20:26.800
So, for your OS, for
your transaction logs, for

432
00:20:26.800 --> 00:20:28.350
your page file, RAID 1 can really work.

433
00:20:29.430 --> 00:20:32.300
But there's times where you
want better performance.

434
00:20:32.300 --> 00:20:36.340
Maybe you've got so
much incoming email that your transaction

435
00:20:36.340 --> 00:20:39.520
logs aren't writing fast enough on RAID 1,
so you want something better.

436
00:20:39.520 --> 00:20:42.900
But you still want redundancy, and
that's where RAID 5 comes along.

437
00:20:42.900 --> 00:20:47.250
RAID 5 tries to give us
a bit of a compromise.

438
00:20:47.250 --> 00:20:51.910
A compromise between performance and
redundancy, right?

439
00:20:51.910 --> 00:20:54.732
With this one, your data gets striped.

440
00:20:54.732 --> 00:20:58.400
And [LAUGH] my slide is slightly
incorrect here, let me correct this.

441
00:20:58.400 --> 00:21:01.390
So when we write our data,
your data gets divided into blocks.

442
00:21:01.390 --> 00:21:04.008
So let's say I've got six
blocks of data that I write.

443
00:21:04.008 --> 00:21:06.870
So block 1 gets written to
the first drive, block 2

444
00:21:06.870 --> 00:21:10.830
gets written to the second drive, and then
parity gets written to the third drive.

445
00:21:10.830 --> 00:21:14.490
And then my other blocks
are just being divided up and

446
00:21:14.490 --> 00:21:17.800
written across the drive in stripes,
so block 1, block 2,

447
00:21:17.800 --> 00:21:22.310
block 3, block 4, block 5, block 6,
all spread across the drives.

448
00:21:23.670 --> 00:21:26.870
Then, across the drives,

449
00:21:26.870 --> 00:21:31.550
there's what are called parity blocks, and
the parity blocks are just a simple little

450
00:21:31.550 --> 00:21:36.380
XOR operation that happens that allows
us to rebuild data if we lose it.

451
00:21:36.380 --> 00:21:38.520
And I don't wanna go too
crazy into the details.

452
00:21:38.520 --> 00:21:39.850
Most of you guys probably
already know this, but

453
00:21:39.850 --> 00:21:44.490
just that, at a high level,
if I write a 1 to this drive, and

454
00:21:44.490 --> 00:21:48.160
I write a 0 to this drive,
I can add those together.

455
00:21:48.160 --> 00:21:49.420
1 plus 0 is 1.

456
00:21:49.420 --> 00:21:52.350
1 is an odd number.

457
00:21:52.350 --> 00:21:55.480
And so we can make a note here
in the parody block that says,

458
00:21:55.480 --> 00:21:57.770
the parity calculation is odd.

459
00:21:57.770 --> 00:22:00.940
Or if it's 1 and 1, those add up to 2,
that's an even number.

460
00:22:00.940 --> 00:22:04.080
So I can put a note here that says
the parity calculation is even.

461
00:22:04.080 --> 00:22:08.781
And then, if I lose one drive, so if one
hard drive completely fails, I can look at

462
00:22:08.781 --> 00:22:13.160
the data I have, and I can look at parity
and I can say should it be even or odd?

463
00:22:13.160 --> 00:22:16.730
And I can use that to figure out whether
it should've been a 1 or a 0 here.

464
00:22:16.730 --> 00:22:21.120
I rebuild the data and
I survive failure, right?

465
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:24.850
RAID 5 allows us to stripe,
which gets more than

466
00:22:24.850 --> 00:22:28.260
one hard drive writing a reading,
that gives us a boost in performance.

467
00:22:28.260 --> 00:22:31.290
And it allows us to recover
from a single drive of failure.

468
00:22:31.290 --> 00:22:32.170
All right.

469
00:22:32.170 --> 00:22:34.290
But there's two problems with RAID 5.

470
00:22:34.290 --> 00:22:38.716
The first problem is whenever you write,
you write to the drive and

471
00:22:38.716 --> 00:22:41.500
you've gotta calculate parity.

472
00:22:41.500 --> 00:22:45.440
Now there's a mathematical operation
being tacked onto every write operation.

473
00:22:45.440 --> 00:22:47.860
If you have a hardware RAID controller
it'll take care of that, but

474
00:22:47.860 --> 00:22:49.920
if you're doing software
you're CPU's doing it.

475
00:22:49.920 --> 00:22:51.640
It's terrible for performance.

476
00:22:51.640 --> 00:22:54.570
So writing to RAID 5 can
be a little more sluggish

477
00:22:54.570 --> 00:22:57.530
because you're having to do
this mathematical operation.

478
00:22:57.530 --> 00:22:58.730
Reads aren't affected by that.

479
00:22:58.730 --> 00:23:02.000
When you do a read you don't have to read
the parity bit unless there's a failure so

480
00:23:02.000 --> 00:23:03.630
you're just reading the regular data.

481
00:23:03.630 --> 00:23:07.080
But notice how each stripe
has one parity block.

482
00:23:07.080 --> 00:23:10.300
So each stripe is one block
shorter than it normally would be.

483
00:23:10.300 --> 00:23:13.227
And in my example where I have
three drives, I can never read for

484
00:23:13.227 --> 00:23:15.090
more than two at a time.

485
00:23:15.090 --> 00:23:18.820
And so I don't get as big of
a performance boost as I did with RAID 0.

486
00:23:18.820 --> 00:23:21.380
RAID 0 gets us great performance.

487
00:23:21.380 --> 00:23:23.950
RAID 5 sacrifices some of this.

488
00:23:23.950 --> 00:23:27.710
That being said, this can be really
suitable for a mailbox database.

489
00:23:27.710 --> 00:23:31.290
If you got a mailbox database, and you're
not really concerned about huge write

490
00:23:31.290 --> 00:23:34.620
performance, cuz just your transaction
logs are getting written to it,

491
00:23:34.620 --> 00:23:38.312
then here you can get reboosts,
but still have redundancy.

492
00:23:38.312 --> 00:23:40.540
So it's a great solution for
your mailbox database.

493
00:23:41.700 --> 00:23:43.120
I don't like to use it though.

494
00:23:43.120 --> 00:23:45.790
And the main reason is
when you have a failure,

495
00:23:45.790 --> 00:23:48.070
you can still read from the disk
without having to calculate parity.

496
00:23:48.070 --> 00:23:50.720
And that means your reads
are all gonna be slower.

497
00:23:50.720 --> 00:23:53.330
So during a failure, reads are slow.

498
00:23:53.330 --> 00:23:55.012
And then when you put a new disk in,

499
00:23:55.012 --> 00:23:57.861
it's gotta rebuild everything
that used be on that disk.

500
00:23:57.861 --> 00:23:59.201
And that takes time.

501
00:23:59.201 --> 00:24:03.241
During that time you could have another
disk fail and now you lose all your data.

502
00:24:03.241 --> 00:24:10.053
And so RAID 5 has sluggish reads during
failure and you're at risk during failure.

503
00:24:10.053 --> 00:24:11.260
You can only lose one drive.

504
00:24:11.260 --> 00:24:13.986
If you lose second drive
all you're data's gone, so

505
00:24:13.986 --> 00:24:16.600
as a result I tend not to use
RAID 5 if I can avoid it.

506
00:24:17.600 --> 00:24:20.380
Instead, RAID 10.

507
00:24:20.380 --> 00:24:25.050
RAID 10 is probably the best solution for
a mailbox database.

508
00:24:25.050 --> 00:24:27.510
If you've got a mailbox database,
and you want great performance and

509
00:24:27.510 --> 00:24:29.770
great redundancy,
RAID 10's a great solution.

510
00:24:30.930 --> 00:24:36.060
What RAID 10 does is it combines RAID 1,
which is all about performance and RAID 0,

511
00:24:36.060 --> 00:24:40.840
which is all about redundancy, and puts
the two together to create a super team.

512
00:24:40.840 --> 00:24:42.740
And this super team's pretty amazing.

513
00:24:42.740 --> 00:24:46.440
The way it works is it
basically stripes your data.

514
00:24:46.440 --> 00:24:51.120
So here I've got block 1 written to this
drive, block 2 written to this drive,

515
00:24:51.120 --> 00:24:54.050
block 3 written back to the first drive,
block 4 to the second drive,

516
00:24:54.050 --> 00:24:56.960
block 5 to the first drive,
block 6 to the second drive.

517
00:24:56.960 --> 00:24:58.679
So it's striping across these disks.

518
00:24:59.730 --> 00:25:02.780
But then it mirrors the disks.

519
00:25:02.780 --> 00:25:05.050
So I've got block 1 here and block 1 here.

520
00:25:05.050 --> 00:25:06.580
Block 3 here, block 3 here.

521
00:25:06.580 --> 00:25:09.560
I've got these duplicates of the data.

522
00:25:09.560 --> 00:25:14.010
So when we look at this,
I've got great performance.

523
00:25:14.010 --> 00:25:17.770
When I wanna read from this,
I can read from multiple disks.

524
00:25:17.770 --> 00:25:19.700
And when I write I can
write to multiple disks.

525
00:25:19.700 --> 00:25:22.350
And if I have a failure I don't
have to calculate parity,

526
00:25:22.350 --> 00:25:23.830
I've just got another
disk I can read from.

527
00:25:23.830 --> 00:25:25.110
The data's already there.

528
00:25:25.110 --> 00:25:28.830
So now we get great performance
even during a failure, and

529
00:25:28.830 --> 00:25:32.160
when it comes time to rebuild
a disk if I have to replace one

530
00:25:32.160 --> 00:25:33.920
I don't have to do
a mathematical operation.

531
00:25:33.920 --> 00:25:35.610
I just copy the data from here.

532
00:25:35.610 --> 00:25:38.810
So it rebuilds way
faster than RAID 5 does.

533
00:25:38.810 --> 00:25:40.430
RAID 10 is great.

534
00:25:40.430 --> 00:25:42.420
Now, it does have its negatives, though.

535
00:25:42.420 --> 00:25:43.710
It's expensive.

536
00:25:43.710 --> 00:25:46.490
I'm wasting 50% of my disks.

537
00:25:46.490 --> 00:25:48.800
Half my disks are dedicated to the mirror.

538
00:25:48.800 --> 00:25:49.910
So I have to buy drives.

539
00:25:49.910 --> 00:25:51.620
Now that used to be a big problem.

540
00:25:51.620 --> 00:25:53.200
Today hard drives are cheap, right?

541
00:25:53.200 --> 00:25:54.290
It's not expensive.

542
00:25:54.290 --> 00:25:58.600
The only expensive part is making sure
you have enough drive ports these days.

543
00:25:58.600 --> 00:26:03.110
So we can stack 14, 30,
100 hard drives, and get

544
00:26:03.110 --> 00:26:06.320
really amazing RAID 10 arrays built out
of that, and get some great performance.

545
00:26:07.460 --> 00:26:10.190
So when we start to divide our server up,
when we say,

546
00:26:10.190 --> 00:26:14.210
all right I've got my operating system
drive, I've got my page file drive,

547
00:26:14.210 --> 00:26:18.100
I've got my transaction logs,
and I got my mailbox database.

548
00:26:18.100 --> 00:26:19.850
How do I wanna divide that up?

549
00:26:19.850 --> 00:26:24.670
A lot of times I'll do RAID 1 mirroring
for the operating system, and

550
00:26:24.670 --> 00:26:28.120
RAID 1 mirroring for the page file.

551
00:26:28.120 --> 00:26:31.360
And then if it's a small or
medium environment, I'll do RAID 1 for

552
00:26:31.360 --> 00:26:34.920
the transaction logs, and
RAID 5 for the mailbox database.

553
00:26:34.920 --> 00:26:36.560
If it's a large environment, or

554
00:26:36.560 --> 00:26:39.570
just an environment that really cares
about performance and has a ton of money,

555
00:26:39.570 --> 00:26:43.670
then I'll do RAID 10 for the transaction
logs and RAID 10 for the mailbox database.

556
00:26:43.670 --> 00:26:45.540
It all comes down to
performance at that point.

557
00:26:45.540 --> 00:26:47.400
But these are things
that we have to chose.

558
00:26:47.400 --> 00:26:51.850
So in my example where I started moving
my mailbox database around to other

559
00:26:51.850 --> 00:26:56.640
hard drives, these hard drives,
some of them might be RAID 5,

560
00:26:56.640 --> 00:26:59.110
they might be RAID 10,
they might be RAID 1.

561
00:26:59.110 --> 00:27:00.570
That's gonna impact performance.

562
00:27:00.570 --> 00:27:04.610
And we need to understand that so
we put our data where it really belongs,

563
00:27:04.610 --> 00:27:06.810
where it's really gonna get
us the best performance.

564
00:27:06.810 --> 00:27:10.050
Because on your system,
your hard drive is the slowest part.

565
00:27:10.050 --> 00:27:12.010
So reading and
writing that mailbox database,

566
00:27:12.010 --> 00:27:14.630
that's what's gonna make your
Exchange server fast or slow.

567
00:27:14.630 --> 00:27:16.900
And it's all about disk
tuning to provide that.

568
00:27:16.900 --> 00:27:20.442
So definitely important stuff that you
wanna make sure that you're aware of.

569
00:27:20.442 --> 00:27:23.290
>> All right, we're gonna talk about
redundancy in another episode too.

570
00:27:23.290 --> 00:27:26.490
We might maintain more than one copy
of our database which can help in

571
00:27:26.490 --> 00:27:28.900
some scenarios as far as performance too.

572
00:27:28.900 --> 00:27:31.260
But what you do on the disk,
that's what's really important.

573
00:27:32.722 --> 00:27:34.960
All right, well that's about it for
this episode.

574
00:27:34.960 --> 00:27:37.670
So in this segment we got a chance
to see how to tune our disks and

575
00:27:37.670 --> 00:27:40.880
some of the different options there for
rearranging where our mailbox database and

576
00:27:40.880 --> 00:27:42.310
transaction log files go.

577
00:27:42.310 --> 00:27:45.620
To really create that optimal performance
inside of Microsoft Exchange.

578
00:27:45.620 --> 00:27:47.980
So we'll go ahead and
wrap this one up right there.

579
00:27:47.980 --> 00:27:53.595
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

580
00:27:53.595 --> 00:27:58.780
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the Exchange 2013 public folder functionality. He discusses how to create and configure public folders. He wraps up the episode by demonstrating how to set permissions and load data into a public folder.
episodes.title: Public Folders
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.461 --> 00:00:10.641
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.641 --> 00:00:13.281
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening,

3
00:00:13.281 --> 00:00:15.381
and welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.381 --> 00:00:16.368
I'm your host,

5
00:00:16.368 --> 00:00:21.050
Don Pezet, back again with another
episode of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:21.050 --> 00:00:23.580
And this is a fun one because
we're going to be talking about

7
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:25.320
public folders in this episode.

8
00:00:25.320 --> 00:00:28.710
And let me tell you,
I've worked with Exchange a long time and

9
00:00:28.710 --> 00:00:33.870
I remember when I was teaching
a Microsoft Exchange 2000 course.

10
00:00:33.870 --> 00:00:35.990
This was 15 years ago.

11
00:00:35.990 --> 00:00:38.430
And I had to tell all my students, hey,

12
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:41.730
if you guys are using public folders,
you need to move away from them.

13
00:00:41.730 --> 00:00:43.400
Microsoft is ending support for them.

14
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:45.560
You need to get away from public folders.

15
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:49.630
But there was this huge public outcry,
and so when Exchange 2003 came out,

16
00:00:49.630 --> 00:00:52.090
Microsoft said, well,
we're going to keep public folders for

17
00:00:52.090 --> 00:00:55.060
now, but
everybody needs to get away from them.

18
00:00:55.060 --> 00:00:57.540
And then Exchange 2007, well,
we'll keep those public folders, but

19
00:00:57.540 --> 00:00:59.550
everyone needs to get away from them.

20
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:03.140
And then Exchange 2010 and now Exchange
2013 and we still have public folders.

21
00:01:03.140 --> 00:01:05.610
Let me tell you guys,
they're not going anywhere.

22
00:01:05.610 --> 00:01:08.930
It's been the thing that Microsoft has
said all this time, they're going away,

23
00:01:08.930 --> 00:01:10.120
they're going away.

24
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:11.500
Nah, they're still here.

25
00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:13.260
And let me tell you what's going on.

26
00:01:13.260 --> 00:01:17.528
Back in the older versions of Exchange,
really all the way up through Exchange

27
00:01:17.528 --> 00:01:21.660
2010, public folders were
a special type of database.

28
00:01:21.660 --> 00:01:23.300
If you've never worked
with public folders,

29
00:01:23.300 --> 00:01:27.040
basically what it was was like
a file system inside of Exchange.

30
00:01:27.040 --> 00:01:29.130
Normally Microsoft Exchange
is an email program.

31
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:31.170
We send emails back and
forward to people and

32
00:01:31.170 --> 00:01:33.520
it stores them as emails
in the email database.

33
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:35.210
Even when you create calendar items and

34
00:01:35.210 --> 00:01:38.730
tasks, in the background they're
really being stored as emails.

35
00:01:38.730 --> 00:01:40.600
It's all just kinda emails in a mailbox.

36
00:01:40.600 --> 00:01:42.750
Well, public folders weren't like that.

37
00:01:42.750 --> 00:01:46.480
There was a special database, and
when you created a public folder and

38
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:50.610
you threw files in there, well,
it was going into this special database.

39
00:01:50.610 --> 00:01:53.190
And Microsoft has other products
that do a better job of that.

40
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:55.240
Exchange is not a very good file server.

41
00:01:56.400 --> 00:01:58.980
This was a feature that was
added 20 years ago that

42
00:01:58.980 --> 00:02:02.250
was really just designed as a temporary
thing to compete with Novell Groupware,

43
00:02:02.250 --> 00:02:05.700
and now that's not
really an issue anymore.

44
00:02:06.850 --> 00:02:09.170
So why do we even still have it?

45
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:12.150
Well, Microsoft says you should
be moving over to SharePoint.

46
00:02:12.150 --> 00:02:14.810
Microsoft SharePoint's a better
place to put your files and

47
00:02:14.810 --> 00:02:16.020
you can get at your data that way.

48
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:17.600
Don't put it in Exchange, right?

49
00:02:17.600 --> 00:02:18.510
Great.

50
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:20.560
But a lot of people still
use public folders.

51
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:21.620
They want that access.

52
00:02:21.620 --> 00:02:24.510
They want their end users to be able
to launch Microsoft Outlook and be

53
00:02:24.510 --> 00:02:27.580
able to browse into their inbox, and then
be able to browse into a public folder and

54
00:02:27.580 --> 00:02:30.480
access reports and
other things all in one place.

55
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:33.050
So what Microsoft did is in Exchange 2013,
they said, all right,

56
00:02:33.050 --> 00:02:34.680
here's what we're gonna do.

57
00:02:34.680 --> 00:02:36.190
Instead of trying to get
rid of public folders,

58
00:02:36.190 --> 00:02:38.960
that's never gonna happen,
let's just change them.

59
00:02:38.960 --> 00:02:42.800
Let's make it where public folders
are stored like emails, and

60
00:02:42.800 --> 00:02:46.660
then we don't have this separate special
magical database we have to deal with.

61
00:02:46.660 --> 00:02:50.350
It's just a regular old mailbox that's
stored just like everything else.

62
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:53.420
And that way our database availability
groups work, our replications, our

63
00:02:53.420 --> 00:02:56.940
backups, our restores, all that works like
normal and it's not a special database.

64
00:02:56.940 --> 00:03:00.130
And that's really what Microsoft
was trying to get away from anyway.

65
00:03:00.130 --> 00:03:02.550
So in 2013 they fixed that.

66
00:03:02.550 --> 00:03:03.510
So Exchange 2013,

67
00:03:03.510 --> 00:03:06.880
our public folders are really just
stored in a mailbox in the back-end, and

68
00:03:06.880 --> 00:03:11.150
it's right along as a regular mailbox
database would be, and it's no big deal.

69
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:13.310
So they're actually kind
of pleasant to work with.

70
00:03:13.310 --> 00:03:15.180
Let's take a look at how it works out.

71
00:03:15.180 --> 00:03:17.420
So here I am in my Exchange admin center.

72
00:03:17.420 --> 00:03:21.600
And I know if I go down here to my
servers, I can go over to databases and

73
00:03:21.600 --> 00:03:23.390
I can see my mailbox databases.

74
00:03:23.390 --> 00:03:26.950
And in previous versions of Exchange you
also had your public folder databases.

75
00:03:26.950 --> 00:03:28.320
But I don't have that.

76
00:03:28.320 --> 00:03:31.050
I do have my public
folders link over here and

77
00:03:31.050 --> 00:03:35.660
notice instead of public folder databases
I have public folder mailboxes.

78
00:03:35.660 --> 00:03:38.140
Now to the end user they're not
gonna notice the difference.

79
00:03:38.140 --> 00:03:39.960
Doesn't mean a single thing to them.

80
00:03:39.960 --> 00:03:42.460
But to us as the admins, it is.

81
00:03:42.460 --> 00:03:44.900
It's a mail box, it's not a database.

82
00:03:44.900 --> 00:03:46.830
So two big benefits of that.

83
00:03:46.830 --> 00:03:49.540
One, we're not having to support
a completely separate database.

84
00:03:49.540 --> 00:03:54.400
And two, any redundancy that we've
set up for our mailbox databases now

85
00:03:54.400 --> 00:03:58.600
applies to the public folders too, so we
don't have to have a separate replication.

86
00:03:58.600 --> 00:04:03.370
It makes our job so much easier but
it is different, so I want to show you

87
00:04:03.370 --> 00:04:07.480
guys how this works and how it kinda gets
set up, so you get a chance to see this.

88
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:09.850
It is important to make sure that
you understand the differences.

89
00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:14.430
You might be tempted when you get in here
to just start creating folders right here.

90
00:04:14.430 --> 00:04:17.250
It's got it where you can hit
the plus sign and start to create it.

91
00:04:17.250 --> 00:04:19.100
But you'll notice there's
a little warning here, and

92
00:04:19.100 --> 00:04:22.270
it says,
before you create a public folder,

93
00:04:22.270 --> 00:04:26.270
please make sure that you created
at least one public folder mailbox.

94
00:04:26.270 --> 00:04:28.260
You have to have a mailbox
to store this stuff in.

95
00:04:29.260 --> 00:04:31.210
Otherwise you can't create the folders.

96
00:04:31.210 --> 00:04:34.610
And that's why I've got this other option
here, the public folder mailboxes.

97
00:04:34.610 --> 00:04:38.950
Now for most companies you're
only gonna need one mailbox.

98
00:04:38.950 --> 00:04:42.630
The first mailbox you create is what's
called the primary public folder mailbox

99
00:04:42.630 --> 00:04:45.860
and it's a read-write copy of your data.

100
00:04:45.860 --> 00:04:51.530
If you create any more mailboxes, they're
secondary mailboxes and they're read only.

101
00:04:51.530 --> 00:04:52.561
You can't write to them.

102
00:04:52.561 --> 00:04:54.130
Now why would I want that?

103
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:55.400
Why would I want read-only
copies of the data?

104
00:04:55.400 --> 00:04:57.080
That's kinda pointless, isn't it?

105
00:04:57.080 --> 00:04:59.800
Well, it's not, for redundancy.

106
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:03.680
If I want to store a copy of my public
folders on a server here in Gainesville,

107
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:08.940
Florida, and I want to store another
copy in London, England, well,

108
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:13.280
it's kind of difficult to have a writable
copy of a mailbox in two different places.

109
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:17.800
But I could have a writable copy here and
put a readable copy in London.

110
00:05:17.800 --> 00:05:21.080
And that way, any of my users over there
in England could access it locally over

111
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:22.920
there, access and read the data.

112
00:05:22.920 --> 00:05:26.690
And only when they change data would
it need to come to the server here.

113
00:05:26.690 --> 00:05:30.880
So that gives us a lot better performance
cuz most people are just reading data.

114
00:05:30.880 --> 00:05:33.910
Writes are far less frequent
inside of a public folder.

115
00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:36.730
So we can create multiple mailboxes for
redundancy.

116
00:05:36.730 --> 00:05:38.470
But for most of us we just need the one.

117
00:05:38.470 --> 00:05:41.070
We create it and then we'll be
able to use that to set things up.

118
00:05:41.070 --> 00:05:42.530
So let's see that here in action.

119
00:05:42.530 --> 00:05:45.710
So I'm going to start by creating
my first public folder mailbox.

120
00:05:45.710 --> 00:05:46.971
And so I need to give it a name.

121
00:05:46.971 --> 00:05:50.943
I'm just going to call mine my Public
Folder Mailbox because I'm not terribly

122
00:05:50.943 --> 00:05:51.880
creative.

123
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:54.020
But if I was going to be putting
this in a different country,

124
00:05:54.020 --> 00:05:57.380
I might call this one my public
folder replica London or

125
00:05:57.380 --> 00:06:00.510
public folder replica Paris, and
that way I'd just know where it's tied to.

126
00:06:01.550 --> 00:06:03.870
And then right here you can specify
the organizational unit and

127
00:06:03.870 --> 00:06:08.150
the AD that this mailbox will be a part
of, and then the mailbox database.

128
00:06:08.150 --> 00:06:10.810
Here's how we pick where it's gonna be.

129
00:06:10.810 --> 00:06:13.410
I can pick a mailbox database
right here in Florida, or

130
00:06:13.410 --> 00:06:16.210
I can pick a mailbox database
that's on a server in London.

131
00:06:16.210 --> 00:06:18.150
I'm picking which database
it's gonna reside in.

132
00:06:18.150 --> 00:06:19.520
And I can always move it later on.

133
00:06:19.520 --> 00:06:22.030
You can move mailboxes
from database to database.

134
00:06:22.030 --> 00:06:24.797
So we can change our mind
pretty easily after the fact.

135
00:06:24.797 --> 00:06:28.085
So I'm gonna go ahead and
hit Browse in the mailbox database and

136
00:06:28.085 --> 00:06:30.080
just choose one of my databases here.

137
00:06:30.080 --> 00:06:31.948
I'll go with my default
database on this one.

138
00:06:31.948 --> 00:06:33.490
I'm not gonna pick an OU.

139
00:06:33.490 --> 00:06:35.340
That just means it'll
go to the default OU.

140
00:06:35.340 --> 00:06:37.310
You could browse and
pick one if you wanted.

141
00:06:37.310 --> 00:06:38.960
If you leave them empty it
just goes to the defaults.

142
00:06:40.470 --> 00:06:43.650
All right, so that's gonna get my
public folder mailbox created.

143
00:06:43.650 --> 00:06:47.810
This is what's replacing the old way
where I go and create a database.

144
00:06:47.810 --> 00:06:51.380
Now it's just using the existing mailbox
database and parking this mailbox in it.

145
00:06:52.980 --> 00:06:57.430
Once I've got that,
now I can go to my public folders and

146
00:06:57.430 --> 00:06:59.250
I can start to work with this.

147
00:06:59.250 --> 00:07:01.700
Now you actually do have
one folder by default.

148
00:07:01.700 --> 00:07:02.290
It's the root.

149
00:07:02.290 --> 00:07:04.010
See this little slash right here?

150
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:07.390
That's letting me know that I'm
in the root of my public folder.

151
00:07:07.390 --> 00:07:12.530
And I can start to create subfolders
underneath it to store data.

152
00:07:12.530 --> 00:07:14.600
And the way you see this
used most commonly is we

153
00:07:14.600 --> 00:07:16.370
create departmental folders.

154
00:07:16.370 --> 00:07:19.830
So I might come in here and create
a folder called Sales for my salespeople.

155
00:07:21.430 --> 00:07:25.160
And then under Sales I might
create Marketing or other ones.

156
00:07:25.160 --> 00:07:27.149
You just start to kinda
branch these things out.

157
00:07:29.130 --> 00:07:32.210
So I got Sales, I've got Marketing,
and I start creating folders for

158
00:07:32.210 --> 00:07:34.480
each of these different organizations.

159
00:07:34.480 --> 00:07:37.400
You can create subfolders
underneath them too.

160
00:07:37.400 --> 00:07:41.030
So maybe you like to have your public
folders broken down by region, and

161
00:07:41.030 --> 00:07:43.930
then inside of a region you have sales and
marketing, or whatever.

162
00:07:43.930 --> 00:07:48.740
Or maybe inside of sales, I wanna break
that up by region or state, however it is.

163
00:07:48.740 --> 00:07:50.860
So under Sales I might
create a new folder.

164
00:07:50.860 --> 00:07:53.300
And I'm just going to click on Sales and
see how my path has changed?

165
00:07:53.300 --> 00:07:54.921
I'm now inside of that Sales folder.

166
00:07:54.921 --> 00:07:56.101
And I can hit plus.

167
00:07:56.101 --> 00:08:01.821
I'm going to add in,
maybe I'll do US sales.

168
00:08:01.821 --> 00:08:05.908
And I'll add another folder for maybe
like U.K. sales or Canada, whoever you

169
00:08:05.908 --> 00:08:10.130
know start adding your various countries
who've got the folders that are there.

170
00:08:11.220 --> 00:08:13.608
When I've got those,
if I go back up to my root, right?

171
00:08:13.608 --> 00:08:16.820
And you can just hit this little
arrow to jump back to your root.

172
00:08:16.820 --> 00:08:21.050
See I've got Marketing and Sales and
under Sales it says has sub-folders yes.

173
00:08:21.050 --> 00:08:22.735
I can tell that it does have sub-folders.

174
00:08:22.735 --> 00:08:25.000
And if I browse in I'll see those.

175
00:08:25.000 --> 00:08:27.930
All right,
now why bother creating sales folders?

176
00:08:27.930 --> 00:08:29.500
I mean subfolders.

177
00:08:29.500 --> 00:08:32.350
The only reason to create
subfolders is for permissions.

178
00:08:32.350 --> 00:08:35.800
I can set different permissions on these
folders to dictate who's allowed to

179
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:40.220
read data, who's allowed to write data,
you know, who's allowed to use this stuff.

180
00:08:40.220 --> 00:08:45.310
So for example, my U.S., I might want to
limit that just to my users who are in

181
00:08:45.310 --> 00:08:50.160
the U.S., or limit the U.K. to users who
are just in the U.K. So, I might go up

182
00:08:50.160 --> 00:08:55.450
here to my recipients, and go to groups
and start creating some groups, right?

183
00:08:55.450 --> 00:09:00.670
I might create a security
group called Sales,

184
00:09:00.670 --> 00:09:04.940
which will be like all of my
sales departments, right?

185
00:09:04.940 --> 00:09:07.260
So I can go in and
create one of those, and

186
00:09:07.260 --> 00:09:13.010
then I might create other groups like U.K.
Sales.

187
00:09:13.010 --> 00:09:18.860
And I'll give it an alias, and

188

in these Is to just come in here and

418
00:19:31.090 --> 00:19:31.730
take your stuff.

419
00:19:31.730 --> 00:19:34.980
So like I've got these quarterly sales
reports and we can just drag and

420
00:19:34.980 --> 00:19:37.470
drop those and that's gonna throw them in.

421
00:19:37.470 --> 00:19:40.800
And your Outlook is basically reaching out
to the servers, uploading these files,

422
00:19:40.800 --> 00:19:42.080
and they're being stored here.

423
00:19:42.080 --> 00:19:47.240
Now I know they're files but
Exchange treats them like emails.

424
00:19:47.240 --> 00:19:49.690
That's why they have a name,
they have a subject.

425
00:19:49.690 --> 00:19:53.260
The file itself is actually an attachment,
kinda stuck to it.

426
00:19:53.260 --> 00:19:55.230
And I'm even getting a live preview.

427
00:19:55.230 --> 00:20:00.260
These are RTF files, Rich Text, and so
it's rendering that Rich Text right there.

428
00:20:00.260 --> 00:20:02.070
If I had thrown a picture or something.

429
00:20:02.070 --> 00:20:03.270
Let's see if I can.

430
00:20:03.270 --> 00:20:05.120
We'll steal a picture from the internet.

431
00:20:05.120 --> 00:20:08.950
This is where things get challenging,

432
00:20:08.950 --> 00:20:11.810
is finding a picture
sometimes that's not crazy.

433
00:20:11.810 --> 00:20:15.230
Actually I guess we could just take
one of these banner ads and [LAUGH].

434
00:20:15.230 --> 00:20:17.790
But if we find a picture and save it,
we could throw a picture in there and

435
00:20:17.790 --> 00:20:19.390
you get live previews of these things.

436
00:20:19.390 --> 00:20:23.720
It's kind of neat to be able to work
with those and manipulate them.

437
00:20:23.720 --> 00:20:25.658
I'm gonna save this Microsoft logo.

438
00:20:25.658 --> 00:20:29.930
And we'll just save that into my images.

439
00:20:29.930 --> 00:20:31.550
And we'll take that and throw it in there.

440
00:20:31.550 --> 00:20:34.520
And so it basically turns
Exchange into a file server.

441
00:20:34.520 --> 00:20:36.110
And I know I said at
the beginning of the episode,

442
00:20:36.110 --> 00:20:38.810
Exchange doesn't make the greatest
file server in the world.

443
00:20:38.810 --> 00:20:42.020
And I'm gonna stand by that one because
it's not really what it's designed for.

444
00:20:42.020 --> 00:20:44.990
But you could use SharePoint,
it does a better job or

445
00:20:44.990 --> 00:20:46.290
you could just use a file server.

446
00:20:46.290 --> 00:20:47.990
That's why we have those things.

447
00:20:47.990 --> 00:20:51.620
But here we go I can see it,
I can see the file render right here.

448
00:20:51.620 --> 00:20:54.420
And now I can share it with anybody
else that's in my department

449
00:20:54.420 --> 00:20:56.340
all right inside that public folder.

450
00:20:56.340 --> 00:21:00.170
So if you've heard the news that
public folders are going away.

451
00:21:00.170 --> 00:21:01.690
Well, they really aren't anymore.

452
00:21:01.690 --> 00:21:05.190
They've survived 15 years now of
Microsoft saying they're going away and

453
00:21:05.190 --> 00:21:07.180
in exchange 2013, they're here to stay.

454
00:21:07.180 --> 00:21:09.020
They've been converted to mailboxes.

455
00:21:09.020 --> 00:21:11.300
They're right there in
the mailbox database store.

456
00:21:11.300 --> 00:21:13.334
And that makes them
really low maintenance,

457
00:21:13.334 --> 00:21:16.330
real easy to handle and you get
the database availability group and

458
00:21:16.330 --> 00:21:19.700
other redundancy features you
have with the mailbox database.

459
00:21:19.700 --> 00:21:20.580
All wrapped into one.

460
00:21:20.580 --> 00:21:23.090
So it's a great solution,
definitely something to take advantage of.

461
00:21:24.312 --> 00:21:27.200
All right, well in this show we got
a chance to see what the public folders

462
00:21:27.200 --> 00:21:28.600
are and how to implement them.

463
00:21:28.600 --> 00:21:32.740
How to get the pubic folder mailboxes
created and then create the public folders

464
00:21:32.740 --> 00:21:37.330
themselves inside of the mailbox and get
that up and operational for our end users.

465
00:21:37.330 --> 00:21:39.830
So, that's a great place for
us to wrap this one up.

466
00:21:39.830 --> 00:21:41.170
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

467
00:21:41.170 --> 00:21:44.957
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pizet and I'll see you next time.

468
00:21:44.957 --> 00:21:49.956
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how Microsoft Exchange assembles a Global Address List. He also shows how to create custom address lists suitable for creating filtered address books for the end users. He ends the show describing the offline address book process.
episodes.title: Address Books
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.510 --> 00:00:11.300
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.300 --> 00:00:14.289
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:14.289 --> 00:00:16.290
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.290 --> 00:00:17.840
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.840 --> 00:00:21.370
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:21.370 --> 00:00:22.631
And in today's episode,

7
00:00:22.631 --> 00:00:26.540
we're gonna take a look at something
that is pretty important, address lists.

8
00:00:26.540 --> 00:00:30.035
Now, address lists are something we can
easily ignore inside of Exchange because

9
00:00:30.035 --> 00:00:31.970
there is a default address
list put in place.

10
00:00:31.970 --> 00:00:34.010
And most people use it, and
they're happy with that.

11
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:35.260
And that's kinda the end of it.

12
00:00:35.260 --> 00:00:39.180
But there's a lot of power in the back end
where we can customize those address lists

13
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:40.300
that people overlook.

14
00:00:40.300 --> 00:00:43.580
And it can really be a neat thing
that you can use to your advantage.

15
00:00:43.580 --> 00:00:46.060
So, let me show you
what I'm talking about.

16
00:00:46.060 --> 00:00:46.802
If I'm an end user,

17
00:00:46.802 --> 00:00:49.130
I'm gonna use something like
Microsoft Outlook as my client.

18
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:51.163
And when I go to create a new email,

19
00:00:51.163 --> 00:00:54.630
I have to pick who that
email's being sent to, right?

20
00:00:54.630 --> 00:00:57.280
So you got your To field,
it's terribly exciting.

21
00:00:57.280 --> 00:00:59.470
Now, we've got our own contacts, right?

22
00:00:59.470 --> 00:01:02.360
Each end user has their own
contacts they keep track of, right?

23
00:01:02.360 --> 00:01:04.230
So I can jump down here to People.

24
00:01:04.230 --> 00:01:06.580
And I'll start to see any
contacts that I have.

25
00:01:06.580 --> 00:01:08.180
Those are just for me.

26
00:01:08.180 --> 00:01:13.210
But if I'm an employee in
a company with 10,000 employees,

27
00:01:13.210 --> 00:01:15.450
shouldn't I see the other
10,000 employees?

28
00:01:15.450 --> 00:01:16.025
Well, you can.

29
00:01:16.025 --> 00:01:17.720
They're not in your contacts by default.

30
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:22.142
This is just for your account, but,
we have what's called the global address

31
00:01:22.142 --> 00:01:25.490
list, or the GAL, G-A-L,
global address list.

32
00:01:25.490 --> 00:01:28.920
That contains all of the recipients for
our organization.

33
00:01:28.920 --> 00:01:33.427
And when I say recipients, that means
mailboxes, contacts, groups, distribution

34
00:01:33.427 --> 00:01:37.670
lists, all that kind of stuff, it will
all be in that global address list.

35
00:01:37.670 --> 00:01:41.300
Now, an end user can see it even
when they're crafting a new email.

36
00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:43.880
If I fire up a new email,
and I come in here,

37
00:01:43.880 --> 00:01:47.200
you've got this Address Book
button up here in the email.

38
00:01:47.200 --> 00:01:52.310
And if I choose that, I start to see
my global address list right there.

39
00:01:52.310 --> 00:01:53.920
I can drop that down and choose Contacts.

40
00:01:53.920 --> 00:01:57.133
Now I just see the contacts on my account,
but I can also drop it down and

41
00:01:57.133 --> 00:01:58.510
choose Global Address List.

42
00:01:58.510 --> 00:02:03.970
And I see everybody, users, groups,
all that stuff, it shows up right here.

43
00:02:03.970 --> 00:02:05.620
I can see it, it's available to me.

44
00:02:05.620 --> 00:02:10.890
Now, the advantage of this is, is that
a new employee on day one, already has

45
00:02:10.890 --> 00:02:14.010
a complete listing of all the employees
in the company that he can email to.

46
00:02:14.010 --> 00:02:18.430
But if you've got 50,000 people in
your organization, that's a lot, and

47
00:02:18.430 --> 00:02:20.420
we probably want to filter that down.

48
00:02:20.420 --> 00:02:24.470
And that's where we want to customize
this global address list a bit, right.

49
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:28.523
And there's a few filters already in
place, right, we've got All Contacts,

50
00:02:28.523 --> 00:02:30.070
All Groups, Rooms, Users.

51
00:02:30.070 --> 00:02:31.960
These are ways we can filter down a bit.

52
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:36.630
But what if I want to filter down to say,
just people in the sales department?

53
00:02:36.630 --> 00:02:38.672
Well, it doesn't give me
a good way to do that, and

54
00:02:38.672 --> 00:02:40.300
in a massive organization we want that.

55
00:02:40.300 --> 00:02:44.480
So, what we'll want to do is on our
server, create additional address list

56
00:02:44.480 --> 00:02:46.930
that are filtered based on
criteria we provide, all right?

57
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:49.130
Let me show you how that works.

58
00:02:49.130 --> 00:02:50.570
It's really not that hard.

59
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:55.160
If we jump back here to our
Exchange administration center,

60
00:02:55.160 --> 00:02:58.130
right, so I'm gonna jump into my EAC.

61
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:01.267
And once I'm in here, you'll see all
the different things on the left side,

62
00:03:01.267 --> 00:03:03.930
and in each of these are different
kind of aspects of our company.

63
00:03:03.930 --> 00:03:07.010
And the one I'm looking for
is organization.

64
00:03:07.010 --> 00:03:10.690
And under organization,
you'll see address lists, right.

65
00:03:10.690 --> 00:03:11.730
These are the address lists for

66
00:03:11.730 --> 00:03:16.590
your company, and you have the Default
Global Address List right there.

67
00:03:16.590 --> 00:03:20.590
That's that primary one that all of
your users are gonna have access to, and

68
00:03:20.590 --> 00:03:24.630
it contains every single person
throughout your organization, all right?

69
00:03:24.630 --> 00:03:27.954
Now, the other ones that are created here,
All Contacts, All Groups,

70
00:03:27.954 --> 00:03:29.862
All Rooms, All Users, Public Folders,

71
00:03:29.862 --> 00:03:33.330
those other ones that are designed
to be those simple filters.

72
00:03:33.330 --> 00:03:36.755
Microsoft encourages you to leave these
alone, leave the default ones be.

73
00:03:36.755 --> 00:03:39.240
Then if you want to create custom ones,
just create your own.

74
00:03:39.240 --> 00:03:43.020
And so we can add those in,
I mentioned sales people, right?

75
00:03:43.020 --> 00:03:47.292
So, if I take a look,
let me go into my Active Directory,

76
00:03:47.292 --> 00:03:50.590
which I have parked around here somewhere.

77
00:03:50.590 --> 00:03:53.829
All right, I'm gonna go into my
Active Directory Users and Computers, and

78
00:03:53.829 --> 00:03:55.890
let's take a look at my OU structure.

79
00:03:55.890 --> 00:03:59.510
So I've got this OU called ITProTV,
and inside of ITProTV,

80
00:03:59.510 --> 00:04:03.920
I've got Accounting, IT,
Marketing, Sales, right.

81
00:04:03.920 --> 00:04:07.070
And say I'm in sales,
I've got Jane Smith and John Doe.

82
00:04:07.070 --> 00:04:11.970
I've got the UK Sales and US Sales,
these groups that are present.

83
00:04:11.970 --> 00:04:15.910
But me, I'm over here in IT,
so I'm separate.

84
00:04:15.910 --> 00:04:21.830
Well, if I jump back to my client, so if
I jump back over to, whoops, there we go.

85
00:04:21.830 --> 00:04:22.920
Jump back over to my client.

86
00:04:22.920 --> 00:04:26.645
When I went into Outlook,
in Outlook, that new email,

87
00:04:26.645 --> 00:04:28.995
my Global Address List,
it contained everybody, right?

88
00:04:28.995 --> 00:04:33.373
So I saw me, Don Pezet, who's in
the IT department, and I saw Sales,

89
00:04:33.373 --> 00:04:36.875
UK Sales, and US Sales,
which were in the sales group.

90
00:04:36.875 --> 00:04:39.215
And I saw Marketing,
which was in the Marketing OU.

91
00:04:39.215 --> 00:04:40.950
It's really the whole thing.

92
00:04:40.950 --> 00:04:44.640
I wanna create a filter based
just on the Sales OU, all right?

93
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:50.800
So, what we do is we jump back to our EAC,
and we create a new address list.

94
00:04:50.800 --> 00:04:53.898
I'm just gonna hit the plus sign
there to create a new one, and

95
00:04:53.898 --> 00:04:56.170
I'm gonna call this
the Sales Address List.

96
00:04:56.170 --> 00:04:57.310
Or, I'll just call it Sales.

97
00:04:58.420 --> 00:05:01.430
From there, we start to pick what
we want to show up, all right.

98
00:05:01.430 --> 00:05:06.200
Do I want it to show all recipient
types or just user mailboxes,

99
00:05:06.200 --> 00:05:08.880
just contacts or a mixture of them, right?

100
00:05:08.880 --> 00:05:11.320
I might not want to show
distribution groups.

101
00:05:11.320 --> 00:05:15.300
I might just want to show users with
Exchange mailboxes or a mixture.

102
00:05:15.300 --> 00:05:18.220
So you can go through and
kinda pick what you wanna see, or

103
00:05:18.220 --> 00:05:20.220
what you wanna be a part of that, right?

104
00:05:20.220 --> 00:05:23.050
So, for example, I might wanna
leave out resource mailboxes.

105
00:05:23.050 --> 00:05:25.380
I don't wanna include things
like rooms and projectors.

106
00:05:25.380 --> 00:05:26.750
I just want it to be people.

107
00:05:26.750 --> 00:05:29.080
So I'll say, yeah,
go ahead and show me users.

108
00:05:29.080 --> 00:05:31.090
Show me contacts, show me groups.

109
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:32.620
But I'll leave out those
resource mailboxes.

110
00:05:33.790 --> 00:05:37.860
And then the real important part is this
guy right here, the add a rule, all right.

111
00:05:37.860 --> 00:05:41.550
Adding a rule is where we dictate where
it's gonna find this information from.

112
00:05:41.550 --> 00:05:43.290
And I'll hit add a rule, and

113
00:05:43.290 --> 00:05:46.200
you can pick from a number of
different things to filter on, right.

114
00:05:46.200 --> 00:05:49.920
You've got things like the State or
province, Company, Department, and

115
00:05:49.920 --> 00:05:52.280
all these Custom attributes, all right.

116
00:05:52.280 --> 00:05:55.040
These are all coming from
the Active Directory.

117
00:05:55.040 --> 00:05:58.530
If I jump back over to my
domain controller, and

118
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:02.210
we take somebody like me
in the Active Directory.

119
00:06:02.210 --> 00:06:06.288
If I pull up my account, I've got
things like that Description, Office,

120
00:06:06.288 --> 00:06:07.860
Telephone number.

121
00:06:07.860 --> 00:06:11.760
And as we browse through here, you'll find
other things that identify that person,

122
00:06:11.760 --> 00:06:13.630
their City, their State.

123
00:06:13.630 --> 00:06:15.080
Those are the things
that we could filter on.

124
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:18.970
So, just show me the employees
that are working out of Florida.

125
00:06:18.970 --> 00:06:21.940
Or just show me the employees
that are in England, right.

126
00:06:21.940 --> 00:06:23.540
And so we can filter on that.

127
00:06:23.540 --> 00:06:27.240
But I find the most useful
is filtering based on OU.

128
00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:33.490
Right, and back on that list, that was the
one that showed up as Recipient container.

129
00:06:33.490 --> 00:06:35.670
So, if I want to filter
by recipient container,

130
00:06:35.670 --> 00:06:40.130
it lets me browse the Active Directory and
pick the OU that has the users I want.

131
00:06:40.130 --> 00:06:43.670
So, I can browse in here,
and I can say, just Sales.

132
00:06:43.670 --> 00:06:44.936
And I'll pick that, and

133
00:06:44.936 --> 00:06:49.170
now it's only gonna show me recipients
that aren't resource mailboxes, right.

134
00:06:49.170 --> 00:06:53.611
I left that one off that are in
the sales OU, and when I save that,

135
00:06:53.611 --> 00:06:56.340
it's gonna create that address list.

136
00:06:56.340 --> 00:07:00.000
And now I've got this list that kinda
breaks that down for me, all right.

137
00:07:00.000 --> 00:07:03.090
Now, notice there's
this Address list path.

138
00:07:03.090 --> 00:07:07.140
By default, every address list
is like a parent address list.

139
00:07:07.140 --> 00:07:09.720
And when we start to create more,

140
00:07:09.720 --> 00:07:13.240
you can choose to nest address
lists underneath the other ones.

141
00:07:13.240 --> 00:07:17.592
So for example, back in Outlook when I was
writing that new email, when I was in my

142
00:07:17.592 --> 00:07:21.760
Address Book, if I drop that down,
see how I've got this All Address Lists?

143
00:07:21.760 --> 00:07:24.510
And these other ones are kinda
nested underneath it.

144
00:07:24.510 --> 00:07:25.440
We can set that up.

145
00:07:25.440 --> 00:07:27.520
We can have a parent, and
then children underneath it.

146
00:07:27.520 --> 00:07:31.360
So, I might have a Sales list,
and then underneath it,

147
00:07:31.360 --> 00:07:34.174
I might have US, UK, and so on.

148
00:07:34.174 --> 00:07:37.370
So kinda breaking it down that way, you
can nest the address lists to create that.

149
00:07:39.860 --> 00:07:41.640
All right,
now when I created the address list,

150
00:07:41.640 --> 00:07:43.340
I did get a little warning that popped up.

151
00:07:43.340 --> 00:07:46.650
And it's just warning me about
how these things get updated.

152
00:07:46.650 --> 00:07:48.519
It's telling me that I've made a change.

153
00:07:48.519 --> 00:07:50.539
But the address list isn't
gonna update on its own.

154
00:07:50.539 --> 00:07:52.091
And that's important to remember,

155
00:07:52.091 --> 00:07:54.800
because these address lists get
updated on a certain interval.

156
00:07:54.800 --> 00:07:57.561
And by default it usually doesn't
happen until midnight, so

157
00:07:57.561 --> 00:08:01.008
if I want these changes to take effect
right away I need to go ahead and push it,

158
00:08:01.008 --> 00:08:02.810
so that's what that warning is.

159
00:08:02.810 --> 00:08:04.250
I'll just say OK to that.

160
00:08:04.250 --> 00:08:06.370
And I can see my Sales
address list right here, and

161
00:08:06.370 --> 00:08:08.730
notice in the Up to Date column,
it says No.

162
00:08:10.300 --> 00:08:12.370
It's not unusual to see No there.

163
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:15.780
If any changes have happened
in your Active Directory and

164
00:08:15.780 --> 00:08:18.640
the address list hasn't been updated yet,
it's gonna say that it's not up to date.

165
00:08:18.640 --> 00:08:22.160
And then it brings it up to date every
night during your maintenance interval,

166
00:08:22.160 --> 00:08:23.220
during that window.

167
00:08:23.220 --> 00:08:25.220
I think the default is midnight to 3 AM,
so

168
00:08:25.220 --> 00:08:27.830
somewhere in that time
it's gonna do that update.

169
00:08:27.830 --> 00:08:29.960
But we can bring it up to date on our own.

170
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:31.170
If you highlight any of these lists,

171
00:08:31.170 --> 00:08:33.690
you'll see the link over
here that says Update and

172
00:08:33.690 --> 00:08:35.350
we can tell it to update it right now.

173
00:08:35.350 --> 00:08:39.210
It's just warning us that if your
address list is big, it can actually

174
00:08:39.210 --> 00:08:42.730
kind of degrade performance on the server
while it rebuilds that address list.

175
00:08:42.730 --> 00:08:46.370
So it's just saying here if it's
more than 3,000 recipients,

176
00:08:46.370 --> 00:08:48.770
you should consider
doing this after hours.

177
00:08:48.770 --> 00:08:52.260
And they give you the PowerShell command
right there, Update-AddressList.

178
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:56.344
To be able to do that, to schedule
it to happen at 2 AM or 5 AM or

179
00:08:56.344 --> 00:08:58.150
some non-peak time.

180
00:08:58.150 --> 00:09:00.430
But my address list is really small,
so I'll go ahead and say Yes and

00:09:00.430 --> 00:09:02.860
let it build right now, and it's done.

182
00:09:02.860 --> 00:09:04.210
And now I can see that it's up to date.

183
00:09:05.675 --> 00:09:07.575
Now when you create
address lists like this,

00:09:07.575 --> 00:09:11.505
the end users don't necessarily see them
right away, and that's because Outlook is

185
00:09:11.505 --> 00:09:15.365
actually downloading these address lists
and displaying them to them locally.

00:09:15.365 --> 00:09:17.835
If they're in Outlook web access it
will normally turn up right away, but

187
00:09:17.835 --> 00:09:20.372
if they're in that Outlook
client it might not be there.

00:09:20.372 --> 00:09:23.072
So for example,
if I go into my address book now and

00:09:23.072 --> 00:09:26.632
drop that down, I don't see my Sales list.

00:09:26.632 --> 00:09:31.292

00:09:31.292 --> 00:09:34.162

00:09:42.810 --> 00:09:43.540

So when I go back in, it'll contact

00:09:50.190 --> 00:09:53.680
Now I'm using my IT technical term of
should which gives me a little bit of

200
00:09:53.680 --> 00:09:57.830
a backout if this doesn't work, but
it should show up pretty shortly.

201
00:09:57.830 --> 00:09:59.370
So when I go into my address list now and

202
00:09:59.370 --> 00:10:02.475
I take a look,
I should see my Sales address list.

00:10:02.475 --> 00:10:03.800
And I still don't, and

that just means that Outlook hasn't

00:10:06.180 --> 00:10:07.770
So we have to give it

00:10:07.770 --> 00:10:10.980
So while we're waiting on that,

00:10:10.980 --> 00:10:12.440
that'll pull up shortly.

00:10:12.440 --> 00:10:15.500
I guess I could switch over to OWA and

00:10:15.500 --> 00:10:19.260
I'm logged into OWA here and

00:10:19.260 --> 00:10:21.350
And I go into my To field for

00:10:21.350 --> 00:10:25.010
who I want to email,
by default it's showing me my contacts.

00:10:42.980 --> 00:10:47.000
It's now filtered and I can pick from

Now I had a couple of users in there,

00:10:51.370 --> 00:10:54.750

00:10:54.750 --> 00:10:57.420
I can actually verify that real quick
if I take a look at my recipients.

00:10:57.420 --> 00:11:00.610
Yeah, sure enough, they don't have

223
00:11:00.610 --> 00:11:03.930
some mailboxes real quick, then they would

224
00:11:03.930 --> 00:11:07.680
But what we've done right here is to
create that custom address list, and

225
00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:10.090
you can really create as
many of these as you need.

226
00:11:10.090 --> 00:11:11.910
Organizations might create a ton.

227
00:11:11.910 --> 00:11:15.530
I know I've worked for companies that
did business in multiple states or

228
00:11:15.530 --> 00:11:16.740
multiple countries, and

229
00:11:16.740 --> 00:11:19.540
you might want to create address
lists that are a little more focused.

230
00:11:19.540 --> 00:11:21.420
If you have 50,000 employees,

231
00:11:21.420 --> 00:11:23.850
what are the odds of you having
multiple employees with the same name?

232
00:11:24.980 --> 00:11:26.140
It happens all the time.

00:11:26.140 --> 00:11:28.300
You might have five different John Smiths.

00:11:28.300 --> 00:11:31.890
But if you work in Florida and you know

235
00:11:31.890 --> 00:11:35.080
also, wouldn't it be nice to filter

236
00:11:35.080 --> 00:11:37.380
That's what these custom
address lists let us do.

237
00:11:37.380 --> 00:11:40.830
So we can whip those up, throw them in
place and really have that functionality.

238
00:11:40.830 --> 00:11:43.920
Now the end users can't do this.

239
00:11:43.920 --> 00:11:45.280
Administrators have to do it, and

00:11:45.280 --> 00:11:48.110
that's because it's done through
the Exchange Administration Center.

241
00:11:48.110 --> 00:11:50.860
That we have to go in here
to our organization and

242
00:11:50.860 --> 00:11:54.740
then go into our address list to
customize that and build them.

243
00:11:54.740 --> 00:11:57.030
Now once you've built an address list,
you can change it.

244
00:11:57.030 --> 00:12:00.100
If I choose it, I can always come in
here and edit it, and we can go in and

245
00:12:00.100 --> 00:12:01.640
start to modify the address list.

246
00:12:01.640 --> 00:12:04.570
So if I choose to add those
resource mailboxes back in,

247
00:12:04.570 --> 00:12:06.510
it's easy to change this after the fact.

248
00:12:06.510 --> 00:12:10.410
Just remember to do an update of

249
00:12:10.410 --> 00:12:12.560
And if you're not sure if
your filter's working,

250
00:12:12.560 --> 00:12:15.600
you've got this nice little
Preview recipients link.

251
00:12:15.600 --> 00:12:18.470
And you can hit that, and it'll give you

252
00:12:18.470 --> 00:12:21.030
look like so
you can then customize it some more

253
00:12:21.030 --> 00:12:23.682
to really meet the needs of what it
is that you're trying to achieve.

254
00:12:25.930 --> 00:12:29.190
All right,
another thing we need to be aware of is,

255
00:12:29.190 --> 00:12:32.220
well it kinda ties back to what I was
talking about a moment ago with Outlook.

256
00:12:32.220 --> 00:12:37.840
With Outlook, it's gonna download a copy
of these address lists to store locally.

257
00:12:37.840 --> 00:12:40.990
And it's checking in with the server from
time to time to get those updates, and

258
00:12:40.990 --> 00:12:43.040
so it can be a little bit behind.

259
00:12:43.040 --> 00:12:47.700
What it's doing is it's creating what's
called an offline address book or and OAB.

260
00:12:47.700 --> 00:12:50.750
And the OAB, it's stored on all
of your Client Access servers.

261
00:12:50.750 --> 00:12:53.200
So your Client Access servers
maintain a copy of the OAB and

262
00:12:53.200 --> 00:12:55.920
when Outlook goes to connect,
it downloads a copy of it.

263
00:12:55.920 --> 00:12:59.420
So that offline address book,
it has to be updated and refreshed and

264
00:12:59.420 --> 00:13:01.470
it has to be distributed
out to your clients.

265
00:13:01.470 --> 00:13:04.170
So it's done automatically for
the most part,

266
00:13:04.170 --> 00:13:07.340
we don't really have to worry about it,
but we can tweak it.

267
00:13:07.340 --> 00:13:11.590
If your organization is huge, if you
have hundreds of thousands of employees,

268
00:13:11.590 --> 00:13:14.050
that offline address
book can be kinda big.

269
00:13:14.050 --> 00:13:17.730
So you might want to create
smaller offline address books that

270
00:13:17.730 --> 00:13:19.670
only contain certain
aspects of your company.

271
00:13:19.670 --> 00:13:22.520
So maybe I have employees in Florida.

272
00:13:22.520 --> 00:13:26.250
And so I only want the offline address
book to contain employees in Florida,

273
00:13:26.250 --> 00:13:27.650
not the rest of the world.

274
00:13:27.650 --> 00:13:30.440
So I could create custom offline
address books for that and

275
00:13:30.440 --> 00:13:32.200
dictate where that goes.

276
00:13:32.200 --> 00:13:36.260
So that's something that we can
certainly do and customize that and

277
00:13:36.260 --> 00:13:39.870
it definitely helps cuz it can take
Outlook a while to get some of this stuff.

278
00:13:39.870 --> 00:13:42.410
Now the offline address books,
they're being built automatically.

279
00:13:42.410 --> 00:13:44.304
I believe the default is at 5 AM.

280
00:13:44.304 --> 00:13:46.930
At 5 AM every day it builds
these offline address books and

281
00:13:46.930 --> 00:13:49.700
it stores them on the hard drive
on your Client Access server.

282
00:13:49.700 --> 00:13:52.590
So it's just inside of the Exchange
directory where they're stored.

283
00:13:52.590 --> 00:13:56.200
And we can actually kinda browse and
find some of them.

00:13:56.200 --> 00:14:02.605
Here, let me take my Client Access server
here and, actually, you know what?

00:14:02.605 --> 00:14:04.765
I think we can find it on
our Mailbox server too,

00:14:04.765 --> 00:14:06.835
let's see if we can find
one of these real quick.

287
00:14:06.835 --> 00:14:08.795
So here I am on my Mailbox server.

288
00:14:08.795 --> 00:14:11.695
The Mailbox server's what actually builds
it, it's where the mailboxes reside,

289
00:14:11.695 --> 00:14:14.705
and then it gets stored on
the Client Access server too.

00:14:14.705 --> 00:14:22.228
So if I browse into C: > Program Files
> Microsoft > Exchange Server > V15.

00:14:22.228 --> 00:14:27.660
And then ClientAccess because it's

00:14:27.660 --> 00:14:29.030

00:14:29.030 --> 00:14:31.650
What you'll find is in that folder there

00:14:31.650 --> 00:14:34.170

address book is stored.

00:14:34.170 --> 00:14:38.126
And apparently mine is going to

Let me do this on the Client Access

00:14:40.990 --> 00:14:44.270
So this is another one of those

00:14:44.270 --> 00:14:46.140
The Mailbox server's

00:14:46.140 --> 00:14:48.040

00:14:48.040 --> 00:14:50.240
So we should be able to

00:14:50.240 --> 00:14:54.346
So if I get too impatient on one I

00:14:56.913 --> 00:14:59.580
And let's see, not seeing it there.

00:14:59.580 --> 00:15:00.260
Here we go.

00:15:00.260 --> 00:15:04.550
So back in my mail server it's got
that OAB, and if I browse into that

00:15:04.550 --> 00:15:06.890
we'll see the offline address book,
if it's been created.

306
00:15:06.890 --> 00:15:10.130
On a clean install, your offline address
book might not have been created yet

307
00:15:10.130 --> 00:15:11.792

308
00:15:11.792 --> 00:15:12.980
But mine's been running for

00:15:12.980 --> 00:15:16.260
a little while and so
I can see I've got a web.config, Temp.

00:15:16.260 --> 00:15:18.630
I've got a U ID folder.

00:15:18.630 --> 00:15:20.370
And this is the offline address book.

00:15:20.370 --> 00:15:21.770
It's not terribly large for mine.

00:15:21.770 --> 00:15:25.259
Mine's pretty small because I
don't have a lot of contacts, so

314
00:15:25.259 --> 00:15:29.190
there's not really a whole heck of
a lot for me to see in this one.

315
00:15:29.190 --> 00:15:33.290
But as your organization grows, what
you'll see is these things start to grow

00:15:33.290 --> 00:15:36.680
also, and
you end up with a large amount of data.

317
00:15:36.680 --> 00:15:39.750
Here's my actual offline address
book right here, oab.xml.

00:15:39.750 --> 00:15:44.360
It's just an XML document, and
mine's 21K, but as I add employees,

00:15:44.360 --> 00:15:46.310

it can become several megabytes.

00:15:46.310 --> 00:15:47.870
Now that's not a big deal, but

00:15:47.870 --> 00:15:51.420

00:15:51.420 --> 00:15:52.421
It can grow to be even bigger.

00:15:52.421 --> 00:15:57.226
And that can be a problem if you have

00:15:57.226 --> 00:16:00.061

00:16:00.061 --> 00:16:00.781
All right.

00:16:00.781 --> 00:16:06.243
Now, when we go to push this out, if we

00:16:06.243 --> 00:16:09.300
they don't give you a way

00:16:09.300 --> 00:16:12.356
So, I can't do it from the Exchange

00:16:12.356 --> 00:16:14.136
I have to do it from the PowerShell.

330
00:16:14.136 --> 00:16:16.553
And in the PowerShell,
we can build these custom address list,

331
00:16:16.553 --> 00:16:18.980
these offline address lists,
and push them out.

332
00:16:18.980 --> 00:16:22.500
And then as far as assigning the offline
address list, what you do is you create

00:16:22.500 --> 00:16:26.790

00:16:26.790 --> 00:16:30.650
But one of the easiest ways to do it is

00:16:30.650 --> 00:16:34.700
If I go down here to my servers, and

And see how I've created

00:16:40.254 --> 00:16:42.425
That's where my Sales
employees are going to be.

00:16:42.425 --> 00:16:46.612
If I edit that mailbox database,

00:16:46.612 --> 00:16:50.080
here to dictate what offline
address book they use.

341
00:16:50.080 --> 00:16:52.620
So I can go here to client settings and

342
00:16:52.620 --> 00:16:56.766
And then anybody who's mailbox I stick
in this mailbox database will use that

343
00:16:56.766 --> 00:16:59.300
particular offline address book, alright.

00:16:59.300 --> 00:17:00.420
But I need to build it first.

00:17:00.420 --> 00:17:03.700
I've only got one offline address book

00:17:03.700 --> 00:17:06.780
I need to create another one just for

00:17:06.780 --> 00:17:10.860
So I'm gonna jump over to my

00:17:10.860 --> 00:17:14.230
I'm gonna whip up the Exchange Shell.

00:17:18.191 --> 00:17:22.050
[LAUGH] I'm gonna try and

00:17:22.050 --> 00:17:22.870
There we go.

00:17:22.870 --> 00:17:24.630
And let me bump my font size up on this

00:17:24.630 --> 00:17:25.980
because I know it'll
be kinda hard to read.

00:17:25.980 --> 00:17:29.399
And what I'm gonna do is I'm
just gonna whip up a real quick

354
00:17:31.690 --> 00:17:35.550
custom offline address book,
soon as that one loads.

355
00:17:35.550 --> 00:17:37.680
So, I do have to do it from
the PowerShell, which kind of stinks,

356
00:17:37.680 --> 00:17:39.710
but you don't have to do
it all that often, right,

00:17:39.710 --> 00:17:42.230
how often are you really
creating offline address books?

358
00:17:42.230 --> 00:17:45.630
It's not something you do everyday, so
we'll just jump in here and knock it out.

00:17:45.630 --> 00:17:50.120
Now the command is incredibly long so

00:17:50.120 --> 00:17:57.570
Let me change my screen width here a bit
to make this all fit on the screen.

00:18:00.060 --> 00:18:00.790
There.

00:18:00.790 --> 00:18:04.540
Alright, and I'm just doing that cuz I

00:18:04.540 --> 00:18:06.893
Alright, so what I'm going to do is,

I'm going to say New-GlobalAddressList,

00:18:11.540 --> 00:18:14.690
So I might create like a SalesGAL.

00:18:14.690 --> 00:18:19.300
And I can define a RecipientFilter.

00:18:19.300 --> 00:18:22.560
And that's what you guys saw me do earlier

00:18:22.560 --> 00:18:25.740
I only wanna show people

Or maybe I wanna do it based

So I could come in and

00:18:37.439 --> 00:18:41.120
Alright, so that's my filter for

00:18:42.630 --> 00:18:46.370
And so that's gonna create that and

00:18:46.370 --> 00:18:50.310
And then I can update it to make sure

00:18:50.310 --> 00:18:52.249

00:18:54.050 --> 00:18:55.240
As soon as it's done, there we go.

00:18:56.550 --> 00:19:02.080
So I'm gonna say, Update-AddressList and
it's the SalesGAL that I wanna update.
