00:19:02.080 --> 00:19:05.230
And that's gonna make sure that
it's up to date if I type it right.

379
00:19:06.490 --> 00:19:07.200
Let's see.

380
00:19:07.200 --> 00:19:08.240
Update.

381
00:19:08.240 --> 00:19:13.810
Oh, it should be
Update-GlobalAddressList SalesGAL.

382
00:19:13.810 --> 00:19:14.640
There we go.

383
00:19:14.640 --> 00:19:16.570
So if I get my syntax right,
it'll work better.

384
00:19:16.570 --> 00:19:19.220
So now I've got that address list created,

00:19:19.220 --> 00:19:20.400
it's got it's filter in place.

The things I just did,

Through the administration center but

00:19:33.660 --> 00:19:36.290
So I'll say new offline address book,
and then I'll come in and

00:19:36.290 --> 00:19:38.130

I'm just gonna call mine my SalesOAB for

And I need to tell it what

you tell it address list

00:19:49.740 --> 00:19:52.160
That's why I wanted to create

00:19:52.160 --> 00:19:55.841
So I'm going to put the SalesGAL
in my SalesOAB, right,

397
00:19:55.841 --> 00:19:59.520
so it's going to basically
put that information.

So, this offline address book is not going
to contain the full global address list,

399
00:20:03.710 --> 00:20:05.485
just this limited one that I need.

400
00:20:05.485 --> 00:20:10.510
Alright, that's gonna create
the offline address book.

401
00:20:10.510 --> 00:20:15.080
And I could stop right there,
take this offline address book, and

402
00:20:15.080 --> 00:20:16.610
attach it to a mailbox database.

403
00:20:16.610 --> 00:20:19.860
So if I have a Sales database, I attach
this offline address book to it, and

404
00:20:19.860 --> 00:20:23.510
then anybody I put in that Sales database
will use this offline address book.

405
00:20:23.510 --> 00:20:24.300
I'm done.

406
00:20:24.300 --> 00:20:25.150
Okay.

407
00:20:25.150 --> 00:20:27.990
But I can go a step further,
and I can create

408
00:20:27.990 --> 00:20:32.030
policies built around this that kind of
dictate how this is going to function.

409
00:20:32.030 --> 00:20:35.380
So, for example, I might want to
filter this a little bit more.

410
00:20:35.380 --> 00:20:40.100
To limit what's inside of it, or to even
add additional addresses inside of it.

411
00:20:40.100 --> 00:20:45.710
So as an example, I might say,
we'll do New-AddressBookPolicy,

412
00:20:45.710 --> 00:20:49.390
and I'll give this one a name of SalesABP.

413
00:20:49.390 --> 00:20:51.870
So this'll be an address book policy.

414
00:20:51.870 --> 00:20:56.080
And I'm going to pick address
lists to go inside of it.

415
00:20:56.080 --> 00:21:00.740
And so, I'm going to say \Sales,
right, setting that path, right,

416
00:21:00.740 --> 00:21:03.230
cuz we can nest address
lists inside of each other.

417
00:21:03.230 --> 00:21:05.540
So I'll just say I'm going
to include the Sales.

418
00:21:05.540 --> 00:21:09.410
I'm going to specify the offline
address book that I want to use,

419
00:21:09.410 --> 00:21:14.840
which is the one I just created, SalesOAB.

420
00:21:14.840 --> 00:21:18.750
And then I can tell it the global address
list that I want these users to use.

421
00:21:18.750 --> 00:21:21.350
Now, the default global
address list is the default.

422
00:21:21.350 --> 00:21:24.470
It's everything, the whole organization.

423
00:21:24.470 --> 00:21:28.080
I want these people's default global
address list to be the sales one so

424
00:21:28.080 --> 00:21:31.850
I'm going to tie that down to SalesGAL.

425
00:21:31.850 --> 00:21:37.670
And then, we haven't talked about rooms,
yet, or resource records.

426
00:21:37.670 --> 00:21:39.580
We're going to talk about
those in another episode.

427
00:21:39.580 --> 00:21:41.040
But when I create a policy like this,

428
00:21:41.040 --> 00:21:44.070
you have to dictate whether
it loads rooms or not.

429
00:21:44.070 --> 00:21:49.730
So I'm going to -RoomList, and I'm just
going to tell it to include all rooms.

430
00:21:49.730 --> 00:21:54.545
Those are for using things like if we want
to do scheduling conference rooms and

431
00:21:54.545 --> 00:21:57.190
things, you can define those and
make them a part of the address list too.

432
00:21:58.470 --> 00:22:02.970
Alright, now once I've done that,
that was a pretty long command and

433
00:22:02.970 --> 00:22:04.100
I didn't really have to do that.

434
00:22:04.100 --> 00:22:05.550
I could have taken
the offline address book and

435
00:22:05.550 --> 00:22:07.350
attached it to the mailbox database.

436
00:22:07.350 --> 00:22:11.370
The problem is, what if I have users
in more than one mailbox database?

437
00:22:11.370 --> 00:22:16.290
Or if I have Sales people and marketing
people in the same mailbox database, and

438
00:22:16.290 --> 00:22:18.130
I want to do separate
global address list there.

439
00:22:18.130 --> 00:22:20.590
I can't do it by assigning
it to the mailbox database.

440
00:22:20.590 --> 00:22:23.980
So by creating a policy like this,
I can take the policy and

441
00:22:23.980 --> 00:22:26.850
apply it to whoever I want, right?

442
00:22:26.850 --> 00:22:30.190
I can come in and say, look for people
whose department is set to Sales and

443
00:22:30.190 --> 00:22:33.840
apply this policy to them, and
now it's really, really granular.

444
00:22:33.840 --> 00:22:36.500
And we do that by doing
something like this.

445
00:22:36.500 --> 00:22:43.585
I'll say Get-Mailbox
-OrganizationalUnit Sales.

446
00:22:43.585 --> 00:22:47.966
Right, give me a list of all
the mailboxes that are in this SalesOU.

447
00:22:47.966 --> 00:22:48.630
Alright.

448
00:22:48.630 --> 00:22:53.270
And so that you know, that's just gonna
give me those people, if I spell it right.

449
00:22:53.270 --> 00:22:54.880
Organizational unit.

450
00:22:54.880 --> 00:22:56.470
There we go.
And apparently I don't have

451
00:22:56.470 --> 00:22:57.040
anybody in there.

452
00:22:57.040 --> 00:22:58.400
Let me take like IT.

453
00:22:59.960 --> 00:23:01.990
There we go.
So you can see, I'm in IT.

454
00:23:01.990 --> 00:23:04.880
So, you can pull up a list
of everybody in that OU, or

455
00:23:04.880 --> 00:23:07.750
everybody whose department is Sales,
or whatever.

456
00:23:07.750 --> 00:23:13.310
And we can pipe that into
a command to assign the policy.

457
00:23:13.310 --> 00:23:19.425
So if I wanted to take everybody in Sales,
and assign that policy to them,

458
00:23:19.425 --> 00:23:24.261
I could just say Set-Mailbox
-AddressBookPolicy, and

459
00:23:24.261 --> 00:23:27.450
then assign SalesABP to them.

460
00:23:27.450 --> 00:23:28.150
And by doing,

461
00:23:28.150 --> 00:23:32.750
that it doesn't matter if I have a mixture
of employees in the same database.

462
00:23:32.750 --> 00:23:34.120
It doesn't matter what
database they're in.

463
00:23:34.120 --> 00:23:38.270
I'm just saying take everybody that's in
that OU, and assign this policy to them,

464
00:23:38.270 --> 00:23:41.580
so that they'll get the offline
address book that we created.

465
00:23:41.580 --> 00:23:44.550
And now when they go into Outlook and
Outlook is offline, or

466
00:23:44.550 --> 00:23:48.310
Outlook is downloaded and running cache
mode, they'll see the address list.

467
00:23:48.310 --> 00:23:50.440
And it'll be filtered down
to just the Sales people,

468
00:23:50.440 --> 00:23:52.700
or just the people in Florida,
just the people in London.

469
00:23:52.700 --> 00:23:54.890
Whatever it is that we wanna create,
right?

470
00:23:54.890 --> 00:23:59.200
Now, that was kind of a pain, running
through those commands to do it, but

471
00:23:59.200 --> 00:24:01.440
it's not something you have
to do very often, right?

472
00:24:01.440 --> 00:24:02.790
You create it, you put it in place.

473
00:24:02.790 --> 00:24:05.590
Now this policy that I applied,

474
00:24:05.590 --> 00:24:07.730
what happens if I create
a new employee in that OU?

475
00:24:08.770 --> 00:24:10.730
This policy wasn't applied to them, right?

476
00:24:10.730 --> 00:24:13.520
It was applied to the people that
were in there at the time I ran it.

477
00:24:13.520 --> 00:24:15.580
So if we want this to be
a long standing thing,

478
00:24:15.580 --> 00:24:17.700
we probably need to schedule
this to run every night.

479
00:24:17.700 --> 00:24:21.800
Just every night, or whenever, reach out
and look if there's new employees and

480
00:24:21.800 --> 00:24:23.510
assign this address book policy to them.

481
00:24:23.510 --> 00:24:25.250
Otherwise they're not gonna have it.

482
00:24:25.250 --> 00:24:29.920
Or when I create new users, if I clone an
existing user, right, instead of creating

483
00:24:29.920 --> 00:24:32.950
a new user from scratch, if I clone one,
then it'll carry over their properties,

484
00:24:32.950 --> 00:24:35.750
which includes which offline
address book they're gonna use.

485
00:24:35.750 --> 00:24:37.900
So that'll help to ensure
that doesn't happen too.

486
00:24:37.900 --> 00:24:39.595
So those are just little things
that we need to be aware of.

487
00:24:39.595 --> 00:24:46.210
Alright, so at first glance, address books
seem pretty simple inside of Exchange,

488
00:24:46.210 --> 00:24:48.810
but there's a lot more that we
can do with them, isn't there?

489
00:24:48.810 --> 00:24:51.560
As far as customizing this,
changing that behavior, and

490
00:24:51.560 --> 00:24:55.280
really getting the address list to
reflect what we want within our company.

491
00:24:55.280 --> 00:24:56.680
It can really make things handy.

492
00:24:56.680 --> 00:24:58.810
Make it a lot easier to find employees,

493
00:24:58.810 --> 00:25:00.409
especially when you have
people with duplicate names.

494
00:25:01.440 --> 00:25:04.070
All right, well that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap this one up.

495
00:25:04.070 --> 00:25:06.520
All those PowerShell commands,
I'll put those in the show notes so

496
00:25:06.520 --> 00:25:08.450
you guys have them and
you can use them for reference.

497
00:25:08.450 --> 00:25:10.670
They'll definitely be available.

498
00:25:10.670 --> 00:25:12.910
But otherwise, for this episode,
I think that wraps it up.

499
00:25:12.910 --> 00:25:14.920
So I hope you guys enjoyed it.

500
00:25:14.920 --> 00:25:17.690
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

501
00:25:17.690 --> 00:25:18.884
And I'll see you next time.

502
00:25:18.884 --> 00:25:24.390
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates the various recipient types found in Exchange. He walks the viewers through creating standard user mailboxes, and then moves on to more specialized recipients like resource mailboxes and shared mailboxes.
episodes.title: Recipients
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.593
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.593 --> 00:00:13.714
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.714 --> 00:00:15.816
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.816 --> 00:00:17.260
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

5
00:00:17.260 --> 00:00:20.639
back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.639 --> 00:00:24.899
And in this episode, we're gonna take a
look at something that's kind of overdue,

7
00:00:24.899 --> 00:00:26.410
recipients, right?

8
00:00:26.410 --> 00:00:30.136
Recipients in Exchange, most of
the people or things that we e-mail,

9
00:00:30.136 --> 00:00:33.612
when you send an e-mail to somebody,
the person in your to field,

10
00:00:33.612 --> 00:00:37.611
right, the person you are sending
your e-mail to, they're a recipient.

11
00:00:37.611 --> 00:00:40.160
They're gonna receive
information from you.

12
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:42.121
So in Exchange, if we expect it to work,

13
00:00:42.121 --> 00:00:45.110
we're gonna need to set up
at least one recipient.

14
00:00:45.110 --> 00:00:49.380
At least one person who can receive
information and deal with it, right?

15
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:51.280
So that's a pretty important thing.

16
00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:55.429
And the most common type of
recipient is a user mailbox.

17
00:00:55.429 --> 00:00:57.807
We have user accounts
inside of Active Directory,

18
00:00:57.807 --> 00:01:01.030
we want them to have a mailbox so
that they can send and receive email.

19
00:01:01.030 --> 00:01:03.600
That's our most common type of recipient.

20
00:01:03.600 --> 00:01:05.211
But under the hood in Exchange,

21
00:01:05.211 --> 00:01:08.321
there's actually like 12
different types of recipients.

22
00:01:08.321 --> 00:01:10.050
There's a ton of different ones.

23
00:01:10.050 --> 00:01:13.600
So in this episode, I wanna tackle
some of the more important ones.

24
00:01:13.600 --> 00:01:17.310
I'm gonna save a few for another episode
though, and those are groups and

25
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:19.050
distribution lists.

26
00:01:19.050 --> 00:01:22.660
Distribution lists are really
just a collection of recipients.

27
00:01:22.660 --> 00:01:25.340
So I wanna make sure we tackle
the individual recipients first and

28
00:01:25.340 --> 00:01:26.859
then we'll talk about
collecting them together.

29
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:30.460
Well, let's start with
the most basic of recipient,

30
00:01:30.460 --> 00:01:32.120
the most important one, the mailbox.

31
00:01:33.220 --> 00:01:37.932
Inside of Microsoft Exchange 2013,
users do not get mail boxes by default,

32
00:01:37.932 --> 00:01:38.634
all right?

33
00:01:38.634 --> 00:01:41.436
When you go and
create a user in the Active Directory,

34
00:01:41.436 --> 00:01:43.560
they don't necessarily get a mailbox.

35
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:47.220
And so that's something that we're
going to have to kinda sort out

36
00:01:47.220 --> 00:01:51.020
to make sure that we get everything right
and in place when we create somebody.

37
00:01:51.020 --> 00:01:58.100
So if I take a look at my Active
Directory, I've got an ITProTV OU created.

38
00:01:58.100 --> 00:02:02.440
I've got a Sales OU created, and inside of
sales, I've got Jane Smith and John Doe.

39
00:02:02.440 --> 00:02:04.380
These are a couple of
users that I whipped up.

40
00:02:04.380 --> 00:02:08.320
Or if I wanna whip up another user here,
I can just come in and do New User and

41
00:02:08.320 --> 00:02:12.050
we'll create,
we'll do Bob Denver, all right?

42
00:02:12.050 --> 00:02:14.820
Bob Denver, he needs email.

43
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:15.400
So here we go.

44
00:02:15.400 --> 00:02:21.300
We'll just get his account whipped up and
we'll give him a super

45
00:02:21.300 --> 00:02:26.610
secure password, which we'll set
not to expire cuz that's awesome.

46
00:02:26.610 --> 00:02:27.910
All right.
So I just whipped up a user.

47
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:32.960
Now as I created this user,
did it ever ask me about an email address?

48
00:02:32.960 --> 00:02:33.750
It didn't.

49
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:37.253
It's got the login name, which kind of
looks like an email address, right?

50
00:02:37.253 --> 00:02:40.460
A user at a fully qualified domain name.

51
00:02:40.460 --> 00:02:44.400
But it's not actually creating
a mailbox for that user.

52
00:02:44.400 --> 00:02:47.030
Now, how do I know it's
not creating a mailbox?

53
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:48.580
Well, I can go and look.

54
00:02:48.580 --> 00:02:51.850
If I jump back over to my
Exchange Administration Center,

55
00:02:52.900 --> 00:02:55.570
we can jump in here, well,
I can try and jump in here.

56
00:02:55.570 --> 00:02:56.580
There we go.

57
00:02:56.580 --> 00:02:59.610
And in the Exchange Administration Center,
it actually defaults to the recipient

58
00:02:59.610 --> 00:03:02.220
view, and right here,
I can see all of my mailboxes.

59
00:03:02.220 --> 00:03:03.040
And I see Don Pezet.

60
00:03:03.040 --> 00:03:06.270
I've got a mailbox, but
I don't see John Doe.

61
00:03:06.270 --> 00:03:09.662
I don't see Jane Smith, and I definitely
don't see Bob Denver, who I just created.

62
00:03:09.662 --> 00:03:13.480
I'm gonna hit refresh to just to make
sure I've got the latest information.

63
00:03:13.480 --> 00:03:14.520
It's not created.

64
00:03:14.520 --> 00:03:15.310
All right.

65
00:03:15.310 --> 00:03:19.410
User accounts in Active Directory
can become recipients, but

66
00:03:19.410 --> 00:03:21.830
they aren't recipients by default.

67
00:03:21.830 --> 00:03:23.866
So if I wanna make them have a mailbox,

68
00:03:23.866 --> 00:03:28.016
what I need to do is I need to make them
what are called mail-enabled objects.

69
00:03:28.016 --> 00:03:29.909
Mail-enabled just means
that they have a mailbox,

70
00:03:29.909 --> 00:03:32.100
that you can actually send email to them.

71
00:03:32.100 --> 00:03:35.630
So when I come into recipients and
mailboxes, and

72
00:03:35.630 --> 00:03:40.270
I hit this plus sign, you'll see that
I can create a user mailbox, and

73
00:03:40.270 --> 00:03:43.320
that's what's gonna mail enable that
object inside of the Active Directory.

74
00:03:43.320 --> 00:03:46.860
Now there's two types of mailboxes they
reference here, a user mailbox and

75
00:03:46.860 --> 00:03:48.350
a linked mailbox.

76
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:49.550
What's that all about?

77
00:03:49.550 --> 00:03:55.200
Well, a user mailbox is where you've got
a user account in your Active Directory.

78
00:03:55.200 --> 00:03:56.570
And you're gonna create a mailbox for
them.

79
00:03:57.580 --> 00:04:02.120
A linked mailbox is where you've
got a user account in somebody

80
00:04:02.120 --> 00:04:06.110
else's Active Directory and you're
gonna create a mailbox for them, right?

81
00:04:06.110 --> 00:04:08.369
So you might have
an Active Directory federation and

82
00:04:08.369 --> 00:04:11.512
you've got a completely separate
forest that you're federated with.

83
00:04:11.512 --> 00:04:14.361
You might have other domains
inside of your environment, and

84
00:04:14.361 --> 00:04:17.920
the users over there in that domain
are over in some other forest.

85
00:04:17.920 --> 00:04:19.788
And you want the mailbox to be right here.

86
00:04:19.788 --> 00:04:23.320
You see that a lot with organizations
where you've got a parent company and

87
00:04:23.320 --> 00:04:25.310
child companies underneath it.

88
00:04:25.310 --> 00:04:28.249
The parent company might wanna
host all the mailboxes, but

89
00:04:28.249 --> 00:04:30.497
the child companies
have their own domains.

90
00:04:30.497 --> 00:04:32.580
So here we would do a linked mailbox.

91
00:04:32.580 --> 00:04:35.070
Well, in my case,
I'm just gonna do a user mailbox.

92
00:04:35.070 --> 00:04:37.060
And when I choose to do a user mailbox,

93
00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:41.960
I've got the opportunity to
create an all new user account.

94
00:04:41.960 --> 00:04:44.420
That means it'll create
an Active Directory user and

95
00:04:44.420 --> 00:04:49.840
a mailbox at the same time, or
I can build one around an existing user.

96
00:04:49.840 --> 00:04:51.170
So I can come in and I can say,

97
00:04:51.170 --> 00:04:54.510
I'm gonna say Bob Denver,
I'm just gonna give him an alias.

98
00:04:54.510 --> 00:04:55.820
You have to give them an alias,

99
00:04:55.820 --> 00:04:59.710
this is like a shortcut name that people
could type to quickly email the person.

100
00:04:59.710 --> 00:05:02.700
And then I can browse and
I can pick an existing user.

101
00:05:02.700 --> 00:05:04.640
And so I can come in and
I can find Bob Denver.

102
00:05:04.640 --> 00:05:07.330
Now, notice how I'm not in this list,
Don Pezet.

103
00:05:07.330 --> 00:05:08.450
I don't show up.

104
00:05:08.450 --> 00:05:10.270
That's because I already have a mailbox,
right?

105
00:05:10.270 --> 00:05:11.080
So I'm not gonna show up.

106
00:05:11.080 --> 00:05:14.110
This is filtered to users
that don't have mailboxes.

107
00:05:14.110 --> 00:05:16.720
And so I'll take ol' Bob Denver and
pick him.

108
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:19.430
And I don't need to provide any of
this other information cuz it's

109
00:05:19.430 --> 00:05:22.230
already defined on the user
account in the Active Directory.

110
00:05:22.230 --> 00:05:27.150
I can go and hit Save and it's gonna
whip up that mailbox for Bob Denver.

111
00:05:27.150 --> 00:05:31.120
Now, when it makes his mailbox, it's gonna
put it in my default mailbox database.

112
00:05:31.120 --> 00:05:33.090
If I have more than one
mailbox database though,

113
00:05:33.090 --> 00:05:35.440
I might want him to reside somewhere else.

114
00:05:35.440 --> 00:05:39.650
So when you bring that user in, you can
choose to create that user mailbox.

115
00:05:39.650 --> 00:05:43.542
You can browse and pick the user,
I'll take Jane Smith this time.

116
00:05:43.542 --> 00:05:47.270
And I'll pick her and
I'll give her an alias.

117
00:05:47.270 --> 00:05:50.510
And then down here at the bottom,
you've got more options.

118
00:05:50.510 --> 00:05:54.670
And under more options, you can pick what
mailbox database they're gonna go into.

119
00:05:54.670 --> 00:05:56.700
That's what'll let you
move that somewhere else.

120
00:05:56.700 --> 00:06:00.370
Or you can assign a address book
policy if you've got one created.

121
00:06:00.370 --> 00:06:03.530
In a previous episode, I showed you guys
how to make address book policies, and

122
00:06:03.530 --> 00:06:07.580
so I can go in and choose that sales
one for Jane, and I can browse and

123
00:06:07.580 --> 00:06:10.720
pick to put her in the sales
mailbox database, right?

124
00:06:10.720 --> 00:06:14.230
Her active directory user
account is already created.

125
00:06:14.230 --> 00:06:17.780
This is just a mailbox that I'm
dictating where it's gonna reside and

126
00:06:17.780 --> 00:06:19.480
what policies she's gonna have.

127
00:06:19.480 --> 00:06:23.270
And so now I've got her account,
she's created, and she's in there.

128
00:06:23.270 --> 00:06:25.900
But I could create new users
from scratch if I wanted.

129
00:06:25.900 --> 00:06:32.790
If I go to new user mailbox and
I create, let's do Christopher Walken.

130
00:06:32.790 --> 00:06:37.410
So I'm gonna create a new user
called Christopher Walken.

131
00:06:37.410 --> 00:06:40.050
And we're gonna give him a mailbox, right?

132
00:06:40.050 --> 00:06:42.990
So there's just some basic
information we need to provide.

133
00:06:42.990 --> 00:06:43.750
User name.

134
00:06:43.750 --> 00:06:44.760
Full name.

135
00:06:44.760 --> 00:06:46.460
User login name here.

136
00:06:46.460 --> 00:06:49.810
So we'll make him Christopher Walken.

137
00:06:49.810 --> 00:06:51.500
I probably need to come up with
a better naming convention,

138
00:06:51.500 --> 00:06:53.710
cuz that's a long user name,
but it'll work.

139
00:06:53.710 --> 00:06:54.774
And we'll get that punched in.

140
00:06:58.452 --> 00:06:59.550
All right.

141
00:06:59.550 --> 00:07:02.010
And then I can go in and set more options,
if I want, on this user.

142
00:07:02.010 --> 00:07:05.100
So it's all set the way that I want
it to be from the very beginning.

143
00:07:05.100 --> 00:07:06.580
Right?
That's kinda the neat part.

144
00:07:06.580 --> 00:07:10.160
By creating it here, I get the user and
the mailbox created at the same time.

145
00:07:10.160 --> 00:07:13.200
Now while this sounds like a great idea,
in practice,

146
00:07:13.200 --> 00:07:14.870
you're not gonna use this very much.

147
00:07:14.870 --> 00:07:15.870
And the reason is,

148
00:07:15.870 --> 00:07:19.760
when we create Active Directory users,
we normally clone an existing user, right,

149
00:07:19.760 --> 00:07:23.404
we duplicate somebody so that we get the
same group memberships and permissions.

150
00:07:23.404 --> 00:07:27.280
If Christopher Walken's my new sales
person, I wanna go copy a sales person so

151
00:07:27.280 --> 00:07:28.830
they have the same memberships.

152
00:07:28.830 --> 00:07:31.550
By doing it this way,
it's not copying anybody.

153
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:34.960
So yeah, I get a mailbox at the same time,
which is nice, but now I've gotta go and

154
00:07:34.960 --> 00:07:38.150
set all those permissions, and
that's harder than creating a mailbox.

155
00:07:38.150 --> 00:07:39.630
So normally we don't do it this way.

156
00:07:39.630 --> 00:07:41.100
We duplicate the user in the AD, and

157
00:07:41.100 --> 00:07:44.000
then we just come in here
in mail enable that user.

158
00:07:44.000 --> 00:07:45.980
That makes life a lot easier.

159
00:07:45.980 --> 00:07:47.593
And you can do this from
the PowerShell too.

160
00:07:47.593 --> 00:07:50.411
The nice part about the PowerShell
is I can mail enable tons of users.

161
00:07:50.411 --> 00:07:54.672
I could say, find every user in the entire
Active Directory, just do like a get-user,

162
00:07:54.672 --> 00:07:56.413
then that's gonna get everybody.

163
00:07:56.413 --> 00:07:58.155
Or get dash AD user.

164
00:07:58.155 --> 00:08:02.149
That'll get everybody, and then pipe that
into the new dash mail box commune and

165
00:08:02.149 --> 00:08:04.900
it'll whip them up and
you'll have it in no time.

166
00:08:04.900 --> 00:08:07.170
So that'll knock things out really fast.

167
00:08:07.170 --> 00:08:09.520
But now, I've got recipients.

168
00:08:09.520 --> 00:08:12.310
I've got these users
that are being created.

169
00:08:12.310 --> 00:08:13.940
Now I can start to email these people.

170
00:08:13.940 --> 00:08:15.180
Now they can receive email.

171
00:08:15.180 --> 00:08:18.430
But there's a little more that I
need to worry about here, right?

172
00:08:18.430 --> 00:08:21.530
When I define these recipients,
what's their email address?

173
00:08:21.530 --> 00:08:23.170
Well, I see it right over here.

174
00:08:23.170 --> 00:08:25.210
Some of them might not
like that email address.

175
00:08:25.210 --> 00:08:27.000
Like here, Christopher Walken.

176
00:08:27.000 --> 00:08:27.560
Oh, you know what?

177
00:08:27.560 --> 00:08:29.110
I spelled his name wrong, didn't I?

178
00:08:29.110 --> 00:08:31.860
If you look at the name,
it's Christopher Waken.

179
00:08:31.860 --> 00:08:33.210
I didn't spell his name right.

180
00:08:33.210 --> 00:08:35.490
So now I need to go in and fix that.

181
00:08:35.490 --> 00:08:38.080
Well there's a lot of options
that they didn't show us

182
00:08:38.080 --> 00:08:40.180
when we initially create the user.

183
00:08:40.180 --> 00:08:41.870
So if you take one of these mailboxes and

184
00:08:41.870 --> 00:08:46.740
you edit it, you'll see a lot more
options that weren't there a moment ago.

185
00:08:46.740 --> 00:08:50.629
And so I'll see things like my general
screen here where I can find my typo,

186
00:08:50.629 --> 00:08:52.496
which was in the alias right there.

187
00:08:52.496 --> 00:08:55.069
Notice how it built the email
address off of the alias and

188
00:08:55.069 --> 00:08:58.652
not off of the user account, and that's
why that alias is kind of important.

189
00:08:58.652 --> 00:09:00.630
All right, so I can fix that.

190
00:09:00.630 --> 00:09:04.290
But that's not actually
gonna fix my other problem.

191
00:09:04.290 --> 00:09:05.690
My problem is the email address.

192
00:09:05.690 --> 00:09:08.280
And as I look down the left side,
you'll see all sorts of stuff here,

193
00:09:08.280 --> 00:09:10.440
including email address.

194
00:09:10.440 --> 00:09:13.050
And I can come in here, and
I can edit that address, or

195
00:09:13.050 --> 00:09:14.027
I can even add more, right?

196
00:09:15.150 --> 00:09:18.190
Maybe Christopher's been using that
email address for weeks now and

197
00:09:18.190 --> 00:09:19.470
just didn't say anything.

198
00:09:19.470 --> 00:09:22.880
And then he comes to me and is like,
it's wrong, can you change it?

199
00:09:22.880 --> 00:09:27.530
But I'm receiving email at that old
address so can I keep the old address?

200
00:09:27.530 --> 00:09:31.400
Or maybe you have somebody who got married
and they wanna change their last name.

201
00:09:31.400 --> 00:09:33.920
Well you want them to have the old
address so they still get that email, but

202
00:09:33.920 --> 00:09:35.540
you want them to have a new address, too.

203
00:09:35.540 --> 00:09:38.579
So we might want to add more addresses
to them and you can certainly do that.

204
00:09:39.730 --> 00:09:43.700
In the background, there's this
recipient update service that runs,

205
00:09:43.700 --> 00:09:48.550
the RUS, and it looks at any new recipient
and it applies a default template

206
00:09:48.550 --> 00:09:51.660
of email addresses to the user,
so that's happening.

207
00:09:51.660 --> 00:09:55.220
You can add more addresses in
addition to the default and

208
00:09:55.220 --> 00:09:58.300
that's no big deal, or,
if you look here at the bottom, it's got

209
00:09:58.300 --> 00:10:01.820
automatically update email addresses
based on the email address policy.

210
00:10:01.820 --> 00:10:04.840
We can turn that off and
then you can remove addresses and

211
00:10:04.840 --> 00:10:07.282
change what's the default and so on.

212
00:10:07.282 --> 00:10:12.290
I'm gonna add the correct address here,
and so I'm gonna add an SMTP address.

213
00:10:12.290 --> 00:10:14.230
You'll see there's other
types of addresses supported,

214
00:10:14.230 --> 00:10:17.928
but SMTP's kind of the world
standard right now.

215
00:10:17.928 --> 00:10:23.280
And I'm gonna punch in
the properly spelled address,

216
00:10:23.280 --> 00:10:24.910
and I'll go ahead and attach that.

217
00:10:24.910 --> 00:10:29.230
Now, notice how the address
that I added says smtp and

218
00:10:29.230 --> 00:10:32.290
it's lowercase, and the other one
says SMTP and it's uppercase.

219
00:10:32.290 --> 00:10:33.470
What's that all about?

220
00:10:33.470 --> 00:10:37.460
Well, the one that's uppercase,
that's the default.

221
00:10:37.460 --> 00:10:41.085
And so this guy right here has been
flagged as the default address for him.

222
00:10:41.085 --> 00:10:44.272
So if he hits reply to an email,
it's gonna reply with that default and

223
00:10:44.272 --> 00:10:45.798
that's gonna be spelled wrong.

224
00:10:45.798 --> 00:10:47.380
So, I may not want that.

225
00:10:47.380 --> 00:10:51.390
I might wanna change that and
that's something that we can do.

226
00:10:51.390 --> 00:10:53.750
When you edit the address,

227
00:10:53.750 --> 00:10:56.370
see how I don't really have an option
to change the default here?

228
00:10:56.370 --> 00:10:57.680
The default's already set.

229
00:10:57.680 --> 00:11:01.790
It's because of this automatic update,
it's pulling from that policy.

230
00:11:01.790 --> 00:11:05.890
And if I turn that off and
save and then come back in and

231
00:11:05.890 --> 00:11:10.640
edit his user account again, now I’ll
be able to come in and manipulate that.

232
00:11:10.640 --> 00:11:14.174
And so when we take a look at these
addresses, we can edit them and

233
00:11:14.174 --> 00:11:18.755
now I’ve got make this reply address that
didn’t show up before because the policy

234
00:11:18.755 --> 00:11:20.380
was defining that.

235
00:11:20.380 --> 00:11:23.030
And so I’ll make this one the default,
the one that’s spelled right.

236
00:11:23.030 --> 00:11:25.411
He’s still got the old one
that’s spelled wrong, but

237
00:11:25.411 --> 00:11:27.033
now he’s got the correct one, too.

238
00:11:27.033 --> 00:11:28.880
All right, so you can have more addresses.

239
00:11:28.880 --> 00:11:29.740
I usually add a bunch.

240
00:11:29.740 --> 00:11:33.960
For me I’ll do D Pizzette,
Don Pizzette, Don dot Pizzette,

241
00:11:33.960 --> 00:11:37.310
you know all the different combinations
of names I think people might type,

242
00:11:37.310 --> 00:11:40.220
I'll add them all in there, and
that way I'll get all those emails.

243
00:11:40.220 --> 00:11:43.080
But then that default is
just Don at whatever.

244
00:11:43.080 --> 00:11:44.800
So you can pick that one that you want.

245
00:11:44.800 --> 00:11:46.590
You can really customize that stuff.

246
00:11:46.590 --> 00:11:48.590
There's other things that
we can tweak in here.

247
00:11:48.590 --> 00:11:52.540
Things like our general information,
name and so on.

248
00:11:52.540 --> 00:11:54.480
This is all being stored
in the Active Directory, so

249
00:11:54.480 --> 00:11:56.940
this updates your Active Directory
record at the same time.

250
00:11:56.940 --> 00:12:01.240
You can go into mailbox usage and you'll
get an example of the last time they

251
00:12:01.240 --> 00:12:04.790
logged in, this user has never logged in,
and how much data they're using,

252
00:12:04.790 --> 00:12:05.800
how big their mailbox is.

253
00:12:05.800 --> 00:12:06.480
That's pretty useful.

254
00:12:07.570 --> 00:12:09.010
You can view contact information.

255
00:12:09.010 --> 00:12:11.370
This, again, it's straight out
of the Active Directory, so

256
00:12:11.370 --> 00:12:13.970
if it's already populated there,
it's gonna be populated here.

257
00:12:13.970 --> 00:12:17.580
Or if we type it here, it'll turn around
and populate it in the Active Directory.

258
00:12:17.580 --> 00:12:23.640
So if I give Christopher a city and
a state, right, we can come in and punch

259
00:12:23.640 --> 00:12:27.750
in some of this data, well now it's gonna
be writing that to the Active Directory.

260
00:12:27.750 --> 00:12:31.050
When you set organizational values,
departments, right?

261
00:12:31.050 --> 00:12:34.060
If we're doing things like filtering
based on department we wanna make sure

262
00:12:34.060 --> 00:12:35.100
those are set.

263
00:12:35.100 --> 00:12:36.410
So we can punch those in.

264
00:12:36.410 --> 00:12:39.990
You've also got some other features,
like whether we're sharing the mailbox,

265
00:12:39.990 --> 00:12:41.070
or sharing other resources.

266
00:12:41.070 --> 00:12:42.580
I'll talk about those more in a minute.

267
00:12:44.920 --> 00:12:45.910
Those are some of the main things.

268
00:12:45.910 --> 00:12:47.510
I do wanna talk about mailbox delegation.

269
00:12:47.510 --> 00:12:49.410
I'll probably save that for
another episode though,

270
00:12:49.410 --> 00:12:51.270
where we can share mailboxes that way.

271
00:12:51.270 --> 00:12:55.220
But basically, once this is done,
I've got that user account there created.

272
00:12:55.220 --> 00:12:56.650
So, there's Christopher Walken.

273
00:12:56.650 --> 00:13:00.559
He's got a properly spelled email
address now and he's ready to rock.

274
00:13:00.559 --> 00:13:04.949
And if I jump over to
the Active Directory user for him, so

275
00:13:04.949 --> 00:13:07.243
if I come in here and find him.

276
00:13:07.243 --> 00:13:10.170
Well, actually finding him's gonna
be a little bit of a challenge.

277
00:13:10.170 --> 00:13:11.170
He's not here in the sales OU,

278
00:13:11.170 --> 00:13:15.750
and that's because when I created the
account I created it through Exchange and

279
00:13:15.750 --> 00:13:21.680
it didn't ask me for an OU, so he'll just
end up in the regular old users container,

280
00:13:21.680 --> 00:13:23.740
and there he is right there,
and I can just move him.

281
00:13:23.740 --> 00:13:25.685
I'll move him into sales.

282
00:13:25.685 --> 00:13:29.087
So we'll throw him over there, and
now I've got him right here in sales.

283
00:13:29.087 --> 00:13:31.640
And if I edit his account and
I go to address,

284
00:13:31.640 --> 00:13:34.400
see how it's got city, state, ZIP code?

285
00:13:34.400 --> 00:13:35.560
It's all tied together, right?

286
00:13:35.560 --> 00:13:38.149
Exchange is storing all this
information in the Active Directory.

287
00:13:40.608 --> 00:13:43.136
All right, now that I've got that user,
he can go and log in.

288
00:13:43.136 --> 00:13:44.884
He can log in to Outlook Web Access or

289
00:13:44.884 --> 00:13:48.751
fire up the Microsoft Outlook Client
Connect and access his mailbox, right.

290
00:13:48.751 --> 00:13:52.945
Now there are a few other types of email
recipients that we might have that

291
00:13:52.945 --> 00:13:55.160
are kinda based around users.

292
00:13:55.160 --> 00:13:59.030
In this example, the user account is
right here in my own Active Directory.

293
00:13:59.030 --> 00:14:00.800
But that's not always the case.

294
00:14:00.800 --> 00:14:02.610
What if you have a contractor, right?

295
00:14:02.610 --> 00:14:04.060
Somebody that you work with a lot.

296
00:14:04.060 --> 00:14:07.690
They've already got their own
email account set up in their own

297
00:14:07.690 --> 00:14:09.710
environment somewhere else.

298
00:14:09.710 --> 00:14:11.520
We don't wanna create a mailbox for
them here.

299
00:14:11.520 --> 00:14:13.060
They've already got their own.

300
00:14:13.060 --> 00:14:16.600
But, I want my employees to see that
contractor in the address list.

301
00:14:16.600 --> 00:14:17.746
I want them to show up.

302
00:14:17.746 --> 00:14:22.874
Well for that, we can create what's called
a contact, and a contact is not a mailbox,

303
00:14:22.874 --> 00:14:26.260
not a user, but
a reference to an external user, right?

304
00:14:26.260 --> 00:14:29.960
An external user with an external mailbox,
that's a contact.

305
00:14:29.960 --> 00:14:34.160
And so, if we jump back over
to the Exchange admin center,

306
00:14:34.160 --> 00:14:35.930
I was under mail boxes.

307
00:14:35.930 --> 00:14:38.540
You'll see over here where I
can jump over to contacts.

308
00:14:38.540 --> 00:14:41.850
And under contacts, I can start
to create these external users.

309
00:14:41.850 --> 00:14:46.220
So maybe I wanna add somebody, so
I'll go over here to mail contact,

310
00:14:47.870 --> 00:14:50.330
and I'll punch in somebody who's external,
right?

311
00:14:50.330 --> 00:14:53.170
Maybe I'll want to be able to email
Bill Gates at a moment's notice, so

312
00:14:53.170 --> 00:14:55.250
I'm gonna add in Bill Gates.

313
00:14:55.250 --> 00:14:56.540
It's got his name.

314
00:14:56.540 --> 00:15:02.610
I can punch in an alias for him, and then
I can punch in his external email address,

315
00:15:02.610 --> 00:15:05.450
which I think is bill@microsoft.com or
something like that.

316
00:15:05.450 --> 00:15:07.320
So I'm just gonna punch that in, right?

317
00:15:07.320 --> 00:15:10.220
And I can pick an OU right here or
where I wanna put this contact, but

318
00:15:10.220 --> 00:15:11.780
I'll just leave it at the default.

319
00:15:11.780 --> 00:15:16.450
When this gets created, I'll now
have a contact in my address list.

320
00:15:16.450 --> 00:15:19.620
When somebody pulls up the global address
list they'll see my Active Directory users

321
00:15:19.620 --> 00:15:21.380
and they'll see Bill Gates.

322
00:15:21.380 --> 00:15:24.800
And if they send an email to Bill Gates,
it just sends it to bill@microsoft.com.

323
00:15:24.800 --> 00:15:26.420
It's an external user.

324
00:15:26.420 --> 00:15:27.840
That's a recipient too, right?

325
00:15:27.840 --> 00:15:31.160
It's a recipient that we can email to,
it's just the mailbox isn't right here.

326
00:15:32.240 --> 00:15:35.450
Now when I created this contact,
there was another option.

327
00:15:35.450 --> 00:15:37.210
What I just did was a mail contact.

328
00:15:37.210 --> 00:15:40.740
That's an external account,
external mailbox, everything's outside.

329
00:15:40.740 --> 00:15:44.070
This is just a reference to
somebody outside our organization.

330
00:15:44.070 --> 00:15:46.895
A mail user's a little bit different,
all right?

331
00:15:46.895 --> 00:15:48.995
Let's go back to that contractor example.

332
00:15:48.995 --> 00:15:51.954
What if I want that contractor to
come into my building and do work?

333
00:15:51.954 --> 00:15:54.193
I want them to sit down and
log in on a computer.

334
00:15:54.193 --> 00:15:55.830
Well, they've got their own mailbox.

335
00:15:55.830 --> 00:15:58.768
They've got their own user account
back at their own company.

336
00:15:58.768 --> 00:16:00.927
But is that gonna let them
log in on a computer?

337
00:16:00.927 --> 00:16:06.700
No, so
a mail user is a special kind of contact.

338
00:16:06.700 --> 00:16:08.940
It's actually
an Active Directory user account.

339
00:16:08.940 --> 00:16:12.340
It's a user account that you can use to
log into computers, but instead of having

340
00:16:12.340 --> 00:16:17.460
a mailbox here, you have an external
mailbox, a mailbox stored somewhere else.

341
00:16:17.460 --> 00:16:19.570
So I might come in and create a mail user.

342
00:16:20.780 --> 00:16:25.320
And come in and define this one, so
we'll do, let's see, we did Bill Gates,

343
00:16:25.320 --> 00:16:26.770
let's do Steve Jobs this time.

344
00:16:26.770 --> 00:16:30.310
So I might want to say Steve Jobs,
cuz he would love to log in and

345
00:16:30.310 --> 00:16:35.260
administer my Windows system, and
I'll punch in that he's steve@apple.com.

346
00:16:35.260 --> 00:16:37.860
That's his external email address.

347
00:16:37.860 --> 00:16:42.340
But then I can attach this to
an existing Active Directory user or

348
00:16:42.340 --> 00:16:45.280
make an all new Active Directory user.

349
00:16:45.280 --> 00:16:48.360
So this one is going to
have a user account.

350
00:16:48.360 --> 00:16:50.130
He'll be able to log in to computers.

351
00:16:50.130 --> 00:16:54.760
He'll be able to use my system,
but his email will be external.

352
00:16:54.760 --> 00:16:58.430
And that's a big deal cuz you don't
want your contractors to have to have

353
00:16:58.430 --> 00:17:01.690
multiple mailboxes just because
they're doing work with you, right?

354
00:17:01.690 --> 00:17:05.240
We wanna try and
keep all this as simple as possible.

355
00:17:05.240 --> 00:17:06.970
So I'll get that created, and

356
00:17:06.970 --> 00:17:11.440
now they show up as a contact, even
though they have an actual user account.

357
00:17:11.440 --> 00:17:14.679
If I jump back to mailboxes,
Steve Jobs doesn't show up there.

358
00:17:14.679 --> 00:17:18.990
He has an actual user account,
but I'm not hosting his mailbox.

359
00:17:18.990 --> 00:17:20.420
That's what's called a mail user.

360
00:17:20.420 --> 00:17:24.070
The two different types of contacts there,
Mail contact and Mail user.

361
00:17:24.070 --> 00:17:26.230
Mail contact is fully external.

362
00:17:26.230 --> 00:17:29.070
Mail user is external email but
a local account.

363
00:17:32.150 --> 00:17:34.750
Another type of recipient
that we can have.

364
00:17:34.750 --> 00:17:38.320
There's a few different
ones that we can do here.

365
00:17:38.320 --> 00:17:40.200
Actually, I think I'm gonna
hold off on resources.

366
00:17:40.200 --> 00:17:41.469
Let's talk about shared mailboxes.

367
00:17:42.620 --> 00:17:45.820
Each example that I've given you guys so
far has been tied around one person.

368
00:17:45.820 --> 00:17:49.460
I've got a contact for Bill Gates,
or a contact for Steve Jobs.

369
00:17:49.460 --> 00:17:52.060
I've got a mailbox for Christopher Walken.

370
00:17:52.060 --> 00:17:53.950
These are individual people.

371
00:17:53.950 --> 00:17:56.240
What if I have somebody generic though?

372
00:17:56.240 --> 00:18:01.110
What if I wanna set up a generic
mailbox for information?

373
00:18:01.110 --> 00:18:04.630
A lot of websites, you go to the website
and at the bottom it says If you have any

374
00:18:04.630 --> 00:18:10.040
questions, email info@microsoft.com or
infor@apple.com or whatever.

375
00:18:10.040 --> 00:18:11.000
That's a generic mailbox.

376
00:18:11.000 --> 00:18:12.180
Who does that go to?

377
00:18:12.180 --> 00:18:14.910
Well, it probably goes
to a generic mailbox

378
00:18:14.910 --> 00:18:17.390
that multiple people can log into and
check.

379
00:18:17.390 --> 00:18:20.000
So it's a special kind of recipient, and

380
00:18:20.000 --> 00:18:22.650
in Exchange that's
called a shared mailbox.

381
00:18:22.650 --> 00:18:25.770
It's a special recipient because it's
not really tied to a single user,

382
00:18:25.770 --> 00:18:27.320
it's multiple users.

383
00:18:27.320 --> 00:18:29.750
And normally a recipient
is a one-to-one thing.

384
00:18:29.750 --> 00:18:32.010
The mailbox is tied to one user.

385
00:18:32.010 --> 00:18:34.100
A shared mailbox breaks that rule.

386
00:18:34.100 --> 00:18:35.900
So let's take a look at that.

387
00:18:35.900 --> 00:18:39.380
Here inside of my admin center,
if I jump over here to shared,

388
00:18:39.380 --> 00:18:43.200
then we can come in and we can start
to create these shared mailboxes.

389
00:18:43.200 --> 00:18:46.127
And what it's gonna do is it's
gonna create a mailbox, and

390
00:18:46.127 --> 00:18:48.830
it's gonna create
an Active Directory user.

391
00:18:48.830 --> 00:18:50.650
It's just gonna disable the user.

392
00:18:50.650 --> 00:18:52.830
So the user will be disabled by default.

393
00:18:52.830 --> 00:19:00.105
So I might come in here and create a new
one which I'll call something like info.

394
00:19:00.105 --> 00:19:05.270
So this is gonna be my information
mailbox, and the alias will just be info.

395
00:19:05.270 --> 00:19:08.700
And for the organizational unit,
maybe I'll stick that in my Sales OU.

396
00:19:10.880 --> 00:19:16.320
So I'm creating this info@lab.itpro.tv,
this generic mailbox.

397
00:19:16.320 --> 00:19:18.503
Okay, in the chat room they give
you the example of a help desk.

398
00:19:18.503 --> 00:19:22.895
You might have helpdesk@lab.itpro.tv and
you'd want all the help desk technicians

399
00:19:22.895 --> 00:19:25.360
to be able to log into
this single mailbox.

400
00:19:25.360 --> 00:19:28.430
Now I could set up a distribution list for
this, right?

401
00:19:28.430 --> 00:19:31.750
An email comes in and
it gets distributed to multiple people.

402
00:19:31.750 --> 00:19:33.610
But here's the problem with
the distribution list,

403
00:19:33.610 --> 00:19:35.231
especially with the help desk example.

404
00:19:36.240 --> 00:19:39.020
How do I know if somebody else has
dealt with that ticket or not?

405
00:19:39.020 --> 00:19:39.740
I don't.

406
00:19:39.740 --> 00:19:42.514
If that distribution list forwards
the ticket to five different techs,

407
00:19:42.514 --> 00:19:45.670
the five techs don't know if one
of the others have dealt with it.

408
00:19:45.670 --> 00:19:47.370
With a shared mailbox, you do.

409
00:19:47.370 --> 00:19:50.270
If you log into the shared mailbox and
it's already marked as read or

410
00:19:50.270 --> 00:19:52.150
it's already been deleted, then it's gone.

411
00:19:52.150 --> 00:19:56.100
So a shared mailbox makes sure that
everybody is on the same page.

412
00:19:56.100 --> 00:19:59.610
All right, then down at the bottom
we've got Send As permissions.

413
00:19:59.610 --> 00:20:02.720
Normally when you create a shared mailbox,
you want people to be able to read

414
00:20:02.720 --> 00:20:06.840
the email in it but not necessarily
send email as that mailbox.

415
00:20:06.840 --> 00:20:11.560
But if I want them to be able to send
email as info@lab.itpro.tv or helpdesk or

416
00:20:11.560 --> 00:20:13.800
whatever, I would add
those people to this list.

417
00:20:15.190 --> 00:20:17.880
But otherwise it's got the information
that I need created here.

418
00:20:17.880 --> 00:20:20.610
I'm gonna go ahead and
just say OK to that.

419
00:20:20.610 --> 00:20:22.950
And it's gonna create it,
it's gonna build it up.

420
00:20:22.950 --> 00:20:25.870
And what it's doing is it's
creating an Active Directory user,

421
00:20:25.870 --> 00:20:29.240
it's mail enabling the user and
then it is disabling the account.

422
00:20:30.390 --> 00:20:32.430
So it did all that in the background.

423
00:20:32.430 --> 00:20:34.770
Or in theory it did it,
I guess we can go and verify.

424
00:20:34.770 --> 00:20:40.350
If I jump over to my domain controller and
I'll just refresh this screen,

425
00:20:40.350 --> 00:20:42.560
there's the info account and
it's probably hard to see.

426
00:20:42.560 --> 00:20:46.350
There's a little, tiny black arrow on
that user, or if I go into their account

427
00:20:46.350 --> 00:20:49.980
information, I should be able to see
in here that the account is disabled.

428
00:20:49.980 --> 00:20:50.500
Yeah, right there.

429
00:20:50.500 --> 00:20:54.330
So the account's been disabled,
but it has been created and

430
00:20:54.330 --> 00:20:58.590
it's got that email address
of info@lab.itpro.tv.

431
00:20:58.590 --> 00:21:04.140
So now what I need to do is I need to give
people permission to open that mailbox.

432
00:21:04.140 --> 00:21:06.065
And the way you do it is
you edit the mailbox.

433
00:21:07.315 --> 00:21:10.765
And then in here you'll have all these
different options on the left side.

434
00:21:10.765 --> 00:21:14.005
And what we wanna do is we wanna give
people full access to the mailbox so

435
00:21:14.005 --> 00:21:16.795
they'll be able to open this up and
get into it.

436
00:21:16.795 --> 00:21:19.787
So on the left side here
you'll see mailbox delegation,

437
00:21:19.787 --> 00:21:22.617
and then you've got Full Access.

438
00:21:22.617 --> 00:21:27.127
I want to give users full access to this
mailbox, so they'll be able to open it up.

439
00:21:27.127 --> 00:21:30.135
And I would just come through and pick,
and I can do this based on a group.

440
00:21:30.135 --> 00:21:33.777
So I could say Sales, anybody in
the Sales department can open this up.

441
00:21:33.777 --> 00:21:36.497
Or I can do individual people,
like I'll just do myself here.

442
00:21:36.497 --> 00:21:41.230
I'm going to add in Don Pezet, so I'm
allowed to open up this shared mailbox.

443
00:21:41.230 --> 00:21:43.540
All right, and
we'll go ahead and save that.

444
00:21:43.540 --> 00:21:46.740
So now I've got permission
to open up the mailbox.

445
00:21:46.740 --> 00:21:48.090
How do I get into it?

446
00:21:48.090 --> 00:21:53.180
Well, back in Outlook, or you can do it
in OWA too, it works either way, but here

447
00:21:53.180 --> 00:21:56.960
in Outlook, when you fire up Outlook by
default it's opening up just your mailbox.

448
00:21:56.960 --> 00:21:58.810
You open up one mailbox.

449
00:21:58.810 --> 00:22:00.990
But you can open up other mailboxes.

450
00:22:00.990 --> 00:22:06.000
If you go up here to File and
then Open & Export,

451
00:22:06.000 --> 00:22:09.610
in here you'll see you've got
the option to open Other User's Folder.

452
00:22:09.610 --> 00:22:13.990
And we can choose that, and I'm gonna just
punch in Info, or you could browse and

453
00:22:13.990 --> 00:22:16.450
find it from the name list,
it'll be in there somewhere.

454
00:22:16.450 --> 00:22:18.500
My address list is not updated yet.

455
00:22:18.500 --> 00:22:20.400
So I'm just gonna type it in
because I don't want to wait for

456
00:22:20.400 --> 00:22:21.410
the address list to refresh.

457
00:22:21.410 --> 00:22:23.240
And I'll go ahead and say OK to that.

458
00:22:23.240 --> 00:22:27.020
It's gonna try and find that user
which it didn't find for me.

459
00:22:27.020 --> 00:22:30.625
Let me make sure I can
type the whole name.

460
00:22:33.469 --> 00:22:37.920
Well, shoot, I might have to get
that address list to refresh.

461
00:22:37.920 --> 00:22:40.630
When you create a new user, they don't
show up in the address list right away and

462
00:22:40.630 --> 00:22:42.710
so it's making it where
Outlook is not gonna pick it.

463
00:22:42.710 --> 00:22:44.490
I'll just do it through
the Outlook web app.

464
00:22:44.490 --> 00:22:46.140
That's another way we can go about it.

465
00:22:46.140 --> 00:22:48.650
When you're looking at your mailbox
here in the Outlook web app,

466
00:22:48.650 --> 00:22:50.070
you can go up to your name.

467
00:22:50.070 --> 00:22:53.450
And if you click on that, you'll see
Open another mailbox right there.

468
00:22:53.450 --> 00:22:58.230
And the nice part is this one is
pulling straight from the server and so

469
00:22:58.230 --> 00:22:59.730
it should have that information already.

470
00:22:59.730 --> 00:23:01.353
If it doesn't,
I'll just have to force my address list.

471
00:23:01.353 --> 00:23:03.280
There it goes, yep, so it found it.

472
00:23:03.280 --> 00:23:06.570
And I can choose Open, and now it's
gonna open that other mailbox, and

473
00:23:06.570 --> 00:23:08.480
I can see info.

474
00:23:08.480 --> 00:23:11.350
So when email comes in, this is the first
time I've logged in, so I've gotta pick

475
00:23:11.350 --> 00:23:18.120
a time zone, we'll go with US Eastern, and
now I'll be in that generic info mailbox.

476
00:23:18.120 --> 00:23:20.460
And I can add this
permission to other users.

477
00:23:20.460 --> 00:23:23.490
The problem with OWA is it opens
it in a separate window, so

478
00:23:23.490 --> 00:23:26.930
I've got my mail here and
I've got Info over here.

479
00:23:26.930 --> 00:23:30.570
If you open it in Outlook,
the actual client,

480
00:23:30.570 --> 00:23:33.690
it can have both mailboxes open at the
same time and that's kind of convenient.

481
00:23:33.690 --> 00:23:34.280
I just have to wait for

482
00:23:34.280 --> 00:23:37.860
my address list to update, or go and
force the address list to update.

483
00:23:37.860 --> 00:23:40.830
But otherwise I've now
got this shared mailbox.

484
00:23:40.830 --> 00:23:44.840
People can email info@lab.itpro.tv and
it will go right here, and

485
00:23:44.840 --> 00:23:48.580
I might have five or ten, however many
service reps that are all monitoring that.

486
00:23:48.580 --> 00:23:51.510
And when one person handles an email,
they can just archive it or

487
00:23:51.510 --> 00:23:55.020
delete it when they're done, and now
other people know that it's been handled.

488
00:23:55.020 --> 00:23:59.270
So kind of a nice way to have that central
gathering place for that information.

489
00:24:01.570 --> 00:24:04.854
There's another type of recipient
that I wanna talk about which is kind

490
00:24:04.854 --> 00:24:07.540
of important,
which is the resource recipient.

491
00:24:07.540 --> 00:24:11.550
But I've talked a little too much and I'm
getting kind of short on time on this one.

492
00:24:11.550 --> 00:24:14.620
So this is probably a good spot for
us to wrap this one up.

493
00:24:14.620 --> 00:24:17.680
In this episode, we got a chance
to see quite a bit of stuff.

494
00:24:17.680 --> 00:24:19.670
We got to see mailbox users.

495
00:24:19.670 --> 00:24:22.770
That's the primary recipient
type inside of Exchange.

496
00:24:22.770 --> 00:24:26.680
We got to see mail contacts
as well as mail users.

497
00:24:26.680 --> 00:24:29.850
Remember that mail contacts
were just external users,

498
00:24:29.850 --> 00:24:33.150
external email, all external,
we just do a reference to it.

499
00:24:33.150 --> 00:24:38.010
Mail user, that was where we have a local
user account but an external mailbox.

500
00:24:38.010 --> 00:24:40.580
And then we got a chance to take
a look at shared mailboxes,

501
00:24:40.580 --> 00:24:42.400
another type of recipient.

502
00:24:42.400 --> 00:24:44.190
Stay tuned, though,
cuz we're gonna do a part two and

503
00:24:44.190 --> 00:24:46.370
I wanna tackle resource recipients.

504
00:24:46.370 --> 00:24:50.610
And these are things like rooms and
projectors, equipment, stuff like that

505
00:24:50.610 --> 00:24:53.320
that we wanna make available and
keep track of inside of Exchange.

506
00:24:53.320 --> 00:24:56.750
It's some really cool functionality, so
we'll check that out in the next episode.

507
00:24:56.750 --> 00:24:58.820
But for now, we'll go ahead and
wrap this one up.

508
00:24:58.820 --> 00:25:02.994
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

509
00:25:02.994 --> 00:25:08.440
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to Exchange recipients. In this episode, Don moves on to more specialized recipients like resource mailboxes and shared mailboxes.
episodes.title: Recipients Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.141 --> 00:00:03.181
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.181 --> 00:00:10.402
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:10.402 --> 00:00:10.942
All right.

4
00:00:10.942 --> 00:00:12.682
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening.

5
00:00:12.682 --> 00:00:15.142
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.142 --> 00:00:16.665
I'm your host Don Pezet,

7
00:00:16.665 --> 00:00:20.580
back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

8
00:00:20.580 --> 00:00:24.740
And because I can't seem to keep myself
quiet, we're actually jumping into part

9
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:28.570
two of the last episode, which was
covering recipients inside of Exchange.

10
00:00:28.570 --> 00:00:30.250
I rambled on a little too long and

11
00:00:30.250 --> 00:00:33.600
I didn't have a chance to get
to the resource mailboxes.

12
00:00:33.600 --> 00:00:36.450
And so we need to take a look at those
today, because they are important,

13
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:37.311
they are on the exam.

14
00:00:37.311 --> 00:00:40.401
It is something that as administrator's
we'll typically have to set up for

15
00:00:40.401 --> 00:00:43.411
our users, and then they can start to
use them and take advantage of them.

16
00:00:43.411 --> 00:00:47.391
So, I guess, before I get ahead of myself,
what the heck is a resource mailbox?

17
00:00:47.391 --> 00:00:52.391
Well, Exchange, deep down inside,
is really just an email server, right?

18
00:00:52.391 --> 00:00:55.931
It does email, it receives email, it sends
email, it sorts it into email boxes and

19
00:00:55.931 --> 00:00:57.360
that's that.

20
00:00:57.360 --> 00:01:02.380
But, Microsoft over the years has added
on, improved it to create a full-on

21
00:01:02.380 --> 00:01:05.360
collaboration suite that
can do all sorts of things.

22
00:01:05.360 --> 00:01:08.940
Well, one of the things that it does
really well, is it's a calendar server.

23
00:01:08.940 --> 00:01:10.800
Every user has their own calendar.

24
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:14.090
And you can have group calendars for
your company, your departments, so

25
00:01:14.090 --> 00:01:17.300
that everybody can see what's
going on in the organization.

26
00:01:17.300 --> 00:01:20.580
Well, one of the things that we typically
put on calendars, are meetings.

27
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:21.570
Tons of meetings, right?

28
00:01:21.570 --> 00:01:24.510
I can't even begin to tell you guys how
many meetings I go to in a given week.

29
00:01:24.510 --> 00:01:26.550
So, we start scheduling meetings.

30
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:28.200
Well, where do you have your meeting?

31
00:01:28.200 --> 00:01:30.740
You probably have a conference room or
two.

32
00:01:30.740 --> 00:01:32.850
And other people wanna schedule meetings.

33
00:01:32.850 --> 00:01:34.120
You wanna schedule meetings.

34
00:01:34.120 --> 00:01:35.590
And now we have conflicts.

35
00:01:35.590 --> 00:01:40.110
So we need a way to track things like
conference rooms, projectors, laptops,

36
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:43.230
other equipment that we
have in limited supply.

37
00:01:43.230 --> 00:01:45.300
That we wanna make sure that
we don't over allocate.

38
00:01:45.300 --> 00:01:46.840
We have two people wanting
the same equipment or

39
00:01:46.840 --> 00:01:50.750
the same room at the same time, and
resource mailboxes let us do that.

40
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:54.720
When you create a resource mailbox,
what you're doing is you're creating

41
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:57.870
basically like an email user
that represents that item.

42
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:01.240
And then we can book it into
meetings into our calendar

43
00:02:01.240 --> 00:02:03.450
to show that it's reserved
at certain times.

44
00:02:03.450 --> 00:02:05.240
And Exchange does a great job of that.

45
00:02:05.240 --> 00:02:09.360
And it's one of the extra recipients
that we have in Exchange, and

46
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:11.500
that's why we're kind of
covering it here in this section.

47
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:12.661
So, let me show you how they work.

48
00:02:12.661 --> 00:02:15.973
I'm logged into my
Exchange Administration Center here, and

49
00:02:15.973 --> 00:02:19.981
under Recipients, you'll see a recipient
type in here called Resources.

50
00:02:19.981 --> 00:02:23.630
And when you jump into Resources, if you
haven't used this, it will be empty.

51
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:26.850
But you can come in and
you can create your resources as needed.

52
00:02:26.850 --> 00:02:29.550
Now, the resources you make are up to you.

53
00:02:29.550 --> 00:02:33.660
Microsoft really just divides them into
two categories, rooms and equipment.

54
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:37.020
So when I hit the plus sign here,
I pick, is this gonna be a room or

55
00:02:37.020 --> 00:02:37.840
an equipment mailbox?

56
00:02:37.840 --> 00:02:41.580
Now in reality, there's not much
difference between the two,

57
00:02:41.580 --> 00:02:43.790
on the backend in Exchange,
there's not much different.

58
00:02:43.790 --> 00:02:46.920
The icon is different when you
see the contact in the list.

59
00:02:46.920 --> 00:02:49.110
And rooms have a capacity,

60
00:02:49.110 --> 00:02:51.950
a certain amount of people that
can be in them, equipment doesn't.

61
00:02:51.950 --> 00:02:54.440
That's really the only
difference between the two, but

62
00:02:54.440 --> 00:02:58.350
it is a visual differentiator and
that kind of helps our end users.

63
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:01.230
So, you'd come through and
define your rooms first, and

64
00:03:01.230 --> 00:03:03.770
then define your equipment and
get those kind of set in.

65
00:03:03.770 --> 00:03:05.849
For rooms,
you're just gonna give it a name.

66
00:03:07.070 --> 00:03:09.880
So I might have conference room a,
b and c.

67
00:03:09.880 --> 00:03:11.700
So I might create Conference Room.

68
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:14.135
Wow, my spelling is amazing today.

69
00:03:14.135 --> 00:03:17.840
[LAUGH] It's just gonna get
worse from here, isn't it?

70
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:20.350
So I might have Conference Room C,
Conference Room A,

71
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:21.670
Conference Room B, whatever.

72
00:03:21.670 --> 00:03:23.850
I create those, and I give them a name.

73
00:03:23.850 --> 00:03:25.600
You can give them an alias.

74
00:03:25.600 --> 00:03:28.800
So I might just call this one
like confc or something, and

75
00:03:28.800 --> 00:03:30.970
then you can pick an OU
where they're gonna reside.

76
00:03:30.970 --> 00:03:33.730
There is actually a user
account tied to these and so

77
00:03:33.730 --> 00:03:36.990
you might want to put that into
a particular organizational unit.

78
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:39.020
There needs to be a user account attached,

79
00:03:39.020 --> 00:03:41.160
because this is kind of
like a shared mailbox.

80
00:03:41.160 --> 00:03:42.330
You might need to change something.

81
00:03:42.330 --> 00:03:45.500
You might need to cancel somebody's
reservation of a room, and somebody will

82
00:03:45.500 --> 00:03:48.040
have to be able to open that conference
room up to be able to change it.

83
00:03:48.040 --> 00:03:50.335
So that's why there's a user account.

84
00:03:50.335 --> 00:03:51.550
You can specify a location.

85
00:03:51.550 --> 00:03:56.980
So this one might be at
the ITProTV Studios, or somewhere else.

86
00:03:56.980 --> 00:04:00.390
You can give it a phone number,
and you can give it a capacity.

87
00:04:00.390 --> 00:04:02.330
That's important because in Outlook,

88
00:04:02.330 --> 00:04:05.800
we have what's called
the Meeting Assistant utility.

89
00:04:05.800 --> 00:04:10.590
And when we go to schedule a meeting,
if you have 50 people being invited, and

90
00:04:10.590 --> 00:04:11.870
you go to pick a meeting room,

91
00:04:11.870 --> 00:04:15.060
it'll actually filter it based on
whether the room is big enough.

92
00:04:15.060 --> 00:04:18.660
So if I have 50 people, and
I say this room has a capacity of 20,

93
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:20.390
it'll hide this one from the list.

94
00:04:20.390 --> 00:04:21.500
Pretty cool, right?

95
00:04:21.500 --> 00:04:24.430
If I leave the capacity empty, though,
it'll just always show up, and

96
00:04:24.430 --> 00:04:25.330
then you can pick it.

97
00:04:25.330 --> 00:04:27.779
But it is a good idea to put the
capacities there to help with selecting.

98
00:04:29.040 --> 00:04:31.640
Then it's got booking requests.

99
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:32.970
Who's allowed to book this?

100
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:37.175
By default, anybody can book the room,
and as long as it's available,

101
00:04:37.175 --> 00:04:39.850
it'll automatically accept it and
put the reservation in there.

102
00:04:39.850 --> 00:04:41.580
But you might not want that, right?

103
00:04:41.580 --> 00:04:44.490
You might want to have certain employees
who are responsible for booking the rooms,

104
00:04:44.490 --> 00:04:46.880
maybe you have a Facilities Manager or
something.

105
00:04:46.880 --> 00:04:51.180
And so you can come in and you can select
who's allowed to accept or decline those.

106
00:04:51.180 --> 00:04:54.460
And then what's gonna happen is that
person will just need to periodically open

107
00:04:54.460 --> 00:04:57.330
this mailbox, look at the requests and
go through and

108
00:04:57.330 --> 00:04:59.150
approve or deny those requests.

109
00:04:59.150 --> 00:05:01.310
But I'm gonna leave mine to automatic.

110
00:05:01.310 --> 00:05:03.640
I don't care who uses the room just
as long as they don't double book it.

111
00:05:05.640 --> 00:05:08.612
There are a few more options you can go if
you really wanna customize like the email

112
00:05:08.612 --> 00:05:10.490
address that's attached to it or whatever.

113
00:05:10.490 --> 00:05:13.110
But for most people,
those are the options that we need, and so

114
00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:17.500
we can get those set, and just hit Save,
and now I'll have a conference room.

115
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:20.700
Equipment is very similar.

116
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:23.070
The only difference with equipment
is we don't really have a capacity.

117
00:05:23.070 --> 00:05:26.790
So if I go up here and hit that plus
sign and do equipment, I can add in,

118
00:05:26.790 --> 00:05:30.940
maybe I've got a shared laptop,
a projector, some kind of cart.

119
00:05:30.940 --> 00:05:33.040
Who knows what we have?

120
00:05:33.040 --> 00:05:36.930
So, I'll just say I've got some kind
of laptop I want to be available.

121
00:05:36.930 --> 00:05:39.900
And, we can specify whether it or
not it automatically accepts.

122
00:05:39.900 --> 00:05:43.242
Notice I don't put a location for
this, and I don't put a capacity,

123
00:05:43.242 --> 00:05:45.580
cuz it's not a room, it's just a piece
of equipment that can move around.

124
00:05:45.580 --> 00:05:47.990
And you can designate delegates
who are responsible for

125
00:05:47.990 --> 00:05:51.000
managing the equipment, all right.

126
00:05:51.000 --> 00:05:52.410
So, I'll go ahead and save that one.

127
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:55.980
And so now I've got some of
these resource contacts created.

128
00:05:55.980 --> 00:05:57.650
What do I need to do from here?

129
00:05:57.650 --> 00:05:58.600
Not much.

130
00:05:58.600 --> 00:06:00.500
From here, it really manages itself.

131
00:06:00.500 --> 00:06:02.330
It's kind of neat how the system works.

132
00:06:02.330 --> 00:06:04.780
For an end user, they go into Outlook, and

133
00:06:04.780 --> 00:06:08.060
I'll use the Outlook web app
here to do this on mine.

134
00:06:08.060 --> 00:06:12.490
And when they go into their system,
they can switch to the counter view, and

135
00:06:12.490 --> 00:06:14.570
they can start to create meetings.

136
00:06:14.570 --> 00:06:18.080
In the full Outlook client,
you've got the full Meeting Wizard.

137
00:06:18.080 --> 00:06:21.090
It's really impressive cuz you can see
everybody's schedules and all of that.

138
00:06:21.090 --> 00:06:23.590
But here inside of OWA,
it's a little more limited.

139
00:06:23.590 --> 00:06:26.260
If I create a new event,
I can start to schedule this.

140
00:06:26.260 --> 00:06:30.610
So I'll say this is some kind
of kick off meeting, and

141
00:06:30.610 --> 00:06:32.640
I can specify where I want that to be.

142
00:06:32.640 --> 00:06:35.270
And for the location,
I can type in a name, or

143
00:06:35.270 --> 00:06:37.510
I've got this add room button over here.

144
00:06:37.510 --> 00:06:42.420
And I can just hit add room, and what
it's doing is it's looking at the time

145
00:06:42.420 --> 00:06:47.020
that I've selected, and it's looking
at the amount of attendees that I have.

146
00:06:47.020 --> 00:06:52.230
And it's listing for me rooms that
are big enough, and rooms that are free.

147
00:06:52.230 --> 00:06:54.920
See how all of these say free beside them?

148
00:06:54.920 --> 00:06:58.400
A room might already be booked
during a certain time, right?

149
00:06:58.400 --> 00:07:00.690
So if I create a meeting,
I'm gonna create this kick off meeting.

150
00:07:00.690 --> 00:07:02.711
I'm gonna put it in Conference Room A.

151
00:07:02.711 --> 00:07:04.489
And see how it just filled that in and

152
00:07:04.489 --> 00:07:06.931
Conference Room A becomes an attendee,
right?

153
00:07:06.931 --> 00:07:09.391
They're listed as somebody
who's gonna be attending.

154
00:07:09.391 --> 00:07:11.671
And then I can start to
invite other people.

155
00:07:11.671 --> 00:07:15.471
So I can use the plus sign here and
go through and pick other people.

156
00:07:15.471 --> 00:07:22.191
I wanna go to my Address List,
and we'll just take all.

157
00:07:22.191 --> 00:07:24.550
Oops, I went to all groups,
I wanted all contacts.

158
00:07:26.530 --> 00:07:28.050
We can invite Bill Gates.

159
00:07:28.050 --> 00:07:32.080
He's a good person to have coming to
our meeting, we'll invite Bob Denver.

160
00:07:32.080 --> 00:07:33.460
This will be a celebrity meeting, right?

161
00:07:33.460 --> 00:07:35.315
I'm just gonna start
inviting these people, and

162
00:07:35.315 --> 00:07:38.870
you'll see as I look down here,
here's laptop, here's projector, right?

163
00:07:38.870 --> 00:07:40.680
So I can start to reserve equipment too.

164
00:07:40.680 --> 00:07:43.490
I'm adding all of these
people as attendees.

165
00:07:43.490 --> 00:07:46.270
Now what's gonna happen is this is
gonna send out a meeting invite

166
00:07:46.270 --> 00:07:47.560
to all these people.

167
00:07:47.560 --> 00:07:51.550
Well, Christopher Walken, Bill Gates,
Bob Denver, they're gonna get the invite.

168
00:07:51.550 --> 00:07:55.110
And they can accept it, or
decline it, or say maybe.

169
00:07:55.110 --> 00:07:58.090
But, laptop is gonna
receive the invite and

170
00:07:58.090 --> 00:07:59.940
Conference Room A is gonna
receive the invite, and

171
00:07:59.940 --> 00:08:03.550
they're gonna automatically accept it,
unless they're booked.

172
00:08:03.550 --> 00:08:05.280
If they're booked already,
they'll decline it.

173
00:08:05.280 --> 00:08:08.420
And I'll get a message saying they
declined, and that'll be my hint to go and

174
00:08:08.420 --> 00:08:10.640
book a different room, or
find a different computer.

175
00:08:10.640 --> 00:08:13.470
So, that's that kind of way
that we keep track of that.

176
00:08:14.740 --> 00:08:17.780
And then we can specify other information
here and then we can save our meeting.

177
00:08:17.780 --> 00:08:20.060
So this one is good,
I'll go ahead and send it.

178
00:08:20.060 --> 00:08:23.330
But, even before I send it,
I can go into Scheduling Assistant, and

179
00:08:23.330 --> 00:08:24.620
in the Scheduling Assistant,

180
00:08:24.620 --> 00:08:29.260
it's gonna help look at those attendees
and try and find times that they're free.

181
00:08:29.260 --> 00:08:33.260
So, like, if that laptop is booked during
this time, I can come in here and look and

182
00:08:33.260 --> 00:08:35.090
say, all right, maybe it's booked here.

183
00:08:35.090 --> 00:08:36.412
When is it available?

184
00:08:36.412 --> 00:08:40.700
And it'll show me rooms and equipment,
then I can look for time slots when they

185
00:08:40.700 --> 00:08:44.940
are available, and start to pick
that best opportunity for me.

186
00:08:44.940 --> 00:08:48.850
So I'm gonna leave this one booked, and
I'll go ahead and send those invites out.

187
00:08:48.850 --> 00:08:53.026
Now, the invites go out, the users are
gonna be pending, but the equipment and

188
00:08:53.026 --> 00:08:55.471
the rooms, they'll automatically accept.

189
00:08:55.471 --> 00:09:00.249
So that should happen pretty quickly,
and when I, whoops, when I pull that

190
00:09:00.249 --> 00:09:04.971
meeting back up, I can see it's scheduled,
right, I did, what did I do?

191
00:09:04.971 --> 00:09:08.610
11:00 AM to 11:30, so
it's just a really short meeting.

192
00:09:08.610 --> 00:09:11.111
It's up and it's going so
we should be in business there,

193
00:09:11.111 --> 00:09:12.870
I've got my kick-off meeting.

194
00:09:12.870 --> 00:09:14.270
Terribly exciting, right?

195
00:09:14.270 --> 00:09:16.520
But if I go and
try to create another meeting.

196
00:09:16.520 --> 00:09:17.980
So I'll create another one.

197
00:09:17.980 --> 00:09:22.700
And if I try and book it and
overlap that time, right?

198
00:09:22.700 --> 00:09:27.150
When I go to add a room, see how
Conference Room A doesn't show up anymore?

199
00:09:27.150 --> 00:09:28.380
It's gone, right?

200
00:09:28.380 --> 00:09:31.620
It's gone because it's already booked
during that time, I can't pick it,

201
00:09:31.620 --> 00:09:32.330
it's not free.

202
00:09:32.330 --> 00:09:37.210
And if I go to my attendees and
I start to add in people, right?

203
00:09:37.210 --> 00:09:42.480
So I can come in here to my attendees,
and I'll find that laptop.

204
00:09:42.480 --> 00:09:46.840
Now I will see the laptop, and
when I add the laptop in as an attendee,

205
00:09:46.840 --> 00:09:48.080
it's gonna let me do it, right?

206
00:09:48.080 --> 00:09:50.950
So there it is, but
that attendee is actually busy.

207
00:09:50.950 --> 00:09:52.460
Now, I don't know it here.

208
00:09:52.460 --> 00:09:55.610
If I hit Send, it's gonna send to that
person and it's gonna bounce back and

209
00:09:55.610 --> 00:09:57.860
say nope, they decline, they're busy, and

210
00:09:57.860 --> 00:09:59.960
that's where that
Scheduling Assistant comes in.

211
00:09:59.960 --> 00:10:03.170
If I go to my Scheduling Assistant,
I can see that laptop, and

212
00:10:03.170 --> 00:10:06.570
I can see that there's a kickoff
meeting at that same time.

213
00:10:06.570 --> 00:10:09.710
When I take a look,
laptop is showing as busy.

214
00:10:09.710 --> 00:10:12.450
And so I can look at laptop's calendar.

215
00:10:12.450 --> 00:10:14.080
When are they not busy?

216
00:10:14.080 --> 00:10:15.870
Oh well, it's available at 12, so

217
00:10:15.870 --> 00:10:19.730
maybe I'll just move my
meeting forward to 12, right?

218
00:10:19.730 --> 00:10:22.890
When that person is available, and
that'll take care of that for me.

219
00:10:22.890 --> 00:10:25.771
And I can say, okay, and now I know that,

220
00:10:25.771 --> 00:10:28.990
that laptop will be available and
not busy in the other meeting.

221
00:10:28.990 --> 00:10:31.550
So we can send that along and
off it goes, right?

222
00:10:31.550 --> 00:10:35.950
So, that's how resource mailboxes
are used, the end users,

223
00:10:35.950 --> 00:10:36.790
it's easy for them, right?

224
00:10:36.790 --> 00:10:38.290
They just use it right
here inside of Outlook.

225
00:10:38.290 --> 00:10:40.350
It's all in the GUI, it's no big deal.

226
00:10:40.350 --> 00:10:44.250
For Administrators, there's two things
we need to be worried about, right?

227
00:10:44.250 --> 00:10:45.450
One is creating them, right?

228
00:10:45.450 --> 00:10:46.802
So we saw, that's easy enough, right?

229
00:10:46.802 --> 00:10:48.642
We go into Resources and we add them in.

230
00:10:48.642 --> 00:10:53.094
And then two, is dictating whether or
not they automatically accept invites or

231
00:10:53.094 --> 00:10:57.420
whether they're managed, and so you
might have to come in and change these.

232
00:10:57.420 --> 00:10:58.870
Like, if I see a lot of contention for

233
00:10:58.870 --> 00:11:02.120
the laptop,
I might need to edit that resource.

234
00:11:02.120 --> 00:11:03.490
And when you jump in there.

235
00:11:03.490 --> 00:11:06.630
it's really like a user mailbox,
there's only so many options, but

236
00:11:06.630 --> 00:11:09.260
you can set who the booking delegates are,
right?

237
00:11:09.260 --> 00:11:13.770
And this is who's allowed to deal with
this, by default and accepting everything,

238
00:11:13.770 --> 00:11:16.330
I can change that and
specify the users who manage it.

239
00:11:16.330 --> 00:11:21.210
You can also set booking options, and
see how it says allow repeated meetings?

240
00:11:21.210 --> 00:11:24.030
I might not want to allow somebody
to do a recurring meeting

241
00:11:24.030 --> 00:11:25.620
that books this room over,
and over, and over again.

242
00:11:25.620 --> 00:11:27.810
I can turn that off or leave it on.

243
00:11:27.810 --> 00:11:31.650
We can restrict it to only allowing
scheduling during business hours, right?

244
00:11:31.650 --> 00:11:33.560
I don't want people booking
this room at midnight.

245
00:11:33.560 --> 00:11:35.170
Just have it during the business hours.

246
00:11:35.170 --> 00:11:39.360
We can always decline if the end
date is beyond this limit, right?

247
00:11:39.360 --> 00:11:41.700
If I say, right here, the booking times.

248
00:11:41.700 --> 00:11:44.550
If I say, I don't want them to be
able to book nine months in advance,

249
00:11:44.550 --> 00:11:45.530
we want it to be limited.

250
00:11:45.530 --> 00:11:50.470
So, here it's got a limit of 180 days, or
what does that work out to, six months.

251
00:11:50.470 --> 00:11:53.550
So, if they try and book something beyond
six months, we can automatically decline.

252
00:11:54.680 --> 00:11:56.171
And then you got a maximum duration.

253
00:11:56.171 --> 00:12:00.191
What's the longest meeting, or the longest
time you want somebody to book a laptop?

254
00:12:00.191 --> 00:12:03.490
Do I want somebody to be able to book
that laptop for two weeks in a row?

255
00:12:03.490 --> 00:12:05.460
No, you probably want to keep
that a little more limited.

256
00:12:05.460 --> 00:12:08.750
So we could limit to a 4 hours,
or 24 hours, or whatever.

257
00:12:08.750 --> 00:12:10.850
All done right here.

258
00:12:10.850 --> 00:12:14.231
You can also tweak things like the email
address, the contact information,

259
00:12:14.231 --> 00:12:15.490
like location and all that.

260
00:12:15.490 --> 00:12:17.500
I didn't see that in the wizard
when I added the box.

261
00:12:17.500 --> 00:12:18.629
Now I can do it right here.

262
00:12:19.830 --> 00:12:23.440
And then other delegations as far as
people who might be able to send on behalf

263
00:12:23.440 --> 00:12:24.000
of that mailbox.

264
00:12:24.000 --> 00:12:27.890
So all these things can be tweaked to
customize that resource record, and

265
00:12:27.890 --> 00:12:29.510
get it to work the way we want, right?

266
00:12:29.510 --> 00:12:31.721
But as an administrator, it really
just comes down to creating these.

267
00:12:31.721 --> 00:12:33.681
You get them put in place,
and you get them there.

268
00:12:33.681 --> 00:12:36.360
Now in real life land,
let me tell you what's gonna happen.

269
00:12:36.360 --> 00:12:37.532
You're gonna set all this up.

270
00:12:37.532 --> 00:12:41.050
You're gonna set it up to be automatic and
it's gonna work great.

271
00:12:41.050 --> 00:12:46.720
And then one day, an end user
is gonna book a conference room.

272
00:12:46.720 --> 00:12:50.890
And then afterwards, your CEO is gonna try
and book that same conference room, and

273
00:12:50.890 --> 00:12:53.957
they're gonna say well, it's busy,
I'll want to kick them out.

274
00:12:53.957 --> 00:12:57.830
All right, well if we have it
