set to auto accept like this.

275
00:12:57.830 --> 00:12:59.212
It's not gonna kick them out, it's booked,

276
00:12:59.212 --> 00:13:01.300
the CEO's gonna have to
pick a different time.

277
00:13:01.300 --> 00:13:05.940
But in real life, we know, CEO gets
priority, we want them to have that room.

278
00:13:05.940 --> 00:13:07.900
So, we're gonna have to get in and
cancel that.

279
00:13:07.900 --> 00:13:11.850
Well, by default, we have to do it,
the administrators, so as an admin,

280
00:13:11.850 --> 00:13:13.590
you've got to go in and do that.

281
00:13:13.590 --> 00:13:16.200
But if you don't want to get
involved with all of that,

282
00:13:16.200 --> 00:13:18.410
it's a good idea to have
a facilities person or

283
00:13:18.410 --> 00:13:21.830
some other kind of like an office manager,
and have them be responsible for it.

284
00:13:21.830 --> 00:13:25.130
So we want to make sure we add them
as delegates to the mailboxes.

285
00:13:25.130 --> 00:13:29.240
So then they can say, all right, I'll just
go into OWA, and I'll go to open another

286
00:13:29.240 --> 00:13:33.430
user's folder, and I'll open up that
projector, or laptop, or conference room.

287
00:13:33.430 --> 00:13:37.330
And then I'll just go decline
the meeting that's already there, and

288
00:13:37.330 --> 00:13:39.110
then tell the CEO to come back in and
book it.

289
00:13:39.110 --> 00:13:41.120
They'll book it and
it'll be in business, right?

290
00:13:41.120 --> 00:13:43.160
So, that happens a lot.

291
00:13:43.160 --> 00:13:46.960
So just expect to add a delegate,
otherwise your gonna be getting

292
00:13:46.960 --> 00:13:50.260
help desk support tickets and you'll have
to become the scheduling coordinator.

293
00:13:50.260 --> 00:13:52.970
Which is not something an IT
person really wants to mess with.

294
00:13:52.970 --> 00:13:54.810
I don't know.
Maybe you do like that.

295
00:13:54.810 --> 00:13:57.582
I don't, so [LAUGH] definitely something
that we're gonna have to put in place.

296
00:13:57.582 --> 00:14:02.220
All right, well,
those are resource mailboxes and

297
00:14:02.220 --> 00:14:04.660
there's not really much
else to cover on them.

298
00:14:04.660 --> 00:14:07.530
You can get really creative and
set them up to work however you want.

299
00:14:07.530 --> 00:14:09.260
I use examples of laptops and projectors.

300
00:14:09.260 --> 00:14:11.540
It might be things like moving vans,
or trucks.

301
00:14:11.540 --> 00:14:14.550
It could be all sorts of crazy things
that you want to book in there,

302
00:14:14.550 --> 00:14:15.410
you just set it up.

303
00:14:15.410 --> 00:14:17.100
Exchange treats them all equally.

304
00:14:18.312 --> 00:14:20.980
All right, well, that's about all
I've got for resource mailboxes,

305
00:14:20.980 --> 00:14:22.000
so we'll wrap things up here.

306
00:14:22.000 --> 00:14:25.210
In this segment, we got a chance to
see setting up conference rooms,

307
00:14:25.210 --> 00:14:28.620
as well as setting up equipment, and
how we can have that shared calendar.

308
00:14:28.620 --> 00:14:30.980
How the Meeting Minder can
take advantage of that and

309
00:14:30.980 --> 00:14:34.090
help to find the best place for
that meeting and get things scheduled.

310
00:14:34.090 --> 00:14:35.650
It's really cool functionality.

311
00:14:35.650 --> 00:14:37.170
Only takes a few minutes to get it set up,

312
00:14:37.170 --> 00:14:39.610
so definitely something you'll
want to take advantage of.

313
00:14:39.610 --> 00:14:41.032
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

314
00:14:41.032 --> 00:14:44.391
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

315
00:14:44.391 --> 00:14:45.717
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the various types of distribution groups found in Exchange 2013. He demonstrates how to create and manage the groups, as well as when one group type would be preferred over another based on a client's needs.
episodes.title: Distribution Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.353 --> 00:00:10.753
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.753 --> 00:00:13.380
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:13.380 --> 00:00:15.510
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.510 --> 00:00:17.520
I'm your host, Don Pizet.

5
00:00:17.520 --> 00:00:20.460
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013 and

6
00:00:20.460 --> 00:00:24.340
in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at distribution groups,

7
00:00:24.340 --> 00:00:27.140
which are kind of an important
part of exchange.

8
00:00:27.140 --> 00:00:30.210
Because often times we find ourselves
sending an email not just to one person

9
00:00:30.210 --> 00:00:33.840
but to a group of people and
if you want to sit there and

10
00:00:33.840 --> 00:00:36.740
add people in your two field over,
over and over again, you can do that.

11
00:00:36.740 --> 00:00:40.100
But if we create a distribution group, we
can quickly and easily send one email and

12
00:00:40.100 --> 00:00:41.810
have it go to multiple recipients.

13
00:00:41.810 --> 00:00:45.050
It's a lot easier than setting up things
like shared mailboxes and all that.

14
00:00:45.050 --> 00:00:47.830
You just fire off an email and
it hits all the people involved.

15
00:00:47.830 --> 00:00:50.720
And the cool part is, with the
distribution group, you can move people

16
00:00:50.720 --> 00:00:54.520
into it, and you can take people out of it
to determine who's getting those emails.

17
00:00:54.520 --> 00:00:59.440
So it really does simplify things like
sharing incoming email across users.

18
00:00:59.440 --> 00:01:01.280
So there's a ton of different uses for it.

19
00:01:01.280 --> 00:01:03.520
Most of you guys are familiar with
distribution groups at this point so

20
00:01:03.520 --> 00:01:05.040
I'm not gonna harp on that.

21
00:01:05.040 --> 00:01:08.870
But, there are actually three different
types of distribution group or

22
00:01:08.870 --> 00:01:10.670
mailing list that we can
use inside of Exchange and

23
00:01:10.670 --> 00:01:13.800
I wanna show you guys those groups and
show you how they can be used and

24
00:01:13.800 --> 00:01:17.320
what their differences are, all right So,
I'm gonna start right here in my

25
00:01:17.320 --> 00:01:20.320
Exchange administration center and
basically I'm logged in.

26
00:01:20.320 --> 00:01:22.360
I've got a couple of recipients
that are sitting here.

27
00:01:22.360 --> 00:01:24.730
There's me, Jane Smith, John Doe, right?

28
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:26.895
However recipients that you guys have.

29
00:01:26.895 --> 00:01:30.690
And if I find that I'm constantly
emailing some of the same people over and

30
00:01:30.690 --> 00:01:33.360
over again, I might choose to
create a distribution group.

31
00:01:33.360 --> 00:01:35.385
Now end users can do this.

32
00:01:35.385 --> 00:01:39.870
End users can fire up Microsoft Outlook
and they can add users to a group.

33
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:41.910
And they can do that
until the cows come home.

34
00:01:41.910 --> 00:01:44.520
Right, but that's being stored
in their local contacts.

35
00:01:44.520 --> 00:01:46.170
And the contacts that
are part of their mail box,

36
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:48.380
it's not shared across the entire company.

37
00:01:48.380 --> 00:01:50.566
So if I want something
that everybody can use,

38
00:01:50.566 --> 00:01:54.040
I need to create it here in
the Exchange administration center.

39
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:57.020
Under recipients,
you'll see groups right up top.

40
00:01:57.020 --> 00:01:57.820
We can go under groups and

41
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:00.485
right here is where we can add
in the different group types.

42
00:02:00.485 --> 00:02:02.553
And when we go to hit this
little plus sign over here,

43
00:02:02.553 --> 00:02:06.415
that's where we'll see our three choices
and three different types of groups.

44
00:02:06.415 --> 00:02:08.285
Well, let's start with
the standard one first.

45
00:02:08.285 --> 00:02:10.305
This guy right here, a distribution group.

46
00:02:10.305 --> 00:02:13.585
A distribution group is designed
to be used for email purposes.

47
00:02:13.585 --> 00:02:16.115
I want to be able to send
an email to one address and

48
00:02:16.115 --> 00:02:18.025
have it go to more than one person, right?

49
00:02:18.025 --> 00:02:19.375
Well, what would be an example of this?

50
00:02:19.375 --> 00:02:20.419
I might have something like.

51
00:02:22.080 --> 00:02:25.960
An executives group, right?

52
00:02:25.960 --> 00:02:29.410
So all of my executive
employees go in here,

53
00:02:29.410 --> 00:02:34.220
and this is the one email list that I
can send to and hit all the executives.

54
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:36.850
So I can give it an alias.

55
00:02:36.850 --> 00:02:40.120
And then I can specify
who's gonna be in it.

56
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:41.890
Now, when I look at some
of my other options here,

57
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:44.340
I've got the organizational unit
where this group is gonna be stored.

58
00:02:44.340 --> 00:02:47.040
It is a group in the Active Directory.

59
00:02:47.040 --> 00:02:49.780
And so I might wanna browse and
choose where I want that to reside.

60
00:02:49.780 --> 00:02:54.850
I'll put mine in the ITProTV OU since
that's where my company's residing.

61
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:56.330
And then I can specify who owns it.

62
00:02:56.330 --> 00:03:00.550
Now, ownership is gonna default to you,
whoever's creating it.

63
00:03:00.550 --> 00:03:02.710
Whoever creates the group,
they're the owner.

64
00:03:02.710 --> 00:03:05.950
And as the owner, that means you have
the permission to put people in,

65
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:09.270
take people out,
to disable the group if you want.

66
00:03:09.270 --> 00:03:10.710
You control that group.

67
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:14.610
You can have more than one owner,
and the owner can be a person or

68
00:03:14.610 --> 00:03:16.450
the owner can be another group.

69
00:03:16.450 --> 00:03:19.490
We can have one group in charge of
another group if you really wanted to.

70
00:03:19.490 --> 00:03:23.210
But, the owner is just important to
determine who is able to manage ownership,

71
00:03:23.210 --> 00:03:24.900
at least in the beginning.

72
00:03:24.900 --> 00:03:27.090
After that, we have who the members are.

73
00:03:27.090 --> 00:03:30.250
Now the default members
are nobody except the owner.

74
00:03:30.250 --> 00:03:32.550
See how it says add
group owners as members.

75
00:03:32.550 --> 00:03:36.360
Well, I might be the network
administrator, but I'm not an executive so

76
00:03:36.360 --> 00:03:37.910
I don't want to be a member of the group.

77
00:03:37.910 --> 00:03:39.540
I don't want to get the executive emails.

78
00:03:39.540 --> 00:03:41.068
So I'm gonna uncheck that.

79
00:03:41.068 --> 00:03:43.890
And now I would come through an add
who ever the executives were.

80
00:03:43.890 --> 00:03:46.780
So maybe Jane Smith is our CIO.

81
00:03:46.780 --> 00:03:50.940
So, I'm gonna come in here and hit plus,
and I'll add in Jane Smith and

82
00:03:50.940 --> 00:03:54.310
any other users that I want, and
now they're gonna be in that group.

83
00:03:54.310 --> 00:03:57.850
So if I send an email to this
executives distribution group,

84
00:03:57.850 --> 00:03:59.301
she's gonna get a copy of it.

85
00:03:59.301 --> 00:04:04.580
And maybe old John Doe is our CTO,
or some other title.

86
00:04:04.580 --> 00:04:07.630
I can add him in and
now both of them will get the emails.

87
00:04:07.630 --> 00:04:10.430
Now, they are getting
separate copies of the email.

88
00:04:10.430 --> 00:04:13.640
So, if one of them marks it as read,
it's still unread for the other, and

89
00:04:13.640 --> 00:04:16.070
if one of them deletes it,
it's still present for the others.

90
00:04:16.070 --> 00:04:19.437
It's actually stored more than
once in the mailbox database.

91
00:04:19.437 --> 00:04:23.157
So it's still separate but
I have one address to be able to reach and

92
00:04:23.157 --> 00:04:25.710
contact these people, all right.

93
00:04:25.710 --> 00:04:29.140
Now the neat thing about this
distribution groups is, by default,

94
00:04:29.140 --> 00:04:30.990
the owner controls who's in it.

95
00:04:30.990 --> 00:04:34.170
So if I make a regular user,
if I make Jane, the owner.

96
00:04:34.170 --> 00:04:36.800
Jane can go and add and
remove people from the group on her own.

97
00:04:36.800 --> 00:04:39.520
She can do it right from inside
of Outlook or Outlook web app.

98
00:04:39.520 --> 00:04:41.695
And it really does make
life a little easier there,

99
00:04:41.695 --> 00:04:43.810
cuz we don't have to administer it.

100
00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:48.260
But you can actually set up cool things,
like self service groups,

101
00:04:48.260 --> 00:04:50.980
where people can opt in and
opt out of the group at their leisure.

102
00:04:50.980 --> 00:04:53.150
I'm going to save that for
a little bit later, but

103
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:55.960
you'll see those options right
down here where it's asking,

104
00:04:55.960 --> 00:05:00.390
should anybody be able to join, or
should anybody be able to leave?

105
00:05:00.390 --> 00:05:04.320
And the default is, well you've gotta
be approved by the group owner.

106
00:05:04.320 --> 00:05:06.050
The group owner controls that.

107
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:08.730
But you can actually set it to be
automatic where people can kind of move

108
00:05:08.730 --> 00:05:10.060
in and out.

109
00:05:10.060 --> 00:05:13.510
And, you know actually, I said the default
had to be approved, but you'll see

110
00:05:13.510 --> 00:05:16.980
here it's actually defaulting to not
being approved so I can switch that.

111
00:05:16.980 --> 00:05:20.380
And I'm gonna make it where the owner
is the person who has to do it.

112
00:05:20.380 --> 00:05:22.610
So we can kinda tweak these settings.

113
00:05:22.610 --> 00:05:25.210
I'll revisit these in a few minutes and
we'll get to see it in action.

114
00:05:26.320 --> 00:05:30.350
But once it's done, I can hit Save, and
I've now got a distribution group, and

115
00:05:30.350 --> 00:05:32.910
if I go back into the properties
of the distribution group,

116
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:35.030
I can see what its email address is.

117
00:05:35.030 --> 00:05:39.370
It's gonna show up in my global address
book, so anybody who goes into Outlook or

118
00:05:39.370 --> 00:05:42.220
OWA and pulls up the global address list,
they'll be able to find

119
00:05:42.220 --> 00:05:47.590
this executives group in there and email
it, and then it'll hit all the executives.

120
00:05:47.590 --> 00:05:51.410
If we edit that, we can go back in here
and look at our email addresses and

121
00:05:51.410 --> 00:05:53.470
it should have,
assuming it's not already taken,

122
00:05:53.470 --> 00:05:56.850
it should've assigned it
executives@itprotv.net.

123
00:05:56.850 --> 00:06:00.330
It uses the alias that I put in to
determine what that email address

124
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:01.790
is going to be.

125
00:06:01.790 --> 00:06:04.150
So there's that alias I
put in when I created it.

126
00:06:04.150 --> 00:06:08.170
And over here,
if I go to my email options,

127
00:06:08.170 --> 00:06:10.700
we can see it got executives@itprotv.net.

128
00:06:10.700 --> 00:06:11.770
I can change that.

129
00:06:11.770 --> 00:06:12.740
I'm gonna have more than one.

130
00:06:12.740 --> 00:06:16.030
I might want to put in some other
aliases on my own just in case.

131
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:20.900
You know,
maybe somebody emails exec@itprotv.net,

132
00:06:20.900 --> 00:06:24.280
or maybe I've got more than one domain and
I want to punch those in.

133
00:06:24.280 --> 00:06:28.050
So I can fill all that stuff out and
it'll get put in there, right?

134
00:06:28.050 --> 00:06:31.250
There are a few other interesting
things you can tailor in here.

135
00:06:31.250 --> 00:06:33.200
For example, delivery management.

136
00:06:33.200 --> 00:06:35.910
Notice the default setting for this group.

137
00:06:35.910 --> 00:06:38.720
Only senders inside my
organization can use it.

138
00:06:39.780 --> 00:06:42.280
What if I'm trying to create
a distribution group that I want

139
00:06:42.280 --> 00:06:44.540
a lot of people to be able to use,
like the internet?

140
00:06:44.540 --> 00:06:49.290
Maybe in my company, I decide that I
want to have an email address called

141
00:06:49.290 --> 00:06:52.320
information or sales,
maybe I have a sales team.

142
00:06:52.320 --> 00:06:55.720
And so
I want to create a sales@itprotv.net.

143
00:06:55.720 --> 00:06:58.160
And I want anybody on the internet
to be able to email it.

144
00:06:58.160 --> 00:07:01.160
Well that's gonna be a problem
because the default setting there,

145
00:07:01.160 --> 00:07:04.200
is that only people in my
organization can do this.

146
00:07:04.200 --> 00:07:08.280
We might need to change that setting to
allow the internet to be able to use it.

147
00:07:08.280 --> 00:07:09.860
Let's run with the sales example.

148
00:07:09.860 --> 00:07:11.730
So I have a sales department, and

149
00:07:11.730 --> 00:07:15.370
in my sales department I have users that
are in there and so I want to be able to

150
00:07:15.370 --> 00:07:19.880
send an email to sales@itprotv.net and
have it go to all those people.

151
00:07:19.880 --> 00:07:22.280
And I also want it to be
available from the internet, so

152
00:07:22.280 --> 00:07:25.450
I know I can whip up
a distribution group and do that.

153
00:07:25.450 --> 00:07:29.640
But the odds are, if you've got a sales
department, you probably already have some

154
00:07:29.640 --> 00:07:31.940
Active Directory groups that
are in place that you're using for

155
00:07:31.940 --> 00:07:36.920
permissions that would be nice if
you could use as email groups also.

156
00:07:36.920 --> 00:07:42.180
Well, a distribution group, by default,
can only be used for email, and that's it.

157
00:07:42.180 --> 00:07:43.750
It can't be used for permissions.

158
00:07:43.750 --> 00:07:46.670
So it's got one purpose, and
that one purpose is email.

159
00:07:46.670 --> 00:07:50.538
But if I have a group that I want
to do both email and permissions,

160
00:07:50.538 --> 00:07:55.640
then instead of creating a distributions
group, I should create a security group.

161
00:07:55.640 --> 00:07:57.800
A security group can be used for
both, right?

162
00:07:57.800 --> 00:07:59.090
Not just email.

163
00:07:59.090 --> 00:08:01.000
So it's done right here form
the same screen, though.

164
00:08:01.000 --> 00:08:03.210
If I come back in here and I hit add.

165
00:08:03.210 --> 00:08:07.245
I can choose to add a security group,
and when I add a security group,

166
00:08:07.245 --> 00:08:11.440
now it's gonna create an active
directory group on the back end.

167
00:08:11.440 --> 00:08:16.490
And so I might create a group
called Sales Department, and

168
00:08:16.490 --> 00:08:18.580
I might give it an alias of just Sales.

169
00:08:18.580 --> 00:08:19.220
All right.

170
00:08:19.220 --> 00:08:21.030
And then I can give it that description.

171
00:08:21.030 --> 00:08:23.120
This is just like the other screen we saw,
right.

172
00:08:23.120 --> 00:08:25.210
We have our owner, we have our members.

173
00:08:25.210 --> 00:08:27.360
I'll add John Doe to this list.

174
00:08:27.360 --> 00:08:29.160
And we get these people put in,

175
00:08:29.160 --> 00:08:32.750
and then when I save it it's
gonna create that group.

176
00:08:32.750 --> 00:08:37.150
Now, when I created it I didn't
point to it there, I should have.

177
00:08:37.150 --> 00:08:40.000
It didn't have that
automatic membership stuff.

178
00:08:40.000 --> 00:08:43.900
Users can't automatically join or
unjoin a security group.

179
00:08:43.900 --> 00:08:45.220
You're either in it or you're not, and

180
00:08:45.220 --> 00:08:48.000
whoever's the owner of that
group is what tailors that, so

181
00:08:48.000 --> 00:08:51.620
we don't have that self-service
portal type kind of configuration.

182
00:08:51.620 --> 00:08:55.200
But now I've got this sales group,
and this sales group is

183
00:08:55.200 --> 00:08:59.480
an actual active directory security group
that I can use to assign permissions.

184
00:08:59.480 --> 00:09:02.760
I can say, anybody who's in the sales
group can print to this printer, or

185
00:09:02.760 --> 00:09:04.590
can write to these files.

186
00:09:04.590 --> 00:09:08.070
But I can also shoot an email
to sales@itprotv.net,

187
00:09:08.070 --> 00:09:09.760
and it's gonna go to all these people,
right.

188
00:09:09.760 --> 00:09:13.505
So it's kind of a multi-purpose group,
I can use it for more than one thing.

189
00:09:13.505 --> 00:09:17.595
But even for this one, I'm gonna
need to edit that, and then go into

190
00:09:17.595 --> 00:09:21.575
its delivery options to set it so that the
outside world will be able to email to it.

191
00:09:21.575 --> 00:09:25.925
So when I go to delivery management,
I can say, senders inside and

192
00:09:25.925 --> 00:09:27.857
outside of the organization
will be able to send to it.

193
00:09:27.857 --> 00:09:30.145
That's an important part
to be able to have that.

194
00:09:31.650 --> 00:09:32.760
All right.

195
00:09:32.760 --> 00:09:36.630
So once we've got that in place,
now you've got that distribution group.

196
00:09:36.630 --> 00:09:40.240
People can receive email,
it comes to that main email and

197
00:09:40.240 --> 00:09:42.900
then it gets distributed out to all
the individual mailboxes behind it.

198
00:09:42.900 --> 00:09:46.850
Now if they reply to that email,
who are they replying as?

199
00:09:46.850 --> 00:09:48.760
Well, they're gonna reply as themselves.

200
00:09:48.760 --> 00:09:51.830
So the email might have gone
to sales@itprotv.net, but

201
00:09:51.830 --> 00:09:56.070
when John replies to it,
he's gonna reply as John@itprotv.net.

202
00:09:56.070 --> 00:09:57.740
And that may be what I want, or

203
00:09:57.740 --> 00:10:00.670
I might want people to be able
to send on behalf of the group.

204
00:10:00.670 --> 00:10:03.730
Now, the group doesn't actually have
a mailbox, so it's a little bit different.

205
00:10:03.730 --> 00:10:05.669
But you'll notice when
we go into the settings,

206
00:10:06.930 --> 00:10:09.540
that you've actually got that option
where you can set delegation.

207
00:10:09.540 --> 00:10:12.660
So you can allow somebody to use
that address when they send.

208
00:10:12.660 --> 00:10:16.970
So if we kinda look down the list here,
you'll see group delegation, and

209
00:10:16.970 --> 00:10:22.150
we can delegate out whether they have
send as or send on behalf of that group.

210
00:10:22.150 --> 00:10:26.040
So even though it doesn't have a dedicated
mailbox, we can still send as it, right.

211
00:10:26.040 --> 00:10:27.400
So it's kind of a neat thing.

212
00:10:27.400 --> 00:10:29.040
I say it doesn't have a dedicated mailbox.

213
00:10:29.040 --> 00:10:31.160
It actually kind of does on the back end.

214
00:10:31.160 --> 00:10:32.690
It doesn't save the email,
but it does exist.

215
00:10:35.150 --> 00:10:38.860
Alright, so those are our first two
types of groups, distribution groups and

216
00:10:38.860 --> 00:10:39.550
security groups.

217
00:10:39.550 --> 00:10:41.710
Remember the key difference there
is security groups can be used for

218
00:10:41.710 --> 00:10:45.540
permissions and email, distribution
groups can just be used for email.

219
00:10:45.540 --> 00:10:49.590
Now it is important that you pick
the right group type from the beginning

220
00:10:49.590 --> 00:10:51.240
cuz you can't change your mind later.

221
00:10:51.240 --> 00:10:56.180
There's no way to convert a distribution
group to a security group or

222
00:10:56.180 --> 00:10:56.690
the other way around.

223
00:10:56.690 --> 00:10:58.410
You can't convert a security
group to a distribution group.

224
00:10:58.410 --> 00:11:00.740
So if you have to change it later on,

225
00:11:00.740 --> 00:11:03.740
You actually have to create an all new
group set it with the same membership and

226
00:11:03.740 --> 00:11:05.940
then delete the other one so
it's kind of a hassle.

227
00:11:05.940 --> 00:11:07.760
Make sure you choose
correctly in the beginning.

228
00:11:09.170 --> 00:11:13.360
All right the other thing, the other group
is what's called a dynamic group and

229
00:11:13.360 --> 00:11:15.930
dynamic groups are the most flexible.

230
00:11:15.930 --> 00:11:18.830
One of the problems with these like I
just set up the sales department group.

231
00:11:18.830 --> 00:11:19.430
Right.

232
00:11:19.430 --> 00:11:24.010
So any time I hire a new salesperson, I've
gotta add them to this group, don't I?

233
00:11:24.010 --> 00:11:25.560
Right, and that's a bit of a pain.

234
00:11:25.560 --> 00:11:29.590
If I'm using templates, then I can
go in and I can copy the user and

235
00:11:29.590 --> 00:11:32.860
I can add them, copying the user
that's already in this group and

236
00:11:32.860 --> 00:11:35.050
it'll automatically add them to the group,
right.

237
00:11:35.050 --> 00:11:40.810
But if I'm using Exchange, right here, for
example, let's say I had an IT department

238
00:11:40.810 --> 00:11:47.320
group, and I went into my active
directory, which is here.

239
00:11:47.320 --> 00:11:52.510
I'll go into my Active Directory, and
I'll go into my IT organizational unit.

240
00:11:52.510 --> 00:11:56.720
And when I go in there, I'll see that
I'm in IT, and so is Jane Smith.

241
00:11:56.720 --> 00:12:01.520
And so I create this IT group,
and I put us in it.

242
00:12:01.520 --> 00:12:02.050
Right?

243
00:12:02.050 --> 00:12:03.950
Now people can email the IT department.

244
00:12:03.950 --> 00:12:07.500
But when I hire a new employee, I have to
remember to put them in that group and

245
00:12:07.500 --> 00:12:11.410
if I'm creating them from the GUI
that's not gonna happen, right?

246
00:12:11.410 --> 00:12:12.460
Let me show you.

247
00:12:12.460 --> 00:12:17.039
So if I go back here, I'm gonna
create a new group that I'll call IT.

248
00:12:17.039 --> 00:12:20.410
So I'm just gonna do a distribution
group and I'll call it IT.

249
00:12:20.410 --> 00:12:23.430
And, you know, we'll give an alias.

250
00:12:24.740 --> 00:12:26.310
And I'm gonna browse through
organizational unit.

251
00:12:26.310 --> 00:12:29.730
I'm gonna put it in the IT
department there, all right?

252
00:12:29.730 --> 00:12:35.078
And then for the members I'll come in
here and I'll add Jane and myself.

253
00:12:37.092 --> 00:12:38.980
So let's just get added in there.

254
00:12:38.980 --> 00:12:41.930
There we go.
And so Jane and I are now in the group.

255
00:12:41.930 --> 00:12:42.630
And things are great.

256
00:12:42.630 --> 00:12:44.390
Right?
People can email the IT department and

257
00:12:44.390 --> 00:12:45.560
we're gonna get it.

258
00:12:45.560 --> 00:12:49.370
But then I hire a new employee and
so I go over here to mailboxes, and

259
00:12:49.370 --> 00:12:50.680
I add a new recipient.

260
00:12:50.680 --> 00:12:52.500
Right, so I'm gonna add a user mailbox.

261
00:12:52.500 --> 00:12:56.230
And this is gonna be, oh I don't know,

262
00:12:56.230 --> 00:13:01.670
we'll just do Tom Jones,
all right, so So tjones.

263
00:13:01.670 --> 00:13:06.710
And so we'll give him a first name here
of Tom and last name of Jones, right?

264
00:13:06.710 --> 00:13:09.475
And for the organizational unit,
I'm going to browse and put them in IT,

265
00:13:09.475 --> 00:13:11.605
because Tom's going to be in
the IT department with us.

266
00:13:11.605 --> 00:13:14.980
And then I can give him his login name and

267
00:13:14.980 --> 00:13:20.780
his password, all right,
and we'll save that.

268
00:13:20.780 --> 00:13:27.040
Now, Tom's in the IT OU, and the IT
Distribution Group is in that OU also.

269
00:13:27.040 --> 00:13:31.210
But, there's nothing that says,
hey put Tom into that group.

270
00:13:31.210 --> 00:13:32.620
So when I go back to my groups, and

271
00:13:32.620 --> 00:13:36.200
I take a look at my IT department,
he's not going to be in it, right.

272
00:13:36.200 --> 00:13:38.140
So I have to remember to come back and
change this.

273
00:13:38.140 --> 00:13:41.450
The more distribution groups that people
are a part of, the harder this becomes.

274
00:13:41.450 --> 00:13:43.225
It becomes a real hassle.

275
00:13:43.225 --> 00:13:47.900
So It'd be nice if we could have
groups that maintain themselves,

276
00:13:47.900 --> 00:13:51.220
where I didn't have to come in and
add every new employee.

277
00:13:51.220 --> 00:13:53.920
Every time I hire somebody, I don't
want to have to come in and add them in.

278
00:13:53.920 --> 00:13:57.018
I just want them to already be there.

279
00:13:57.018 --> 00:13:59.050
So in my scenario,
I don't have that right now.

280
00:13:59.050 --> 00:14:02.440
A dynamic distribution
group will help me do that.

281
00:14:02.440 --> 00:14:06.750
The way a dynamic distribution group works
is it doesn't have a hard-set membership.

282
00:14:06.750 --> 00:14:09.090
We don't say,
here's the members of this group.

283
00:14:09.090 --> 00:14:13.820
Instead, we give it an active directory
query, a query that it can run that says,

284
00:14:13.820 --> 00:14:17.210
here's how you can figure
out who your membership is.

285
00:14:17.210 --> 00:14:19.910
And every time somebody sends
an email to that group,

286
00:14:19.910 --> 00:14:21.750
it does a query to figure
out who the members are.

287
00:14:21.750 --> 00:14:24.490
So it's always up to date and
we don't have to remember to do it.

288
00:14:24.490 --> 00:14:26.210
So that's pretty cool.

289
00:14:26.210 --> 00:14:28.150
If we add new users,
they're automatically added.

290
00:14:28.150 --> 00:14:31.050
If we fire people, disable accounts,
they're automatically removed.

291
00:14:31.050 --> 00:14:32.760
No maintenance required, all right?

292
00:14:32.760 --> 00:14:34.730
But it does require setting
up a little bit of a query,

293
00:14:34.730 --> 00:14:36.450
we have to kind of sort that out.

294
00:14:36.450 --> 00:14:40.340
In the GUI there's some nice really
easy drop down boxes we can use, but

295
00:14:40.340 --> 00:14:42.540
you can go to the PowerShell
an you can get really specific.

296
00:14:42.540 --> 00:14:46.420
You can say give me just people in the IT
department whose last name starts with

297
00:14:46.420 --> 00:14:48.490
S and who also work in Florida.

298
00:14:48.490 --> 00:14:49.940
You can do that right?

299
00:14:49.940 --> 00:14:51.970
From the GUI it's a little
more simplified but

300
00:14:51.970 --> 00:14:54.270
the GUI actually gives us
the key one that we need.

301
00:14:54.270 --> 00:14:57.190
Most of the times dynamic
distribution groups are based on

302
00:14:57.190 --> 00:14:59.180
organizational unit membership.

303
00:14:59.180 --> 00:15:03.400
I can say, I want an IT
distribution group that's based on

304
00:15:03.400 --> 00:15:07.220
all the people in the IT department who
are all gonna be in the IT OU and so

305
00:15:07.220 --> 00:15:10.820
I can just build it right around that and
it's automatically gonna update.

306
00:15:10.820 --> 00:15:11.990
Now, be careful.

307
00:15:11.990 --> 00:15:14.240
The more of these groups you create,

308
00:15:14.240 --> 00:15:17.060
the more active directory queries
that are happening, right?

309
00:15:17.060 --> 00:15:18.690
Because every time
somebody sends an email,

310
00:15:18.690 --> 00:15:20.780
it's gotta do that query
to look up the membership.

311
00:15:20.780 --> 00:15:25.040
So if this is a really high traffic
address, if it's receiving millions of

312
00:15:25.040 --> 00:15:28.770
emails a day, that can be a little bit
burdensome on the domain controllers so

313
00:15:28.770 --> 00:15:30.480
you might have to improve
your domain controllers.

314
00:15:30.480 --> 00:15:31.860
Just monitor performance.

315
00:15:31.860 --> 00:15:34.000
Most people aren't receiving
email at that volume and

316
00:15:34.000 --> 00:15:38.160
so it's not a big deal and it'll be
a negligible impact on your server.

317
00:15:38.160 --> 00:15:39.630
So let’s create one of these dynamic ones.

318
00:15:39.630 --> 00:15:43.070
I'm gonna delete this IT group that I just
created cuz it does not meet my needs,

319
00:15:43.070 --> 00:15:44.350
right, or wait we'll create a new one.

320
00:15:44.350 --> 00:15:45.550
We'll do a help desk.

321
00:15:45.550 --> 00:15:48.710
I want a help desk email that
goes to all my IT people, right?

322
00:15:48.710 --> 00:15:52.470
So I'm gonna go to add and this time I'm
gonna choose dynamic distribution group.

323
00:15:52.470 --> 00:15:54.800
Now notice there's no
dynamic security group.

324
00:15:54.800 --> 00:15:57.800
It doesn't support that because It
would be an exponential increase,

325
00:15:57.800 --> 00:15:59.500
the amount of lookups you'd have to do.

326
00:15:59.500 --> 00:16:00.878
Every time you accessed a file or
a folder,

327
00:16:00.878 --> 00:16:02.448
it would have to look up
that group membership and

328
00:16:02.448 --> 00:16:03.500
that would just be a nightmare.

329
00:16:03.500 --> 00:16:04.640
So you can't do that.

330
00:16:04.640 --> 00:16:08.050
But I can do a dynamic distribution group,
and it's very similar to the other one.

331
00:16:08.050 --> 00:16:09.210
We give it a name.

332
00:16:09.210 --> 00:16:10.510
I'll call this one Help Desk.

333
00:16:10.510 --> 00:16:12.090
I'll give it an alias.

334
00:16:12.090 --> 00:16:13.858
I'll just call it helpdesk, or

335
00:16:13.858 --> 00:16:18.710
this could be support if we want it to
be our tech support, whatever it is.

336
00:16:18.710 --> 00:16:20.940
We can specify the organizational
unit it resides in,

337
00:16:20.940 --> 00:16:22.569
I'll pop this into the IT department.

338
00:16:24.380 --> 00:16:27.550
Who the owner is, and if I leave it blank,
it's just gonna make me the owner, so,

339
00:16:27.550 --> 00:16:28.890
I don't have to worry there.

340
00:16:28.890 --> 00:16:31.060
But then after that is where
the screen gets different.

341
00:16:31.060 --> 00:16:34.138
Here's where we can start
to specify our query, okay.

342
00:16:34.138 --> 00:16:36.170
And the query's made up of two parts.

343
00:16:36.170 --> 00:16:38.924
The first part is what type of
recipients I wanna get, all right.

344
00:16:38.924 --> 00:16:44.120
Now, if I pointed at the IT OU and
this group is in the IT OU it kind

345
00:16:44.120 --> 00:16:46.980
of creates a bit of a loop, and I might
not want to get other groups and stuff.

346
00:16:46.980 --> 00:16:51.420
So I'm really just looking for people
that have Exchange mailboxes, right?

347
00:16:51.420 --> 00:16:54.560
I might not want contacts or resource
mailboxes or other things like that so

348
00:16:54.560 --> 00:16:55.770
I can filter those out.

349
00:16:55.770 --> 00:16:57.800
Usually we just want people
with mailboxes, all right?

350
00:16:57.800 --> 00:16:58.820
We don't want anything else.

351
00:16:59.890 --> 00:17:01.570
Then, we add our rules.

352
00:17:01.570 --> 00:17:05.360
And your rule is basically what's
specifying the people to find.

353
00:17:05.360 --> 00:17:07.550
So if I want people who
are in a particular OU,

354
00:17:07.550 --> 00:17:10.970
who work in a particular state,
I can add these rules in.

355
00:17:10.970 --> 00:17:12.550
You can add multiple ones.

356
00:17:12.550 --> 00:17:15.902
Now, in the GUI we only
have these canned rules.

357
00:17:15.902 --> 00:17:19.002
But from PowerShell, you can actually
write really complex ones and

358
00:17:19.002 --> 00:17:22.380
do whatever you want, but these are some
of the key ones that we might want.

359
00:17:22.380 --> 00:17:23.330
For example,

360
00:17:23.330 --> 00:17:28.358
Recipient container, I just want users
that have mailboxes that are in the IT OU.

361
00:17:28.358 --> 00:17:30.582
And so I'm gonna pick that role.

362
00:17:30.582 --> 00:17:35.930
That's the one I want, people in
the IT department organizational unit.

363
00:17:35.930 --> 00:17:38.458
And now when I save that,
this distribution group,

364
00:17:38.458 --> 00:17:40.540
I don't have to tell it the membership.

365
00:17:40.540 --> 00:17:44.230
It just goes and queries the AD, looks
in that OU and gets those users back.

366
00:17:44.230 --> 00:17:46.930
And it should be doing that already, okay?

367
00:17:46.930 --> 00:17:50.950
So if I edit that, there's not a whole
heck of a lot that I can change on them.

368
00:17:50.950 --> 00:17:53.310
I'm not gonna see all the membership
stuff because that's all static.

369
00:17:53.310 --> 00:17:54.440
Well, I mean it's dynamic.

370
00:17:54.440 --> 00:17:55.840
It's querying it in the background.

371
00:17:55.840 --> 00:17:59.570
But I can see membership and
modify the query.

372
00:17:59.570 --> 00:18:03.420
So I can tweak that query if I need to,
to get it set just right, and then we can

373
00:18:03.420 --> 00:18:06.050
adjust our delivery management,
just like any other distribution group.

374
00:18:06.050 --> 00:18:09.160
I'd probably want to make this one,
public, all right.

375
00:18:09.160 --> 00:18:12.048
But where this gets really cool is
if I come in and add a new mailbox,

376
00:18:12.048 --> 00:18:15.059
it's automatically going to get
added to this distribution group.

377
00:18:15.059 --> 00:18:19.980
And when you take a look at these,
that makes life a lot easier.

378
00:18:19.980 --> 00:18:24.800
So now, if I were to fire off
an email to helpdesk@itprotv.net,

379
00:18:24.800 --> 00:18:26.780
it does a query in the background.

380
00:18:26.780 --> 00:18:31.231
It looks for everybody in that IT OU,
and that's who the email goes to.

381
00:18:31.231 --> 00:18:33.480
And if I disable a user,
it doesn't go to them anymore.

382
00:18:33.480 --> 00:18:35.803
If I move them out of the OU,
it doesn't go to them anymore.

383
00:18:35.803 --> 00:18:39.340
And if I had new users, they're
automatically added in, so pretty cool.

384
00:18:39.340 --> 00:18:40.511
We have to maintain that query.

385
00:18:40.511 --> 00:18:43.140
That's a little bit of extra work,
all right?

386
00:18:43.140 --> 00:18:46.610
So, dynamic distribution groups are a
great way to take the load off of us as

387
00:18:46.610 --> 00:18:47.130
administrators.

388
00:18:47.130 --> 00:18:48.690
They automatically update.

389
00:18:48.690 --> 00:18:52.130
But another solution is just to push
that load off to our end users and say,

390
00:18:52.130 --> 00:18:54.150
let's let them deal with it, right?

391
00:18:54.150 --> 00:18:58.530
We can create distribution groups that
have self-service membership, right?

392
00:18:58.530 --> 00:19:00.615
And that's kinda what I
highlighted earlier, but

393
00:19:00.615 --> 00:19:03.096
let me show you the kinda details,
how we can get this set up.

394
00:19:03.096 --> 00:19:07.260
And let the end users do the work for us,
cuz that kinda is nice when it happens.

395
00:19:07.260 --> 00:19:11.880
So, let's say, for example,
that we've got a distribution group for

396
00:19:11.880 --> 00:19:13.320
some leadership training we're doing.

397
00:19:13.320 --> 00:19:14.970
Right, so there's gonna be
some leadership training, and

398
00:19:14.970 --> 00:19:16.390
they want a leadership email address.

399
00:19:16.390 --> 00:19:22.450
So we create a distribution group and
we call it Leadership Training, all right?

400
00:19:22.450 --> 00:19:24.740
And the Leadership Training is optional.

401
00:19:24.740 --> 00:19:27.440
Users can choose to be a part of
the training or they can choose not to.

402
00:19:27.440 --> 00:19:28.860
Right, if they're a leader,
they wanna be a part of it.

403
00:19:28.860 --> 00:19:30.675
If they're not, then they don't.

404
00:19:30.675 --> 00:19:33.745
So what we don't wanna do, though, is we
don't want to have to constantly add or

405
00:19:33.745 --> 00:19:35.355
remove people from the list.

406
00:19:35.355 --> 00:19:37.948
So we want to set this up so
that users can opt in, right.

407
00:19:37.948 --> 00:19:40.778
They can join the list, or they can
leave it at their own advance, right,

408
00:19:40.778 --> 00:19:42.445
just whatever they want.

409
00:19:42.445 --> 00:19:46.320
So I'm gonna create this,
and I'll pop it into our OU.

410
00:19:46.320 --> 00:19:48.160
I'll leave the administrator
here as the owner.

411
00:19:48.160 --> 00:19:51.180
We would add in whoever was in charge of
the leadership group, we would add them.

412
00:19:51.180 --> 00:19:54.855
So maybe it's Jane Smith, so
I'll add her as an owner also.

413
00:19:54.855 --> 00:19:57.809
And you can stay an owner as
administrator if you want.

414
00:19:57.809 --> 00:20:03.690
You don't have to, but it's kind of up
to how you plan on administering this.

415
00:20:03.690 --> 00:20:05.920
And then down here we can add
the group owners as members.

416
00:20:05.920 --> 00:20:08.760
Now, I don't wanna be a member,
but we'll make Jane a member.

417
00:20:08.760 --> 00:20:10.888
And so I'm gonna have to manually add her.

418
00:20:10.888 --> 00:20:14.140
And you could add anybody else that wanted
too, but I'll just add Jane for now.

419
00:20:14.140 --> 00:20:15.600
Okay, so there's Jane.

420
00:20:15.600 --> 00:20:19.220
And then down below I can pick
how the membership is controlled.

421
00:20:19.220 --> 00:20:21.010
Now, there's three ways to do it.

422
00:20:21.010 --> 00:20:22.400
One, we can close it off.

423
00:20:22.400 --> 00:20:25.464
All right, if you close it off,
Jane would have to manually go and

424
00:20:25.464 --> 00:20:27.210
add people to the group or remove it.

425
00:20:27.210 --> 00:20:27.710
She's an owner.

426
00:20:27.710 --> 00:20:29.210
She can do it, all right?

427
00:20:29.210 --> 00:20:31.200
But she'd have to do it manually.

428
00:20:31.200 --> 00:20:33.696
But if we choose one of the other two,
open and closed.

429
00:20:33.696 --> 00:20:35.730
These are a little bit different, okay?

430
00:20:35.730 --> 00:20:41.070
With closed, users can see the group,
and they can request to join.

431
00:20:41.070 --> 00:20:44.820
But if they request to join, they'll
be rejected automatically, all right.

432
00:20:44.820 --> 00:20:46.492
Now Jane'll see that rejection.

433
00:20:46.492 --> 00:20:48.607
And she could go and
override that if you wanted, but

434
00:20:48.607 --> 00:20:50.900
it'll just be rejected automatically.

435
00:20:50.900 --> 00:20:55.820
But open, anybody can see the group,
and they can join it, right?

436
00:20:55.820 --> 00:20:59.340
It says here, they can join this group
without being approved by the group owner.

437
00:20:59.340 --> 00:21:01.859
They don't have to get approval,
they can just opt-in.

438
00:21:01.859 --> 00:21:05.020
And then if they want out,
right down here, they can opt-out.

439
00:21:05.020 --> 00:21:08.680
Open means anyone can come in and
leave when they want, all right?

440
00:21:08.680 --> 00:21:12.840
Closed means they can't come and go,
Jane will have to manually add them.

441
00:21:12.840 --> 00:21:17.300
Owner approval means they
can submit a request, and

442
00:21:17.300 --> 00:21:20.340
Jane will have to approve or
decline it based on her decision.

443
00:21:20.340 --> 00:21:23.700
She'll get an email with a little check or
an x, and she'll pick and

444
00:21:23.700 --> 00:21:25.660
choose whether she wants to let them in.

445
00:21:25.660 --> 00:21:27.997
But if I make this one open,
I'm just gonna make it open,

446
00:21:27.997 --> 00:21:30.345
any employee can join
the leadership group if they want.

447
00:21:30.345 --> 00:21:34.705
I'll save that, and
now users can opt-in on their own, okay.

448
00:21:34.705 --> 00:21:37.345
Now this is gonna require
a little bit of user education.

449
00:21:37.345 --> 00:21:40.093
So now that we've got that set up,
we go and we tell Jane, hey Jane,

450
00:21:40.093 --> 00:21:41.815
we set up that mailing list you needed.

451
00:21:41.815 --> 00:21:44.965
You've got your leadership group,
here's what you need to tell people.

452
00:21:44.965 --> 00:21:47.799
Send out an email to the users,
or whatever, and just say,

453
00:21:47.799 --> 00:21:51.159
hey If you'd like to be a part of my
group, here's what you need to do.

454
00:21:51.159 --> 00:21:54.890
Log into OWA, go into your settings,
and join the group.

455
00:21:54.890 --> 00:21:55.860
Here's the steps, right?

456
00:21:55.860 --> 00:21:57.230
Let me show you guys how it works.

457
00:21:57.230 --> 00:22:01.782
I'll do an incognito window or
InPrivate browsing.

458
00:22:01.782 --> 00:22:05.747
Shows which browser I normally use,
but I'll [LAUGH] go ahead and

459
00:22:05.747 --> 00:22:07.817
get logged into OWA, all right?

460
00:22:07.817 --> 00:22:09.996
And when I login,
I'm gonna login as myself.

461
00:22:09.996 --> 00:22:17.450
So, I'll be dpezet@itvpro.net and
I'll sign in.

462
00:22:17.450 --> 00:22:19.800
All right, so
I'm gonna get logged in here now.

463
00:22:19.800 --> 00:22:23.540
Jane, I made her a member of the group,
but nobody else was a member of the group.

464
00:22:23.540 --> 00:22:24.830
It's just Jane.

465
00:22:24.830 --> 00:22:26.980
So when I get logged in, I'm not a member.

466
00:22:26.980 --> 00:22:28.740
But I can opt-in to it.

467
00:22:28.740 --> 00:22:30.380
I'll go into my settings.

468
00:22:30.380 --> 00:22:31.731
I'll go into the groups area, and

469
00:22:31.731 --> 00:22:33.839
you'll be able to see
the groups that are available.

470
00:22:33.839 --> 00:22:39.737
And you can pick and choose to join
the group, so let me just save that.

471
00:22:39.737 --> 00:22:40.358
And we'll get in there.

472
00:22:40.358 --> 00:22:43.871
Now, where it's not intuitive, the reason
you have to tell the end users is most end

473
00:22:43.871 --> 00:22:47.660
users, they're gonna see these
groups in their global address list.

474
00:22:47.660 --> 00:22:50.363
And they're gonna think,
well how do I join it?

475
00:22:50.363 --> 00:22:51.576
And they're in the global address list.

476
00:22:51.576 --> 00:22:54.741
And so, it's not intuitive for them to
think, I've gotta go into my options, but

477
00:22:54.741 --> 00:22:55.930
that's exactly how it works.

478
00:22:55.930 --> 00:23:00.640
So, I gotta go up here to my gear, and
in here we can go into our Options.

479
00:23:00.640 --> 00:23:05.330
And in your Options, inside of OWA
on the left side, you've got groups.

480
00:23:05.330 --> 00:23:08.725
And when you go to groups, that's what's
gonna pull up the groups that you're

481
00:23:08.725 --> 00:23:12.330
already a member of as well as showing
ones that you could potentially join.

482
00:23:12.330 --> 00:23:13.450
So we'll give that
a second while it updates.

483
00:23:13.450 --> 00:23:15.670
This is the first time
I've logged in I guess.

484
00:23:15.670 --> 00:23:17.437
See how it shows distribution
groups I belong to?

485
00:23:17.437 --> 00:23:19.115
I already belong to IT, right?

486
00:23:19.115 --> 00:23:22.420
And groups that I own,
these are ones that I'm the manager of.

487
00:23:23.500 --> 00:23:25.920
And so if you were Jane and
you wanted to add or remove people,

488
00:23:25.920 --> 00:23:28.310
you'd go right in here to groups
that I own, and edit the group.

489
00:23:28.310 --> 00:23:30.510
And you could then edit its membership,
right?

490
00:23:30.510 --> 00:23:33.100
But if I want to join a group,
right up here,

491
00:23:33.100 --> 00:23:37.665
you'll see the little people with a plus
sign, and that lets us join a group.

492
00:23:37.665 --> 00:23:40.770
Or the people with a minus
sign lets us leave a group.

493
00:23:40.770 --> 00:23:44.540
And if we've got it set to open,
we can hit the people with a plus.

494
00:23:44.540 --> 00:23:47.510
We can go to join, and
here's all the groups that are open.

495
00:23:47.510 --> 00:23:50.270
I've got sales department, IT,
apparently I left those open.

496
00:23:50.270 --> 00:23:52.920
But I can choose Leadership Training, and

497
00:23:52.920 --> 00:23:58.730
if it's set to truly be open,
then I'm gonna be able to join it.

498
00:23:58.730 --> 00:24:02.850
If it's set to owner approval,
this will kick off an email to Jane.

499
00:24:02.850 --> 00:24:05.730
Jane'll get an email, and she'll be able
to approve or decline it, just like any

500
00:24:05.730 --> 00:24:08.428
kind of calendar invite you approve or
decline, that's what she'll get.

501
00:24:08.428 --> 00:24:11.180
And if she approves it, I'm in, and
if she declines it, I'm not, right?

502
00:24:11.180 --> 00:24:15.240
But in this case I can select the group I
want and I can hit the join button, and

503
00:24:15.240 --> 00:24:16.830
it's gonna update.

504
00:24:16.830 --> 00:24:17.960
I should be joining that group.

505
00:24:17.960 --> 00:24:20.740
There we go, I've successfully joined
the group Leadership Training.

506
00:24:20.740 --> 00:24:23.799
Or it would say, an email has been
sent to the group administrator for

507
00:24:23.799 --> 00:24:24.712
approval, right.

508
00:24:24.712 --> 00:24:26.940
So it's kind of letting me
know what that status is.

509
00:24:26.940 --> 00:24:30.680
And when I close out, now I can see
I'm in the Leadership Training, right.

510
00:24:30.680 --> 00:24:32.962
I'm a member of that group,
I opted in, and

511
00:24:32.962 --> 00:24:35.325
I didn't have to get
the help desk involved.

512
00:24:35.325 --> 00:24:38.215
And then if I decide I'm kinda
done with the leadership group.

513
00:24:38.215 --> 00:24:39.472
I've learned all I'm gonna learn.

514
00:24:39.472 --> 00:24:42.888
I can come right back into here,
choose Leadership Training, and

515
00:24:42.888 --> 00:24:44.500
choose to unjoin it.

516
00:24:44.500 --> 00:24:47.650
And here it'll say it's going to unjoin
me, and now I'm out of the group.

517
00:24:47.650 --> 00:24:50.720
The owner of the group didn't have to
do anything, and the IT department,

518
00:24:50.720 --> 00:24:52.400
the administrators,
didn't have to do anything.

519
00:24:52.400 --> 00:24:54.810
That's really the perfect
world right there, right?

520
00:24:54.810 --> 00:24:59.040
So, dynamic access groups,
they can query that AD and

521
00:24:59.040 --> 00:25:01.300
automatically build up the membership.

522
00:25:01.300 --> 00:25:04.593
These guys, though, self service groups,
the end users can control it themselves,

523
00:25:04.593 --> 00:25:05.550
so that's pretty cool.

524
00:25:05.550 --> 00:25:07.930
It's a neat way to do it.

525
00:25:07.930 --> 00:25:10.130
All right, that's about all I've
got on distribution groups.

526
00:25:10.130 --> 00:25:12.730
Do remember that if you want to get some
really complex queries written in there,

527
00:25:12.730 --> 00:25:14.800
you can drop to PowerShell and
you can write some amazing ones.

528
00:25:14.800 --> 00:25:18.010
Check out Microsoft's Technet website,
they've got some great examples on there.

529
00:25:18.010 --> 00:25:21.088
But the GUI part, that’s really all
they want you to know for the exam.

530
00:25:21.088 --> 00:25:23.740
And in real life, [LAUGH] it’s
what most of us are going to use,

531
00:25:23.740 --> 00:25:27.097
cuz organizational units really lend
themselves to filtering pretty well.

532
00:25:27.097 --> 00:25:30.570
All right, well, in this episode, we got
a chance to see some new recipient types,

533
00:25:30.570 --> 00:25:32.380
right, the distribution groups.

534
00:25:32.380 --> 00:25:36.170
And we saw standard distribution groups,
which are just used for email, and

535
00:25:36.170 --> 00:25:38.670
we saw the self-service
functionality on those.

536
00:25:38.670 --> 00:25:42.813
We got to see security groups,
which are used for email and permissions.

537
00:25:42.813 --> 00:25:45.763
And then lastly we got to see
dynamic distribution groups,

538
00:25:45.763 --> 00:25:49.800
which can do an LDAP query to populate
automatically and stay up to date.

539
00:25:49.800 --> 00:25:51.180
Three different types of groups,

540
00:25:51.180 --> 00:25:54.120
three different use case scenarios,
all useful, right?

541
00:25:54.120 --> 00:25:56.790
And definitely something you'll
end up using in the real world.

542
00:25:56.790 --> 00:25:58.580
So, hope you guys enjoyed it.

543
00:25:58.580 --> 00:26:02.680
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

544
00:26:02.680 --> 00:26:08.228
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates the various methods for users to delegate access to their Exchange email. He covers Send As, Send on Behalf of, and Full Access delegations as well as which should be used in what scenarios.
episodes.title: Mailbox Delegation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.559
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.559 --> 00:00:13.452
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening and

3
00:00:13.452 --> 00:00:16.018
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.018 --> 00:00:18.737
I'm your host Don Pezet
back again with another

5
00:00:18.737 --> 00:00:21.210
episode of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:21.210 --> 00:00:24.836
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at delegating permissions on

7
00:00:24.836 --> 00:00:28.253
a mailbox or as I like to call it,
pushing our work off on somebody else.

8
00:00:28.253 --> 00:00:31.501
Because why bother sending your own email
when somebody else can do it for you?

9
00:00:31.501 --> 00:00:34.007
[LAUGH] So
this is actually a pretty common setup,

10
00:00:34.007 --> 00:00:35.543
where you get a lot of people.

11
00:00:35.543 --> 00:00:39.666
People who are executives, like a CEO
where they get a high volume of email and

12
00:00:39.666 --> 00:00:44.360
they can't possibly deal with all the
email themselves, so they have assistants.

13
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:47.312
Or it might be like a celebrity,
who has a celebrity mailbox and

14
00:00:47.312 --> 00:00:49.947
they have an agent or
a PR firm that handles the replies.

15
00:00:49.947 --> 00:00:54.511
So there's plenty of times where we need
other people not necessarily to be able

16
00:00:54.511 --> 00:00:57.914
to have full access to our mailbox,
but to be able to reply or

17
00:00:57.914 --> 00:01:02.360
send emails on our behalf and that's
a feature that's built in to Exchange.

18
00:01:02.360 --> 00:01:04.952
And it's one of the more interesting ones,
because there's so

19
00:01:04.952 --> 00:01:07.050
many different ways to configure it.

20
00:01:07.050 --> 00:01:09.070
Sending on behalf of somebody or

21
00:01:09.070 --> 00:01:12.980
delegating permissions to send as you,
it's something we can set up as

22
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:16.020
administrators right inside of
the Exchange Admin Center or

23
00:01:16.020 --> 00:01:20.110
it's something the end users can set up
themselves without getting us involved.

24
00:01:20.110 --> 00:01:22.495
So from that perspective,
the setting it up in Outlook,

25
00:01:22.495 --> 00:01:23.899
we can just let them deal with it.

26
00:01:23.899 --> 00:01:25.267
That's not our problem.

27
00:01:25.267 --> 00:01:28.470
But we can set it up inside of Exchange,
so we need to know it.

28
00:01:28.470 --> 00:01:30.821
It is on the exam and it's something
we just want to be aware of.

29
00:01:30.821 --> 00:01:34.180
So let's take a look at that and
I'll give you guys an example.

30
00:01:34.180 --> 00:01:38.088
So here inside my Exchange environment,
I've got a couple recipients set up and

31
00:01:38.088 --> 00:01:39.709
I've got Bob Denver right here.

32
00:01:39.709 --> 00:01:43.483
And so Bob, he might be really busy a nd
he needs somebody to be able to send email

33
00:01:43.483 --> 00:01:44.600
on his behalf.

34
00:01:44.600 --> 00:01:48.413
So maybe he has an assistant and we'll say
that Jane Smith here is his assistant.

35
00:01:48.413 --> 00:01:53.330
And we want Jane to be able to
send emails on Bob's behalf.

36
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:57.078
So if we go and take Bob's account here,
we can edit his account.

37
00:01:57.078 --> 00:01:59.244
And in tthe settings for his mailbox,

38
00:01:59.244 --> 00:02:02.707
you'll see down here where
we've got mailbox delegation.

39
00:02:02.707 --> 00:02:06.520
Now there's actually three
different ways to do delegation.

40
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:08.300
The first one is Send As.

41
00:02:08.300 --> 00:02:10.055
Well, Send As is kind of
what I'm talking about.

42
00:02:10.055 --> 00:02:15.840
I want Jane to be able to Send As Bob and
right beneath it, I've got Send on Behalf.

43
00:02:15.840 --> 00:02:18.520
I want Jane to Send on Behalf of Bob also.

44
00:02:18.520 --> 00:02:20.120
What's the difference?

45
00:02:20.120 --> 00:02:22.080
Well, the difference is how this shows up.

46
00:02:22.080 --> 00:02:28.530
If I give Jane Send As permissions, she
can now send an email as if she were Bob.

47
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:31.444
And whoever receives the email
will have no way to know,

48
00:02:31.444 --> 00:02:33.492
whether it was Bob that sent it or Jane.

49
00:02:33.492 --> 00:02:36.213
It's very obvious that it was
just sent by Bob and that's it.

50
00:02:36.213 --> 00:02:39.120
They have no idea about who else
might have been behind the scenes.

51
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:44.080
So when we choose Send As,
we're obscuring who the actual sender is.

52
00:02:44.080 --> 00:02:48.302
When we do Send on Behalf though,
they'll receive an email and

53
00:02:48.302 --> 00:02:52.844
the recipient who receives that
email will see this email comes from

54
00:02:52.844 --> 00:02:55.246
Jane Smith on behalf of Bob Denver.

55
00:02:55.246 --> 00:02:59.387
So it's actually indicated right there
in the from field that it was sent by

56
00:02:59.387 --> 00:03:00.504
somebody else, but

57
00:03:00.504 --> 00:03:04.390
somebody with the authority to
email on that person's behalf.

58
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:08.905
So the choice we're really making here is
do we want to be apparent that somebody's

59
00:03:08.905 --> 00:03:10.399
impersonating somebody?

60
00:03:10.399 --> 00:03:11.901
Or do we want it to be seamless and

61
00:03:11.901 --> 00:03:14.980
invisible that somebody's
impersonating somebody?

62
00:03:14.980 --> 00:03:17.534
Send As,
that's the seamless invisible one.

63
00:03:17.534 --> 00:03:19.930
Send on Behalf, that's the visible one.

64
00:03:19.930 --> 00:03:22.004
The one you can tell what's going on.

65
00:03:22.004 --> 00:03:23.710
There is a third way to do it.

66
00:03:23.710 --> 00:03:27.647
If you scroll down to the very
bottom here, you've got Full Access.

67
00:03:27.647 --> 00:03:30.735
We could give Jane Full Access
to Bob's mailbox,

68
00:03:30.735 --> 00:03:34.340
that's a lot different
than the send permissions.

69
00:03:34.340 --> 00:03:37.120
Send permissions,
Jane can send emails Bob, but

70
00:03:37.120 --> 00:03:41.030
she couldn't necessarily go in and
delete emails out of his mailbox.

71
00:03:42.140 --> 00:03:45.130
She doesn't have that, she has
the permission to send not to go in and

72
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:46.210
delete things.

73
00:03:46.210 --> 00:03:49.325
If I give her full access though,
she can do whatever she wants.

74
00:03:49.325 --> 00:03:50.830
Now sometimes we want that.

75
00:03:50.830 --> 00:03:53.950
We want her to be able to create
calendar items or approve or

76
00:03:53.950 --> 00:03:55.680
decline meeting invitations.

77
00:03:55.680 --> 00:03:59.580
We might want her to be able to
delete emails to clean up an inbox.

78
00:03:59.580 --> 00:04:03.014
So if it's that tight of a partnership
between the people, then yeah,

79
00:04:03.014 --> 00:04:06.695
you'll probably do full access and
give them all the access that they need.

80
00:04:06.695 --> 00:04:09.870
But let's start here with just the Send
on Behalf of, cuz that's the one that's

81
00:04:09.870 --> 00:04:12.730
the easiest to see and
we'll get a chance to see how that works.

82
00:04:12.730 --> 00:04:15.836
So if I want Jane to be able to send
on Bob's behalf, I can come in and

83
00:04:15.836 --> 00:04:17.453
just add her to the list of people.

84
00:04:17.453 --> 00:04:21.760
So I'm gonna hit the plus sign and
I'll pick Jane and we'll get her added in.

85
00:04:21.760 --> 00:04:23.177
And you can add more than one person,

86
00:04:23.177 --> 00:04:25.987
you might have a whole team of people
that handles this person's email.

87
00:04:25.987 --> 00:04:29.170
You just punch each one of them in and
then you'll be in business.

88
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:32.735
So I'm gonna get that set and I'll save
it right there and now, it's got it.

89
00:04:32.735 --> 00:04:36.890
Now, what if I want Jane to be able
to send on several people's behalf?

90
00:04:36.890 --> 00:04:40.090
Well, I can go through and
edit each of their mailboxes one by one or

91
00:04:40.090 --> 00:04:41.819
we could do it from the PowerShell.

92
00:04:41.819 --> 00:04:44.745
And from the PowerShell,
it's a little more convenient,

93
00:04:44.745 --> 00:04:48.194
cuz you can do like a Get-Mailbox to
pull all the mailboxes you want and

94
00:04:48.194 --> 00:04:51.570
then feed that into the command
to assign her permissions.

95
00:04:51.570 --> 00:04:54.601
Just to show an example,
if I wanna give her permissions over Bob's

96
00:04:54.601 --> 00:04:57.803
mailbox from the PowerShell,
the command looks something like this.

97
00:04:57.803 --> 00:05:02.945
I would say Set-Mailbox,
cuz I'm changing some mailbox settings and

98
00:05:02.945 --> 00:05:06.380
I'm changing Bob Denver's mailbox.

99

And if you're not sure if the name of

But if you're not sure,
you can always experiment around I'll do

00:05:12.990 --> 00:05:17.080
a Get-Mailbox bobdenver so yeah,
I can see that is the mailbox that I want.

00:05:18.310 --> 00:05:21.702
And so I'm gonna say,

00:05:21.702 --> 00:05:29.100
And then I'm gonna say,
GrantSendOnBehalfTo.

00:05:29.100 --> 00:05:34.411
That's the permission that I wanna give

00:05:34.411 --> 00:05:36.820
Oops, if I put a space in there,

00:05:36.820 --> 00:05:37.382

Well, we might want to do the Get-Mailbox

00:05:52.300 --> 00:05:54.304

00:05:55.990 --> 00:05:59.664
It's easier than the GUI that's

00:05:59.664 --> 00:06:02.640
Now the other permissions
kind of come into play too.

00:06:02.640 --> 00:06:06.504
If I wanted to give her Send As or
if I wanted to give her full access,

00:06:06.504 --> 00:06:08.026
I could just modify this.

117
00:06:08.026 --> 00:06:13.380
For the access rights,
here I'm saying, -GrantSendOnBehalfTo.

118
00:06:13.380 --> 00:06:18.019
We could also say, oh,
guess the other ones are extended rights.

119
00:06:18.019 --> 00:06:19.580
The command's a little bit different.

120
00:06:19.580 --> 00:06:25.036
Like if I wanted to give her Send As,
there's a difference.

121
00:06:25.036 --> 00:06:27.458
[LAUGH] This is gonna get a little
confusing, so let me try and

00:06:27.458 --> 00:06:29.440

123
00:06:29.440 --> 00:06:33.500
When we look at Bob's account and
we go under mailbox delegation,

124
00:06:33.500 --> 00:06:37.430
see how they're Send As, there's Send
on Behalf and there's Full Access.

125
00:06:38.630 --> 00:06:43.290
Send on Behalf is the only one the end
users can configure themselves.

126
00:06:43.290 --> 00:06:46.506
And so,
it's like a very high-level permission.

127
00:06:46.506 --> 00:06:49.780
The end user can do it,
the admins can do it, it's very flexible.

128
00:06:49.780 --> 00:06:53.329
And so when I do it in PowerShell,
I've actually got a tag for

129
00:06:53.329 --> 00:06:55.358
that, -GrandSendOnBehalfTo.

130
00:06:55.358 --> 00:06:57.620
So nice and easy to do that one.

131
00:06:57.620 --> 00:07:02.350
But the other two, Send As, where
you're actually impersonating somebody.

132
00:07:02.350 --> 00:07:05.287
Or Full Access, where you have
total access to the mailbox,

133
00:07:05.287 --> 00:07:08.291
those are a big deal and
end users can't do those on their own.

134
00:07:08.291 --> 00:07:10.670
They can't set those
permissions on their own.

135
00:07:10.670 --> 00:07:13.027
We have to set those for them.

136
00:07:13.027 --> 00:07:17.179
And so as a result, I don't have this nice

137
00:07:17.179 --> 00:07:20.800
to give Jane that access, instead it
has to be a little bit different.

138
00:07:20.800 --> 00:07:25.136
We have to say, ExtendedRights Send-As and

139
00:07:25.136 --> 00:07:30.395
then we have to specify who
that user's is going to be.

140
00:07:30.395 --> 00:07:32.595
The user in this case is janesmith.

141
00:07:32.595 --> 00:07:33.290
And actually, you know what?

00:07:33.290 --> 00:07:36.383
I'm doing sent mailbox,

143
00:07:36.383 --> 00:07:38.947
It's an ExtendedRight on
the Active Directory object, so

144
00:07:38.947 --> 00:07:41.677
the command's gonna look a little
bit different for this one.

145
00:07:41.677 --> 00:07:46.295
It's gonna be Add-ADPermission,
there we go.

146
00:07:46.295 --> 00:07:51.149
And I'm gonna be adding it
to bobdenver's account and

147
00:07:51.149 --> 00:07:56.108
then I'll say,
-ExtendedRights Send-As -user and

148
00:07:56.108 --> 00:07:59.496
then that's where it's janesmith.

149
00:07:59.496 --> 00:08:01.063
It's a different command.

150
00:08:01.063 --> 00:08:02.922
And so, why is it so different?

151
00:08:02.922 --> 00:08:05.590
Well, it's because it's actually
a permission on the account.

152
00:08:05.590 --> 00:08:07.740
Administrators have to set it,
the end users can't do it.

153
00:08:07.740 --> 00:08:11.770
So it's not tied to the mailbox as much as
it is tied to the active directory user

154
00:08:11.770 --> 00:08:12.990
account itself.

155
00:08:12.990 --> 00:08:15.420
And so this would give her
the full send as permissions.

156
00:08:15.420 --> 00:08:16.660
Now, I don't want to do that just yet.

I want to hold off, cuz I want to show you

All right now I've assigned her send

00:08:28.120 --> 00:08:32.260

So you can add somebody in right here,

So I'm just gonna leave

00:09:54.570 --> 00:09:59.150
now, he can send emails, or

Jane.

So to do that,

You hit the ellipsis button,

But once you've got

see how she can drop that down and

He's in the list because she's

she can choose to send as Bob Denver

Okay.

Now, if the permissions are set correctly,

my address right, so she's going to try to

She doesn't have send of behalf

here's a system administrator

If I switch back to my account.

00:13:31.630 --> 00:13:34.690

00:13:36.410 --> 00:13:42.204

Now when I get logged in, what I expect to

Either way, that's how it worked.

00:14:17.920 --> 00:14:19.465

00:14:19.465 --> 00:14:24.560
Now, we can change that to give

00:14:24.560 --> 00:14:25.800
now it's gonna be different.

00:14:25.800 --> 00:14:28.730
And that's what I was kinda showing

290
00:14:28.730 --> 00:14:32.050
if I give her send as permissions

00:14:32.050 --> 00:14:37.430
now she can actually act as that person

00:14:37.430 --> 00:14:41.960
So we can do that, we can jump into our
Exchange settings, we can edit Bob and

00:14:41.960 --> 00:14:46.560
we can go in here and

00:14:46.560 --> 00:14:49.250

00:14:49.250 --> 00:14:51.756
You don't want somebody to be in both,

00:14:51.756 --> 00:14:54.300
It will actually let you do it,

297
00:14:54.300 --> 00:14:57.580
So you usually want somebody to either
have send as or send on behalf of,

298
00:14:57.580 --> 00:14:58.080
not both.

299
00:14:59.560 --> 00:15:02.270
But now,
when she has that send as permission,

300
00:15:02.270 --> 00:15:03.940
it's not on behalf of Bob anymore.

301
00:15:03.940 --> 00:15:06.560
It's actually as Bob.

302
00:15:06.560 --> 00:15:09.930
And so when people receive those emails,

303
00:15:09.930 --> 00:15:11.360
They'll just see that it's from Bob.

304
00:15:12.540 --> 00:15:15.590
Now, making changes like this

00:15:15.590 --> 00:15:20.210
So I just made the change, but it could be
an hour before it actually takes effect,

306
00:15:20.210 --> 00:15:22.960
so don't expect this one to happen

307
00:15:22.960 --> 00:15:25.940
And that's because the permissions
have to propagate out and

308
00:15:25.940 --> 00:15:28.460
Outlook caches a lot
of this stuff offline.

309
00:15:28.460 --> 00:15:30.350
So it's actually kind of
cached her permissions.

310
00:15:30.350 --> 00:15:32.470
And so it can take a little while for

311
00:15:32.470 --> 00:15:37.020
Now the other permission that was in

00:15:37.020 --> 00:15:40.970
The send as ones,
those she can send email as the person,

00:15:40.970 --> 00:15:43.670
she can read the email cuz
you might want to reply.

314
00:15:43.670 --> 00:15:44.950
But she can't delete anything.

315
00:15:44.950 --> 00:15:47.485
If we do the send, I mean,

00:15:47.485 --> 00:15:49.435
then she can do whatever she wants.

317
00:15:49.435 --> 00:15:51.593
She can delete emails and

00:15:51.593 --> 00:15:54.253
So we do have to be careful with that one.

00:15:54.253 --> 00:15:58.838
If we want to give somebody Full
access via the GUI is the easiest.

00:15:58.838 --> 00:16:01.647
You can do it from the PowerShell too,
though.

321
00:16:01.647 --> 00:16:07.032
And from the PowerShell the command
is a little bit different.

00:16:07.032 --> 00:16:08.350
What did I do here?

00:16:08.350 --> 00:16:10.130
I left that command up from before.

00:16:10.130 --> 00:16:13.782
So [COUGH] if we wanna set it from
