00:16:13.782 --> 00:16:18.680
Add-MailboxPermission -Identity.

326
00:16:18.680 --> 00:16:23.350
And we can specify who we're assigning
permissions to, so I might say bobdenver.

327
00:16:23.350 --> 00:16:25.430
I want to assign permissions.

328
00:16:25.430 --> 00:16:29.025
And then I want to assign
permissions to janesmith.

329
00:16:29.025 --> 00:16:31.645
That's the person I'm
giving permissions to, and

330
00:16:31.645 --> 00:16:39.425
I wanna give her -AccessRights FullAccess.

331
00:16:39.425 --> 00:16:42.065
And then we can say, and
this is kind of an important part.

332
00:16:42.065 --> 00:16:45.285
By default it applies to
the root of the mailbox and

333
00:16:45.285 --> 00:16:47.015
not necessarily the subfolders.

334
00:16:47.015 --> 00:16:47.935
And so I need to come in and

335
00:16:47.935 --> 00:16:53.056
say -InheritanceType All, to make sure
that it trickles down to cover everything,

336
00:16:53.056 --> 00:16:56.810
calendars, tasks, all the other
different items that make up Outlook.

337
00:16:56.810 --> 00:16:57.950
I want to make sure I cover all of that.

338
00:16:57.950 --> 00:17:02.500
And when we set this, now she'll
have full access to the mailbox.

339
00:17:02.500 --> 00:17:06.030
She can send emails, she can delete items,
she can manipulate things, and

340
00:17:06.030 --> 00:17:08.250
have that full access to
the system that she needs.

341
00:17:08.250 --> 00:17:11.670
So just depends on whether or
not that's what we're trying to go for.

342
00:17:11.670 --> 00:17:15.110
It's another one where it's certainly
easier to do via the GUI, but

343
00:17:15.110 --> 00:17:17.810
if you're just trying to grant somebody
full access to all the mailbox,

344
00:17:17.810 --> 00:17:18.920
maybe it's an attorney and

345
00:17:18.920 --> 00:17:23.850
they need to do some kind of e-discovery,
we can do it here using a bulk command.

346
00:17:23.850 --> 00:17:25.520
There's other ways to do e-discovery too.

347
00:17:25.520 --> 00:17:26.470
You don't have to do it this way.

348
00:17:27.830 --> 00:17:30.040
All right, so
once those permissions are assigned,

349
00:17:30.040 --> 00:17:31.600
now Jane can start to do anything.

350
00:17:31.600 --> 00:17:35.210
And I guess we can test it out and
see if it takes effect fast enough.

351
00:17:35.210 --> 00:17:37.630
Let me switch over to Jane.

352
00:17:38.940 --> 00:17:39.720
It does take a while, so

353
00:17:39.720 --> 00:17:42.150
I won't be surprised if this
one doesn't work right now, but

354
00:17:42.150 --> 00:17:43.340
we'll give it a shot here.

355
00:17:43.340 --> 00:17:45.341
So I'm gonna pull up Jane.

356
00:17:45.341 --> 00:17:48.309
And the first thing I'm gonna do
is I'm gonna close Outlook and

357
00:17:48.309 --> 00:17:52.005
come back into it, because Outlook does
cache a lot of this stuff offline, and

358
00:17:52.005 --> 00:17:54.140
I want to make sure that it is clean.

359
00:17:54.140 --> 00:17:58.141
So I'm just going to close Outlook and
make sure that it actually closes,

360
00:17:58.141 --> 00:17:58.923
which it did.

361
00:17:58.923 --> 00:18:00.245
And then we'll fire it back up again.

362
00:18:02.165 --> 00:18:05.156
All right, so when Outlook fires up it's
supposed to reach out to the server and

363
00:18:05.156 --> 00:18:06.390
get the new permissions.

364
00:18:06.390 --> 00:18:09.100
The server might not have updated
things yet, but it should've happened.

365
00:18:09.100 --> 00:18:11.870
And once that does occur,
now she can come in here and

366
00:18:11.870 --> 00:18:14.410
start to craft email as other people.

367
00:18:14.410 --> 00:18:20.500
So she can craft an email as Bob Denver,
and then she can send an email to me.

368
00:18:20.500 --> 00:18:25.342
And for the subject line we'll we'll

369
00:18:25.342 --> 00:18:30.036
just say this is a test using send as.

370
00:18:30.036 --> 00:18:31.855
All right, and so
she's going to send it along.

371
00:18:31.855 --> 00:18:36.640
Now to her, she doesn't see the difference
between send as and send on behalf.

372
00:18:36.640 --> 00:18:37.770
It doesn't tell her that.

373
00:18:37.770 --> 00:18:40.000
It's up to what we've set to dictate that.

374
00:18:41.120 --> 00:18:43.540
And we'll send that along and off it goes.

375
00:18:43.540 --> 00:18:48.110
It's gonna think about it, so [LAUGH]
it's gonna send that email any time now.

376
00:18:48.110 --> 00:18:51.500
Oh, you know what, I rushed through
Outlook, it hadn't fully connected to

377
00:18:51.500 --> 00:18:55.070
the server yet, so there might be
a certificate warning somewhere.

378
00:18:55.070 --> 00:18:55.780
Doesn't look like it.

379
00:18:55.780 --> 00:18:56.980
All right, so I just have to be patient.

380
00:18:56.980 --> 00:18:58.310
But that one we'll send along and

381
00:18:58.310 --> 00:19:01.500
the big difference is when I receive it
I won't see that on behalf of anymore.

382
00:19:01.500 --> 00:19:03.385
I'll just see that it's
actually from Bob Denver.

383
00:19:04.600 --> 00:19:07.330
All right, so
as far as mailbox delegation is concerned,

384
00:19:07.330 --> 00:19:10.523
those are a couple of different ways
that we can go about doing that.

385
00:19:10.523 --> 00:19:13.400
Yeah, apparently it is just
gonna sit there and stall on me.

386
00:19:13.400 --> 00:19:14.970
So let me switch back to my account.

387
00:19:14.970 --> 00:19:16.820
But those are kind of the key things.

388
00:19:16.820 --> 00:19:18.295
Just remember the difference
between the three.

389
00:19:18.295 --> 00:19:19.865
On the exam it can be really confusing and

390
00:19:19.865 --> 00:19:22.955
in real life it can be confusing
because all three are very similar.

391
00:19:24.105 --> 00:19:26.565
All right, well let's go ahead and
wrap this one up here.

392
00:19:26.565 --> 00:19:30.005
So in this episode we got a chance to
see sending the delegations out or

393
00:19:30.005 --> 00:19:32.075
setting delegations for our users.

394
00:19:32.075 --> 00:19:34.155
Remember the difference between the three.

395
00:19:34.155 --> 00:19:37.145
Send As,
you're truly impersonating the user and

396
00:19:37.145 --> 00:19:40.865
whoever receives the email won't know
whether it came from that user or you.

397
00:19:40.865 --> 00:19:43.580
Send on Behalf,
you're impersonating the user but

398
00:19:43.580 --> 00:19:46.790
it shows that you're doing that, so
whoever receives the email will know

399
00:19:46.790 --> 00:19:49.460
that it was sent actually
written by somebody else.

400
00:19:49.460 --> 00:19:53.520
And then Full Access, that gives you
total access to the mailbox to be

401
00:19:53.520 --> 00:19:56.250
able to do whatever you want,
including sending as and

402
00:19:56.250 --> 00:19:59.860
that would be the highest level of trust
that we'd give somebody on a mailbox.

403
00:19:59.860 --> 00:20:01.640
It's effectively creating
a shared mailbox at that point.

404
00:20:02.720 --> 00:20:06.120
All right, well, that's about all I've
got on delegating mailbox permissions.

405
00:20:06.120 --> 00:20:07.800
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

406
00:20:07.800 --> 00:20:11.400
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

407
00:20:11.400 --> 00:20:17.330
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to configured "accepted domains" in Exchange 2013. This is a critical piece to ensure mail flows properly in a new Exchange install. He ends the episode by configuring Address Policies to apply the new domain suffix to new and existing user accounts.
episodes.title: Email Address Policies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.045 --> 00:00:10.045
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.050 --> 00:00:11.805
All right.

3
00:00:11.805 --> 00:00:13.187
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

4
00:00:13.187 --> 00:00:15.788
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.788 --> 00:00:17.316
I'm your host Don Pezet,

6
00:00:17.316 --> 00:00:21.209
back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

7
00:00:21.209 --> 00:00:25.174
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at the email policies that

8
00:00:25.174 --> 00:00:27.001
are defined inside of Exchange.

9
00:00:27.001 --> 00:00:28.475
And when I say email policies,

10
00:00:28.475 --> 00:00:31.263
there's actually several
different kinds of policies.

11
00:00:31.263 --> 00:00:34.494
So, the one that I'm talking
about today is what's really,

12
00:00:34.494 --> 00:00:37.242
what used to be called
the Recipient Update Policy.

13
00:00:37.242 --> 00:00:41.217
Whenever you create a mailbox inside
of Exchange, it gets an email address,

14
00:00:41.217 --> 00:00:43.130
it's a default email address.

15
00:00:43.130 --> 00:00:46.219
And if you've ever wondered how does
Exchange pick what your default email

16
00:00:46.219 --> 00:00:48.632
address is, well,
there's a policy that defines that.

17
00:00:48.632 --> 00:00:49.404
And we can go and

18
00:00:49.404 --> 00:00:53.277
manipulate that policy to change what
our default email addresses end up as.

19
00:00:53.277 --> 00:00:55.247
So, that's a pretty neat
thing to be able to do,

20
00:00:55.247 --> 00:00:57.630
and it's actually not very hard at all.

21
00:00:57.630 --> 00:00:58.983
There's other things we can do with it,
too.

22
00:00:58.983 --> 00:01:04.040
For example, you might want your users to
get more than one email address, right?

23
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:06.948
And so, we can define that in our
policy to say when we create new users,

24
00:01:06.948 --> 00:01:09.241
give them these five different
addresses or whatever.

25
00:01:09.241 --> 00:01:11.144
And in that way,
it's able to cover all that and

26
00:01:11.144 --> 00:01:14.012
provide it without somebody going
in manually entering in addresses.

27
00:01:14.012 --> 00:01:14.813
It's pretty neat stuff.

28
00:01:14.813 --> 00:01:18.530
And it's something that we need
to do on Exchange servers.

29
00:01:18.530 --> 00:01:19.993
Usually early on in the set up,

30
00:01:19.993 --> 00:01:22.651
you might make changes too
later on down the road, too.

31
00:01:22.651 --> 00:01:24.390
All right.
Well, lets take a look at this, and

32
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:26.190
I'll show you what I mean.

33
00:01:26.190 --> 00:01:28.752
I'm in an Exchange system here and
I got my recipient list.

34
00:01:28.752 --> 00:01:32.676
And if I were to create a new mailbox,
right, I'm just going to come in here and

35
00:01:32.676 --> 00:01:36.854
whip up a new mailbox real quick, maybe
we'll create one for, oh, I don't know.

36
00:01:36.854 --> 00:01:37.934
Who do I want to give a mailbox to?

37
00:01:37.934 --> 00:01:40.292
We'll give one to,
we'll do John Travolta, all right.

38
00:01:40.292 --> 00:01:41.495
He needs a mailbox.

39
00:01:41.495 --> 00:01:43.392
So, I'm gonna create one.

40
00:01:43.392 --> 00:01:45.088
It's sad these are the people
that popped into my mind.

41
00:01:45.088 --> 00:01:47.404
[LAUGH] So we'll create one for
old John Travolta,

42
00:01:47.404 --> 00:01:50.450
who it occurs to me I don't really
know how to spell his last name.

43
00:01:50.450 --> 00:01:51.646
So, we'll just figure that out there.

44
00:01:51.646 --> 00:01:53.527
So I'm going to and create this.

45
00:01:53.527 --> 00:01:55.864
And if someone asks me for
a user login name,

46
00:01:55.864 --> 00:01:59.420
the user login name looks
like an email address, right?

47
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:01.510
But, it's not their actual email address.

48
00:02:01.510 --> 00:02:04.518
So, when you punch something in here,
like I might punch in John,

49
00:02:04.518 --> 00:02:06.364
I want him to be john@lab.itpro.tv.

50
00:02:06.364 --> 00:02:07.083
Okay?

51
00:02:07.083 --> 00:02:10.425
Is that the email address
he's going to end up with?

52
00:02:10.425 --> 00:02:10.938
It doesn't know.

53
00:02:10.938 --> 00:02:12.319
It doesn't know from here.

54
00:02:12.319 --> 00:02:15.999
It looks at a policy to find out what
the address is actually going to be.

55
00:02:15.999 --> 00:02:20.526
And so, I can assign him a password,
and it's gonna create that account and

56
00:02:20.526 --> 00:02:25.078
we'll see what that email address actually
ends up as here in just a moment.

57
00:02:25.078 --> 00:02:27.307
So it's gonna go and look for that policy.

58
00:02:27.307 --> 00:02:28.583
It's gonna create the email address.

59
00:02:28.583 --> 00:02:30.265
It's gonna attach it to the user.

60
00:02:30.265 --> 00:02:32.130
All done in the background.

61
00:02:32.130 --> 00:02:35.561
And I can see over here his email
address is johntravolta@lab.itpro.tv.

62
00:02:35.561 --> 00:02:36.513
All right?

63
00:02:36.513 --> 00:02:38.022
Well, that's not what I typed.

64
00:02:38.022 --> 00:02:40.112
That's not what I typed for
the login name.

65
00:02:40.112 --> 00:02:42.621
Right?
Email address is different.

66
00:02:42.621 --> 00:02:45.029
All right.
Now, if I edit John, I can go in, and

67
00:02:45.029 --> 00:02:47.095
I can find his email addresses.

68
00:02:47.095 --> 00:02:48.416
Right?
So right here under the mailbox,

69
00:02:48.416 --> 00:02:49.277
I can go to email addresses.

70
00:02:49.277 --> 00:02:51.298
There it is, and I can change it.

71
00:02:51.298 --> 00:02:53.600
Well, can I change it?

72
00:02:53.600 --> 00:02:57.040
If I take this email address right
here and I go to edit it, right?

73
00:02:57.040 --> 00:02:57.817
Here it is.
I can go in.

74
00:02:57.817 --> 00:02:59.339
I can start to modify, and
I'm going to change it.

75
00:02:59.339 --> 00:03:02.880
I want him to be john@lab.itpro.tv,
and I set it.

76
00:03:02.880 --> 00:03:03.552
Okay.

77
00:03:03.552 --> 00:03:07.535
It's going to try and
set that, and it fails.

78
00:03:07.535 --> 00:03:09.235
Now, why did it fail?

79
00:03:09.235 --> 00:03:12.466
It failed because that email
address was set by a policy,

80
00:03:12.466 --> 00:03:15.034
and the policy is
overriding what I typed in.

81
00:03:15.034 --> 00:03:16.252
It's not letting me change it.

82
00:03:16.252 --> 00:03:17.145
All right?

83
00:03:17.145 --> 00:03:19.130
So if I say okay to that and
I go and edit the user and

84
00:03:19.130 --> 00:03:22.007
go back into his email addresses,-
it's back to the way that it was.

85
00:03:22.007 --> 00:03:22.890
It didn't change.

86
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:23.574
Right?

87
00:03:23.574 --> 00:03:27.069
Instead, it added a second address.

88
00:03:27.069 --> 00:03:31.447
You can add to the policy, but
you can't override the policy by default.

89
00:03:31.447 --> 00:03:35.130
If you want to override it,
you've got to undo this check mark here.

90
00:03:35.130 --> 00:03:36.890
If I undo this check mark,

91
00:03:36.890 --> 00:03:40.180
now I can modify his addresses
because the policy doesn't apply.

92
00:03:41.180 --> 00:03:42.650
On a positive side,
that gives me some control.

93
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:46.621
On a negative side, what if I want to
make a bulk change down the road, right?

94
00:03:46.621 --> 00:03:47.909
Maybe I add some new domain.

95
00:03:47.909 --> 00:03:54.300
I add ITprotv.net, so I want everybody
to have an ITproTV.net address.

96
00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:59.660
Well, if I modify my policy, any user the
policy applies will get that new address,

97
00:03:59.660 --> 00:04:02.110
except for
john because I disabled the policy.

98
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:05.523
So it's not necessarily not the greatest
thing to go in and disable that policy.

99
00:04:05.523 --> 00:04:08.661
Instead, if we wanna change
the way users addresses work,

100
00:04:08.661 --> 00:04:11.240
we should go and modify the policy itself.

101
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:12.579
So, let's take a look at that.

102
00:04:12.579 --> 00:04:15.273
So the email address policy is
actually defined right back here.

103
00:04:15.273 --> 00:04:18.450
If I go into my Exchange admin center,
on my left side,

104
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:20.740
you will see all the different things.

105
00:04:20.740 --> 00:04:23.562
And what we're looking for
is a section on mail flow.

106
00:04:23.562 --> 00:04:25.292
It's not the most intuitive, I guess.

107
00:04:25.292 --> 00:04:26.692
But if you think about mail flow,

108
00:04:26.692 --> 00:04:29.692
this is dictating how email moves
through our Exchange organization.

109
00:04:29.692 --> 00:04:35.032
And inside of mail flow, you'll find
your email address policies, all right.

110
00:04:35.032 --> 00:04:38.562
The email address policies, those
are what dictates what addresses we get,

111
00:04:38.562 --> 00:04:41.452
how our users are getting an email
address generated for them.

112
00:04:41.452 --> 00:04:45.204
And if you take it, you'll have at least
one, right, you have to have one, and

113
00:04:45.204 --> 00:04:46.617
that's the default policy.

114
00:04:46.617 --> 00:04:48.727
Now you can have more than one policy, and

115
00:04:48.727 --> 00:04:53.200
that's pretty neat because you might have
different employees with different needs.

116
00:04:53.200 --> 00:04:56.417
Maybe you have multiple
companies under one umbrella.

117
00:04:56.417 --> 00:04:59.052
And so, you want people in
Company A to get one email address and

118
00:04:59.052 --> 00:05:01.316
people in Company B to get
a different email address.

119
00:05:01.316 --> 00:05:03.300
You can define policies that do that.

120
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:06.408
So, they have a priority, and
they're applied in order.

121
00:05:06.408 --> 00:05:09.366
Only one policy applies to a user,
so, the first one that matches for

122
00:05:09.366 --> 00:05:12.747
them is what applies, and so the order
these are in is kind of important for us.

123
00:05:12.747 --> 00:05:13.570
All right.

124
00:05:13.570 --> 00:05:15.382
I'm gonna take this default policy and
I'm gonna edit it.

125
00:05:15.382 --> 00:05:17.637
And when you going into
the settings of the policy,

126
00:05:17.637 --> 00:05:19.584
there's not a whole heck
of a lot to change.

127
00:05:19.584 --> 00:05:23.045
Right here we've got the name,
which you can change on other policies,

128
00:05:23.045 --> 00:05:24.020
not on the default.

129
00:05:25.290 --> 00:05:27.680
And then,
we've got our email address format.

130
00:05:27.680 --> 00:05:28.935
This is the important one.

131
00:05:28.935 --> 00:05:34.379
See how it's got an email address format
defined as something @lab.itpro.tv?

132
00:05:34.379 --> 00:05:37.480
There's that domain that they're
getting that address for.

133
00:05:37.480 --> 00:05:41.040
And if I edit that,
I can go in and I can change it.

134
00:05:41.040 --> 00:05:45.887
And if you look at it, you'll see here
this accepted domain is lab.itpro.tv, and

135
00:05:45.887 --> 00:05:50.478
then how it's generating the email
address, alias@contoso.com, right?

136
00:05:50.478 --> 00:05:52.858
And then,
you'll see these other examples down here.

137
00:05:52.858 --> 00:05:58.593
John.Smith, JSmith, JohnS, Smith.John, all
these other formats that I can pick from.

138
00:05:58.593 --> 00:06:03.039
Or ,we can do a complete custom address
and enter in a different format here.

139
00:06:03.039 --> 00:06:06.685
And it's got this Learn More link which is
kind of important because if you're gong

140
00:06:06.685 --> 00:06:09.356
to build your own address,
you have to use their variables.

141
00:06:09.356 --> 00:06:12.597
And so, here's the variables
that they've got, like %G for

142
00:06:12.597 --> 00:06:15.056
the first name, %S for
the last name and so on.

143
00:06:15.056 --> 00:06:19.733
And you can use these to build your own
custom format if you want, all right.

144
00:06:19.733 --> 00:06:24.270
Now, you've probably noticed one problem
that I'm gonna bump into which is all

145
00:06:24.270 --> 00:06:26.617

00:13:00.380 --> 00:13:03.644
