365
00:17:50.470 --> 00:17:53.730
And I'll go ahead and save that,
so it's gonna create his account.

366
00:17:53.730 --> 00:17:55.740
And it's gonna see the policy
that applies to him and

367
00:17:55.740 --> 00:17:57.010
give him the appropriate addresses.

368
00:17:57.010 --> 00:17:59.950
It's gonna hit that
ITProTV employees policy.

369
00:17:59.950 --> 00:18:03.190
But then if I create another user and
I put them somewhere other than ITProTV,

370
00:18:03.190 --> 00:18:06.310
then the default policy will apply and
they'll get a different address.

371
00:18:06.310 --> 00:18:09.920
Or at least eventually when
the system decides to create it.

372
00:18:09.920 --> 00:18:13.870
So [LAUGH] that'll happen eventually, but
you guys get an idea here of how to set

373
00:18:13.870 --> 00:18:16.610
these email address policies up,
getting them in place and

374
00:18:16.610 --> 00:18:20.050
getting people the information they
need to be able to communicate.

375
00:18:20.050 --> 00:18:23.990
Key things to remember here, definitely
make sure you set that accepted domain.

376
00:18:23.990 --> 00:18:28.320
If I add email addresses to somebody and
its a domain that I'm not accepting,

377
00:18:28.320 --> 00:18:31.250
then it's gonna get blocked,
the email's just gonna get dropped.

378
00:18:31.250 --> 00:18:33.480
So we're gonna make sure we add
it to an accepted domain first,

379
00:18:33.480 --> 00:18:34.600
and then add it to our policy.

380
00:18:34.600 --> 00:18:35.980
Oh there, it just finished.

381
00:18:35.980 --> 00:18:39.930
All right, so I can see that Clint
Eastwood did get CEastwood@itprotv.net,

382
00:18:39.930 --> 00:18:41.470
he's got the right address.

383
00:18:41.470 --> 00:18:44.450
And if I edit him,
he should have three addresses, right?

384
00:18:44.450 --> 00:18:46.560
So, if I look, sure enough,
he's got all three.

385
00:18:46.560 --> 00:18:51.290
He's also has Clint.Eastwood@ITProTV.net,
and ClintEastwood@Lab.ITProTV.

386
00:18:51.290 --> 00:18:53.590
He's getting all the addresses
from that policy.

387
00:18:54.750 --> 00:18:59.270
And if I create another user,
and maybe we'll do,

388
00:18:59.270 --> 00:19:03.999
I don't know, let's do Telly Savalas.

389
00:19:05.100 --> 00:19:07.070
I'm really digging deep here for actors.

390
00:19:07.070 --> 00:19:10.870
So [LAUGH] we'll punch in Telly Savalas.

391
00:19:10.870 --> 00:19:12.410
We're gonna give him an account.

392
00:19:12.410 --> 00:19:16.000
And for his OU, I"m just gonna
put him in the regular users OU.

393
00:19:16.000 --> 00:19:22.770
He's not gonna be in ITProTV,
and we'll punch in a password.

394
00:19:24.850 --> 00:19:25.950
There we go.

395
00:19:25.950 --> 00:19:26.920
And so it's gonna create his account.

396
00:19:26.920 --> 00:19:29.580
He's not an ITProTV,
the default policy will apply to him.

397
00:19:29.580 --> 00:19:31.720
He'll get a different set of addresses.

398
00:19:31.720 --> 00:19:34.120
So, really cool to have
that flexibility and

399
00:19:34.120 --> 00:19:36.930
the fact that we can modify
this policy after the fact and

400
00:19:36.930 --> 00:19:40.250
it updates all of our users, makes
managing email addresses really easy.

401
00:19:40.250 --> 00:19:44.130
Just be aware,
that if you disable the policy on a user,

402
00:19:44.130 --> 00:19:49.060
if you override it, then from now on, from
now until eternity, you'll have to go and

403
00:19:49.060 --> 00:19:51.260
manually edit that user
to add new addresses.

404
00:19:51.260 --> 00:19:53.460
And so that makes things
a little more burdensome.

405
00:19:53.460 --> 00:19:57.310
So yeah, sure enough, Telly has been
created and he doesn't have ITProTV.net.

406
00:19:57.310 --> 00:20:02.180
He just has lab.ITPro.TV and if I edit
his account and take a look at his

407
00:20:02.180 --> 00:20:05.900
email addresses, he didn't end up with
the three addresses, he just got the one.

408
00:20:05.900 --> 00:20:07.665
Different policy, for the different user.

409
00:20:09.585 --> 00:20:11.025
All right, well in this episode,

410
00:20:11.025 --> 00:20:14.335
we got a chance to see our email
address policies and how they work.

411
00:20:14.335 --> 00:20:16.685
We got to see how to assign
those to different OU's, so

412
00:20:16.685 --> 00:20:19.905
that different users got different
addresses based on their needs.

413
00:20:19.905 --> 00:20:23.145
And we got a chance to see the accepted
domain screen which we haven't messed with

414
00:20:23.145 --> 00:20:27.275
yet, where we can add more domains to
our system to be able to receive those.

415
00:20:27.275 --> 00:20:28.680
So pretty neat stuff.

416
00:20:28.680 --> 00:20:31.720
All said and done, definitely something
that you're gonna have to configure in

417
00:20:31.720 --> 00:20:35.470
your environment if you have more than one
email domain, or if you just want people

418
00:20:35.470 --> 00:20:38.960
to have more than one address to
catch typos or things like that.

419
00:20:38.960 --> 00:20:41.080
You'll want to mess around with
the policies and the addresses.

420
00:20:41.080 --> 00:20:43.210
So pretty cool stuff, definitely useful.

421
00:20:43.210 --> 00:20:45.020
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed it.

422
00:20:45.020 --> 00:20:48.631
That's all for our show, so signing
off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet, and

423
00:20:48.631 --> 00:20:49.848
I'll see you next time.

424
00:20:49.848 --> 00:20:54.682
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the various methods that a client can use to connect to Exchange 2013. He demonstrates MAPI, Outlook Anywhere, ActiveSync, POP3, IMAP4 and SMTP. He also gives some pointers as to when one connectivity method is preferred over another.
episodes.title: Client Connectivity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.103 --> 00:00:10.750
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:10.750 --> 00:00:13.771
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:13.771 --> 00:00:15.940
welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:15.940 --> 00:00:20.960
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again with
another episode of Microsoft Exchange

5
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:25.080
2013, and in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at client connectivity.

6
00:00:25.080 --> 00:00:28.510
Now we've talked about client access
servers before and how they serve as that

7
00:00:28.510 --> 00:00:32.310
gateway for people to get inside of
their network, and access their email.

8
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:36.220
But what we haven't talked about are all
the different ways that somebody can

9
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:38.850
connect, and there's actually quite a few.

10
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:41.500
On the exam, they really want you
to know the four big ones, so

11
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:45.050
we're gonna take a look at those and kind
of look at how that connectivity works.

12
00:00:45.050 --> 00:00:48.230
And if you're somebody who's been
working with Microsoft exchange for

13
00:00:48.230 --> 00:00:51.480
a long time,
well things have changed a little bit, so

14
00:00:51.480 --> 00:00:54.210
we need to be aware of some of
the changes that have happened, and

15
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:57.600
see how people get into our system
in the first place, all right.

16
00:00:57.600 --> 00:01:00.320
Well let me just run down
the big four real quick,

17
00:01:00.320 --> 00:01:02.370
when somebody connects
to Microsoft Exchange,

18
00:01:02.370 --> 00:01:06.020
there's really four primary methods
they can use to connect, right.

19
00:01:06.020 --> 00:01:10.550
The original method that Microsoft
developed for Exchange, this is way back.

20
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:13.710
Just to give you an example, the first
version of Exchange that I worked with was

21
00:01:13.710 --> 00:01:19.420
Microsoft Exchange 5.0, and it was back
in 1999 or 2000, right around in there.

22
00:01:19.420 --> 00:01:20.960
So a very long time ago.

23
00:01:20.960 --> 00:01:25.080
And their primary connectivity
method was a protocol called MAPI.

24
00:01:25.080 --> 00:01:28.430
And MAPI stood for the Messaging
Application Programming Interface.

25
00:01:28.430 --> 00:01:33.930
And it was designed for Microsoft Outlook,
so Microsoft Outlook used a proprietary

26
00:01:33.930 --> 00:01:38.860
protocol to connect directly to Exchange,
and the reason Microsoft did that was

27
00:01:38.860 --> 00:01:44.140
because it allowed Outlook to connect
directly to the mailbox database.

28
00:01:44.140 --> 00:01:47.060
Outlook could actually take email and
stick it right in the database, and

29
00:01:47.060 --> 00:01:49.390
it could grab email
right from the database.

30
00:01:49.390 --> 00:01:51.790
And back then,
you just had one Exchange server.

31
00:01:51.790 --> 00:01:54.800
You didn't have all these
separate roles like we do now.

32
00:01:54.800 --> 00:01:59.700
But over time, as Microsoft started
breaking things into separate roles,

33
00:01:59.700 --> 00:02:01.770
we ended up with some problems, right.

34
00:02:01.770 --> 00:02:04.650
For example,
you might have hub transport rules,

35
00:02:04.650 --> 00:02:09.670
rules that do something like apply a legal
disclaimer to the bottom of an email.

36
00:02:09.670 --> 00:02:11.920
So if you're attaching a legal
disclaimer to an email,

37
00:02:11.920 --> 00:02:15.930
as it passes through your system,
well you need to be able to catch it,

38
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:18.580
intercept the email while it
passes through to add that.

39
00:02:18.580 --> 00:02:22.400
But with the old MAPI protocol if
somebody was sending an email and

40
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:26.060
they were an internal user and
they were emailing another internal user,

41
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:28.150
it would go right into the database.

42
00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:31.770
But we had no way to apply those rules,
and so that was a problem.

43
00:02:31.770 --> 00:02:34.270
And so starting back in Exchange 2007,

44
00:02:34.270 --> 00:02:36.210
Microsoft started to swap that around and
they said,

45
00:02:36.210 --> 00:02:40.890
from now on all e-mail has to go through
a hub transport server regardless of

46
00:02:40.890 --> 00:02:45.470
whether it's MAPI or not, it's got to
go through that hub transport server.

47
00:02:45.470 --> 00:02:48.500
And when that happened It really, kind of,

48
00:02:48.500 --> 00:02:53.250
started to spell the end of MAPI,
that MAPI wasn't as useful anymore.

49
00:02:53.250 --> 00:02:55.740
You used to get better performance,
because you went right to the database,

50
00:02:55.740 --> 00:02:58.310
but you don't anymore, and
so now you've lost that.

51
00:02:58.310 --> 00:03:01.220
And, so instead,
we start moving out into some

52
00:03:01.220 --> 00:03:03.890
other protocols that
are gonna be more common, so.

53
00:03:03.890 --> 00:03:08.490
If I were doing this show ten years ago,
MAPI would be like the primary method for

54
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:09.540
connecting.

55
00:03:09.540 --> 00:03:11.830
Today, it's very rarely used, right?

56
00:03:11.830 --> 00:03:13.600
So it's not really common at all.

57
00:03:13.600 --> 00:03:17.060
So instead, we're gonna see one
of the three other connections.

58
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:20.510
The other connection, the one that
Microsoft considers the primary one now,

59
00:03:20.510 --> 00:03:22.470
is what's called Outlook Anywhere.

60
00:03:22.470 --> 00:03:26.530
Outlook Anywhere is where we
take that MAPI type traffic, and

61
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:28.050
we send it over HTTP.

62
00:03:28.050 --> 00:03:32.750
Now they don't call it MAPI anymore,
because we've lost that messaging API, and

63
00:03:32.750 --> 00:03:39.310
so instead it's now called RPC over HTTP,
or the remote procedure call over HTTP.

64
00:03:39.310 --> 00:03:43.450
Now, the neat thing about that is it's
going to take your email traffic,

65
00:03:43.450 --> 00:03:47.180
this direct software access
that comes out of Outlook, and

66
00:03:47.180 --> 00:03:48.610
it's gonna send it over to the HTTP.

67
00:03:48.610 --> 00:03:50.390
Or really the HTTPs, right?

68
00:03:50.390 --> 00:03:53.975
So tccp port 443,
which is allowed on almost every network.

69
00:03:53.975 --> 00:03:56.140
MAPI might be blocked on a firewall.

70
00:03:56.140 --> 00:03:59.440
But HTTPs,
almost everybody lets that's through.

71
00:03:59.440 --> 00:04:02.680
And so outlook could be running
inside your environment, outside.

72
00:04:02.680 --> 00:04:05.610
You can be anywhere in the world,
and you can connect back to

73
00:04:05.610 --> 00:04:08.280
your exchange server and
establish that connection to your mailbox.

74
00:04:08.280 --> 00:04:09.980
That's outlook anywhere, and

75
00:04:09.980 --> 00:04:13.070
that's the primary connectivity
method that Microsoft has.

76
00:04:13.070 --> 00:04:16.560
When you fire up Microsoft Outlook,
as an internal or external users or

77
00:04:16.560 --> 00:04:20.715
whatever, it's outlook anywhere
that you're using to connect with.

78
00:04:20.715 --> 00:04:23.335
There are two more for
our backwards compatibility.

79
00:04:23.335 --> 00:04:28.225
There's POP3 and IMAP4, and
those two have been around a long time.

80
00:04:28.225 --> 00:04:31.085
Those are the original email protocols,
not created by Microsoft.

81
00:04:31.085 --> 00:04:33.945
Microsoft made MAPI,
Microsoft made Outlook Anywhere.

82
00:04:33.945 --> 00:04:37.075
But POP3 and IMAP4,
those were created back in the Unix days,

83
00:04:37.075 --> 00:04:41.410
really in the late 70s,
early 80s, a long time ago.

84
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:42.750
And they're very prevalent.

85
00:04:42.750 --> 00:04:46.910
POP3 not so much anymore but
IMAP4 is still very prevalent out there.

86
00:04:46.910 --> 00:04:52.430
Any device can connect to an exchange
server using IMAP4, if it's a Blackberry,

87
00:04:52.430 --> 00:04:57.580
an Iphone, Android tablet,
a Linux box, a Mac, a Windows Pc.

88
00:04:57.580 --> 00:04:59.950
Pretty much everybody supports POP3 and
IMAP4.

89
00:05:01.050 --> 00:05:03.090
But there's some features we lose out on.

90
00:05:03.090 --> 00:05:04.850
And that's where we'd rather
have Outlook Anywhere.

91
00:05:04.850 --> 00:05:07.080
We'd rather run Microsoft Outlook.

92
00:05:07.080 --> 00:05:08.930
And be able to connect that way.

93
00:05:08.930 --> 00:05:11.310
So those are the four
primary connection methods.

94
00:05:11.310 --> 00:05:15.490
There's one or two more that I should
probably mention here that might pop up,

95
00:05:15.490 --> 00:05:19.390
which are things like
Exchange ActiveSync an Outlook Web App.

96
00:05:19.390 --> 00:05:19.980
All right?

97
00:05:19.980 --> 00:05:23.820
Those are not the common connectivity
methods, cuz it's not really a client

98
00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:28.170
connecting anymore, but it's you using
a client that runs directly on the server.

99
00:05:28.170 --> 00:05:29.260
So, Outlook Web App.

100
00:05:29.260 --> 00:05:30.690
Outlook Web App,
you're pulling up a webpage.

101
00:05:30.690 --> 00:05:32.428
And the webpage has all your email.

102
00:05:32.428 --> 00:05:34.970
Well that web page is being
rendered by the server itself, so

103
00:05:34.970 --> 00:05:37.990
you're not running a client,
you run a web browser to do it that way.

104
00:05:37.990 --> 00:05:39.960
So it's not like a client
connectivity method, but

105
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:43.090
it is a way to get into your email, so
Outlook Web App is pretty important, and

106
00:05:43.090 --> 00:05:45.880
ActiveSync is the same thing,
but for mobile devices.

107
00:05:45.880 --> 00:05:51.130
So if you have an iOS phone or an Android
phone, Windows Mobile, they can only

108
00:05:51.130 --> 00:05:55.412
use Exchange ActiveSync to connect right
into that mailbox and get your access.

109
00:05:55.412 --> 00:05:58.750
And ActiveSync is doing the bulk of the
data rendering on its side on the server

110
00:05:58.750 --> 00:06:02.930
side, and you phone is just rendering on
the screen in typically a web browser or

111
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:04.710
some other kind of mail
client that's been defined.

112
00:06:04.710 --> 00:06:06.570
So, those are a little bit different.

113
00:06:06.570 --> 00:06:09.950
But these are all different
mechanisms somebody can connect with.

114
00:06:09.950 --> 00:06:13.980
The key thing to remember,
is that they're not always turned on.

115
00:06:13.980 --> 00:06:16.980
That you can turn these on and
off based on your own needs.

116
00:06:16.980 --> 00:06:19.530
You may want some of them,
you may not want others.

117
00:06:19.530 --> 00:06:22.250
Some are turned on by default,
some are turned off by default.

118
00:06:22.250 --> 00:06:25.700
So in this episode, I want to go through
each one, and just kind of examine them,

119
00:06:25.700 --> 00:06:28.450
see how they work, and
see how we can turn them on and off.

120
00:06:28.450 --> 00:06:29.320
All right.

121
00:06:29.320 --> 00:06:30.660
The first thing I wanna show you,

122
00:06:30.660 --> 00:06:34.000
is kinda how these show up inside
of the exchange admin center.

123
00:06:34.000 --> 00:06:38.570
So I'm gonna pull up my server here, and
I've got a client access server pulled up

124
00:06:38.570 --> 00:06:43.820
here, and I can basically get
into my exchange admin centers.

125
00:06:43.820 --> 00:06:45.820
Just let me log into that real quick.

126
00:06:45.820 --> 00:06:49.090
And when I get logged in to
the exchange admin center,

127
00:06:49.090 --> 00:06:50.980
I'm gonna see my recipients, right?

128
00:06:50.980 --> 00:06:53.330
That's the default screen,
when you pullout the admin center.

129
00:06:53.330 --> 00:06:57.820
I'll see my recipients here, and for
each recipient, I can turn on and

130
00:06:57.820 --> 00:07:00.940
off the connectivity methods individually,
right?

131
00:07:00.940 --> 00:07:03.900
When I start to choose a user,
so like if I choose James Smith.

132
00:07:04.940 --> 00:07:05.690
Here's James Smith.

133
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:08.080
And over on the right side
I can see some options.

134
00:07:08.080 --> 00:07:12.740
Not all the options that I want, but I can
see here disable exchange active scene,

135
00:07:12.740 --> 00:07:14.710
disable OWA for devices.

136
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:16.580
So, there's a few little things there.

137
00:07:16.580 --> 00:07:21.140
But I don't see anything for Pop3 or
IMap4, or that kind of stuff.

138
00:07:21.140 --> 00:07:23.300
So, for
that I've really got the edit the users.

139
00:07:23.300 --> 00:07:26.050
So if I come in here and edit James, and

140
00:07:26.050 --> 00:07:28.490
I go in here, you'll start to
see some different options.

141
00:07:28.490 --> 00:07:31.070
The one I'm looking for
is mailbox features.

142
00:07:31.070 --> 00:07:34.130
And right here in mailbox features,
I'll see some of the same stuff.

143
00:07:34.130 --> 00:07:36.260
Here's disable exchange active scene.

144
00:07:36.260 --> 00:07:38.060
Disable OWA for devices.

145
00:07:38.060 --> 00:07:38.620
Right?

146
00:07:38.620 --> 00:07:41.670
But I'll also see Outlook Web App.

147
00:07:41.670 --> 00:07:43.490
I can disable that or enable it.

148
00:07:43.490 --> 00:07:46.307
If you see disable,
that means it's already enabled and so

149
00:07:46.307 --> 00:07:47.385
this one is turned on.

150
00:07:47.385 --> 00:07:51.760
I can see IMap, Pop3 and MAPI,
and how all of them are enabled,

151
00:07:51.760 --> 00:07:57.616
that means that by default, this user can
connect with any of these methods, right?

152
00:07:57.616 --> 00:07:59.363
Well, that's not entirely true.

153
00:07:59.363 --> 00:08:04.640
Because, for example, the IMAP and
POP3 services are disabled by default.

154
00:08:04.640 --> 00:08:06.529
So she's allowed to connect,
but if she tries,

155
00:08:06.529 --> 00:08:09.073
it's going to fail,
cuz the server is not configured properly.

156
00:08:09.073 --> 00:08:11.590
So there's really two pieces
of the configuration.

157
00:08:11.590 --> 00:08:15.611
There's the server side and
then there's the user, the recipient side.

158
00:08:15.611 --> 00:08:18.132
We have to have the services
enabled on the server and

159
00:08:18.132 --> 00:08:21.430
then we have to have the services
allowed for the recipient.

160
00:08:21.430 --> 00:08:23.432
And here,
we can see they're all allowed for her.

161
00:08:23.432 --> 00:08:26.935
But maybe I don't want her to use POP3,
so I could come in here and

162
00:08:26.935 --> 00:08:29.690
I could hit Disable and
it's gonna disable POP3.

163
00:08:30.880 --> 00:08:33.338
And so now it says, POP3 Disabled and
I can turn it back on, if I want.

164
00:08:33.338 --> 00:08:35.806
But otherwise,
she can't connect via POP3 anymore,

165
00:08:35.806 --> 00:08:37.970
but her other protocols
are still turned on.

166
00:08:37.970 --> 00:08:40.921
So here's where we can see all those
different connectivity methods and

167
00:08:40.921 --> 00:08:42.476
we can kinda tweak and work with that.

168
00:08:42.476 --> 00:08:46.500
Now notice how Outlook Anywhere
doesn't show up in here.

169
00:08:46.500 --> 00:08:48.900
And that's because Outlook Anywhere or

170
00:08:48.900 --> 00:08:53.310
RPC over HTTP,
that's wrapped up here under MAPI.

171
00:08:53.310 --> 00:08:56.488
By the time it gets to the server,
it just looks like MAPI traffic.

172
00:08:56.488 --> 00:09:01.690
It's been tunneled over HTTP to get to the
server, so it's kind of wrapped together.

173
00:09:01.690 --> 00:09:02.550
Those used to be separate.

174
00:09:02.550 --> 00:09:05.718
In earlier versions of Exchange
they were separate, but

175
00:09:05.718 --> 00:09:09.230
now all the connectivity is
shown as Outlook Anywhere.

176
00:09:09.230 --> 00:09:11.940
Let me show you,
cuz this can get a little confusing.

177
00:09:11.940 --> 00:09:13.030
I wanna show you an example.

178
00:09:13.030 --> 00:09:15.935
So let me jump back to an actual client.

179
00:09:15.935 --> 00:09:18.450
So here, I am on a Windows 7 machine.

180
00:09:18.450 --> 00:09:21.952
And if I fire up Outlook,
I've got Outlook on this system and

181
00:09:21.952 --> 00:09:26.830
I just used autodiscover, so
it automatically configured itself.

182
00:09:26.830 --> 00:09:29.940
In previous versions of Exchange when it
auto-configured, it would use MAPI and

183
00:09:29.940 --> 00:09:32.280
it would connect directly to that server.

184
00:09:32.280 --> 00:09:34.904
But in newer versions,
it uses Outlook Anywhere.

185
00:09:34.904 --> 00:09:38.690
But just looking at the client, we don't
really have a way of knowing that.

186
00:09:38.690 --> 00:09:41.360
When I look at this down here at
the bottom, I can see connected to

187
00:09:41.360 --> 00:09:44.680
Microsoft Exchange, but it really
doesn't tell me about how I'm connected.

188
00:09:44.680 --> 00:09:48.450
It just says that I am connected,
that's terribly exciting.

189
00:09:48.450 --> 00:09:50.757
So [LAUGH] I don't really
get to see how I connected.

190
00:09:50.757 --> 00:09:53.560
If I want to see that though,
there's a neat little hidden option.

191
00:09:53.560 --> 00:09:57.820
Down by my system clock,
I can see the Outlook icon right there.

192
00:09:57.820 --> 00:10:00.605
And if you right-click on that icon,
you see some options here.

193
00:10:00.605 --> 00:10:03.697
Show New Mail, most of this has
to do with notifications, but

194
00:10:03.697 --> 00:10:05.230
there's a hidden option.

195
00:10:05.230 --> 00:10:11.340
If you hold Ctrl on your keyboard,
if you hold Ctrl while you right-click.

196
00:10:11.340 --> 00:10:15.350
So if I hold Ctrl and right-click,
I get some new options.

197
00:10:15.350 --> 00:10:16.717
Test Email AutoConfiguration.

198
00:10:16.717 --> 00:10:18.690
We used that in the autodiscover episode.

199
00:10:18.690 --> 00:10:21.879
If you haven't seen that one, we used
that one to do some troubleshooting and

200
00:10:21.879 --> 00:10:24.055
testing, but
right above it is Connection Status.

201
00:10:24.055 --> 00:10:25.851
Connection Status is really useful,

202
00:10:25.851 --> 00:10:28.910
cuz it shows you how you're
connected to the server.

203
00:10:28.910 --> 00:10:32.354
And so I can look right in here and
I can find out am I using POP3?

204
00:10:32.354 --> 00:10:33.395
Am I using IMAP4?

205
00:10:33.395 --> 00:10:35.276
Am I using Outlook Anywhere?

206
00:10:35.276 --> 00:10:36.436
Which one am I using?

207
00:10:36.436 --> 00:10:39.933
And so I can see, I've got three
connections to the server and

208
00:10:39.933 --> 00:10:42.498
each of mine are connected to lab-cas01.

209
00:10:42.498 --> 00:10:43.501
It's also really useful,

210
00:10:43.501 --> 00:10:45.910
cuz you can see which client
access server you're connected to.

211
00:10:45.910 --> 00:10:47.736
You might have more than
one client access server.

212
00:10:47.736 --> 00:10:50.690
Here, we'll figure out which
one we're connected to.

213
00:10:50.690 --> 00:10:53.470
And see how it says, proxy server?

214
00:10:53.470 --> 00:10:55.635
And then an actual server name here,
what's that all about?

215
00:10:55.635 --> 00:10:58.940
Well, the proxy server is
your client access server.

216
00:10:58.940 --> 00:11:02.212
The actual server is the mailbox
server on the back-end.

217
00:11:02.212 --> 00:11:05.990
Client access servers are really just
proxying your connection to the mailbox.

218
00:11:05.990 --> 00:11:09.511
Nobody is allowed to directly connect
to the mailbox server anymore,

219
00:11:09.511 --> 00:11:10.597
those days are gone.

220
00:11:10.597 --> 00:11:12.410
We used to have that and now that's gone.

221
00:11:12.410 --> 00:11:15.388
Now everybody connects to a client
access server, but at the end of the day

222
00:11:15.388 --> 00:11:18.859
the client access server is turning around
and accessing the mailbox server for you.

223
00:11:18.859 --> 00:11:22.200
That way, you don't have to know what
mailbox server your mailbox is on.

224
00:11:22.200 --> 00:11:23.645
The client access server
will figure that out.

225
00:11:23.645 --> 00:11:26.490
You just connect to any of the client
access servers in your network,

226
00:11:26.490 --> 00:11:29.310
in your organization and
you'll get connected.

227
00:11:29.310 --> 00:11:34.562
But if I scroll over, I'll see a lot
more in protocol is what I'm looking for

228
00:11:34.562 --> 00:11:39.587
right here and I can see the protocol
listed for my account is RPC/HTTP.

229
00:11:39.587 --> 00:11:41.738
That means I'm taking my MAPI traffic,

230
00:11:41.738 --> 00:11:45.240
which is remote procedure
called traffic or RPC traffic.

231
00:11:45.240 --> 00:11:49.840
I'm encapsulating that in HTTP and
its really doing SSL, so it'll be

232
00:11:49.840 --> 00:11:54.400
TCP port 443 and sending it across
the network to the client access server.

233
00:11:54.400 --> 00:11:57.605
The client access server receives it,
decrypts the data,

234
00:11:57.605 --> 00:11:59.411
cuz it's encrypted in transit.

235
00:11:59.411 --> 00:12:01.858
Decrypts the data and
then figures out what it is,

236
00:12:01.858 --> 00:12:05.881
reaches out to the mailbox server and gets
the appropriate data and the connection

237
00:12:05.881 --> 00:12:09.970
between the client access server and
the mailbox server is encrypted also.

238
00:12:09.970 --> 00:12:13.120
So we have end-to-end encryption
even on the local area network and

239
00:12:13.120 --> 00:12:16.500
that's really a nice feature to have,
but I can see that I'm connected.

240
00:12:16.500 --> 00:12:19.599
I can see my RPC port is 6001.

241
00:12:19.599 --> 00:12:24.033
But I'm actually going over HTTP, so
it's truly going over port 443, but

242
00:12:24.033 --> 00:12:26.183
the encapsulated port is 6001 and

243
00:12:26.183 --> 00:12:29.680
I'm connected to an exchange
server on the other end.

244
00:12:29.680 --> 00:12:32.686
Now, I have three connections open and
I can see why right here.

245
00:12:32.686 --> 00:12:35.200
One connection is to
the Exchange directory.

246
00:12:35.200 --> 00:12:39.645
That's just to be able to look up
contacts, to be able to find distribution

247
00:12:39.645 --> 00:12:44.163
groups, to figure out what's in a
distribution group as well as to actually

248
00:12:44.163 --> 00:12:48.559
access my email and I usually have
a listening and a speaking connection.

249
00:12:48.559 --> 00:12:52.773
So, one of these is for listening for
new email coming from the server and

250
00:12:52.773 --> 00:12:54.070
retrieving it.

251
00:12:54.070 --> 00:12:57.060
The other one is for sending email and
communicating up to the server, so

252
00:12:57.060 --> 00:12:57.948
I've got those two.

253
00:12:57.948 --> 00:13:00.110
And if you scroll over here,
you can see this session type.

254
00:13:00.110 --> 00:13:02.383
We've got a background,
a foreground and a cache.

255
00:13:02.383 --> 00:13:05.839
These guys are all just kind of
running and doing their activities, so

256
00:13:05.839 --> 00:13:08.030
you can see that health status.

257
00:13:08.030 --> 00:13:11.713
A little over further, I can see the
actual connection type here of HTTP and

258
00:13:11.713 --> 00:13:14.299
that I've got my connections
that are up and going.

259
00:13:14.299 --> 00:13:18.500
So really neat information here,
all kinda hidden away in this tool.

260
00:13:18.500 --> 00:13:21.640
This is handy, because sometimes
you might fire up Outlook and

261
00:13:21.640 --> 00:13:25.032
not know is somebody running,
are they running Outlook Anywhere?

262
00:13:25.032 --> 00:13:28.440
Are they running POP3 or IMAP4,
which one are they running?

263
00:13:28.440 --> 00:13:29.276
Here we can find out.

264
00:13:29.276 --> 00:13:32.762
You just have to remember
to hit Ctrl while you right

265
00:13:32.762 --> 00:13:38.160
click on the Outlook icon in the taskbar
and you'll be able to see that.

266
00:13:38.160 --> 00:13:41.440
So those are some of the different things
we need to be aware of as far as client

267
00:13:41.440 --> 00:13:42.172
connectivity.

268
00:13:42.172 --> 00:13:46.060
Let's take a look at some of the other
things that we might need to customize.

269
00:13:46.060 --> 00:13:47.618
I mentioned, Outlook Anywhere.

270
00:13:47.618 --> 00:13:51.120
Now, Outlook Anywhere is enabled by
default when you install Exchange.

271
00:13:51.120 --> 00:13:52.731
We don't have to turn that on and

272
00:13:52.731 --> 00:13:56.679
our Outlook clients will autodiscover
the server and configure themselves.

273
00:13:56.679 --> 00:13:59.180
Well, for internal servers, they will.

274
00:13:59.180 --> 00:14:02.420
If they're outside the network,
they might not find it.

275
00:14:02.420 --> 00:14:04.814
And so for outside users,
they've gotta use autodiscover and

276
00:14:04.814 --> 00:14:05.818
we've gotta tweak that.

277
00:14:05.818 --> 00:14:07.694
So if you haven't launched it,

278
00:14:07.694 --> 00:14:10.970
we did a two part episode on
configuring autodiscover.

279
00:14:10.970 --> 00:14:11.926
Definitely jump back and

280
00:14:11.926 --> 00:14:14.255
check that episode out,
cuz we show how to take care of that.

281
00:14:14.255 --> 00:14:17.000
But otherwise, for our intro people,
it's automatically configured.

282
00:14:17.000 --> 00:14:20.557
And it's really nice, because you might
have 10,000 computers on your network.

283
00:14:20.557 --> 00:14:24.034
And those 10,000 employees can sit down,
they can launch Outlook and

284
00:14:24.034 --> 00:14:26.857
it will look to the Active Directory,
find their settings and

285
00:14:26.857 --> 00:14:28.500
take them right to their mailbox.

286
00:14:28.500 --> 00:14:30.338
They don't have to know
the name of the server.

287
00:14:30.338 --> 00:14:32.420
They don't have to know anything
about your infrastructure.

288
00:14:32.420 --> 00:14:34.632
They don't have to know IP addresses or
port numbers.

289
00:14:34.632 --> 00:14:37.310
They just launch Outlook and
it automatically configures.

290
00:14:37.310 --> 00:14:40.211
It's really awesome stuff,
o that's kind of cool.

291
00:14:40.211 --> 00:14:42.866
There's not much we need to
tweak about Outlook Anywhere,

292
00:14:42.866 --> 00:14:45.480
there are a few little things
that we need tweaked though.

293
00:14:45.480 --> 00:14:48.470
Let me show you, if I get back
into my Exchange Admin Center.

294
00:14:48.470 --> 00:14:51.320
Here in the Exchange Admin Center,
if I go down to servers.

295
00:14:52.450 --> 00:14:55.980
Under servers, I can see the list
of servers that I have and

296
00:14:55.980 --> 00:15:00.100
any client access server is
an Outlook Anywhere connection point.

297
00:15:00.100 --> 00:15:05.900
They cal it an SCP or a service connection
point and any cast will work for that.

298
00:15:07.030 --> 00:15:09.232
Well, if I go to virtual directories,

299
00:15:09.232 --> 00:15:12.972
here's where I can actually see
the Outlook Web App connection and

300
00:15:12.972 --> 00:15:17.681
the autodiscover connection and how people
are getting connected to that system.

301
00:15:17.681 --> 00:15:20.695
And these virtual directories
are all dictating, basically,

302
00:15:20.695 --> 00:15:23.810
the names of these folders and
how people can connect.

303
00:15:23.810 --> 00:15:26.940
We don't normally need to tweak these,
but you can change the directory names.

304
00:15:26.940 --> 00:15:30.652
If you want people to connect to OWA
under a different folder or whatever, but

305
00:15:30.652 --> 00:15:34.750
these are being pulled in when people
connect via those other protocols.

306
00:15:34.750 --> 00:15:38.689
Now the reason I bring this up is
that with Outlook Anywhere and

307
00:15:38.689 --> 00:15:43.639
with these virtual directories, SSL
certificates can be a bit of a problem.

308
00:15:43.639 --> 00:15:47.360
When you install your server,
it's automatically configured.

309
00:15:47.360 --> 00:15:51.277
Outlook Anywhere is already running,
but it's running with a self-signed

310
00:15:51.277 --> 00:15:54.363
certificate and so
are all these virtual directories here.

311
00:15:54.363 --> 00:15:56.732
They're all using a self
signed certificate and

312
00:15:56.732 --> 00:15:59.457
that means that your clients
probably won't trust it.

313
00:15:59.457 --> 00:16:02.845
And if your clients don't trust it
Then they're gonna fail to connect.

314
00:16:02.845 --> 00:16:06.953
So one of the things that we'll need to do
is to jump over to our certificates and

315
00:16:06.953 --> 00:16:09.270
get a certificate that they do trust.

316
00:16:09.270 --> 00:16:12.400
This certificate right here,
the one labelled Microsoft Exchange,

317
00:16:12.400 --> 00:16:17.600
see down here it's listed for IMAP, POP,
IIS, SMTP, it's listed for all of them.

318
00:16:17.600 --> 00:16:19.050
And so in order for this to work for

319
00:16:19.050 --> 00:16:22.010
people to connect, they're gonna
have to use this certificate.

320
00:16:22.010 --> 00:16:23.530
If they don't trust it, it's gonna fail.

321
00:16:23.530 --> 00:16:25.480
That means Outlook anywhere is gonna fail.

322
00:16:25.480 --> 00:16:27.640
It means the Outlook web app is
gonna throw an error, in fact,

323
00:16:27.640 --> 00:16:29.030
I should see that error right now.

324
00:16:29.030 --> 00:16:33.585
If I go to a client, and
I try to log into the Outlook web app.

325
00:16:33.585 --> 00:16:36.355
Oh shoot, no,
I must have trusted the certificate, so

326
00:16:36.355 --> 00:16:37.355
I'm not getting that error.

327
00:16:37.355 --> 00:16:40.655
But if they to were use the full name of
the server they should get the error.

328
00:16:40.655 --> 00:16:46.403
So, if I do lab-caso1.itprotv.net/owa.

329
00:16:46.403 --> 00:16:49.717
Nope, I've already trusted that name too.

330
00:16:49.717 --> 00:16:52.665
So [LAUGH] if you haven't trusted the name
though, you're gonna get an error.

331
00:16:52.665 --> 00:16:55.060
It's gonna show the certificate
is not trusted.

332
00:16:55.060 --> 00:16:56.640
So when it comes to Outlook anywhere,

333
00:16:56.640 --> 00:16:59.930
one of the only things that we ever really
need to configure is that certificate.

334
00:16:59.930 --> 00:17:03.470
And it's just a matter of coming here
into certificates and issuing a new one.

335
00:17:03.470 --> 00:17:05.950
If you have your own public
key infrastructure, and

336
00:17:05.950 --> 00:17:09.800
your clients all trust it, then you
can just issue your own certificate.

337
00:17:09.800 --> 00:17:12.870
But if you don't have a public key
infrastructure, then you need to generate

338
00:17:12.870 --> 00:17:16.820
a certificate request and
take that to a trusted provider.

339
00:17:16.820 --> 00:17:19.160
Somebody like VeriSign, Thought, DigiCert.

340
00:17:19.160 --> 00:17:21.510
I like DigiCert, but
you can go to whatever one.

341
00:17:21.510 --> 00:17:24.230
Submit your certificate,
and pay them some money.

342
00:17:24.230 --> 00:17:27.703
[LAUGH] They'll issue you a certificate,
and the nice part is that all your clients

343
00:17:27.703 --> 00:17:30.336
will trust that certificate,
and now that system will work.

344
00:17:30.336 --> 00:17:33.157
So that's really one of the only
things that we needed tweak about

345
00:17:33.157 --> 00:17:34.250
Outlook anywhere.

346
00:17:34.250 --> 00:17:37.020
And that basic RPC over HTTP.

347
00:17:37.020 --> 00:17:39.360
Some of the other protocols
are a little more involved though.

348
00:17:40.500 --> 00:17:41.790
OWA's automatically configured.

349
00:17:41.790 --> 00:17:43.790
We saw it right here in
the virtual directories.

350
00:17:43.790 --> 00:17:46.070
I can find that OWA directory right there,

351
00:17:46.070 --> 00:17:49.750
and it's attached to labcas01,
cuz that's my client access server.

352
00:17:49.750 --> 00:17:50.960
If you have five cas, or

353
00:17:50.960 --> 00:17:53.470
five client access servers,
you'll see them all right here.

354
00:17:53.470 --> 00:17:55.060
And you can filter it down if you want.

355
00:17:55.060 --> 00:17:58.940
I can say like,
just show me The OWA virtual directories.

356
00:17:58.940 --> 00:18:02.340
And I would just see OWA for
those different client access servers.

357
00:18:02.340 --> 00:18:03.500
And we can go in and configure them.

358
00:18:03.500 --> 00:18:07.160
And by configure them,
there's really not much we can do.

359
00:18:07.160 --> 00:18:10.290
If you edit it, you can change that URL.

360
00:18:10.290 --> 00:18:12.370
But it's not really the greatest
idea to change that,

361
00:18:12.370 --> 00:18:15.320
because clients expect it
to be in a certain place.

362
00:18:15.320 --> 00:18:17.670
But you can also add an external URL,
and that is handy.

363
00:18:17.670 --> 00:18:22.060
You might have one URL for internal users,
and another URL for external users.

364
00:18:22.060 --> 00:18:24.140
And so, we can set that right here.

365
00:18:24.140 --> 00:18:26.260
You can also tweak their authentication.

366
00:18:26.260 --> 00:18:29.920
Now for OWA,
it's doing forms based authentication.

367
00:18:29.920 --> 00:18:32.330
When you go to the webpage you see that

368
00:18:32.330 --> 00:18:34.530
spot where it asks user name and
a password.

369
00:18:34.530 --> 00:18:36.690
But you might want to
automate that process, right.

370
00:18:36.690 --> 00:18:39.950
Automate the login process and
do Windows on occasion.

371
00:18:39.950 --> 00:18:41.400
And so,
you'll see those options are in here.

372
00:18:41.400 --> 00:18:44.530
You can turn on integrated Windows
authentication or other ones.

373
00:18:44.530 --> 00:18:46.660
That form is the default.

374
00:18:46.660 --> 00:18:47.250
All right?

375
00:18:47.250 --> 00:18:49.830
And notice the form,
how it's asking for domain/user name.

376
00:18:49.830 --> 00:18:50.700
You can tweak that.

377
00:18:50.700 --> 00:18:54.960
Like, I can say, just take a user name,
And then specify the domain by default.

378
00:18:54.960 --> 00:18:57.420
So if you only have one domain,
you might as well do this.

379
00:18:57.420 --> 00:19:01.320
You can set the domain, and now users can
log in just by putting in their username

380
00:19:01.320 --> 00:19:04.160
instead of having to do
domain slash username.

381
00:19:04.160 --> 00:19:05.840
It's a little more intuitive.

382
00:19:05.840 --> 00:19:07.850
Or you can do user principal name.

383
00:19:07.850 --> 00:19:11.110
And that's cool because if your user
principal name is your e-mail address,

384
00:19:11.110 --> 00:19:12.720
people log in with their e-mail address.

385
00:19:12.720 --> 00:19:19.493
So my UPN is Itprotv.net,
then I can log in as DPizet@itprotv.net.

386
00:19:19.493 --> 00:19:20.990
All right, so

387
00:19:20.990 --> 00:19:24.530
those are a couple of different options
that we can tweak on Outlook Web Access.

388
00:19:24.530 --> 00:19:26.650
Now we've also got support for
POP3 and IMAP4,

389
00:19:26.650 --> 00:19:30.470
and ideally we're not going to
use those cuz they're, well,

390
00:19:30.470 --> 00:19:34.480
none of it's feature rich as doing
the Outlook anywhere connectivity.

391
00:19:34.480 --> 00:19:36.200
But, there's a reason for
having them, right?

392
00:19:36.200 --> 00:19:37.515
Compatibility.

393
00:19:37.515 --> 00:19:40.850
POP3 is pretty much compatible
with everything out there, but

394
00:19:40.850 --> 00:19:41.970
it's got it's limitations.

395
00:19:41.970 --> 00:19:45.430
You know, it downloads emails and
removes them from the server by default.

396
00:19:45.430 --> 00:19:47.500
That means that if your client
has a failed hard drive or

397
00:19:47.500 --> 00:19:48.410
whatever, they could lose data.

398
00:19:48.410 --> 00:19:49.590
That's kind of bad.

399
00:19:49.590 --> 00:19:52.500
Also, POP3 doesn't play nice if
you have more than one machine.

400
00:19:52.500 --> 00:19:55.140
If you check an email and
mark it as read on one machine,

401
00:19:55.140 --> 00:19:58.810
the other machine doesn't see that, so
that's kind of a problem with POP3.

402
00:19:58.810 --> 00:20:01.930
And finally, it doesn't support folders,
and I know for me, that's a showstopper.

403
00:20:01.930 --> 00:20:03.730
I gotta have folders in my mailbox.

404
00:20:03.730 --> 00:20:08.560
IMAP4, on the other hand, supports folders
so you can do nice organizations, and

405
00:20:08.560 --> 00:20:10.040
it leaves the emails on the server.

406
00:20:10.040 --> 00:20:12.010
You download the headers
until you read them.

407
00:20:12.010 --> 00:20:15.680
And if you mark an email as read on one
machine, your other machines will see it.

408
00:20:15.680 --> 00:20:18.840
And IMAP4's still widely used today,
because there's a lot of

409
00:20:18.840 --> 00:20:23.490
clients out there that don't necessarily
support Exchange, Active Sync or whatever.

410
00:20:23.490 --> 00:20:26.210
IMAP4 is supported by
darn near everything.

411
00:20:26.210 --> 00:20:28.270
Well, in Microsoft exchange
we have IMAP4 support,

412
00:20:28.270 --> 00:20:31.780
and we have POP3 support,
it's just turned off by default.

413
00:20:31.780 --> 00:20:33.900
So if we want to use it,
we need to jump in there and make and

414
00:20:33.900 --> 00:20:36.220
make a couple little
configuration changes.

415
00:20:36.220 --> 00:20:38.510
First off, we need to jump in
to make sure that POP3 and

416
00:20:38.510 --> 00:20:39.920
IMAP4 are enabled for our users.

417
00:20:39.920 --> 00:20:41.400
And we saw at the beginning
of the episode.

418
00:20:41.400 --> 00:20:43.670
It's enabled by default, so
we don't have to mess with that.

419
00:20:43.670 --> 00:20:48.619
But the IMAP4 and POP3 services
are actually stopped on the server, so

420
00:20:48.619 --> 00:20:50.010
we need to fix that.

421
00:20:50.010 --> 00:20:52.830
So let's take a look at my server here and
we'll get that squared away.

422
00:20:52.830 --> 00:20:56.050
So what I need to do is, I need to
jump over to my client access server.

423
00:20:56.050 --> 00:20:57.690
Here's my client access server.

424
00:20:57.690 --> 00:21:02.380
And I'm just gonna go into my server
manager and go to tools and services.

425
00:21:02.380 --> 00:21:06.160
And I'm gonna hunt down
the Microsoft Exchange POP3 and

426
00:21:06.160 --> 00:21:10.030
IMAP4 services, so they're right down here
in the exchange block, and here they are.

427
00:21:10.030 --> 00:21:12.380
And see how they're set to manually start?

428
00:21:12.380 --> 00:21:15.132
So they're not started automatically,
so I need to change that.

429
00:21:15.132 --> 00:21:17.900
I'm gonna come in here and
just set that to automatic, so

430
00:21:17.900 --> 00:21:22.820
they will start up when my system starts,
and then I'll start the services myself.

431
00:21:22.820 --> 00:21:26.200
Now, in previous versions of Exchange,
that's all we had to do.

432
00:21:26.200 --> 00:21:28.730
We just had to start these
two services and that was it.

433
00:21:28.730 --> 00:21:33.560
But in Exchange 2013, POP3 and IMAP4 have
now been broken into a front end and

434
00:21:33.560 --> 00:21:34.960
a back end service.

435
00:21:34.960 --> 00:21:39.620
And what I'm turning on here is actually
just a front end, or a proxy, for POP3 and

436
00:21:39.620 --> 00:21:40.220
IMAP4.

437
00:21:40.220 --> 00:21:42.270
So you connect to the front end server,
and

438
00:21:42.270 --> 00:21:44.410
then it proxies you to
the back end server.

439
00:21:44.410 --> 00:21:47.760
And that means I need to
jump to my mailbox servers.

440
00:21:47.760 --> 00:21:52.190
Any mailbox server where I have mailboxes
that I need POP3 or IMAP4 support for,

441
00:21:52.190 --> 00:21:56.170
I need to jump to that mailbox server,
and turn on those services there too.

442
00:21:56.170 --> 00:22:00.510
So here I am on my mailbox server, and
I'll just go to tools and services.

443
00:22:00.510 --> 00:22:04.480
And I'm gonna hunt down not the exact
same service, but pretty close.

444
00:22:04.480 --> 00:22:05.300
If we browse down and

445
00:22:05.300 --> 00:22:08.790
find it, you'll notice that
the name is a little bit different.

446
00:22:08.790 --> 00:22:14.760
See how it's
Microsoft Exchange IMAP4 Backend, right?

447
00:22:14.760 --> 00:22:19.470
That's that backend service for IMAP4,
and then the POP3 one right there too.

448
00:22:19.470 --> 00:22:20.370
It's a different service.

449
00:22:20.370 --> 00:22:22.540
This is the backend, but
you've gotta enable this too, or

450
00:22:22.540 --> 00:22:24.000
it's not going to work.

451
00:22:24.000 --> 00:22:26.050
So I'm gonna get in here
that one to automatic.

452
00:22:27.640 --> 00:22:28.990
And I'll start it up.

453
00:22:28.990 --> 00:22:29.690
That's POP3.

454
00:22:29.690 --> 00:22:31.150
Then I'll do the same thing for IMAP4.

455
00:22:31.150 --> 00:22:32.440
I'm doing them both together.

456
00:22:32.440 --> 00:22:33.430
You don't have to.

457
00:22:33.430 --> 00:22:35.330
Maybe I don't need POP3,
I just want IMAP4,

458
00:22:35.330 --> 00:22:38.250
then you can just turn that one on and
leave POP3 off.

459
00:22:38.250 --> 00:22:40.900
By all means,
leave services off if you don't need them,

460
00:22:40.900 --> 00:22:42.460
It just increase your tack surface.

461
00:22:43.770 --> 00:22:46.780
All right, the other thing is when
I open these, I'm opening them,

462
00:22:46.780 --> 00:22:47.890
I'm starting the services.

463
00:22:47.890 --> 00:22:53.770
But I might need to adjust my
firewall to allow port 110 or 143 for

464
00:22:53.770 --> 00:22:59.250
POP3 and IMAP4 unsecure, or 993 and
995 first are the secure versions.

465
00:22:59.250 --> 00:23:01.190
I might need to allow those
through my firewall too.

466
00:23:01.190 --> 00:23:03.030
All right,
they're already clear on my firewalls, so

467
00:23:03.030 --> 00:23:04.350
I don't have to worry about that.

468
00:23:04.350 --> 00:23:07.050
But at this stage, I should be good to go.

469
00:23:07.050 --> 00:23:09.600
POP3 and IMAP4 are enabled for my users.

470
00:23:09.600 --> 00:23:11.740
I've now started the services.

471
00:23:11.740 --> 00:23:13.690
There's some basic
configuration you can do.

472
00:23:13.690 --> 00:23:14.630
You don't have to, right.

473
00:23:14.630 --> 00:23:17.840
I can jump down here to my servers and
take LabCastle1.

474
00:23:17.840 --> 00:23:19.840
There's my client access server.

475
00:23:19.840 --> 00:23:24.980
And if I edit that I've got some POP3 and
IMAP4 settings in here that I can tweak.

476
00:23:24.980 --> 00:23:28.430
I can adjust the settings, but
there's not much to adjust.

477
00:23:28.430 --> 00:23:31.590
The port number it's running on,
what type of encryption you're using.

478
00:23:31.590 --> 00:23:34.370
You'll see mine's defaulting to TLS and
ports that we're bound to.

479
00:23:34.370 --> 00:23:36.430
Those are the things that we can tweak.

480
00:23:36.430 --> 00:23:37.980
There's not a whole lot
of reason to tweak those.

481
00:23:37.980 --> 00:23:40.420
And if we go into more options,
it's mostly time out values.

482
00:23:40.420 --> 00:23:41.500
So all this different time out and

483
00:23:41.500 --> 00:23:44.670
maximum connections settings,
things we don't normally need to adjust.

484
00:23:44.670 --> 00:23:47.290
So usually starting the services
is enough to get it going.

485
00:23:47.290 --> 00:23:48.590
And we're in business.

486
00:23:48.590 --> 00:23:49.830
So let's test it out.

487
00:23:49.830 --> 00:23:52.230
I'm gonna jump over to my client.

488
00:23:52.230 --> 00:23:53.270
Well, I'm on my client.

489
00:23:53.270 --> 00:23:55.520
And I wanna get connected
with a third party client.

490
00:23:55.520 --> 00:23:57.820
I'm gonna connect with
a program called Postbox.

491
00:23:57.820 --> 00:23:59.731
This is what I like to use.

492
00:23:59.731 --> 00:24:02.807
And in Postbox,
I can add in that Exchange account.

493
00:24:02.807 --> 00:24:05.889
So I'm just gonna go up here to Tools and
options.

494
00:24:05.889 --> 00:24:09.820
And over to my accounts,
I'm gonna add in a new mail account.

495
00:24:09.820 --> 00:24:12.960
And when I add it, I'll punch in account,
I'll log in as Jane Smith.

496
00:24:13.980 --> 00:24:15.860
So I'm gonna punch hers in.

497
00:24:15.860 --> 00:24:20.480
Now, I know that auto discover
is not gonna work for this.

498
00:24:20.480 --> 00:24:23.553
Auto discover is always gonna try and
set you up for Outlook anywhere, right?

499
00:24:23.553 --> 00:24:25.350
And I need to login with POP3 or IMAP4.

500
00:24:25.350 --> 00:24:30.770
So, I'm gonna have to go into my
manual setup option and specify that.

501
00:24:30.770 --> 00:24:31.750
But fortunately, it's pretty easy.

502
00:24:31.750 --> 00:24:35.726
I can say here, username is jsmith,
it's actually jsmith@itprotv.net, but

503
00:24:35.726 --> 00:24:36.830
I can leave it jsmith.

504
00:24:36.830 --> 00:24:37.490
It'll be fine.

505
00:24:37.490 --> 00:24:40.140
If you have more than one domain,
you might need to specify a domain there.

506
00:24:40.140 --> 00:24:42.110
I've only got one domain so
I can leave it off.

507
00:24:42.110 --> 00:24:48.450
My server is lab-cas01.itprotv.net,
and then the protocol.

508
00:24:48.450 --> 00:24:51.702
I wanna use IMAP, and
then you'll see that port is 143.

509
00:24:51.702 --> 00:24:54.534
Now 143 is nonsecure by default.

510
00:24:54.534 --> 00:24:57.762
If you're using SSL,
you wanna use 993, but

511
00:24:57.762 --> 00:25:02.515
even when you connect on 143,
you can tell it to use TLS, all right?

512
00:25:02.515 --> 00:25:06.635
And if we tell it to use TLS, it's gonna
connect on 143, that's immediately gonna

513
00:25:06.635 --> 00:25:10.335
say hey I wanna switch to transport layer
security, give me your certificate.

514
00:25:10.335 --> 00:25:13.225
And then you'll do a key exchange and
you'll switch to encrypted and so

515
00:25:13.225 --> 00:25:14.345
that's what I'm gonna do.

516
00:25:14.345 --> 00:25:17.915
And on the exchange side,
it's set that way too, if I

517
00:25:17.915 --> 00:25:23.420
go back to my server settings around here
somewhere, and I find my IMAP4 settings.

518
00:25:23.420 --> 00:25:26.360
See how it's set for
log on method secure TLS?

519
00:25:26.360 --> 00:25:30.240
And for that 143 it says TLS or
unencrypted.

520
00:25:30.240 --> 00:25:32.830
If somebody connects unencrypted,
it's not gonna let them log in,

521
00:25:32.830 --> 00:25:35.600
because we're requiring TLS for log in.

522
00:25:35.600 --> 00:25:36.160
All right?
So

523
00:25:36.160 --> 00:25:37.610
that's gonna give me a secure connection.

524
00:25:38.880 --> 00:25:42.360
Then my outgoing server, I can punch
that in, and I'm using the same for

525
00:25:42.360 --> 00:25:43.030
my outgoing server.

526
00:25:43.030 --> 00:25:43.890
You might have a different one.

527
00:25:43.890 --> 00:25:47.664
And then we can specify SMTP,
and it's much the same way.

528
00:25:47.664 --> 00:25:52.569
We've got port 25 for unencrypted,
port 587 for encrypted, and with port 25,

529
00:25:52.569 --> 00:25:54.160
you could switch to SSL, but

530
00:25:54.160 --> 00:25:58.560
most of the time we're gonna use start
TLS, which requires us to be on 587.

531
00:25:58.560 --> 00:26:02.710
So, I'm setting that up to be able
to connect, and I'll go ahead and

532
00:26:02.710 --> 00:26:03.870
finish that up.

533
00:26:03.870 --> 00:26:06.534
Now, assuming it works,
I should be able to hit, get mail,

534
00:26:06.534 --> 00:26:09.253
it's gonna reach out to the server,
and get my email, if I put

535
00:26:09.253 --> 00:26:12.780
the wrong password in, that'll kinda
slow things down a bit, but we'll see.

536
00:26:12.780 --> 00:26:15.890
There we go, I connected,
and I can read my email.

537
00:26:15.890 --> 00:26:19.760
So, now I'm connected via IMAP4,
so Outlook anywhere.

538
00:26:19.760 --> 00:26:20.830
MAPI, right?

539
00:26:20.830 --> 00:26:23.690
The Messaging Application Programming
Interface, those connectivities,

540
00:26:23.690 --> 00:26:25.650
those are the ones that
Microsoft wants you to use.

541
00:26:25.650 --> 00:26:26.610
Those are fully featured.

542
00:26:26.610 --> 00:26:30.188
They give you your calendar,
your tasks, your contacts,

543
00:26:30.188 --> 00:26:32.633
all that other stuff and email, right?

544
00:26:32.633 --> 00:26:36.113
But if you're using third party clients,
if you're using mobile phones, or

545
00:26:36.113 --> 00:26:39.740
whatever, that don't have full exchange
functionality, you can use IMAP4.

546
00:26:39.740 --> 00:26:43.650
You'll get all your email,
your folders, you can organize things.

547
00:26:43.650 --> 00:26:45.321
You lose your contacts, right?

548
00:26:45.321 --> 00:26:49.347
You lose your task list or your calendar,
but you can get those other ways.

549
00:26:49.347 --> 00:26:51.447
Right?
There's other ways like Web DAV for

550
00:26:51.447 --> 00:26:56.380
pulling down contacts and stuff you can
do, or LDAP for pulling down contacts.

551
00:26:56.380 --> 00:26:57.720
But IMAP4 won't do it.

552
00:26:57.720 --> 00:27:01.930
So, if we just need email connectivity,
IMAP4 works out pretty well.

553
00:27:01.930 --> 00:27:05.600
POP3 is there also which is far less
popular, we just need to turn it on.

554
00:27:06.720 --> 00:27:10.976
All right, so in this episode we've got a
chance to see quite a few different email

555
00:27:10.976 --> 00:27:12.283
connectivity methods.

556
00:27:12.283 --> 00:27:17.020
We started with talking about OWA and
Outlook anywhere, and MAPI, right?

557
00:27:17.020 --> 00:27:19.470
Those are the ones that
Microsoft wants us to use.

558
00:27:19.470 --> 00:27:23.690
Then we talked about POP3 and IMAP4 which
are also out there which are available for

559
00:27:23.690 --> 00:27:25.380
compatibility, so we've got those.

560
00:27:25.380 --> 00:27:28.350
And at the end of the day, it's up to you
to pick the ones that you want, the ones

561
00:27:28.350 --> 00:27:31.020
that you need or the ones that you even
choose to support for your clients.

562
00:27:31.020 --> 00:27:33.290
Cuz you might not wanna
support all of those right?

563
00:27:33.290 --> 00:27:34.940
So you just kinda pick and choose.

564
00:27:34.940 --> 00:27:36.930
Get the ones you need and
get them in place.

565
00:27:37.992 --> 00:27:39.760
All right, so that's about it for
this episode.

566
00:27:39.760 --> 00:27:42.230
That's Client Connectivity,
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

567
00:27:42.230 --> 00:27:44.940
We've got more exchange
content coming down the road.

568
00:27:44.940 --> 00:27:48.340
But for now, signing off for
IT Pro Tv, I'm Don Pizette and

569
00:27:48.340 --> 00:27:49.773
I'll see you next time.

570
00:27:49.773 --> 00:27:55.990
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the Autodiscover service in Exchange 2013. He demonstrates how Microsoft Outlook clients can automatically configure themselves to access an Exchange server. He also explains the steps needed to support clients outside of your local network.
episodes.title: Autodiscover
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.414
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:10.414 --> 00:00:12.589
All right, good morning, good afternoon,

3
00:00:12.589 --> 00:00:15.751
and good evening and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.751 --> 00:00:17.840
I'm your host Don Pezet,

5
00:00:17.840 --> 00:00:21.230
back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:24.540
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at the mysterious

7
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:25.910
Autodiscover service.

8
00:00:25.910 --> 00:00:30.050
Now Autodiscover is a really neat
function that's built into Exchange.

9
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:32.200
It was actually introduced
several versions ago, but

10
00:00:32.200 --> 00:00:35.470
it's gotten a little better with each
version of Exchange that's come out, and

11
00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:39.130
what Autodiscover does is
it allows your clients

12
00:00:39.130 --> 00:00:43.800
to be able to launch Microsoft Outlook and
have it automatically configure itself to

13
00:00:43.800 --> 00:00:45.890
connect to your server without
you having to do anything.

14
00:00:45.890 --> 00:00:49.450
Now back in the day when you fired
up somebody's new computer for

15
00:00:49.450 --> 00:00:51.060
the first time you'd have
to fire up Outlook and

16
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:55.100
you'd have to put in the server name,
the username, the password.

17
00:00:55.100 --> 00:00:57.270
You'd have to know the ports
to connect on the server.

18
00:00:57.270 --> 00:01:00.710
You'd have to know a lot of information
that an average end user doesn't know.

19
00:01:00.710 --> 00:01:04.810
So just getting connected to e-mail in the
first place usually required the help of,

20
00:01:04.810 --> 00:01:06.620
well, the support team, right?

21
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:09.020
Your desktop engineers,
your help desk techs, or

22
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:13.060
whoever to get people connected, but with
Autodiscover you don't need that anymore.

23
00:01:13.060 --> 00:01:17.460
Now people just launch Outlook and
it magically finds your server, finds your

24
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:20.980
settings, gets everything configured in
your email, and you didn't have to have

25
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:24.600
any intimate knowledge of the background
infrastructure or anything like that.

26
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:26.260
And that's really, really useful.

27
00:01:26.260 --> 00:01:30.890
All right, now the reason I say
Autodiscover is mysterious is that for

28
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:32.510
most of us we don't have to configure it.

29
00:01:32.510 --> 00:01:33.570
It just works.

30
00:01:33.570 --> 00:01:38.345
You install Exchange, and
all of a sudden your system auto detects.

31
00:01:38.345 --> 00:01:41.280
And that's true for
your local area network.

32
00:01:41.280 --> 00:01:42.905
For machines on your own network,

33
00:01:42.905 --> 00:01:44.300
Autodiscover will work
right out of the box.

34
00:01:44.300 --> 00:01:46.430
You really don't have to tweak anything.

35
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:50.520
But if you've got users that are
connecting from home, from outside of your

36
00:01:50.520 --> 00:01:53.850
network, if they're out their on the WAM
on the Internet somewhere, that's not so

37
00:01:53.850 --> 00:01:54.615
automatic anymore.

38
00:01:54.615 --> 00:01:55.820
It's not so magic.

39
00:01:55.820 --> 00:01:57.820
Now we have to get a bit involved.

40
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:00.740
And so in this episode we're gonna
take a look at how AutoDiscover works.

41
00:02:00.740 --> 00:02:03.020
How the nice,
easy automatic stuff works, and

42

00:02:33.140 --> 00:02:36.310

00:02:36.310 --> 00:02:38.840

00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:43.340
What they do is they create what's called

that service control, oh sorry,

That service connection point,

Every client access server you have

So when I launch Outlook, it'll be the

00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:19.820

Not by default.

00:05:31.410 --> 00:05:34.240
So the reason this is stalling

00:05:34.240 --> 00:05:36.270

eventually I'll get a little pop-up and

00:05:36.270 --> 00:05:39.930
it'll say do you wanna trust this and

117
00:05:39.930 --> 00:05:43.630
But what I can do to kinda usher

00:05:43.630 --> 00:05:48.921
One, I can go out and buy a legitimate

00:05:48.921 --> 00:05:51.170
Verisign, Thought,

00:05:51.170 --> 00:05:54.290
You go out and you buy a certificate

You put that on your server and now your

00:05:57.940 --> 00:06:01.110
That works for small businesses,

00:06:01.110 --> 00:06:02.230
But for large organizations,

00:06:04.220 --> 00:06:08.190

00:06:11.070 --> 00:06:13.410

00:06:13.410 --> 00:06:14.420
They're your own, and

00:06:14.420 --> 00:06:17.710
machines that are joined to your

00:06:17.710 --> 00:06:22.550
But mine's not going to trust it

00:06:22.550 --> 00:06:23.990
but I don't have a true

00:06:23.990 --> 00:06:26.620

So, to do that quickly and easily, you can

00:06:38.910 --> 00:06:44.400
And when I browse to the server I'm gonna

00:06:44.400 --> 00:06:49.870
right, so when I browse to

It's telling me that certificate's not

00:06:54.710 --> 00:06:58.570

00:06:58.570 --> 00:06:59.940
And I want to trust it.

00:06:59.940 --> 00:07:02.410
So, if I want to trust it,

00:07:05.380 --> 00:07:08.890
And what I want to do, is I basically

00:07:10.930 --> 00:07:14.220
I know it, but, in a real production

00:07:17.170 --> 00:07:19.980

So I'm just going to throw

00:07:24.750 --> 00:07:28.230

And now if I close that window down,

00:07:40.510 --> 00:07:43.160
And this time when I browse

00:07:45.470 --> 00:07:48.030
is that I didn't get a certificate prompt,

00:07:48.030 --> 00:07:50.200
It's trusting the certificate this time.

00:07:50.200 --> 00:07:51.663
And if I fire up my Outlook,

00:07:51.663 --> 00:07:56.073
now when it goes to autoconfigure it's

00:07:56.073 --> 00:07:58.945
So one of the key steps to getting

00:07:58.945 --> 00:08:02.160
your certificates squared away, so we're

00:08:02.160 --> 00:08:05.366
But now it's gonna find his settings,

00:08:05.366 --> 00:08:08.170

00:08:08.170 --> 00:08:11.190
Now the discovery process,

00:08:11.190 --> 00:08:13.780
different steps to try and

168
00:08:13.780 --> 00:08:17.220
Step one, well it looks to

00:08:17.220 --> 00:08:19.670
And so mine just did that look to

00:08:19.670 --> 00:08:22.050
that's what's gonna happen
on your local area network.

171
00:08:22.050 --> 00:08:26.670
But if you're not on a local area network,
step two, it looks to DNS.

172
00:08:26.670 --> 00:08:29.440
It looks to DNS to find
an auto discover record to

173
00:08:29.440 --> 00:08:31.590

174
00:08:31.590 --> 00:08:33.650
Now mine didn't do that cuz
I'm on a local network, but

175
00:08:33.650 --> 00:08:36.530
if I'm on an external server
it's going to have to do that.

176
00:08:36.530 --> 00:08:39.340
So here I see it,
it just moved through this and it's fine.

177
00:08:39.340 --> 00:08:40.730
There is a step three.

178
00:08:40.730 --> 00:08:43.600
So, first it does look
to the active directory.

179
00:08:43.600 --> 00:08:45.570
Second, it looks to DNS.

180
00:08:45.570 --> 00:08:49.650
Third, it looks for
a special SRV record in DNS.

181
00:08:49.650 --> 00:08:53.660
Now that's separate from step two because

182
00:08:53.660 --> 00:08:56.770
they're not all supported, so
that's kind of like a last ditch effort

183
00:08:56.770 --> 00:08:59.570
before it finally gives up and
auto discover fails.

00:08:59.570 --> 00:09:02.910
If auto discover fails, then users get

00:09:05.770 --> 00:09:09.460

00:09:09.460 --> 00:09:10.840
So here, it's automatically configured.

00:09:10.840 --> 00:09:13.410
If I finish that,

And if I'm John Doe and I just sat down

00:09:26.140 --> 00:09:27.870
I'm in it, and I'm working, right?

00:09:27.870 --> 00:09:31.530
The end-user didn't have to

00:09:31.530 --> 00:09:35.130
All they had to know was

00:09:35.130 --> 00:09:36.430
That's what auto discover does.

00:09:36.430 --> 00:09:38.560
That's the real power of it, all right?

00:09:38.560 --> 00:09:41.110
But as you saw with the certificate,

00:09:41.110 --> 00:09:44.130

00:09:44.130 --> 00:09:45.480
to get it running smoothly.

00:09:45.480 --> 00:09:48.390
So here, I'm in my mailbox and

00:09:48.390 --> 00:09:52.920
Well, let's take a look at a few

00:09:52.920 --> 00:09:54.730

00:09:54.730 --> 00:09:56.020
I mentioned certificates.

00:09:56.020 --> 00:09:59.890
Certificates are probably the big part,

00:09:59.890 --> 00:10:05.200

207
00:10:05.200 --> 00:10:07.060
That's the internal server name.

208
00:10:07.060 --> 00:10:10.601
But if they're external, they're
connecting with a different name, right?

209
00:10:10.601 --> 00:10:12.469
And so now you're gonna have
your certificate fail because

210
00:10:12.469 --> 00:10:13.224
of the different name.

211
00:10:13.224 --> 00:10:14.663
So that's something we're

212
00:10:14.663 --> 00:10:17.123
And then just where the certificate
is issued from in the first place.

213
00:10:17.123 --> 00:10:21.141
So, at a minimum,
we're gonna need to fix our certificate.

214
00:10:21.141 --> 00:10:24.103
At a maximum though, we're gonna need to
do some DNS work to kind of get things

00:10:24.103 --> 00:10:26.121
squared away and
get everything working properly.

00:10:26.121 --> 00:10:29.117
So let's kind of jump through the hoops

00:10:29.117 --> 00:10:33.704
All right, I'm gonna jump back

00:10:33.704 --> 00:10:38.790

00:10:38.790 --> 00:10:41.675
And in there we'll be able

00:10:41.675 --> 00:10:44.085

00:10:44.085 --> 00:10:46.925
When you go into the EAC,

00:10:46.925 --> 00:10:49.305
you'll see a bunch of stuff,

00:10:49.305 --> 00:10:53.220
And then in the server section,

Here's where it keeps your certificates,

00:10:55.870 --> 00:10:58.970

00:10:58.970 --> 00:11:01.300
And every Exchange server's important, but

So what you'll wanna do is hit this

From here, you can see all

00:11:15.461 --> 00:11:16.337
For example,

00:11:20.644 --> 00:11:22.765
Microsoft Exchange, and WMSVC.

00:11:22.765 --> 00:11:23.843
All right, what are these?

00:11:23.843 --> 00:11:27.048
Well the first one, that's used for

00:11:27.048 --> 00:11:29.377
When two Exchange servers

Server 2012, so that's the one that's
