00:12:51.160 --> 00:12:56.260
doing Outlook WebApp, and auto discover
is using the web service also.

266
00:12:56.260 --> 00:12:57.720
So this is the important certificate.

267
00:12:57.720 --> 00:12:59.880
This is the one that I care about.

268
00:12:59.880 --> 00:13:03.770
And if you look at it you'll see this
is a self-signed certificate, and

269
00:13:03.770 --> 00:13:07.530
the issuer is my server, lab-cass01.

270
00:13:07.530 --> 00:13:10.045
When you install your client access
server, you'll see the same thing, right?

271
00:13:10.045 --> 00:13:12.330
Well, it'll be your server name,
that'll be different, but

272
00:13:12.330 --> 00:13:14.110
you'll have that self-signed certificate.

273
00:13:14.110 --> 00:13:16.380
And so the certificate error
that I saw a moment ago?

274
00:13:16.380 --> 00:13:19.350
Well, it wasn't so much an error,
just the things took too long.

275
00:13:19.350 --> 00:13:23.120
That error, that's caused by
the self-signed certificate.

276
00:13:23.120 --> 00:13:24.950
So, you got two choices.

277
00:13:24.950 --> 00:13:27.470
One, trust the self-signed certificate.

278
00:13:27.470 --> 00:13:29.030
That's what I did a second ago.

279
00:13:29.030 --> 00:13:33.610
Or two, issue a new certificate and
use it instead, right?

280
00:13:33.610 --> 00:13:36.250
And you can see we've got a nice little
plus sign up here you can hit to issue

281
00:13:36.250 --> 00:13:37.540
a new certificate.

282
00:13:37.540 --> 00:13:40.895
Now I could create a new
self signed certificate, but

283
00:13:40.895 --> 00:13:42.650
there's not really a whole
lot of point in that.

284
00:13:42.650 --> 00:13:45.410
Maybe you just don't trust
the certificate that Microsoft issued so

285
00:13:45.410 --> 00:13:46.740
you wanna issue your own.

286
00:13:46.740 --> 00:13:49.710
Maybe the one that was there got
compromised and so you wanna do a new one.

287
00:13:49.710 --> 00:13:53.507
Those would be reasons you might do
a self-signed cert, but otherwise you're

288
00:13:53.507 --> 00:13:57.092
gonna create a request for a certificate
from a certification authority.

289
00:13:57.092 --> 00:14:01.053
Now that CA,
it might be a public one, right?

290
00:14:01.053 --> 00:14:03.094
I mentioned like DigiCert or
Verisign, those guys.

291
00:14:03.094 --> 00:14:05.870
You can go and buy a certificate
from them, it works great and

292
00:14:05.870 --> 00:14:09.465
it has the added benefit of knowing that
all of your clients are gonna trust it,

293
00:14:09.465 --> 00:14:11.939
whether they're joined your domain or
not, right?

294
00:14:11.939 --> 00:14:15.133
Or, this CA could be one of your own,
right?

295
00:14:15.133 --> 00:14:19.229
You could take any domain controller and
add the active directory certificates

296
00:14:19.229 --> 00:14:22.296
services to it and
turn it into a certification authority.

297
00:14:22.296 --> 00:14:24.540
You could start issuing your own certs.

298
00:14:24.540 --> 00:14:27.310
On a positive side you could issue
certs without paying for them, right?

299
00:14:27.310 --> 00:14:28.450
It's your own.

300
00:14:28.450 --> 00:14:33.170
On a negative side, only computers
joined to your domain will trust it.

301
00:14:33.170 --> 00:14:36.410
Computers that are not joined to your
domain aren't going to trust it and

302
00:14:36.410 --> 00:14:41.550
so you'll have to go to them and manually
make them trust your route authority.

303
00:14:41.550 --> 00:14:44.118
And so, there's a little bit
of extra work to do there.

304
00:14:44.118 --> 00:14:45.478
But normally, we're gonna buy one.

305
00:14:45.478 --> 00:14:47.793
And the reason I say we're
gonna buy one is because,

306
00:14:47.793 --> 00:14:49.483
whose gonna connect to your Outlook?

307
00:14:49.483 --> 00:14:52.141
Well, you might have people
on mobile phones, right?

308
00:14:52.141 --> 00:14:53.998
This is the age of bring your own device,
right?

309
00:14:53.998 --> 00:14:56.900
So you might have people on mobile phones,
iPads.

310
00:14:56.900 --> 00:15:00.875
They might have their own tablets,
there own desktops, there own laptops that

311
00:15:00.875 --> 00:15:05.815
are not computers that you control and
they just wanna be able to login to OWA.

312
00:15:05.815 --> 00:15:09.225
Or they just wanna be able to fire up
their Outlook client and connect securely.

313
00:15:09.225 --> 00:15:12.355
And since we don't have control of that
device, we can't make it trust our

314
00:15:12.355 --> 00:15:16.935
certificate, and as a result it's better
off for us to just go and buy one, right?

315
00:15:16.935 --> 00:15:18.255
Now be careful,

316
00:15:18.255 --> 00:15:23.470
when you buy a certificate because your
server has more than one name, right?

317
00:15:23.470 --> 00:15:24.331
Let me show you what I mean.

318
00:15:24.331 --> 00:15:28.453
If I go to create this request, and I hit
Next, it's gonna ask for a friendly name.

319
00:15:28.453 --> 00:15:29.928
And the friendly name is
whatever you want, right?

320
00:15:29.928 --> 00:15:33.459
You could call the certificate
Bob if you wanted to, but

321
00:15:33.459 --> 00:15:36.480
I'll call this one my
Public ISS Certificate.

322
00:15:36.480 --> 00:15:40.240
Or some kind of name that let's us
remember what its purpose is, right,

323
00:15:40.240 --> 00:15:42.320
why we got that certificate.

324
00:15:42.320 --> 00:15:46.460
And then, it's gonna ask if I want
to do a wild card certificate.

325
00:15:46.460 --> 00:15:49.060
Now, wild card certificates are when
we do when we don't have a true server

326
00:15:49.060 --> 00:15:49.609
name in there.

327
00:15:49.609 --> 00:15:54.572
So, instead of having
lab/casso1.itprotv.net I might

328
00:15:54.572 --> 00:15:56.914
have star.itprotv.net.

329
00:15:56.914 --> 00:15:59.982
Now, wild cards certificates
are nice cuz you can use them for

330
00:15:59.982 --> 00:16:02.873
more than one name But
if the certificate is compromised,

331
00:16:02.873 --> 00:16:05.823
it's now been compromised
across more than one system, so

332
00:16:05.823 --> 00:16:09.350
while we have that possibility
we don't normally do it, right.

333
00:16:09.350 --> 00:16:13.290
So on our next page we'll see where we
can start to pick other options and

334
00:16:13.290 --> 00:16:14.990
get a little more specific.

335
00:16:14.990 --> 00:16:17.460
It's asking where I want to
store my certificate request.

336
00:16:17.460 --> 00:16:21.610
We'll normally just put that on our
client access server or on our desktop,

337
00:16:21.610 --> 00:16:23.940
somewhere like that so
we can save that request.

338
00:16:23.940 --> 00:16:25.450
I'll store it on the cast server.

339
00:16:26.700 --> 00:16:28.790
And then it's gonna ask for
some additional information, right?

340
00:16:28.790 --> 00:16:30.090
What am I gonna use it for?

341
00:16:30.090 --> 00:16:31.810
And when you look at this screen,

342
00:16:31.810 --> 00:16:35.500
here's where we start to see the multiple
names our server might have, right?

343
00:16:35.500 --> 00:16:39.300
Looking at this, on the left side
I've got a list of services.

344
00:16:39.300 --> 00:16:42.000
And on the right side I've got
the domain name attached to them.

345
00:16:42.000 --> 00:16:45.980
And you'll see like Outlook Web App
is listed twice, right?

346
00:16:45.980 --> 00:16:46.580
Why twice?

347
00:16:46.580 --> 00:16:51.760
Well, one is when accessed from
the Intranet, my LAN clients.

348
00:16:51.760 --> 00:16:54.530
And the other is when accessed
from the Internet, right?

349
00:16:54.530 --> 00:16:56.620
From the WAN clients.

350
00:16:56.620 --> 00:17:00.700
And when people connect they might
connect with different names and

351
00:17:00.700 --> 00:17:03.060
so here is where we have
to square that away.

352
00:17:03.060 --> 00:17:08.560
For example, I might want my LAN clients
to connect to a server called lab-cas01,

353
00:17:08.560 --> 00:17:11.590
just a single name.

354
00:17:11.590 --> 00:17:12.400
Right?

355
00:17:12.400 --> 00:17:17.140
Or maybe it is lab dash cas01-itprotv.net.

356
00:17:17.140 --> 00:17:20.930
All right, but then on the WAN,
on the internet side,

357
00:17:20.930 --> 00:17:22.640
I want that server to be
called something different.

358
00:17:22.640 --> 00:17:27.020
I want it to be called
mail at itprotv.net.

359
00:17:27.020 --> 00:17:28.205
Different names.

360
00:17:28.205 --> 00:17:30.215
And that's very common to have that.

361
00:17:30.215 --> 00:17:31.465
One set of names internally.

362
00:17:31.465 --> 00:17:33.115
A different set of names externally.

363
00:17:33.115 --> 00:17:34.775
Or some kind of shared name,

364
00:17:34.775 --> 00:17:37.555
if we're doing like load-balancing
services or whatever.

365
00:17:37.555 --> 00:17:40.605
There might be a shared name that we're
using instead of this particular server.

366
00:17:40.605 --> 00:17:45.215
So, we can go through and edit these to
specify what we want that name to be for

367
00:17:45.215 --> 00:17:46.540
our clients to connect.

368
00:17:46.540 --> 00:17:47.100
All right.

369
00:17:47.100 --> 00:17:49.350
Now you can use the same name for
everything.

370
00:17:49.350 --> 00:17:53.380
I could just take this one name and copy
and paste it across all these guys, and

371
00:17:53.380 --> 00:17:56.370
then it's gonna be the same
everywhere across the board, right?

372
00:17:56.370 --> 00:17:59.020
And the advantage of doing
it that way is internal or

373
00:17:59.020 --> 00:18:01.520
external clients are always
set the same way.

374
00:18:01.520 --> 00:18:04.610
We just have to make sure that name can
resolve internally and externally, right?

375
00:18:04.610 --> 00:18:08.710
I need to be able to do this DNS look up
from my internal network as well as my

376
00:18:08.710 --> 00:18:09.550
external network.

377
00:18:09.550 --> 00:18:12.150
And I'm manually putting them in here.

378
00:18:12.150 --> 00:18:13.170
This is a habit of mine.

379
00:18:13.170 --> 00:18:14.560
I always do this manually.

380
00:18:14.560 --> 00:18:19.100
In reality if you leave the WAN one
empty then it just uses the WAN one, so

381
00:18:19.100 --> 00:18:22.560
it was actually already using this
setting, but I like to hard set it

382
00:18:22.560 --> 00:18:25.840
anyway just so that I'm certain because
there can be some confusion and

383
00:18:25.840 --> 00:18:27.870
it helps with troubleshooting later on.

384
00:18:27.870 --> 00:18:32.320
But also, you'll notice some differences
like this right here, Autodiscover.

385
00:18:32.320 --> 00:18:35.720
When somebody does Autodiscover
from the Internet,

386
00:18:35.720 --> 00:18:39.300
they're looking up
AutoDiscover.itprotv.net, right?

387
00:18:39.300 --> 00:18:42.670
A completely different name
than all the others, and

388
00:18:42.670 --> 00:18:44.600
we need to leave that be, right?

389
00:18:44.600 --> 00:18:47.710
Autodiscover first off it
looks to the active directory.

390
00:18:47.710 --> 00:18:50.490
If it can't find the active directory,
then it looks for DNS.

391
00:18:50.490 --> 00:18:52.740
And what it's looking for
in DNS is a record.

392
00:18:52.740 --> 00:18:57.790
Auto discover dot followed by
whatever your email domain name is.

393
00:18:57.790 --> 00:19:02.505
So if I say that my email is
jdoe@itprotv.net, it's gonna look for

394
00:19:02.505 --> 00:19:06.410
autodiscover.itprotv.net that's why
I've gotta have that entry in there.

395
00:19:06.410 --> 00:19:08.000
So I'm gonna leave that one be.

396
00:19:08.000 --> 00:19:10.960
But notice POP and
IMAP it gave them internal names,

397
00:19:10.960 --> 00:19:12.260
that's not terribly useful.

398
00:19:12.260 --> 00:19:14.520
So I'm gonna go ahead and change those so

399
00:19:14.520 --> 00:19:17.029
that they're mapped to that
publicly resolvable name.

400
00:19:19.050 --> 00:19:21.530
So now we'll get that nice and
squared down the list.

401
00:19:21.530 --> 00:19:23.030
And I'll do the same
with Outlook anywhere.

402
00:19:24.650 --> 00:19:27.960
And now we've got that same consistent
name being used across the board.

403
00:19:29.660 --> 00:19:34.070
On my next screen, now it's gonna
show me about my certificate.

404
00:19:34.070 --> 00:19:37.720
Notice how the certificate
has more than one name.

405
00:19:37.720 --> 00:19:40.730
In the old days when you
bought an SSL certificate,

406
00:19:40.730 --> 00:19:45.090
it just had one name www.itprotv.net or
something like that.

407
00:19:45.090 --> 00:19:48.890
But this server has more than one name.

408
00:19:48.890 --> 00:19:53.170
It has lab-cas01.itprotv.net and
it's got autodiscover.itprotv.net.

409
00:19:53.170 --> 00:19:55.760
And, technically, it's not showing
up here, but I'm gonna add it.

410
00:19:55.760 --> 00:19:58.790
It's got lab-cas01 by
itself with no domain.

411
00:19:58.790 --> 00:19:59.370
Right?
So

412
00:19:59.370 --> 00:20:02.470
these are all different
names this one server has.

413
00:20:02.470 --> 00:20:07.010
Well, if I buy a certificate with
one domain and somebody connects on

414
00:20:07.010 --> 00:20:10.280
a different domain, they're going to get a
certificate error, and we don't want that.

415
00:20:10.280 --> 00:20:12.750
Auto discover does not
like certificate errors.

416
00:20:12.750 --> 00:20:15.130
We've got to make sure our
certificates are on the up and up.

417
00:20:15.130 --> 00:20:18.390
Fortunately, almost every
certification vendor our there

418
00:20:18.390 --> 00:20:22.550
supports what are called subject
alternative names, sans.

419
00:20:22.550 --> 00:20:23.680
So when you buy a certificate,

420
00:20:23.680 --> 00:20:27.300
it has one primary name,
that's the first one on the list.

421
00:20:27.300 --> 00:20:29.950
And then all the others
are alternative names.

422
00:20:29.950 --> 00:20:32.140
Other names somebody might
use when they connect.

423
00:20:32.140 --> 00:20:36.780
It's important that your certificate has
all of the names of your server listed

424
00:20:36.780 --> 00:20:40.130
in order to avoid certificate errors,
so I'm gonna add those in.

425
00:20:40.130 --> 00:20:44.200
Now there is one more here itprotv.net,
and that's because when

426
00:20:44.200 --> 00:20:49.390
autodiscover does the lookup against the
DNS, the first thing it actually looks for

427
00:20:49.390 --> 00:20:52.710
is your domain,
forward slash auto discover, right?

428
00:20:52.710 --> 00:20:55.440
And that's assuming that you
have your root domain pointed at

429
00:20:55.440 --> 00:20:58.290
a client access server
which almost nobody does.

430
00:20:58.290 --> 00:21:00.020
So, that really doesn't get hit.

431
00:21:00.020 --> 00:21:03.770
And then it moves on to the next one
which is autodiscover.itprotv,net and

432
00:21:03.770 --> 00:21:05.649
that's why it's got both
of those entries in there.

433
00:21:07.200 --> 00:21:09.300
All right.
So I'm gonna leave that be and

434
00:21:09.300 --> 00:21:12.760
I'll move forward on that and now we can
start to punch in the information for

435
00:21:12.760 --> 00:21:14.470
our certificate to request it.

436
00:21:14.470 --> 00:21:19.670
Now, when this is done, it's gonna
be doing the request against, well,

437
00:21:19.670 --> 00:21:20.630
a public server somewhere.

438
00:21:20.630 --> 00:21:26.110
It's gonna generate a CSR, a Certificate
of Request and we can take that CSR and

439
00:21:26.110 --> 00:21:28.570
send it up to whoever it is we're
buying a certificate from and

440
00:21:28.570 --> 00:21:31.300
they'll sell you the certificate, and then
you come back here and you load it in.

441
00:21:32.360 --> 00:21:35.580
That's the process, and if you've watched
our server episodes where we show

442
00:21:35.580 --> 00:21:38.390
setting up a public key infrastructure,
you guys have seen that before,

443
00:21:38.390 --> 00:21:41.810
but that's the basic process of
getting that certificate in.

444
00:21:41.810 --> 00:21:44.790
So here we just finish filling this
out and then we go and pay some money.

445
00:21:45.910 --> 00:21:50.370
If I'm using the self-signed certificate,
though, how do I edit this stuff?

446
00:21:50.370 --> 00:21:52.970
Well, if we're doing
the self-sign certificate,

447
00:21:52.970 --> 00:21:56.650
you can actually modify that right up
here under our virtual directories.

448
00:21:56.650 --> 00:21:58.650
If you choose virtual directories,

449
00:21:58.650 --> 00:22:01.690
you'll see the web addresses that
are being used for everything.

450
00:22:01.690 --> 00:22:03.040
For Outlook web app, for

451
00:22:03.040 --> 00:22:06.520
the Exchange control panel,
now the exchange administration center.

452
00:22:06.520 --> 00:22:08.700
You'll see ActiveSync,
the offline address book,

453
00:22:08.700 --> 00:22:10.980
all these different things right here.

00:22:10.980 --> 00:22:13.600
And if you click
the little wrench up here,

455
00:22:13.600 --> 00:22:18.130
this will let you configure those
external client access domain names.

456
00:22:18.130 --> 00:22:18.780
And so we can say,

457
00:22:18.780 --> 00:22:22.580
when somebody connects, here's the address
they're gonna be connecting to.

458
00:22:22.580 --> 00:22:23.630
And it says right here,

459
00:22:23.630 --> 00:22:27.030
select the client access servers
that people will be connecting to.

460
00:22:27.030 --> 00:22:29.040
And what the external domain is.

461
00:22:29.040 --> 00:22:31.470
So this is kinda the counterpart
to the certificate.

462
00:22:31.470 --> 00:22:35.360
We've gotta fill this out too so
that our servers know to listen.

463
00:22:35.360 --> 00:22:38.120
I might have ten different
client access servers.

464
00:22:38.120 --> 00:22:41.340
But I only want two of them to
be connected to the Internet.

00:22:41.340 --> 00:22:45.090
And so I would come in here and hit the +
sign and just add the two that I wanted.

466
00:22:45.090 --> 00:22:47.160
Now I've only got one so I'll add that in.

467
00:22:47.160 --> 00:22:49.670
But, if I had ten, I would just
pick the two that I wanted, and

468
00:22:49.670 --> 00:22:53.160
add them to that list, and then here
I would give them the public name.

469
00:22:53.160 --> 00:22:56.890
Now, if I have two client access servers,
I might be load balancing across them, so

470
00:22:56.890 --> 00:22:58.780
I'll have one shared name between them.

471
00:22:58.780 --> 00:23:00.360
I've only got one, though, so

472
00:23:00.360 --> 00:23:05.450
I can put in the individual name of
that server, and there we've got it set.

473
00:23:06.580 --> 00:23:11.040
And now it's gonna tie that in, and now my
system will now when somebody connects,

474
00:23:11.040 --> 00:23:12.390
this is the name they're connecting to.

475
00:23:12.390 --> 00:23:16.280
My certificate should match that,
it should have that name attached to it.

476
00:23:16.280 --> 00:23:19.080
And if it doesn't,
well we'll need to go and correct that.

477
00:23:19.080 --> 00:23:21.240
So I'm gonna give that a moment
while it updates that.

478
00:23:21.240 --> 00:23:23.490
Now, what's it doing in the background.

479
00:23:23.490 --> 00:23:26.540
In the background, it's reaching
out to the Client Access Server and

00:23:26.540 --> 00:23:28.110
it's reaching out to the Active Directory.

481
00:23:28.110 --> 00:23:30.960
And it's populating the fields
with that domain name to say

00:23:30.960 --> 00:23:34.570
here's the new name that we're gonna
use when people connect externally.

483
00:23:34.570 --> 00:23:36.530
And now when Auto Discover runs,

484
00:23:36.530 --> 00:23:38.930
that's the name that they're gonna
learn when they try and connect.

485
00:23:38.930 --> 00:23:41.770
So we'll give that a moment
while it turns alarm.

486
00:23:41.770 --> 00:23:44.920
Now after that's done,
if I used a self signed cert,

487
00:23:44.920 --> 00:23:46.950
I'll need to make sure it's
got the right names in it.

488
00:23:46.950 --> 00:23:48.030
It should.

489
00:23:48.030 --> 00:23:51.270
We can actually cheat a little bit
double check this while that's running.

490
00:23:51.270 --> 00:23:53.900
If I come back here and take a look
at the certificate that I've got, oh,

491
00:23:53.900 --> 00:23:54.490
it just finished.

492
00:23:54.490 --> 00:23:55.420
So I'll close that out.

493
00:23:56.450 --> 00:23:58.555
there we go.
We can take a look at the certificate I

494
00:23:58.555 --> 00:24:02.839
had issued before and if we edit that one,
this is the self-signed certificate it

495
00:24:02.839 --> 00:24:06.707
had installed and I can see that it
does have lab/casso.itprotv.net.

496
00:24:06.707 --> 00:24:10.250
But, shoot, I thought I was going to
be able to use this certificate, but

497
00:24:10.250 --> 00:24:12.320
I'm missing something aren't I?

498
00:24:12.320 --> 00:24:14.970
I'm missing autodiscover that itprotv.net.

499
00:24:14.970 --> 00:24:17.160
So, I actually can't use my
self-assigned certificate,

500
00:24:17.160 --> 00:24:19.030
so I'm going to have some problems there.

501
00:24:19.030 --> 00:24:22.800
So, what I need to do is issue a new
self-assigned certificate to fix that

502
00:24:22.800 --> 00:24:23.460
on my server.

503
00:24:23.460 --> 00:24:25.688
So, I'll do a new self-assigned cert,

504
00:24:25.688 --> 00:24:29.610
which is really just about the same
as issuing a true certificate.

505
00:24:29.610 --> 00:24:33.260
The only difference is that part where
we upload our request to a provider and

506
00:24:33.260 --> 00:24:34.560
pay for it, we don't do that.

507
00:24:34.560 --> 00:24:36.970
Instead, our server just
issues the certificate.

508
00:24:36.970 --> 00:24:40.230
So, I'll call this my,
you know, new self-signed cert.

509
00:24:41.570 --> 00:24:42.680
And I'm gonna add in

510
00:24:44.200 --> 00:24:47.910
the server I'm attaching this
to which is just LabCass 01.

511
00:24:47.910 --> 00:24:50.550
And then I'm gonna have
to update my names.

512
00:24:50.550 --> 00:24:52.700
And see it remembered all the names
from where I filled them out earlier.

513
00:24:52.700 --> 00:24:54.490
So it's got all that information in there.

514
00:24:54.490 --> 00:24:56.150
Actually, it didn't
remember these last two.

515
00:24:56.150 --> 00:24:57.850
So let me update those.

516
00:24:57.850 --> 00:25:00.970
I'm not using POP or IMAP anyway,
so I'm not too worried about it.

517
00:25:00.970 --> 00:25:04.310
But still, it's best to have it correct
because otherwise you'll have a problem

518
00:25:04.310 --> 00:25:06.430
down the road and
you won't remember where this was.

519
00:25:06.430 --> 00:25:08.450
So, we'll just go in and update that.

520
00:25:09.720 --> 00:25:11.320
And then we'll be in good shape.

521
00:25:13.120 --> 00:25:17.140
All right, so once I've got that, it's
got the names, there's the server name.

522
00:25:17.140 --> 00:25:19.790
Autodiscover is in there,
the domain name is in there.

523
00:25:19.790 --> 00:25:22.790
I might go ahead and choose to add in the
single name, just to be on the safe side.

524
00:25:22.790 --> 00:25:23.980
Even though nobody should be using that.

525
00:25:23.980 --> 00:25:26.900
I'll punch it in and
then I'll finish that up.

526
00:25:26.900 --> 00:25:31.080
Now, if I were doing the other stiffy
request, this would generate a request

527
00:25:31.080 --> 00:25:34.540
that I would upload, pay and
then download the response.

528
00:25:34.540 --> 00:25:38.470
Here, since it's self signed, it just
automatically approves it and there it is.

529
00:25:38.470 --> 00:25:40.930
There's my new self signed cert.

530
00:25:40.930 --> 00:25:42.490
But if I look at the services down here,

531
00:25:42.490 --> 00:25:44.630
see how it's only attached to IMAP and
POP?

532
00:25:44.630 --> 00:25:46.950
So it's not attached everywhere yet.

533
00:25:46.950 --> 00:25:48.900
So I need to edit that.

534
00:25:48.900 --> 00:25:52.180
And when I go into this I'll
see services on the left and

535
00:25:52.180 --> 00:25:53.910
here's where I can attach
to everything else.

536
00:25:53.910 --> 00:25:58.800
And I'm gonna attach it to to SMTP,
IMAP, POP and ISS I'm not using unified

537
00:25:58.800 --> 00:26:01.850
messaging, but it wouldn't hurt to
go ahead and attach it to that also.

538
00:26:01.850 --> 00:26:05.130
And now that's the certificate I'm
using across the board for this server.

539
00:26:05.130 --> 00:26:05.940
All right?

540
00:26:05.940 --> 00:26:07.260
And let's see.

541
00:26:07.260 --> 00:26:09.690
Oh, it's warning me about unified
messaging cuz I'm not actually using it,

542
00:26:09.690 --> 00:26:10.475
so I'll turn that off.

543
00:26:10.475 --> 00:26:11.460
[LAUGH] There we go.

544
00:26:11.460 --> 00:26:14.080
That's what I get for
trying to be complete.

545
00:26:14.080 --> 00:26:16.700
All right, so
it's asking me if I'm sure that I wanna

546
00:26:16.700 --> 00:26:19.010
override the existing certificate,
and I am.

547
00:26:19.010 --> 00:26:19.660
I'll override it.

548
00:26:21.530 --> 00:26:22.660
And then we should be in business.

549
00:26:24.120 --> 00:26:28.770
So once that's done, there we go, now
I've got the new certificate in place and

550
00:26:28.770 --> 00:26:29.710
I should be ready to rock.

551
00:26:29.710 --> 00:26:34.010
Now when somebody fires up Outlook and
goes to connect, Autodiscover's gonna run,

552
00:26:34.010 --> 00:26:37.590
it's gonna see that cert and
that name and it's gonna move from there.

553
00:26:37.590 --> 00:26:40.350
Now we already saw that, whoops,

554
00:26:40.350 --> 00:26:43.120
we already saw that with our user JDoe,
right?

555
00:26:43.120 --> 00:26:44.920
If I switch back over to JDoe, or

556
00:26:44.920 --> 00:26:50.300
John Doe,
he was the one who auto configured, right?

557
00:26:50.300 --> 00:26:52.540
He did auto discovery,
he found the server and he connected.

558
00:26:52.540 --> 00:26:55.690
Now how do I actually know that worked?

559
00:26:55.690 --> 00:26:56.300
It's all hidden.

560
00:26:56.300 --> 00:26:57.530
It's all in the background, right?

561
00:26:57.530 --> 00:26:58.870
So how do we know what happened?

562
00:26:58.870 --> 00:27:01.920
Well, there's actually a neat
little feature that we can use

563
00:27:01.920 --> 00:27:02.870
that's a hidden feature.

564
00:27:02.870 --> 00:27:04.480
So, I wanna show you guys this one.

565
00:27:04.480 --> 00:27:05.860
My head's covering it up though.

566
00:27:05.860 --> 00:27:09.070
Can we get my computer full screen for
a second?

567
00:27:09.070 --> 00:27:13.550
So down in the bottom right corner in
our taskbar, we've got our clock and

568
00:27:13.550 --> 00:27:14.629
our other little items.

569
00:27:15.680 --> 00:27:19.480
And what you'll see down here is that
Outlook actually has its own little system

570
00:27:19.480 --> 00:27:20.670
tray icon.

571
00:27:20.670 --> 00:27:22.060
And in that system tray,

572
00:27:22.060 --> 00:27:24.100
if you right-click on it,
you've got some options, right?

573
00:27:24.100 --> 00:27:26.480
And there's nothing too fancy in here.

574
00:27:26.480 --> 00:27:30.620
But if you hold down
control on your keyboard,

575
00:27:30.620 --> 00:27:33.560
when you right-click you'll
actually see some hidden options.

576
00:27:33.560 --> 00:27:37.360
So I'm gonna hold Control and
right-click on that Outlook icon.

577
00:27:37.360 --> 00:27:43.910
And notice how I've got connection status,
and test email auto configuration.

578
00:27:43.910 --> 00:27:47.260
That is what's gonna let
us see the auto discover.

579
00:27:47.260 --> 00:27:50.740
So when we click on that, it's gonna
launch this window and here I can type in

580
00:27:50.740 --> 00:27:54.930
anybody's email address, and we'll be
able to see what's going on there.

581
00:27:54.930 --> 00:27:58.850
So, when I come in and I type in J Doe and
I punch in his password,

582
00:27:58.850 --> 00:28:02.240
cuz it's actually gonna try and connect,
I could do my account and try mine.

583
00:28:02.240 --> 00:28:06.830
We can hit task and it's gonna test out
auto discover and see if it's working.

584
00:28:06.830 --> 00:28:11.730
And it's gonna give us detailed feedback,
so that people can see what's going on and

585
00:28:11.730 --> 00:28:12.490
get that information.

586
00:28:12.490 --> 00:28:13.920
This is normally hidden.

587
00:28:13.920 --> 00:28:14.800
It's all in the background.

588
00:28:14.800 --> 00:28:15.740
We don't see it.

589
00:28:15.740 --> 00:28:18.440
This is gonna test it out and
give us that information.

590
00:28:18.440 --> 00:28:21.080
So, if we give it just a second
it's running through that process.

591
00:28:21.080 --> 00:28:23.160
It should be seeing our new certificate.

592
00:28:23.160 --> 00:28:25.340
And it'll let us know if it's working or
not.

593
00:28:25.340 --> 00:28:28.310
If it fails, we know we need to
troubleshoot it and fortunately,

594
00:28:28.310 --> 00:28:31.490
it'll give us information
as to what to troubleshoot.

595
00:28:31.490 --> 00:28:35.130
Now it's doing a lot more that
just basic auto discover.

596
00:28:35.130 --> 00:28:38.000
What it's doing is it's running
through all of the different types of

597
00:28:38.000 --> 00:28:38.650
auto discover.

598
00:28:38.650 --> 00:28:41.890
It's testing port connectivity seeing
if it can reach out to the server.

599
00:28:41.890 --> 00:28:43.550
It's checking all of that.

600
00:28:43.550 --> 00:28:46.180
So that's why it's saying it may
take up to a minute we just have to

601
00:28:46.180 --> 00:28:46.790
give it some time.

602
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:50.640
And then when it's done we'll be
able to see the log file output.

603
00:28:50.640 --> 00:28:52.250
And you can actually look
at some of it right now.

604
00:28:52.250 --> 00:28:53.770
See how it's reaching out?

605
00:28:53.770 --> 00:28:58.710
And it's reaching out in my case to
mail.itprotv.net for IMAP for some reason.

606
00:28:58.710 --> 00:29:01.270
And then we'll see pop.itprotv.net,

607
00:29:01.270 --> 00:29:05.680
and a few others as it's reaching out
trying to find these different servers.

608
00:29:05.680 --> 00:29:09.900
And at the end of the day, this is
the one I'm looking for right here.

609
00:29:09.900 --> 00:29:11.150
Attempting URL.

610
00:29:11.150 --> 00:29:13.000
It's looking for auto discover, and

611
00:29:13.000 --> 00:29:17.970
see how it looks for
lab-caso1.itprotv.net/autodiscover.

612
00:29:17.970 --> 00:29:23.040
It's looking for that folder on my client
access server and it's connected to it and

613
00:29:23.040 --> 00:29:26.000
then it's gonna start
responding back with answers.

614
00:29:26.000 --> 00:29:29.030
Here it's trying to connect via POP and
IMAP, and these are all failing.

615
00:29:29.030 --> 00:29:31.320
See how these are all failed,
failed, failed failed failed?

616
00:29:31.320 --> 00:29:35.670
Well, POP and
IMAP are disabled in Exchange by default.

617
00:29:35.670 --> 00:29:39.760
When we connect we need to either
connect via MAPI, the old way, or

618
00:29:39.760 --> 00:29:42.070
by RCP over HTTP which is that new way.

619
00:29:42.070 --> 00:29:46.840
And so I do expect to see failures, but
I also expect to see some successes.

620
00:29:46.840 --> 00:29:48.700
SMTP is succeeding.

621
00:29:48.700 --> 00:29:50.680
We are able to connect with SMTP.

622
00:29:50.680 --> 00:29:53.630
And then we should be
connected to our mailbox also.

623
00:29:53.630 --> 00:29:56.990
So all this is kinda going on, where we
can see that information right here and

624
00:29:56.990 --> 00:29:57.890
use it for troubleshooting.

625
00:30:00.210 --> 00:30:04.265
Well, what we've seen right here is
the basic functions of AutoDiscover.

626
00:30:04.265 --> 00:30:08.585
Discover and how it works out of
the box but there's a lot more to it.

627
00:30:08.585 --> 00:30:11.085
We still need to see how it
looks from the Internet, but

628
00:30:11.085 --> 00:30:13.505
I'm kind of running a little
short on time on this episode.

629
00:30:13.505 --> 00:30:16.385
So we're gonna have to do a part two on
this to take a look at the Internet side

630
00:30:16.385 --> 00:30:18.895
of getting connected to
an auto discover server.

631
00:30:18.895 --> 00:30:21.545
So, in this episode,
we got a chance to see auto discover.

632
00:30:21.545 --> 00:30:23.735
We saw what it does, we say how it works.

633
00:30:23.735 --> 00:30:26.535
We talked about a little bit about
the certificate, and the issues we can run

634
00:30:26.535 --> 00:30:29.730
into there and how we might have to
generate some of our own certificates.

635
00:30:29.730 --> 00:30:34.570
And we got to see how to troubleshoot it
using the little hidden away test for

636
00:30:34.570 --> 00:30:36.700
autodiscover inside of Microsoft Outlook.

637
00:30:36.700 --> 00:30:39.450
But stay tuned because in episode two
we're going to look at getting our

638
00:30:39.450 --> 00:30:40.520
internet users connecting.

639
00:30:40.520 --> 00:30:43.220
Here this was a local area user,
somebody joined to the domain and

640
00:30:43.220 --> 00:30:44.470
that was the easy one.

641
00:30:44.470 --> 00:30:46.680
It's the ones that are outside,
the ones that are external.

642
00:30:46.680 --> 00:30:47.830
They're the hard ones.

643
00:30:47.830 --> 00:30:50.500
And so we're gonna get a chance to see
that when somebody connects in and

644
00:30:50.500 --> 00:30:52.570
some of the stuff we have to
do to get that squared away.

645
00:30:52.570 --> 00:30:53.500
So stay tuned for that.

646
00:30:53.500 --> 00:30:56.490
But for this episode,
signing off for ITProTV.

647
00:30:56.490 --> 00:30:58.999
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

648
00:30:58.999 --> 00:31:03.143
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to the Autodiscover episode. In the last episode, Don demonstrated LAN connectivity. In this episode, he demonstrates configuring Autodiscover for external clients. He ends the episode demonstrating the MailTips feature in Exchange 2013.
episodes.title: Autodiscover Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.037 --> 00:00:10.712
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.712 --> 00:00:11.536
All right.

3
00:00:11.536 --> 00:00:12.220
Good morning.

4
00:00:12.220 --> 00:00:13.591
Good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:13.591 --> 00:00:16.070
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.070 --> 00:00:17.980
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:17.980 --> 00:00:21.820
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

8
00:00:21.820 --> 00:00:24.430
And in fact,
back again with more Auto Discover.

9
00:00:24.430 --> 00:00:27.920
This is part two of our Microsoft
exchange Auto Discover episodes and

10
00:00:27.920 --> 00:00:32.430
we're gonna be taking a look at the latter
half of the Auto Discover service.

11
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:35.840
In our first episode we got a chance to
see Auto Discover from the perspective of

12
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:36.840
internal clients,

13
00:00:36.840 --> 00:00:41.350
from our land clients, our machines that
are joined to our Active Directory domain.

14
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:44.210
But what about clients that
aren't a part of our domain?

15
00:00:44.210 --> 00:00:47.060
What if somebody's on their own
personal computer at home or

16
00:00:47.060 --> 00:00:51.150
they're on their Android, or IOS, or
Windows Mobile phone, and it's not

17
00:00:51.150 --> 00:00:55.000
connected to our systems at all, and they
want Auto Discover to work there, also.

18
00:00:55.000 --> 00:00:57.550
All right, well, there's a few
things that we're gonna have to do.

19
00:00:57.550 --> 00:01:01.480
First off, when Auto Discover runs,
the first thing it does is look for

20
00:01:01.480 --> 00:01:03.110
is your Active Directory information.

21
00:01:03.110 --> 00:01:04.270
And for these types of clients.

22
00:01:04.270 --> 00:01:06.350
For external clients that doesn't exist.

23
00:01:06.350 --> 00:01:09.800
So step two, they look to DNS.

24
00:01:09.800 --> 00:01:11.940
They look to DNS and they're looking for

25
00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:15.710
one of two records that tell them
where to find Auto Discover.

26
00:01:15.710 --> 00:01:18.970
And it doesn't matter which of the two
because neither of them exist by default.

27
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:21.030
We've got to create them
if we want that to work.

28
00:01:21.030 --> 00:01:21.710
All right.

29
00:01:21.710 --> 00:01:25.540
So what you need to do is, you need to
think about your user's e-mail addresses.

30
00:01:25.540 --> 00:01:30.050
Now in the first part I showed you guys
logging in with the domain user and

31
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:31.810
I fired up Outlook.

32
00:01:31.810 --> 00:01:36.270
And you probably saw there where Outlook,
it figured out the person's name,

33
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:37.650
it figured out their e-mail address,

34
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:40.620
all we had to do was click next
a few times and we were configured.

35
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:41.220
All right?

36
00:01:41.220 --> 00:01:44.240
Let's watch that same process here for
an external use.r So

37
00:01:44.240 --> 00:01:48.722
here I am on a workstation that
has a crazy background, but

38
00:01:48.722 --> 00:01:51.570
[LAUGH] here I'm on a workstation for
Jane Doe.

39
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:53.002
And apparently Jane really likes fish.

40
00:01:53.002 --> 00:01:55.900
So [LAUGH] got all sorts
of aquatic stuff here.

41
00:01:55.900 --> 00:02:00.910
But if I take a look at her computer,
we can see that it's a LAB client,

42
00:02:00.910 --> 00:02:02.320
but it's in WORKGROUP.

43
00:02:02.320 --> 00:02:02.860
Work group.

44
00:02:02.860 --> 00:02:04.390
She's not joined to the domain.

45
00:02:04.390 --> 00:02:07.570
So she's an external user,
she's at home, she fires up Outlook,

46
00:02:07.570 --> 00:02:08.640
she's not joined to a domain.

47
00:02:08.640 --> 00:02:09.960
What's she gonna get?

48
00:02:09.960 --> 00:02:12.110
Well Outlook is gonna fire up.

49
00:02:12.110 --> 00:02:13.450
And if this is the first time,

50
00:02:13.450 --> 00:02:16.280
it's gonna offer to set her
up with a new profile, right?

51
00:02:16.280 --> 00:02:18.640
And it's gonna say, do you want
to connect to an e-mail account?

52
00:02:18.640 --> 00:02:22.410
And when she hits Next,
if we were joined in the Active Directory,

53
00:02:22.410 --> 00:02:25.750
this would auto populate with
your name and e-mail address and

54
00:02:25.750 --> 00:02:28.440
you'd click Next, but
now it's just sitting here.

55
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:31.770
All right, it's sitting here because as
an external user it has no way of knowing.

56
00:02:31.770 --> 00:02:33.505
It doesn't know what your
e-mail address is and

57
00:02:33.505 --> 00:02:35.848
it can't look in the Active Directory for
it so we have to tell it.

58
00:02:35.848 --> 00:02:40.321
So she's gonna come in here and
put her information, and so,

59
00:02:40.321 --> 00:02:44.449
you know, if her email account
is set up for Jane Smith and

60
00:02:44.449 --> 00:02:48.418
her email address is jsmith@itprotv.net,
right?

61
00:02:48.418 --> 00:02:51.670
And you're going to punch that in and what
our password is, you'll punch that in.

62
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:55.800
All right, now it is asking for
information, the user has to provide

63
00:02:55.800 --> 00:02:59.100
information but, this is all
information that your user should have.

64
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:02.120
They know their name, hopefully,
they know their e-mail address, and

65
00:03:02.120 --> 00:03:03.330
they know their password.

66
00:03:03.330 --> 00:03:07.910
So it's not like we're asking them for
a server URL or port numbers or

67
00:03:07.910 --> 00:03:11.530
any of the crazy stuff the users don't
know, this is information they do know.

68
00:03:11.530 --> 00:03:15.612
And when we hit Next, what's going to
happen is Outlook is going to say,

69
00:03:15.612 --> 00:03:18.050
all right I'm not joining the Active
Directory, so I have to skip step one and

70
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:19.660
I'm going to go to step two.

71
00:03:19.660 --> 00:03:21.460
Step two is look to DNS.

72
00:03:21.460 --> 00:03:23.130
And it's going to take your domain name.

73
00:03:23.130 --> 00:03:24.720
My domain name here is itprotv.net.

74
00:03:24.720 --> 00:03:27.210
It's going to take that domain name,
and it's going to look for

75
00:03:27.210 --> 00:03:31.770
a server at itprotv.net, and on that
server it's going to look for a folder.

76
00:03:31.770 --> 00:03:37.340
It's basically going to do a secure web
connection, https on tcp port 443 and

77
00:03:37.340 --> 00:03:41.420
it's gonna look for
ITProTV.net/autodiscover all right?

78
00:03:41.420 --> 00:03:45.210
And then inside of there
/autodiscover.xml it's gonna look for

79
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:47.320
that file to get configuration, all right.

80
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:52.045
Now very few people actually have a
non-web server sitting at this address and

81
00:03:52.045 --> 00:03:55.095
you definitely don't have exchange servers
sitting there on a normal environment.

82
00:03:55.095 --> 00:03:57.495
So, that's not always gonna work for us.

83
00:03:57.495 --> 00:04:01.425
Maybe if our e-mail domain is
specifically for e-mail, but

84
00:04:01.425 --> 00:04:02.925
most people don't have that.

85
00:04:02.925 --> 00:04:06.305
So, after that one fails it's
gonna go to the second effort.

86
00:04:06.305 --> 00:04:12.020
And the second effort is to look for
autodiscover.itprotv.net.

87
00:04:12.020 --> 00:04:14.652
So I need to make sure that for
my users out there on the Internet,

88
00:04:14.652 --> 00:04:19.560
auto discover.itprotv.net has to resolve
to one my client access servers.

89
00:04:19.560 --> 00:04:21.080
And there's a really easy way to do that.

90
00:04:21.080 --> 00:04:22.320
Let me show you.

91
00:04:22.320 --> 00:04:24.060
I'm gonna jump over to one
of my domain controllers.

92
00:04:24.060 --> 00:04:25.330
And this is where I'm running DNS.

93
00:04:25.330 --> 00:04:28.200
Now, you might be running
DNS on your own servers.

94
00:04:28.200 --> 00:04:31.902
You might be running it on
an external service like GoDaddy or

95
00:04:31.902 --> 00:04:37.266
Register.com, Hover.com,
one of those guys, it doesn't matter.

96
00:04:37.266 --> 00:04:40.440
Whoever it is that's hosting your DNS,
you go to that server and

97
00:04:40.440 --> 00:04:43.330
you find your forward lookup zone for
your network.

98
00:04:43.330 --> 00:04:48.202
So mine was itprotv.net and
what we need to do is add in a record for

99
00:04:48.202 --> 00:04:49.730
Auto Discover.

100
00:04:49.730 --> 00:04:53.230
Now you could add an A-record in there,
but I typically don't.

101
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:57.610
The reason is we normally already have
a record for our client access server and

102
00:04:57.610 --> 00:04:59.310
there's no reason you can't reuse that.

103
00:04:59.310 --> 00:05:04.070
We can just do an alias that
says autodiscover.itprotv.net

104
00:05:04.070 --> 00:05:05.990
points to this already existing server.

105
00:05:05.990 --> 00:05:06.900
All right?

106
00:05:06.900 --> 00:05:10.520
And the way you do that in DNS is
with a CNAME or a canonical name.

107
00:05:10.520 --> 00:05:12.470
So I'm gonna right click
here on itprotv.net,

108
00:05:12.470 --> 00:05:16.600
and I'll do a new alias which is a CNAME.

109
00:05:16.600 --> 00:05:19.450
And my alias is just
gonna be autodiscover.

110
00:05:19.450 --> 00:05:20.655
And see what it's filling in for me?

111
00:05:20.655 --> 00:05:23.760
Autodiscover.itprotv.net, right?

112
00:05:23.760 --> 00:05:26.500
That's what these clients
are gonna be looking for.

113
00:05:26.500 --> 00:05:30.820
And all I have to do is point that at
any one of my client access servers.

114
00:05:30.820 --> 00:05:31.960
Well, I shouldn't say it that way.

115
00:05:31.960 --> 00:05:33.520
Not any client access server.

116
00:05:33.520 --> 00:05:36.810
It's gotta be a client access server
that's accessible from the Internet.

117
00:05:36.810 --> 00:05:39.030
You might have ten client access servers.

118
00:05:39.030 --> 00:05:41.150
But only two are accessible
from the Internet.

119
00:05:41.150 --> 00:05:44.670
So I need this to point to one of those
guys that's exposed to the Internet.

120
00:05:44.670 --> 00:05:47.360
And if I'm doing load balancing on it,
then I would want to point to the load

121
00:05:47.360 --> 00:05:50.410
balancing virtual name,
not the physical names of the servers.

122
00:05:50.410 --> 00:05:53.250
So there's different places
you might point this.

123
00:05:53.250 --> 00:05:57.760
But at a minimum, you need to point it
to one of your Client Access Servers.

124
00:05:57.760 --> 00:06:00.960
So I'm gonna find my lab-caso1.

125
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:02.980
And I'll say okay to that.

126
00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:03.550
All right.

127
00:06:03.550 --> 00:06:10.045
So now autodiscover.itprotv.net is
pointing to lab-cas01.itprotv.net.

128
00:06:10.045 --> 00:06:14.410
Now the advantage of doing CNAME is if
I ever want to change that server's IP,

129
00:06:14.410 --> 00:06:17.630
I can just go and
change lab-cas01's IP, and

130
00:06:17.630 --> 00:06:19.930
the alias points in the new IP,
you're done.

131
00:06:19.930 --> 00:06:23.970
If I had done an A-record instead,
anytime I change the cast IP I would

132
00:06:23.970 --> 00:06:27.180
have to go and change the A-record for
the Auto Discover's IP also.

133
00:06:27.180 --> 00:06:29.110
I'd have to change it in two places and

134
00:06:29.110 --> 00:06:31.600
the odds are we'll forget,
things break and you got problems.

135
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:33.450
So it's always better
to do a CNAME if can.

136
00:06:34.460 --> 00:06:38.740
But now if there's an external client
that's trying to resolve this,

137
00:06:38.740 --> 00:06:41.800
they'll actually be able to find it and
they'll get the client access server.

138
00:06:41.800 --> 00:06:45.639
And we can test that out right from our
client if we fire up a command prompt.

139
00:06:46.650 --> 00:06:49.680
And let me just boost up that font
size a little bit so we can see it.

140
00:06:52.000 --> 00:06:57.630
And they can just do a quick NS lookup
of autodiscover.itprotv.net and

141
00:06:57.630 --> 00:07:02.170
see if it resolves.

142
00:07:02.170 --> 00:07:05.690
And I can see that it's an alias
that's pointing to lab-cas01

143
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:08.840
that resolves to 192.168.0.12.

144
00:07:08.840 --> 00:07:11.560
And, so there is no server at
auto discover.itvpro.net, but

145
00:07:11.560 --> 00:07:13.240
this points us to it.

146
00:07:13.240 --> 00:07:16.950
And, so now we can get there, and
we should be able to resolve that,

147
00:07:16.950 --> 00:07:19.920
assuming the client accessor
is exposed to the Internet.

148
00:07:19.920 --> 00:07:22.510
Now, when I say exposed to the Internet,
what do we mean?

149
00:07:22.510 --> 00:07:25.590
At a minimum, just for
Auto Discover to work.

150
00:07:25.590 --> 00:07:28.140
We need TCP port 443, right?

151
00:07:28.140 --> 00:07:29.570
Secure HTTP traffic.

152
00:07:29.570 --> 00:07:30.130
That's what we need.

153
00:07:30.130 --> 00:07:30.650
We need that open.

154
00:07:30.650 --> 00:07:32.130
Right?
You're gonna need that for

155
00:07:32.130 --> 00:07:34.430
Outlook web access or Outlook web app.

156
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:36.300
You're gonna need it for
the offline address book.

157
00:07:36.300 --> 00:07:38.180
You're gonna need it for
the exchange control panel.

158
00:07:38.180 --> 00:07:40.070
So, you're gonna need
that port open anyway.

159
00:07:40.070 --> 00:07:43.150
So, on a client access
server at a minimum.

160
00:07:43.150 --> 00:07:46.560
We need that 443 open, TCP port 443 for
people to be able to connect.

161
00:07:46.560 --> 00:07:50.010
And that's going to make Auto Discover,
Outlook Web Ap, all those other ones,

162
00:07:50.010 --> 00:07:52.140
it's going to make them all work,
all right.

163
00:07:52.140 --> 00:07:54.160
But there's a few other services
we need to be aware of.

164
00:07:54.160 --> 00:07:57.720
When you're configuring that client access
server to be exposed to the iInternet

165
00:07:57.720 --> 00:07:59.050
you may wanna configure a few more.

166
00:07:59.050 --> 00:08:00.960
And I'll post all these
with the show notes.

167
00:08:00.960 --> 00:08:02.590
But let me just show you right here.

168
00:08:02.590 --> 00:08:06.360
These are the ports that we want to
make available from the Internet for

169
00:08:06.360 --> 00:08:07.930
different services.

170
00:08:07.930 --> 00:08:09.710
So for example, SMTP.

171
00:08:09.710 --> 00:08:13.830
You're incoming and
outgoing email uses S/SMTP.

172
00:08:13.830 --> 00:08:17.310
So if this client access server's going
to be that point of entry, we're going

173
00:08:17.310 --> 00:08:22.490
to need to have port 25 open for
non-secure and port 587 open for secure.

174
00:08:22.490 --> 00:08:25.820
Your clients, right like Outlook,
they'll use that 587,

175
00:08:25.820 --> 00:08:29.675
they'll use that secure connection,
but servers when they're moving

176
00:08:29.675 --> 00:08:31.933
e-mail back and forth will use this
non-secure port 25, all right.

177
00:08:33.730 --> 00:08:35.800
If you choose to use pop 3.

178
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:40.730
You'll need port 110 for
non-secure and 995 for secure.

179
00:08:40.730 --> 00:08:44.440
And if you choose to support IMAP4,
you'll need 143 for

180
00:08:44.440 --> 00:08:48.060
IMAP nonsecure and
then 993 for secure IMAP.

181
00:08:48.060 --> 00:08:50.220
And you don't have to turn them all on.

182
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:51.860
Maybe I just want the secure ones.

183
00:08:51.860 --> 00:08:53.920
So I might not turn on 110 and 143.

184
00:08:53.920 --> 00:08:55.680
I might just turn on 995 and 993.

185
00:08:55.680 --> 00:08:57.930
Now, what do I mean by turned on?

186
00:08:57.930 --> 00:08:58.980
Well, I mean.

187
00:08:58.980 --> 00:09:02.060
Go to your firewall and
open up those ports on the firewall.

188
00:09:02.060 --> 00:09:06.700
Your firewall will be blocking these by
default for your client access server.

189
00:09:06.700 --> 00:09:09.430
But at a minimum we need this guy and

190
00:09:09.430 --> 00:09:12.350
another neat little thing here it
doesn't have to be direct connectivity.

191
00:09:12.350 --> 00:09:15.670
We don't have to allow our clients
to connect directly to this.

192
00:09:15.670 --> 00:09:17.490
You might have a reverse proxy.

193
00:09:17.490 --> 00:09:19.954
Right, there's plenty of companies
out there that make reverse proxies,

194
00:09:19.954 --> 00:09:20.860
even Microsoft.

195
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:24.640
Microsoft has their threat-management
gateway which used to be the ISA,

196
00:09:24.640 --> 00:09:26.390
the Internet Security and
Acceleration server.

197
00:09:26.390 --> 00:09:28.508
Now it's there,
the threat-management gateway.

198
00:09:28.508 --> 00:09:33.440
And it can sit in-between your cache, your
client access servers, and the Internet.

199
00:09:33.440 --> 00:09:35.030
And it can inspect traffic.

200
00:09:35.030 --> 00:09:37.800
And block attacks before they
even get to your system.

201
00:09:37.800 --> 00:09:41.340
It could be things like
a Cisco Intrusion Detection Service.

202
00:09:41.340 --> 00:09:47.195
If could be a say, F5, they have
the firepass boxes that do the same thing.

203
00:09:47.195 --> 00:09:50.075
There's a number of different vendors out
there that make these reverse proxies that

204
00:09:50.075 --> 00:09:51.725
can sit in between your system and
the Internet.

205
00:09:51.725 --> 00:09:56.277
So if that's the case,
you need 443 open to the reverse proxy.

206
00:09:56.277 --> 00:09:58.395
And then the proxy would need to
be able to talk to your server.

207
00:09:58.395 --> 00:10:00.835
So just keep that in mind,
your security configuration might vary.

208
00:10:02.420 --> 00:10:05.246
All right, but assuming all of that's
open, we should be able to connect and

209
00:10:05.246 --> 00:10:06.940
Auto Discover should work.

210
00:10:06.940 --> 00:10:10.370
Now I'm throwing my IT department
should in there to give me some

211
00:10:10.370 --> 00:10:11.620
coverage if it doesn't work.

212
00:10:11.620 --> 00:10:16.310
But I'm gonna punch in my name, my e-mail
address, and when I hit Next it's gonna

213
00:10:16.310 --> 00:10:20.780
look first for itprotv.net/autodiscover,
which it's not going to find.

214
00:10:20.780 --> 00:10:24.830
Then it's gonna fail over to
Auto Discover to itprotv.net,

215
00:10:24.830 --> 00:10:27.150
which we just created and it will find.

216
00:10:27.150 --> 00:10:28.690
And so
it's gonna reach out to that system.

217
00:10:28.690 --> 00:10:33.710
It's searching for the settings and it
should find those settings and configure.

218
00:10:33.710 --> 00:10:37.900
Now Auto Discover over the wham
almost always takes longer.

219
00:10:37.900 --> 00:10:41.080
It's gotta reach along the Internet and
connect to the stuff.

220
00:10:41.080 --> 00:10:44.220
And, so it may take a little bit longer,
but when its done, it'll connect.

221
00:10:44.220 --> 00:10:49.520
Now, the most common point of failure here
if this doesn't work, are certificates.

222
00:10:49.520 --> 00:10:52.460
If there are certificates on
the server and we don't trust them,

223
00:10:52.460 --> 00:10:55.260
then Auto Discover is going to fail,
and its not going to work right?

224
00:10:55.260 --> 00:10:56.870
So certificates are that
number one problem,

225
00:10:56.870 --> 00:11:00.090
that we might have to go and re-issue
certificates, or get updated ones.

226
00:11:00.090 --> 00:11:03.930
An easy way to test that while we wait is
to just fire up a web browser and try and

227
00:11:03.930 --> 00:11:05.390
log in to OWA.

228
00:11:05.390 --> 00:11:13.430
So if I browse to my client
access server-OWA, right?

229
00:11:13.430 --> 00:11:16.110
If I go to the OWA page and
it goes secure,

230
00:11:16.110 --> 00:11:18.050
I see the little lock up here there,
right?

231
00:11:18.050 --> 00:11:20.830
If I get the red bar,
I know I've got a certificate problem and

232
00:11:20.830 --> 00:11:22.980
that's going to make
Auto Discover not work.

233
00:11:22.980 --> 00:11:25.410
And you can test even further.

234
00:11:25.410 --> 00:11:32.280
I went to, the sever that I went
to was lab-cas01.itprotv.net.

235
00:11:32.280 --> 00:11:37.210
But that's not what my clients
are going to, are they?

236
00:11:37.210 --> 00:11:40.880
They're going to autodiscover.itprotv.net.

237
00:11:40.880 --> 00:11:44.390
And so I can punch that in as if
I was gonna login to OWA there.

238
00:11:44.390 --> 00:11:51.800
And so I'm saying, I'm trying to say,
https://autodiscover.itprotv.net/owa and

239
00:11:51.800 --> 00:11:55.500
when I browse to that,
it's gonna hit the CNAME.

240
00:11:55.500 --> 00:11:58.700
So I still see Auto Discover up there,
and my lock is still good.

241
00:11:58.700 --> 00:12:00.760
So in my case, my certificates are good.

242
00:12:00.760 --> 00:12:02.360
I shouldn't have any problems there.

243
00:12:02.360 --> 00:12:03.730
Let's go see what Outlook is doing.

244
00:12:03.730 --> 00:12:06.720
Oh, and Outlook is finished
while I gabbed on and on.

245
00:12:06.720 --> 00:12:09.580
Now, it downloaded the settings
from Auto Discover, so

246
00:12:09.580 --> 00:12:11.320
now it knows the server to connect to.

247
00:12:11.320 --> 00:12:12.980
It knows the ports to use.

248
00:12:12.980 --> 00:12:14.540
It knows all that information.

249
00:12:14.540 --> 00:12:16.760
We gave it our username and password.

250
00:12:16.760 --> 00:12:18.550
We're now configured.

251
00:12:18.550 --> 00:12:21.040
You could actually go in and
change the settings if you wanted,

252
00:12:21.040 --> 00:12:22.280
manually go in and mess with it.

253
00:12:22.280 --> 00:12:26.180
But for the most part, it's done,
and now Outlook is gonna fire up and

254
00:12:26.180 --> 00:12:27.690
I'm connected.

255
00:12:27.690 --> 00:12:32.300
I had to create that DNSS record to
get this to work and have it in place.

256
00:12:32.300 --> 00:12:33.670
Now, the cool part is,

257
00:12:33.670 --> 00:12:38.210
once this is set up,
It's not just set up for basic Outlook.

258
00:12:38.210 --> 00:12:42.700
It's also set up for other advanced
features like the offline address book and

259
00:12:42.700 --> 00:12:43.920
Mail Tips for example.

260
00:12:43.920 --> 00:12:45.200
Let me show you Mail Tips.

261
00:12:45.200 --> 00:12:47.070
Mail Tips are a neat feature.

262
00:12:47.070 --> 00:12:50.660
It's a feature that's kind of
tacked on to the Outlook Web app.

263
00:12:50.660 --> 00:12:53.930
And Auto Discover connects it, but
a lot of people don't even know it exists.

264
00:12:53.930 --> 00:12:56.000
And so you never see Mail Tips very much.

265
00:12:56.000 --> 00:13:00.820
What Microsoft did is they said, look,
a lot of times, people draft e-mails, and

266
00:13:00.820 --> 00:13:01.570
they get blocked.

267
00:13:01.570 --> 00:13:04.270
You get an NDR, a nondelivery report.

268
00:13:04.270 --> 00:13:06.090
That NDR doesn't always come right away.

269
00:13:06.090 --> 00:13:07.450
You guys have probably had this before.

270
00:13:07.450 --> 00:13:09.640
Have you ever sent an email, and

271
00:13:09.640 --> 00:13:14.650
then a day later you get a message
saying this email has been delayed?

272
00:13:14.650 --> 00:13:16.440
Or this email failed to deliver?

273
00:13:16.440 --> 00:13:18.980
What you're getting is
a nondelivery report, and NDR.

274
00:13:18.980 --> 00:13:20.790
And, that's telling you
there was a problem but

275
00:13:20.790 --> 00:13:21.650
you didn't know that right away.

276
00:13:21.650 --> 00:13:23.360
It took a while for that to happen.

277
00:13:23.360 --> 00:13:28.330
Well, there are times where we
already know something is gonna fail.

278
00:13:28.330 --> 00:13:30.970
And so the server can actually
tell people ahead of time, or

279
00:13:30.970 --> 00:13:31.930
it can just tell them anything.

280
00:13:31.930 --> 00:13:34.390
You can actually give it
any message you want, and

281
00:13:34.390 --> 00:13:35.880
that will generate what's
called a Mail Tip.

282
00:13:35.880 --> 00:13:39.960
A little on screen prompt that
let you know there's a problem.

283
00:13:39.960 --> 00:13:44.070
And I like to use Mail Tips as a great
way to test connectivity beyond just your

284
00:13:44.070 --> 00:13:45.800
basic email connectivity.

285
00:13:45.800 --> 00:13:46.990
So let me show you how Mail Tips work.

286
00:13:48.090 --> 00:13:52.920
Let's say that I'm a user,
I'm Jane here, I'm logged in.

287
00:13:52.920 --> 00:13:55.850
And I'm about to fire off an e-mail to me,
to Don Pezet.

288
00:13:57.760 --> 00:13:59.300
I'm not in the office, right?

289
00:13:59.300 --> 00:14:01.300
Or maybe I've been fired.

290
00:14:01.300 --> 00:14:02.240
So I've been fired, but

291
00:14:02.240 --> 00:14:05.400
my e-mail account is still active
because we're collecting e-mails on it.

292
00:14:05.400 --> 00:14:07.070
But I've been fired.

293
00:14:07.070 --> 00:14:10.310
Well, I might want a way to
tell Jane that that's happened.

294
00:14:10.310 --> 00:14:12.500
I haven't disabled the account
cuz I'm still collecting e-mails.

295
00:14:12.500 --> 00:14:14.080
So she doesn't necessarily know that.

296
00:14:14.080 --> 00:14:16.820
If she goes in to craft a new e-mail.

297
00:14:16.820 --> 00:14:21.050
She could fire off an e-mail to Don Pezet.

298
00:14:21.050 --> 00:14:25.120
And it'll find me in the list
cuz my account's not disabled.

299
00:14:25.120 --> 00:14:32.160
And I need a quick favor, and
can you update this document for me?

300
00:14:32.160 --> 00:14:33.380
Or something like that.

301
00:14:33.380 --> 00:14:34.200
All right?

302
00:14:34.200 --> 00:14:35.890
So she fires off this e-mail.

303
00:14:35.890 --> 00:14:39.510
She doesn't know that my account is no
longer active, that I've been terminated.

304
00:14:39.510 --> 00:14:41.260
It's all invisible to her, right?

305
00:14:41.260 --> 00:14:43.530
And then, maybe later on down the road,

306
00:14:43.530 --> 00:14:47.990
we disable that account and now she
tries to e-mail and she gets an NDR.

307
00:14:47.990 --> 00:14:50.283
Wouldn't it have been nice if we could
have given her some kind of confirmation

308
00:14:50.283 --> 00:14:51.370
ahead of time for that?

309
00:14:51.370 --> 00:14:52.670
And, a Mail Tip will do it.

310
00:14:52.670 --> 00:14:56.920
So, all we have to do is as an
administrator, if we log into our exchange

311
00:14:56.920 --> 00:15:00.960
admin center, you can go to recipients and
you can pick somebody's mail box.

312
00:15:00.960 --> 00:15:01.820
So, I'll take my mailbox.

313
00:15:03.050 --> 00:15:05.980
And when you edit the mailbox, you'll see
different settings down the left side,

314
00:15:05.980 --> 00:15:08.400
and one of them is a Mail Tip, right?

315
00:15:08.400 --> 00:15:12.070
And here,
you can type in any message you want.

316
00:15:12.070 --> 00:15:14.875
You can type up to 175 characters,
kinda like a tweet.

317
00:15:14.875 --> 00:15:17.170
[LAUGH] You can type
whatever you want in there.

318
00:15:17.170 --> 00:15:19.830
And when a user goes
to e-mail this person,

319
00:15:19.830 --> 00:15:24.970
they'll see this message on screen letting
them now before they even hit send.

320
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:27.840
We can avoid those NDR's
before they even happen.

321
00:15:27.840 --> 00:15:32.960
So we can say something like,
this employee has been terminated.

322
00:15:34.880 --> 00:15:40.700
Please forward requests to John Doe or
somebody else.

323
00:15:40.700 --> 00:15:42.740
Just giving them that
message to let them know.

324
00:15:42.740 --> 00:15:44.070
So that's the Mail Tip that I'm defining.

325
00:15:45.650 --> 00:15:50.260
Mail tips are delivered by a secure
web connection between Outlook and

326
00:15:50.260 --> 00:15:52.600
the mail server, the client access server.

327
00:15:52.600 --> 00:15:55.300
We're checking in to get those
alongside of our e-mail.

328
00:15:55.300 --> 00:15:57.400
It's like a secondary connection.

329
00:15:57.400 --> 00:16:01.450
So, when I go back to Jane,
here she is in Outlook, and

330
00:16:01.450 --> 00:16:07.500
if we go to craft a new e-mail,
and we go to e-mail me, right?

331
00:16:07.500 --> 00:16:09.780
When we do that, in the background,

332
00:16:09.780 --> 00:16:13.700
it's gonna do a lookup to see if
there's any Mail Tips available.

333
00:16:13.700 --> 00:16:15.950
And, it's gonna populate them and
display them right here.

334
00:16:15.950 --> 00:16:18.850
Now, Mail Tips take a little
bit to actually get in there,

335
00:16:18.850 --> 00:16:20.090
because a lot of this gets cached.

336
00:16:20.090 --> 00:16:23.740
Remember, Outlook runs in
cache mode by default, so

337
00:16:23.740 --> 00:16:27.005
this information is getting kind of
cached down, and then run locally.

338
00:16:27.005 --> 00:16:29.050
Your Mail Tips actually get cached too.

339
00:16:29.050 --> 00:16:32.476
If there's e-mail that you, or people that
you e-mail frequently, you'll cache their

340
00:16:32.476 --> 00:16:35.860
Mail Tips, so you'll see them even when
you're offline, which is pretty neat.

341
00:16:35.860 --> 00:16:37.890
But, it means I'm not going
to see this one right away.

342
00:16:37.890 --> 00:16:41.220
But we'll see it, there's actually
a couple of ways we can generate this one,

343
00:16:41.220 --> 00:16:43.310
let me log in to OWA and
we'll see it here.

344
00:16:44.460 --> 00:16:49.240
So if I log in as, let's see,
who is she, janesmith@itprotv.net,

345
00:16:49.240 --> 00:16:53.800
which I think I've misspelled
every single time this episode.

346
00:16:53.800 --> 00:16:55.480
So I'm gonna get logged in as her,

347
00:16:55.480 --> 00:17:00.180
apparently this is the first
time she's logged in, all right.

348
00:17:00.180 --> 00:17:02.830
And OWA is nice because it's not cached,
right?

349
00:17:02.830 --> 00:17:05.060
We're seeing information
right from the server.

350
00:17:05.060 --> 00:17:10.995
So when she drafts an e-mail here, and
she goes to e-mail Don Pezet, right?

351
00:17:10.995 --> 00:17:14.005
It's searching for
that user and it finds me, and

352
00:17:14.005 --> 00:17:17.035
then look at the message that just
appeared right there, Don Pezet.

353
00:17:17.035 --> 00:17:18.255
This employee has been terminated.

354
00:17:18.255 --> 00:17:19.835
Please forward requests to John Doe.

355
00:17:19.835 --> 00:17:22.245
She sees an on-screen prompt
that lets her know that.

356
00:17:22.245 --> 00:17:23.395
That's a Mail Tip.

357
00:17:23.395 --> 00:17:23.945
Okay?

358
00:17:23.945 --> 00:17:26.595
And that's one of the other things
that Auto Discover is configuring.

359
00:17:26.595 --> 00:17:31.205
It configures a lot of things,
your e-mail, your contacts, your calendar,

360
00:17:31.205 --> 00:17:34.070
your tasks, right,
getting all that set up with the server.

361
00:17:34.070 --> 00:17:35.520
It sets up a lot.

362
00:17:35.520 --> 00:17:36.870
It's really pretty interesting.

363
00:17:36.870 --> 00:17:39.710
Pretty neat stuff,
all done with automatic discovery.

364
00:17:41.552 --> 00:17:44.200
All right,
I feel like I'm leaving something out but

365
00:17:44.200 --> 00:17:46.110
I think that's the bulk of it.

366
00:17:46.110 --> 00:17:50.640
Let my just scan my notes real quick,
oh it looks like that's about it.

367
00:17:50.640 --> 00:17:53.440
So key things to remember here,
let's wrap this one up.

368
00:17:53.440 --> 00:17:56.380
So key things to remember when it
comes to setting up Auto Discover,

369
00:17:56.380 --> 00:17:57.978
it really is two separate entities.

370
00:17:57.978 --> 00:18:01.640
There's Auto Discover for LAN clients,
clients that are joined to your domain.

371
00:18:01.640 --> 00:18:05.560
And then there's Auto Discover for
external clients, people that are outside.

372
00:18:05.560 --> 00:18:09.600
On the inside we need to make sure
that we've got valid certificates.

373
00:18:09.600 --> 00:18:12.990
That's important, although the self-signed
certificate might work fine for us.

374
00:18:12.990 --> 00:18:15.556
We also need to make sure that our clients
are joining the Active Directory and

375
00:18:15.556 --> 00:18:17.210
Auto Discover will work.

376
00:18:17.210 --> 00:18:20.810
For clients on the outside,
we need valid certificates, same thing.

377
00:18:20.810 --> 00:18:24.490
But we also need to make
sure that we've got

378
00:18:24.490 --> 00:18:28.270
our firewall open to allow connectivity,
and that we've got a DNS record.

379
00:18:28.270 --> 00:18:31.530
Because the Active Directory lookups
won't work for those external users.

380
00:18:31.530 --> 00:18:33.778
So that's an important one to make
sure that we've got that too.

381
00:18:33.778 --> 00:18:38.220
All right, but
after that Auto Discover just works.

382
00:18:38.220 --> 00:18:41.080
You get it configured and you put it outta
your mind, and you forget all about it and

383
00:18:41.080 --> 00:18:44.040
years go by everybody is already
configuring and it really works out well,

384
00:18:44.040 --> 00:18:45.030
so that's basically it.

385
00:18:46.040 --> 00:18:48.940
All right well, in this episode we got
a chance to see the second part of

386
00:18:48.940 --> 00:18:49.600
Auto Discover.

387
00:18:49.600 --> 00:18:51.180
We created a DNS entry.

388
00:18:51.180 --> 00:18:52.900
Remember I did a CNAME on that one.

389
00:18:52.900 --> 00:18:56.060
CNAME or aliases are always better than
a records cuz it makes maintenance

390
00:18:56.060 --> 00:18:57.080
a little bit easier.

391
00:18:57.080 --> 00:18:58.960
We saw that external client connect.

392
00:18:58.960 --> 00:19:01.890
We also saw how we could test that
connectivity, actually we saw that in part

393
00:19:01.890 --> 00:19:04.980
one, to make sure that Auto Discover
is working for our users.

394
00:19:04.980 --> 00:19:08.130
And then at the end of the episode I
covered Mail Tips, a little bit off topic,

395
00:19:08.130 --> 00:19:11.015
but it's something that is set up
as part of Auto Discover also.

396
00:19:11.015 --> 00:19:12.955
So definitely something
you want to be aware of.

397
00:19:12.955 --> 00:19:15.575
And easy to use, a neat little
feature that's baked in there,

398
00:19:15.575 --> 00:19:17.377
a lot of people don't know about it.

399
00:19:17.377 --> 00:19:19.875
All right well that's all I've got for
Auto Discover, so

400
00:19:19.875 --> 00:19:21.365
we'll wrap this two part series up.

401
00:19:21.365 --> 00:19:22.675
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

402
00:19:22.675 --> 00:19:26.515
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

403
00:19:26.515 --> 00:19:27.272
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes the viewers into the world of bring your own device (BYOD) clients. He demonstrates the mobile device management features found in Exchange 2013. He ends the episode by applying a mobile security policy to an Android device.
episodes.title: Mobile Access
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.227 --> 00:00:10.750
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.750 --> 00:00:11.597
All right.

3
00:00:11.597 --> 00:00:13.470
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

4
00:00:13.470 --> 00:00:16.080
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:17.411
I'm your host Don Pezet,

6
00:00:17.411 --> 00:00:20.807
back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

7
00:00:20.807 --> 00:00:21.877
And in this episode,

8
00:00:21.877 --> 00:00:25.450
we're going to be taking a look at
the exciting world of mobile access.

9
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:28.970
And by mobile access I mean, well,
the whole bring your own device movement.

10
00:00:28.970 --> 00:00:31.130
You got a lot people bringing cell phones,
and tablets,

11
00:00:31.130 --> 00:00:33.330
and all sorts of other
gear into your network.

12
00:00:33.330 --> 00:00:36.730
And it does create a little
bit of a management issue and

13
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:39.860
it creates a bit of a security risk,
by having this data out there.

14
00:00:39.860 --> 00:00:44.830
Well fortunately Microsoft Exchange
2013 has an amazing set of mobile device

15
00:00:44.830 --> 00:00:49.010
management or MDM features built right
into it, so we don't need third party

16
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:52.830
software like a Blackberry Enterprise
Server or Good Server, or whatever.

17
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:56.059
We can use the MDM built right
into Exchange to manage and

18
00:00:56.059 --> 00:01:00.180
secure our remote devices and
even to remote wipe them if they get lost,

19
00:01:00.180 --> 00:01:04.716
all while letting users maintain control
of their own device through the whole

20
00:01:04.716 --> 00:01:06.660
bring your own device movement.

21
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:10.332
So it's pretty neat, and
this works with Windows mobile phone,

22
00:01:10.332 --> 00:01:14.820
with Android, with iOS, Microsoft
doesn't really care which phone you use.

23
00:01:14.820 --> 00:01:19.770
Now they do have limited features on some
things like on BlackBerries, but on IOS,

24
00:01:19.770 --> 00:01:22.870
Android, and Windows Mobile, the big
three those, well I say the big three,

25
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:24.300
Windows Mobile is like small three.

26
00:01:24.300 --> 00:01:28.570
But, [LAUGH], we've got that functionality
and features to secure and manage them,

27
00:01:28.570 --> 00:01:31.200
so let's take a look at how that works.

28
00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:34.580
First off, whenever you set
up a user inside of Exchange,

29
00:01:34.580 --> 00:01:38.070
the whole mobile functionality
is kind of enabled by default.

30
00:01:38.070 --> 00:01:41.120
They get that functionality
on their account.

31
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:44.470
If I take a look at a user, like here
I am in my Exchange admin center.

32
00:01:44.470 --> 00:01:48.090
If I go under recipients and I take any
one of these, I'll just take mine for

33
00:01:48.090 --> 00:01:49.420
example.

34
00:01:49.420 --> 00:01:52.330
If I go and edit the user,
when we go and look in the user,

35
00:01:52.330 --> 00:01:55.760
you'll see different things, and
we're looking for mailbox features.

36
00:01:55.760 --> 00:01:57.250
And here you'll see things
that are turned on.

37
00:01:57.250 --> 00:02:00.110
And right down here,
I've got mobile devices.

38
00:02:00.110 --> 00:02:05.200
And you'll see Exchange ActiveSync and
OWA for Devices.

39
00:02:05.200 --> 00:02:09.000
Those are two different connectivity
methods that devices can use to establish

40
00:02:09.000 --> 00:02:10.440
a connection to your mailbox.

41
00:02:10.440 --> 00:02:12.970
And it's not just as simple
as checking your email.

42
00:02:12.970 --> 00:02:15.670
If it would just checking your email,
you'd use POP3 or

43
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:16.990
IMAP4 and then you'd be done.

44
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:21.990
But what these two methods
bring us is a lot more.

45
00:02:21.990 --> 00:02:23.196
Let's talk about ActiveSync.

46
00:02:23.196 --> 00:02:25.830
ActiveSync is the primary
connection method.

47
00:02:25.830 --> 00:02:26.850
And that's the one we wanted.

48
00:02:26.850 --> 00:02:28.030
This is a little confusing here.

49
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:30.970
So see how it says
Disable Exchange Active Synch?

50
00:02:30.970 --> 00:02:33.770
That's how I know ActiveSync
is turned on for me right now.

51
00:02:33.770 --> 00:02:37.160
And so by default it's turned on, and
it's giving me the option to turn it off.

52
00:02:37.160 --> 00:02:40.020
If I turn it off, it'll change to
say Enable Exchange ActiveSync and

53
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:41.568
I can turn that on.

54
00:02:41.568 --> 00:02:46.580
The way ActiveSync works is it uses
autodiscover, which if you watch our

55
00:02:46.580 --> 00:02:51.890
autodiscover episode, you're familiar
with, a client like an Android phone, can

56
00:02:51.890 --> 00:02:56.680
look at your email address, reach out to
the internet, and find your mail server.

57
00:02:56.680 --> 00:03:00.380
And when it finds your mail server
it can look for the ActiveSync

58
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:03.950
configuration file that'll tell it how
a phone should connect to the server.

59
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:06.450
And when it connects,
it provides your username and password and

60
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:10.820
now it has access to your email,
your tasks, your calendar, your contacts,

61
00:03:10.820 --> 00:03:13.940
all that information right
there from your phone.

62
00:03:13.940 --> 00:03:17.880
But at the same time,
it enables two really cool things.

63
00:03:17.880 --> 00:03:21.020
The first is a security policy.

64
00:03:21.020 --> 00:03:24.530
In exchange we have a mobile
security policy where we can dictate

65
00:03:24.530 --> 00:03:27.290
hey your phone has to have a screen lock
after a certain amount of minutes and

66
00:03:27.290 --> 00:03:30.610
it's got to be a pin number of
greater than these amount of numbers.

67
00:03:30.610 --> 00:03:32.660
Or we need to be able to
remote wipe your machine.

68
00:03:32.660 --> 00:03:35.040
Or we need to limit the apps
you're allowed to run.

69
00:03:35.040 --> 00:03:38.880
That's part of the security policy, and
when you connect the Exchange ActiveSync,

70
00:03:38.880 --> 00:03:40.830
that's what enables that policy.

71
00:03:40.830 --> 00:03:41.600
Right?

72
00:03:41.600 --> 00:03:47.010
The other thing that enables is what's
called Direct Push Notification.

73
00:03:47.010 --> 00:03:51.380
On older mobile systems, the way they
worked is you'd connect through a POP3 or

74
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:55.030
IMAP4 and then 15 minutes or every 10
minutes your phone would reach out and

75
00:03:55.030 --> 00:03:56.650
check your mailbox for new mail.

76
00:03:56.650 --> 00:03:57.190
Right.

77
00:03:57.190 --> 00:03:59.020
Well, you might not get a lot of email.

78
00:03:59.020 --> 00:04:03.330
And if you don't get a lot of email it's
checking all throughout the day keeping

79
00:04:03.330 --> 00:04:05.650
your phone awake, and
burning up your battery.

80
00:04:05.650 --> 00:04:08.860
And so a lot of systems that did that,
these are called pull notifications where

81
00:04:08.860 --> 00:04:10.580
you reach out to the server and
pull them down.

82
00:04:11.770 --> 00:04:14.840
Those pull notifications drain
your battery and that stinks.

83
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:16.480
And people wanna know
about email right away,

84
00:04:16.480 --> 00:04:18.270
they don't wanna wait 10 or 15 minutes.

85
00:04:18.270 --> 00:04:21.920
So if you lowered it down to one minute
you definitely saw a hit on your battery.

86
00:04:21.920 --> 00:04:24.660
Well, the way direct
push notifications work

87
00:04:24.660 --> 00:04:28.220
is instead of your client reaching out to
the server every so often to check for

88
00:04:28.220 --> 00:04:32.830
mail, the server tells you
when new email comes in.

89
00:04:32.830 --> 00:04:36.590
So if an hour goes by and no emails come
in, the server just doesn't bother you.

90
00:04:36.590 --> 00:04:39.300
But if an email does come in,
the server immediately tells you.

91
00:04:39.300 --> 00:04:44.150
So you get a battery savings, and you get
immediate notification of new email and

92
00:04:44.150 --> 00:04:45.710
that's really cool, all right?

93
00:04:45.710 --> 00:04:48.310
Let me talk a little bit about
direct push before I move into

94
00:04:48.310 --> 00:04:49.690
the configuration stuff.

95
00:04:49.690 --> 00:04:55.480
So the way direct push works is by
manipulating the way TCP works.

96
00:04:55.480 --> 00:04:57.590
TCP, the transmission control protocol,

97
00:04:57.590 --> 00:05:01.360
is used for the majority of our
communications on the internet.

98
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:03.890
When you reach out to a website,
for example,

99
00:05:03.890 --> 00:05:09.010
you open up a TCP session to a server and
you say, give me a copy of your webpage.

100
00:05:09.010 --> 00:05:13.740
And the server responds by transmitting
the webpage over that session.

101
00:05:13.740 --> 00:05:15.580
Well the session has a timeout, and

102
00:05:15.580 --> 00:05:18.548
it says hey, give me a copy of
the webpage and you got 30 seconds.

103
00:05:18.548 --> 00:05:22.080
And if the 30 seconds run out
then the session times out and

104
00:05:22.080 --> 00:05:25.610
you get an error message on your screen,
and you can try again, right?

105
00:05:25.610 --> 00:05:29.250
Well with direct push, what happens is
your phone reaches out to Exchange,

106
00:05:29.250 --> 00:05:32.740
and it says hey,
give me any new email I get.

107
00:05:32.740 --> 00:05:38.180
And then it sets the time out to
a really big number, all right?

108
00:05:38.180 --> 00:05:39.700
I think it's 30 minutes.

109
00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:41.240
It might be a full hour.

110
00:05:41.240 --> 00:05:42.260
I think it's 30 minutes.

111
00:05:42.260 --> 00:05:43.910
So, it sets if for like 30 minutes.

112
00:05:43.910 --> 00:05:45.960
And it says, hey,
if I get a new email, send it to me.

113
00:05:45.960 --> 00:05:48.864
And the server says, okay, I'm gonna wait.

114
00:05:48.864 --> 00:05:49.887
And it just start to wait.

115
00:05:49.887 --> 00:05:51.630
It just sits there,and it waits.

116
00:05:51.630 --> 00:05:55.190
And if a new email comes in,
it can immediately send it to us.

117
00:05:55.190 --> 00:05:57.300
But if nothing comes in,
it waits the full 30 minutes, and

118
00:05:57.300 --> 00:06:00.200
right at the end of the 30 minutes,
it says, oop, you didn't get an email,

119
00:06:00.200 --> 00:06:03.880
and then the session closes, and
