your phone opens a new session.

120
00:06:03.880 --> 00:06:07.030
And so now your phone's only opening
a session once every half hour, that's no

121
00:06:07.030 --> 00:06:10.410
big deal, and then it just sits there and
waits for the server to respond back.

122
00:06:10.410 --> 00:06:14.420
It's very efficient, it's very quick,
and it works really well, all right.

123
00:06:14.420 --> 00:06:15.950
Now there are some little
quirks that can happen.

124
00:06:15.950 --> 00:06:18.212
You might have a firewall for
example, that's monitoring for

125
00:06:18.212 --> 00:06:21.214
extended sessions and blocking them so you
might have to tweak your firewall a bit.

126
00:06:21.214 --> 00:06:23.496
But pretty much every
system does this today so

127
00:06:23.496 --> 00:06:27.000
most firewalls are already aware of it and
it's not a big deal.

128
00:06:27.000 --> 00:06:31.010
But that's another function of
Exchange ActiveSync, all right.

129
00:06:31.010 --> 00:06:34.400
Now not every device supports
Exchange ActiveSync.

130
00:06:34.400 --> 00:06:37.530
If, let's say, you decided you're
gonna open up your own company and

131
00:06:37.530 --> 00:06:39.750
you're gonna make your own Android phone.

132
00:06:39.750 --> 00:06:41.256
So, you start manufacturing
your own Android phone.

133
00:06:41.256 --> 00:06:44.619
If you want to support ActiveSync,
you have to call Microsoft up, and

134
00:06:44.619 --> 00:06:46.048
sign a licensing agreement.

135
00:06:46.048 --> 00:06:48.928
You have to pay them money, you have to
pay a certain amount of money per phone

136
00:06:48.928 --> 00:06:51.673
that you sell, and so some companies say,
you know what, forget that,

137
00:06:51.673 --> 00:06:54.530
we're not gonna support ActiveSync,
we wanna save the money.

138
00:06:54.530 --> 00:06:55.870
And so they don't do it.

139
00:06:55.870 --> 00:06:59.260
And for
those devices they have option number two.

140
00:06:59.260 --> 00:07:03.200
Option number two is OWA for devices and
that's this one right here at the bottom.

141
00:07:03.200 --> 00:07:07.550
And what it is, is Outlook Web App, it's
the web interface but it's designed where

142
00:07:07.550 --> 00:07:11.310
instead of giving us a nice GUI that's all
pretty, it just gives you a bunch of XML.

143
00:07:11.310 --> 00:07:13.680
A bunch of raw XML data.

144
00:07:13.680 --> 00:07:17.430
And you can have a client on your phone
that interprets that XML data and

145
00:07:17.430 --> 00:07:19.110
renders it in its own client.

146
00:07:19.110 --> 00:07:23.080
And so you still have access to
your contacts, your calendar,

147
00:07:23.080 --> 00:07:24.590
your inbox, your to-do list.

148
00:07:24.590 --> 00:07:28.160
You still have access to all that, it's
just done without that ActiveSync license.

149
00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:32.220
And it's done without direct push, and
it's done without the security policies.

150
00:07:32.220 --> 00:07:34.270
You loose a lot of functionality
by doing it that way.

151
00:07:34.270 --> 00:07:35.580
But those are the two.

152
00:07:35.580 --> 00:07:38.830
If I'm in a high security environment and
I want to ensure that my policies

153
00:07:38.830 --> 00:07:42.040
are taking effect,
I'd probably disable OWA for devices.

154
00:07:42.040 --> 00:07:45.990
But if I'm just wanting anybody to be
able to connect whatever way works,

155
00:07:45.990 --> 00:07:46.830
this is secure.

156
00:07:46.830 --> 00:07:50.470
It does use SSL, but I don't get
the benefit of policies and so on.

157
00:07:50.470 --> 00:07:53.708
So those are kind of the two different
connectivity methods that we have.

158
00:07:53.708 --> 00:07:56.177
Now I mentioned these security policies.

159
00:07:56.177 --> 00:08:00.864
When people connect up, there's a security
policy that's created, and it's applied.

160
00:08:00.864 --> 00:08:04.365
On the left side of my EAC,
you'll see mobile.

161
00:08:04.365 --> 00:08:07.017
And under mobile,
here we've got mobile device access and so

162
00:08:07.017 --> 00:08:09.830
it's got information about
who's allowed to connect.

163
00:08:09.830 --> 00:08:14.440
But right beside it,
is the mobile device mailbox policies.

164
00:08:14.440 --> 00:08:17.310
And here's where I can define
how my devices are handled.

165
00:08:17.310 --> 00:08:20.890
You can have just one big
policy that covers everybody or

166
00:08:20.890 --> 00:08:23.680
you can create different policies for
different users.

167
00:08:23.680 --> 00:08:26.300
Maybe my sales people
have one set of policies.

168
00:08:26.300 --> 00:08:28.030
My executives have another policy.

169
00:08:28.030 --> 00:08:31.180
My mailbox [INAUDIBLE] my marketing
people have a third policy.

170
00:08:31.180 --> 00:08:34.470
You can define each one different because
some people might have sensitive data,

171
00:08:34.470 --> 00:08:35.920
some people might not.

172
00:08:35.920 --> 00:08:37.760
But usually we stick with the default,
right?

173
00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:39.240
All employees are treated the same way.

174
00:08:39.240 --> 00:08:41.510
We have a standard level of security.

175
00:08:41.510 --> 00:08:45.980
And you can edit that and here's where you
can define all sorts of really neat stuff.

176
00:08:45.980 --> 00:08:49.080
Well, not so much on this screen, but if
I go to security, here's the neat stuff.

177
00:08:49.080 --> 00:08:49.920
All right?

178
00:08:49.920 --> 00:08:53.960
I might want to require that, hey if
you're connecting your company mailbox

179
00:08:53.960 --> 00:08:56.170
onto your phone,
we need to secure that data.

180
00:08:56.170 --> 00:08:58.470
So, you need to have
a password on your phone.

181
00:08:58.470 --> 00:09:00.530
We're gonna require you
to have a password.

182
00:09:00.530 --> 00:09:02.540
And maybe we don't want a simple password.

183
00:09:02.540 --> 00:09:04.510
Maybe we wanna require
it to be alpha-numeric.

184
00:09:04.510 --> 00:09:07.110
Maybe we want it to be letters and
numbers and all that stuff.

185
00:09:07.110 --> 00:09:08.560
But normally you would
want it to be a pin.

186
00:09:08.560 --> 00:09:10.080
That would be a simple password.

187
00:09:10.080 --> 00:09:12.610
And so they're showing those here,
simple password sequences.

188
00:09:12.610 --> 00:09:15.890
You can set it so it includes
a certain amount of characters.

189
00:09:15.890 --> 00:09:19.120
You can require encryption on the device.

190
00:09:19.120 --> 00:09:23.510
iOS and Android both support
encrypting the device.

191
00:09:23.510 --> 00:09:26.830
iOS I believe does it by default,
Android doesn't do it by default.

192
00:09:26.830 --> 00:09:28.470
Blackberry does do it by default.

193
00:09:28.470 --> 00:09:30.440
So different ones have different
requirements there, but

194
00:09:30.440 --> 00:09:32.870
you can choose to require
the device be encrypted.

195
00:09:32.870 --> 00:09:34.750
You can set that minimum password link,

196
00:09:34.750 --> 00:09:36.550
maybe I want it to be at
least four characters.

197
00:09:37.620 --> 00:09:41.230
Number of sign on failures
before a device is wiped.

198
00:09:41.230 --> 00:09:44.660
You can make it where if somebody's
trying to brute force the password and

199
00:09:44.660 --> 00:09:46.900
they get it wrong too many times,
it erases the phone.

200
00:09:46.900 --> 00:09:47.850
That's kinda neat, right?

201
00:09:47.850 --> 00:09:50.010
A great way to secure that data.

202
00:09:50.010 --> 00:09:53.340
We've also got required sign in
after the device has been active.

203
00:09:53.340 --> 00:09:56.790
So if somebody walks away from their
tablet, and they didn't lock it,

204
00:09:56.790 --> 00:10:00.380
right, how long do we want it to
go before requiring that sign in?

205
00:10:00.380 --> 00:10:02.910
So I might set that to something lower,
like five minutes.

206
00:10:02.910 --> 00:10:03.880
Okay.

207
00:10:03.880 --> 00:10:06.040
Here we got enforce a password lifetime.

208
00:10:06.040 --> 00:10:08.480
A lot of people set a PIN on their
phone and then they never change it.

209
00:10:08.480 --> 00:10:12.030
So maybe I want to set a maximum time for
them to be able to use that password

210
00:10:12.030 --> 00:10:15.710
before they have to change it again and
a password recycle count.

211
00:10:15.710 --> 00:10:19.145
I don't want them reusing the same
password over and over again, so

212
00:10:19.145 --> 00:10:21.557
I might say remember
the last five passwords and

213
00:10:21.557 --> 00:10:25.793
don't let them use the same one until it's
been five times since they've done it.

214
00:10:25.793 --> 00:10:29.378
So these are examples of some of
the different things we can set, so

215
00:10:29.378 --> 00:10:31.435
that when people bring their device.

216
00:10:31.435 --> 00:10:35.852
We can at least apply some basic security
principles to it and active sync,

217
00:10:35.852 --> 00:10:40.618
in addition to connecting them to their
mail will also enforce this policy yo make

218
00:10:40.618 --> 00:10:42.670
sure they meet our requirements.

219
00:10:45.402 --> 00:10:46.770
All right,
now if I want somebody to connect,

220
00:10:46.770 --> 00:10:50.110
it's pretty straight forward
because it uses auto-discover.

221
00:10:50.110 --> 00:10:52.900
So I've got an Android tablet right here.

222
00:10:52.900 --> 00:10:56.230
And so if I want to connect this Android
tablet up to my Exchange environment I can

223
00:10:56.230 --> 00:11:00.130
just go into my settings, and
I can go down here to my accounts.

224
00:11:00.130 --> 00:11:03.110
So I'm gonna add an account and
I'm gonna choose corporate.

225
00:11:03.110 --> 00:11:04.670
Now some of them will
actually say exchange,

226
00:11:04.670 --> 00:11:06.860
some say corporate,
there's different names there.

227
00:11:06.860 --> 00:11:10.400
But if I click on that you'll see here
we can set up an Exchange account.

228
00:11:10.400 --> 00:11:12.520
And so I'm gonna connect this one to Jane.

229
00:11:12.520 --> 00:11:20.180
So, Jane is jsmith@itprotv.net,, and
then I can punch in her password.

230
00:11:20.180 --> 00:11:24.060
Now, on an Outlook client if you
join to the active directory,

231
00:11:24.060 --> 00:11:25.720
it can populate this information for us.

232
00:11:25.720 --> 00:11:28.200
But most phones aren't joined
to our Active Directory.

233
00:11:28.200 --> 00:11:30.230
So, you're gonna have to type
in a name and a password.

234
00:11:30.230 --> 00:11:34.040
But it's gonna use this name,
the domain name, to go out and

235
00:11:34.040 --> 00:11:37.150
do a DNS lookup to find
the servers to get connected.

236
00:11:37.150 --> 00:11:41.490
And when it gets connected, it's gonna
download that security policy first and

237
00:11:41.490 --> 00:11:45.130
apply the policy and
then it's gonna set up my email account.

238
00:11:45.130 --> 00:11:47.980
So when I hit next,
it's reaching out to that server, and

239
00:11:47.980 --> 00:11:50.370
it's trying to connect and so
here it's gathering that information.

240
00:11:50.370 --> 00:11:54.870
Now, on mine it got it a little bit wrong,
so I'm gonna have to correct some of this.

241
00:11:54.870 --> 00:12:00.690
My username is jsmith@itprotv.net.

242
00:12:00.690 --> 00:12:02.900
My password, my server name.

243
00:12:02.900 --> 00:12:06.170
It got that wrong for some reason,
so I'll just have to punch that in.

244
00:12:06.170 --> 00:12:08.190
I may not have configured
all to discover here.

245
00:12:08.190 --> 00:12:10.162
We've got a secure SSL connection.

246
00:12:10.162 --> 00:12:15.300
For ActiveSync to work, we have to trust
the certificate on the other side.

247
00:12:15.300 --> 00:12:18.472
If we're using a self sign certificate or
a certificate

248
00:12:18.472 --> 00:12:22.460
issued by a CA that our phones don't
trust, that can cause a problem.

249
00:12:22.460 --> 00:12:24.973
Some phones are locked down by
the cell phone providers and

250
00:12:24.973 --> 00:12:27.743
they don't allow you to modify
the trusted root authorities and

251
00:12:27.743 --> 00:12:30.015
that means you can't trust
your own certificates.

252
00:12:30.015 --> 00:12:34.001
So fortunately, this one has an option
that says accept all SSL certificates and

253
00:12:34.001 --> 00:12:35.354
that'll let me use my own.

254
00:12:35.354 --> 00:12:38.232
All right, so
we can punch that information in and

255
00:12:38.232 --> 00:12:41.041
then next it's gonna reach
out to that server and

256
00:12:41.041 --> 00:12:45.170
try and get us connected and
couldn't open connection to the servers.

257
00:12:45.170 --> 00:12:46.750
So, did I type it wrong?

258
00:12:46.750 --> 00:12:48.610
Lab dash cas01 dot itprotv dot net.

259
00:12:48.610 --> 00:12:49.430
You know what?

260
00:12:49.430 --> 00:12:52.480
I'll just punch in the IP to
save me a little time here.

261
00:12:52.480 --> 00:12:54.570
And we'll definitely
get connected that way.

262
00:12:54.570 --> 00:12:57.350
I'm not sure what DNS server this is
using, so it might not be looking me up.

263
00:12:57.350 --> 00:13:01.470
That might be, there we go,
that's why my auto discover didn't work.

264
00:13:01.470 --> 00:13:03.490
I'm probably using the wrong DNS servers.

265
00:13:03.490 --> 00:13:05.270
All right, so
here I can see that I'm connected.

266
00:13:05.270 --> 00:13:09.290
It says it requires that I allow it
to remotely control some features,

267
00:13:09.290 --> 00:13:10.640
what does that mean?

268
00:13:10.640 --> 00:13:15.030
Well, this is the security policy from
ActiveSync downloading to this device.

269
00:13:15.030 --> 00:13:20.030
If I say cancel, that refuses
the policy and I can't set up my email.

270
00:13:20.030 --> 00:13:21.750
But if I say okay.

271
00:13:21.750 --> 00:13:24.050
I'm now accepting ActiveSync and

272
00:13:24.050 --> 00:13:26.770
that security policy is
going to apply to my device.

273
00:13:26.770 --> 00:13:29.605
I can see my inbox checking
is set to push, right?

274
00:13:29.605 --> 00:13:32.800
ActiveSync gives me that
direct push technology and

275
00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:34.620
it's gonna sync up a certain
amount of days, and

276
00:13:34.620 --> 00:13:38.562
then we can specify all the other settings
that I might wanna tweak for my mailbox.

277
00:13:38.562 --> 00:13:40.350
All right.

278
00:13:40.350 --> 00:13:42.660
After that's done, here it is,
that's my account, and

279
00:13:42.660 --> 00:13:44.840
I can see I've already got
some new email coming in.

280
00:13:44.840 --> 00:13:47.918
I'm getting a warning here that I'm
activating the device administrator.

281
00:13:47.918 --> 00:13:52.510
I'm giving ActiveSync permission to
erase all data, set password rules,

282
00:13:52.510 --> 00:13:54.320
lock the screen, and so on.

283
00:13:54.320 --> 00:13:56.820
This is that security policy applying,
right?

284
00:13:56.820 --> 00:14:00.580
When that's done,
here I'm taking my security screen,

285
00:14:00.580 --> 00:14:03.680
the security policy is
requiring me to set a PIN.

286
00:14:03.680 --> 00:14:07.870
So I need to go in and set a PIN,
which I'll set right here.

287
00:14:07.870 --> 00:14:11.150
I'm going super secure and
setting it to one, two, three, four, and

288
00:14:11.150 --> 00:14:12.400
now I've got a PIN.

289
00:14:12.400 --> 00:14:14.570
So when I lock my screen,
in order to unlock it,

290
00:14:14.570 --> 00:14:15.760
I'll have to punch in that PIN number.

291
00:14:15.760 --> 00:14:18.340
Right?
There's that level security being enforced

292
00:14:18.340 --> 00:14:20.560
by the exchange security policy.

293
00:14:20.560 --> 00:14:25.270
And now when I go into my email
client I can go into email and

294
00:14:25.270 --> 00:14:26.070
here's my work email.

295
00:14:26.070 --> 00:14:29.210
Here's that email that came in from
the administrator, and now I'm good to go.

296
00:14:29.210 --> 00:14:31.100
I'm connected to my calendar and
all those other things.

297
00:14:32.210 --> 00:14:35.980
So that's the first taste we get
of mobile device management.

298
00:14:35.980 --> 00:14:40.610
At a minimum, we can use the mobile
device security policies to manage

299
00:14:40.610 --> 00:14:44.290
how secure our systems are and to keep
them locked down so that if somebody is

300
00:14:44.290 --> 00:14:48.120
gonna maintain a copy of our corporate
e-mail it's at least under basic security.

301
00:14:48.120 --> 00:14:51.470
If they leave their phone
on a taxi cab somewhere,

302
00:14:51.470 --> 00:14:54.032
well I know it's at least got a PIN
number and the screen is locked.

303
00:14:54.032 --> 00:14:59.220
Right, so at a minimum we've got that but
there's a lot more we can do too.

304
00:14:59.220 --> 00:15:01.350
For example,
now that this is connected to ActiveSync,

305
00:15:01.350 --> 00:15:03.800
what happens if this
person loses their phone?

306
00:15:03.800 --> 00:15:07.510
If they lose their phone,
we might wanna remote wipe it.

307
00:15:07.510 --> 00:15:09.410
There's two ways to remote wipe a phone.

308
00:15:09.410 --> 00:15:10.730
The administrators, we can do it.

309
00:15:10.730 --> 00:15:13.800
We can remote wipe any phone
connected to exchange.

310
00:15:13.800 --> 00:15:15.590
The end user can do it also though.

311
00:15:15.590 --> 00:15:16.920
They can wipe their own phone.

312
00:15:16.920 --> 00:15:19.600
They can actually do it
through Outlook Web App.

313
00:15:19.600 --> 00:15:21.860
If they go to Outlook Web App and
go into their settings,

314
00:15:21.860 --> 00:15:24.650
they'll see their phones right there,
and they can wipe their own phone or

315
00:15:24.650 --> 00:15:28.030
their own tablet, this is a tablet here,
they can wipe their own device.

316
00:15:28.030 --> 00:15:30.200
Now for remote wipe to work
the device has to be on, right?

317
00:15:30.200 --> 00:15:33.230
We've got to be able to send
the signal to it, but assuming it's on,

318
00:15:33.230 --> 00:15:35.210
we can get a signal to it and wipe it.

319
00:15:35.210 --> 00:15:38.010
As an administrator,
it's actually pretty easy for us to do it.

320
00:15:38.010 --> 00:15:39.280
I wanna see that.

321
00:15:39.280 --> 00:15:40.980
We can do a remote wipe on this one.

322
00:15:42.510 --> 00:15:46.798
If I go back to my Exchange administration
settings, or my Exchange admin center,

323
00:15:46.798 --> 00:15:50.553
we can jump in here, and if I go to my
recipients I can find the recipient.

324
00:15:50.553 --> 00:15:55.161
So Jane calls me, and she says, Don,
I left my tablet on a taxicab and

325
00:15:55.161 --> 00:15:57.635
I've got all sorts of data on there.

326
00:15:57.635 --> 00:15:59.648
I don't know if I can get it back,
can we just wipe it?

327
00:15:59.648 --> 00:16:01.884
And I say oh yeah give
me just a minute Jane.

328
00:16:01.884 --> 00:16:05.190
I can log into the EAC,
I can find her account.

329
00:16:06.520 --> 00:16:11.005
And if we edit here account you'll see
some different options here across

330
00:16:11.005 --> 00:16:14.419
the left, and if we look we can find our,
oh wait sorry.

331
00:16:14.419 --> 00:16:15.534
I'm in the wrong spot.

332
00:16:15.534 --> 00:16:20.620
If we highlight Jane Smith over here
on the right side, if you scroll down.

333
00:16:20.620 --> 00:16:21.840
It's kinda buried away.

334
00:16:21.840 --> 00:16:25.530
We've got mobile devices, and
then you got view details right there.

335
00:16:25.530 --> 00:16:28.160
That's where we need to go to
actually see her mobile devices.

336
00:16:28.160 --> 00:16:29.360
I know it's kinda counter-intuitive.

337
00:16:29.360 --> 00:16:31.260
I always want to pull up
the properties of her account.

338
00:16:31.260 --> 00:16:33.070
But the devices are nested over here.

339
00:16:33.070 --> 00:16:36.010
So if I go to view details,
it's gonna pull it up and

340
00:16:36.010 --> 00:16:38.240
there I can see her Android device, right?

341
00:16:38.240 --> 00:16:39.820
There's here Android tablet.

342
00:16:39.820 --> 00:16:42.040
I can see that it's been
granted access to the system.

343
00:16:42.040 --> 00:16:45.530
It's active right now but she lost it and
if she had more than one device,

344
00:16:45.530 --> 00:16:47.320
I'd see them all right here in the list.

345
00:16:47.320 --> 00:16:49.280
This is also where I could
change her security policy.

346
00:16:49.280 --> 00:16:52.090
If I wanted her to have a different policy
than the default, I could browse and

347
00:16:52.090 --> 00:16:53.930
change it right here too.

348
00:16:53.930 --> 00:16:55.720
But in this case she lost her device.

349
00:16:55.720 --> 00:16:58.410
And if you look up here at the options
you'll see where we can do things like

350
00:16:58.410 --> 00:16:59.650
block the device.

351
00:16:59.650 --> 00:17:00.980
Maybe I don't want to wipe it.

352
00:17:00.980 --> 00:17:04.080
I just want to stop it from accessing
our system until she finds it.

353
00:17:04.080 --> 00:17:06.270
And then when she finds it
I can re enable it again.

354
00:17:06.270 --> 00:17:07.790
So you can hit block.

355
00:17:07.790 --> 00:17:08.700
and she finds the device and

356
00:17:08.700 --> 00:17:11.440
I come and re-enable, well that's
what you want to do at the minimum.

357
00:17:11.440 --> 00:17:15.750
But as we look you can see wipe data, and
that's what we want to do if the phone is

358
00:17:15.750 --> 00:17:17.910
lost, and
we don't think we're going to get it back.

359
00:17:17.910 --> 00:17:21.440
Or, if it's got sensitive data, and I just
want to erase it before the battery dies.

360
00:17:21.440 --> 00:17:23.210
Because the battery will die eventually,

361
00:17:23.210 --> 00:17:25.030
even if it's just sitting
there on a park bench.

362
00:17:25.030 --> 00:17:28.150
So, I'm going to hit that button, and
it's going to tell me we are going to

363
00:17:28.150 --> 00:17:32.240
wipe that device, just going to reach
out and knock that out and clear it.

364
00:17:32.240 --> 00:17:33.980
So I'll go ahead and say OK to that, and

365
00:17:33.980 --> 00:17:36.760
it's now sending a wipe
ping to that system.

366
00:17:36.760 --> 00:17:39.200
So see how it says wipe pending?

367
00:17:39.200 --> 00:17:41.450
It sent the ping to the other system and
it's saying hey,

368
00:17:41.450 --> 00:17:42.860
you need to erase yourself.

369
00:17:42.860 --> 00:17:44.890
Now if the other system is off.

370
00:17:44.890 --> 00:17:47.570
Maybe whoever's got the phone
turned off the wireless,

371
00:17:47.570 --> 00:17:49.090
the signal is not gonna get there.

372
00:17:49.090 --> 00:17:51.920
So it's gonna keep trying,
it's gonna keep trying over and over and

373
00:17:51.920 --> 00:17:53.240
over again forever.

374
00:17:53.240 --> 00:17:55.510
It's just gonna keep
trying until we stop it.

375
00:17:55.510 --> 00:17:59.688
That way if the device ever does come back
online, it'll receive that message, and

376
00:17:59.688 --> 00:18:01.180
it'll wipe.

377
00:18:01.180 --> 00:18:04.580
Meanwhile, if I go back to the device,
things just look like normal.

378
00:18:04.580 --> 00:18:07.970
And what's gonna happen is this
device is gonna receive that ping.

379
00:18:07.970 --> 00:18:11.690
And as soon as that happens it's
gonna reboot and erase itself.

380
00:18:11.690 --> 00:18:14.800
It's gonna wipe itself,
clear the data and then we're safe.

381
00:18:14.800 --> 00:18:17.520
So as an admin we can do
it right here centrally.

382
00:18:17.520 --> 00:18:20.820
As a user they can do it
through Outlook web app.

383
00:18:20.820 --> 00:18:23.890
Just log into OWA and go into their
settings and they can knock it out there.

384
00:18:24.890 --> 00:18:25.840
All right.

385
00:18:25.840 --> 00:18:30.460
A couple other things that we need to
think about with mobile devices like this.

386
00:18:30.460 --> 00:18:31.770
When I went under my EAC and

387
00:18:31.770 --> 00:18:34.890
I went to mobile, you'll notice
there was this mobile device access.

388
00:18:34.890 --> 00:18:36.280
What's that all about?

389
00:18:36.280 --> 00:18:39.600
Well, by default,
if you enable Exchange Active Sync for

390
00:18:39.600 --> 00:18:43.310
a user, they can connect any
mobile device they want.

391
00:18:43.310 --> 00:18:44.880
It's turned on for them,
they can connect whenever.

392
00:18:44.880 --> 00:18:49.430
So, they might have iPhones and iPads,
they might have Windows mobile phones,

393
00:18:49.430 --> 00:18:53.000
they might have Android Phones, tablets,
whatever they're connecting it all.

394
00:18:53.000 --> 00:18:55.850
They can go crazy, but
we know that some devices

395
00:18:55.850 --> 00:18:59.680
that some devices might be more secure
than others and in our IT department,

396
00:18:59.680 --> 00:19:02.100
we might only want to
support certain devices.

397
00:19:02.100 --> 00:19:07.980
Maybe you tell your employees, alright,
we're gonna support any Nokia Lumia Phone.

398
00:19:07.980 --> 00:19:10.840
And we'll support any iPhone but

399
00:19:10.840 --> 00:19:14.120
we'll only support Samsung Android
phones and that's it.

400
00:19:15.170 --> 00:19:17.200
Well, what if somebody goes and
they get a Nexus, or

401
00:19:17.200 --> 00:19:19.310
they get some other kind of phone and
they want to hook it up.

402
00:19:19.310 --> 00:19:20.360
Well, by default, they can.

403
00:19:20.360 --> 00:19:21.810
There's nothing stopping them.

404
00:19:21.810 --> 00:19:24.930
But, we can create access settings.

405
00:19:24.930 --> 00:19:27.900
Access settings that let us pick and
choose which phones and

406
00:19:27.900 --> 00:19:29.420
devices get approved.

407
00:19:29.420 --> 00:19:31.620
So you'll see the two
different options we've got.

408
00:19:31.620 --> 00:19:33.640
Option one is to set up a quarantine.

409
00:19:33.640 --> 00:19:37.740
A quarantine is, we say anyone can
connect a phone, but it's gonna go into

410
00:19:37.740 --> 00:19:43.020
the quarantine until I decide
whether to approve it or decline it.

411
00:19:43.020 --> 00:19:46.180
So this will pool up, and as an admin
you'll have to go in once a day or

412
00:19:46.180 --> 00:19:48.410
however often, and
choose to approve phones.

413
00:19:48.410 --> 00:19:50.840
And now,
it's you controlling what devices get in.

414
00:19:52.300 --> 00:19:56.530
Option two is you can define access rules
that specifically state types of hardware,

415
00:19:56.530 --> 00:19:58.040
types of devices that you want to allow.

416
00:19:58.040 --> 00:20:00.630
I'll add a rule here, so
you can see an example.

417
00:20:00.630 --> 00:20:04.180
When I create device access,
you can specify a device family.

418
00:20:04.180 --> 00:20:06.150
And so I can browse and pick that family.

419
00:20:06.150 --> 00:20:08.780
Now all families is kind of the default.

420
00:20:08.780 --> 00:20:12.320
As we create our own families
in here we'll start to see more.

421
00:20:12.320 --> 00:20:13.800
Right now I've just got
that one set to all.

422
00:20:13.800 --> 00:20:17.100
So I'll say all families, and
then you can specify particular models.

423
00:20:17.100 --> 00:20:20.860
Now I don't have any models defined
in my system so that's blank for me.

424
00:20:20.860 --> 00:20:24.590
So this one is basically
going to be everything.

425
00:20:24.590 --> 00:20:29.410
And here's where we can say allow access,
block access, or quarantine access.

426
00:20:29.410 --> 00:20:30.770
And if we want to quarantine,

427
00:20:30.770 --> 00:20:34.550
that means they can connect, it'll go into
quarantine, and then we have to go in and

428
00:20:34.550 --> 00:20:36.230
actually approve that
to be able to connect.

429
00:20:36.230 --> 00:20:37.730
They'll just end up right there.

430
00:20:37.730 --> 00:20:40.690
Otherwise, we can specify
particular models.

431
00:20:40.690 --> 00:20:43.810
And once that's done, we can say,
all right, if it's an iPhone or

432
00:20:43.810 --> 00:20:45.330
iOS, we allow it.

433
00:20:45.330 --> 00:20:47.740
Or if it's a Nokia Lumina, we allow it.

434
00:20:47.740 --> 00:20:50.790
Or I can say Nokia Luminas,
and then specific models,

435
00:20:50.790 --> 00:20:54.230
maybe I just want the 520 and
920 and that's it.

436
00:20:54.230 --> 00:20:58.920
So we can punch those in and it'll
approve those, or I just want Android,

437
00:20:58.920 --> 00:21:01.150
Nexus, and Samsung Galaxy's.

438
00:21:01.150 --> 00:21:02.180
You punch those in.

439
00:21:02.180 --> 00:21:06.450
So you can be really specific to
dictate which devices are supported

440
00:21:06.450 --> 00:21:07.990
in your environment.

441
00:21:07.990 --> 00:21:10.350
Now, this list is empty by default.

442
00:21:10.350 --> 00:21:12.920
So I don't really have any
device families or models.

443
00:21:12.920 --> 00:21:16.470
And if you click the learn more link,
it'll take you to Microsoft site.

444
00:21:16.470 --> 00:21:19.350
And they explain how to add more in.

445
00:21:19.350 --> 00:21:22.450
And when it comes to adding these in,
the reason they don't put them in there

446
00:21:22.450 --> 00:21:24.330
automatically is that
they change all the time.

447
00:21:24.330 --> 00:21:26.600
There's new devices being
released all the time.

448
00:21:26.600 --> 00:21:29.540
And so you gotta put them in based
on their hardware identifiers so

449
00:21:29.540 --> 00:21:30.390
that you can recognize it.

450
00:21:30.390 --> 00:21:32.990
So they kind of walk you through
that process of getting them added.

451
00:21:32.990 --> 00:21:35.890
But it is a neat function of
Exchange Active Sync to be able to limit

452
00:21:35.890 --> 00:21:37.649
the types of devices that can connect.

453
00:21:39.820 --> 00:21:42.740
And then like I said on the mobile device
policies we can always create more than

454
00:21:42.740 --> 00:21:43.460
one policy.

455
00:21:43.460 --> 00:21:47.930
As you add more policies in, you dictate
what that policy is going to be.

456
00:21:47.930 --> 00:21:49.930
And then you can attach
that to different people.

457
00:21:49.930 --> 00:21:53.160
You can use the PowerShell
to apply to entire OU's.

458
00:21:53.160 --> 00:21:54.760
So different departments
have different settings.

459
00:21:54.760 --> 00:21:57.080
There's a lot of flexibility there.

460
00:21:57.080 --> 00:22:00.750
So this is a fully featured mobile
device management MDM suite.

461
00:22:00.750 --> 00:22:05.520
The only thing that it doesn't do is it
doesn't give us the ability to install

462
00:22:05.520 --> 00:22:08.920
apps on people's phones, or
uninstall apps on people's phones.

463
00:22:08.920 --> 00:22:10.240
We didn't see that.

464
00:22:10.240 --> 00:22:12.540
For that we need a full MDM suite, and

465
00:22:12.540 --> 00:22:15.180
there's plenty of third party
providers out there for that.

466
00:22:15.180 --> 00:22:17.400
But most people don't need
that level of functionality.

467
00:22:17.400 --> 00:22:19.000
On a bring your own device,

468
00:22:19.000 --> 00:22:22.090
we typically want end users to still be
able to run their own applications right.

469
00:22:22.090 --> 00:22:23.520
It's their device, they paid for it.

470
00:22:23.520 --> 00:22:26.770
They might still wanna install their
own apps, so we leave that be.

471
00:22:26.770 --> 00:22:29.470
We just wanna make sure that the device
is at least secured with a PIN and

472
00:22:29.470 --> 00:22:31.630
password to be able to secure the system.

473
00:22:31.630 --> 00:22:34.690
So that's basically the key components
there of that mobile device.

474
00:22:37.181 --> 00:22:41.090
Now, other than that, that's basically
it for mobile device management.

475
00:22:41.090 --> 00:22:43.200
Just be aware that it
does use auto-discover.

476
00:22:43.200 --> 00:22:44.920
So we gotta make sure that
auto-discover is configured.

477
00:22:44.920 --> 00:22:48.970
If you haven't already, check out our,
two part auto-discover episode that we did

478
00:22:48.970 --> 00:22:51.270
that kind of covered how
to get that configured.

479
00:22:51.270 --> 00:22:54.050
All mobile devices
are treated as external,

480
00:22:54.050 --> 00:22:55.380
because they're not joined to your domain.

481
00:22:55.380 --> 00:22:58.320
So their gonna look for DNS, And
find your servers that way, so

482
00:22:58.320 --> 00:22:59.650
make sure that you've got that.

483
00:22:59.650 --> 00:23:02.550
Also be aware of the problem
that I ran into where

484
00:23:02.550 --> 00:23:05.010
I didn't know what DNS my phone was using.

485
00:23:05.010 --> 00:23:07.840
It was on a different network, so
I had to punch in my server by IP.

486
00:23:07.840 --> 00:23:09.470
That's not ideal, right?

487
00:23:09.470 --> 00:23:13.540
We wanna make sure that our DNS
names are able to be looked up from

488
00:23:13.540 --> 00:23:14.780
outside of the network.

489
00:23:14.780 --> 00:23:17.075
So you gotta make sure your
DNS structure is proper.

490
00:23:17.075 --> 00:23:20.330
But other than that you've got an MDM
in place and you're ready to rock.

491
00:23:21.412 --> 00:23:24.630
All right well in this episode we got a
chance to see the mobile device management

492
00:23:24.630 --> 00:23:25.520
inside of Exchange.

493
00:23:25.520 --> 00:23:27.120
We saw how to add a mobile device.

494
00:23:27.120 --> 00:23:30.640
We saw how to create a security policy and
how to remote wipe a device.

495
00:23:30.640 --> 00:23:34.160
So we got a chance to see some of those
different settings and how they function.

496
00:23:34.160 --> 00:23:36.100
And all in all not too painful.

497
00:23:36.100 --> 00:23:37.570
So definitely a cool feature.

498
00:23:37.570 --> 00:23:40.040
One you'll want to make use of
out there in the real world.

499
00:23:40.040 --> 00:23:42.870
All right well I hope you
guys enjoyed the episode.

500
00:23:42.870 --> 00:23:46.481
signing off for ITProTV I'm Don Pizette
and I'll see you next time.

501
00:23:46.481 --> 00:23:52.620
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to configure high availability for Client Access Servers in Exchange 2013. He walks the viewers through the process of installing and configuring the Network Load Balancing feature found in Windows 2012.
episodes.title: Network Load Balancing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.138
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.138 --> 00:00:12.973
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:12.973 --> 00:00:14.876
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.876 --> 00:00:15.877
I'm your host,

5
00:00:15.877 --> 00:00:20.490
Don Pezet back again with another
episode of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:20.990
In this episode,

7
00:00:20.990 --> 00:00:25.610
we're gonna be taking a look at how to
make client access servers redundant.

8
00:00:25.610 --> 00:00:27.180
Now that's really important to us,

9
00:00:27.180 --> 00:00:31.980
because client access servers are kinda
the front face, what our end users see.

10
00:00:31.980 --> 00:00:35.000
When they fire up Microsoft Outlook,
when they go to Outlook Web App,

11
00:00:35.000 --> 00:00:39.280
when they want to access their email,
they talk to a client access server.

12
00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:42.470
Now the client access server's turning
around and talking to a mailbox server.

13
00:00:42.470 --> 00:00:44.870
And the mailbox servers
need to be redundant too.

14
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:47.450
But the way we make them redundant
is through what's called a database

15
00:00:47.450 --> 00:00:48.370
availability group.

16
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:50.520
We'll have a separate
episode that covers that.

17
00:00:50.520 --> 00:00:53.230
But for this episode,
we wanna cover Client Access Servers.

18
00:00:53.230 --> 00:00:57.239
Now Client Access Servers are kind of
unique because they don't really have

19
00:00:57.239 --> 00:00:58.220
any data.

20
00:00:58.220 --> 00:01:01.600
When a user connects, they connect
to the Client Access Server, and

21
00:01:01.600 --> 00:01:06.310
it proxies them back to the right mailbox
server, to where the real data is.

22
00:01:06.310 --> 00:01:08.440
So at the end of the day,

23
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:12.800
a client doesn't really care which
Client Access Server they connect to.

24
00:01:12.800 --> 00:01:14.820
They do care about which mailbox server.

25
00:01:14.820 --> 00:01:17.739
Because if they connect to a mailbox
server that doesn't have their mailbox,

26
00:01:17.739 --> 00:01:19.028
they're not gonna see any email.

27
00:01:19.028 --> 00:01:21.770
But they can connect to any
Client Access Server and

28
00:01:21.770 --> 00:01:24.269
it will send them to
the right mailbox server.

29
00:01:24.269 --> 00:01:27.561
So on a Client Access Server the easiest
way to make them redundant is to have

30
00:01:27.561 --> 00:01:28.390
more than one.

31
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:31.138
You just bring up more than one
Client Access Server now you've redundant.

32
00:01:31.138 --> 00:01:35.635
The only problem with that is it's not
like an automatic failover, right?

33
00:01:35.635 --> 00:01:37.225
Take my example here.

34
00:01:37.225 --> 00:01:40.325
In my system,
I've got two exchange servers, right?

35
00:01:40.325 --> 00:01:43.105
I've got Exchange Server 01 and
Exchange Server 02.

36
00:01:43.105 --> 00:01:47.132
If I go to my server list here they're
both client axis servers, right?

37
00:01:47.132 --> 00:01:49.782
So I know that I could
fire up a web browser and

38
00:01:49.782 --> 00:01:54.862
I could point to lab-EXCHSERV01 and
get into OWA.

39
00:01:54.862 --> 00:01:57.472
And in fact,
I'm logged into with OWA right here.

40
00:01:57.472 --> 00:02:04.050
But just the same, I could point to
lab-EXCHSERV02 and log into OWA.

41
00:02:04.050 --> 00:02:07.220
Here, I'm logged in as Jane Smith
on this one but same thing, right?

42
00:02:07.220 --> 00:02:10.290
It doesn't really matter which
Client Axis Server I connect to.

43
00:02:10.290 --> 00:02:11.670
So rule number one for

44
00:02:11.670 --> 00:02:14.450
redundancy with a Client Axis Server
is just to have more that one, right?

45
00:02:14.450 --> 00:02:16.710
You should always have two or
more for that redundancy.

46
00:02:17.770 --> 00:02:21.650
But if Server 1 were to fail,
if it goes offline,

47
00:02:21.650 --> 00:02:25.900
as an end user I would browse to it and
I would get a failed connect.

48
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:28.440
Then I would have to know
to switch to Server 2.

49
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:31.135
Well, what if I would want
to make that automatic?

50
00:02:31.135 --> 00:02:32.629
We can do that.
We can do that and

51
00:02:32.629 --> 00:02:34.420
actually done really easy.

52
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:36.500
It's not like we have to set
up some crazy cluster or

53
00:02:36.500 --> 00:02:38.030
have shared storage or anything.

54
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:42.740
We can set up what's called
Windows Load Balancing Services, WLBS, or

55
00:02:42.740 --> 00:02:45.105
Network Load Balancing, NLB.

56
00:02:45.105 --> 00:02:46.290
There's two different names for it.

57
00:02:46.290 --> 00:02:48.820
You'll see it written different
ways on Microsoft's website.

58
00:02:48.820 --> 00:02:52.170
On the exam they'll call it
Network Load Balancing or NLB.

59
00:02:52.170 --> 00:02:56.140
With Network Load Balancing, we create
a virtual server, like a fake server.

60
00:02:56.140 --> 00:02:57.960
The clients go to the fake server and

61
00:02:57.960 --> 00:03:00.670
it then directs them to
the real servers behind it.

62
00:03:00.670 --> 00:03:02.300
So now I can have a fake server and

63
00:03:02.300 --> 00:03:04.920
people don't have to remember that they're
connecting to server number two or

64
00:03:04.920 --> 00:03:08.410
server number one,
they connect to the fake server.

65
00:03:08.410 --> 00:03:11.150
Let me show you how it works,
it's really not that hard.

66
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:13.300
We're gonna start here
on one of our servers.

67
00:03:13.300 --> 00:03:15.670
And so here I am on Lab-Exchserv01.

68
00:03:15.670 --> 00:03:17.409
Doesn't really matter
which one I start on,

69
00:03:17.409 --> 00:03:20.350
because at the end of the day they're
all gonna get balanced, right?

70
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:23.910
But I'm gonna start on Server 01, and
I'm gonna go up here to Manage, and

71
00:03:23.910 --> 00:03:26.460
I'm gonna do Add Roles and Features.

72
00:03:26.460 --> 00:03:30.880
And what we're gonna do is just add
the Network Load Balancing feature.

73
00:03:30.880 --> 00:03:32.870
When you move through the setup here,

74
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:35.870
it's gonna offer to install
various roles on our server.

75
00:03:35.870 --> 00:03:37.650
And we'll have the option
install features and

76
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:40.490
when you look at the rolls the low
balancing is not in there.

77
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:44.180
But when you get into the features
you can skim down the list and

78
00:03:44.180 --> 00:03:47.180
in here you'll find
Network Load Balancing.

79
00:03:47.180 --> 00:03:49.680
Now we're going to use it for
Exchange Client Access.

80
00:03:49.680 --> 00:03:50.970
But you could use it for anything.

81
00:03:50.970 --> 00:03:54.670
It works with IIS, Remote Desktop like
if you're setting up terminal servers.

82
00:03:54.670 --> 00:03:58.110
You can load balance any traffic
with Network Load Balancing.

83
00:03:58.110 --> 00:03:59.810
We just want to use it for
our Client Access Servers.

84
00:03:59.810 --> 00:04:02.100
So I'm going to choose that
Network Load Balancing and

85
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:03.480
I'm going to add that feature.

86
00:04:04.790 --> 00:04:09.400
Now, once its installed we'll
have the ability to set up a load

87
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:13.660
balancing cluster, which is a very simple
form of cluster that just directs traffic

88
00:04:13.660 --> 00:04:14.540
between these nodes.

89
00:04:14.540 --> 00:04:16.180
So I'm gonna go ahead and
get these installed.

90
00:04:16.180 --> 00:04:20.820
Now, technically, I don't have to install,
and it'll be on the second node.

91
00:04:20.820 --> 00:04:23.990
When I go to set it up,
it'll push the settings over to it.

92
00:04:23.990 --> 00:04:26.420
But it does make things go
a little bit faster to do it.

93
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:29.950
So I'm gonna jump over to my second
node and do the same thing over here.

94
00:04:29.950 --> 00:04:32.413
I'm just gonna go to add roles and
features and

95
00:04:32.413 --> 00:04:34.316
I'm gonna add in that NLB feature.

96
00:04:34.316 --> 00:04:37.870
But like I said, I don't technically
have to do this, it would do it for me.

97
00:04:37.870 --> 00:04:41.750
I just want to speed things up a little
bit, so I'm gonna add that feature and

98
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:43.490
get that installed here.

99
00:04:43.490 --> 00:04:47.390
Now as part of that feature it's
installing the management tools for

100
00:04:47.390 --> 00:04:48.730
NLB and that's what I really need.

101
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:54.160
I can go into the management tools and
I can define a new load balancing cluster.

102
00:04:54.160 --> 00:04:56.440
And when I define that new cluster
I point to the servers and

103
00:04:56.440 --> 00:04:59.540
if they don't have NLB installed it
will install it there for me, right.

104
00:04:59.540 --> 00:05:00.870
It just takes time.

105
00:05:00.870 --> 00:05:03.685
And then it sets up the various
other settings to make it balanced.

106
00:05:03.685 --> 00:05:06.290
So that's what I'm doing right
here is getting that installed.

107
00:05:06.290 --> 00:05:07.605
So there we go, we got it.

108
00:05:07.605 --> 00:05:11.958
Once you've got it installed in your
server manager, you can go to tools and

109
00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:17.320
under tools you'll have the Network
Load Balancing Manager, or NLB manager.

110
00:05:17.320 --> 00:05:18.380
And we can fire that up, and

111
00:05:18.380 --> 00:05:21.800
that's where we go to configure
NLB clusters, all right?

112
00:05:21.800 --> 00:05:26.150
I'm gonna call it a cluster, and
I know people get a little paranoid or

113
00:05:26.150 --> 00:05:29.440
panicky on that one, cuz clusters
are notoriously difficult to set up.

114
00:05:29.440 --> 00:05:31.919
You'll see that this type of cluster
is actually really easy to set up.

115
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:35.770
So the first thing I'll notice is that
under Network Load Balancing clusters,

116
00:05:35.770 --> 00:05:36.320
I don't have any.

117
00:05:36.320 --> 00:05:38.980
It's just kinda empty, so
I need to create a new one.

118
00:05:38.980 --> 00:05:42.100
And I'm just gonna right-click on that and
choose New Cluster.

119
00:05:42.100 --> 00:05:44.100
And now we can define a host.

120
00:05:44.100 --> 00:05:45.780
We need to connect to one host and

121
00:05:45.780 --> 00:05:48.200
it's gonna be the person
who starts the cluster.

122
00:05:48.200 --> 00:05:49.740
And it doesn't really matter who I pick.

123
00:05:49.740 --> 00:05:51.950
I could pick node 1, node 2, whatever.

124
00:05:51.950 --> 00:05:54.610
'Cause at the end of the day I'm going to
add the other nodes and it all balances,

125
00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:59.382
but I'm going to start with
my lab-exchserve01, and

126
00:05:59.382 --> 00:06:02.680
I'll hit connect, and
it's going to connect up to that server.

127
00:06:02.680 --> 00:06:04.907
And see what it's pulling here,
the IP address of that server.

128
00:06:04.907 --> 00:06:08.290
That server is 192.168.0.911.

129
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:10.020
That IP address is important.

130
00:06:10.020 --> 00:06:12.420
Now, when we do Network Load Balancing,

131
00:06:12.420 --> 00:06:15.070
it's a good idea to have
multiple network adapters.

132
00:06:15.070 --> 00:06:18.120
Now, I've only got one network adapter
in mine, so that's all it's showing.

133
00:06:18.120 --> 00:06:20.470
If I had more than one network adapter,
they would show up here.

134
00:06:20.470 --> 00:06:23.530
Now, why is it important to have
more than one network adapter?

135
00:06:23.530 --> 00:06:27.142
Well, if I wanna remotely manage
one node in this cluster,

136
00:06:27.142 --> 00:06:30.914
I don't wanna connect to node 2,
I wanna connect to node 1.

137
00:06:30.914 --> 00:06:33.161
Well if they've all got
a shared connection,

138
00:06:33.161 --> 00:06:35.360
how do I know which one
I'm gonna connect to?

139
00:06:35.360 --> 00:06:37.430
I'm gonna get balanced,
I might connect to different ones.

140
00:06:37.430 --> 00:06:40.200
So by having a dedicated adapter for
management purposes,

141
00:06:40.200 --> 00:06:42.270
it makes it really easy to manage that.

142
00:06:42.270 --> 00:06:45.680
I don't have to have the second adapter,
but it is generally a good idea.

143
00:06:45.680 --> 00:06:48.470
But I'm gonna stick with this one and
I'll go ahead and move forward.

144
00:06:48.470 --> 00:06:50.980
If I had more than one, I'd be picking
the one that was gonna be used for

145
00:06:50.980 --> 00:06:51.620
configuration.

146
00:06:52.990 --> 00:06:53.840
All right.

147
00:06:53.840 --> 00:06:59.100
Then it's listing the cluster information,
I have to set a priority.

148
00:06:59.100 --> 00:07:00.860
In a cluster, you always have a master.

149
00:07:00.860 --> 00:07:05.840
Somebody is the main node in that cluster,
and it picks that based on a priority.

150
00:07:05.840 --> 00:07:07.450
The first node you add is priority one,

151
00:07:07.450 --> 00:07:09.550
the second node is priority two,
and so on.

152
00:07:09.550 --> 00:07:12.780
But you might have one server that's maybe
better hardware than the others, and

153
00:07:12.780 --> 00:07:14.000
you want that to be the primary.

154
00:07:14.000 --> 00:07:18.600
So you could set it's priority to one, and
you'll see that it goes from one to 32.

155
00:07:18.600 --> 00:07:22.070
And that's our first indicator that
when we build a Load Balancing Cluster,

156
00:07:22.070 --> 00:07:24.400
we have a maximum of 32 nodes, right?

157
00:07:24.400 --> 00:07:27.649
So you can have up to 32 client access
servers that you're balancing across.

158
00:07:29.100 --> 00:07:31.620
Then it's got the dedicated IP address for

159
00:07:31.620 --> 00:07:33.920
this system, 192.68.0.11,
I'm fine with that.

160
00:07:33.920 --> 00:07:36.860
And my initial host state is started.

161
00:07:36.860 --> 00:07:40.340
When this system comes up, it's gonna
start up, it's not gonna go into standby.

162
00:07:40.340 --> 00:07:44.940
Now this dedicated IP address, that's
the dedicated IP address of this node.

163
00:07:44.940 --> 00:07:47.480
I'm gonna have a shared
IP address in a minute.

164
00:07:47.480 --> 00:07:48.620
That'll be the virtual one,

165
00:07:48.620 --> 00:07:51.370
the one that's shared across all the nodes
that my clients are gonna connect to.

166
00:07:53.330 --> 00:07:56.600
And here on this next screen is
where I pick that shared IP.

167
00:07:56.600 --> 00:07:59.191
It's gonna create basically like
a fake server on the network.

168
00:07:59.191 --> 00:08:01.611
And our clients are gonna
connect to that fake server.

169
00:08:01.611 --> 00:08:04.691
So this is the shared IP that's
gonna bounce between my nodes.

170
00:08:04.691 --> 00:08:05.951
I'm gonna go and hit add.

171
00:08:05.951 --> 00:08:07.611
And I'll punch in an IP address.

172
00:08:07.611 --> 00:08:11.517
Now it needs to be an IP that's
in the same range as my nodes, so

173
00:08:11.517 --> 00:08:12.920
they can see it.

174
00:08:12.920 --> 00:08:16.316
So, I'm gonna give mine 192.168.0.222.

175
00:08:16.316 --> 00:08:21.380
My individual node was 192.168.0.11,
so it'll be able to see this.

176
00:08:21.380 --> 00:08:25.583
And it's subnet mask, I could do
a IPv6 balancerm if I wanted to.

177
00:08:25.583 --> 00:08:27.630
But in my case, I'm gonna do IPv4.

178
00:08:31.213 --> 00:08:35.085
And we had a question in the chat room
about if you had a single interface,

179
00:08:35.085 --> 00:08:36.496
could you add a second IP?

180
00:08:36.496 --> 00:08:38.980
Well, you could, but
you actually don't have to.

181
00:08:38.980 --> 00:08:42.834
My node is gonna keep
the 192.168.0.11 address.

182
00:08:42.834 --> 00:08:45.314
So in the future,
if I wanna manage this one node,

183
00:08:45.314 --> 00:08:49.290
I could always connect in on that
.11 address, it will still have it.

184
00:08:49.290 --> 00:08:51.163
If I connect to .222, I'll get balance.

185
00:08:51.163 --> 00:08:54.480
I don't know where I'm gonna go, but
.11 will always send me to this one node.

186
00:08:54.480 --> 00:08:58.017
I just have to remember the IP and you
could create DNS entries to take care of

187
00:08:58.017 --> 00:09:00.668
that, there's a number of
ways to get around that too.

188
00:09:00.668 --> 00:09:03.400
So .222, that's gonna be my shared one.

189
00:09:04.670 --> 00:09:08.483
And I'll move forward and here,
it's got that configuration for me and

190
00:09:08.483 --> 00:09:10.495
I need to give it a Full Internet name.

191
00:09:10.495 --> 00:09:11.868
It's gonna be a fake server.

192
00:09:11.868 --> 00:09:14.510
So it's gonna have to have a DNS entry,
so people can find it and

193
00:09:14.510 --> 00:09:15.930
I need to give it a full name.

194
00:09:15.930 --> 00:09:23.050
Well, my servers are called lab-exchserv
and then a number to identify the node.

195
00:09:23.050 --> 00:09:25.079
This is gonna be the core
of my cluster though, so

196
00:09:25.079 --> 00:09:26.669
I'm just gonna leave the number off.

197
00:09:26.669 --> 00:09:32.258
This'll be lab-exchserv, but
notice it wants a full name,

198
00:09:32.258 --> 00:09:35.490
so I need to add .lab.itpro.tv.

199
00:09:35.490 --> 00:09:39.653
I need to add that, so it knows its full
domain name and I'm gonna have to go and

200
00:09:39.653 --> 00:09:42.270
create a DNS entry for
this here in a minute.

201
00:09:42.270 --> 00:09:46.543
That points to 192.168.0.222.

202
00:09:46.543 --> 00:09:50.089
Now when you set up load balancing,
there's three different modes that it can

203
00:09:50.089 --> 00:09:53.085
operate in and
they each kinda have their pros and cons.

204
00:09:53.085 --> 00:09:55.191
Unicast mode is really the preferred one,
but

205
00:09:55.191 --> 00:09:57.520
it generates a little more
traffic on the network.

206
00:09:57.520 --> 00:10:01.154
Basically, when somebody
connects to 192.168.222,

207
00:10:01.154 --> 00:10:03.449
the load balancer's gonna look at that and

208
00:10:03.449 --> 00:10:08.010
it's gonna evenly distribute the user
across all the servers in the cluster.

209
00:10:08.010 --> 00:10:10.080
So if there's two servers in the cluster,

210
00:10:10.080 --> 00:10:13.630
it'll send 50% of the traffic
to 1 node and 50% to the other.

211
00:10:14.630 --> 00:10:19.505
It doesn't wanna have to load balance
every single packet from that client,

212
00:10:19.505 --> 00:10:24.380
so what it does in unicast mode is it
actually tells that client the MAC address

213
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:26.713
of a particular node in the cluster.

214
00:10:26.713 --> 00:10:29.433
So from now on,
they'll just go straight to that node.

215
00:10:29.433 --> 00:10:31.360
That's normally what we want.

216
00:10:31.360 --> 00:10:34.080
But if a node fails, we

217
00:10:34.080 --> 00:10:37.860
might have cached MAC addresses that take
a little while to flip over to the other.

218
00:10:37.860 --> 00:10:40.140
So unicast is very reliable, but

219
00:10:40.140 --> 00:10:43.330
it doesn't necessarily failover
as fast as some of the others.

220
00:10:43.330 --> 00:10:48.587
Multicast and IGMP Multicast,
these two, they failover instantly.

221
00:10:48.587 --> 00:10:51.654
You have this one multicast
address you go to and

222
00:10:51.654 --> 00:10:55.411
then the nodes can pick up that
traffic and receive it, but

223
00:10:55.411 --> 00:11:00.670
not every switch and not every router
allows us to do IGMP traffic across it.

224
00:11:00.670 --> 00:11:03.643
So if IGMP is not supported on your
network, you'll need to do unicast.

225
00:11:03.643 --> 00:11:07.048
Unicast always works, but
the failover time might be five,

226
00:11:07.048 --> 00:11:10.380
ten seconds and
I know that doesn't sound like a lot.

227
00:11:10.380 --> 00:11:14.045
But if you have really critical
software and that's too much time,

228
00:11:14.045 --> 00:11:16.049
then you don't wanna go that route.

229
00:11:16.049 --> 00:11:19.973
Well, for a client access server,
we're talking about Outlook Web App,

230
00:11:19.973 --> 00:11:21.860
which is just HTTP traffic.

231
00:11:21.860 --> 00:11:26.252
We might be talking about POP3 or
IMAP4 and all of those can handle a 10 or

232
00:11:26.252 --> 00:11:29.334
15 second outage,
that's not a big deal to them.

233
00:11:29.334 --> 00:11:32.550
So I'm gonna stick to unicast,
because it's the most reliable.

234
00:11:35.329 --> 00:11:37.310
Now, the big decision.

235
00:11:38.840 --> 00:11:42.680
If I have two network adapters,
one for management and one for

236
00:11:42.680 --> 00:11:45.210
the cluster,
I can leave it at the default.

237
00:11:45.210 --> 00:11:48.950
The default is,
it's gonna load balance all traffic.

238
00:11:48.950 --> 00:11:53.960
Anything that I send to 192.168.0.222
will get balanced across these nodes and

239
00:11:53.960 --> 00:11:55.280
off we go.

240
00:11:55.280 --> 00:11:58.010
And it's an easy config,
I just leave it at the default.

241
00:11:58.010 --> 00:12:00.557
But if I've only got one network adapter,

242
00:12:00.557 --> 00:12:03.688
I need to be careful about
what I'm load balancing.

243
00:12:03.688 --> 00:12:05.860
I don't necessarily want
to load balance everything.

244
00:12:05.860 --> 00:12:11.110
And so we can take this rule and delete it
and add new ones or change it and specify

245
00:12:11.110 --> 00:12:14.510
exactly what we want to load balance and
then leave everything else off.

246
00:12:15.540 --> 00:12:18.363
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna add a new rule and

247
00:12:18.363 --> 00:12:20.729
I'm gonna specify what I'm balancing.

248
00:12:20.729 --> 00:12:22.769
Now, it's asking for what IP address.

249
00:12:22.769 --> 00:12:25.620
If your cluster has more than one IP,
you can pick from those here.

250
00:12:25.620 --> 00:12:27.044
But in my case, I've only got one IP.

251
00:12:27.044 --> 00:12:30.050
So, I'm not gonna worry about that and
then I specify the port ranges.

252
00:12:31.140 --> 00:12:33.444
Now, we need to think about
what we're balancing.

253
00:12:33.444 --> 00:12:36.608
On a client access server,
what do you have?

254
00:12:36.608 --> 00:12:38.460
Well, you have Outlook Web App.

255
00:12:38.460 --> 00:12:41.638
And maybe the Exchange Control Panel or
the Exchange Admin Center,

256
00:12:41.638 --> 00:12:43.208
a couple other things like that.

257
00:12:43.208 --> 00:12:46.225
They all run on port 80 and port 443.

258
00:12:46.225 --> 00:12:50.958
80 is unsecure and Exchange will
actually do a redirect over to secure.

259
00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:55.875
So I'm gonna add a rule that says,
I load balance port 80 and it's just TCP.

260
00:12:55.875 --> 00:12:58.779
You could say, if it was TCP and
UDP or if it was both,

261
00:12:58.779 --> 00:13:03.270
you can specify that there and
then you can specify a filtering mode.

262
00:13:03.270 --> 00:13:08.250
Now the default filtering mode is
that we have multiple hosts, but

263
00:13:08.250 --> 00:13:11.110
we're gonna try and
connect somebody to a single host.

264
00:13:11.110 --> 00:13:14.120
And when they reconnect,
they're gonna stay on that host.

265
00:13:14.120 --> 00:13:16.087
You don't want every time
somebody clicks on a page for

266
00:13:16.087 --> 00:13:18.366
them to jump over to another host,
their session would reset.

267
00:13:18.366 --> 00:13:20.590
They'd have to re log in,
we don't want that.

268
00:13:20.590 --> 00:13:24.019
So instead, we want them always to go back
to the same node unless that node fails.

269
00:13:24.019 --> 00:13:25.850
So we've got single affinity.

270
00:13:25.850 --> 00:13:29.015
When you connect, you hit that node and
you stay on that node for

271
00:13:29.015 --> 00:13:31.488
the rest of your session,
but you can change it.

272
00:13:31.488 --> 00:13:34.640
You can balance it based on network,
you can set a timeout.

273
00:13:34.640 --> 00:13:37.610
We can manipulate how that
functions if we want, but

274
00:13:37.610 --> 00:13:39.913
the default here is to go multiple host.

275
00:13:39.913 --> 00:13:42.810
Now you can do single host,
you can disable the port range.

276
00:13:42.810 --> 00:13:46.159
There's a couple other mechanisms there,
but the default is typically what we want.

277
00:13:46.159 --> 00:13:48.680
So, I'm just doing port 80 and
then I'm gonna come back in and

278
00:13:48.680 --> 00:13:49.620
add a few other things.

279
00:13:49.620 --> 00:13:52.679
Now it's gonna warn me, it's overlapping
with that role that we've already got.

280
00:13:52.679 --> 00:13:54.080
So, I need to get rid of that role role.

281
00:13:54.080 --> 00:13:55.510
I can just edit that role and change it.

282
00:13:55.510 --> 00:14:01.018
I can just change this one to be port 80
and then add in my other roles as needed.

283
00:14:01.018 --> 00:14:07.155
So there's 80 and then I'll need to do
the same thing for 443 and punch that in.

284
00:14:07.155 --> 00:14:11.433
So that's gonna take care of OWA and the
Exchange Admin Center and all those guys,

285
00:14:11.433 --> 00:14:13.357
I need to think about my other ports.

286
00:14:13.357 --> 00:14:18.596
If I'm doing POP3 or IMAP4,
it might be port 110 or

287
00:14:18.596 --> 00:14:22.731
143, port 597, port 25 for SMTP.

288
00:14:22.731 --> 00:14:24.599
All those other ports that we use,

289
00:14:24.599 --> 00:14:28.100
I would wanna add in the ones
that I'm load balancing.

290
00:14:28.100 --> 00:14:31.195
Anything that's not in this list If
somebody goes to my shared IP on a port

291
00:14:31.195 --> 00:14:34.109
less non-list, the traffic just
gets thrown away and that's it.

292
00:14:34.109 --> 00:14:37.080
So, it's almost like
a mini firewall in a way.

293
00:14:38.590 --> 00:14:40.521
So, I'm just gonna add in
my web traffic for now.

294
00:14:40.521 --> 00:14:43.568
You guys know,
you can add in other ports as you need it.

295
00:14:43.568 --> 00:14:46.120
That's gonna create my cluster.

296
00:14:46.120 --> 00:14:49.956
Now I've got a one node cluster, which
is pretty much completely useless, but

297
00:14:49.956 --> 00:14:53.409
it is gonna create that and get it put
in place and I've got that server.

298
00:14:53.409 --> 00:14:55.750
There's the virtual IP
that's attached to it.

299
00:14:55.750 --> 00:14:59.524
Now, I'm gonna wait for that to turn
green and then I'll add a second node and

300
00:14:59.524 --> 00:15:02.040
that's when this cluster
becomes really useful.

301
00:15:02.040 --> 00:15:07.200
Then I'll have two nodes and the traffic
is gonna get balanced across them evenly,

302
00:15:07.200 --> 00:15:09.750
50% to 1, 50% to the other.

303
00:15:09.750 --> 00:15:14.350
If I bring in a third node, now it's
gonna do 33% on each 1 of them and

304
00:15:14.350 --> 00:15:16.511
distribute across them evenly.

305
00:15:16.511 --> 00:15:20.190
Now, what if you have one server
that's maybe better than the others?

306
00:15:20.190 --> 00:15:22.274
Maybe it's got more memory or so on.

307
00:15:22.274 --> 00:15:25.590
You can actually go in and
tweak the balancing on these.

308
00:15:25.590 --> 00:15:28.671
So when you take a look at them,
you've got your host priority and

309
00:15:28.671 --> 00:15:29.688
other information.

310
00:15:29.688 --> 00:15:34.416
If we start to edit some of these nodes,
you can start to specify that priority

311
00:15:34.416 --> 00:15:37.909
value to manipulate which one
is gonna get more traffic or

312
00:15:37.909 --> 00:15:43.630
less traffic, so that's definitely
something we can do as the system runs.

313
00:15:43.630 --> 00:15:47.261
I just got my little green square on
my nodes, so I'm gonna come in here and

314
00:15:47.261 --> 00:15:48.328
add in another host.

315
00:15:48.328 --> 00:15:54.041
I'm just going to right-click on the
cluster and choose Add Host To Cluster and

316
00:15:54.041 --> 00:15:58.227
I'm gonna put in lab-exchserve02,
my other server.

317
00:15:58.227 --> 00:16:00.996
So, it's gonna connect up to it and
find its IP address.

318
00:16:00.996 --> 00:16:04.430
There it is, it's 192.168.0.12.

319
00:16:04.430 --> 00:16:07.670
Now its gonna connect up and most of
the settings that I had to provide for

320
00:16:07.670 --> 00:16:09.950
the other server,
I don't have to provide here.

321
00:16:09.950 --> 00:16:12.590
Because it's just gonna learn
them from the existing config.

322
00:16:12.590 --> 00:16:14.391
So it's just showing me my IP.

323
00:16:14.391 --> 00:16:17.840
I can set a priority, and
then I can set its status.

324
00:16:17.840 --> 00:16:21.049
But when I move forward,
see how it didn't ask me for a virtual IP?

325
00:16:21.049 --> 00:16:23.208
It already knows the virtual IP.

326
00:16:23.208 --> 00:16:27.180
And it already knows the ports to forward
because that was what was on other one, so

327
00:16:27.180 --> 00:16:29.110
it's already got that information.

328
00:16:29.110 --> 00:16:31.720
But I could come in and edit these,
and kinda tweak some things.

329
00:16:31.720 --> 00:16:34.600
Notice down here I've got that
handling priority I could change

330
00:16:34.600 --> 00:16:36.380
if we wanted to manipulate these values.

331
00:16:36.380 --> 00:16:39.860
But otherwise right now,
it's doing an equal load.

332
00:16:39.860 --> 00:16:42.549
It's that load that lets me
influence how much traffic it gets.

333
00:16:42.549 --> 00:16:45.882
If I edit that and I go down here
to this load and uncheck it.

334
00:16:45.882 --> 00:16:48.000
See how it's 50% right now?

335
00:16:48.000 --> 00:16:51.750
Maybe I only want this server to get
30% and the other server gets 70%.

336
00:16:51.750 --> 00:16:52.870
So I can manipulate that and

337
00:16:52.870 --> 00:16:56.950
that's what's gonna change
the distribution across these servers.

338
00:16:56.950 --> 00:17:01.005
I'm gonna leave mine equal, though,
cuz my servers are actually identical, so

339
00:17:01.005 --> 00:17:02.966
I don't really care which one we go to.

340
00:17:02.966 --> 00:17:07.186
Now if the network load balancing feature
was not installed on the other server,

341
00:17:07.186 --> 00:17:10.535
it's gonna reach out and install it,
and then once it's done,

342
00:17:10.535 --> 00:17:12.650
it'll bring it into the cluster.

343
00:17:12.650 --> 00:17:16.270
But in my case it is already installed,
so it's just gonna reach out and

344
00:17:16.270 --> 00:17:19.130
it says Pending, it's getting it
configured on the other side, and

345
00:17:19.130 --> 00:17:21.020
it's gonna put it in place.

346
00:17:21.020 --> 00:17:23.520
So that's reaching out and it's doing it.

347
00:17:23.520 --> 00:17:26.730
While we're waiting on that,
I need to create a DNS entry for

348
00:17:26.730 --> 00:17:28.450
this new fake server.

349
00:17:28.450 --> 00:17:33.591
So I'm gonna jump over to my domain
controller where I'm running DNS.

350
00:17:33.591 --> 00:17:39.030
And I'm just gonna jump into my DNS screen
here, and I'll browse into my domain.

351
00:17:39.030 --> 00:17:43.210
And in my DNS records here,
I'll see LAB-EXCHSERV01, LAB-EXCHSERV02,

352
00:17:43.210 --> 00:17:45.090
that's how people are connecting
to them directly.

353
00:17:45.090 --> 00:17:49.070
I'm gonna create a new A record in here,
and

354
00:17:49.070 --> 00:17:54.960
remember I called my cluster LAB-EXCHSERV
and I just didn't put a number on it.

355
00:17:54.960 --> 00:17:57.070
That was gonna be that virtual node.

356
00:17:57.070 --> 00:18:02.756
And I'll put in the IP address
of that node, 192.168.0.222.

357
00:18:02.756 --> 00:18:06.921
So I'm just gonna punch that in,
I can create a reverse record for

358
00:18:06.921 --> 00:18:10.060
it if I want to, and
we'll get that put in place.

359
00:18:10.060 --> 00:18:13.140
So now I've got this server
that's not a real server.

360
00:18:13.140 --> 00:18:17.203
If somebody browses to
lab-exchserv.lab.itpro.tv,

361
00:18:17.203 --> 00:18:20.707
they'll resolve 192.168.0.222.

362
00:18:20.707 --> 00:18:24.330
When they go to that IP,
they hit the load balance cluster.

363
00:18:24.330 --> 00:18:27.008
They hit one of the nodes on that cluster.

364
00:18:27.008 --> 00:18:31.791
And then that node evaluates where traffic
is laid across the other nodes and

365
00:18:31.791 --> 00:18:34.860
sends us to usually the least busy node.

366
00:18:34.860 --> 00:18:37.285
And we get nice load balancing
across our hardware.

367
00:18:37.285 --> 00:18:42.160
So it's pretty cool that we could just
start adding more Client Access servers

368
00:18:42.160 --> 00:18:44.360
and our end users still
go to the same address.

369
00:18:44.360 --> 00:18:47.545
So if we notice our Client Access servers
are getting too busy, we just add another

370
00:18:47.545 --> 00:18:50.780
one and we add another one and add another
one and add more as you need them.

371
00:18:50.780 --> 00:18:52.590
And now your clients are taken care of.

372
00:18:52.590 --> 00:18:56.830
Or if you need to take one out for
maintenance, you can shut one down and

373
00:18:56.830 --> 00:18:58.900
the clients will just get
sent to other servers.

374
00:18:58.900 --> 00:19:00.960
And now you can do your Windows updates or

375
00:19:00.960 --> 00:19:03.965
whatever it is you're doing on that
system and bring it back online.

376
00:19:03.965 --> 00:19:06.905
So it's all hidden to the users
because they connect to

377
00:19:06.905 --> 00:19:08.685
this virtual server right here.

378
00:19:09.995 --> 00:19:13.645
All right,
let's take a look at our status, oh, wait,

379
00:19:13.645 --> 00:19:15.045
this one's still sitting here.

380
00:19:15.045 --> 00:19:16.727
Let's take a look at our status here.

381
00:19:16.727 --> 00:19:19.912
I can see that LAB-EXCHSERV02
is now in the cluster, and

382
00:19:19.912 --> 00:19:22.582
if I look at their status,
the status is Converged.

383
00:19:22.582 --> 00:19:24.224
Converged is what you wanna see.

384
00:19:24.224 --> 00:19:28.312
That means the cluster nodes
are all talking to each other,

385
00:19:28.312 --> 00:19:31.822
they've got the same configuration and
they're all happy.

386
00:19:31.822 --> 00:19:36.510
And since their load is set to 50-50,
half the traffic's getting sent to one and

387
00:19:36.510 --> 00:19:39.010
half the traffic's getting
sent to the other.

388
00:19:39.010 --> 00:19:40.380
Let's see if this is working.

389
00:19:40.380 --> 00:19:43.540
I'm gonna go to a client,
let's see, here's my client.

390
00:19:43.540 --> 00:19:45.990
And let me just close these
Internet Explorer windows.

391
00:19:45.990 --> 00:19:47.790
I wanna start from scratch.

392
00:19:47.790 --> 00:19:51.660
I'm gonna fire up an Internet Explorer
window, and I'm gonna browse

393
00:19:53.590 --> 00:20:00.630
to https://lab-exchserv.lab.itpro.tv.

394
00:20:00.630 --> 00:20:05.063
I'm browsing to that virtual
name that I just defined in DNS,

395
00:20:05.063 --> 00:20:09.258
that's gonna resolve to 192.168.0.222.

396
00:20:09.258 --> 00:20:12.282
And I'm gonna hit the network
load balancer, and

397
00:20:12.282 --> 00:20:16.700
the load balancer is gonna direct me
to one of the nodes on the back-end.

398
00:20:16.700 --> 00:20:20.132
And actually, I forgot something,
that's not gonna work.

399
00:20:20.132 --> 00:20:22.132
Whoops, let me try that again.

400
00:20:22.132 --> 00:20:28.639
All right, so
if I browse to https://lab.exchserv,

401
00:20:28.639 --> 00:20:31.174
I need to add in /owa.

402
00:20:31.174 --> 00:20:32.690
There's actually nothing
on that parent page.

403
00:20:32.690 --> 00:20:34.330
I need to get into Outlook web app.

404
00:20:34.330 --> 00:20:36.127
So it's gonna reach into that cluster and

405
00:20:36.127 --> 00:20:38.870
it's gonna get directed
to one of the nodes.

406
00:20:38.870 --> 00:20:40.500
So that takes care of the servers.

407
00:20:40.500 --> 00:20:42.550
Let's jump over to a client and
see if this works.

408
00:20:42.550 --> 00:20:45.080
So I'm gonna jump over to a machine and
remember,

409
00:20:45.080 --> 00:20:47.820
we created a virtual server,
a fake server.

410
00:20:47.820 --> 00:20:52.505
I should be able to fire open a command
prompt and do something crazy like ping

411
00:20:52.505 --> 00:20:57.890
192.168.0.222, that's that virtual IP,
and I'm getting ping responses.

412
00:20:57.890 --> 00:21:02.870
There's no actual server at 222, it's the
load balancing cluster that I'm hitting.

413
00:21:02.870 --> 00:21:05.310
And so if I fire up a web browser and

414
00:21:05.310 --> 00:21:08.330
I point to that cluster,
I'll get load balanced.

415
00:21:08.330 --> 00:21:12.339
If I go to https://lab.exchserv,

416
00:21:12.339 --> 00:21:19.633
that's that load balance cluster
we just made, and I'll go to /owa.

417
00:21:19.633 --> 00:21:21.520
Well, I'm getting a certificate warning.

418
00:21:21.520 --> 00:21:23.170
Now why am I getting
a certificate warning?

419
00:21:23.170 --> 00:21:25.870
Well, each server had
a self-signed certificate.

420
00:21:25.870 --> 00:21:30.440
So LAB-EXCHSERV01, LAB-EXCHSERV02,
they had self-signed certificates.

421
00:21:30.440 --> 00:21:34.110
Now I'm accessing it with a different
domain name and it doesn't match.

422
00:21:34.110 --> 00:21:40.100
So I'll need to generate an SSL
certificate that matches LAB-EXCHSERV and

423
00:21:40.100 --> 00:21:43.460
attach that to all of my Client Access
servers that are in this load balancing

424
00:21:43.460 --> 00:21:45.230
cluster so the certificate matches.

425
00:21:45.230 --> 00:21:48.380
But aside from that,
I am actually in here.

426
00:21:48.380 --> 00:21:51.420
And if I go and try and
log in, I can get in there.

427
00:21:51.420 --> 00:21:55.430
Now looking at this, do I know if I'm
connected to Exchange Server 1 or

428
00:21:55.430 --> 00:21:56.850
Exchange Server 2?

429
00:21:56.850 --> 00:21:57.540
I don't.

430
00:21:57.540 --> 00:22:00.020
The end user doesn't know whether
they're on one or the other.

431
00:22:00.020 --> 00:22:00.960
It's seamless to them.

432
00:22:00.960 --> 00:22:04.870
They just see this general server
name that's part of the cluster

433
00:22:04.870 --> 00:22:06.320
that we defined.

434
00:22:06.320 --> 00:22:09.200
But if I go and take a look at
the certificate attached to this thing,

435
00:22:09.200 --> 00:22:10.740
I can find out who it is.

436
00:22:10.740 --> 00:22:12.240
I'm attached to server number 2.

437
00:22:13.600 --> 00:22:16.850
I connected to a generic name but I ended
up on server number 2 because that's where

438
00:22:16.850 --> 00:22:19.370
the load balancing cluster
felt I should have ended up.

439
00:22:19.370 --> 00:22:21.400
So half the traffic being
sent to one server,

440
00:22:21.400 --> 00:22:23.370
half the traffic being sent to the other.

441
00:22:23.370 --> 00:22:26.320
Now the really cool stuff here
is that if we see our servers

442
00:22:26.320 --> 00:22:29.400
start to get really busy,
we can start to add more servers in.

443
00:22:29.400 --> 00:22:30.850
And they don't have to be identical.

444
00:22:30.850 --> 00:22:33.610
I can add in servers with more memory or
better processors, or

445
00:22:33.610 --> 00:22:35.745
they can be weaker memory and
just add a bunch more of them.

446
00:22:35.745 --> 00:22:38.590
Whatever it is that I need,
I can add them in there.

447
00:22:38.590 --> 00:22:41.420
And if I need to do maintenance
I can take a server out.

448
00:22:41.420 --> 00:22:44.290
Now it probably won't be on the Exchange
exam but I do want to show you guys how to

449
00:22:44.290 --> 00:22:47.510
take a server out for maintenance and
create the least impact.

450
00:22:47.510 --> 00:22:51.352
Because when a user's logged in on one
server and they get moved to another node,

451
00:22:51.352 --> 00:22:55.460
it resets their session and they have to
login again, and that annoys the users.

452
00:22:55.460 --> 00:22:57.770
So we want to try and
keep that to a minimum if we can.

453
00:22:57.770 --> 00:23:00.230
You don't want people
constantly relogging in.

454
00:23:00.230 --> 00:23:03.880
So in network load balancing,
we have a feature called drain stop.

455
00:23:03.880 --> 00:23:07.470
What drain stop does is it says,
take a server and

456
00:23:07.470 --> 00:23:10.440
don't send any more connections to it,
but let

457
00:23:10.440 --> 00:23:15.230
the existing connections continue to work
until those users log out on their own.

458
00:23:15.230 --> 00:23:17.840
And that way, over a period of
time the users trickle out, and

459
00:23:17.840 --> 00:23:19.810
now the server becomes available.

460
00:23:19.810 --> 00:23:21.540
So let me show you how that works.

461
00:23:21.540 --> 00:23:24.350
So let's say that I need to do some
maintenance on node number two.

462
00:23:24.350 --> 00:23:26.130
Right, this LAB-EXCHSERV02.

463
00:23:26.130 --> 00:23:28.540
I want to take it out and
do some Windows updates.

464
00:23:28.540 --> 00:23:34.200
So I can right-click on that, and
I can go to Control Host > Drainstop.

465
00:23:34.200 --> 00:23:37.290
I could just choose Stop and that would
take it out of commission right now.

466
00:23:37.290 --> 00:23:42.010
But if I choose Drainstop, it's gonna say,
don't send any new people to that server

467
00:23:43.040 --> 00:23:45.900
but let the existing connections finish.

468
00:23:45.900 --> 00:23:50.160
So if I've got a session open, like this
OWA session here, it'll let me finish.

469
00:23:50.160 --> 00:23:52.490
And then when I'm done, I sign out,

470
00:23:52.490 --> 00:23:57.740
my session's over, we kinda close,
and then that's the end of it.

471
00:23:57.740 --> 00:24:02.698
Well, back here, it's watching that,
and when the last session is done,

472
00:24:02.698 --> 00:24:04.952
then this server will go offline.

473
00:24:04.952 --> 00:24:07.091
And when it's offline,
then I can go and do maintenance.

474
00:24:07.091 --> 00:24:09.151
Now that might take 5 minutes,
it might take 20 minutes.

475
00:24:09.151 --> 00:24:11.611
I think 20 minutes is the default.

476
00:24:11.611 --> 00:24:16.971
There is a setting that defines
the maximum time it'll wait.

477
00:24:16.971 --> 00:24:18.508
Let's see if I can remember
where that setting is,

478
00:24:18.508 --> 00:24:20.650
it's been a long time since
I've messed with that one.

479
00:24:20.650 --> 00:24:24.620
But somewhere is a limit on how long it
will wait, I want to say it's 20 minutes

480
00:24:24.620 --> 00:24:27.470
and after 20 minutes if there's still
somebody in there it just kicks them out.

481
00:24:27.470 --> 00:24:32.100
But for me, I'm logged out,
if I go and create a new sessions, so

482
00:24:32.100 --> 00:24:38.840
if I fire up a web browser and, and
try and browse back to that system, right.

483
00:24:38.840 --> 00:24:42.990
I'm gonna go and
get connected in, here we go, and

484
00:24:42.990 --> 00:24:46.920
now if I look at the certificate on this
one I can see I'm connected to Serve 01,

485
00:24:46.920 --> 00:24:49.180
see how it just flipped
me over to the other one.

486
00:24:49.180 --> 00:24:53.300
Anybody new is gonna get connected to
Serve 01, Serve 02 empties out, and

487
00:24:53.300 --> 00:24:56.450
when it's actually empty, this will
change to let me know the node is down.

488
00:24:56.450 --> 00:24:59.010
Right now It says that it's converging,

489
00:24:59.010 --> 00:25:00.910
it's still kind of going
through that process.

490
00:25:00.910 --> 00:25:03.850
Sometimes this screen doesn't refresh very
well, so I'm just going to right-click and

491
00:25:03.850 --> 00:25:05.830
refresh, and it's probably down already.

492
00:25:05.830 --> 00:25:07.210
And yep there it is, yep.

493
00:25:07.210 --> 00:25:08.620
I can see that it's stopped,

494
00:25:08.620 --> 00:25:11.090
I'm now free to do whatever
maintenance on that system I need.

495
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:13.600
I can reboot it, do updates, whatever.

496
00:25:13.600 --> 00:25:16.375
And when I'm done I just
bring it back into the pool.

497
00:25:16.375 --> 00:25:20.250
You can right-click on it,
go to control host and go to Start, and

498
00:25:20.250 --> 00:25:24.630
that's gonna bring it back into the pool,
and be ready for action, right.

499
00:25:24.630 --> 00:25:27.610
So, really neat that we get that
functionality, this works for

500
00:25:27.610 --> 00:25:30.250
all the client access server functions.

501
00:25:30.250 --> 00:25:35.010
OWA, Outlook Anywhere, POP3,
IMAP 4, it works great for

502
00:25:35.010 --> 00:25:40.030
all those, you can get it set up It does
not work for mailbox databases, all right?

503
00:25:40.030 --> 00:25:43.710
You cannot load balance user
across mailbox databases.

504
00:25:43.710 --> 00:25:48.300
Their mailbox exists actively on
one server and one server only.

505
00:25:48.300 --> 00:25:50.250
Even if you have database
availability groups and

506
00:25:50.250 --> 00:25:54.330
the email is stored in more than one
place, there's only one active copy, and

507
00:25:54.330 --> 00:25:55.940
that's what users need to connect to.

508
00:25:55.940 --> 00:25:59.272
So don't do NLB on a mailbox
database server, or if you do,

509
00:25:59.272 --> 00:26:00.820
cuz technically I'm doing here.

510
00:26:00.820 --> 00:26:05.440
If you do, don't try and balance the ports
that it uses for the mailbox database,

511
00:26:05.440 --> 00:26:08.680
right, that are RPC and MapE ports,
don't try and load balance those.

512
