00:26:08.680 --> 00:26:14.590
Be really specific and only load balance
the client access ports like I did here,

513
00:26:14.590 --> 00:26:17.040
so that's how we kind
of keep that in line.

514
00:26:17.040 --> 00:26:19.530
But using Windows Load Balancing Service
it's not very hard,

515
00:26:19.530 --> 00:26:23.360
it's pretty easy to get set up, it's
a part of Windows Server Standard Edition,

516
00:26:23.360 --> 00:26:26.010
you don't have to pay extra for it,
you don't need clustered hardware.

517
00:26:26.010 --> 00:26:28.910
It's a quick and
easy way to get load balancing in place,

518
00:26:28.910 --> 00:26:31.730
to get redundancy in place,
and to get seamless,

519
00:26:31.730 --> 00:26:36.490
invisible maintenance in place, to keep
the servers up and keep your users happy.

520
00:26:36.490 --> 00:26:39.570
So it's a really great system, and
it's all built right in there.

521
00:26:40.610 --> 00:26:44.050
All right, so in this episode we got
a chance to see the Windows load balancing

522
00:26:44.050 --> 00:26:47.820
system and how we can use that to
create redundant client access servers.

523
00:26:47.820 --> 00:26:51.350
Real important to keep the visibility
of our network up and healthy.

524
00:26:51.350 --> 00:26:52.160
Pretty easy to implement,

525
00:26:52.160 --> 00:26:54.980
definitely something you'll want to
use out there in the production world.

526
00:26:54.980 --> 00:26:58.481
All right, well, I hope you guys enjoyed
the episode, signing off for ITProTV,

527
00:26:58.481 --> 00:27:00.432
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

528
00:27:00.432 --> 00:27:05.810
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the default send and receive connectors present in Exchange 2013. He then demonstrates how to create custom connectors, and some of the various scenarios where that would be necessary.
episodes.title: Send/Receive Connectors
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.037 --> 00:00:13.768
All right good morning,
good afternoon and and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.768 --> 00:00:15.641
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.641 --> 00:00:19.850
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Exchange 2013.

5
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:24.090
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at Send and Receive Connectors.

6
00:00:24.090 --> 00:00:27.470
And if you haven't heard of these guys,
they're kind of important.

7
00:00:27.470 --> 00:00:31.590
Any email coming in or out of your
organization passes through a Send or

8
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:33.060
a Receive Connector.

9
00:00:33.060 --> 00:00:35.840
It sends for the outgoing,
receives are for the incoming.

10
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:40.090
And they dictate whether or not that
email is even allowed to pass through.

11
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:42.890
And if you've set up a brand
new install of Exchange 2013,

12
00:00:42.890 --> 00:00:45.730
you might have noticed a little problem.

13
00:00:45.730 --> 00:00:47.790
That your unable to send to the internet.

14
00:00:47.790 --> 00:00:50.280
And that's because the default
configuration of Center Receive

15
00:00:50.280 --> 00:00:53.140
Connectors, isn't configured
properly right out to the internet.

16
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:54.750
So it gives you a little bit of a problem.

17
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:56.760
We got to make sure we go in and
we tweak these.

18
00:00:56.760 --> 00:00:59.070
All right, now, you might ask yourself,

19
00:00:59.070 --> 00:01:02.330
why doesn't Microsoft configure this stuff
for me, so it works right out of the box?

20
00:01:02.330 --> 00:01:05.930
The answer is, there's a lot of
room to make mistakes here, and

21
00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:11.040
if you make a mistake your server can
potentially be open to relay spam.

22
00:01:11.040 --> 00:01:14.330
So Microsoft says, we're going
to set it up for internal email.

23
00:01:14.330 --> 00:01:17.600
And if you want external, if you want
email to the Internet, you can set it up

24
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:21.340
yourself and make sure that it is set up
properly so you're not relaying spam.

25
00:01:21.340 --> 00:01:24.320
We definitely don't wanna get on one of
those email blacklists that's out there,

26
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:26.900
then you gotta go through
the headache of getting delisted and

27
00:01:26.900 --> 00:01:28.100
it's just a nightmare.

28
00:01:28.100 --> 00:01:31.430
Fortunately, it's not that hard to set up,
we just need to know to do it.

29
00:01:31.430 --> 00:01:32.000
All right.

30
00:01:32.000 --> 00:01:33.560
Let me show you what I mean.

31
00:01:33.560 --> 00:01:35.900
First off, we need to kind of
understand where these send and

32
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:39.570
receive connectors come in, and
it all has to do with mail flow.

33
00:01:39.570 --> 00:01:41.880
In some of the other episodes,
we've talked about mail flow,

34
00:01:41.880 --> 00:01:45.630
which is talking really about how that
email moves from server to server through

35
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:46.900
your organization.

36
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:50.882
And inside of mail flow,
you'll see things like accepted domains.

37
00:01:50.882 --> 00:01:54.980
These are domains that we're
allowed to receive email for, but

38
00:01:54.980 --> 00:01:57.380
as far as sending, we can send as anybody.

39
00:01:57.380 --> 00:02:00.630
But you'll see right here, you've got your
receive and your send connectors where

40
00:02:00.630 --> 00:02:04.050
we can define how that email,
what are the entry points for the email,

41
00:02:04.050 --> 00:02:07.590
what are the exits point for the email,
and how we want that to flow.

42
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:11.400
Now, before we do that, I wanna show
you guys something real quick about my

43
00:02:11.400 --> 00:02:14.350
topology, and
then we'll look at the default settings.

44
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:18.280
So, I'm gonna jump all the way down here
to servers and pull up my list of servers.

45
00:02:18.280 --> 00:02:21.270
In my exchange topology,
I have three exchange servers.

46
00:02:21.270 --> 00:02:25.250
I have Lab Exchanger Server 1,
it's just a mailbox server.

47
00:02:25.250 --> 00:02:28.260
Number two is a client access server,
number three is a mailbox and

48
00:02:28.260 --> 00:02:29.580
a client access server.

49
00:02:29.580 --> 00:02:32.800
And the reason I did this is I wanna
show you guys the different connectors

50
00:02:32.800 --> 00:02:34.890
that are set up by default for each one.

51
00:02:34.890 --> 00:02:37.840
I have not modified my
connectors one single bit, so

52
00:02:37.840 --> 00:02:39.770
these are the default ones that we've got.

53
00:02:39.770 --> 00:02:42.540
It'll have some created for
each of these, all right.

54
00:02:42.540 --> 00:02:46.910
Now, when we go and start to define
these settings, what you'll notice

55
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:51.510
is that each server maintains its
own receive connectors, right?

56
00:02:51.510 --> 00:02:55.590
The receive connectors for incoming email,
that's dictated on each individual server.

57
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:58.160
But the send connectors for
going out to the internet,

58
00:02:58.160 --> 00:03:00.920
those are actually shared, so
it's a little bit of a different behavior

59
00:03:00.920 --> 00:03:03.430
between the different connector types and
we'll see that in the configuration.

60
00:03:04.640 --> 00:03:09.710
Alright, now when I jump back to mail flow
and I go up here to my receive connectors

61
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:13.670
remember how I said receive connectors are
managed per server So the first thing I

62
00:03:13.670 --> 00:03:18.230
see is this drop-down box, where I
can pick what server I'm looking at.

63
00:03:18.230 --> 00:03:22.880
If I jump over to send connectors, see how
I don't have that server drop-down box?

64
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:25.640
And that's because these are shared
across all the servers, right, so

65
00:03:25.640 --> 00:03:26.810
that's a little bit different.

66
00:03:26.810 --> 00:03:28.820
And also notice I don't have any.

67
00:03:28.820 --> 00:03:30.480
There's no send connectors.

68
00:03:30.480 --> 00:03:31.380
Why not?

69
00:03:31.380 --> 00:03:33.260
Well, that means I can't send email.

70
00:03:33.260 --> 00:03:35.040
It doesn't mean you can't send any email.

71
00:03:35.040 --> 00:03:36.880
You can send internal email.

72
00:03:36.880 --> 00:03:41.220
Internal email is any email destined for
one of these accepted domains.

73
00:03:41.220 --> 00:03:45.310
So I have lab.itpro.tv and itprotv.net.

74
00:03:45.310 --> 00:03:48.770
If I send an email to either of those
domains, I handle it internally,

75
00:03:48.770 --> 00:03:49.910
that works fine.

76
00:03:49.910 --> 00:03:51.340
I've got internal email.

77
00:03:51.340 --> 00:03:54.500
But if I try and email somebody on
the Internet, it's gonna bounce.

78
00:03:54.500 --> 00:03:55.040
It's gonna fail.

79
00:03:55.040 --> 00:03:57.670
It's not gonna be able to
get out to the Internet.

80
00:03:57.670 --> 00:04:00.150
I can receive email from the Internet, but

81
00:04:00.150 --> 00:04:02.980
I can't send to it myself,
because I have no Send connectors.

82
00:04:02.980 --> 00:04:06.240
So that's absolutely something we're gonna
have to correct if we want our system

83
00:04:06.240 --> 00:04:07.930
to function properly.

84
00:04:07.930 --> 00:04:09.430
Now, on the Receive side,

85
00:04:09.430 --> 00:04:12.260
Microsoft has already set up
some received connectors for me.

86
00:04:12.260 --> 00:04:16.660
And the connectors they set up vary based
on what type of server it is, right.

87
00:04:16.660 --> 00:04:19.620
Remember when you install Exchange,
you pick from some server roles.

88
00:04:19.620 --> 00:04:22.080
You pick whether you want it
to be a Mailbox server or

89
00:04:22.080 --> 00:04:24.510
whether it's a Client Access server.

90
00:04:24.510 --> 00:04:27.970
And those servers have some
other functions they perform.

91
00:04:27.970 --> 00:04:31.920
For example there's
the Front End Transport service.

92
00:04:31.920 --> 00:04:35.790
And the hub transport service, and
then the mailbox transport service.

93
00:04:35.790 --> 00:04:40.080
Those three are what used to be
called the Hub Transport Server.

94
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:42.820
Microsoft broke those up
into three services, and

95
00:04:42.820 --> 00:04:44.760
spread them across our
servers in different ways.

96
00:04:44.760 --> 00:04:47.350
And that changes these receive connectors.

97
00:04:47.350 --> 00:04:48.370
All right?

98
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:50.230
If you're a mailbox server.

99
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:53.460
A mailbox server's gonna run
the hub transport service and

100
00:04:53.460 --> 00:04:55.190
the mailbox transport service.

101
00:04:55.190 --> 00:04:59.610
It's the one that's responsible for
applying our transport rules and

102
00:04:59.610 --> 00:05:01.520
putting email in the mailboxes.

103
00:05:01.520 --> 00:05:03.660
This is what's actually gonna to
be putting email in the mailbox.

104
00:05:03.660 --> 00:05:04.950
That's kind of important.

105
00:05:04.950 --> 00:05:09.160
And so when I pick a server that's
a mailbox server like my server number one

106
00:05:09.160 --> 00:05:11.530
or my server number three,
they're both mailbox servers.

107
00:05:11.530 --> 00:05:14.460
They're gonna have two received
connectors by default.

108
00:05:14.460 --> 00:05:18.100
And if you look at them,
one is a Client Proxy, and

109
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:20.560
one is just called default, all right.

110
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:22.000
The default is the most common one.

111
00:05:22.000 --> 00:05:26.320
If I edit the default and
take a look at it, what we'll see in here

112
00:05:26.320 --> 00:05:30.040
is that it's basically a receive
connector, it's set up to receive email,

113
00:05:30.040 --> 00:05:34.440
it has a limit on it holding
emails to below 35 megabytes.

114
00:05:34.440 --> 00:05:38.290
So if I get an email that's bigger than 35
megabytes, I reject it, email's too big.

115
00:05:38.290 --> 00:05:40.030
You might want to make that bigger for
your environment or

116
00:05:40.030 --> 00:05:41.500
smaller for your environment, right?

117
00:05:41.500 --> 00:05:42.400
I hate email attachments.

118
00:05:42.400 --> 00:05:43.810
So you might wanna make it smaller.

119
00:05:43.810 --> 00:05:47.100
Though we can define right here
that it's allowed to receive email.

120
00:05:47.100 --> 00:05:51.140
And under security, we say who
are allowed to receive email from.

121
00:05:51.140 --> 00:05:53.270
And if you look at who
you're receiving it from,

122
00:05:53.270 --> 00:05:55.430
you're receiving only
encrypted connections.

123
00:05:55.430 --> 00:05:56.790
If I look at this list, right?

124
00:05:56.790 --> 00:06:01.780
TLS, basic authentication users using TLS
and Exchange Server Authentication, right?

125
00:06:01.780 --> 00:06:04.040
So it's only authenticated users.

126
00:06:04.040 --> 00:06:08.320
And then down here it's limited to
Exchange servers, Legacy Exchange servers,

127
00:06:08.320 --> 00:06:12.200
those would be like Exchange 2000 and
earlier, and Exchange users.

128
00:06:12.200 --> 00:06:14.580
See how Anonymous users are not checked.

129
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:17.950
If I receive an email from the internet,
are they gonna authenticate against me?

130
00:06:17.950 --> 00:06:19.330
Not normally, right?

131
00:06:19.330 --> 00:06:24.030
So, a mailbox server will not
accept unauthenticated connections.

132
00:06:24.030 --> 00:06:25.890
It's protected,
you can't send an email to it.

133
00:06:25.890 --> 00:06:28.260
And that's because your not suppose to.

134
00:06:28.260 --> 00:06:31.150
Incoming email from the internet is
suppose to go to a client access server,

135
00:06:31.150 --> 00:06:32.500
not a mailbox server.

136
00:06:32.500 --> 00:06:34.330
And that's why that
permission is not enabled.

137
00:06:34.330 --> 00:06:37.520
And then if I go down to Scoping,
I'll see it's tied to

138
00:06:37.520 --> 00:06:41.320
all the email addresses on this server and
it's tied to Port 25.

139
00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:43.760
That's the SMTP port, right?

140
00:06:43.760 --> 00:06:46.260
SMTP is not encrypted by default, but

141
00:06:46.260 --> 00:06:49.370
under security,
I'm requiring authentication and

142
00:06:49.370 --> 00:06:54.480
encryption, so it'll have to be encrypted
SMTP to connect to the mailbox.

143
00:06:54.480 --> 00:06:56.560
Internet users are not gonna
be able to connect to that.

144
00:06:56.560 --> 00:06:59.820
This is suitable only for
internal connections, right?

145
00:06:59.820 --> 00:07:06.350
So the take-away from this screen is that
any mailbox server will have secure,

146
00:07:06.350 --> 00:07:11.000
encrypted receive connectors, so
only internal servers can talk to it.

147
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:13.500
Internet email can not
go to a mailbox server.

148
00:07:13.500 --> 00:07:16.260
Now that's one of the connectors,
the one on port 25,

149
00:07:16.260 --> 00:07:18.620
there's this other one client proxy.

150
00:07:18.620 --> 00:07:19.770
What's that all about?

151
00:07:19.770 --> 00:07:22.900
Well, if I take a look at the client proxy
it's actually going to be set up the same

152
00:07:22.900 --> 00:07:23.970
as the other one.

153
00:07:23.970 --> 00:07:26.390
The big difference is the scoping.

154
00:07:26.390 --> 00:07:28.920
When we look at the scoping
it's tied to port 465.

155
00:07:28.920 --> 00:07:33.250
And when we go under security, notice how
Legacy Exchange Server is turned off.

156
00:07:33.250 --> 00:07:35.520
And it's got Exchange servers and
Exchange users.

157
00:07:35.520 --> 00:07:38.140
This is the connector that Outlook uses.

158
00:07:38.140 --> 00:07:40.250
If you're running Microsoft Outlook,
it's gonna try and

159
00:07:40.250 --> 00:07:44.450
connect your exchange servers on
TCP465 and establish a session there.

160
00:07:44.450 --> 00:07:46.420
So, this is a connection proxy for

161
00:07:46.420 --> 00:07:48.840
Outlook to be able to connect to
the mailbox server, all right.

162
00:07:48.840 --> 00:07:51.337
If you're not using Outlook,
then you're not using this connector.

163
00:07:51.337 --> 00:07:54.147
The server's will use it io talk
to each other, but otherwise,

164
00:07:54.147 --> 00:07:55.823
it won't get used for anything else.

165
00:07:55.823 --> 00:07:59.414
So, that's what this one is for,
the client proxy is really for Outlook,

166
00:07:59.414 --> 00:07:59.994
all right.

167
00:07:59.994 --> 00:08:02.385
So looking at this configuration here for

168
00:08:02.385 --> 00:08:06.140
a mailbox server it's just
internal connections.

169
00:08:06.140 --> 00:08:10.188
If I switch to a client access server
that's where things get different.

170
00:08:10.188 --> 00:08:14.375
It has a a client front end,

171
00:08:14.375 --> 00:08:17.325
a default front end, and
an outbound proxy front end.

172
00:08:17.325 --> 00:08:19.915
Now it's got three different connectors.

173
00:08:19.915 --> 00:08:23.865
And the reason here is that it's
allowing clients to connect, right?

174
00:08:23.865 --> 00:08:27.905
People that are running Outlook or
other third party email clients,

175
00:08:27.905 --> 00:08:29.700
people that are using SMTP but

176
00:08:29.700 --> 00:08:34.170
it's also allowing unauthenticated
internet connections to come in.

177
00:08:34.170 --> 00:08:37.180
Cuz if we wanna receive email from the
internet, it has to be unauthenticated.

178
00:08:37.180 --> 00:08:39.220
People won't have a user
end password on our system.

179
00:08:39.220 --> 00:08:41.620
They need to be able to connect and
deposit email.

180
00:08:41.620 --> 00:08:43.970
Now that doesn't mean we want people to
just be able to send whatever the heck

181
00:08:43.970 --> 00:08:44.540
they want, right?

182
00:08:44.540 --> 00:08:46.000
We wanna limit it just to us.

183
00:08:46.000 --> 00:08:51.430
And so, by default, we will only
receive email from accepted domains.

184
00:08:51.430 --> 00:08:55.830
If it's email that's going to somebody
at itprotv.net or email going to

185
00:08:55.830 --> 00:09:00.340
somebody at lab.itpro.tv, I'll allow
it to come in my receive connector.

186
00:09:00.340 --> 00:09:01.250
But if it's destined for

187
00:09:01.250 --> 00:09:06.190
somebody at gmail.com or at microsoft.com,
that's not mine, I'm gonna throw it away.

188
00:09:06.190 --> 00:09:07.060
That would be a relay.

189
00:09:07.060 --> 00:09:08.930
I don't want a relay by default.

190
00:09:08.930 --> 00:09:11.220
And so that's how these
connectors are configured.

191
00:09:11.220 --> 00:09:13.680
If I go to my receive connectors and
I look at this default.

192
00:09:13.680 --> 00:09:16.505
I'm gonna edit the default front end one.

193
00:09:16.505 --> 00:09:18.540
And when you look at it, it's set up here.

194
00:09:18.540 --> 00:09:20.790
It's got that maximum mail size set.

195
00:09:20.790 --> 00:09:24.200
Under security,
I've got security is available but

196
00:09:24.200 --> 00:09:26.930
I also have anonymous enabled.

197
00:09:26.930 --> 00:09:27.670
Right?

198
00:09:27.670 --> 00:09:30.130
Anybody can connect to this
without authenticating.

199
00:09:30.130 --> 00:09:32.550
They can just connect and
start sending email.

200
00:09:32.550 --> 00:09:36.270
All right, now under scoping,
I can see that this is tied to port 25, so

201
00:09:36.270 --> 00:09:39.560
these are my SMTP connections,
what we receive email from.

202
00:09:39.560 --> 00:09:41.720
And it's not requiring authentication.

203
00:09:41.720 --> 00:09:43.060
That sounds risky.

204
00:09:43.060 --> 00:09:45.590
But it's limited to the accepted domain,
so

205
00:09:45.590 --> 00:09:48.450
that's what stops this
from being a true relay.

206
00:09:48.450 --> 00:09:49.080
All right?

207
00:09:49.080 --> 00:09:52.060
So we've got this one set up, and that's
what's allowing internet email to come in.

208
00:09:52.060 --> 00:09:57.200
So If I want internet email to come
directly into my mail organization,

209
00:09:57.200 --> 00:10:02.580
I can go and change the MX records in
DNS to point right to this server,

210
00:10:02.580 --> 00:10:04.980
and internet email will
now flow to this server,

211
00:10:04.980 --> 00:10:08.240
it'll receive it on this default connector
and, as long as it's destined for

212
00:10:08.240 --> 00:10:10.870
an accepted domain,
it'll flow into the mailboxes.

213
00:10:10.870 --> 00:10:13.960
Will reach out using one
of the private connectors

214
00:10:13.960 --> 00:10:18.440
to talk to the mailbox server and get the
email deposited in the mailbox, all right.

215
00:10:18.440 --> 00:10:19.490
Now, what are these other two?

216
00:10:19.490 --> 00:10:22.840
Well, we've got this client front end here
and if you take a look at the client front

217
00:10:22.840 --> 00:10:25.660
end, this is like the client
on the back end, right.

218
00:10:25.660 --> 00:10:28.590
We'll see similar settings across these,
we've got security.

219
00:10:28.590 --> 00:10:32.570
Anonymous is disabled and
it's set up for exchange users, right?

220
00:10:32.570 --> 00:10:35.520
And if I look at the scoping,
this one is tied to port 587.

221
00:10:35.520 --> 00:10:38.960
This is an encrypted SMTP connection,
right.

222
00:10:38.960 --> 00:10:45.760
Secure SMTP uses 587 so Outlook can
use this or POP 3 and IMAP 4 users.

223
00:10:45.760 --> 00:10:48.290
They have to specify
an SMTP server to send.

224
00:10:48.290 --> 00:10:51.120
Now on this one,
we require authentication,

225
00:10:51.120 --> 00:10:52.900
because when they authenticate,

226
00:10:52.900 --> 00:10:57.460
they might be sending email to somebody at
gmail.com or somebody at microsoft.com.

227
00:10:57.460 --> 00:11:00.020
And we want a relay for
authenticated users.

228
00:11:00.020 --> 00:11:03.870
So this connector is different
from the default one,

229
00:11:03.870 --> 00:11:06.840
in that we allow relays here on this one,
right?

230
00:11:06.840 --> 00:11:08.640
Now that's like a check
mark we can turn on.

231
00:11:08.640 --> 00:11:11.780
You can go into PowerShell and manipulate
it, but right from here the default,

232
00:11:11.780 --> 00:11:14.060
the way that it is setup,
is that this one will allow that relay.

233
00:11:15.770 --> 00:11:18.056
And then lastly we have
this outbound proxy, and

234
00:11:18.056 --> 00:11:22.040
the outbound proxy that's what we're using
when we connect back to other servers.

235
00:11:22.040 --> 00:11:25.380
So if I look at my settings,
see how it's limited to Exchange servers?

236
00:11:25.380 --> 00:11:27.770
And if I go down to
the scoping it's on port 717.

237
00:11:27.770 --> 00:11:31.700
That's not a standard email
port that we're used to seeing.

238
00:11:31.700 --> 00:11:34.220
It's one that Exchange servers
are using to be able to communicate

239
00:11:34.220 --> 00:11:35.300
between each other.

240
00:11:35.300 --> 00:11:38.630
And we'll see that if you setup like
an edge transport server it can be used to

241
00:11:38.630 --> 00:11:41.555
talk to that too although
it doesn't have to be.

242
00:11:41.555 --> 00:11:45.070
Alright, so those are some of the
connectors that are defined by default.

243
00:11:45.070 --> 00:11:49.600
We might choose to define some
custom connectors if we want, right?

244
00:11:49.600 --> 00:11:52.230
If we have special needs that
go beyond what the defaults are,

245
00:11:52.230 --> 00:11:55.420
we can create our own connectors, or
we can even modify these if we want to.

246
00:11:55.420 --> 00:11:58.270
Alright, I want to show you one more
example before I start modifying this

247
00:11:58.270 --> 00:11:59.230
stuff, though.

248
00:11:59.230 --> 00:12:03.180
What if you're a mailbox server and
a client access server?

249
00:12:03.180 --> 00:12:06.340
So, lab, my server number three here
is both mailbox and client accss.

250
00:12:07.410 --> 00:12:11.080
When we look at that, see how it ends
up with five different connectors?

251
00:12:11.080 --> 00:12:16.310
It's a mixture and if I sort by role,
I can see these three are my front end.

252
00:12:16.310 --> 00:12:19.070
Those are the ones that I'm getting
from the client access role.

253
00:12:19.070 --> 00:12:20.490
And these bottom two are hub transport.

254
00:12:20.490 --> 00:12:22.290
Those are the ones I'm getting
from the mailbox role.

255
00:12:22.290 --> 00:12:26.320
So even though I'm one server, I'm acting
like two completely separate servers.

256
00:12:26.320 --> 00:12:29.750
And I'm actually going to be
relaying email between myself

257
00:12:29.750 --> 00:12:32.310
as I move things from the client
access role to the mailbox role.

258
00:12:32.310 --> 00:12:35.870
So even though you're running both of
the same server, it's still technically

259
00:12:35.870 --> 00:12:39.240
two separate entities,
two separate roles running on that server,

260
00:12:39.240 --> 00:12:41.975
and they've gotta communicate between
each other, so it will show up like this.

261
00:12:41.975 --> 00:12:46.320
Alright now, let's say I've got some
kind of business partner out there.

262
00:12:46.320 --> 00:12:51.050
Somebody who is gonna be sending email to
me, and they need to send email to me.

263
00:12:51.050 --> 00:12:55.600
I wanna relay for them, but they can't
authenticate, or something of that nature.

264
00:12:55.600 --> 00:12:57.630
I've got something that
I need to customize.

265
00:12:57.630 --> 00:13:00.740
Or you can create custom receive
connectors that are tailored to

266
00:13:00.740 --> 00:13:01.940
that particular partner.

267
00:13:01.940 --> 00:13:04.340
There's all sorts of different
things we can do there.

268
00:13:04.340 --> 00:13:07.380
So for example,
I can jump back to my front end server and

269
00:13:07.380 --> 00:13:10.690
I can add in a new receive connector and
when I add that

270
00:13:10.690 --> 00:13:14.730
new receive connector I can give it a name
and I can specify what it's intent is for.

271
00:13:14.730 --> 00:13:18.410
Is this a custom one that I
want to tailor everything and

272
00:13:18.410 --> 00:13:20.320
allow an application to relay.

273
00:13:20.320 --> 00:13:24.050
Is this internal use only for receiving
email, is it a partner connection,

274
00:13:24.050 --> 00:13:27.450
I'm receiving trusted connections
from another partner or

275
00:13:27.450 --> 00:13:30.520
is this some kind of client like
a non Outlook client connecting.

276
00:13:30.520 --> 00:13:32.700
You can dictate that right here.

277
00:13:32.700 --> 00:13:36.750
An example of how I might use this
is let's say that you got a big

278
00:13:36.750 --> 00:13:39.970
office printer and you want that
printer to be able to send email.

279
00:13:39.970 --> 00:13:42.460
You want it to be able to send email
to anybody in the world, right?

280
00:13:42.460 --> 00:13:45.020
Maybe it's got one of those
scan to email functions.

281
00:13:45.020 --> 00:13:49.000
And so, I want it to be able to send
the email through my mail server.

282
00:13:49.000 --> 00:13:51.620
But it can't authenticate it, doesn't
support providing username and password.

283
00:13:51.620 --> 00:13:56.570
I could create a custom receive
connector just for that printer and

284
00:13:56.570 --> 00:14:00.970
then open it up to allow it to relay now
to be able to send through my mail system

285
00:14:00.970 --> 00:14:03.440
and I won't have to worry about
the authentication side, alright?

286
00:14:03.440 --> 00:14:06.930
So I'll call this my office printer,
right, so

287
00:14:06.930 --> 00:14:08.790
that's the name that
I'm gonna assign to it.

288
00:14:08.790 --> 00:14:10.590
I'm going to tell her
that this one's custom,

289
00:14:10.590 --> 00:14:12.350
right I'm going to allow
an application to relay.

290
00:14:13.460 --> 00:14:15.340
And then we can specify our bindings.

291
00:14:15.340 --> 00:14:20.010
Now the binding is if I have more than one
network adaptor on my Exchange server,

292
00:14:20.010 --> 00:14:22.200
which network adaptor is it listening on,
and

293
00:14:22.200 --> 00:14:27.290
this is important because you only
have one port 25 on each IP address,

294
00:14:27.290 --> 00:14:31.400
so if you have more than one IP address,
you could split this up.

295
00:14:31.400 --> 00:14:34.210
The default is to say all
available IP addresses, so

296
00:14:34.210 --> 00:14:38.040
if I have more than one address, all of
them are gonna be listening on port 25.

297
00:14:38.040 --> 00:14:41.770
Well, I've already got
a connector listening on port 25.

298
00:14:41.770 --> 00:14:44.880
So I'm going to edit this and
I'm going to change it.

299
00:14:44.880 --> 00:14:49.020
And I can save a specific IP
address on my, system IPv4 or IPv6,

300
00:14:49.020 --> 00:14:51.370
or I could say all of them.

301
00:14:51.370 --> 00:14:54.150
If I do all of them, I'm going to
need to pick a different port number.

302
00:14:54.150 --> 00:14:56.670
So I'm going to say, 60,025.

303
00:14:56.670 --> 00:15:00.920
On my printer, when I set it up,
I'm going to point to the server and

304
00:15:00.920 --> 00:15:04.830
tell it to use port 60025 so
it will know the port to use to connect.

305
00:15:06.130 --> 00:15:06.690
Alright.

306
00:15:06.690 --> 00:15:09.780
So that's gonna be the scope for
this thing and I'll hit next.

307
00:15:09.780 --> 00:15:12.020
And now the remote network.

308
00:15:12.020 --> 00:15:15.110
I wanna limit this just to that printer.

309
00:15:15.110 --> 00:15:17.710
I don't want anybody to connect
because I'm gonna be turning off

310
00:15:17.710 --> 00:15:19.160
authentication, right.

311
00:15:19.160 --> 00:15:22.630
So I need them to be able
to be limited and secure.

312
00:15:22.630 --> 00:15:27.200
And so the best way to do that is to kind
of come in here and edit this IP address.

313
00:15:27.200 --> 00:15:30.980
I just removed that catch all and
put in a specific address.

314
00:15:30.980 --> 00:15:37.350
So maybe that printer is 192.168.0.223,
I'll put in exactly that address.

315
00:15:38.540 --> 00:15:39.750
And you can decide your notation.

316
00:15:39.750 --> 00:15:41.270
So if you wanna do a whole
you subnet you can.

317
00:15:41.270 --> 00:15:45.112
Maybe I won't allow unauthenticated
email from my whole internal subnet,

318
00:15:45.112 --> 00:15:47.993
anybody on my internal network
can send email great, but

319
00:15:47.993 --> 00:15:51.833
we usually don't wanna go that far I'm
gonna do just this printer right, so

320
00:15:51.833 --> 00:15:55.281
I'm adding that one IP specifically,
so now when I receive email.

321
00:15:55.281 --> 00:15:59.701
From 192.168.0.223 on port 60025,

322
00:15:59.701 --> 00:16:04.033
this received connector is
what's gonna take effect.

323
00:16:04.033 --> 00:16:05.137
All right?

324
00:16:05.137 --> 00:16:09.055
So I'll finish that up and now I've
got the receive connector created.

325
00:16:09.055 --> 00:16:12.575
From there I can edit it, and
in its settings I can go in and

326
00:16:12.575 --> 00:16:16.075
manipulate security, and
I'm gonna set this one to Allow anonymous.

327
00:16:16.075 --> 00:16:19.255
I want anonymous connections to be able to
come into this one, because the printer,

328
00:16:19.255 --> 00:16:22.965
for whatever reason, doesn't support
authentication, so I can customize that.

329
00:16:22.965 --> 00:16:24.375
But I'm not putting myself at risk.

330
00:16:24.375 --> 00:16:28.001
Normally I'd cringe at this, like [SOUND],
I don't want just anybody to be able to

331
00:16:28.001 --> 00:16:30.962
connect, here it's okay because
I've limited it to that one IP.

332
00:16:30.962 --> 00:16:33.469
Now, in theory,
somebody could spoof that IP,

333
00:16:33.469 --> 00:16:36.540
so this isn't foolproof but
it is limiting it to internal.

334
00:16:36.540 --> 00:16:39.260
I don't have to worry about
Internet users connecting to that.

335
00:16:39.260 --> 00:16:42.530
And I can always modify my scoping if I
wanna change that port number or whatever,

336
00:16:42.530 --> 00:16:44.290
I can come in and change that too.

337
00:16:44.290 --> 00:16:48.220
So now I've got a custom receive
connector just for that office printer so

338
00:16:48.220 --> 00:16:49.170
that it can connect.

339
00:16:49.170 --> 00:16:52.320
It can be anonymous, and
it can start to relay email, and

340
00:16:52.320 --> 00:16:53.590
it'll have it right there, right?

341
00:16:54.740 --> 00:16:59.080
So just remember that receive connectors,
this is the way for email to come in

342
00:16:59.080 --> 00:17:03.130
your organization, and the default
configuration is probably fine for

343
00:17:03.130 --> 00:17:06.130
most people, but there are times
when you might wanna configure that.

344
00:17:06.130 --> 00:17:07.010
You might wanna modify it.

345
00:17:08.110 --> 00:17:12.979
The one area where we absolutely
have to modify are send connectors.

346
00:17:12.979 --> 00:17:14.454
The send connector's the way out.

347
00:17:14.454 --> 00:17:16.636
How do we get out of our organization?

348
00:17:16.636 --> 00:17:19.330
And when you go out,
you use a send connector.

349
00:17:19.330 --> 00:17:22.520
The problem is by default,
we don't have any.

350
00:17:22.520 --> 00:17:26.190
So by default you can only send email to
people that are in your organization and

351
00:17:26.190 --> 00:17:27.132
that's that.

352
00:17:27.132 --> 00:17:29.410
If wanna send people outside
of our organization,

353
00:17:29.410 --> 00:17:31.110
we've gotta create a send connector.

354
00:17:31.110 --> 00:17:34.500
And for most people, we wanna be
able to send to the Internet, so

355
00:17:34.500 --> 00:17:36.070
that's usually where we start.

356
00:17:36.070 --> 00:17:40.090
When you create a send connector, the send
connectors are built upon a domain name.

357
00:17:40.090 --> 00:17:44.590
So you say when I'm sending email to
this domain, here's how you get there.

358
00:17:44.590 --> 00:17:48.629
So we may set up an Internet one
that's gonna catch all domains.

359
00:17:48.629 --> 00:17:50.684
And you say all domains by
using an asterisk, right?

360
00:17:50.684 --> 00:17:51.566
A wild card.

361
00:17:51.566 --> 00:17:55.073
So a wild card sim connector is
usually the first thing that we make.

362
00:17:55.073 --> 00:17:56.326
I'm gonna come in here and create one.

363
00:17:56.326 --> 00:17:57.626
I'll just hit the plus sign.

364
00:17:57.626 --> 00:17:58.984
And it's going to ask
me what I'm creating.

365
00:17:58.984 --> 00:18:02.351
I'm gonna call this my Internet Connector,
right?

366
00:18:02.351 --> 00:18:04.906
This is what's gonna actually give
me that Internet functionality.

367
00:18:04.906 --> 00:18:07.043
And down here you can specify
what it is your trying to do.

368
00:18:07.043 --> 00:18:09.584
And they've actually got one made for
us already, Internet.

369
00:18:09.584 --> 00:18:11.630
We wanna send Internet email.

370
00:18:11.630 --> 00:18:13.700
I could choose custom and
just put a star for

371
00:18:13.700 --> 00:18:16.199
the domain, by choosing Internet
that's what it's gonna do for me.

372
00:18:17.520 --> 00:18:21.470
All right, then I can hit Next, and
it's gonna ask how I wanna send it.

373
00:18:21.470 --> 00:18:24.150
Now when it comes to email,
there's two ways to send email.

374
00:18:25.190 --> 00:18:28.800
One way,
is that I'm sending an email to gmail.com.

375
00:18:28.800 --> 00:18:32.890
I can go to DNS,
I can find the gmail.com domain, and

376
00:18:32.890 --> 00:18:36.120
I can look for the mx records,
look for the mail exchanges, and

377
00:18:36.120 --> 00:18:39.010
when I find the mail exchanges now I know
the server to communicate with, right?

378
00:18:39.010 --> 00:18:40.564
This happens all the time
in the background.

379
00:18:40.564 --> 00:18:42.665
Here let me just show you real quick.

380
00:18:42.665 --> 00:18:44.765
Most of you guys probably
already know this but for

381
00:18:44.765 --> 00:18:48.880
those of you that don't let me just show
you a quick example of how this works.

382
00:18:48.880 --> 00:18:54.940
So, if I'm gonna send an email
to somebody like Gmail, right?

383
00:18:54.940 --> 00:18:57.895
So if I have some kind of Gmail
account that's out there and

384
00:18:57.895 --> 00:18:59.356
I want to send an email to it.

385
00:18:59.356 --> 00:19:03.845
Well, what happens is, it turns around and
looks at the DNS and it says okay, so

386
00:19:03.845 --> 00:19:06.937
I've got an email for
gmail.com, where do I send it?

387
00:19:06.937 --> 00:19:10.096
And in DNS it has all these MX records.

388
00:19:10.096 --> 00:19:16.180
These MX records, these guys right here,
that's what tells us who to send it too.

389
00:19:16.180 --> 00:19:17.934
And so
now our server can send email there and

390
00:19:17.934 --> 00:19:19.890
it'll get to the mail
box where it's destined.

391
00:19:21.070 --> 00:19:22.770
The problem is,

392
00:19:22.770 --> 00:19:27.140
we don't always want our server to
be reaching out there specifically.

393
00:19:27.140 --> 00:19:30.780
Maybe we pay for
email filtering service like Postini,

394
00:19:30.780 --> 00:19:34.878
maybe we have an Internet service provider
that provides mail flow for us, right?

395
00:19:34.878 --> 00:19:37.250
So we wanna take the load off of our
servers and move it somewhere else.

396
00:19:37.250 --> 00:19:39.799
Here we use a Barracuda spam and
virus firewall, so

397
00:19:39.799 --> 00:19:42.778
we want all our outgoing email
to go through that firewall.

398
00:19:42.778 --> 00:19:46.297
Don't go directly to Gmail,
go to our firewall first, right?

399
00:19:46.297 --> 00:19:50.269
And so for that, we can override the
default behavior of using MX records and

400
00:19:50.269 --> 00:19:52.440
tell it to use a smart host, all right?

401
00:19:52.440 --> 00:19:54.230
And that's this option
that's right below here.

402
00:19:54.230 --> 00:19:55.825
So, I've got my MX record.

403
00:19:55.825 --> 00:19:59.019
And then I've got route mail through
smart hosts, and that just says,

404
00:19:59.019 --> 00:20:01.265
don't go direct,
go through this other person.

405
00:20:01.265 --> 00:20:07.105
And so you could add in the firewall or
third party filtering service or your ISP.

406
00:20:07.105 --> 00:20:10.880
You punch in their IP address here, and
then any outgoing email you have will just

407
00:20:10.880 --> 00:20:13.495
go to that third party provider,
all right?

408
00:20:13.495 --> 00:20:16.191
Well, I'm not gonna set that, I'm gonna
stick with MX records for right now, so

409
00:20:16.191 --> 00:20:17.600
we'll set that up.

410
00:20:17.600 --> 00:20:19.350
And then we can hit Next.

411
00:20:19.350 --> 00:20:22.033
And then it's gonna say
what the address space is.

412
00:20:22.033 --> 00:20:25.722
Now this is gonna be an Internet
connector, so the address space for

413
00:20:25.722 --> 00:20:27.871
the Internet connector is everybody.

414
00:20:27.871 --> 00:20:31.999
Every domain that's out there on
the Internet, it's going to match this, so

415
00:20:31.999 --> 00:20:35.123
when I hit Add I'm not just
gonna punch in a regular domain,

416
00:20:35.123 --> 00:20:37.331
I'm gonna punch in a star, an asterisk.

417
00:20:37.331 --> 00:20:39.769
An asterisks means every domain all right?

418
00:20:39.769 --> 00:20:43.109
Everybody that's out there on the
Internet, anybody that's not internal to

419
00:20:43.109 --> 00:20:46.600
me, and internal would be like
lab.itpro.tv in my example.

420
00:20:46.600 --> 00:20:49.550
Now notice there's a cost, what if I have

421
00:20:49.550 --> 00:20:54.190
more than one send connector that matches
an email, how does it pick a winner?

422
00:20:54.190 --> 00:20:56.330
Well, it picks based on this cost.

423
00:20:56.330 --> 00:21:01.530
And so I can define the cost of this line,
and the lowest cost wins.

424
00:21:01.530 --> 00:21:04.980
So, I might have a connector
that runs through my span and

425
00:21:04.980 --> 00:21:06.790
virus firewall with a cost of one,

426
00:21:06.790 --> 00:21:11.080
and I might have a connector that
bypasses firewall with a cost of then.

427
00:21:11.080 --> 00:21:13.910
And that way it always goes to
the firewall unless the firewall fails and

428
00:21:13.910 --> 00:21:15.320
then it moves onto the next one and

429
00:21:15.320 --> 00:21:17.330
it goes through that one with
the higher cost and bypasses it.

430
00:21:17.330 --> 00:21:21.700
So, you can set up kinda redundancies that
way, by manipulating these costs, right?

431
00:21:21.700 --> 00:21:24.330
I'm just gonna leave mine at a cost of 1,
and I'll save it.

432
00:21:25.500 --> 00:21:26.270
All right.

433
00:21:26.270 --> 00:21:29.890
So then, we do have the option
to scope the send connector.

434
00:21:29.890 --> 00:21:33.800
By default, any of my email servers
are gonna be able to use this, but

435
00:21:33.800 --> 00:21:35.910
if I scope it I can limit the server.

436
00:21:35.910 --> 00:21:37.500
Now, why would I wanna do that?

437
00:21:37.500 --> 00:21:40.560
Maybe I want all of my outgoing email

438
00:21:40.560 --> 00:21:44.030
to go through one particular
client access server.

439
00:21:44.030 --> 00:21:48.740
So I can set that, I can limit it
by scoping that send connector.

440
00:21:48.740 --> 00:21:51.410
But if I just want all these
servers to send out on their own,

441
00:21:51.410 --> 00:21:53.560
I can leave that unchecked and
they'll do all of them.

442
00:21:53.560 --> 00:21:56.659
But that's just what's gonna dictate that
so we can tie it to a particular system.

443
00:21:57.840 --> 00:22:00.460
All right, and on the next screen is
where we pick that system, right?

444
00:22:00.460 --> 00:22:02.400
Who's my source server?

445
00:22:02.400 --> 00:22:04.710
And I can add in all of
those servers if I want.

446
00:22:04.710 --> 00:22:07.270
See, I've got all my client
access servers here.

447
00:22:07.270 --> 00:22:08.660
Or I could add in just one,

448
00:22:08.660 --> 00:22:13.100
and it's all gonna get flown right
through that one system, all right?

449
00:22:13.100 --> 00:22:16.460
So in my case I'll put them both,
here's my two client access servers.

450
00:22:16.460 --> 00:22:19.140
Now, if one server's down we can just
go through the other one, right?

451
00:22:19.140 --> 00:22:20.880
It can use either one,
we get that redundancy.

452
00:22:23.000 --> 00:22:23.610
All right.

453
00:22:23.610 --> 00:22:26.480
Once that's done,
I've now created my first send connector,

454
00:22:26.480 --> 00:22:27.950
my Internet connector.

455
00:22:27.950 --> 00:22:30.010
And now I can send email to the Internet,
right?

456
00:22:30.010 --> 00:22:32.960
Now outgoing email can actually go out.

457
00:22:32.960 --> 00:22:37.200
Email to internal domains can go and
email to external domains can go, right?

458
00:22:37.200 --> 00:22:38.970
For most people,
you're gonna stop right there.

459
00:22:38.970 --> 00:22:40.498
You just need one send connector.

460
00:22:40.498 --> 00:22:41.033
You're done.

461
00:22:41.033 --> 00:22:42.531
Now you've got connectivity
to the Internet.

462
00:22:42.531 --> 00:22:46.090
But, let's say you start doing
business with a business partner, and

463
00:22:46.090 --> 00:22:48.937
you are communicating back and
forth with them a lot, and

464
00:22:48.937 --> 00:22:52.966
you want to set up a VPN tunnel, or maybe
you've already set up the VPN tunnel, so

465
00:22:52.966 --> 00:22:56.440
that you can securely
communicate with their network.

466
00:22:56.440 --> 00:22:59.630
Well, maybe you wan email
to that vendor to go across

467
00:22:59.630 --> 00:23:02.200
the VPN tunnel instead of
going out to the Internet.

468
00:23:02.200 --> 00:23:05.120
So I want to change the mail flow for
that.

469
00:23:05.120 --> 00:23:06.070
I want the mail flow for

470
00:23:06.070 --> 00:23:10.010
email going to my business partner to go
over this VPN tunnel instead, all right?

471
00:23:10.010 --> 00:23:14.980
Well, for that, I can create a dedicated
send connector that overrides this one,

472
00:23:14.980 --> 00:23:15.920
all right?

473
00:23:15.920 --> 00:23:16.480
So I'm gonna do that.

474
00:23:16.480 --> 00:23:20.801
I'm gonna add in another send connector,
and when I start to create this one,

475
00:23:20.801 --> 00:23:22.186
I can put in what this is.

476
00:23:22.186 --> 00:23:24.902
This'll be my business partner, right?

477
00:23:24.902 --> 00:23:28.977
And I'm gonna say that is going to be, you
could say custom, I'm gonna say partner,

478
00:23:28.977 --> 00:23:32.230
so we want to route email to
a trusted third-party server, right?

479
00:23:32.230 --> 00:23:35.460
Now, I can say custom and just specify
the destination, same thing, but

480
00:23:35.460 --> 00:23:37.598
I'll go with partner, all right?

481
00:23:37.598 --> 00:23:40.150
Here it's gonna ask to send it, all right?

482
00:23:40.150 --> 00:23:43.985
Now it's defaulting to doing an MX record
associated with the recipient domain.

483
00:23:43.985 --> 00:23:47.796
And notice it's not letting me pick
that route through a smart host, okay?

484
00:23:47.796 --> 00:23:50.759
And the reason is, it's assuming if
I've got a trusted business partner,

485
00:23:50.759 --> 00:23:53.180
that I've modified the MX records
to be able to reflect that.

486
00:23:53.180 --> 00:23:55.310
Now in my case, I haven't.

487
00:23:55.310 --> 00:23:57.522
So, I'm gonna back up.

488
00:23:57.522 --> 00:23:58.916
And this time I'll choose Custom so

489
00:23:58.916 --> 00:24:02.380
that it let's me do it, cuz I don't want
to go and modify DNS if I don't have to.

490
00:24:02.380 --> 00:24:05.200
All right, so on this one I'm gonna say,
hey I wanna route this email through

491
00:24:05.200 --> 00:24:07.790
a smart host and
I'm gonna add in who that host is.

492
00:24:07.790 --> 00:24:09.660
And so I'll call them and I'll say,

493
00:24:09.660 --> 00:24:11.820
hey on your network what's the IP
address of your mail server.

494
00:24:11.820 --> 00:24:15.020
So I can just send directly to it and
cross that VPN tunnel.

495
00:24:15.020 --> 00:24:16.940
And so they'll give you an internal IP, so

496
00:24:16.940 --> 00:24:21.360
maybe something like 172.16.0.100,
or whatever it is.

497
00:24:21.360 --> 00:24:23.420
Maybe you have a fully
qualified domain name.

498
00:24:23.420 --> 00:24:25.350
Whatever it is on their network
that you want to reach out to,

499
00:24:25.350 --> 00:24:26.610
to that other system.

500
00:24:29.420 --> 00:24:31.602
All right, email flowing through here,

501
00:24:31.602 --> 00:24:34.605
for my partner's domain,
I'm gonna send to this host.

502
00:24:34.605 --> 00:24:37.910
All right, then we specify
whether we want to authenticate.

503
00:24:37.910 --> 00:24:40.750
I'm not gonna do authentication, it's
gonna be encrypted over the VPN tunnel,

504
00:24:40.750 --> 00:24:42.320
so we'll just send it along.

505
00:24:42.320 --> 00:24:44.940
But you might have authentication,
they give you a user and password and

506
00:24:44.940 --> 00:24:47.050
now you can send it along,
you'd specify it right here.

507
00:24:48.660 --> 00:24:50.660
Then the address space, this is important.

508
00:24:50.660 --> 00:24:54.490
I did a star when I created that Internet
one, right, every domain on the Internet.

509
00:24:54.490 --> 00:24:59.790
But here it's just the business partner,
so I would add their domain name in here.

510
00:24:59.790 --> 00:25:05.070
So for this one it's businesspartner.net,
or whatever their address happens to be.

511
00:25:05.070 --> 00:25:07.730
So I'm just gonna punch in that domain.

512
00:25:07.730 --> 00:25:11.770
Any email that's going to
a user@businesspartner.net it's

513
00:25:11.770 --> 00:25:12.830
gonna use this connector.

514
00:25:14.560 --> 00:25:17.070
All right, then I could add in more
than one if I needed to right there.

515
00:25:19.040 --> 00:25:21.940
All right then we specify what servers
are allowed to do the connection,

516
00:25:21.940 --> 00:25:23.630
and we'll probably pick all of ours.

517
00:25:23.630 --> 00:25:25.300
But you might wanna limit
it to one in particular.

518
00:25:25.300 --> 00:25:26.070
You can do that.

519
00:25:26.070 --> 00:25:28.804
Maybe not all these servers had
access to the VPN tunnel, so

520
00:25:28.804 --> 00:25:30.566
I would just pick the servers that do.

521
00:25:32.749 --> 00:25:35.670
And then we can finish that up, and
you'll see I've got a new connector.

522
00:25:35.670 --> 00:25:37.158
Here's my BusinessPartner connector.

523
00:25:37.158 --> 00:25:41.120
Any email that's going to that domain is
going to get sent over to this connector.

524
00:25:41.120 --> 00:25:44.230
And then everything else is going
to hit my internet connector.

525
00:25:44.230 --> 00:25:47.250
Now I've got outbound email
functioning on my system and

526
00:25:47.250 --> 00:25:49.540
that business partner is
being handled separately.

527
00:25:49.540 --> 00:25:50.750
So when it comes to send and

528
00:25:50.750 --> 00:25:54.980
receive connectors, they're a great
way to manipulate mail flow.

529
00:25:54.980 --> 00:25:57.600
How mail comes in and how mail goes out.

530
00:25:57.600 --> 00:26:00.420
And fortunately they're one of those
things where we usually set them up and

531
00:26:00.420 --> 00:26:01.790
then we never have to touch them again.

532
00:26:01.790 --> 00:26:03.340
You just ignore them and that's it.

533
00:26:03.340 --> 00:26:06.390
But, if you ever need to change
mail flows, that's where you do it.

534
00:26:07.440 --> 00:26:09.480
All right, well in this episode we
got a chance to see our send and

535
00:26:09.480 --> 00:26:10.220
receive connectors.

536
00:26:10.220 --> 00:26:14.000
Remember the send connectors,
those were how our outbound email flows.

537
00:26:14.000 --> 00:26:16.860
And we might need to customize that if
we're trying to redirect business partner

538
00:26:16.860 --> 00:26:20.100
stuff, or redirect all our mail to flow
through a firewall or virus scan or

539
00:26:20.100 --> 00:26:21.300
something like that.

540
00:26:21.300 --> 00:26:23.620
Our receive connectors is
how our email comes in.

541
00:26:23.620 --> 00:26:26.550
And we might need to modify those if
we're trying to change permissions,

542
00:26:26.550 --> 00:26:27.240
authentication.

543
00:26:27.240 --> 00:26:30.390
Or if we're trying to set up exceptions,
like for on office printer or

544
00:26:30.390 --> 00:26:33.510
other device, we may need to
manipulate those receive connectors.

545
00:26:33.510 --> 00:26:36.090
The other time we modify them Is

546
00:26:36.090 --> 00:26:39.160
when we're just trying to change which
servers are responsible for what.

547
00:26:39.160 --> 00:26:41.788
But they're very important, and
at a minimum you're gonna need to

548
00:26:41.788 --> 00:26:44.292
create one send connector to be
able to connect to the internet.

549
00:26:44.292 --> 00:26:47.240
Otherwise your exchange server
is gonna be internal only.

550
00:26:47.240 --> 00:26:48.870
So definitely be aware of that.

551
00:26:48.870 --> 00:26:52.320
But that's a pretty good run down on
the two connectors, and how we use them.

552
00:26:52.320 --> 00:26:54.180
So that's all I got for this episode.

553
00:26:54.180 --> 00:26:55.510
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

554
00:26:55.510 --> 00:26:59.488
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

555
00:26:59.488 --> 00:27:03.992
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how Transport Rules function in Exchange 2013. He then demonstrates how to configure Transport Rules to achieve common scenarios like appending a legal disclaimer to all emails.
episodes.title: Transport Rules
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.183 --> 00:00:10.513
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.513 --> 00:00:13.552
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.552 --> 00:00:15.593
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.593 --> 00:00:17.393
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.393 --> 00:00:20.263
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.263 --> 00:00:23.973
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at Hub Transport Rules.

7
00:00:23.973 --> 00:00:26.182
Now, hub transport rules are, I'm sorry,

8
00:00:26.182 --> 00:00:29.683
I should actually call them by their
new name which is Transport Rules.

9
00:00:29.683 --> 00:00:31.553
We kinda got rid of that hub.

10
00:00:31.553 --> 00:00:36.198
So transport rules are a really neat
service inside of Exchange that allows us

11
00:00:36.198 --> 00:00:39.423
to do stuff to emails that
passes through our system.

12
00:00:39.423 --> 00:00:40.933
And that's kinda neat.

13
00:00:40.933 --> 00:00:43.103
Let's back this up a little bit.

14
00:00:43.103 --> 00:00:46.399
At the very beginning of the episode I
called these hub transport rules and

15
00:00:46.399 --> 00:00:49.698
that's because in previous versions
of Exchange you have what was called

16
00:00:49.698 --> 00:00:51.110
a Hub Transport Server.

17
00:00:51.110 --> 00:00:54.300
And that server was responsible for
applying hub transport rules.

18
00:00:54.300 --> 00:01:00.460
Well, in new Exchange 2013 at least, you
don't have a hub transport server anymore.

19
00:01:00.460 --> 00:01:02.312
Now you have a hub transport service, so

20
00:01:02.312 --> 00:01:06.018
its not a dedicated server its a service
that runs right on your mailbox servers,

21
00:01:06.018 --> 00:01:09.778
and so that's why Microsoft said you know
what we're gonna take the hub transport

22
00:01:09.778 --> 00:01:13.470
role over we're just gonna drop the hub
off and we'll call it a transport rule.

23
00:01:13.470 --> 00:01:16.660
When email is being transported
through your system,

24
00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:18.890
you can define rules that apply to it.

25
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:22.948
Now a lot of us use rules like these all
the time anyway you have Outlook rules,

26
00:01:22.948 --> 00:01:23.720
Inbox rules.

27
00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:26.960
I might have rules that say if
I get an email from Ronnie,

28
00:01:26.960 --> 00:01:28.520
send it to my recycle bin.

29
00:01:28.520 --> 00:01:31.390
Or if I get an email from somebody else,
I might forward it along, or

30
00:01:31.390 --> 00:01:33.230
do think you'll put it
in a particular folder.

31
00:01:33.230 --> 00:01:37.020
These are rules that we can dictate
that say what happens to email.

32
00:01:37.020 --> 00:01:41.550
Well, a transport rule is the same thing,
except it's done at the server level.

33
00:01:41.550 --> 00:01:44.730
So it can be applied to all email
passing through your organization, and

34
00:01:44.730 --> 00:01:46.130
that's pretty important, right?

35
00:01:46.130 --> 00:01:48.740
That means we can do a lot of
really cool stuff with it.

36
00:01:48.740 --> 00:01:53.160
Now, one of the neat things we have
with the Exchanges Design, is that

37
00:01:53.160 --> 00:01:58.810
every single email, 100% of your email,
passes through the hub transport service.

38
00:01:58.810 --> 00:01:59.760
It has to.

39
00:01:59.760 --> 00:02:05.320
And every mailbox server in Exchange
2013 is a hub transport service system.

40
00:02:05.320 --> 00:02:07.910
It's all running a copy
of the transport service.

41
00:02:07.910 --> 00:02:12.400
So if it's an inside email going out,
if it's an outside email coming in,

42
00:02:12.400 --> 00:02:16.720
if it's two internal users emailing each
other, now it doesn't go outside at all.

43
00:02:16.720 --> 00:02:21.640
It still goes through the hub transport
service on a mailbox server somewhere.

44
00:02:21.640 --> 00:02:24.910
And the odds are it's gonna pass through
the hub transport service on more than one

45
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:28.390
server as it moves around to get to
the destination where it needs to be.

46
00:02:28.390 --> 00:02:33.260
So the hub transport service is in
a unique position, it's the only service

47
00:02:33.260 --> 00:02:38.140
of all the services in exchange that
actually sees 100% of the email.

48
00:02:38.140 --> 00:02:39.850
It sees it all.

49
00:02:39.850 --> 00:02:42.900
So that's what gives it that unique
ability to create these rules.

50
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:45.830
Back in the old days, you used to
have where Microsoft Outlook could

51
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:47.560
directly contact the mailbox database.

52
00:02:47.560 --> 00:02:50.220
And that meant there was no way to
apply rules to it at the server and

53
00:02:50.220 --> 00:02:52.020
that created a lot of issues.

54
00:02:52.020 --> 00:02:53.810
Or if we did we had to create rules and

55
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:56.390
synchronize them across all
the servers and it was a nightmare.

56
00:02:56.390 --> 00:02:57.860
Well now we don't have that problem,

57
00:02:57.860 --> 00:03:02.090
because all email without exception
goes thru the hub transport rule, or

58
00:03:02.090 --> 00:03:05.710
hub transport service, and
that's where we can apply these rules.

59
00:03:05.710 --> 00:03:07.370
Well, let me show you
where these rules are and

60
00:03:07.370 --> 00:03:09.670
then we'll talk about some the different
things we can do with them.

61
00:03:09.670 --> 00:03:13.638
So here I'm logged into my Exchange
Administration Center, and in the EAC if

62
00:03:13.638 --> 00:03:19.370
you login and you go down to mail flow,
inside of mail flow you'll see rules.

63
00:03:19.370 --> 00:03:20.240
It's the first tab, and

64
00:03:20.240 --> 00:03:22.790
it's usually chosen by default
that I've clicked off of it here.

65
00:03:22.790 --> 00:03:25.100
But you can go into rules, and
you can see rules that you have.

66
00:03:25.100 --> 00:03:26.730
Now by default, there's no rules.

67
00:03:27.770 --> 00:03:31.190
Any email is allowed to come in,
any email is allowed to go out, and

68
00:03:31.190 --> 00:03:32.770
it does so unmodified.

69
00:03:32.770 --> 00:03:35.660
We don't touch them at all,
they just flow through.

70
00:03:35.660 --> 00:03:36.990
That's the default.

71
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:41.720
Then it's up to us to come through and
configure what we want to have happen.

72
00:03:41.720 --> 00:03:43.840
What are some examples of what
we might want to have happen?

73
00:03:43.840 --> 00:03:47.320
Well, a great example is that we might
want to apply a legal disclaimer to

74
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:48.120
our email.

75
00:03:48.120 --> 00:03:49.730
I'm sure you guys have
received one of those before.

76
00:03:49.730 --> 00:03:53.130
You get an email and you read it and then
right below the person's signature is this

77
00:03:53.130 --> 00:03:57.730
big disclaimer, and it says this email
is intended for the recipient only.

78
00:03:57.730 --> 00:03:59.870
If you've received this email in error,
please delete it.

79
00:03:59.870 --> 00:04:00.830
Something like that.

80
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:05.310
It's just junk, legal stuff, and if you've
ever wondered why people even bother with

81
00:04:05.310 --> 00:04:07.240
that, it's called due diligence.

82
00:04:07.240 --> 00:04:10.750
If they ever take somebody to court for
having information they shouldn't have and

83
00:04:10.750 --> 00:04:13.340
that person says, well,
you accidentally sent me this email.

84
00:04:13.340 --> 00:04:16.290
They can say, well we put a disclaimer
right at the bottom that says you're

85
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:17.400
not supposed to have that.

86
00:04:17.400 --> 00:04:21.070
So we did our due diligence and
now they can take you to court.

87
00:04:21.070 --> 00:04:23.390
If they didn't do that then
they couldn't go to cour.

88
00:04:23.390 --> 00:04:25.250
So it's really just for
litigation purposes.

89
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:26.860
Most of the time we don't
really care about it.

90
00:04:26.860 --> 00:04:28.760
But it is an important thing to have.

91
00:04:28.760 --> 00:04:32.610
Well, how will we make sure that all of
our users are putting the legal disclaimer

92
00:04:32.610 --> 00:04:33.730
on their email?

93
00:04:33.730 --> 00:04:34.880
The short answer is you can't.

94
00:04:34.880 --> 00:04:37.980
You can't trust your users
to do it all the time, so

95
00:04:37.980 --> 00:04:42.800
instead, we can use a transport rule
to do it, that says anytime an email

96
00:04:42.800 --> 00:04:45.770
passes through our system,
stick this disclaimer on the bottom.

97
00:04:45.770 --> 00:04:46.910
It's a really simple process.

98
00:04:46.910 --> 00:04:48.070
Let me show you how it works.

99
00:04:48.070 --> 00:04:49.920
We can go in here and
we can create a rule.

100
00:04:49.920 --> 00:04:53.810
And when you create a rule, the very
first option is create a new rule.

101
00:04:53.810 --> 00:04:57.060
And that's the one that gives
you full capability to pick and

102
00:04:57.060 --> 00:04:59.320
choose exactly what you
want this rule to do.

103
00:05:00.400 --> 00:05:03.070
All the other ones are templates.

104
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:07.090
Microsoft includes about ten templates
here that are common things that you might

105
00:05:07.090 --> 00:05:08.220
want to do.

106
00:05:08.220 --> 00:05:10.920
So I mentioned attaching
a legal disclaimer.

107
00:05:10.920 --> 00:05:14.280
Well, that's actually option number
three here, apply disclaimers.

108
00:05:14.280 --> 00:05:16.330
Now I could choose create new rule.

109
00:05:16.330 --> 00:05:18.080
And create this myself by hand.

110
00:05:18.080 --> 00:05:21.270
But because they've given me a template,
I can just use that.

111
00:05:21.270 --> 00:05:24.323
Now, when I click on the template,
it's really no different than if

112
00:05:24.323 --> 00:05:27.970
I created the rule myself, except it's
already got some values filled in for me.

113
00:05:27.970 --> 00:05:29.470
Now what is it filling in?

114
00:05:29.470 --> 00:05:33.140
When you make a rule,
the rule is made up of three parts.

115
00:05:33.140 --> 00:05:37.080
The first part is a condition, and you'll
hear Microsoft refer to it as a predicate

116
00:05:37.080 --> 00:05:39.400
sometimes on the exam you
might see that word predicate.

117
00:05:39.400 --> 00:05:40.210
It's just conditions.

118
00:05:41.220 --> 00:05:44.080
What emails will this policy apply to?

119
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:48.050
We don't normally want a rule
to apply to a 100% of our email.

120
00:05:48.050 --> 00:05:50.630
So for example,
if I'm attaching a legal disclaimer,

121
00:05:50.630 --> 00:05:54.590
a legal disclaimer needs to be attached
to emails that I'm sending out.

122
00:05:54.590 --> 00:05:59.840
If it's an internal user sending it to an
outside user, I want the disclaimer there.

123
00:05:59.840 --> 00:06:02.960
But what if it's an internal user
sending to another internal user?

124
00:06:02.960 --> 00:06:04.600
Do I need the disclaimer there?

125
00:06:04.600 --> 00:06:06.050
Maybe.

126
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:07.700
But it's up to me,
it's up to my environment.

127
00:06:07.700 --> 00:06:08.700
It's kinda situational.

128
00:06:08.700 --> 00:06:11.020
I have to pick whether or not I want that.

129
00:06:11.020 --> 00:06:13.580
Or what if it's an outside
email coming in?

130
00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:15.740
It's an email somebody
else sent coming in to me.

131
00:06:15.740 --> 00:06:17.956
Do I wanna attach a disclaimer there?

132
00:06:17.956 --> 00:06:19.115
Probably not.

133
00:06:19.115 --> 00:06:23.885
So we define conditions,
let's say what emails they apply to.

134
00:06:23.885 --> 00:06:26.365
Then we define actions.

135
00:06:26.365 --> 00:06:28.025
And actions are what we're gonna do to it.

136
00:06:28.025 --> 00:06:29.825
In this case we're gonna pin some text and
email.

137
00:06:30.935 --> 00:06:35.315
And then lastly there's an optional
third part which are exceptions.

138
00:06:35.315 --> 00:06:37.785
Your conditions may grab a lot of email,
and

139
00:06:37.785 --> 00:06:41.390
then you do exceptions to exclude
certain traffic from that rule.

140
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:43.120
So you can specify all that.

141
00:06:43.120 --> 00:06:44.350
It's all in three parts.

142
00:06:44.350 --> 00:06:47.820
Conditions, actions, exceptions.

143
00:06:47.820 --> 00:06:51.210
Now on the screen, when we look at it
by default, you only see conditions and

144
00:06:51.210 --> 00:06:52.020
actions.

145
00:06:52.020 --> 00:06:55.300
The exceptions are hidden away
under this more options button.

146
00:06:55.300 --> 00:06:57.060
And I'll be honest with you guys.

147
00:06:57.060 --> 00:06:59.230
Just get used to hitting
that more options button,

148
00:06:59.230 --> 00:07:02.490
because when you look at things
like the do the following.

149
00:07:02.490 --> 00:07:05.790
Do the following, that's the action
that we take, if I drop that down,

150
00:07:05.790 --> 00:07:09.900
see how I only see like six actions,
that's not very exciting.

151
00:07:09.900 --> 00:07:12.330
I can forward the message for approval,

152
00:07:12.330 --> 00:07:15.740
I can redirect the message,
I can reject the message,

153
00:07:15.740 --> 00:07:20.140
delete the message, blind copy the message
or append a disclaimer and that's it.

154
00:07:20.140 --> 00:07:21.120
Just six things.

155
00:07:21.120 --> 00:07:22.460
That's not exciting.

156
00:07:22.460 --> 00:07:29.100
But if you click on more options, now
that do the following has a lot of stuff.

157
00:07:29.100 --> 00:07:30.890
And a lot of these have arrows that
branch out into even more things.

158
00:07:30.890 --> 00:07:35.140
You'll see there's a ton of options
in here and a ton of power.

159
00:07:35.140 --> 00:07:36.520
So just get used to hitting more options.

160
00:07:36.520 --> 00:07:38.820
You're pretty much gonna
need that all the time.

161
00:07:38.820 --> 00:07:40.220
But, when you go in here and

162
00:07:40.220 --> 00:07:43.310
start to define this rule,
you're telling it what you want it to do.

163
00:07:43.310 --> 00:07:47.328
Let me go back to this simple screen,
where I'm just applying a disclaimer.

164
00:07:47.328 --> 00:07:50.227
The first part is, well,
I do need to give it a name, so

165
00:07:50.227 --> 00:07:52.766
I'm just gonna call this
my legal disclaimer.

166
00:07:52.766 --> 00:07:56.717
And then apply this rule if,
these are my conditions.

167
00:07:56.717 --> 00:07:58.359
Who does this apply to?

168
00:07:58.359 --> 00:08:01.740
And if I'm doing a legal disclaimer,
I might wanna just come in here and say,

169
00:08:01.740 --> 00:08:03.140
apply to all messages.

170
00:08:03.140 --> 00:08:06.173
I want this to apply to
100% of the messages.

171
00:08:06.173 --> 00:08:08.120
But there's a little problem there.

172
00:08:08.120 --> 00:08:13.150
My problem is I don't necessarily want
it to apply to outside emails coming in.

173
00:08:13.150 --> 00:08:14.870
So now, I need to make a choice.

174
00:08:14.870 --> 00:08:16.760
The choice is kind of a difficult one.

175
00:08:16.760 --> 00:08:20.140
Sometimes I can get my
email selected right here

176
00:08:20.140 --> 00:08:22.640
without having to do exceptions.

177
00:08:22.640 --> 00:08:25.340
Other times, I have to use an exception.

178
00:08:25.340 --> 00:08:27.960
So we kind of have to fiddle with this a
bit to find out which one's gonna work in

179
00:08:27.960 --> 00:08:30.500
our scenario and
everybody's scenario is different.

180
00:08:30.500 --> 00:08:32.320
So it's not a one size fits all.

181
00:08:32.320 --> 00:08:35.050
You've really got to tune
this to your own environment.

182
00:08:35.050 --> 00:08:39.400
So if I want this to apply to every email,
be it internal or

183
00:08:39.400 --> 00:08:43.480
inside going out, I just don't want it
to apply to outside people coming in.

184
00:08:43.480 --> 00:08:46.940
I could drop this down and
pick from the different lists.

185
00:08:46.940 --> 00:08:51.154
And you'll see things like if
the sender is dot dot dot.

186
00:08:51.154 --> 00:08:52.528
When you see the ellipses,

187
00:08:52.528 --> 00:08:56.270
the three dots, that's your hint
that there's more to this one.

188
00:08:56.270 --> 00:09:00.680
So I can say apply this
rule if the sender is, and

189
00:09:00.680 --> 00:09:03.820
I could pick a particular person or
a group.

190
00:09:03.820 --> 00:09:06.090
And so now, it's just going to
apply to that individual person.

191
00:09:06.090 --> 00:09:07.792
Well I wanna grab all of
my internal users and

192
00:09:07.792 --> 00:09:09.361
I don't have a good way of doing it here.

193
00:09:09.361 --> 00:09:10.731
So I'm gonna cancel that.

194
00:09:10.731 --> 00:09:13.339
And then I'll look and
see if the sender is located,

195
00:09:13.339 --> 00:09:16.190
that would be if they're
in a particular place.

196
00:09:16.190 --> 00:09:20.870
If the sender is a member of some group
but I don't have a good group for that.

197
00:09:20.870 --> 00:09:23.330
If the sender address includes well,
all right.

198
00:09:23.330 --> 00:09:25.700
So maybe I could do my domains but
if I have a bunch of domains,

199
00:09:25.700 --> 00:09:26.730
that's kind of a hassle.

200
00:09:26.730 --> 00:09:31.950
So none of these really help me for
getting just internal employees.

201
00:09:31.950 --> 00:09:34.420
So I'm gonna choose Apply to all Messages.

202
00:09:34.420 --> 00:09:36.533
And then I'll create an exception for

203
00:09:36.533 --> 00:09:39.644
when the sender is outside
when the sender is external.

204
00:09:39.644 --> 00:09:42.344
Sometimes you have to use an exception
sometimes you can get away

205
00:09:42.344 --> 00:09:44.100
without using one.

206
00:09:44.100 --> 00:09:45.150
And then I'm gonna do the following.

207
00:09:45.150 --> 00:09:47.220
I'm going to append a disclaimer.

208
00:09:47.220 --> 00:09:49.760
Now, when you choose append a disclaimer

209
00:09:49.760 --> 00:09:53.200
over here it's got
an option to enter in text.

210
00:09:53.200 --> 00:09:54.740
So that what I need to do.

211
00:09:54.740 --> 00:09:59.180
So I'm going to hit Enter text and
I'm gonna specify that disclaimer text.

212
00:09:59.180 --> 00:10:04.910
So I'll just say something like,
we can be really detailed here,

213
00:10:04.910 --> 00:10:07.360
we can say whatever it is.

214
00:10:07.360 --> 00:10:11.190
I'll just say do not read this email.

215
00:10:11.190 --> 00:10:13.040
That's the easy way to be safe.

216
00:10:13.040 --> 00:10:14.720
We told you not to read it,
and you read it.

217
00:10:14.720 --> 00:10:15.550
So there we go.

218
00:10:15.550 --> 00:10:18.620
So you can define your disclaimer with
whatever syntax your legal department

219
00:10:18.620 --> 00:10:19.480
gives you, you punch it in there.

220
00:10:20.750 --> 00:10:23.970
So, that's what we're gonna be doing
right there, appending that disclaimer.

221
00:10:23.970 --> 00:10:27.520
Now, I need to do an exception, and
exceptions don't show up by default.

222
00:10:27.520 --> 00:10:28.710
So I'm gonna have to go to more options.

223
00:10:28.710 --> 00:10:29.470
But before I do that,

224
00:10:29.470 --> 00:10:31.540
let me talk about some of these
other things that we've got here.

225
00:10:31.540 --> 00:10:33.150
We've got audit this rule.

226
00:10:34.310 --> 00:10:36.600
Do we want to do logging for this rule?

227
00:10:36.600 --> 00:10:37.761
And you might.

228
00:10:37.761 --> 00:10:40.410
If this is some kind of security
concern then we might need to log it or

229
00:10:40.410 --> 00:10:42.830
if we're just doing testing,
you might want to log it today.

230
00:10:42.830 --> 00:10:45.570
But you'll see on here we've
got options for testing too.

231
00:10:45.570 --> 00:10:49.680
You got enforce, that means the rule
is active and applying to the system.

232
00:10:49.680 --> 00:10:51.030
And you've got testing.

233
00:10:51.030 --> 00:10:54.020
Testing doesn't actually apply the rule.

234
00:10:54.020 --> 00:10:57.870
The rule is sort of in effect,
you won't be attaching legal disclaimers.

235
00:10:57.870 --> 00:11:04.280
If you choose test with policy tips,
then when you draft an email, you'll see

236
00:11:04.280 --> 00:11:09.270
a mail tip appear that will tell you what
would happen if this policy was enforced.

237
00:11:09.270 --> 00:11:10.420
So that's one way to do it.

238
00:11:10.420 --> 00:11:14.200
If you choose test without policy tips,
every time this policy would apply,

239
00:11:14.200 --> 00:11:15.980
it will send you an email
letting you know.

240
00:11:15.980 --> 00:11:17.780
It's a good way to test.

241
00:11:17.780 --> 00:11:21.310
Both of those require connecting
up with Office 365 though.

242
00:11:21.310 --> 00:11:23.320
And so if you're running in
a standalone environment,

243
00:11:23.320 --> 00:11:25.450
these two tests are not really useful.

244
00:11:25.450 --> 00:11:27.570
So if you're trying to test the rule and

245
00:11:27.570 --> 00:11:31.590
you want to really throttle it down,
you should set up a apply this rule and

246
00:11:31.590 --> 00:11:35.580
limit it just to your account or just to a
test account and test the rule with that.

247
00:11:35.580 --> 00:11:38.420
And then switch it to apply to all
messages and then you're taken care of.

248
00:11:40.280 --> 00:11:43.180
So I'm gonna hit more options though,
cuz I need to set an exception.

249
00:11:43.180 --> 00:11:48.230
And now, you'll see apply this rule if,
that's my condition, do the following,

250
00:11:48.230 --> 00:11:52.190
that's my action, and except if,
there's my exceptions.

251
00:11:52.190 --> 00:11:56.009
And I'm gonna add an exception, and
I'm gonna say, if the sender and

252
00:11:56.009 --> 00:11:59.765
then notice I've got some nice little
options in here like this one,

253
00:11:59.765 --> 00:12:01.939
if the sender is external or internal.

254
00:12:01.939 --> 00:12:03.570
I'm gonna choose that.

255
00:12:03.570 --> 00:12:06.055
And I'm gonna choose if
the sender is outside.

256
00:12:06.055 --> 00:12:10.460
If this isn't email being sent from
somebody outside my organization.

257
00:12:10.460 --> 00:12:13.050
I don't want to attach a legal
disclaimer to their stuff.

258
00:12:13.050 --> 00:12:15.360
I want it attached to mine.

259
00:12:15.360 --> 00:12:18.210
So now,
internal users will have this apply.

260
00:12:18.210 --> 00:12:22.010
So inside email going out or
inside email going to inside people.

261
00:12:22.010 --> 00:12:25.637
But outside email coming in,
this rule won't apply.

262
00:12:25.637 --> 00:12:29.102
And I'll go ahead and
save my rule and now it's saying,

263
00:12:29.102 --> 00:12:31.920
do I wanna apply this
to all future messages?

264
00:12:31.920 --> 00:12:34.480
And I'll say yes, and
looks like I got a problem.

265
00:12:34.480 --> 00:12:35.710
It says I got an error here.

266
00:12:35.710 --> 00:12:38.520
Please fix the highlighted fields and
try saving again.

267
00:12:38.520 --> 00:12:40.610
Oh, my fallback option.

268
00:12:40.610 --> 00:12:44.090
Up here I've got this legal disclaimer,
and I didn't set a fallback option.

269
00:12:44.090 --> 00:12:45.600
See how it lit up in red?

270
00:12:45.600 --> 00:12:50.050
So what do you do if it fails
to attach the legal disclaimer?

271
00:12:50.050 --> 00:12:51.460
Something could happen.

272
00:12:51.460 --> 00:12:54.750
If the email is encrypted,
can we attach a legal disclaimer?

273
00:12:54.750 --> 00:12:56.330
Kind of hard to do that.

274
00:12:56.330 --> 00:12:58.250
So there's situations where it might fail.

275
00:12:58.250 --> 00:13:00.710
So what do we do if it fails?

276
00:13:00.710 --> 00:13:03.670
Well you can hit select one and
you can pick an option.

277
00:13:03.670 --> 00:13:07.750
And we can say rapid,
which means just stick the disclaimer on

278
00:13:07.750 --> 00:13:10.450
after the encrypted stuff,
you can do that.

279
00:13:10.450 --> 00:13:11.950
Or we can say ignore it.

280
00:13:11.950 --> 00:13:16.690
Just let the email go through without
a legal disclaimer or we can reject it.

281
00:13:16.690 --> 00:13:18.830
And if that legal disclaimer is there,

282
00:13:18.830 --> 00:13:21.470
if your legal department has asked you
to do that, it's pretty important.

283
00:13:21.470 --> 00:13:23.360
We probably wanna reject the email.

284
00:13:23.360 --> 00:13:27.210
If we can't attach the disclaimer,
we need to reject it.

285
00:13:27.210 --> 00:13:31.190
So these are the options that we have to
pick and now that I've got that said I

286
00:13:31.190 --> 00:13:35.588
should be able to save my rule and
Will have this rule.

287
00:13:35.588 --> 00:13:40.530
So now, 100% of the emails that
are moving through my organization

288
00:13:40.530 --> 00:13:44.610
get this rule applied to them and if the
sender is outside it doesn't do anything.

289
00:13:44.610 --> 00:13:47.690
But if the sender is internal,
this rule applies and

290
00:13:47.690 --> 00:13:49.310
it will append that disclaimer.

291
00:13:49.310 --> 00:13:53.020
Now as you create rules, you're going to
notice this priority filed over here and

292
00:13:53.020 --> 00:13:54.150
this one got a priority of zero.

293
00:13:55.410 --> 00:14:00.180
As you create the rules, the priority
determines the order they're applied in.

294
00:14:00.180 --> 00:14:02.530
And so as they go through,
it starts at the top and it goes down.

295
00:14:02.530 --> 00:14:05.560
You wanna have more than one rule
that applies to the same email.

296
00:14:05.560 --> 00:14:07.688
It's very common.

297
00:14:07.688 --> 00:14:09.240
So keep that in mind.

298
00:14:09.240 --> 00:14:13.840
Now, if you've got a rule that
rejects email for some reason.

299
00:14:13.840 --> 00:14:16.840
Then you might wanna choose to
stop processing rules and say,

300
00:14:16.840 --> 00:14:19.820
don't process any more rules cuz you're
just wasting resources at that point.

301
00:14:19.820 --> 00:14:21.410
You're already gonna reject the email.

302
00:14:21.410 --> 00:14:24.510
And so that option was in there when
we were in the advanced settings.

303
00:14:24.510 --> 00:14:27.890
It's buried in there that you can tell
it to stop processing after this rule.

304
00:14:27.890 --> 00:14:29.210
If I scroll down here it is.

305
00:14:29.210 --> 00:14:30.880
Stop processing more rules.

306
00:14:30.880 --> 00:14:34.970
So if this rule results in an email
being rejected then I don't wanna

307
00:14:34.970 --> 00:14:37.141
process anything else after that.

308
00:14:37.141 --> 00:14:38.270
It's just wasting time.

309
00:14:38.270 --> 00:14:39.270
I can turn that on.

310
00:14:39.270 --> 00:14:40.560
But most of the time we want that off.

311
00:14:40.560 --> 00:14:44.330
We want all of our rules to apply
cuz it might not be this rule that

312
00:14:44.330 --> 00:14:45.060
rejects the email.

313
00:14:45.060 --> 00:14:46.370
It might be another rule that does so

314
00:14:46.370 --> 00:14:48.830
we gotta give it a chance to
get through all those rules.

315
00:14:48.830 --> 00:14:52.010
But it means the order of
these rules is important.

316
00:14:52.010 --> 00:14:53.060
And so you'll see my up and

317
00:14:53.060 --> 00:14:55.430
down arrows where we can change
the order they're applied in.

318
00:14:55.430 --> 00:14:57.960
So just be aware that it's
applied from top to bottom.

319
00:14:57.960 --> 00:14:59.740
In this order.

320
00:14:59.740 --> 00:15:02.781
So now, emails passing through my
organization are gonna get a legal

321
00:15:02.781 --> 00:15:04.580
disclaimer attached to them.

322
00:15:04.580 --> 00:15:08.010
That's one example of something
I can do with a transport rule.

323
00:15:08.010 --> 00:15:08.960
What are some other examples?

324
00:15:08.960 --> 00:15:12.130
Well actually here,
