let's see if this one even works first.

325
00:15:12.130 --> 00:15:15.929
So if I go in and draft a new email,
so I'm gonna create a new email here.

326
00:15:15.929 --> 00:15:21.510
And I'm gonna email Jane Smith, and I'll
just call this my legal disclaimer test.

327
00:15:22.900 --> 00:15:25.650
This is testing my legal disclaimer.

328
00:15:27.630 --> 00:15:29.620
So this email is going to
pass through my server.

329
00:15:29.620 --> 00:15:32.870
It's going to pass through my hub
transport service, and the transport

330
00:15:32.870 --> 00:15:36.770
rule is going to apply, legal disclaimer
should get attached beneath it.

331
00:15:36.770 --> 00:15:39.650
So I might have my own email signature or
whatever.

332
00:15:39.650 --> 00:15:43.571
And then I send that along, and
we'll see what happens after that.

333
00:15:43.571 --> 00:15:46.542
While we're waiting on that,
we can go into our other rules, and

334
00:15:46.542 --> 00:15:47.957
we can create some other ones.

335
00:15:47.957 --> 00:15:49.280
Another example of something we might do.

336
00:15:49.280 --> 00:15:50.932
Disclaimers are popular.

337
00:15:50.932 --> 00:15:52.859
Blocking attachments.

338
00:15:52.859 --> 00:15:57.241
Maybe I'm worried about people
opening Visual Basic scripts or

339
00:15:57.241 --> 00:15:59.600
executables, things like that.

340
00:15:59.600 --> 00:16:03.130
Well, Microsoft Outlook actually has
its own attachment screen in place,

341
00:16:03.130 --> 00:16:05.350
so we don't normally
have to worry about that.

342
00:16:05.350 --> 00:16:08.550
But we can create our own
rules that are very specific.

343
00:16:08.550 --> 00:16:10.365

344
00:16:10.365 --> 00:16:13.813
I might want to set it where some users

345
00:16:13.813 --> 00:16:16.960

00:16:16.960 --> 00:16:18.740
Let me show you.

00:16:18.740 --> 00:16:21.020
So if I add a new rule here,
I don't have a rule.

00:16:21.020 --> 00:16:22.960
Well, I guess I have
filter by message size.

00:16:22.960 --> 00:16:24.320
I could maybe do that one.

But I'm not so concerned about the message

00:16:27.890 --> 00:16:30.230
So this one doesn't specifically
single out attachments.

352
00:16:30.230 --> 00:16:34.230
So I'm gonna go to create new rule and

353
00:16:34.230 --> 00:16:41.440
And I'll call this one, maybe we'll say
block VBS attachments right I just don't

354
00:16:41.440 --> 00:16:45.917

355
00:16:47.230 --> 00:16:49.650
Apply this rule if,

00:16:49.650 --> 00:16:52.400
I wanna filter every message for

357
00:16:52.400 --> 00:16:55.589
And then do the following, we'll see
the list here of what we want to do.

358
00:16:56.950 --> 00:16:58.320
Actually, I need to change that.

00:16:58.320 --> 00:16:59.760
I don't want this to apply to every email.

00:16:59.760 --> 00:17:02.210
I want it to apply to emails
that have a VBS attachment.

361
00:17:02.210 --> 00:17:05.400
That's kind of important,
so I need to change that.

362
00:17:05.400 --> 00:17:09.610
And as I look here I've got Any

363
00:17:09.610 --> 00:17:12.490
Well, I'm not worried about
the content of the attachment,

364
00:17:12.490 --> 00:17:15.150
I'm worried about the file extension,
and that's not gonna do.

365
00:17:15.150 --> 00:17:20.060
So I'm gonna need to go into my More
options and under more options I can say

00:17:20.060 --> 00:17:23.810
If any attachment, and
now I see a lot more options.

367
00:17:23.810 --> 00:17:26.390
If the content includes certain words or
patterns.

368
00:17:26.390 --> 00:17:28.440
If the file name matches a pattern.

369
00:17:28.440 --> 00:17:32.430
If the file extension includes
these words that's what I want.

370
00:17:32.430 --> 00:17:34.700
And now we can add in whatever we want.

371
00:17:34.700 --> 00:17:40.490
I'll add in VBS, BAT, CMD, EXE,
anything that I want to filter out.

00:17:40.490 --> 00:17:43.020
Now I do know Outlook's

00:17:43.020 --> 00:17:44.820
what if I'm not connecting with Outlook?

00:17:44.820 --> 00:17:47.530
What if I'm connecting with some
third-party mail client that doesn't have

00:17:47.530 --> 00:17:48.850

00:17:48.850 --> 00:17:50.760
Well, here we can do it

00:17:50.760 --> 00:17:53.160
we'll knock it out before it

378
00:17:53.160 --> 00:17:55.340
So it never even makes it to

379
00:17:57.050 --> 00:18:00.560
So now I can say if the attachment
includes one of those things

380
00:18:00.560 --> 00:18:03.930
we're gonna block it, and now I need

381
00:18:03.930 --> 00:18:05.400
Now when you block it you
need to make a choice.

382
00:18:05.400 --> 00:18:07.030
There's two ways to block an email.

383
00:18:07.030 --> 00:18:08.540
You can silently block it.

384
00:18:08.540 --> 00:18:11.030
You just delete it and
throw it away and nobody knows.

385
00:18:11.030 --> 00:18:15.460
Or you can block it and send a message to
the sender so they know what happened.

386
00:18:15.460 --> 00:18:18.360
And you can say hey, sorry,
that attachment type's not allowed.

387
00:18:18.360 --> 00:18:19.480
So we can let them know, and so

388
00:18:19.480 --> 00:18:24.360
when you look at blocked messages
you'll see reject and delete.

389
00:18:24.360 --> 00:18:25.840
Delete is that silent block.

390
00:18:25.840 --> 00:18:28.000
It will silently delete it and
that's the end of it.

391
00:18:28.000 --> 00:18:31.140
Reject, we can send it back

392
00:18:31.140 --> 00:18:34.000
And boy, that's a pleasure to read,

393
00:18:34.000 --> 00:18:37.510
Or we can say reject the message and

00:18:37.510 --> 00:18:40.500
And we can specify the file type

395
00:18:41.530 --> 00:18:46.280
attached to the message is not allowed.

396
00:18:46.280 --> 00:18:47.870
So we can specify that.

397
00:18:47.870 --> 00:18:49.100
You don't have to reject it though.

00:18:49.100 --> 00:18:52.350
There's actually an option in here

00:18:52.350 --> 00:18:53.700
where you can strip the attachment.

400
00:18:53.700 --> 00:18:56.740
Where you can say send it along

00:18:56.740 --> 00:18:58.290
It's buried in here somewhere.

402
00:18:58.290 --> 00:19:01.830
But we'll just leave it right here,

403
00:19:01.830 --> 00:19:04.320
And I can put in exceptions if I wanted,

00:19:05.460 --> 00:19:10.340
Oh, in the chat room, Guido mentioned

00:19:10.340 --> 00:19:11.570
Those might be another

00:19:11.570 --> 00:19:13.090
There's a ton of different

407
00:19:14.540 --> 00:19:16.570
So we can punch that in,
I'm gonna block those attachments.

00:19:16.570 --> 00:19:19.490
And now if somebody tries to send one

00:19:19.490 --> 00:19:21.490
they'll get a message

410
00:19:21.490 --> 00:19:26.390
Since I didn't filter any exceptions,

411
00:19:26.390 --> 00:19:29.620
Outside users emailing in,
inside users mailing out and so on.

412
00:19:29.620 --> 00:19:30.200
It's gonna do that.

413
00:19:32.040 --> 00:19:34.730
Now if I'm blocking those attachments and

00:19:34.730 --> 00:19:39.710
I might wanna move this one up to the top

00:19:39.710 --> 00:19:40.870
Now why would I do that?

00:19:40.870 --> 00:19:44.010
Well, I don't wanna attach to a disclaimer

Why go through the trouble

And if I'm gonna reject the email anyway,

00:19:50.635 --> 00:19:53.995
I might wanna stop processing

00:19:53.995 --> 00:19:57.585
So there's a couple of different things

00:19:57.585 --> 00:20:00.465
Again, you'll have to tweak it a bit for

All right,

00:20:03.665 --> 00:20:07.095
Oh, email whitelist and blacklists.

425
00:20:07.095 --> 00:20:11.540
In Exchange, in Microsoft Outlook,

00:20:11.540 --> 00:20:13.100
So it looks at an email and

00:20:13.100 --> 00:20:16.300

assigns a spam confidence level and

00:20:16.300 --> 00:20:19.460
if the spam level is high enough
it'll get sent to your junk mail.

00:20:20.610 --> 00:20:23.680
Well, I might have emails that

00:20:23.680 --> 00:20:25.950

I want to say any email coming from

00:20:36.340 --> 00:20:40.090
So I can create a new rule, and

00:20:43.990 --> 00:20:45.060

But basically you create a rule, and

439
00:20:52.030 --> 00:20:56.890

440
00:20:56.890 --> 00:21:01.230

and I could add in myself.

441
00:21:01.230 --> 00:21:04.130
So if the sender's me,
I want this rule to apply.

00:21:05.580 --> 00:21:07.250
And you can add more conditions.

00:21:07.250 --> 00:21:10.260
I could add other conditions
in here to say, and

444
00:21:10.260 --> 00:21:12.320
the sender's in this group or whatever.

00:21:12.320 --> 00:21:13.629
You can get really
specific with this stuff.

00:21:13.629 --> 00:21:17.775
But I'm gonna say if the sender is me,
and you could add more here too,

00:21:17.775 --> 00:21:22.690
saying like Don Pezet or Ronnie Wong or

00:21:22.690 --> 00:21:23.656
And then do the following.

00:21:23.656 --> 00:21:28.690
And see how it's saying, set the spam

00:21:28.690 --> 00:21:31.150
If you look at it you
can set it from Bypass,

00:21:31.150 --> 00:21:34.650
which is always gonna get through,
or 0 through 9.

00:21:34.650 --> 00:21:37.130
If you set it to 9,
you're creating a blacklist.

00:21:37.130 --> 00:21:38.740
This email will go to spam.

454
00:21:38.740 --> 00:21:41.070
Or you could really just reject
it at that point if you want, but

455
00:21:41.070 --> 00:21:42.570
going to spam is usually a little better.

00:21:42.570 --> 00:21:45.140
Cuz the end users can still get

457
00:21:45.140 --> 00:21:47.150
So if I'm doing a blacklist
I'd choose that.

458
00:21:47.150 --> 00:21:50.250
But a whitelist I'd wanna set to 0 or

459
00:21:50.250 --> 00:21:52.010
Bypass just means send it

460
00:21:52.010 --> 00:21:54.330
don't put it in junk mail, and let it go.

461
00:21:54.330 --> 00:21:57.450
So couple of different ways that we can

462
00:21:57.450 --> 00:22:01.310
bypass and then I could put in exceptions
if I want to, but I'm not going to.

463
00:22:01.310 --> 00:22:05.550
I'll save that and
now emails from me will automatically

464
00:22:05.550 --> 00:22:08.320
bypass the spam confidence level and

00:22:10.232 --> 00:22:13.720
All right, let's see,

We did have a question

00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:43.730
All right, tagging bulk mail.

00:22:43.730 --> 00:22:45.320
If I'm receiving mailing lists.

00:22:45.320 --> 00:22:46.790
No, this is kind of a fun one.

480
00:22:46.790 --> 00:22:53.340
If I get a lot of email spam,
not email spam, but just bulk mailings,

481
00:22:53.340 --> 00:22:56.660
we could go ahead and tag those to make
it easier for users to recognize that.

482
00:22:56.660 --> 00:22:58.600
There's certain keywords you can look for.

483
00:22:58.600 --> 00:23:00.680
A great example is unsubscribe.

484
00:23:00.680 --> 00:23:05.550
If you see the word unsubscribe in
the email, the odds are it's bulk mail.

485
00:23:05.550 --> 00:23:08.510
If I send you an email personally,
am I gonna have unsubscribe in that?

486
00:23:08.510 --> 00:23:11.890
No, you're not gonna unsubscribe from
me sending you a personal email.

487
00:23:11.890 --> 00:23:15.150
But if I'm a bulk mailer, if I'm sending
you an advertisement I'm required by law

488
00:23:15.150 --> 00:23:16.910
to have the word unsubscribe there.

489
00:23:16.910 --> 00:23:20.130
And even the malicious guys will put
the word unsubscribe in there and

490
00:23:20.130 --> 00:23:21.790
they'll link to their own spam site or
whatever.

491
00:23:21.790 --> 00:23:26.330
But you could key off of that word and
say if the email message body contains

492
00:23:26.330 --> 00:23:29.685
the word unsubscribe,
set the spam confidence level to seven.

00:23:29.685 --> 00:23:31.660
There's a good chance that this is spam.

00:23:31.660 --> 00:23:35.130
Or one of my favorites is you can

00:23:35.130 --> 00:23:36.586
Let me show you what I mean.

00:23:36.586 --> 00:23:41.539
So I'm going to create a rule here,
and I'll call this Bulk Mailings,

497
00:23:41.539 --> 00:23:45.685
and I can apply the rule if I'm
going to look for something.

498
00:23:45.685 --> 00:23:48.932
I might say if the subject or
body includes And

499
00:23:48.932 --> 00:23:51.762
you can start to put in things, right?

500
00:23:51.762 --> 00:23:56.220
What are some of the things that
you normally see in a bulk mailing?

501
00:23:56.220 --> 00:23:57.690
The word unsubscribe.

502
00:23:59.430 --> 00:24:00.210
Right?

503
00:24:00.210 --> 00:24:02.180
And you can do regular expressions here.

504
00:24:02.180 --> 00:24:05.400
So if you wanna like search for
a different case and all that stuff,

505
00:24:05.400 --> 00:24:06.980
it'll accept regular expressions.

506
00:24:06.980 --> 00:24:09.380
But I'm just gonna put in like,
unsubscribe.

00:24:09.380 --> 00:24:16.510
Other things like if you are having
trouble viewing this email, right?

508
00:24:17.730 --> 00:24:20.960
Bulk mailings always have that link, if
there's an HTML email and it's not right,

00:24:20.960 --> 00:24:23.170
you can click on the link and
it will take you to their site.

510
00:24:23.170 --> 00:24:25.610
If I send you a personal
email am I gonna write that?

00:24:25.610 --> 00:24:26.907
No.
I mean these are things that you

512
00:24:26.907 --> 00:24:27.470
can look for.

513
00:24:27.470 --> 00:24:31.496
So I'm just looking for those key words
and then I can say what I'm gonna do, so

514
00:24:31.496 --> 00:24:35.768
I'm gonna do the following and if you look

00:24:35.768 --> 00:24:38.350
forward the message well
the one I wants not here.

00:24:38.350 --> 00:24:42.672
I gotta hit more options and in more

00:24:42.672 --> 00:24:47.275
that we can start to mess with the email
we can modify the message properties and

00:24:47.275 --> 00:24:50.270
you'll see things like

00:24:50.270 --> 00:24:53.780
Setting the spam confidence level,
that's not even what I want.

00:24:53.780 --> 00:24:54.460
Let's see, here.

00:24:54.460 --> 00:24:59.370
Prepend the subject of the message

00:24:59.370 --> 00:25:02.090
And I'm just gonna add the word bulk

00:25:02.090 --> 00:25:04.550

00:25:04.550 --> 00:25:07.870
So now, when the email comes in right

00:25:07.870 --> 00:25:09.820
it will have the word

00:25:09.820 --> 00:25:12.980
The users will see that and they'll

527

they'll say,
oh okay this is probably a bulk mailer.

00:25:15.110 --> 00:25:17.010
And it helps them to quickly

not that's email that's intended for them.

00:25:20.120 --> 00:25:21.900
So I can append that.

You might have, a rating system.

You have top secret, secret,

And so you might look for

then stick in the subject
line this is classified or

00:25:32.990 --> 00:25:36.130
unclassified so people can recognize

00:25:36.130 --> 00:25:38.060
There's all sorts of different
things that you can do in here.

537
00:25:38.060 --> 00:25:40.510
All right.

00:25:40.510 --> 00:25:42.390
So, I'll punch that in, and

00:25:42.390 --> 00:25:45.670
And so now if somebody has those things

00:25:45.670 --> 00:25:46.310
get flagged.

00:25:46.310 --> 00:25:47.930
Right?
And I could go and, whoops.

Where's my here.

00:25:50.010 --> 00:25:52.079
I could go and craft a new email to Jane.

00:25:54.150 --> 00:25:56.040
And my email,

00:25:56.040 --> 00:25:58.850
I know it's not gonna get flagged to

00:25:58.850 --> 00:26:03.470
But maybe I'm gonna use some of those

00:26:03.470 --> 00:26:08.070
So like this is a sample bulk message

00:26:10.080 --> 00:26:14.050
and I can say,
buy my product, it's awesome!

00:26:15.120 --> 00:26:21.580
And then something like the whole

00:26:21.580 --> 00:26:25.640
If you are having trouble viewing

you specify those phrases in here so

Right?
And it's gonna look for that content and

00:26:37.780 --> 00:26:39.080
All right.
It'll take that action and

00:26:39.080 --> 00:26:40.930
hopefully add that word

00:26:42.710 --> 00:26:44.840
All right.

00:26:44.840 --> 00:26:47.020

00:26:47.020 --> 00:26:50.440
There's really just two more I wanna

00:26:50.440 --> 00:26:55.700
One option is, what if we get email and

It's our own employee,

00:26:57.830 --> 00:27:00.790
You gotta couple of neat things

When you look at the actions

Under Actions,

00:27:16.640 --> 00:27:20.180
you can redirect their email to another
employee to take care of that, right?

568
00:27:20.180 --> 00:27:21.800
So that's one thing that you could do.

569
00:27:21.800 --> 00:27:25.590
You can also redirect it to make
sure that it gets moderated.

570
00:27:25.590 --> 00:27:27.980
See this forward the message for approval?

571
00:27:27.980 --> 00:27:31.628
You can forward the message to
a particular person or a manager, and

572
00:27:31.628 --> 00:27:35.470
in Outlook or in OWA, they'll have
a message, allow the email or not?

573
00:27:35.470 --> 00:27:38.854
And if they allow it, then it'll go to
the recipient, if they don't allow it,

574
00:27:38.854 --> 00:27:39.990
it gets rejected.

575
00:27:39.990 --> 00:27:42.680
So now you can moderate somebody's email.

576
00:27:42.680 --> 00:27:45.750
You might have employees that you don't
want, or maybe you have a child right,

577
00:27:45.750 --> 00:27:48.470
and they're not of the legal age and
so you don't want them

578
00:27:48.470 --> 00:27:51.270
getting external emails that
haven't been filtered and approved.

579
00:27:51.270 --> 00:27:52.230
You can do it right here.

580
00:27:52.230 --> 00:27:56.950
So those are some other actions that
are kinda neat that take action and

581
00:27:56.950 --> 00:28:00.000
just allow you to do
a lot of different stuff.

582
00:28:00.000 --> 00:28:02.448
All right, well I fired off
a couple of emails this episode,

583
00:28:02.448 --> 00:28:05.430
let's jump over to Jane's mailbox and
see what they look like on her end.

584
00:28:07.300 --> 00:28:10.376
Now I've got Jane's mailbox pulled
up back here in the background and

585
00:28:10.376 --> 00:28:13.260
right off the bat I can see here's
that message about my product.

586
00:28:13.260 --> 00:28:15.420
I said buy my product,
unsubscribe here and

587
00:28:15.420 --> 00:28:18.550
you can see that subject line has
the word bulk appended to it right there.

588
00:28:18.550 --> 00:28:20.680
I could've also bumped
the spam confidence level too.

589
00:28:20.680 --> 00:28:22.170
You can take more than one action,

590
00:28:22.170 --> 00:28:24.400
and that would have really
cranked that one up.

591
00:28:24.400 --> 00:28:26.340
Here's my legal disclaimer test,
and sure enough,

592
00:28:26.340 --> 00:28:31.390
that legal disclaimer is right there at
the end, tacked on at the end to let her

593
00:28:32.860 --> 00:28:36.510
know that this is a private email
that shouldn't be read or whatever.

594
00:28:36.510 --> 00:28:37.030
All right.

595
00:28:37.030 --> 00:28:38.800
That's what these
transport rules are doing.

596
00:28:38.800 --> 00:28:40.350
And it's all applying on the server.

597
00:28:40.350 --> 00:28:44.040
So it doesn't matter whether
you connect with Outlook or

598
00:28:44.040 --> 00:28:49.020
some email client on Android, iOS web,
Windows Mobile, whatever, doesn't matter.

599
00:28:49.020 --> 00:28:50.540
It's the server that's doing this.

600
00:28:50.540 --> 00:28:53.160
And all the email is passing
through the server and so

601
00:28:53.160 --> 00:28:55.340
all the emails have these rules applied.

602
00:28:55.340 --> 00:28:59.370
So transport rules, are a real
powerful function found inside of

603
00:28:59.370 --> 00:29:02.120
Microsoft Exchange and it's definitely
one of the neater things to work with.

604
00:29:03.240 --> 00:29:05.530
All right, well, that's about all
I've got on Transport Rules, so

605
00:29:05.530 --> 00:29:09.200
this is a pretty good spot for us to wrap
this one up In this episode we gotta

606
00:29:09.200 --> 00:29:12.610
choose to see what transport rules were
and what they were made up of right?

607
00:29:12.610 --> 00:29:16.550
Remember we've got the condition,
the action and the exceptions right?

608
00:29:16.550 --> 00:29:19.680
So we saw how to build those and we saw
some of the examples of the ways we can

609
00:29:19.680 --> 00:29:21.970
use Transport Rules in our organization.

610
00:29:21.970 --> 00:29:24.820
Definitely fun stuff you'll
want to take advantage of it.

611
00:29:24.820 --> 00:29:26.800
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

612
00:29:26.800 --> 00:29:28.190
Signing off for ITProTV.

613
00:29:28.190 --> 00:29:30.180
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

614
00:29:30.180 --> 00:29:35.890
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores the message queues maintained by the Hub Transport Service found on Exchange Mailbox servers. He demonstrates how the queues work as well as troubleshooting and monitoring techniques.
episodes.title: Message Queues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.020 --> 00:00:10.020
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.058 --> 00:00:12.811
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

3
00:00:12.811 --> 00:00:15.597
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.597 --> 00:00:17.118
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.118 --> 00:00:20.937
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.937 --> 00:00:24.570
In this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at message ques.

7
00:00:24.570 --> 00:00:26.110
Now message ques, by and large,

8
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:29.050
are something that just runs in the
background that we don't even think about.

9
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:34.800
When email comes in to our
organization it makes its way over to,

10
00:00:34.800 --> 00:00:36.760
well usually, to our client access server.

11
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:40.111
That's our receive connector
where SMTP is running and

12
00:00:40.111 --> 00:00:43.331
where our front-end transport
service is running.

13
00:00:43.331 --> 00:00:45.605
But think about front-end
transport services,

14
00:00:45.605 --> 00:00:48.904
it doesn't handle mail very long,
it receives it and moves it along, so

15
00:00:48.904 --> 00:00:52.223
the front-end transport service
doesn't actually have a true queue.

16
00:00:52.223 --> 00:00:53.816
The email goes in the memory and

17
00:00:53.816 --> 00:00:57.622
then moves right on out the server
again it doesn't stay there very long.

18
00:00:57.622 --> 00:01:02.515
Then it sends it to a mailbox server and
on the mailbox server that's where you

19
00:01:02.515 --> 00:01:08.181
have the hub transport service, which then
connects to the mailbox transport service.

20
00:01:08.181 --> 00:01:11.410
The hub transport service
does have queues.

21
00:01:11.410 --> 00:01:14.290
It receives emails, and
it writes them to the hard drive.

22
00:01:14.290 --> 00:01:17.460
It actually maintains queue folders
right there on the hard drive, and

23
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:19.980
it puts the emails there
while it sorts them out.

24
00:01:19.980 --> 00:01:21.700
The hub transport server
does a lot of things.

25
00:01:21.700 --> 00:01:23.870
It has to figure out where
the email needs to go.

26
00:01:23.870 --> 00:01:26.260
It needs to apply any transport
rules if its got any.

27
00:01:26.260 --> 00:01:27.430
It's gotta do malware scanning.

28
00:01:27.430 --> 00:01:31.310
All the various things that happen
in the hub transport service.

29
00:01:31.310 --> 00:01:33.500
Then when it knows where it's going,

30
00:01:33.500 --> 00:01:36.920
it sends that email either to
another hub transport service

31
00:01:36.920 --> 00:01:40.610
on a server somewhere else if its gotta
different destination, or it sends it

32
00:01:40.610 --> 00:01:44.890
to the mailbox transport service where the
email's finally deposited in the mailbox.

33
00:01:44.890 --> 00:01:47.960
The mailbox transport service
also doesn't have queues.

34
00:01:47.960 --> 00:01:52.140
It receives an email, stores it in memory,
writes it to the mailbox database, and

35
00:01:52.140 --> 00:01:53.300
then it's gone.

36
00:01:53.300 --> 00:01:59.600
So the only place we actually have
queues are in the hub transfer service.

37
00:01:59.600 --> 00:02:02.510
And the hub transfer service runs on
all of our mailbox servers, and so

38
00:02:02.510 --> 00:02:03.710
they've got message queues there.

39
00:02:03.710 --> 00:02:05.740
Now, we don't normally care about them.

40
00:02:05.740 --> 00:02:09.280
And the reason is emails come in,
they then get processed,

41
00:02:09.280 --> 00:02:11.970
then they get written to the mailbox
database, and then they're gone.

42
00:02:11.970 --> 00:02:14.060
The emails remain in the database, and

43
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:17.550
they remain in our transaction log files
for the database, so they stay there.

44
00:02:17.550 --> 00:02:19.720
So we never really need the queues.

45
00:02:19.720 --> 00:02:23.500
So if we don't really need them,
why do I bring them up?

46
00:02:23.500 --> 00:02:27.180
Well, you don't need queues
when things are running right.

47
00:02:27.180 --> 00:02:30.300
When things are running the way they're
supposed to be you don't need queues.

48
00:02:30.300 --> 00:02:33.870
Email flows right through the system and
your queues stay empty.

49
00:02:33.870 --> 00:02:38.590
But if something is wrong, if something
is wrong your ques start to grow.

50
00:02:38.590 --> 00:02:42.790
Email just starts backing up and your
ques get bigger and bigger and bigger.

51
00:02:42.790 --> 00:02:46.580
So ques are something you wanna keep an
eye on because as they get bigger that's

52
00:02:46.580 --> 00:02:48.160
gonna indicate a problem.

53
00:02:48.160 --> 00:02:51.797
And the problem could be your problem,
it could be somebody elses problem, but

54
00:02:51.797 --> 00:02:54.038
it's the ques that'll
help you identify that.

55
00:02:54.038 --> 00:02:56.779
Well, first off, how do we see the queues?

56
00:02:56.779 --> 00:03:00.170
Well, if you're in the exchange admin
center, the short answer is you can't.

57
00:03:00.170 --> 00:03:04.390
There's no really good way to view
the queues in the admin center.

58
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:06.050
I know the queues are there.

59
00:03:06.050 --> 00:03:10.990
When I go to my servers, I know my
mailbox servers do have these queues.

60
00:03:10.990 --> 00:03:13.150
I know they're there,
but I can't see them.

61
00:03:13.150 --> 00:03:14.820
They don't give me a tool
to be able to do that.

62
00:03:15.980 --> 00:03:18.790
The only way to view the queues,
well, I guess there's two ways.

63
00:03:18.790 --> 00:03:20.040
You could drop and PowerShell.

64
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:22.596
In the PowerShell,
you've got the Get-Queue command.

65
00:03:22.596 --> 00:03:24.560
Or Get-Queue, that cmdlet and

66
00:03:24.560 --> 00:03:27.160
you can run that and you can pull
your queues and see what's in them.

67
00:03:27.160 --> 00:03:29.030
But there is a graphical utility for

68
00:03:29.030 --> 00:03:31.980
it, it's just not in
the exchange admin center.

69
00:03:31.980 --> 00:03:35.690
So if you're on your own client there's
not a really good way to see it.

70
00:03:35.690 --> 00:03:39.270
But if you jump over to any
of your exchange servers

71
00:03:39.270 --> 00:03:44.030
on your exchange server you'll have
a tool called the exchange tool box.

72
00:03:44.030 --> 00:03:46.670
And the exchange tool box, it's
installed automatically with exchange.

73
00:03:46.670 --> 00:03:48.700
I didn't have to choose to install that.

74
00:03:48.700 --> 00:03:53.800
And when you run it, it gives you access
to a few really interesting things.

75
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:57.200
So when it get's connected, you'll see
that you have the ability to view your

76
00:03:57.200 --> 00:04:00.700
queues, as well as to do some
other troubleshooting things.

77
00:04:00.700 --> 00:04:02.120
So, it's pretty neat.

78
00:04:02.120 --> 00:04:04.190
The queues are what I'm concerned
about though and so if I look,

79
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:06.410
I've got my Queue Viewer right here.

80
00:04:06.410 --> 00:04:08.520
And if I run that,
it's gonna open up those queues.

81
00:04:08.520 --> 00:04:12.350
Now, on a busy server,
it can take a moment for this to load and

82
00:04:12.350 --> 00:04:15.770
it's asking for me to pick a hub transport
server and so I'll browse and pick one.

83
00:04:16.780 --> 00:04:19.680
And, well,
eventually it'll let me pick one.

84
00:04:19.680 --> 00:04:22.200
So [LAUGH] I ran this on
my client access server, so

85
00:04:22.200 --> 00:04:24.260
it's making me connect
to my mailbox server.

86
00:04:24.260 --> 00:04:26.620
If I'd connected on a mailbox server,
it would have been faster.

87
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:30.620
Remember the hub transport service,
and the mailbox transport service,

88
00:04:30.620 --> 00:04:35.150
they run on the mailbox servers,
only the front-end transport service

89
00:04:35.150 --> 00:04:37.220
runs on the client access box, so
that's why I had to pick that.

90
00:04:38.230 --> 00:04:40.260
I'll set that as my default, so
I don't have to do it again, but

91
00:04:40.260 --> 00:04:43.300
it's gonna connect and it's gonna
show me the queues on that system.

92
00:04:43.300 --> 00:04:46.610
Now, I expect to see two queues.

93
00:04:46.610 --> 00:04:49.420
Now, there could be three,
there could be 100.

94
00:04:49.420 --> 00:04:53.040
But I always expect to see,
usually, two or three.

95
00:04:53.040 --> 00:04:56.330
And when we look in here, I'll see I've
actually got those two or three right now.

96
00:04:56.330 --> 00:04:58.310
So the submission queue.

97
00:04:58.310 --> 00:05:00.330
You're always going to
have the submission queue.

98
00:05:00.330 --> 00:05:04.020
No matter what, that's the one
that you're always going to see.

99
00:05:04.020 --> 00:05:08.740
If I'm submitting an email, if an email
is coming in, or an email is going out.

100
00:05:08.740 --> 00:05:10.460
The hub transport service receives it and

101
00:05:10.460 --> 00:05:12.520
immediately sticks it in
the submission queue.

102
00:05:12.520 --> 00:05:15.230
Submission means it hasn't
been processed yet.

103
00:05:15.230 --> 00:05:17.680
It hasn't had the transport rules applied.

104
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:19.200
It hasn't found its destination.

105
00:05:19.200 --> 00:05:20.550
It doesn't know where it's going yet.

106
00:05:20.550 --> 00:05:21.730
So it goes there.

107
00:05:22.730 --> 00:05:26.895
Then, the server's gonna look at it and
figure out what to do with it.

108
00:05:26.895 --> 00:05:32.245
If it's an internal email, you're gonna
get an SMTP delivery to mailbox queue.

109
00:05:32.245 --> 00:05:33.375
Like this.

110
00:05:33.375 --> 00:05:35.435
So you'll see these mailbox queues appear.

111
00:05:35.435 --> 00:05:36.943
And that's another one
that I expect to see.

112
00:05:36.943 --> 00:05:40.095
You're usually gonna have emails moving
through your system at a pretty regular

113
00:05:40.095 --> 00:05:42.515
rate, so you can expect to
see that mailbox queue there.

114
00:05:43.550 --> 00:05:46.590
And then you might have a third
one which is your error queue.

115
00:05:46.590 --> 00:05:48.320
If there's emails that
come through corrupted,

116
00:05:48.320 --> 00:05:50.810
that are damaged,
they'll go into this error queue.

117
00:05:50.810 --> 00:05:51.370
I don't have it.

118
00:05:51.370 --> 00:05:54.180
That means I don't have any corrupted
email but you might see that one appear.

119
00:05:55.400 --> 00:05:58.300
Those are three queues
that can be long standing.

120
00:05:58.300 --> 00:06:00.910
They can stay there and be there for
days, weeks, months, years, whatever.

121
00:06:00.910 --> 00:06:01.480
They'll be there.

122
00:06:03.058 --> 00:06:06.440
But there's hundred,
literally hundreds, maybe thousands of

123
00:06:06.440 --> 00:06:09.490
other queues that might appear that
are transient, they come and go.

124
00:06:10.550 --> 00:06:15.590
When I get an email, and it's an outbound
email, I'm sending it out, I need to send

125
00:06:15.590 --> 00:06:20.820
email to somebody at gmail.com, somebody
at yahoo.com, somebody at microsoft.com.

126
00:06:20.820 --> 00:06:24.270
Well, we create a queue for
each of those domains.

127
00:06:24.270 --> 00:06:26.754
Your mail server does an MX record lookup.

128
00:06:26.754 --> 00:06:29.560
It looks DNS from the mail
exchanger records.

129
00:06:29.560 --> 00:06:32.320
And that mail exchanger tells
it where to send the email to.

130
00:06:32.320 --> 00:06:36.318
Emails going to somebody at microsoft.com,
go to one set of mail servers.

131
00:06:36.318 --> 00:06:40.660
And somebody at google.com,
somebody at Gmail, somebody at Yahoo!

132
00:06:40.660 --> 00:06:42.100
Those all go to different servers.

133
00:06:42.100 --> 00:06:44.660
And it'll create a queue for each one.

134
00:06:44.660 --> 00:06:49.430
If the remote server is down then
my queue for Gmail, my queue for

135
00:06:49.430 --> 00:06:52.450
Microsoft or whatever,
will sit there and build up.

136
00:06:52.450 --> 00:06:54.480
And email will sit in the queue.

137
00:06:54.480 --> 00:06:55.630
Now the queue's retry.

138
00:06:55.630 --> 00:06:57.450
They retry the transmit periodically.

139
00:06:57.450 --> 00:06:59.460
Then it actually works
on a weird interval.

140
00:06:59.460 --> 00:07:03.110
So it'll try 3 times, 30 seconds apart.

141
00:07:03.110 --> 00:07:06.240
So in the first minute and
a half it'll try three times.

142
00:07:06.240 --> 00:07:09.810
If that fails then it stretches
it out to a bigger window and

143
00:07:09.810 --> 00:07:12.010
it tries three times every six hours.

144
00:07:12.010 --> 00:07:14.090
So now it's spread out more further.

145
00:07:15.230 --> 00:07:19.050
Then it tries at a bigger
window over a 72 hour period,

146
00:07:19.050 --> 00:07:22.390
well actually, I tried it for
3 days to send an email.

147
00:07:22.390 --> 00:07:25.280
Now by the time it gets there
it sends the user a warning

148
00:07:25.280 --> 00:07:27.810
saying this email has been delayed,
so you know it's been delayed, but

149
00:07:27.810 --> 00:07:31.250
it will retry because connectivity to the
remote server might just be intermittent.

150
00:07:31.250 --> 00:07:34.520
It might just temporarily failed and
so it'll queued that message.

151
00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:36.570
Now it's rare do we
have to wait that long.

152
00:07:36.570 --> 00:07:39.160
Because every time somebody
sends an email to that domain,

153
00:07:39.160 --> 00:07:40.620
it's gonna retry the queue.

154
00:07:40.620 --> 00:07:42.830
So while I say it might be 30 seconds or

155
00:07:42.830 --> 00:07:46.900
then 6 hours, it usually happens
far more in advance of that.

156
00:07:46.900 --> 00:07:50.072
But if you see a queue for an external
domain and it's sitting there getting

157
00:07:50.072 --> 00:07:53.509
bigger, well, it just usually means that,
that remote site is not connected.

158
00:07:53.509 --> 00:07:56.773
But if you see all of your queues
getting bigger and bigger and

159
00:07:56.773 --> 00:07:59.918
bigger That's an indication
that you've got a problem.

160
00:07:59.918 --> 00:08:03.190
Maybe your internet connection has failed.

161
00:08:03.190 --> 00:08:05.918
Maybe your system has been
added to an email blacklist,

162
00:08:05.918 --> 00:08:09.240
one of those spam blacklists and
so everybody is rejecting you now.

163
00:08:09.240 --> 00:08:12.074
Those are all cases where your queue
is going to get bigger and bigger.

164
00:08:12.074 --> 00:08:14.476
So that does happen all the time.

165
00:08:14.476 --> 00:08:17.810
All right, let me show you
an example of how the queues work.

166
00:08:17.810 --> 00:08:20.560
I want to get an email stuck in my queues.

167
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:23.320
But the problem is, it's kind of hard
to get an email stuck in the queue.

168
00:08:23.320 --> 00:08:25.130
They move through pretty quickly.

169
00:08:25.130 --> 00:08:28.338
So, what I'm gonna do is,
I'm gonna simulate a database failure.

170
00:08:28.338 --> 00:08:33.510
So, I'm gonna jump back into my EAC, and
I'll go to my servers, and my databases.

171
00:08:33.510 --> 00:08:36.925
And I'm gonna take my mailbox database,
and I'm just going to dismount it.

172
00:08:36.925 --> 00:08:40.050
So, your database is mounted
pretty much all the time.

173
00:08:40.050 --> 00:08:42.770
If you dismount it, it takes it offline.

174
00:08:42.770 --> 00:08:45.230
When your database is offline,
you don't lose email.

175
00:08:45.230 --> 00:08:48.660
New email can come in,
it just gets stuck in the queue.

176
00:08:48.660 --> 00:08:52.050
It stays in the queue until
the database becomes available again.

177
00:08:52.050 --> 00:08:56.630
So I just dismounted that and now I'm
gonna send an email into the system.

178
00:08:56.630 --> 00:09:00.680
Now if I were to fire up Outlook or
Outlook web app or whatever

179
00:09:00.680 --> 00:09:05.070
they're not gonna be able to get into
my mailbox to be able to send an email.

180
00:09:05.070 --> 00:09:07.890
So I just can't even get connected
if my mailbox isn't available.

181
00:09:07.890 --> 00:09:10.460
So, there's a neat way that
we can generate email that's

182
00:09:10.460 --> 00:09:11.930
really useful for testing.

183
00:09:11.930 --> 00:09:16.060
If you're troubleshooting a mail server,
it's really a neat thing that you can do

184
00:09:16.060 --> 00:09:20.910
where you can use TelNet to connect
directly to an SMTP server and

185
00:09:20.910 --> 00:09:22.145
inject email into it.

186
00:09:22.145 --> 00:09:25.030
And it's useful, because you can
simulate different scenarios,

187
00:09:25.030 --> 00:09:28.030
emails destined for
different places and things like that.

188
00:09:28.030 --> 00:09:30.390
So that's what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna open up a command prompt.

189
00:09:31.535 --> 00:09:36.110
And Telnet is actually not installed
by default in Windows, so if

190
00:09:36.110 --> 00:09:39.300
you're gonna use it you need to make sure
you add it, and it's easy enough to add.

191
00:09:39.300 --> 00:09:42.050
You just go into your Server Manager, and

192
00:09:42.050 --> 00:09:45.990
in Server Manager you can go up to Manage,
and Add Roles and Features.

193
00:09:45.990 --> 00:09:49.540
And the Telnet client is just
a feature you add that feature in.

194
00:09:49.540 --> 00:09:51.770
So I've already got
that here on my system.

195
00:09:51.770 --> 00:09:55.070
And what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
use Telnet to connect in and

196
00:09:55.070 --> 00:09:57.780
generate an email to a user in my system.

197
00:09:57.780 --> 00:09:58.680
Now if you want to do that,

198
00:09:58.680 --> 00:10:02.340
the first thing you need to do is you
need to say Telnet and then your server.

199
00:10:02.340 --> 00:10:05.000
Well, I'm on my client access server, so

200
00:10:05.000 --> 00:10:08.440
I'm just gonna connect to 127.0.0.1,
my sever.

201
00:10:08.440 --> 00:10:11.120
But if I was on a workstation,
I would specify the server name.

202
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:16.160
So Lab-CAS01.itprotv.net, or
whatever the name of your server is.

203
00:10:16.160 --> 00:10:20.530
And then if I stop right there,
it's gonna telnet on port 23.

204
00:10:20.530 --> 00:10:23.560
I need to add a 25 to the end so
it knows that I wanna telnet on port 25,

205
00:10:23.560 --> 00:10:26.180
I wanna simulate SMTP traffic.

206
00:10:27.420 --> 00:10:30.870
So I'm gonna run that and
I've now connected to the mail server.

207
00:10:30.870 --> 00:10:34.830
Now I can talk to the mail server but
I have to talk to it using it's language.

208
00:10:34.830 --> 00:10:37.860
And that's a little bit weird but
it's what I need to do.

209
00:10:37.860 --> 00:10:42.740
So you start off by saying helo,
which is H-E-L-O, only one L.

210
00:10:42.740 --> 00:10:44.510
And specify the name of you workstation.

211
00:10:44.510 --> 00:10:48.730
So maybe I'm on like dplaptop.itprotv.net
or something like that.

212
00:10:48.730 --> 00:10:51.920
So you say who you are.

213
00:10:51.920 --> 00:10:55.110
Then, you say who
the email is coming from.

214
00:10:55.110 --> 00:10:57.810
So I'm gonna say mail from and
then who it's from.

215
00:10:57.810 --> 00:10:59.950
And I'm gonna say this one is from me,

216
00:10:59.950 --> 00:11:04.300
so Don Pezet and then I'll put
my actual email here at the end.

217
00:11:04.300 --> 00:11:08.820
So maybe I'm dpezet@itprotv.net,
or something like that, right?

218
00:11:08.820 --> 00:11:11.950
So this is an internal email coming in.

219
00:11:11.950 --> 00:11:17.050
Then, I have to say who it's to,
and I'm gonna say RCPT TO.

220
00:11:17.050 --> 00:11:20.690
We're indicating the recipient
that this is destined for.

221
00:11:20.690 --> 00:11:24.110
Oh actually, it's warning me there
about my invalid address cuz I provided

222
00:11:24.110 --> 00:11:25.640
an internal address.

223
00:11:25.640 --> 00:11:26.560
And so I need to correct that.

224
00:11:26.560 --> 00:11:28.040
Now here's where things
get a little challenging.

225
00:11:29.120 --> 00:11:32.800
Normally it's a server
connecting this way, not us.

226
00:11:32.800 --> 00:11:34.350
Does a server make mistakes?

227
00:11:34.350 --> 00:11:34.870
No.

228
00:11:34.870 --> 00:11:36.150
So a server always gets it right.

229
00:11:36.150 --> 00:11:39.240
If you make a typo or you type an address
that's not valid or something like that

230
00:11:39.240 --> 00:11:43.430
and you get a warning, well, then you
kinda have to start all over again.

231
00:11:43.430 --> 00:11:48.560
You have to exit out of the session and
kinda get back in there a second time.

232
00:11:48.560 --> 00:11:50.560
And it can be a little
challenging to get out.

233
00:11:50.560 --> 00:11:54.280
Like quit is technically the key word to
get out and eventually it'll exit, but

234
00:11:54.280 --> 00:11:57.476
a lot of times it's just easier to [LAUGH]
close the window and start over again.

235
00:11:57.476 --> 00:12:00.847
So that's what I'll do and this time
I'll just use like an external address.

236
00:12:02.210 --> 00:12:05.920
All right, so I'm gonna connect
to that internal host on port 25.

237
00:12:05.920 --> 00:12:08.090
I'll say, helo.

238
00:12:08.090 --> 00:12:10.990
And if you leave your workstation name
off, some servers will allow you to do

239
00:12:10.990 --> 00:12:12.610
that, and just see how it
just kinda resolved the name?

240
00:12:12.610 --> 00:12:13.330
So I'll do that.

241
00:12:13.330 --> 00:12:18.610
And then I'm gonna say mail from and
this time I'll just specify my external

242
00:12:18.610 --> 00:12:24.280
address, so I'll say this mail
is coming from don@ITPro.tv.

243
00:12:24.280 --> 00:12:25.540
And then I'll say who it's to.

244
00:12:25.540 --> 00:12:29.070
And I'm going to do an email to,
I'll do Jane Smith here, so

245
00:12:29.070 --> 00:12:33.220
I'll say JSmith@itprotv.net.

246
00:12:33.220 --> 00:12:35.420
So she's a user here, so
I get recipient and sender okay.

247
00:12:36.480 --> 00:12:41.290
Then I need to give it the data for
the email, so I'll say data and the very

248
00:12:41.290 --> 00:12:45.580
first line I need to say subject colon
followed by what I want the subject to be.

249
00:12:45.580 --> 00:12:50.580
So I'll say this is a test
email from outside.

250
00:12:50.580 --> 00:12:51.790
Oops, which I spelled wrong.

251
00:12:51.790 --> 00:12:53.730
I spelled it wrong, and
unfortunately I can't use backspace.

252
00:12:53.730 --> 00:12:55.860
Those keys have already
been sent to the server, so

253
00:12:55.860 --> 00:12:58.280
I'll just have to accept
that I can't spell.

254
00:12:58.280 --> 00:13:01.100
Then after that we start to provide
our actual email message and so

255
00:13:01.100 --> 00:13:02.920
I'll just say this is a test email.

256
00:13:04.160 --> 00:13:05.020
I hope you get it.

257
00:13:06.840 --> 00:13:09.090
I put a lot of effort into it.

258
00:13:10.950 --> 00:13:12.530
So you just type your email.

259
00:13:12.530 --> 00:13:15.830
And then when you're done with the email,
notice this little message here.

260
00:13:15.830 --> 00:13:18.600
Press enter, a period, and enter.

261
00:13:18.600 --> 00:13:20.860
So I'll press enter, a period and enter.

262
00:13:20.860 --> 00:13:24.760
And that's how it knows the email is done,
and so it's been flagged, and

263
00:13:24.760 --> 00:13:27.710
it'll take it a second, but it's actually
generating the email, there we go.

264
00:13:27.710 --> 00:13:30.062
And see how it says queued mail for
delivery.

265
00:13:30.062 --> 00:13:32.384
It's queued it and it's ready to go.

266
00:13:32.384 --> 00:13:35.506
And from here I can quit, some servers
will automatically kick you out,

267
00:13:35.506 --> 00:13:39.000
I'm gonna quit by typing quit and now I've
got an email that went into the queue.

268
00:13:40.110 --> 00:13:41.850
I know the email went into the queue and

269
00:13:41.850 --> 00:13:45.170
by doing it this way, I just took
my mail client out of the equation.

270
00:13:45.170 --> 00:13:49.430
So if you're troubleshooting Outlook or
Thunderbird, or some other mail client.

271
00:13:49.430 --> 00:13:51.860
Doing it this way says,
what if I don't use the client?

272
00:13:51.860 --> 00:13:53.490
What if I just do it by hand?

273
00:13:53.490 --> 00:13:55.680
Do I get to that SMTP server?

274
00:13:55.680 --> 00:13:58.180
Maybe I can't even connect to
the SMTP server in the first place.

275
00:13:58.180 --> 00:13:59.060
And you'd see that right here.

276
00:14:00.160 --> 00:14:00.860
But it's connected.

277
00:14:00.860 --> 00:14:03.180
Now, that's going to go into the queue.

278
00:14:03.180 --> 00:14:07.040
It went into the front end
transport service first, right?

279
00:14:07.040 --> 00:14:09.343
Cuz I connected to my
client access server.

280
00:14:09.343 --> 00:14:12.907
It then sends it to the transport
service back on the mailbox server.

281
00:14:12.907 --> 00:14:16.623
Now it went to the mailbox server
that hosted Jane Smith's email, so

282
00:14:16.623 --> 00:14:17.527
it went to hers.

283
00:14:17.527 --> 00:14:21.070
And it went into that queue and that queue
says okay well I know where it needs to

284
00:14:21.070 --> 00:14:23.741
go, it needs to go to a mailbox
database on the inside and so

285
00:14:23.741 --> 00:14:25.121
it moved it to mailbox queue.

286
00:14:25.121 --> 00:14:28.881
And then It tries to go to the mailbox
database, but it's offline.

287
00:14:28.881 --> 00:14:31.400
So that email should now
be stuck in a queue.

288
00:14:31.400 --> 00:14:36.570
And if I jump back to my
queue viewer right here,

289
00:14:36.570 --> 00:14:41.940
I do see that I've got a mailbox database
queue and it's got two emails stuck in it.

290
00:14:41.940 --> 00:14:44.460
Now I only drafted one email,
what's this other one?

291
00:14:44.460 --> 00:14:47.971
Well, there's a lot of status messages and
other emails that are getting generated in

292
00:14:47.971 --> 00:14:50.728
the background that go to system accounts,
and we never see those.

293
00:14:50.728 --> 00:14:52.720
So some of these might be that, but

294
00:14:52.720 --> 00:14:55.824
one of them is probably
the email that I just drafted.

295
00:14:55.824 --> 00:15:00.145
And so I can take that queue, and with
any of these queues, if you kinda look at

296
00:15:00.145 --> 00:15:04.271
them, they usually have like
a pseudo-random number attached to them so

297
00:15:04.271 --> 00:15:07.288
we don't get duplicate
queue names across servers.

298
00:15:07.288 --> 00:15:11.450
But I can see this is SMTP delivery to
a mailbox and it's in a retry state.

299
00:15:12.460 --> 00:15:14.310
It's already tried to
deliver the mail once and

300
00:15:14.310 --> 00:15:16.940
it failed,
now it's waiting to retry again.

301
00:15:16.940 --> 00:15:19.260
And it will try every 30 seconds for
three times and

302
00:15:19.260 --> 00:15:21.250
then it will go to
a bigger window of time.

303
00:15:21.250 --> 00:15:24.890
And if you don't wanna wait you
can come in and force it to retry.

304
00:15:24.890 --> 00:15:26.890
When you right click,
see how you've got retry?

305
00:15:26.890 --> 00:15:28.448
So I can tell her go ahead and
retry again.

306
00:15:28.448 --> 00:15:32.779
Or if that server's just not coming
back up I can say go ahead and

307
00:15:32.779 --> 00:15:35.089
remove the messages with an NDR.

308
00:15:35.089 --> 00:15:38.382
In other words, cancel the messages and
send a non-delivery report

309
00:15:38.382 --> 00:15:41.580
back to whoever it was who sent
us the email in the first place.

310
00:15:41.580 --> 00:15:42.460
So it can do that.

311
00:15:42.460 --> 00:15:46.175
Or we can remove the messages
without sending an NDR.

312
00:15:46.175 --> 00:15:49.716
Just delete them and that's it, now nobody
knows what happened in the email right?

313
00:15:49.716 --> 00:15:51.074
But normally you wanna try and retry.

314
00:15:51.074 --> 00:15:56.098
Now if we know there's a problem you can
suspend the queue and now the queue goes

315
00:15:56.098 --> 00:16:01.676
into suspension state It's not retrying,
but it is continuing to accumulate email.

316
00:16:01.676 --> 00:16:03.382
So even though the database is offline,

317
00:16:03.382 --> 00:16:06.670
I'm not losing email it's
just pooling up right here.

318
00:16:06.670 --> 00:16:09.920
Now I said that one of these
emails is probably my email.

319
00:16:09.920 --> 00:16:12.250
Wouldn't it be nice if we could
tell whether it was or not?

320
00:16:12.250 --> 00:16:13.280
Well you can.

321
00:16:13.280 --> 00:16:17.250
If you double click on the queue
it'll show you what's inside it.

322
00:16:17.250 --> 00:16:20.990
And so I can see here's
an email from don@itpro.tv.

323
00:16:20.990 --> 00:16:22.380
Right?
That's that email that I

324
00:16:22.380 --> 00:16:23.750
drafted a moment ago.

325
00:16:23.750 --> 00:16:27.910
And I can see there's another email
from health mailbox blah blah blah.

326
00:16:27.910 --> 00:16:29.590
That's one of those system accounts.

327
00:16:29.590 --> 00:16:31.480
Right?
And it's doing just a health check.

328
00:16:31.480 --> 00:16:33.970
It's actually monitoring whether
the databases are up itself, and

329
00:16:33.970 --> 00:16:36.030
this is how it knows
the database is offline.

330
00:16:36.030 --> 00:16:38.204
So it sends these every couple of seconds.

331
00:16:38.204 --> 00:16:41.783
But as I look over I can see some
information about where it came from,

332
00:16:41.783 --> 00:16:42.967
where it's going to.

333
00:16:42.967 --> 00:16:47.331
And I can even see the subject line here,
This is a test email from outside.

334
00:16:47.331 --> 00:16:50.690
And if there was an error,
I can see the error message.

335
00:16:50.690 --> 00:16:53.336
So looking at this other one,
it's been in the queue longer, so

336
00:16:53.336 --> 00:16:56.976
it's got a nice big message that's telling
me here, the mailbox database is offline.

337
00:16:56.976 --> 00:16:58.520
I can see what the problem is.

338
00:16:58.520 --> 00:17:02.160
That's the really cool part about
these queues is you can see the error.

339
00:17:02.160 --> 00:17:05.050
If I'm getting rejected on the other
side because I'm blacklisted,

340
00:17:05.050 --> 00:17:06.640
the error will say that.

341
00:17:06.640 --> 00:17:07.980
If I can't reach the other side,

342
00:17:07.980 --> 00:17:10.810
if the DNS lookup fails,
the error message will say that.

343
00:17:10.810 --> 00:17:14.350
I can see why it's failing,
and that's pretty neat.

344
00:17:14.350 --> 00:17:15.350
And if you double click on it,

345
00:17:15.350 --> 00:17:19.120
you can actually get the header of
that message, and we can see it now.

346
00:17:19.120 --> 00:17:21.410
Notice how it doesn't
show the messages body?

347
00:17:21.410 --> 00:17:24.470
The Queue Viewer is designed for
administrators to troubleshoot,

348
00:17:24.470 --> 00:17:28.150
it's not designed for
us to eavesdrop on people's email.

349
00:17:28.150 --> 00:17:30.770
So, it doesn't give you the ability
to see the message body.

350
00:17:30.770 --> 00:17:34.450
But, you do see the subject line, and
then you can see the header of it.

351
00:17:34.450 --> 00:17:37.860
And that header is useful cuz we can use
this for troubleshooting things, right?

352
00:17:37.860 --> 00:17:40.580
The header contains a lot
of good information.

353
00:17:40.580 --> 00:17:41.580
Now the problem with the header,

354
00:17:41.580 --> 00:17:44.900
though, is that it can sometimes
be really complex, right?

355
00:17:44.900 --> 00:17:47.160
There is a lot of stuff in here, and
this is actually a small header.

356
00:17:47.160 --> 00:17:50.180
Let me show you,
I copied a header before the show.

357
00:17:50.180 --> 00:17:52.520
Here's a header from an email
that I received yesterday.

358
00:17:52.520 --> 00:17:55.660
So when we look at this,
there's a lot of stuff.

359
00:17:55.660 --> 00:17:59.010
We've got more than one
Received From message.

360
00:17:59.010 --> 00:18:01.710
How did I receive an email
from three different servers?

361
00:18:01.710 --> 00:18:04.790
Well it means it passed through three
different servers before getting to me.

362
00:18:04.790 --> 00:18:07.810
And I can see who it's from, and
who it's to, and all this other data.

363
00:18:07.810 --> 00:18:10.190
What is all this stuff?

364
00:18:10.190 --> 00:18:13.020
Well, if you memorize it,
you learn each of these, then you know and

365
00:18:13.020 --> 00:18:14.220
you can read these headers pretty easy.

366
00:18:14.220 --> 00:18:18.085
But if you can't what you can do
is you can just copy this, and

367
00:18:18.085 --> 00:18:21.990
if I go back to my Exchange Toolbox,
here's where I went to the Queue Viewer,

368
00:18:21.990 --> 00:18:25.780
right above it is
the Remote Connectivity Analyzer.

369
00:18:25.780 --> 00:18:29.490
Now the Remote Connectivity Analyzer is
not a tool that runs right here on our

370
00:18:29.490 --> 00:18:31.140
machine, it's just a web page.

371
00:18:31.140 --> 00:18:34.430
And so you can bypass this entirely and
go to the web page.

372
00:18:34.430 --> 00:18:39.360
But if you fire it up, it's Microsoft's
web site testconnectivity.microsoft.com.

373
00:18:39.360 --> 00:18:40.240
So easy to remember.

374
00:18:40.240 --> 00:18:44.028
So on any workstation you go to
testconnectivity.microsoft.com, and

375
00:18:44.028 --> 00:18:46.880
you get all sorts of email
tests that you can run.

376
00:18:46.880 --> 00:18:50.320
It'll test whether Exchange ActiveSync
is working on your server,

377
00:18:50.320 --> 00:18:54.020
whether Exchange Web Services are working,
whether Outlook can connect.

378
00:18:54.020 --> 00:18:55.850
It's gonna test each one of these.

379
00:18:55.850 --> 00:18:58.550
You can test your SMTP server, right?

380
00:18:58.550 --> 00:19:03.600
I can do an inbound SMTP email test,
then way down here at the bottom,

381
00:19:03.600 --> 00:19:06.720
it's kind of off my screen,
let me resize this window, here we go.

382
00:19:06.720 --> 00:19:08.950
Way down here at the bottom,
I got a nice little Next button, and

383
00:19:08.950 --> 00:19:11.770
we can start to move through that and then
you specify who you're trying to email,

384
00:19:11.770 --> 00:19:14.250
and it will generate
an email from Microsoft and

385
00:19:14.250 --> 00:19:16.850
send it to your SMTP server and
you can see if you got it.

386
00:19:16.850 --> 00:19:17.820
Did you get that email?

387
00:19:17.820 --> 00:19:21.720
So kind of cool that you can run
these tests right from their site.

388
00:19:21.720 --> 00:19:24.440
You can do POP and IMAP tests also.

389
00:19:24.440 --> 00:19:27.240
With those, on the next screen,
it actually asks you for

390
00:19:27.240 --> 00:19:28.420
some user account information.

391
00:19:28.420 --> 00:19:29.860
So you need a sample user.

392
00:19:29.860 --> 00:19:32.130
And it'll login as your user,
generate an e-mail, and

393
00:19:32.130 --> 00:19:35.030
then it'll tell you right here on
the page whether or not it succeeded.

394
00:19:35.030 --> 00:19:36.400
But one of the more useful tools,

395
00:19:36.400 --> 00:19:41.880
if I go back,
is right over here the Message Analyzer.

396
00:19:41.880 --> 00:19:46.220
And you can take that Message Analyzer,
and you can paste your header right here.

397
00:19:46.220 --> 00:19:48.720
So I'm taking the header from here.

398
00:19:48.720 --> 00:19:51.170
I just copied that, and
I'm pasting it right in here.

399
00:19:51.170 --> 00:19:55.320
And when you hit Analyze Header,
it's gonna take that header and

400
00:19:55.320 --> 00:19:59.380
turn it into a nice little table
that's a heck of a lot easier to read.

401
00:19:59.380 --> 00:20:01.520
So, remember how I had
those three received froms?

402
00:20:01.520 --> 00:20:03.640
And I was like,
how do you get an email from all three?

403
00:20:03.640 --> 00:20:07.670
Well, right here it shows Hop 1,
Hop 2, Hop 3.

404
00:20:07.670 --> 00:20:10.330
I had three hops in the path
of getting the email.

405
00:20:10.330 --> 00:20:12.930
Here's the servers I went through,
name and IP.

406
00:20:12.930 --> 00:20:17.240
Here's the delay each server introduced,
so I can see each of those.

407
00:20:17.240 --> 00:20:18.560
And then the message type.

408
00:20:18.560 --> 00:20:22.280
I can see that it went over TLS,
it was submitted via MAPI, apparently,

409
00:20:22.280 --> 00:20:24.000
I can see how that kind
of processed through.

410
00:20:25.000 --> 00:20:26.700
And then after that I get
my other headers, and

411
00:20:26.700 --> 00:20:30.130
it breaks them down showing the name
of the header and what they are.

412
00:20:30.130 --> 00:20:33.550
And if I don't know what it is, if I
look at one of these and I'm like okay,

413
00:20:33.550 --> 00:20:36.920
what is XMS has attach.

414
00:20:36.920 --> 00:20:39.010
Well you can click on it, and
it'll take you to a page and

415
00:20:39.010 --> 00:20:40.850
it'll tell you what that is so
you can interpret it.

416
00:20:40.850 --> 00:20:42.320
So really kinda handy.

417
00:20:42.320 --> 00:20:46.230
A neat little tool to have to be
able to decipher this information.

418
00:20:46.230 --> 00:20:50.180
So that's just
testconnectivity.microsoft.com.

419
00:20:50.180 --> 00:20:52.860
It's a website they set up a while back,
it's been available.

420
00:20:52.860 --> 00:20:57.680
It has all sort of Office365 tests,
but they work on regular Exchange

421
00:20:57.680 --> 00:21:02.040
too because on premises Exchange
is the same as Office365 Exchange.

422
00:21:02.040 --> 00:21:04.640
The difference is just what
servers it's running on.

423
00:21:04.640 --> 00:21:06.770
Microsoft servers versus yours.

424
00:21:06.770 --> 00:21:09.240
So you can take advantage of
a lot of these different things.

425
00:21:09.240 --> 00:21:11.680
Even on the client side,
it's got troubleshooting tools here for

426
00:21:11.680 --> 00:21:15.630
the end users, so they can run
the client connectivity analyzer.

427
00:21:15.630 --> 00:21:18.610
And it'll tell you like, hey you got
a firewall here blocking connectivity or

428
00:21:18.610 --> 00:21:20.440
whatever, and
it'll help you identify that.

429
00:21:20.440 --> 00:21:22.580
Really neat stuff,
a great way to troubleshoot.

430
00:21:24.680 --> 00:21:28.080
All right, and so as I watch here my
queues are starting to build up, right.

431
00:21:28.080 --> 00:21:29.980
I've got some more things appearing.

432
00:21:29.980 --> 00:21:32.500
So some additional messages
popping up in that queue.

433
00:21:32.500 --> 00:21:35.860
And that's a great way to identify
that you've got a problem, right?

434
00:21:35.860 --> 00:21:39.010
If your queues are growing,
you know there's an issue.

435
00:21:39.010 --> 00:21:41.180
They shouldn't be getting bigger,
they should shrink.

436
00:21:41.180 --> 00:21:44.960
Now, the more traffic your server moves,
the bigger these queues might be.

437
00:21:44.960 --> 00:21:47.640
If you're pushing thousands
of emails per minute,

438
00:21:47.640 --> 00:21:50.620
then you should expect to see
1,000 emails in your queue, right?

439
00:21:50.620 --> 00:21:54.090
But if you push 50 emails a minute, and

440
00:21:54.090 --> 00:21:56.550
you got 1,000 emails in your queue,
then you got a problem.

441
00:21:56.550 --> 00:21:59.690
You got an issue and you've got to
make sure that you jump in there and

442
00:21:59.690 --> 00:22:00.980
find out where that hangup is.

443
00:22:00.980 --> 00:22:03.750
And looking at this error
is a great way to see it.

444
00:22:03.750 --> 00:22:07.310
So message queues in Exchange,
for the most part we ignore them.

445
00:22:07.310 --> 00:22:10.080
We don't even think about it,
it's all automatic in the background.

446
00:22:10.080 --> 00:22:12.920
The front end transport service and
the mailbox transport service don't

447
00:22:12.920 --> 00:22:16.140
even use queues,
the hub transport service does though.

448
00:22:16.140 --> 00:22:19.550
And we wanna watch it just as
an indicator of a problem,

449
00:22:19.550 --> 00:22:22.370
it's a great test to be able to
see whether you got any issues.

450
00:22:22.370 --> 00:22:25.840
And remember from the PowerShell you can
do the Get-Queue command, and so you can

451
00:22:25.840 --> 00:22:28.870
view it from PowerShell too if you want to
automate it or create your own reports.

452
00:22:28.870 --> 00:22:29.970
You can do all sorts of neat stuff.

453
00:22:29.970 --> 00:22:33.055
And there's plenty of third party products
out there that monitor your queue

454
00:22:33.055 --> 00:22:34.380
links also, and so

455
00:22:34.380 --> 00:22:37.641
they can report back and you get just
a wealth of information from there.

456
00:22:37.641 --> 00:22:39.930
All right.

457
00:22:39.930 --> 00:22:43.335
I think that's about all
I've got on the queues,

458
00:22:43.335 --> 00:22:46.990
just be aware that there's a number of
different errors that can appear there and

459
00:22:46.990 --> 00:22:48.350
we just need to keep an eye on it.

460
00:22:48.350 --> 00:22:50.430
It's a great troubleshooting utility.

461
00:22:50.430 --> 00:22:52.010
All right, well this is a great
place to wrap this one up.

462
00:22:52.010 --> 00:22:52.810
So in this episode,

463
00:22:52.810 --> 00:22:56.490
we got a chance to see the email
queues inside of Microsoft Exchange.

464
00:22:56.490 --> 00:22:59.960
We saw how to use the Exchange
toolbox to access the queue viewer and

465
00:22:59.960 --> 00:23:01.740
see those message queues.

466
00:23:01.740 --> 00:23:05.160
And we got to take a look at
Microsoft's test connectivity website,

467
00:23:05.160 --> 00:23:08.570
where we can evaluate our system, our
connectivity, whether things are working.

468
00:23:08.570 --> 00:23:12.200
And we can see it from Microsoft's
perspective, which is useful for testing

469
00:23:12.200 --> 00:23:17.780
as well as deciphering those email message
headers to see information about them,

470
00:23:17.780 --> 00:23:20.380
where they come from, where they're
going to and all that other information.

471
00:23:20.380 --> 00:23:23.520
So, just some great resources
right there available for you.

472
00:23:23.520 --> 00:23:26.830
So, that's about it for this episode,
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

473
00:23:26.830 --> 00:23:30.692
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

474
00:23:30.692 --> 00:23:36.860
[MUSIC].

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains Microsoft Exchange Edge Transport Servers and their purpose. He then walks the viewers through the prerequisites and installation process.
episodes.title: Installing Edge Servers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.227
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.227 --> 00:00:13.310
All right good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.310 --> 00:00:15.451
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTv.

4
00:00:15.451 --> 00:00:19.815
I'm your host Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Microsoft Exchange

5
00:00:19.815 --> 00:00:21.090
2013.

6
00:00:21.090 --> 00:00:25.980
In this episode, we're going to be
taking a look at Edge Transport Servers.

7
00:00:25.980 --> 00:00:29.770
When Exchange 2013 first came out,
there were only two roles.

8
00:00:29.770 --> 00:00:33.275
There was the mailbox server role and
the client access server role.

9
00:00:33.275 --> 00:00:38.020
And then when Service Pack One came out,
they reintroduced one of the older roles

10
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:42.230
from Exchange, kind of brought it back
called the Edge Transport role, all right?

11
00:00:42.230 --> 00:00:45.550
And the reason they didn't roll it out
in the very beginning was that you could

12
00:00:45.550 --> 00:00:48.700
actually use Exchange 2012 Edge Transport
Servers just fine with Exchange 2013.

13
00:00:48.700 --> 00:00:53.460
And part of the reason for
that was how these servers work.

14
00:00:53.460 --> 00:00:56.880
So let's talk a little bit about how an
edge transport server works to see why it

15
00:00:56.880 --> 00:01:00.910
didn't really matter if we ran 2010 or
2013, and to this day it still doesn't

16
00:01:00.910 --> 00:01:04.630
really matter, but you do want to
run the latest software if you can.

17
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:07.690
But let's take a look at a topology and
I'll show you what I mean.

18
00:01:07.690 --> 00:01:12.330
So here's an example of an exchange
environment where we've got our

19
00:01:12.330 --> 00:01:16.490
internal mail servers, right, our client
access server and our mailbox server.

20
00:01:16.490 --> 00:01:21.100
Now, when email is coming into our
organization, it's generally gonna pass

21
00:01:21.100 --> 00:01:24.550
to the front-end transport service
on the client access server, and

22
00:01:24.550 --> 00:01:27.920
then go to the hub transport service back
here on the mailbox server, all right?

23
00:01:27.920 --> 00:01:30.860
And then the mailbox server has
the mailbox transport service,

24
00:01:30.860 --> 00:01:33.660
where it actually delivers
that content into a mailbox.

25
00:01:33.660 --> 00:01:36.130
Well, if it's Internet email,

26
00:01:36.130 --> 00:01:39.380
It can actually go straight to the hub
transport server on the mailbox server.

27
00:01:39.380 --> 00:01:41.790
We normally do proxy it through
the client access server for

28
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:46.110
security purposes, but security purposes,
what do I mean by that?

29
00:01:46.110 --> 00:01:48.730
Well I mean you don't want people directly

30
00:01:48.730 --> 00:01:52.340
asking your mailbox server cuz if
they could compromise that server

31
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:54.760
in theory they could access
other people's mailboxes.

32
00:01:54.760 --> 00:01:57.340
You definitely don't want the Internet
being able to access those

33
00:01:57.340 --> 00:01:58.470
mailbox servers.

34
00:01:58.470 --> 00:02:01.290
So passing through the client access
server gives you an extra layer of

35
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:06.040
defense, but it's not much of an extra
layer, because that client access server,

36
00:02:06.040 --> 00:02:08.520
if you think about it,
it's joined to your domain, right?

37
00:02:08.520 --> 00:02:11.820
It's gotta be joined to the domain,
because Exchange stores its configuration

38
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:16.850
in the Active Directory, and so,
it's a member of your local area network.

39
00:02:16.850 --> 00:02:19.680
If somebody compromises
the client access server,

40
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:23.900
they could begin to access resources
inside your network and that would be bad.

41
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:29.200
So, what an edge transport server does,
is it sits in between.

42
00:02:29.200 --> 00:02:33.050
It sits in between your secure, internal
servers, that we don't want the outside

43
00:02:33.050 --> 00:02:36.730
world to get to, and the Internet,
where the bad people are.

44
00:02:36.730 --> 00:02:39.650
Bad people like all of us
watching this show right now.

45
00:02:39.650 --> 00:02:44.850
So the Edge Transport Server is designed
to sit in your DMZ and to be isolated

46
00:02:44.850 --> 00:02:49.330
from the network except for the barest
minimum of communications necessary.

47
00:02:49.330 --> 00:02:52.982
Now the Edge Transport Server really
does take security to a high level.

48
00:02:52.982 --> 00:02:55.616
For example,
it's not even joined to the domain, right?

49
00:02:55.616 --> 00:02:59.496
If somebody compromises the Edge Transport
Server, it's not joined to the domain.

50
00:02:59.496 --> 00:03:02.337
It can't authenticate against
any server on the inside.

51
00:03:02.337 --> 00:03:03.840
It's not able to communicate.

52
00:03:03.840 --> 00:03:05.480
It's a dead end.

53
00:03:05.480 --> 00:03:09.670
The Edge Transport server also only
maintains very minimal email queues.

54
00:03:09.670 --> 00:03:12.710
An email comes in, it can scan and

55
00:03:12.710 --> 00:03:17.130
filter email right there, and
then send it on into the internal network.

56
00:03:17.130 --> 00:03:20.940
So if somebody were to compromise this
system the only email they would have

57
00:03:20.940 --> 00:03:24.440
access to is email that was being
scanned at that moment as it was being

58
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:25.970
transmitted through.

59
00:03:25.970 --> 00:03:28.660
So fairly secure from that respect too.

60
00:03:28.660 --> 00:03:31.910
Also, it doesn't even have
a list of user accounts.

61
00:03:31.910 --> 00:03:34.290
Now, that might sound kinda weird, right?

62
00:03:34.290 --> 00:03:36.580
This thing is gonna receive email for us.

63
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:38.990
How does it know who's a good account and
who's a bad account?

64
00:03:38.990 --> 00:03:42.380
And it actually does it
through a really slick system.

65
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:47.050
What happens is the Edge Transport Server,
it's not joined to our domain.

66
00:03:47.050 --> 00:03:49.120
So it doesn't have a view
of Active Directory.

67
00:03:49.120 --> 00:03:50.600
It doesn't know what
user accounts we have.

68
00:03:50.600 --> 00:03:52.870
It doesn't even know
the exchange configuration, but

69
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:56.510
it's got to know something, otherwise
it's not going to be able to do its job.

70
00:03:56.510 --> 00:04:01.830
So it leverages what's called the Active
Directory Lightweight Directory Services.

71
00:04:01.830 --> 00:04:07.390
What the ADLDS does,
is it lets you run a very

72
00:04:07.390 --> 00:04:11.680
small selection of data from
the active directory, all right?

73
00:04:11.680 --> 00:04:14.320
The example I gave is like a phone book,
right?

74
00:04:14.320 --> 00:04:17.230
If you get a phone book,
you come here to Gainesville, Florida and

75
00:04:17.230 --> 00:04:19.900
grab the Gainesville phonebook,
if you remember phonebook's,

76
00:04:19.900 --> 00:04:21.980
the big paper things that
have phone numbers in them.

77
00:04:21.980 --> 00:04:23.170
Some of you might not.

78
00:04:23.170 --> 00:04:25.720
But if you crack open a phonebook
what do you have in there?

79
00:04:25.720 --> 00:04:27.880
You have a person's name,
you have their address, and

80
00:04:27.880 --> 00:04:30.560
you have their phone number,
and that's it, right?

81
00:04:30.560 --> 00:04:34.980
You just have enough information to be
able to find that person and talk to them.

82
00:04:34.980 --> 00:04:37.080
But you don't know what
their hair color is.

83
00:04:37.080 --> 00:04:38.260
You don't know how old they are.

84
00:04:38.260 --> 00:04:40.200
You don't know what
kind of car they drive.

85
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:41.250
That stuff isn't in there.

86
00:04:41.250 --> 00:04:43.530
The phone book is a very,
very simplified version.

87
00:04:43.530 --> 00:04:45.980
Well, that's what
the Edge Transport Servers do.

88
00:04:45.980 --> 00:04:50.490
They have a very, very simplified
version of the active directory.

89
00:04:50.490 --> 00:04:53.780
In fact it's so simplified that it
really just contains a couple of things.

90
00:04:53.780 --> 00:04:57.980
It contains what mailbox servers
it needs to talk to, right?

91
00:04:57.980 --> 00:05:01.100
When email comes in,
it needs to know who to send the email to.

92
00:05:01.100 --> 00:05:04.360
So it has a list of mailbox servers
that it can talk to, right, and

93
00:05:04.360 --> 00:05:06.340
it uses the GUID's of the servers.

94
00:05:06.340 --> 00:05:08.490
So it doesn't even really
know the name of the server.

95
00:05:08.490 --> 00:05:10.470
It doesn't know that it
Lab dash mailbox 01.

96
00:05:10.470 --> 00:05:13.300
It just sees the GUID for that server.

97
00:05:13.300 --> 00:05:17.280
So, if somebody were to compromise
the system, they would just see GUID's.

98
00:05:17.280 --> 00:05:22.170
And then as far as email addresses, it
doesn't have them, which is kind of cool.

99
00:05:22.170 --> 00:05:23.990
If somebody hacks into
an edge transport server,

100
00:05:23.990 --> 00:05:26.030
they can't figure out
your email address list.

101
00:05:26.030 --> 00:05:31.000
What it does is your mailbox
server on the back end takes all

102
00:05:31.000 --> 00:05:36.140
the email addresses from Active Directory
and Exchange, and it hashes them.

103
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:40.430
It does a SHA-256 one way hash,
and it takes those hash values and

104
00:05:40.430 --> 00:05:42.680
it sends them to
the Edge Transport Server.

105
00:05:42.680 --> 00:05:46.380
And so when an edge transport server
receives and email and it's to deposit or

106
00:05:46.380 --> 00:05:48.530
to Don@itpro.tv, right?

107
00:05:48.530 --> 00:05:51.980
It takes take that name, Don@itpro.tv,
and it does a SHA-256 hash.

108
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:58.340
And then it looks at the hash list from
the servers inside, and looks for a match.

109
00:05:58.340 --> 00:06:02.290
If it finds a match, that mailbox exists
on the inside and we need to process it.

110
00:06:02.290 --> 00:06:04.940
If it doesn't find a match,
it throws the email away.

111
00:06:04.940 --> 00:06:05.982
Sorry, recipient not found.

112
00:06:05.982 --> 00:06:09.690
But the Edge Transport Server doesn't
actually know what my email address is.

113
00:06:09.690 --> 00:06:14.150
It doesn't know that I'm don@itpro.tv,
it just sees that SHA-256 hash.

114
00:06:14.150 --> 00:06:18.150
So, another way to have that security,
if this server gets compromised, somebody

115
00:06:18.150 --> 00:06:21.720
can't lift our usernames out of it, they
can't lift out e-mail addresses out of it.

116
00:06:21.720 --> 00:06:23.310
They just see a big hash table.

117
00:06:23.310 --> 00:06:24.740
Right, and that's that.

118
00:06:24.740 --> 00:06:26.320
So, pretty cool, right?

119
00:06:26.320 --> 00:06:28.940
They really wanted to
make this thing as risk

120
00:06:28.940 --> 00:06:32.460
free as possible to stick in between us
and the network, and the internet, right?

121
00:06:32.460 --> 00:06:36.350
Now, you don't have to use an Edge
transport server, plenty of people don't.

122
00:06:36.350 --> 00:06:37.640
Instead of using an Edge transport server,

123
00:06:37.640 --> 00:06:42.290
you might use a third party product,
like a Barracuda spam and virus firewall.

124
00:06:42.290 --> 00:06:44.270
It kinda serves the same purpose, right?

125
00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:48.250
It sits in your DMZ, in between the
Internet and your internal network, and

126
00:06:48.250 --> 00:06:51.640
it does filtering before content even
makes it inside of your network so

127
00:06:51.640 --> 00:06:53.220
that's kinda cool.

128
00:06:53.220 --> 00:06:58.170
But by doing edge transport servers we've
got Microsoft Edge transport servers.

129
00:06:58.170 --> 00:07:01.080
We have Microsoft exchange servers and
it's all running on top of Windows.

130
00:07:01.080 --> 00:07:02.630
We have a common environment, right?

131
00:07:02.630 --> 00:07:03.370
We have a common,

132
00:07:03.370 --> 00:07:06.680
consistent environment with one company
that we need to reach out to for support

133
00:07:06.680 --> 00:07:10.380
and that's one of the big benefits of
doing an Edge transport server like this.

134
00:07:10.380 --> 00:07:11.260
All right.

135
00:07:11.260 --> 00:07:12.460
But it is a weird beast, right?

136
00:07:12.460 --> 00:07:15.420
It's a lot different than the other
servers, so getting an Edge transport

137
00:07:15.420 --> 00:07:19.350
server installed is a pretty
interesting process, all right?

138
00:07:19.350 --> 00:07:21.550
There's a few things we need to do, okay?

139
00:07:21.550 --> 00:07:24.050
Step one, we need to get a server, right?

140
00:07:24.050 --> 00:07:26.990
So you get a physical server and
you provision it in your DMZ, so

141
00:07:26.990 --> 00:07:30.990
we're gonna deploy that server here in our
DMZ, so not on our local area network.

142
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:34.670
It's gonna start in this separate network
where we expose it to the Internet.

143
00:07:34.670 --> 00:07:37.610
Then we need to configure
some firewall rules.

144
00:07:37.610 --> 00:07:38.250
Okay.

145
00:07:38.250 --> 00:07:39.560
Notice how I've got two firewalls.

146
00:07:39.560 --> 00:07:41.920
You might have two firewalls,
you might have one firewall, but

147
00:07:41.920 --> 00:07:44.570
hopefully you have at least
a firewall in your environment.

148
00:07:44.570 --> 00:07:48.400
We need to allow SMTP port 25 in and

149
00:07:48.400 --> 00:07:50.940
out, between the Internet and
the Edge Transport server.

150
00:07:50.940 --> 00:07:51.480
Right?

151
00:07:51.480 --> 00:07:53.832
We're gonna change our mail
exchanger records to point to

152
00:07:53.832 --> 00:07:56.765
the Edge Transport Server instead of
pointing to some internal server.

153
00:07:56.765 --> 00:07:58.660
So, the outside world, the Internet,

154
00:07:58.660 --> 00:08:01.351
needs to be able to connect
to the Edge Transport Server.

155
00:08:01.351 --> 00:08:04.230
So SMTP port 25, or TCB port 25 in and

156
00:08:04.230 --> 00:08:08.810
out on our public firewall,
on our WAN connection.

157
00:08:08.810 --> 00:08:12.470
On the LAN side we need the DMZ,
we need this Edge Transport Server

158
00:08:12.470 --> 00:08:17.070
to be able to communicate with SMTP
port 25 to our mailbox servers.

159
00:08:17.070 --> 00:08:20.274
Okay, not to the client access servers,
I've kind of got that drawn here cuz I was

160
00:08:20.274 --> 00:08:23.140
using it for another example but,
if do it that way, there.

161
00:08:23.140 --> 00:08:25.440
It actually connects directly
to the mailbox server.

162
00:08:25.440 --> 00:08:28.540
We don't need the front end transport
service because our Edge Transport Server

163
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:30.260
is the front end transport service.

164
00:08:30.260 --> 00:08:32.800
We need to connect to the hub
transport service which is back in our

165
00:08:32.800 --> 00:08:33.880
mailbox server.

166
00:08:33.880 --> 00:08:39.920
So we need SMTP TCP port 25 to be
open inbound and outbound, okay?

167
00:08:39.920 --> 00:08:44.380
Inbound, we need the DMZ server to be
able to send email to the mailbox server.

168
00:08:44.380 --> 00:08:47.210
And outbound, we need the mailbox
server to be able to relay

169
00:08:47.210 --> 00:08:49.620
through the Edge Transport Server
on the way out.

170
00:08:49.620 --> 00:08:51.520
You don't have to do that,
but it's good practice.

171
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:54.790
It's a good practice to be sending your
in and out through this one place,

172
00:08:54.790 --> 00:08:58.190
that way we can set up filtering
rules one place, right.

173
00:08:59.510 --> 00:09:03.492
The other thing is there's one extra
special port that we have to approve,

174
00:09:03.492 --> 00:09:04.390
all right?

175
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:06.770
SMTP, we know we need that,
cuz that's how email comes in, and

176
00:09:06.770 --> 00:09:08.870
that's how email goes out,
so we gotta have those.

177
00:09:08.870 --> 00:09:14.750
But, the Edge Transport Server,
it can't see the Active Directory, right?

178
00:09:14.750 --> 00:09:16.880
It's using
the Lightweight Directory Service, and

179
00:09:16.880 --> 00:09:20.920
