it's gonna populate that with data,
like those hashes for user accounts.

180
00:09:20.920 --> 00:09:22.800
So anytime I add a new mailbox back here,

181
00:09:22.800 --> 00:09:25.700
the Edge Transport Server has
to find out about it, okay?

182
00:09:25.700 --> 00:09:29.510
But we don't want
the Edge Transport Server to reach

183
00:09:29.510 --> 00:09:31.280
into our network to get that data.

184
00:09:31.280 --> 00:09:33.600
We don't want that, cuz then if
somebody compromised the server,

185
00:09:33.600 --> 00:09:35.550
they could reach in and get the data.

186
00:09:35.550 --> 00:09:42.270
So what we need to do is approve for the
mailboxes to push the changes to the DMZ.

187
00:09:42.270 --> 00:09:47.610
In other words, an internal server can
send data to the Edge Transport Server,

188
00:09:47.610 --> 00:09:49.710
the Edge Transport Server can't talk back.

189
00:09:49.710 --> 00:09:52.483
And that means that if the Edge Transport
Server gets compromised, they can't send

190
00:09:52.483 --> 00:09:55.233
data back to change the configuration,
they can't manipulate things like that.

191
00:09:55.233 --> 00:09:59.120
They can just damage the Edge Server,
they can't do anything else, right?

192
00:09:59.120 --> 00:10:04.940
But we can make changes all we want on the
inside and they'll push to the DMZ server.

193
00:10:04.940 --> 00:10:10.409
Now all of that's done on TCP port 50636.

194
00:10:10.409 --> 00:10:15.714
So 50,636, it's a port that Microsoft
picked, it's not a registered port.

195
00:10:15.714 --> 00:10:20.120
It's just one of the freely available
ones that they use, so 50636.

196
00:10:20.120 --> 00:10:26.090
You want it outbound, the mailbox server
to the Edge Transport Server, right?

197
00:10:26.090 --> 00:10:28.950
Not the other way around, don't do
Edge Transport Server back in, all right?

198
00:10:28.950 --> 00:10:31.600
And if you have more
than one mailbox server,

199
00:10:31.600 --> 00:10:35.030
they all need to be able to connect
to the Edge Transport Server.

200
00:10:35.030 --> 00:10:37.880
Because if one fails, another server's
gotta push those changes, right?

201
00:10:37.880 --> 00:10:40.590
So we need to approve that for
each one, all right?

202
00:10:40.590 --> 00:10:44.280
Now, if you've got
Active Directory sites configured,

203
00:10:44.280 --> 00:10:47.140
then you've got mailbox servers in
different sites and you'll likely

204
00:10:47.140 --> 00:10:49.800
have different Edge Transport Servers
in those different sites.

205
00:10:49.800 --> 00:10:52.940
So when I approve this for the firewall,
it's all within the same site, right?

206
00:10:52.940 --> 00:10:56.960
So mailbox servers in this site need to be
able to talk to the Edge Transport Server.

207
00:10:56.960 --> 00:11:00.210
If I have other sites, they don't need to
be able to talk to it because their email

208
00:11:00.210 --> 00:11:04.120
is gonna come to this site first and
then go out to the DMZ.

209
00:11:04.120 --> 00:11:06.800
So think in terms of
Active Directory sites.

210
00:11:06.800 --> 00:11:09.830
So on the network side, that's one
of the things that I need to do.

211
00:11:09.830 --> 00:11:12.310
Second, I need to build up my server.

212
00:11:12.310 --> 00:11:17.369
Now the server needs to be Windows Server
2008 R2 or Windows Server 2012.

213
00:11:17.369 --> 00:11:21.480
And then we can install the Exchange
2013 system on here and

214
00:11:21.480 --> 00:11:23.440
choose the Edge Transport role.

215
00:11:23.440 --> 00:11:26.070
Now you can do it from the command
line using the setup command, or

216
00:11:26.070 --> 00:11:27.640
you can use the GUI to do it.

217
00:11:27.640 --> 00:11:30.520
But either way there is
one prerequisite we need.

218
00:11:30.520 --> 00:11:33.330
Remember we installed Exchange
2013 in our other episodes,

219
00:11:33.330 --> 00:11:35.470
there were a ton of prerequisites,
I had to do a lot.

220
00:11:35.470 --> 00:11:38.287
We had to do
the Unified Communications Framework,

221
00:11:38.287 --> 00:11:43.223
we had to do .NET Framework 4.5, we had to
do the Windows Management Framework 4.0.

222
00:11:43.223 --> 00:11:46.550
We had to do a ton of roles and features.

223
00:11:46.550 --> 00:11:48.260
I had a little script
that I ran that did that,

224
00:11:48.260 --> 00:11:50.950
if you've seen the episode,
it's a lot of stuff.

225
00:11:50.950 --> 00:11:53.520
On an Edge Transport Server
there's only one prerequisite, and

226
00:11:53.520 --> 00:11:56.040
that's the Active Directory
Lightweight Directory Service.

227
00:11:56.040 --> 00:11:59.160
So we need to get that installed
before we can install Exchange.

228
00:11:59.160 --> 00:12:00.870
So let's take a look at that.

229
00:12:00.870 --> 00:12:04.630
So here I am on an Edge Transport Server,
I just called it LAB-EDGE01.

230
00:12:04.630 --> 00:12:07.660
And if I look at the server,
it's just in a work group.

231
00:12:07.660 --> 00:12:11.000
I didn't join it to my domain,
this is gonna be going in my DMZ so

232
00:12:11.000 --> 00:12:15.900
don't bother joining it to the domain,
it's just a stand alone server, okay.

233
00:12:15.900 --> 00:12:19.710
It is a good idea to have the server
with a static IP address.

234
00:12:19.710 --> 00:12:23.410
And we actually do need to
configure a little bit of DNS.

235
00:12:23.410 --> 00:12:26.590
Basically the Edge Transport Server,
remember how I said we need TCP

236
00:12:26.590 --> 00:12:31.840
port 25 to be able to send SMTP traffic
to the mailbox servers on the inside?

237
00:12:31.840 --> 00:12:36.640
Our Edge Transport Server needs to
be able to resolve the DNS name

238
00:12:36.640 --> 00:12:39.550
of our mailbox servers, and
the reverse needs to be true also.

239
00:12:39.550 --> 00:12:43.940
The mailbox servers need to be
able to resolve the DNS entry for

240
00:12:43.940 --> 00:12:45.200
our Edge Transport Server.

241
00:12:45.200 --> 00:12:49.400
So we probably need to have a static IP so
we can do DNS entries for that.

242
00:12:49.400 --> 00:12:52.450
Now on mine, this is a default install so
I'm in a work group and

243
00:12:52.450 --> 00:12:53.690
I have a DHCP address.

244
00:12:53.690 --> 00:12:58.080
So I'm gonna change that, I'm gonna come
in here and modify my IP address and

245
00:12:58.080 --> 00:13:00.300
I'm gonna statically assign it.

246
00:13:00.300 --> 00:13:02.750
So I'll just punch that in here and

247
00:13:02.750 --> 00:13:07.260
I'll make this one, we'll do .14 and
I'll punch in its gateway.

248
00:13:07.260 --> 00:13:10.840
Now, your DMZ network probably has a
different address, so you'll have to punch

249
00:13:10.840 --> 00:13:15.010
in IP address that's appropriate for
yours, and a DNS server you can use.

250
00:13:15.010 --> 00:13:17.850
And that DNS server needs to be able to
resolve those internal server names, so

251
00:13:17.850 --> 00:13:20.220
you might need to set up
a dedicated DNS server for this.

252
00:13:20.220 --> 00:13:23.870
I'm just gonna use an internal one,
all right.

253
00:13:23.870 --> 00:13:28.510
Now, on the DNS side, I need a DNS entry,
and I need to have a name and

254
00:13:28.510 --> 00:13:31.280
a domain, a fully qualified domain name.

255
00:13:31.280 --> 00:13:34.428
Now, normally we get that domain name from
being joined to the Active Directory.

256
00:13:34.428 --> 00:13:38.870
I'm not joined to the Active Directory so
I'm gonna need to set that on the server.

257
00:13:38.870 --> 00:13:42.630
So, I'm gonna go in here and
take my server name.

258
00:13:42.630 --> 00:13:43.840
I've got this computer name up here and

259
00:13:43.840 --> 00:13:46.810
I'll click on that and
I'm gonna go into Change.

260
00:13:46.810 --> 00:13:48.300
And I'm not gonna change
the computer name but

261
00:13:48.300 --> 00:13:52.350
if I hit More,
I can set my primary DNS suffix.

262
00:13:52.350 --> 00:13:56.940
And I've been using the ITProTV.net
domain so I'll do ITProTV.net.

263
00:13:56.940 --> 00:14:01.544
And that way my server knows, yeah,
you're not joined at the domain, but

264
00:14:01.544 --> 00:14:05.872
your fully qualified name is
LAB-EDGE01.itprotv.net, okay.

265
00:14:05.872 --> 00:14:08.937
So I'll go ahead and save that.

266
00:14:08.937 --> 00:14:10.850
And now I've got it set, all right?

267
00:14:10.850 --> 00:14:13.440
Now I do need to restart for
that to take effect, so I'll go ahead and

268
00:14:13.440 --> 00:14:14.310
let it restart.

269
00:14:14.310 --> 00:14:16.320
Well, actually I could do one more thing.

270
00:14:16.320 --> 00:14:18.920
I'm gonna do restart later, because

271
00:14:18.920 --> 00:14:21.890
I need to install the Active Directory
Lightweight Directory Services role.

272
00:14:21.890 --> 00:14:23.580
And so I can do that real quick and
then reboot,

273
00:14:23.580 --> 00:14:25.520
and kinda kill two birds with one stone.

274
00:14:25.520 --> 00:14:27.740
So I'll go up here to Manage
in Add Roles and Features.

275
00:14:29.260 --> 00:14:33.530
And in my Role list, if I can ever get it,
here we go, you can look down and

276
00:14:33.530 --> 00:14:36.240
there's the Active Directory
Lightweight Directory Services.

277
00:14:36.240 --> 00:14:40.310
I'm just gonna check that one off and
we'll add that feature and

278
00:14:40.310 --> 00:14:41.020
we'll let it get installed.

279
00:14:41.020 --> 00:14:42.862
I'm not checking anything else,
just kinda letting it go.

280
00:14:42.862 --> 00:14:46.565
That's the only prerequisite that I had so
I'll get that installed and

281
00:14:46.565 --> 00:14:48.799
then we can reboot the server, all right?

282
00:14:48.799 --> 00:14:54.499
The install's pretty quick cuz LDS is
pretty lightweight, thus the name.

283
00:14:54.499 --> 00:14:57.599
So there's not much for
it to install and get going.

284
00:14:57.599 --> 00:15:01.671
But while we're waiting on that I can
jump over to my domain controller,

285
00:15:01.671 --> 00:15:03.780
which is parked over here.

286
00:15:03.780 --> 00:15:07.020
And I can go into DNS and
I can start to set up my DNS entries.

287
00:15:07.020 --> 00:15:10.696
Now, I could have set up dynamic DNS
registration, but we're not normally

288
00:15:10.696 --> 00:15:14.384
gonna open that on the firewall for
our Edge Transport Server to get inside.

289
00:15:14.384 --> 00:15:16.555
So you're normally gonna have
to manually create these.

290
00:15:16.555 --> 00:15:20.595
And so if I go in my forward lookup zone,
I can see my internal servers.

291
00:15:20.595 --> 00:15:25.018
And I'm just gonna add a new
entry in here, a new A record,

292
00:15:25.018 --> 00:15:29.175
which I'll call LAB-EDGE01.ITProTV.net,
and

293
00:15:29.175 --> 00:15:34.260
I'll punch in its IP address
that we assign to it, all right.

294
00:15:34.260 --> 00:15:37.150
And what that's gonna do is it's gonna
make it where my internal servers,

295
00:15:37.150 --> 00:15:41.120
my mailbox servers, will be able to
resolve the Edge Transport Server by name.

296
00:15:41.120 --> 00:15:44.020
And my Edge Server pointing here
will be able to resolve my internal

297
00:15:44.020 --> 00:15:45.010
servers by name.

298
00:15:45.010 --> 00:15:47.390
So now we've got name resolution,
that's really important,

299
00:15:47.390 --> 00:15:48.522
otherwise this whole thing doesn't work.

300
00:15:48.522 --> 00:15:53.030
All right, so back here, this one's
finished installing, we can go ahead and

301
00:15:53.030 --> 00:15:54.119
restart this guy.

302
00:15:54.119 --> 00:15:59.678
And once it restarts, it's got its
IP address, it's got its DNS name.

303
00:15:59.678 --> 00:16:02.729
Then we're ready to install Exchange,
okay?

304
00:16:02.729 --> 00:16:06.760
Now when we install Exchange,
there is something we need to remember.

305
00:16:06.760 --> 00:16:10.730
We've got three roles in Exchange,
Client Access server, Mailbox server, and

306
00:16:10.730 --> 00:16:12.120
Edge Transport server.

307
00:16:12.120 --> 00:16:15.640
And in other episodes, I mentioned how
you could have a server be a dedicated

308
00:16:15.640 --> 00:16:18.650
Client Access Server, or a dedicated
Mailbox Server, or it could be both.

309
00:16:18.650 --> 00:16:21.310
It could be the Client Access and
Mailbox server.

310
00:16:21.310 --> 00:16:25.290
But Edge Transport,
always has to be alone, all right.

311
00:16:25.290 --> 00:16:28.035
If you install
the Edge Transport Service on a server,

312
00:16:28.035 --> 00:16:30.670
it cannot be a Client Access or
Mailbox server also.

313
00:16:30.670 --> 00:16:33.338
It can only be Edge Transport and
that's because it's supposed to be

314
00:16:33.338 --> 00:16:35.730
stuck out in the DMZ, and
it's supposed to be secure.

315
00:16:35.730 --> 00:16:37.836
If you install these other
roles we start to lose that.

316
00:16:37.836 --> 00:16:40.910
They have to be joined to the Active
Directory, Edge Transport doesn't.

317
00:16:40.910 --> 00:16:45.572
Now, you can join your Edge Transport
server to the Active Directory if you

318
00:16:45.572 --> 00:16:46.170
want to.

319
00:16:46.170 --> 00:16:48.460
It's not really recommended.

320
00:16:48.460 --> 00:16:51.460
We're going for security here,
but you can, it'll do that.

321
00:16:51.460 --> 00:16:53.092
But it does have to be by itself.

322
00:16:53.092 --> 00:16:57.317
All right, so that server is rebooted,
and when I get logged back into it,

323
00:16:57.317 --> 00:16:59.412
now I'm ready to install Exchange.

324
00:16:59.412 --> 00:17:03.625
All right, so from here I can launch
my Exchange installation disc, and

325
00:17:03.625 --> 00:17:05.292
I'll do it through the GUI.

326
00:17:05.292 --> 00:17:07.359
From the command line
if you just setup.exe,

327
00:17:07.359 --> 00:17:09.162
it's got some command line modifiers.

328
00:17:09.162 --> 00:17:12.996
So you can say /r: and
that's gonna tell it to install a role and

329
00:17:12.996 --> 00:17:17.912
then you just et for Edge Transport and
that'll install the Edge Transport role.

330
00:17:17.912 --> 00:17:21.872
But here I'm just gonna do it through the
GUI where it's a nice little check box.

331
00:17:21.872 --> 00:17:26.363
Now if I pick Client Access or
if I pick the Mailbox role,

332
00:17:26.363 --> 00:17:29.622
it's not gonna me pick Edge Transport.

333
00:17:29.622 --> 00:17:33.263
But once I'm picking Edge Transport it
won't let me Client Access or Mailbox, so

334
00:17:33.263 --> 00:17:36.712
it kinda saves you from making that
mistake, but it's not that big of a deal.

335
00:17:36.712 --> 00:17:40.582
Here it's just copying over some files and
getting those cached and ready.

336
00:17:40.582 --> 00:17:45.082
And then as soon as it's done it's gonna
ask about some default settings as far as

337
00:17:45.082 --> 00:17:47.082
the customer experience program.

338
00:17:47.082 --> 00:17:50.980
And then I'll be able to pick my roles and
move from there.

339
00:17:50.980 --> 00:17:55.050
If you haven't installed LDS, we'll
get a red flag telling us it's missing

340
00:17:55.050 --> 00:17:57.990
the requirement and we can go and
correct it and get it done.

341
00:17:57.990 --> 00:18:02.120
So if you forget it it'll keep you honest.

342
00:18:02.120 --> 00:18:05.250
All right, so here it's just getting
things ready to launch that install and

343
00:18:05.250 --> 00:18:05.970
then we'll get installed.

344
00:18:05.970 --> 00:18:09.350
Now when you install the Edge Transport
server it can't see the AD.

345
00:18:09.350 --> 00:18:10.420
It's not joined at the domain.

346
00:18:10.420 --> 00:18:14.460
So it's up, it's running but
it's completely useless.

347
00:18:14.460 --> 00:18:17.000
So once the install's actually
done we're gonna have to

348
00:18:17.000 --> 00:18:18.340
connect it to our internal environment.

349
00:18:18.340 --> 00:18:20.960
So there's a lot more work than
just doing the basic install.

350
00:18:20.960 --> 00:18:24.760
All right, I'm gonna agree to my licensing
agreement and I'll use recommended

351
00:18:24.760 --> 00:18:28.830
settings for the experience program and
then here's where I get to pick my roles.

352
00:18:28.830 --> 00:18:32.470
Now, if I choose Mailbox or
Client Access, Edge Transport grayed out.

353
00:18:32.470 --> 00:18:34.610
If I choose Edge Transport
it grays the other ones out.

354
00:18:34.610 --> 00:18:38.207
So I can just be an Edge Transport
server and that's what I want, so

355
00:18:38.207 --> 00:18:39.950
we'll go ahead and install it.

356
00:18:39.950 --> 00:18:43.887
And this is one of that fastest installs
that Exchange does because it doesn't need

357
00:18:43.887 --> 00:18:47.656
mailbox databases, it doesn't need
the special services in the background,

358
00:18:47.656 --> 00:18:50.830
it doesn't need unified communication,
it doesn't need IaaS.

359
00:18:50.830 --> 00:18:55.184
It just needs LDS, some mail queues and
the SMTP service, so it's gonna get

360
00:18:55.184 --> 00:19:00.250
installed, and then I'll be up and
running as an Edge Transport server.

361
00:19:00.250 --> 00:19:02.120
It's also gonna install
the Exchange Management Tools,

362
00:19:02.120 --> 00:19:04.270
which is kinda nice because
I'm gonna need those.

363
00:19:04.270 --> 00:19:05.200
Because when this is done,

364
00:19:05.200 --> 00:19:09.740
what we have to do is generate
what's called an Edge Subscription.

365
00:19:09.740 --> 00:19:11.420
What's an Edge Subscription?

366
00:19:11.420 --> 00:19:15.030
Well if we go back to my diagram here,
I mentioned how the Mailbox Servers

367
00:19:15.030 --> 00:19:18.650
are gonna be allowed to push changes
to the Edge Transport server.

368
00:19:18.650 --> 00:19:19.290
Okay?

369
00:19:19.290 --> 00:19:22.030
Well, that's what called
an Edge Subscription.

370
00:19:22.030 --> 00:19:25.860
The Edge Server will subscribe
to receiving those changes.

371
00:19:25.860 --> 00:19:30.000
It basically creates a key,
like a private key,

372
00:19:30.000 --> 00:19:35.600
to be able to authenticate and
we put that key on our Mailbox servers.

373
00:19:35.600 --> 00:19:38.890
And the Mailbox servers can then send
changes to the Edge Transport server and

374
00:19:38.890 --> 00:19:41.220
it looks at the key and
determines whether valid or not.

375
00:19:41.220 --> 00:19:44.810
And if it's valid, it applies the changes
and if it's not valid it rejects them, so

376
00:19:44.810 --> 00:19:46.830
it has a basic degree of security.

377
00:19:46.830 --> 00:19:48.600
But we've got to set that up.

378
00:19:48.600 --> 00:19:51.290
And then once we've got
the Edge Subscription in place,

379
00:19:51.290 --> 00:19:53.906
we can start up what's called EdgeSync.

380
00:19:53.906 --> 00:19:58.800
And with EdgeSync, the Mailbox servers
will start to synchronize changes out

381
00:19:58.800 --> 00:20:00.010
to the Edge Transport server.

382
00:20:00.010 --> 00:20:02.180
All right, now how does that work?

383
00:20:02.180 --> 00:20:05.510
Well there's actually two different things
that we're replicating when we send out to

384
00:20:05.510 --> 00:20:06.810
the Edge Transport server.

385
00:20:06.810 --> 00:20:10.254
The first part is our basic
server configuration and

386
00:20:10.254 --> 00:20:14.330
information there,
things like what are accepted domains.

387
00:20:14.330 --> 00:20:16.794
If you've got five different
domains in Exchange,

388
00:20:16.794 --> 00:20:19.340
the Edge Transport server
needs to know that.

389
00:20:19.340 --> 00:20:22.940
Cuz any other domain it's gonna
reject as an unauthorized relay.

390
00:20:22.940 --> 00:20:25.800
So that data is being
synchronized once every hour, so

391
00:20:25.800 --> 00:20:29.428
every one hour the Mailbox server
is sending that data up, okay.

392
00:20:29.428 --> 00:20:35.480
But then there's the recipient data,
all the mailboxes that we have.

393
00:20:35.480 --> 00:20:37.810
When you create a mailbox,
that has to get hashed and

394
00:20:37.810 --> 00:20:40.310
has to get sent up to
the Edge Transport server, all right.

395
00:20:40.310 --> 00:20:43.200
That happen every four hours, all right.

396
00:20:43.200 --> 00:20:45.550
Every four hours,
that's kind of a long time.

397
00:20:45.550 --> 00:20:48.920
That means it's only happening,
what is that, six times a day.

398
00:20:48.920 --> 00:20:52.320
So, if you just added a new user
mailbox and you need it to be active,

399
00:20:52.320 --> 00:20:55.050
right now you're gonna have to wait.

400
00:20:55.050 --> 00:20:57.230
It depends on where
you're at in that time.

401
00:20:57.230 --> 00:21:00.400
It might be another four hours before it
replicates, it might be another two hours,

402
00:21:00.400 --> 00:21:02.230
you don't know where
you are in that window.

403
00:21:02.230 --> 00:21:06.450
So we can always force that subscription
to happen, force that sync to happen.

404
00:21:06.450 --> 00:21:08.570
But you've got the Edge Subscription.

405
00:21:08.570 --> 00:21:11.420
That's the authenticated connection that
we build between the Mailbox servers and

406
00:21:11.420 --> 00:21:12.580
the Edge Transport server.

407
00:21:12.580 --> 00:21:16.520
And then you've got EdgeSync, which is
actually synchronizing that stuff along.

408
00:21:16.520 --> 00:21:18.880
So we'll get a chance to see that.

409
00:21:18.880 --> 00:21:22.270
Now in the chat room we got the question,
does it need to be set up on both servers?

410
00:21:22.270 --> 00:21:23.060
Do they need to be running?

411
00:21:24.110 --> 00:21:28.340
What you do is you generate
the subscription on your Edge server and

412
00:21:28.340 --> 00:21:29.340
then it creates a file.

413
00:21:29.340 --> 00:21:32.090
And you take that file to
your internal Mailbox server.

414
00:21:32.090 --> 00:21:35.510
And you can pick any Mailbox
server you want in your site, and

415
00:21:35.510 --> 00:21:37.800
you import it there, and
that's what creates the subscription.

416
00:21:37.800 --> 00:21:42.027
Now, when you do that it'll create
the subscription on all the mailbox

417
00:21:42.027 --> 00:21:43.374
servers in that site.

418
00:21:43.374 --> 00:21:47.928
All right, but if you add another mailbox
server in the future in that site you'll

419
00:21:47.928 --> 00:21:52.614
need to rerun it you'll need to re-import
that file again because it won't add it to

420
00:21:52.614 --> 00:21:53.874
new Mailbox servers.

421
00:21:53.874 --> 00:21:56.829
Now you might not care about that
if you've already got five servers,

422
00:21:56.829 --> 00:22:00.235
sending out to the Edge Transport Server
that's more then enough you don't need

423
00:22:00.235 --> 00:22:01.254
that sixth one to do it.

424
00:22:01.254 --> 00:22:04.886
But if you only had one before and now
you're adding a second Mailbox server for

425
00:22:04.886 --> 00:22:08.370
redundancy, well, you'll want that
one to have the edge subscription.

426
00:22:08.370 --> 00:22:09.550
So you'll just need to re-import the file.

427
00:22:09.550 --> 00:22:12.750
You don't have to regenerate the file, you
can just re-import the same file again and

428
00:22:12.750 --> 00:22:13.560
it'll set those up.

429
00:22:14.580 --> 00:22:16.000
So at this point
the install's gonna run and

430
00:22:16.000 --> 00:22:18.630
we're gonna watch this little
blue bar creep across the screen.

431
00:22:18.630 --> 00:22:21.340
And when it's done we'll need
to get our subscription set up.

432
00:22:21.340 --> 00:22:23.345
Now, I don't wanna bore
you guys with this and

433
00:22:23.345 --> 00:22:26.080
they're actually kinda running a little
short on time in this episode anyway.

434
00:22:26.080 --> 00:22:27.020
So why don't we do this?

435
00:22:27.020 --> 00:22:30.750
Why don't we wrap up this episode here,
and we'll do a part two.

436
00:22:30.750 --> 00:22:34.020
And in part two we'll verify
the installation completed, and

437
00:22:34.020 --> 00:22:35.720
we'll go ahead and
set up that subscription and

438
00:22:35.720 --> 00:22:38.180
get it communicating with our
servers inside of the network.

439
00:22:38.180 --> 00:22:41.040
We'll get a chance to see that process and
get it all done in action.

440
00:22:41.040 --> 00:22:46.280
So definitely stay tuned for the sequel,
the exciting conclusion to this episode.

441
00:22:46.280 --> 00:22:49.120
But for this episode,
we'll go ahead and wrap here.

442
00:22:49.120 --> 00:22:52.250
What we got a chance to see today were
what an Edge Transport server was,

443
00:22:52.250 --> 00:22:53.840
where it falls in your network, and

444
00:22:53.840 --> 00:22:57.880
how to get the prerequisites taken
care of to do that initial install.

445
00:22:57.880 --> 00:23:00.450
We got it all knocked out here so
we're ready to move on but

446
00:23:00.450 --> 00:23:01.960
we'll do that in part two.

447
00:23:01.960 --> 00:23:03.500
So I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

448
00:23:03.500 --> 00:23:07.250
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

449
00:23:07.250 --> 00:23:13.730
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to the Installing Edge Servers episode. Now that the server is installed, Don demonstrates how to connect the server to the internal network and verify replication between the systems.
episodes.title: Installing Edge Servers Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.655
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.655 --> 00:00:13.947
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.947 --> 00:00:16.158
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.158 --> 00:00:20.342
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again with
another episode of Microsoft Exchange

5
00:00:20.342 --> 00:00:22.871
2013, and not just any old episode, right?

6
00:00:22.871 --> 00:00:26.764
This is the exciting conclusion to
our two part series on installing

7
00:00:26.764 --> 00:00:29.649
the Edge Transport
server in Exchange 2013.

8
00:00:29.649 --> 00:00:33.817
In our last episode, we left off with,
well, with the role installing, right?

9
00:00:33.817 --> 00:00:36.526
And so we had a little blue bar
kinda creeping across our screen and

10
00:00:36.526 --> 00:00:37.074
that was it.

11
00:00:37.074 --> 00:00:40.667
Well, in that episode we talked about
what the Edge Transport server was,

12
00:00:40.667 --> 00:00:44.160
and how to get that install going,
now we need to make it active.

13
00:00:44.160 --> 00:00:47.610
So once the install finishes,
you reboot your server, and

14
00:00:47.610 --> 00:00:51.040
now we've gotta connect it
to our internal systems.

15
00:00:51.040 --> 00:00:54.210
But remember, the Edge Transport
server's supposed to sit in the DMZ, and

16
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:57.910
it's not allowed to reach in and
make changes in the inside network.

17
00:00:57.910 --> 00:01:01.616
So what we have to do,
is we have to generate the subscription

18
00:01:01.616 --> 00:01:05.904
on our Edge Transport server,
take that subscription inside to one of

19
00:01:05.904 --> 00:01:10.569
our mailbox servers, and actually
create the subscription on the inside.

20
00:01:10.569 --> 00:01:13.635
And then that sort of will push the
changes back out to the Edge server, so

21
00:01:13.635 --> 00:01:15.596
it's kind of a circle, right?

22
00:01:15.596 --> 00:01:18.782
Well, when we generate an Edge
subscription, what you're really doing,

23
00:01:18.782 --> 00:01:21.093
is generating authentication credentials,
right?

24
00:01:21.093 --> 00:01:23.284
The Edge Transport server is
not joined to your domain.

25
00:01:23.284 --> 00:01:26.487
It doesn't have some user account
that we can use to connect to it, so

26
00:01:26.487 --> 00:01:28.080
we need something else.

27
00:01:28.080 --> 00:01:31.225
And the Edge subscription basically
contains a security key, so

28
00:01:31.225 --> 00:01:34.607
this is like generating a private key,
public key pair kind of thing.

29
00:01:34.607 --> 00:01:37.788
We're generating this private key
that we'll take to the inside, and

30
00:01:37.788 --> 00:01:39.430
we need to do that securely.

31
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:42.305
So let me show you the process of
actually getting that connected, and

32
00:01:42.305 --> 00:01:43.192
getting it in place.

33
00:01:43.192 --> 00:01:46.398
So here I've got the server from the last
episode, it finished installing, and

34
00:01:46.398 --> 00:01:48.630
it rebooted,
you do have to reboot after the install.

35
00:01:48.630 --> 00:01:52.545
And now that it's up, I'm in
Edge Transport server, it's very exciting,

36
00:01:52.545 --> 00:01:54.847
except the server's not
doing a darn thing.

37
00:01:54.847 --> 00:01:57.150
If it doesn't have a subscription,
it's not gonna work,

38
00:01:57.150 --> 00:01:59.690
so it's just sitting here doing nothing,
all right?

39
00:01:59.690 --> 00:02:02.120
So now, I need to go in and
create a subscription, and

40
00:02:02.120 --> 00:02:04.173
we do it from
the Exchange Management Shell.

41
00:02:04.173 --> 00:02:08.757
So I'm gonna get into my Exchange
Management Shell, and once I'm in there,

42
00:02:08.757 --> 00:02:11.719
I'll be able to generate
that subscription, and

43
00:02:11.719 --> 00:02:14.130
it's just an XML file that we generate.

44
00:02:14.130 --> 00:02:17.633
So I'm gonna use
the New-EdgeSubscription commandlet, and

45
00:02:17.633 --> 00:02:19.624
it'll create this XML file for me.

46
00:02:19.624 --> 00:02:24.532
Once I've got the XML file, I need to copy
it to like a USB key, or burn it to CD, or

47
00:02:24.532 --> 00:02:28.540
something like that, and
take it inside my network, all right?

48
00:02:28.540 --> 00:02:30.751
The idea here is that
your server's in the DMZ.

49
00:02:30.751 --> 00:02:33.837
If you're setting the server up on your
LAN first and then you're going to move

50
00:02:33.837 --> 00:02:36.500
it to the DMZ, then you can actually
copy it across the network, but

51
00:02:36.500 --> 00:02:38.820
normally we would use like a USB key.

52
00:02:38.820 --> 00:02:43.779
So I'm going to come in here and
say New-EdgeSubscription, and then,

53
00:02:43.779 --> 00:02:48.250
-FileName, and the name of the XML
file I wanna generate, and so

54
00:02:48.250 --> 00:02:51.850
I'll just create C:\EdgeSub.xml,
all right?

55
00:02:51.850 --> 00:02:54.052
And so that's gonna generate,
and here it is,

56
00:02:54.052 --> 00:02:56.197
just giving me a little
bit of notice about it,

57
00:02:56.197 --> 00:02:59.775
that I'm generating this to set up
EdgeSync replication, and that this file

58
00:02:59.775 --> 00:03:04.130
does contain some information in it that's
secure, and so I need to handle it safely.

59
00:03:04.130 --> 00:03:08.972
And then its warning me right here, I need
to complete the subscription in the next

60
00:03:08.972 --> 00:03:12.358
1440 minutes, in other words,
this file expires.

61
00:03:12.358 --> 00:03:14.953
So if somebody else gets a hold
of my subscription down the road,

62
00:03:14.953 --> 00:03:16.680
its not gonna be any good to them, right?

63
00:03:16.680 --> 00:03:20.775
This file is only good for 1440 minutes.

64
00:03:20.775 --> 00:03:23.179
So I'll go ahead and
say Yes to generate it, and

65
00:03:23.179 --> 00:03:25.118
its gonna build a subscription file.

66
00:03:25.118 --> 00:03:27.793
All right, now what's in that file?

67
00:03:27.793 --> 00:03:31.160
If I browse on my hard drive,
to my C drive, this is where I put it.

68
00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:37.350
Right there is EdgeSub, and if I open
it up, it is just an XML file, right?

69
00:03:37.350 --> 00:03:39.427
And so if we look in here at it,
what does it have?

70
00:03:39.427 --> 00:03:43.383
Well, we start off with some basic
information, here's my server, LAB-EDGE01,

71
00:03:43.383 --> 00:03:46.431
It's got the name of the server,
LAB-EDGE01.itprotv.net,

72
00:03:46.431 --> 00:03:48.440
that's that fully qualified name.

73
00:03:48.440 --> 00:03:51.670
Remember in the first episode I
said we had to have valid DNS name

74
00:03:51.670 --> 00:03:53.420
resolution between the systems?

75
00:03:53.420 --> 00:03:54.981
Here's where it gets that name.

76
00:03:54.981 --> 00:03:58.480
And then right here, EdgeCertificateBlob.

77
00:03:58.480 --> 00:04:02.180
There's that private key, that
authentication that it's gonna be using

78
00:04:02.180 --> 00:04:04.360
and that is a long, long line, right?

79
00:04:04.360 --> 00:04:08.430
That's the whole giant value
that represents that key,

80
00:04:08.430 --> 00:04:10.610
that's what we have to keep safe,
all right?

81
00:04:10.610 --> 00:04:11.840
Because for the next 1440 minutes,

82
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:15.850
if somebody gets a hold of that,
they could create a false subscription,

83
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:19.580
and they could start pushing changes onto
your Edge server and they could turn it

84
00:04:19.580 --> 00:04:22.900
into a spam relay if they wanted, so
we have to make sure to keep this secure.

85
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:25.436
Think of it as like your
administrator password, all right?

86
00:04:25.436 --> 00:04:28.348
And then you got the effective date and
the duration,

87
00:04:28.348 --> 00:04:31.914
that's where it's getting
that 1440 minutes, all right?

88
00:04:31.914 --> 00:04:34.583
So I've got all that right there,
now I just need to take this and

89
00:04:34.583 --> 00:04:35.880
bring it in on my other server.

90
00:04:35.880 --> 00:04:37.927
Now, notice right here, this server type.

91
00:04:37.927 --> 00:04:42.679
The server type is some really
crazy characters here, okay?

92
00:04:42.679 --> 00:04:47.153
There's actually some binary data right in
there, and that's gonna cause a little bit

93
00:04:47.153 --> 00:04:51.084
of a problem when we do the import on
this, and so we'll see the import command

94
00:04:51.084 --> 00:04:54.918
is a little bit weird because of that,
but just be aware that that is there.

95
00:04:54.918 --> 00:04:59.780
All right, so my next step is to take this
file and copy it to my internal server.

96
00:04:59.780 --> 00:05:02.605
Now normally I'd send this to a USB key,
but because I'm in a lab,

97
00:05:02.605 --> 00:05:04.180
I can actually do it over my network.

98
00:05:04.180 --> 00:05:08.769
We wouldn't normally want to do that,
but I'll send it across.

99
00:05:08.769 --> 00:05:12.101
So I'm gonna browse over to my mailbox
server, and just paste it over there, so

100
00:05:12.101 --> 00:05:14.140
it's on the mailbox server, all right?

101
00:05:14.140 --> 00:05:16.914
By doing it with a USB key,
I can have them on separate networks and

102
00:05:16.914 --> 00:05:17.928
maintain my security.

103
00:05:17.928 --> 00:05:21.099
All right,
now I can jump over to my mailbox server.

104
00:05:21.099 --> 00:05:24.812
And so here I am on LAB-MAILBOX01, and you
can pick any of the mailbox servers that

105
00:05:24.812 --> 00:05:28.002
are in the same active directory site
to create this Edge subscription,

106
00:05:28.002 --> 00:05:28.837
cuz when you do it,

107
00:05:28.837 --> 00:05:32.110
it creates the subscription across
all the mailbox servers in that site.

108
00:05:33.340 --> 00:05:36.650
So here I'm gonna get into my
Exchange Management Shell also, and

109
00:05:36.650 --> 00:05:39.380
I'm going to import that subscription.

110
00:05:39.380 --> 00:05:42.376
Now the command for
doing it's actually not that bad.

111
00:05:42.376 --> 00:05:47.276
The command itself would be
New-EdgeSubscription, and

112
00:05:47.276 --> 00:05:50.976
then file name and
you specify the file, but

113
00:05:50.976 --> 00:05:54.310
I'm gonna have a bit of a problem here.

114
00:05:54.310 --> 00:05:57.128
The binary data in that file is
gonna cause an issue, and so

115
00:05:57.128 --> 00:05:59.557
just pointing it to a file
name isn't gonna work.

116
00:05:59.557 --> 00:06:01.303
In fact, if I finish this command,

117
00:06:01.303 --> 00:06:05.290
it'll give me a nice little error
telling me that I can't use file name.

118
00:06:05.290 --> 00:06:09.090
And so what I actually have to do,
is bring the data in as byte data and

119
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:11.303
that makes the syntax really bizarre.

120
00:06:11.303 --> 00:06:14.060
I don't know why Microsoft did
this exactly, but they did and so

121
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:18.110
we have to work around it, fortunately
this isn't something you do very often.

122
00:06:18.110 --> 00:06:20.603
So instead of using file name,
I'm gonna use file data.

123
00:06:20.603 --> 00:06:25.041
Which is basically saying, open the file
and read the data into this command byte

124
00:06:25.041 --> 00:06:28.390
by byte, so that it gets it,
and it's correct, all right?

125
00:06:28.390 --> 00:06:32.827
So I'll say file data, and I'm gonna
tell it that I'm bringing in byte data,

126
00:06:32.827 --> 00:06:35.264
I know this just gets awesome doesn't it?

127
00:06:35.264 --> 00:06:40.640
And I'm gonna use $Get-Content to
open the contents of the file,

128
00:06:40.640 --> 00:06:47.170
and the path to that file, and so for
me it's C:/EdgeSub.xml is where I put it.

129
00:06:48.960 --> 00:06:53.501
And then from there,
I need to kinda close this off so

130
00:06:53.501 --> 00:06:57.950
it understands that the encoding is byte,
right?

131
00:06:57.950 --> 00:07:01.454
I'm pulling in byte data and
I only need to read it once, so

132
00:07:01.454 --> 00:07:03.410
I'm gonna do a ReadCount of 0.

133
00:07:03.410 --> 00:07:07.331
Computer's starting memory was 0, so that
like a ReadCount of 1 would be the true

134

00:17:46.770 --> 00:17:49.640
So, what testing the edge
subscription does, is it, or

362
00:17:49.640 --> 00:17:53.560
edge synchronization, is it looks to see
if we can see the server, and then it

363
00:17:53.560 --> 00:17:56.745
gives you information about the status of
all the things we've configured on it.

364
00:17:56.745 --> 00:17:58.240
But we haven't configured anything yet.

365
00:17:58.240 --> 00:18:00.010
So that's why I didn't go to that command.

366
00:18:00.010 --> 00:18:03.190
This is more useful down the road, like
later one when we've configured things we

367
00:18:03.190 --> 00:18:05.370
can check the status of all
the services and so on.

368
00:18:05.370 --> 00:18:07.320
Before right now I don't
usually use that one.

369
00:18:07.320 --> 00:18:11.300
But just be aware that is a test dash
edge synchronization command you can run.

370
00:18:11.300 --> 00:18:12.790
All right, well,

371
00:18:12.790 --> 00:18:16.160
this point, my subscription has been
brought into my internal server.

372
00:18:16.160 --> 00:18:19.440
I'm talking to the external server so
I'm pushing changes to it.

373
00:18:19.440 --> 00:18:20.810
I should be ready to rock.

374
00:18:20.810 --> 00:18:23.030
Let's verify one more thing though.

375
00:18:23.030 --> 00:18:28.120
I'm gonna jump over to my Exchange admin
center, and in my Exchange admin center.

376
00:18:28.120 --> 00:18:31.120
I should see some new receive
connectors that are set up.

377
00:18:31.120 --> 00:18:33.320
So if I go down here to mail flow and

378
00:18:33.320 --> 00:18:38.160
I take a look at my receive connectors,
when I look at the receive connectors

379
00:18:38.160 --> 00:18:40.370
I've got my basic settings
in place like normal, right?

380
00:18:40.370 --> 00:18:41.980
Nothing too special there, but

381
00:18:41.980 --> 00:18:46.010
on the send connector side, now I see
those EdgeSync connections, right?

382
00:18:46.010 --> 00:18:47.450
Here's the EdgeSync.

383
00:18:47.450 --> 00:18:48.950
Default first site name to internet.

384
00:18:48.950 --> 00:18:50.970
Right, so this is our outgoing stuff.

385
00:18:50.970 --> 00:18:53.910
And then we got inbound to
default first site name.

386
00:18:53.910 --> 00:18:57.750
These are the send connectors that were
created that actually connect our site

387
00:18:57.750 --> 00:18:59.020
to the edge transport service.

388
00:18:59.020 --> 00:19:02.700
So those are in place, and they're up
in running, they're doing their job.

389
00:19:02.700 --> 00:19:05.470
We can always come in and edit them and
tweak their settings, change things if you

390
00:19:05.470 --> 00:19:09.300
want to but for the most part it's
set the way that we need them.

391
00:19:09.300 --> 00:19:13.190
At this stage, we've got an edge
transport server and we're now up and

392
00:19:13.190 --> 00:19:16.250
running and
it's doing what it needs to do.

393
00:19:16.250 --> 00:19:17.420
Now what is it doing?

394
00:19:17.420 --> 00:19:18.136
Not really much.

395
00:19:18.136 --> 00:19:21.070
[LAUGH] Right now it's
just relaying email.

396
00:19:21.070 --> 00:19:24.990
So right now it's giving you security just
through obscuring your email address list

397
00:19:24.990 --> 00:19:26.410
and that's it, right.

398
00:19:26.410 --> 00:19:28.840
But where the real power of the Edge
Transport server comes in is when we go

399
00:19:28.840 --> 00:19:30.830
and configure the advanced things.

400
00:19:30.830 --> 00:19:33.800
On the Edge Transport server,
we can filter out spam,

401
00:19:33.800 --> 00:19:35.170
we can filter out viruses.

402
00:19:35.170 --> 00:19:38.060
You can put policies in place that
white-list and blacklist IPs.

403
00:19:38.060 --> 00:19:41.750
You can do all sorts of security
measures like that, and

404
00:19:41.750 --> 00:19:46.410
it will filter email before it
even gets into your organization.

405
00:19:46.410 --> 00:19:48.380
And that's where the real power is.

406
00:19:48.380 --> 00:19:53.330
So what we need to do next is to actually
get in there and set up those rules.

407
00:19:53.330 --> 00:19:56.750
But that would be something
great to cover in part three,

408
00:19:56.750 --> 00:19:59.560
right, in our next episode when we
start to get into actually configuring

409
00:19:59.560 --> 00:20:03.620
all the rules and filtering for
the Exchange Edge Transport server.

410
00:20:03.620 --> 00:20:07.320
So definitely stay tuned for
that one but for this episode,

411
00:20:07.320 --> 00:20:10.930
our Edge Transport server's up,
it's running, it's happy.

412
00:20:10.930 --> 00:20:13.160
Things are running the way
they're supposed to run,

413
00:20:13.160 --> 00:20:14.090
now we just need to configure it.

414
00:20:14.090 --> 00:20:15.950
So we'll definitely want
to tune back in for that.

415
00:20:15.950 --> 00:20:19.320
But in this episode we got a chance to
see setting up that Edge subscription,

416
00:20:19.320 --> 00:20:22.530
doing the Edge synchronization, and
testing it and troubleshooting it

417
00:20:22.530 --> 00:20:26.270
to actually make sure it's up and running
and doing what it's supposed to do.

418
00:20:26.270 --> 00:20:28.210
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the episode!

419
00:20:28.210 --> 00:20:31.610
Definitely tune back in for configuring
the rules and filtering on this server,

420
00:20:31.610 --> 00:20:32.990
cuz that's where it really becomes useful.

421
00:20:32.990 --> 00:20:34.880
And it'll definitely be
a good one to watch.

422
00:20:34.880 --> 00:20:35.920
I hope to see you then.

423
00:20:35.920 --> 00:20:40.345
But for now, signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

424
00:20:40.345 --> 00:20:46.210
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks the viewers through the available transport agents found on an Edge Transport server. He demonstrates several scenarios where transport rules can be applied to improve email security. He ends the episode by showing how to replicate the rules between Edge servers.
episodes.title: Configuring Rules
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.093 --> 00:00:10.303
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.303 --> 00:00:13.173
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:13.173 --> 00:00:15.240
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.240 --> 00:00:17.190
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.190 --> 00:00:19.570
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:24.690
And in this episode we're gonna
continue our Edge server adventure,

7
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:27.870
as we jump in and
actually get some rules configured.

8
00:00:27.870 --> 00:00:29.490
If you've been watching
our previous episodes,

9
00:00:29.490 --> 00:00:34.315
we saw how to install an Edge transport
server, we saw how to set up Edge sync and

10
00:00:34.315 --> 00:00:36.990
an Edge subscription, and
we've got all that in place.

11
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:41.610
And we have an Edge Transport server up,
but we didn't really make it do anything.

12
00:00:41.610 --> 00:00:44.720
Anything other than just receiving and
sending email which is fine,

13
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:48.400
but there's so much more we can
do with an Edge Transport server.

14
00:00:48.400 --> 00:00:51.850
An Edge Transport server is designed
to provide like the ultimate

15
00:00:51.850 --> 00:00:54.490
place to implement security
on your email network.

16
00:00:54.490 --> 00:00:58.290
So if you're scanning for viruses,
if you're scanning for spam and

17
00:00:58.290 --> 00:01:01.660
things like that, by catching
it on the edge transport server,

18
00:01:01.660 --> 00:01:05.430
you stop it from ever getting
inside your private network.

19
00:01:05.430 --> 00:01:07.310
And that gives you a great
level of security and

20
00:01:07.310 --> 00:01:11.470
protection and really is kind of the whole
point of the edge transport server.

21
00:01:11.470 --> 00:01:14.400
If you're just using it
as like an SMTP relay,

22
00:01:14.400 --> 00:01:16.230
an Edge transport server
is kind of overkill.

23
00:01:16.230 --> 00:01:18.890
You can probably use your ISP
to provide that service, and

24
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:20.920
now it's one less system to maintain.

25
00:01:20.920 --> 00:01:24.820
But if you really want the power, that's
where an Edge transport server comes in.

26
00:01:24.820 --> 00:01:27.850
And the way we get that power is
by configuring what are called

27
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:28.610
transport rules.

28
00:01:28.610 --> 00:01:33.200
Now, we've seen transport rules in
other episodes where we set up,

29
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:35.950
on a mailbox server we created some
transport rules to add things like

30
00:01:35.950 --> 00:01:37.350
a legal disclaimer or whatever.

31
00:01:37.350 --> 00:01:38.560
And you can do that.

32
00:01:38.560 --> 00:01:40.320
But on an edge transport server,

33
00:01:40.320 --> 00:01:43.440
the transport rules are really
focused on security.

34
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:47.270
And so to do that, there's these transport
agents that run in the background and

35
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:49.100
they let us perform all
sorts of crazy actions.

36
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:51.880
Let me show you how they work
on an edge transport server.

37
00:01:51.880 --> 00:01:53.470
So here I am on my edge
transport server and

38
00:01:53.470 --> 00:01:56.790
I'm just gonna jump into my
exchange management shelf.

39
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:01.680
And there's a neat little command you can
run, which is just Get-TransportAgent,

40
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:03.535
which I'll get to eventually, there we go.

41
00:02:03.535 --> 00:02:08.170
Get-TransportAgent, and it'll show you all
the different agents that are installed

42
00:02:08.170 --> 00:02:10.830
and enabled on an Edge Transport server.

43
00:02:10.830 --> 00:02:14.600
On a mailbox server, some of these
are enabled, a lot of them are disabled.

44
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:17.060
On an Edge Transport server,
they're all turned on, and

45
00:02:17.060 --> 00:02:19.920
that's because Microsoft assumes
you're going to be doing these things.

46
00:02:19.920 --> 00:02:21.570
And if you look at what's available,

47
00:02:21.570 --> 00:02:24.840
you've got things like
connection filtering agent.

48
00:02:24.840 --> 00:02:28.400
You might not want to allow certain
email servers to connect at all.

49
00:02:28.400 --> 00:02:30.360
Right?
There might be a email server out there

50
00:02:30.360 --> 00:02:33.500
that you know is a spam relay and
you just wanna block that server outright.

51
00:02:33.500 --> 00:02:34.760
So you can create a connection filter,

52
00:02:34.760 --> 00:02:37.980
that says, don't even, don't even ask
that server for a username and password.

53
00:02:37.980 --> 00:02:40.800
Don't, don't ask it anything,
just don't even let that IP connect.

54
00:02:41.830 --> 00:02:44.270
You might wanna do address rewriting,
right?

55
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:47.520
The address rewriting inbound agent and
address rewriting outbound agent.

56
00:02:47.520 --> 00:02:51.960
You can take an email and you can take
the sender or recipient address and

57
00:02:51.960 --> 00:02:54.070
change it to something else.

58
00:02:54.070 --> 00:02:54.680
Right?
For

59
00:02:54.680 --> 00:02:58.145
example, I might have a distribution
list inside of my network that's called

60
00:02:58.145 --> 00:03:01.580
salespeople@itprotv.net.

61
00:03:01.580 --> 00:03:06.060
But on the outside,
I want it to be info at ITPro.TV.

62
00:03:06.060 --> 00:03:10.200
Well, I can take email coming in for
info at ITPro.TV and

63
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:14.440
rewrite that destination to sales
at whatever and send it internally.

64
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:16.390
So you can do rewrites as
the emails pass through,

65
00:03:16.390 --> 00:03:18.029
it's a great way to obscure addresses.

66
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:21.480
Then we see things like
our edge rule agent.

67
00:03:21.480 --> 00:03:24.010
That's going to be what makes all these
rules apply and what's going to be

68
00:03:24.010 --> 00:03:28.280
pulling the rules from inside if we're
pushing these from an internal server.

69
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:29.700
Then we'll see our content filter.

70
00:03:29.700 --> 00:03:33.970
The content filter agent is kind of fun,
well as fun as these things get.

71
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:38.670
It lets you look for key words and
phrases inside emails and take actions.

72
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:40.180
And that action could be to block it, but

73
00:03:40.180 --> 00:03:45.520
it's normally to apply a [COUGH]
spam confidence level, an SCL.

74
00:03:45.520 --> 00:03:47.900
So you can assign an SCL based
on content in the email.

75
00:03:47.900 --> 00:03:50.420
You can look for
words like Rolex or Viagra.

76
00:03:50.420 --> 00:03:54.140
You can look for
words like Unsubscribe or phrases.

77
00:03:54.140 --> 00:03:56.120
If you're having trouble
reading this email.

78
00:03:56.120 --> 00:03:59.780
That's not stuff a normal person would use
so you could look for those phrases and

79
00:03:59.780 --> 00:04:02.480
adjust the SCL appropriately
using the content filter.

80
00:04:03.640 --> 00:04:06.180
The sender ID agent, all right.

81
00:04:06.180 --> 00:04:09.340
When somebody sends an email, they say
what their email address is, right?

82
00:04:09.340 --> 00:04:10.300
The from field.

83
00:04:10.300 --> 00:04:14.320
So you might get an email from me and
it's says it's from Don@itpro.tv.

84
00:04:14.320 --> 00:04:18.180
Well, your server can go and
do a lookup and say, all right,

85
00:04:18.180 --> 00:04:22.920
I'm gonna go find the itpro.tv domain, and
I'm gonna look for an SPF record, right.

86
00:04:22.920 --> 00:04:25.470
That's the sender policy framework and
it's gonna look to see

87
00:04:25.470 --> 00:04:29.240
what email servers are allowed to
send email for ITPro.TV, right.

88
00:04:29.240 --> 00:04:33.466
And if you're getting my email from one
of those servers then it's probably good.

89
00:04:33.466 --> 00:04:35.460
But if you're getting that
email from a different server,

90
00:04:35.460 --> 00:04:38.150
a server that's not on the list,
I probably wanna block that.

91
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:39.040
It's probably spam.

92
00:04:39.040 --> 00:04:44.270
And that's what sender ID filtering is and
the sender ID agent is what checks that.

93
00:04:44.270 --> 00:04:46.180
Now with it, it's on by default.

94
00:04:46.180 --> 00:04:48.940
We might wanna turn it off, but otherwise
we'd usually just leave that one alone.

95
00:04:48.940 --> 00:04:51.210
There's not a whole heck
of a lot to do on that one.

96
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:55.780
All right then we've got these sender
filter and the recipient filter agent.

97
00:04:55.780 --> 00:04:59.250
You might want to whitelist or
blacklist individual users.

98
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:02.400
You might have an e-mail that's
constantly sending you spam and

99
00:05:02.400 --> 00:05:04.170
you can't unsubscribe from it, so

100
00:05:04.170 --> 00:05:07.190
you could block that right at the edge of
transport server, and it never comes in.

101
00:05:08.810 --> 00:05:10.250
The protocol analysis agent.

102
00:05:10.250 --> 00:05:15.120
We can look into the protocol itself and
see if, if it's like SMTP

103
00:05:15.120 --> 00:05:19.230
emails that are coming in with certain
header types that aren't allowed or

104
00:05:19.230 --> 00:05:20.650
certain header types that are malformed.

105
00:05:20.650 --> 00:05:23.190
And then you've got
the attachment filtering.

106
00:05:23.190 --> 00:05:25.250
Attachment filtering's where, well,
you look at the attachment and

107
00:05:25.250 --> 00:05:28.980
you can filter based on the extension,
based on the size.

108
00:05:28.980 --> 00:05:32.870
There's all sorts of different things that
you can filter on to allow or denying it.

109
00:05:32.870 --> 00:05:36.750
So, a lot of different stuff there that
you can pull and actually deal with.

110
00:05:36.750 --> 00:05:40.040
So, these are all the agents that
are running in the background.

111
00:05:40.040 --> 00:05:42.040
Some of them we'll work with,
some of them we won't.

112
00:05:42.040 --> 00:05:44.260
You kinda pick and
choose based on your environment.

113
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:47.470
But in this episode I wanted to show you
guys a couple of real world examples of

114
00:05:47.470 --> 00:05:49.830
how you might use these rules, all right.

115
00:05:49.830 --> 00:05:53.410
Now, each agent has a different
command that we use to go in and

116
00:05:53.410 --> 00:05:54.090
kind of set things.

117
00:05:54.090 --> 00:05:56.680
We have some PowerShell
commandlets that we have to use.

118
00:05:56.680 --> 00:05:58.460
Unfortunately there's no GUI for this.

119
00:05:58.460 --> 00:06:01.740
We can't use the GUI to manage our Edge
Transport Server so we've got to do it

120
00:06:01.740 --> 00:06:04.960
from our management shell and
just dive in there and start to set these.

121
00:06:04.960 --> 00:06:07.010
So let me show you some examples.

122
00:06:07.010 --> 00:06:11.430
All right, first off, let's say that you
use one of those real time block lists,

123
00:06:11.430 --> 00:06:12.440
right, an RBL.

124
00:06:12.440 --> 00:06:16.550
There's a lot of companies out there like
Spamhaus that maintain email blocklists

125
00:06:16.550 --> 00:06:20.270
where they list all the servers out there
that have been identified as sending spam.

126
00:06:20.270 --> 00:06:23.350
So you can set your server to
reject connections from them,

127
00:06:23.350 --> 00:06:24.730
I might wanna turn that on.

128
00:06:24.730 --> 00:06:29.364
So, using Spamhaus as an example,
if I wanna set that up,

129
00:06:29.364 --> 00:06:34.012
the command to do it would
be Add-IPBlockListProvider.

130
00:06:36.262 --> 00:06:39.829
All right, so this is the command that's
gonna be reaching into the connection

131
00:06:39.829 --> 00:06:41.040
filtering agent.

132
00:06:41.040 --> 00:06:43.690
And I'm gonna be adding
some new block list.

133
00:06:43.690 --> 00:06:44.820
I need to give it a name.

134
00:06:44.820 --> 00:06:48.120
And I'll just call mine Spamhaus,
all right.

135
00:06:48.120 --> 00:06:51.180
And then I need to give
it a look up domain.

136
00:06:51.180 --> 00:06:56.920
The way that spam block list work is when
you get an email from a particular domain,

137
00:06:56.920 --> 00:07:00.430
you can take that domain and
send it to a DNS server that's out there.

138
00:07:00.430 --> 00:07:03.550
And the way we find that DNS server
is by specifying the lookup domain.

139
00:07:03.550 --> 00:07:08.188
And the one that Spamhaus
uses is zen.spamhaus.org and

140
00:07:08.188 --> 00:07:12.250
then we can specify what
to do about these things.

141
00:07:12.250 --> 00:07:15.190
So I'll say, any match, dollar sign, true.

142
00:07:15.190 --> 00:07:17.600
The way it works is if you do
a DNS lookup for a domain and

143
00:07:17.600 --> 00:07:21.130
it doesn't get an answer back,
then it's not on the blacklist, it's okay.

144
00:07:21.130 --> 00:07:25.410
But if you get any kind of response back
then that means it's on the block list and

145
00:07:25.410 --> 00:07:26.070
we can take action.

146
00:07:26.070 --> 00:07:29.700
So I'm saying if I get any match and
I'll try and spell it right.

147
00:07:29.700 --> 00:07:33.190
If any match happens,
then I want to treat it as a spam relay,

148
00:07:33.190 --> 00:07:35.900
somebody I don't want
to receive email from.

149
00:07:35.900 --> 00:07:39.980
And then we can just say
that this is enabled.

150
00:07:39.980 --> 00:07:42.820
So, I'll set enabled to true cuz
you can disable this temporarily if

151
00:07:42.820 --> 00:07:44.650
you're trying to troubleshoot.

152
00:07:44.650 --> 00:07:46.420
And then we do other
rejection options here.

153
00:07:46.420 --> 00:07:50.500
So, I'll say reject response so
that I can send a custom error message.

154
00:07:50.500 --> 00:07:54.630
Otherwise you're just gonna get one of
those five point one messages that's not

155
00:07:54.630 --> 00:07:57.423
really informative So
I'm gonna give him a message and

156
00:07:57.423 --> 00:08:01.580
I'll just say something like server
rejected by email blacklist.

157
00:08:01.580 --> 00:08:04.620
And that way, if somebody on the other end
is trying to send me email they're getting

158
00:08:04.620 --> 00:08:05.970
rejected, they can see why.

159
00:08:05.970 --> 00:08:09.220
Like oh, apparently I got on a blacklist,
I need to take care of that.

160
00:08:09.220 --> 00:08:13.440
And when we run that, assuming I
don't have typos, looks like I do.

161
00:08:13.440 --> 00:08:14.220
Let's see, add,

162
00:08:14.220 --> 00:08:17.880
a parameter cannot be found that
matches parameter name reject response.

163
00:08:17.880 --> 00:08:18.980
So, let me see.

164
00:08:18.980 --> 00:08:21.330
Oh, it's not reject,
it's rejection response.

165
00:08:21.330 --> 00:08:26.670
So let me just update that and
there we go.

166
00:08:26.670 --> 00:08:28.390
Now I have a real time block list.

167
00:08:28.390 --> 00:08:30.800
And you'll see it's got a priority of one,
I can go in and

168
00:08:30.800 --> 00:08:33.770
start adding more if I have
other block lists I wanna add

169
00:08:33.770 --> 00:08:36.330
you can go crazy with it,
you don't want to go too crazy.

170
00:08:36.330 --> 00:08:40.900
But now any time a server connects, I'm
gonna run them against the blacklist, and

171
00:08:40.900 --> 00:08:43.030
if they're in the blacklist,
I'll just reject their email, right?

172
00:08:43.030 --> 00:08:48.030
So pretty easy to jump that one right
in there and get that taken care of.

173
00:08:48.030 --> 00:08:51.040
Another example is I might wanna
setup a spam quarantine, right?

174
00:08:51.040 --> 00:08:54.520
What happens to email when the spam
competence level is too high?

175
00:08:54.520 --> 00:08:57.290
Well by default it goes in
your end user's junk mail.

176
00:08:57.290 --> 00:08:58.680
What if you wanna intercept
that ahead of time and

177
00:08:58.680 --> 00:09:00.050
say don't put it in their junk mail?

178
00:09:00.050 --> 00:09:04.220
Let's create a quarantine and set it
aside so the end users don't even see it.

179
00:09:04.220 --> 00:09:05.530
And then if they wanna look for

180
00:09:05.530 --> 00:09:07.630
something in spam they can just
reach out to the help desk.

181
00:09:07.630 --> 00:09:09.500
Well we can create a spam
quarantine that does that.

182
00:09:09.500 --> 00:09:12.140
And the Edge Transport Server
is where we want to apply that.

183
00:09:12.140 --> 00:09:15.150
So the way we do that is with
our content filtering agent.

184
00:09:15.150 --> 00:09:23.326
So I'm gonna say Set-ContentFilterConfig,
-, and I'm gonna set a QuarantineMailbox.

185
00:09:23.326 --> 00:09:26.160
Now, the quarantine mailbox,
I need to give it an email address for

186
00:09:26.160 --> 00:09:27.710
a mailbox inside of my system, so

187
00:09:27.710 --> 00:09:32.120
I might create something like
spam@itprotv.net or something like that.

188
00:09:32.120 --> 00:09:35.340
This is gonna be the mailbox I'm
gonna redirect these emails to.

189
00:09:35.340 --> 00:09:36.270
All right?

190
00:09:36.270 --> 00:09:43.480
Then I can say the SCL quarantine enabled,
there.

191
00:09:43.480 --> 00:09:44.865
So I'm actually gonna
turn the quarantine on.

192
00:09:44.865 --> 00:09:46.520
Cuz quarantine's off by default.

193
00:09:46.520 --> 00:09:48.700
It does actually make it to the end-users.

194
00:09:48.700 --> 00:09:51.675
So I'll do a $ true on that one.

195
00:09:51.675 --> 00:09:55.765
And then I need to set
the SCL quarantine threshold.

196
00:09:55.765 --> 00:09:59.795
And the threshold is the lowest
SCL value that I actually used to

197
00:09:59.795 --> 00:10:00.615
move things to a quarantine.

198
00:10:00.615 --> 00:10:03.205
I'm gonna set mine to six,
which is probably a little aggressive.

199
00:10:03.205 --> 00:10:05.000
You might wanna choose something higher.

200
00:10:05.000 --> 00:10:06.320
But I'll choose six.

201
00:10:06.320 --> 00:10:08.270
Anything that gets an SCL of six or

202
00:10:08.270 --> 00:10:11.790
higher, send to the quarantine
instead of the intended user.

203
00:10:11.790 --> 00:10:14.013
So, that's going to run and
it's going to put in place.

204
00:10:14.013 --> 00:10:16.420
And here it shows me no
settings have been modified.

205
00:10:16.420 --> 00:10:20.220
So apparently, I've already set it or
it must already be at six.

206
00:10:20.220 --> 00:10:22.760
But if you were at something lower or
higher, then it's going to adjust it down.

207
00:10:25.320 --> 00:10:27.420
Let's see, what other things might we do?

208
00:10:27.420 --> 00:10:29.290
Well, that content filter.

209
00:10:29.290 --> 00:10:33.320
Maybe there's certain keywords that
I want to filter on like unsubscribe.

210
00:10:33.320 --> 00:10:34.750
Well I could add a keyword filter.

211
00:10:34.750 --> 00:10:39.394
I could say Add-ContentFilterPhrase.

212
00:10:39.394 --> 00:10:42.820
And then I can specify the phrase
that I want to filter on.

213
00:10:42.820 --> 00:10:45.110
And this is where you can
do all sorts of things.

214
00:10:45.110 --> 00:10:47.660
I'll say look for unsubscribe.

215
00:10:47.660 --> 00:10:49.550
But you could be looking for other things,

216
00:10:49.550 --> 00:10:52.060
whoops, which if I spell
it right will work better.

217
00:10:52.060 --> 00:10:53.700
But you could do phrases.

218
00:10:53.700 --> 00:10:56.000
If you're having trouble reading this
email, that's one of my favorites.

219
00:10:56.000 --> 00:10:58.750
Those are different things
that you can key off of.

220
00:10:58.750 --> 00:11:03.310
And then from there, we basically specify
what we need to do with it, right?

221
00:11:03.310 --> 00:11:08.330
And a lot of times what we wanna do
with it is simply Influence the SCL.

222
00:11:08.330 --> 00:11:11.966
And the way we influence the SCL is by
saying whether this is a good word or

223
00:11:11.966 --> 00:11:14.950
a bad word, so
there's only two influences that we have.

224
00:11:14.950 --> 00:11:19.054
You can say good word if this is something
that should improve your SCL and

225
00:11:19.054 --> 00:11:20.000
make it better.

226
00:11:20.000 --> 00:11:24.329
Or you can say if it's a bad word
which is something that will

227
00:11:24.329 --> 00:11:27.800
increase your SCL number
which makes it worse.

228
00:11:27.800 --> 00:11:30.970
So, an SCL of zero is great.

229
00:11:30.970 --> 00:11:32.470
It's not spam, it's gonna get through.

230
00:11:32.470 --> 00:11:34.240
An SCL of nine is really bad.

231
00:11:34.240 --> 00:11:35.500
It is spam, right.

232
00:11:35.500 --> 00:11:38.450
So by saying bad word,
we make that number a little bit higher.

233
00:11:38.450 --> 00:11:41.640
And for each bad word that it hits,
it's making it worse and worse and

234
00:11:41.640 --> 00:11:43.680
worse until it finally gets
that SCL rating of nine.

235
00:11:45.500 --> 00:11:48.290
All right, so we'll set that,
and I just set that influence for

236
00:11:48.290 --> 00:11:50.130
the phrase unsubscribe.

237
00:11:50.130 --> 00:11:52.740
And you can continue to add
more phrases as you want.

238
00:11:52.740 --> 00:11:56.430
And you can do just a get dash content
folder phrase to see the whole list of

239
00:11:56.430 --> 00:11:59.730
what you filtered.

240
00:11:59.730 --> 00:12:00.810
We might also have,

241
00:12:00.810 --> 00:12:03.070
let's say there's a business partner
out there that we deal with.

242
00:12:03.070 --> 00:12:04.720
We don't want to spam filter them at all.

243
00:12:04.720 --> 00:12:06.870
We want to get all the email from them,
or the opposite.

244
00:12:06.870 --> 00:12:08.763
We have a server that we
absolutely want to block and

245
00:12:08.763 --> 00:12:10.180
we don't want to get email from them.

246
00:12:10.180 --> 00:12:13.590
You can set IP white list and black list.

247
00:12:13.590 --> 00:12:15.220
It's pretty straightforward.

248
00:12:15.220 --> 00:12:23.240
The way we do that is by saying
Add-IPAllowListEntry-IPAddress

249
00:12:23.240 --> 00:12:25.290
followed by the address of
the server we're gonna allow.

250
00:12:25.290 --> 00:12:27.740
So let's say that there's
a server at 1.1.1,

251
00:12:27.740 --> 00:12:32.740
I can add that and now any email that I
get from that server is gonna be allowed.

252
00:12:32.740 --> 00:12:34.730
It's gonna bypass the spam filter.

253
00:12:34.730 --> 00:12:36.380
We won't apply an SCL or
anything like that and

254
00:12:36.380 --> 00:12:37.800
it's gonna come in through the system.

255
00:12:37.800 --> 00:12:39.085
I just white listed that server.

256
00:12:39.085 --> 00:12:42.719
And you can block list it the same
way instead of doing an IPAllowList,

257
00:12:42.719 --> 00:12:46.240
we could come in and say,
maybe there's a server 2.2.2.2.

258
00:12:46.240 --> 00:12:49.370
And I don't want to allow that one.

259
00:12:49.370 --> 00:12:50.350
I want to block it.

260
00:12:50.350 --> 00:12:53.580
So I just change that
word from allow to block.

261
00:12:53.580 --> 00:12:55.520
Now, 2.2.2.2 is on my block list.

262
00:12:56.580 --> 00:13:00.130
Anytime the server at 2.2.2 tries
to connect, I don't ask it for

263
00:13:00.130 --> 00:13:01.010
a username and password.

264
00:13:01.010 --> 00:13:01.820
I don't ask it for anything.

265
00:13:01.820 --> 00:13:03.790
I just immediately disconnect it and
that's it.

266
00:13:03.790 --> 00:13:06.220
I won't allow them to
connect to my SMTP server.

267
00:13:08.070 --> 00:13:12.020
All right, so
there's a couple of entries there.

268
00:13:12.020 --> 00:13:14.370
Let's see, what else do we have?

269
00:13:14.370 --> 00:13:18.620
Oh, so here I was whitelisting and
blacklisting entire servers.

270
00:13:18.620 --> 00:13:20.140
Maybe it's not an entire
server that I want.

271
00:13:20.140 --> 00:13:22.600
Maybe it's an individual user or a domain.

272
00:13:22.600 --> 00:13:25.560
I wanna whitelist this domain or
I wanna whitelist this user.

273
00:13:25.560 --> 00:13:27.970
So there's a few ways we can do that.

274
00:13:27.970 --> 00:13:32.414
You can say Set-ContentFilterConfig and

275
00:13:32.414 --> 00:13:38.586
we can say -BypassSenders and
what this is gonna do is allow

276
00:13:38.586 --> 00:13:43.780
us to add email addresses
to the spam bypass list.

277
00:13:43.780 --> 00:13:48.750
So I might say,
boy I always want to get email from

278
00:13:48.750 --> 00:13:54.340
Don@itpro.tv if I can
remember my on email address.

279
00:13:54.340 --> 00:13:59.017
And if I have more than one, you just
stick quote marks around it and then add

280
00:13:59.017 --> 00:14:03.810
commas between each one, so you can add
more than one address if you wanted.

281
00:14:03.810 --> 00:14:08.280
So I'm gonna add Don@itpro.tv and
what did you get upset about here?

282
00:14:08.280 --> 00:14:11.420
Doesn't match bypass senders.

283
00:14:11.420 --> 00:14:13.420
Oh, it's bypassed.

284
00:14:14.430 --> 00:14:15.110
I have to add it.

285
00:14:15.110 --> 00:14:16.180
It's kinda past tense there.

286
00:14:16.180 --> 00:14:17.980
So bypassed senders.

287
00:14:17.980 --> 00:14:18.880
There we go.

288
00:14:18.880 --> 00:14:20.180
And now I can add that to the list.

289
00:14:20.180 --> 00:14:22.380
So, now, any time an email comes in and

290
00:14:22.380 --> 00:14:27.610
it shows as being sent by Don@itpro.tv,
it's gonna bypass the spam list.

291
00:14:27.610 --> 00:14:32.090
I can do the same thing for
BypassedSenderDomains.

292
00:14:35.480 --> 00:14:39.014
And then I could add in itpro.tv.

293
00:14:40.240 --> 00:14:43.380
And then anytime I get an email that
says its from somebody at itpro.tv,

294
00:14:43.380 --> 00:14:45.620
it'll bypass the spam list and
that'll get through.

295
00:14:45.620 --> 00:14:49.820
So that's another great way to
be able to kind of bypass that.

296
00:14:49.820 --> 00:14:51.530
A couple of questions in the chat room.

297
00:14:51.530 --> 00:14:54.919
One was, can we do the same thing on
the mail server, and the answer is yes.

298
00:14:55.920 --> 00:14:58.460
On the mailbox server,
these aren't turned on by default.

299
00:14:58.460 --> 00:14:59.080
Well not all of them.

300
00:14:59.080 --> 00:15:02.090
Some of them are, but most of them aren't
turned on by default because Microsoft

301
00:15:02.090 --> 00:15:03.960
assumes you're doing that at your Edge.

302
00:15:03.960 --> 00:15:05.935
They assume you've got
an Edge transport server or

303
00:15:05.935 --> 00:15:10.410
that you've got some third party system
like a Barracuda virus and spam firewall.

304
00:15:10.410 --> 00:15:11.760
If you've got one of those,

305
00:15:11.760 --> 00:15:14.470
you don't need to do the filtering
here on a mailbox server.

306
00:15:14.470 --> 00:15:17.170
But you can jump over to mailbox server,
do these same commands.

307
00:15:17.170 --> 00:15:20.590
Anything that runs the transport service,
which are mailbox servers and

308
00:15:20.590 --> 00:15:23.280
Edge transport servers,
they can all do that.

309
00:15:23.280 --> 00:15:25.340
So you can configure it there.

310
00:15:25.340 --> 00:15:28.386
The other question in the chat room was
are these Exchange Powershell commands,

311
00:15:28.386 --> 00:15:29.070
and that's yes.

312
00:15:29.070 --> 00:15:31.360
If you just run the regular Powershell
you're not going to have this.

313
00:15:31.360 --> 00:15:33.860
You have to have
the Exchange Powershell modules loaded.

314
00:15:33.860 --> 00:15:36.550
So when you install Exchange,

315
00:15:37.550 --> 00:15:39.860
it actually adds that
Exchange Management Shell right there.

316
00:15:39.860 --> 00:15:40.960
So we need that to be able
to see these commands.

317
00:15:43.787 --> 00:15:47.958
All right so, that was white listing
a server, white listing a user,

318
00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.950
white listing a domain, right?

319
00:15:49.950 --> 00:15:53.710
Couple of different ways to set
that up as bypassed senders, okay?

320
00:15:53.710 --> 00:15:56.380
You can do bypassed recipients also,
it's really the same command.

321
00:15:56.380 --> 00:15:58.261
You just say bypassed recipients, and

322
00:15:58.261 --> 00:16:00.830
now it is based on who is
receiving the email, right?

323
00:16:00.830 --> 00:16:06.113
This is the from field,
recipients will be the to field.

324
00:16:06.113 --> 00:16:06.776
All right, but

325
00:16:06.776 --> 00:16:09.736
otherwise those are the same basic
syntax there to white list those.

326
00:16:09.736 --> 00:16:13.364
Now when you specify all these settings,
you can get them put in place,

327
00:16:13.364 --> 00:16:17.659
you get them loaded up, and now your Edge
transport server is filtering this content

328
00:16:17.659 --> 00:16:20.410
before it ever makes it
inside your network.

329
00:16:20.410 --> 00:16:22.020
It's really kinda that perfect solution.

330
00:16:23.020 --> 00:16:25.800
So this is what we really need
to do to get the server working

331
00:16:25.800 --> 00:16:26.580
the way that we want.

332
00:16:26.580 --> 00:16:27.820
So just be familiar with these.

333
00:16:27.820 --> 00:16:28.950
There's a lot of different commands, and

334
00:16:28.950 --> 00:16:31.410
I'll put all the commands in the show
notes so you guys can have them.

335
00:16:31.410 --> 00:16:33.940
But there's a lot of different
commands that are out there.

336
00:16:33.940 --> 00:16:36.930
You kinda have to pick and choose what's
right for your environment to get it set

337
00:16:36.930 --> 00:16:40.150
up the way that you want and
get it configured properly.

338
00:16:40.150 --> 00:16:43.070
Now, let's talk about something
that I haven't mentioned so far.

339
00:16:43.070 --> 00:16:47.330
When you have an Edge transport server,
it's suppose to be the entry point to get

340
00:16:47.330 --> 00:16:50.640
into your network and it can be the exit
point also if you want it to be.

341
00:16:50.640 --> 00:16:53.440
But it's the one that's
exposed to the internet.

342
00:16:53.440 --> 00:16:56.710
So, when somebodies sending an email
in your organization it passes through

343
00:16:56.710 --> 00:16:58.690
the Edge transport server first and
then it goes inside.

344
00:16:58.690 --> 00:17:02.190
And that's why the Edge transport server
is suck a great place to put these rules.

345
00:17:02.190 --> 00:17:06.522
Cuz you might have 50 mailbox servers, but
you've got this one Edge transport server,

346
00:17:06.522 --> 00:17:09.668
this one point of entry,
where you can filter people's access.

347
00:17:09.668 --> 00:17:14.530
So that really works out well,
unless the Edge transport server fails.

348
00:17:14.530 --> 00:17:16.600
What happens if the Edge
transport server fails?

349
00:17:16.600 --> 00:17:19.710
Now email can't get in or
out of your organization right?

350
00:17:19.710 --> 00:17:22.930
So we need high availability for
Edge transport servers.

351
00:17:22.930 --> 00:17:26.700
Well fortunately, Edge transport
servers don't really store any data.

352
00:17:26.700 --> 00:17:30.230
So there's not much to back up or
replicate or whatever.

353
00:17:30.230 --> 00:17:34.136
If we want more Edge transport servers, we
just install more Edge transport servers.

354
00:17:34.136 --> 00:17:36.249
You install a second or
a third or a fourth and

355
00:17:36.249 --> 00:17:39.117
you set up Edge subscriptions for
each one of them, right?

356
00:17:39.117 --> 00:17:42.658
You do Egge subscriptions, they do their
own Edge sync and they're up and running.

357
00:17:42.658 --> 00:17:43.780
All right so that's no big deal.

358
00:17:43.780 --> 00:17:46.670
Redundancy on Edge transport
server is super easy.

359
00:17:46.670 --> 00:17:49.950
All we have to do to make it redundant for
the internet, is to go in and

360
00:17:49.950 --> 00:17:53.580
modify our MX records,
our mail exchange records in DNS.

361
00:17:53.580 --> 00:17:56.250
Our MX records should point to all
of our Edge transport servers.

362
00:17:56.250 --> 00:17:59.560
And you can set priorities to change
which one gets used by default, but

363
00:17:59.560 --> 00:18:01.600
if one fails,
people just move on to the next one.

364
00:18:01.600 --> 00:18:03.750
Super easy to do redundancy there.

365
00:18:03.750 --> 00:18:07.130
Where the challenge is comes
in these rules, right.

366
00:18:07.130 --> 00:18:11.390
The configuration for the most part is
being pushed from the mailbox server

367
00:18:11.390 --> 00:18:14.360
to the Edge Transport server
as part of Edge subscriptions.

368
00:18:14.360 --> 00:18:16.550
But these rules aren't.

369
00:18:16.550 --> 00:18:19.520
I'm configuring these rules right
here on my Edge Transport server.

370
00:18:19.520 --> 00:18:23.711
So if I have five Edge transport servers,
I just configured one of them.

371
00:18:23.711 --> 00:18:27.332
I've now got to go and do the same thing
over again on each of the other four edge

372
00:18:27.332 --> 00:18:30.040
transport servers and
that's kind of a pain.

373
00:18:30.040 --> 00:18:32.330
First off,
it's a pain just that I have to do it.

374
00:18:32.330 --> 00:18:35.810
Secondly, it's a pain because, you guys
saw it I made some typos doing this.

375
00:18:35.810 --> 00:18:37.780
Well, imagine if I had to
do it four more times.

376
00:18:37.780 --> 00:18:40.130
I'm gonna get really frustrated
cuz I suck at typing, right?

377
00:18:40.130 --> 00:18:44.320
So we don't want that, well fortunately
Microsoft made it pretty easy

378
00:18:44.320 --> 00:18:48.870
to clone the configuration of one
Edge transport server on your others.

379
00:18:48.870 --> 00:18:52.840
We can actually export this configuration
which will include the rules.

380
00:18:52.840 --> 00:18:55.974
And we can import that on our
other Edge transport servers and

381
00:18:55.974 --> 00:18:58.310
they'll have the same rules.

382
00:18:58.310 --> 00:19:02.446
It's just cloning the config of an Edge
transport server and it's super easy.

383
00:19:02.446 --> 00:19:03.464
I say it's super easy.

384
00:19:03.464 --> 00:19:05.002
It's super easy if you
remember the commands,

385
00:19:05.002 --> 00:19:06.655
we gotta type of a few commands out here.

386
00:19:06.655 --> 00:19:10.160
Microsoft's actually created a few
scripts for us that help us to do this.

387
00:19:10.160 --> 00:19:12.110
Let me show you how it works.

388
00:19:12.110 --> 00:19:14.340
I'm going to start here on my Edge
transport server that we just setup.

389
00:19:14.340 --> 00:19:16.390
So let's say this one is now setup,
it's It's perfect,

390
00:19:16.390 --> 00:19:18.640
it's got everything the way I want it.

391
00:19:18.640 --> 00:19:21.660
So I want to export its configuration.

392
00:19:21.660 --> 00:19:25.060
Well,there's a script buried away
in the Exchange install directory.

393
00:19:25.060 --> 00:19:28.590
So I need to get into the Exchange
install directory which is

394
00:19:28.590 --> 00:19:38.100
c:/programfiles/microsoft/exchangeserver/-
version15/scripts.

395
00:19:38.100 --> 00:19:41.310
That nice long path there rolls,
right off the tongue.

396
00:19:41.310 --> 00:19:44.553
There's a ton of scripts in here,
if you pull up the directory,

397
00:19:44.553 --> 00:19:46.543
that do all sorts of different things.

398
00:19:46.543 --> 00:19:50.084
Look at all these PS1 files
that are rolling by, or PSD1s.

399
00:19:50.084 --> 00:19:52.560
There's a ton of stuff that
can do all sorts of things.

400
00:19:52.560 --> 00:19:56.990
All right, well what I want is I wanna
be able to export my configuration.

401
00:19:56.990 --> 00:19:59.990
And so
there is a export edge config script.

402
00:19:59.990 --> 00:20:04.547
If I were to scroll around in here
it would turn up somewhere in here.

403
00:20:04.547 --> 00:20:07.703
Export, there it is, ExportEdgeConfig.ps1.

404
00:20:07.703 --> 00:20:08.850
That's the script I want.

405
00:20:08.850 --> 00:20:11.620
It's gonna let me export this config so
I can then turn around and

406
00:20:11.620 --> 00:20:13.059
import it on other servers.

407
00:20:14.190 --> 00:20:15.950
So I'm gonna run that script.

408
00:20:17.100 --> 00:20:21.520
I'm gonna call it, by saying .\ because
