you have to reference the folder name,

409
00:20:21.520 --> 00:20:22.970
cuz this folder is not in the path.

410
00:20:22.970 --> 00:20:25.182
PowerShell's really particular about that.

411
00:20:25.182 --> 00:20:30.308
And I'm gonna call
ExportEdgeConfig.ps1 and

412
00:20:30.308 --> 00:20:35.062
then I'm gonna tell it to CloneConfigData.

413
00:20:35.062 --> 00:20:36.780
And then I need to tell
it where to clone it to.

414
00:20:36.780 --> 00:20:41.482
And I'll just put it in c:\EdgeConfig.xml.

415
00:20:41.482 --> 00:20:42.760
It is an xml file.

416
00:20:42.760 --> 00:20:44.346
You can give it whatever
extension you want,

417
00:20:44.346 --> 00:20:46.620
but at the end of the day it is
an xml file that it's gonna create.

418
00:20:46.620 --> 00:20:51.411
And so this is gonna dump that
configuration into C:\EdgeConfig.xml.

419
00:20:51.411 --> 00:20:53.360
Okay, so I'm gonna run that.

420
00:20:53.360 --> 00:20:56.440
And it's now dumping that configuration,
including all the rules and

421
00:20:56.440 --> 00:20:57.880
other things into that file.

422
00:20:57.880 --> 00:20:59.560
All right, so there we go.

423
00:20:59.560 --> 00:21:01.620
It told me it's done.

424
00:21:01.620 --> 00:21:03.780
And if I use Notepad,
I can actually look at it.

425
00:21:05.130 --> 00:21:05.910
And I can fire it up.

426
00:21:05.910 --> 00:21:08.989
And here it is.
We can kinda browse in here, and

427
00:21:08.989 --> 00:21:11.267
see what that looks like.

428
00:21:11.267 --> 00:21:13.947
Let me make this font a little bit
bigger so we can kinda read it,

429
00:21:13.947 --> 00:21:16.985
Notepad is not necessarily the greatest
for increasing font size, but

430
00:21:16.985 --> 00:21:19.390
we'll give it a shot, there we go.

431
00:21:19.390 --> 00:21:22.120
Alright so looking at a lot of this
is just information about like

432
00:21:22.120 --> 00:21:25.770
directory sizes you know quotas and
things that are set on stuff.

433
00:21:25.770 --> 00:21:28.620
But there's some important
things in here as we look down

434
00:21:28.620 --> 00:21:31.200
as far as our basic
configuration is concerned.

435
00:21:31.200 --> 00:21:34.940
And so as you scroll eventually in here,
we'll start to find things like

436
00:21:34.940 --> 00:21:38.420
what our whitelists are,
what our content filters are, and so on.

437
00:21:38.420 --> 00:21:40.760
And this is a pretty big file.

438
00:21:40.760 --> 00:21:41.850
If I scroll through here,

439
00:21:41.850 --> 00:21:45.070
you'll see there is a lot of
information tucked away in here.

440
00:21:45.070 --> 00:21:48.070
And this is the full configuration
of our Edge transport server.

441
00:21:48.070 --> 00:21:50.010
There's a lot in here.

442
00:21:50.010 --> 00:21:53.260
Here I'm in some of, like,
attachment filter entries, right?

443
00:21:53.260 --> 00:21:54.460
And so we can see some of the filters.

444
00:21:54.460 --> 00:21:58.150
Like here it's filtering out basic
files and batch files and so on.

445
00:21:58.150 --> 00:22:01.470
I think we added those in another show,
so that's why they're turning up here.

446
00:22:01.470 --> 00:22:04.629
But each of the configs will
be located in here somewhere.

447
00:22:05.960 --> 00:22:09.290
So, I can take this and import it on
another system and I'll be in business.

448
00:22:09.290 --> 00:22:11.432
Except there's a little gotcha.

449
00:22:11.432 --> 00:22:16.500
When it exports to config,
it's the true config for this server.

450
00:22:16.500 --> 00:22:19.350
And so there's information
in here that is not unique.

451
00:22:19.350 --> 00:22:20.960
For example, right here.

452
00:22:20.960 --> 00:22:26.240
The distinguish name of
the server is LAB-EDGE01.

453
00:22:26.240 --> 00:22:28.580
If I'm gonna import this
config on another server,

454
00:22:28.580 --> 00:22:30.645
is that server gonna be called LAB-EDGE01?

455
00:22:30.645 --> 00:22:32.850
No, it's gonna have a different name.

456
00:22:32.850 --> 00:22:37.890
So, before I can use this file,
I need to make it a little more generic.

457
00:22:37.890 --> 00:22:40.560
I need to strip out the private stuff.

458
00:22:40.560 --> 00:22:44.220
And the way we do that is not by
actually stripping it out, but

459
00:22:44.220 --> 00:22:46.720
by creating an answer file.

460
00:22:46.720 --> 00:22:51.760
An answer file takes this file,
locates the stuff

461
00:22:51.760 --> 00:22:56.450
that should be unique and it creates an
answer file that overrides those values.

462
00:22:56.450 --> 00:22:59.180
We need to override that distinguish name.

463
00:22:59.180 --> 00:23:03.455
We need to override any entry in here that
refers to the IP address of this server.

464
00:23:03.455 --> 00:23:05.900
And fortunately we've got
a script that can do that too.

465
00:23:07.070 --> 00:23:09.660
So what we would do from here
is we would take this file,

466
00:23:09.660 --> 00:23:13.210
this EdgeConfig.xml that we've just made.

467
00:23:13.210 --> 00:23:16.790
We would copy that to a USB key or
whatever and take it to our other Edge

468
00:23:16.790 --> 00:23:21.920
servers, and on the other Edge servers,
step one you'll generate an answer file.

469
00:23:21.920 --> 00:23:23.350
Cuz the answer file is
gonna be different for

470
00:23:23.350 --> 00:23:26.230
each Edge server it's gonna be
a different name, different IP address.

471
00:23:26.230 --> 00:23:31.380
And then two, we import the config
with our newly created answer file.

472
00:23:31.380 --> 00:23:32.760
So let me show you how to
create an answer file.

473
00:23:32.760 --> 00:23:34.550
I'm just gonna do it
here in the same server,

474
00:23:34.550 --> 00:23:37.361
but it doesn't matter it will be the same
on any server that we ran it on.

475
00:23:38.540 --> 00:23:40.880
So it's a script, I'll need to get
in the script directory first,

476
00:23:40.880 --> 00:23:42.690
which is this where I already am.

477
00:23:42.690 --> 00:23:47.050
And then from here I'm gonna call
the script ImportEdgeConfig.

478
00:23:47.050 --> 00:23:50.920
So I did ExportEdgeConfig to get it out,
import is what's gonna bring it in.

479
00:23:50.920 --> 00:23:53.210
Now I'm not actually importing here.

480
00:23:53.210 --> 00:23:54.630
I'm creating an answer file.

481
00:23:54.630 --> 00:23:57.250
So I'm gonna tell it in a minute
that this is not a true import.

482
00:23:57.250 --> 00:23:59.340
So I'm gonna start just by
calling this script though.

483
00:23:59.340 --> 00:24:02.890
ImportEdgeConfig.ps1.

484
00:24:02.890 --> 00:24:07.212
I'm gonna tell it where
I'm getting my data from.

485
00:24:07.212 --> 00:24:13.560
So -CloneConfigData: and
then I'll point to where I put the file.

486
00:24:14.990 --> 00:24:16.950
So, so far it's kinda the same
as the other command.

487
00:24:16.950 --> 00:24:17.580
Right?

488
00:24:17.580 --> 00:24:19.190
But here's where things
get a little different.

489
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:23.757
I need to add -IsImport $false.

490
00:24:23.757 --> 00:24:25.220
All right.

491
00:24:25.220 --> 00:24:28.530
That's what's gonna let the script know,
don't import this config yet.

492
00:24:28.530 --> 00:24:29.870
Run in your other mode.

493
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:32.230
The only other mode is to
generate an answer file.

494
00:24:32.230 --> 00:24:36.761
So by doing IsImport $false,
tells it to create an answer file.

495
00:24:38.220 --> 00:24:43.630
And then I can say CloneConfigAnswer: and

496
00:24:43.630 --> 00:24:45.380
tell it where I want
the answer file to be.

497
00:24:45.380 --> 00:24:48.884
And I'll just make this one C:/answer.xml.

498
00:24:48.884 --> 00:24:50.130
All right.

499
00:24:50.130 --> 00:24:52.390
So now it's gonna run.

500
00:24:52.390 --> 00:24:55.420
It's not going to import the config,

501
00:24:55.420 --> 00:25:00.785
it's gonna locate any unique values, and
create an answer file overriding them.

502
00:25:00.785 --> 00:25:03.110
Overriding anywhere
the computer name is used,

503
00:25:03.110 --> 00:25:07.050
anywhere the IP address is used,
anywhere the private encryption key.

504
00:25:07.050 --> 00:25:08.150
See how it's got this here,

505
00:25:08.150 --> 00:25:11.610
passwords will be encrypted with the
default script encryption key and so on?

506
00:25:11.610 --> 00:25:14.730
Basically, we have an Edge subscription
here that's different from the Edge

507
00:25:14.730 --> 00:25:17.380
subscription from the other server,
and so we've got different keys,

508
00:25:17.380 --> 00:25:21.980
we've got different information, and so
it's basically overriding that, okay.

509
00:25:21.980 --> 00:25:23.110
And then once that's done,

510
00:25:23.110 --> 00:25:25.840
it creates an answer file that
has everything that's different.

511
00:25:25.840 --> 00:25:29.220
Now, my answer file is gonna be the least
entertaining of any answer file.

512
00:25:29.220 --> 00:25:30.925
Cuz I ran it on the same server, right?

513
00:25:30.925 --> 00:25:32.980
So what's not gonna match?

514
00:25:32.980 --> 00:25:36.430
Nothing, everything's gonna match here,
so it doesn't have to override anything.

515
00:25:36.430 --> 00:25:40.190
But on a different server it has to
override name, IP, security key,

516
00:25:40.190 --> 00:25:41.660
it has to override a lot of stuff.

517
00:25:41.660 --> 00:25:45.645
So when you look at the answer
file that created, so for me,

518
00:25:45.645 --> 00:25:50.950
C:/answer.xml, it'll have this
machine specific settings.

519
00:25:50.950 --> 00:25:55.400
And in between these two tags,
it'll have all the overridden values.

520
00:25:55.400 --> 00:25:57.820
Everything that should be
unique will be overridden,

521
00:25:57.820 --> 00:26:01.120
and it'll update it to reflect
the server that you're on.

522
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:04.010
So it populates it out
exactly as you need it.

523
00:26:04.010 --> 00:26:09.210
And at that stage, now you can just import
it and it'll have everything you need.

524
00:26:09.210 --> 00:26:13.082
You can just hit your up arrow
to bring that command back and

525
00:26:13.082 --> 00:26:18.640
where you've got IsImport $false,
you change that to IsImport $true, right?

526
00:26:18.640 --> 00:26:21.360
Now it knows that you wanna do the import,
and

527
00:26:21.360 --> 00:26:25.200
this is the answer file that it's
going to read instead of writing.

528
00:26:25.200 --> 00:26:27.070
And now it's gonna import the config and

529
00:26:27.070 --> 00:26:31.620
get us all set up the way that we want
it to be, and we'll be in business.

530
00:26:31.620 --> 00:26:35.940
So if I get all the rules set
up perfectly on one server,

531
00:26:35.940 --> 00:26:39.070
I run the ExportEdgeConfig
script to dump its config.

532
00:26:39.070 --> 00:26:41.630
I copy the config to all my other servers.

533
00:26:41.630 --> 00:26:45.100
I do the import as a false to
generate the answer file and

534
00:26:45.100 --> 00:26:46.705
then I do the import as a true.

535
00:26:46.705 --> 00:26:48.810
And I've even seen people where,

536
00:26:48.810 --> 00:26:51.990
if you make a lot of changes to your
servers, where they automate this.

537
00:26:51.990 --> 00:26:55.590
Where they say, every night at midnight,
dump the configs

538
00:26:55.590 --> 00:26:57.720
copy into the other servers and
have the other servers import them.

539
00:26:57.720 --> 00:26:59.540
You can automate them through
PowerShell scripts and

540
00:26:59.540 --> 00:27:01.760
the task scheduler, if you want.

541
00:27:01.760 --> 00:27:03.770
But even running it
manually is not a big deal,

542
00:27:03.770 --> 00:27:06.150
if you don't make a lot of
changes on your Edge servers.

543
00:27:06.150 --> 00:27:10.270
So, here we run through that process,
we get loaded up, and you're in business.

544
00:27:10.270 --> 00:27:13.790
So this is the real power of the Edge
servers, is that we can configure

545
00:27:13.790 --> 00:27:17.910
very specific rules that dictate what
email's allowed through and what isn't.

546
00:27:17.910 --> 00:27:21.460
We can do whitelist, blacklist,
content filters, all that crazy stuff, and

547
00:27:21.460 --> 00:27:25.508
it happens before the email gets
inside of our organization.

548
00:27:25.508 --> 00:27:29.810
And then second, we can easily clone
it across more than one Edge server,

549
00:27:29.810 --> 00:27:32.730
which makes redundancy and
backups super easy.

550
00:27:32.730 --> 00:27:33.680
We don't need clusters.

551
00:27:33.680 --> 00:27:35.140
We don't need shared storage.

552
00:27:35.140 --> 00:27:38.549
We just clone this simple config cross
the systems and you're in business.

553
00:27:38.549 --> 00:27:41.050
And even in terms of doing
backups of the server,

554
00:27:41.050 --> 00:27:44.291
we don't really need to backup
an Edge Transport server do we?

555
00:27:44.291 --> 00:27:47.580
If we have that Edge config file,
that config export,

556
00:27:47.580 --> 00:27:52.081
because we can build up an all new server
and just import that config file and

557
00:27:52.081 --> 00:27:53.880
now it's back the way it was.

558
00:27:53.880 --> 00:27:57.200
You'll have to setup the Edge subscription
again, you've always gotta do that but

559
00:27:57.200 --> 00:27:59.200
otherwise we can import that file and
you're back in business.

560
00:27:59.200 --> 00:28:02.660
So instead of backing up the server you
just copy that XML file to a USB key

561
00:28:02.660 --> 00:28:03.880
and you're done.

562
00:28:03.880 --> 00:28:06.200
And if you don't change it for six months,
you don't need to back it up for

563
00:28:06.200 --> 00:28:08.775
six months cuz the key has
everything that you need.

564
00:28:08.775 --> 00:28:12.550
Edge Transport servers don't really hold
any sensitive data other than the rule

565
00:28:12.550 --> 00:28:13.395
configuration.

566
00:28:13.395 --> 00:28:14.520
So pretty easy to get that.

567
00:28:15.940 --> 00:28:18.828
All right, well that's about all
I've got on Edge Transport servers.

568
00:28:18.828 --> 00:28:20.940
So this is a pretty good
spot to wrap this one up.

569
00:28:20.940 --> 00:28:24.900
In this episode we got a chance to see
configuring various rule types and

570
00:28:24.900 --> 00:28:26.240
a few real world examples there.

571
00:28:26.240 --> 00:28:28.980
And then we wrapped up talking
about how to export those rules and

572
00:28:28.980 --> 00:28:32.500
import them on our other Edge
transport servers for redundancy.

573
00:28:32.500 --> 00:28:36.600
And, on that note, that's about all I've
got to say on Edge transport servers, so

574
00:28:36.600 --> 00:28:37.440
we're gonna wrap it up here.

575
00:28:37.440 --> 00:28:41.529
I hope you guys enjoyed it,
signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

576
00:28:41.529 --> 00:28:42.877
And I'll see you next time.

577
00:28:42.877 --> 00:28:49.260
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses some of the different methods available for monitoring replication health in Exchange 2013. He begins by demonstrating how to use the PowerShell to query Database Copy status and Database Availability Group health. He then demonstrates using several counters in the Windows Performance Monitor to record performance trends over longer periods of time.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintenance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.226 --> 00:00:10.548
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.548 --> 00:00:11.320
All right.

3
00:00:11.320 --> 00:00:13.100
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

4
00:00:13.100 --> 00:00:15.457
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.457 --> 00:00:19.820
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again with
another episode of Microsoft Exchange.

6
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:22.880
And in this episode, we're gonna be
looking at some pretty important stuff.

7
00:00:22.880 --> 00:00:27.610
Because it's all about monitoring and
maintaining our exchange environment.

8
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:31.190
Now when we get Exchange all configured,
and put into place, and everything's

9
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:35.170
working the way we want, that's great,
but things rarely stay that way.

10
00:00:35.170 --> 00:00:38.550
You guys know as well as I do
that the longer a server runs,

11
00:00:38.550 --> 00:00:40.840
the more likely issues are going to arise.

12
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:45.150
And we need to know how to be able
to spot that problems are there and

13
00:00:45.150 --> 00:00:48.130
then to try and isolate the areas where
the problems are originating from.

14
00:00:48.130 --> 00:00:51.100
So we can kind of keep our service up and
running and healthy.

15
00:00:51.100 --> 00:00:52.550
So that's what we wanna
tackle in this episode,

16
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:55.320
some of the different things to look out
for, some of the different tools that

17
00:00:55.320 --> 00:00:59.630
are available for us and which tools are
appropriate for which needs, all right.

18
00:00:59.630 --> 00:01:02.760
Now, obviously monitoring our exchange
environment is a pretty big topic.

19
00:01:02.760 --> 00:01:04.690
There's a lot of different
things to monitor.

20
00:01:04.690 --> 00:01:08.590
And I've kind of shown you some of those
throughout this series as we've gone along

21
00:01:08.590 --> 00:01:13.150
but, just in general, let's say this
is your first day at a brand new job.

22
00:01:13.150 --> 00:01:16.570
You've got this exchange environment
you've never touched before and

23
00:01:16.570 --> 00:01:20.000
you just wanna look at it and get
an idea of whether it's healthy or not.

24
00:01:20.000 --> 00:01:21.150
All right.
Well,

25
00:01:21.150 --> 00:01:23.810
let me walk you through some of the
different things that I like to look at

26
00:01:23.810 --> 00:01:27.120
just for my own self when I go work
on these types of environments.

27
00:01:27.120 --> 00:01:30.380
One of the first places I
like to start is replication.

28
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:30.900
All right.

29
00:01:30.900 --> 00:01:33.910
Most people who deploy
exchange in this day in age

30
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:35.140
are gonna worry about redundancy.

31
00:01:35.140 --> 00:01:36.950
They're gonna worry about availability.

32
00:01:36.950 --> 00:01:40.256
If you're really worried about problems on
your network, you need to have a plan B.

33
00:01:40.256 --> 00:01:41.115
Right?

34
00:01:41.115 --> 00:01:45.920
And there's no better plan B than
replicated server stored somewhere else.

35
00:01:45.920 --> 00:01:49.500
Now for client access servers we don't
really have to worry about it so much,

36
00:01:49.500 --> 00:01:50.840
right, because on a client access server,

37
00:01:50.840 --> 00:01:53.730
if I want redundancy I just bring
up another client access server.

38
00:01:53.730 --> 00:01:55.560
There's no real data stored in them.

39
00:01:55.560 --> 00:01:56.290
That's easy, right.

40
00:01:56.290 --> 00:01:58.680
There's nothing really to deal with there.

41
00:01:58.680 --> 00:02:01.740
But on the mailbox side it's
a lot more challenging.

42
00:02:01.740 --> 00:02:04.690
And we saw that back in the database
availability groups episodes,

43
00:02:04.690 --> 00:02:08.160
if you haven't see those yet,
just definitely jump over and watch those.

44
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:10.960
But with a database availability group,

45
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:13.810
exchange is basically
setting up a cluster,

46
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:19.110
a cluster without shared storage which
means that whole mailbox database

47
00:02:19.110 --> 00:02:23.320
has to be replicated across the network
to whoever else is in that cluster.

48
00:02:23.320 --> 00:02:26.820
And when you set that up initially,
things might go great.

49
00:02:26.820 --> 00:02:29.850
But then over time,
network conditions might change or

50
00:02:29.850 --> 00:02:33.840
server conditions might change, and that
replication might not be working properly.

51
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:35.110
And if that's the case,

52
00:02:35.110 --> 00:02:38.910
you might have a fully redundant
environment that's way out of date.

53
00:02:38.910 --> 00:02:42.660
And the data that you're replicating is
just not making it to the other side, and

54
00:02:42.660 --> 00:02:46.520
now when a failure occurs, that
redundant copy doesn't help you, right?

55
00:02:46.520 --> 00:02:50.440
Or even worse,
maybe the redundant copy is down, and

56
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:53.290
you don't know it,
because the main copy is up and running.

57
00:02:53.290 --> 00:02:56.225
If the main database is up and running,
your end users are in their email,

58
00:02:56.225 --> 00:03:00.610
everything's happy, mail is flowing,
you might not realize that meanwhile,

59
00:03:00.610 --> 00:03:04.460
on the back end, a secondary copy of
that database is actually off line.

60
00:03:04.460 --> 00:03:06.950
So it's important that we monitor that and
we keep an eye on it, and

61
00:03:06.950 --> 00:03:09.230
there's a few different ways to do that.

62
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:11.700
Now I know we can go through
the exchange administration center.

63
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:12.660
The webpage.

64
00:03:12.660 --> 00:03:13.630
We can browse in there.

65
00:03:13.630 --> 00:03:15.900
We get some basic status information.

66
00:03:15.900 --> 00:03:18.945
But the really good data
is found in the PowerShell.

67
00:03:18.945 --> 00:03:22.685
There's a ton of PowerShell commandlets
that we can use to look at performance on

68
00:03:22.685 --> 00:03:27.035
our server, as well as just
doing various health tests, and

69
00:03:27.035 --> 00:03:29.855
there's the good old trusty
performance monitor.

70
00:03:29.855 --> 00:03:34.545
The performance monitor gives us a ton of
data about all the aspects of our system

71
00:03:34.545 --> 00:03:35.685
and so we can use those too.

72
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:39.810
So let's say this is me sitting down
on a server for the first time and

73
00:03:39.810 --> 00:03:42.780
I wanna make sure that
replication is running smooth.

74
00:03:42.780 --> 00:03:44.410
Let's walk through the paces.

75
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:45.990
Let me start here with the GUI.

76
00:03:45.990 --> 00:03:49.810
In the GUI, we can quickly just
jump right down to servers.

77
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:53.630
And then under servers, you can take
a look at a few different places.

78
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:55.730
We've got our servers right here,
they kind of show up,

79
00:03:55.730 --> 00:03:57.500
obviously your server
should be in the list.

80
00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:01.377
If we go to databases you should be able
to find your database like I've got this

81
00:04:01.377 --> 00:04:04.807
one here, sales DB and it shows us
having multiples copies, right.

82
00:04:04.807 --> 00:04:09.260
So this database is present on two
different servers lab mailbox 01 and

83
00:04:09.260 --> 00:04:12.109
lab castle 1, so
it should be in both places.

84
00:04:12.109 --> 00:04:16.958
And over here on the right side if I
scroll down I'll see some basic health

85
00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.380
information.

86
00:04:18.380 --> 00:04:21.030
Now the health information isn't
really all that great, right.

87
00:04:21.030 --> 00:04:24.840
I mean it's showing me that it's active
and mounted here, it's passive and

88
00:04:24.840 --> 00:04:26.560
healthy down here, right?

89
00:04:26.560 --> 00:04:27.780
So those are good.

90
00:04:27.780 --> 00:04:30.530
What I really need to look for
is this guy right here.

91
00:04:30.530 --> 00:04:31.910
Copy queue length.

92
00:04:31.910 --> 00:04:32.510
Okay?

93
00:04:32.510 --> 00:04:34.300
Now what is the copy queue length?

94
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:36.320
Well, when a change happens, right,

95
00:04:36.320 --> 00:04:39.630
when email comes in it's writing
to whoever's active and mounted.

96
00:04:39.630 --> 00:04:42.160
So in my case it's writing to mailbox01.

97
00:04:42.160 --> 00:04:44.490
And then once that's done,

98
00:04:44.490 --> 00:04:48.410
the transaction log that contains that
rite is shipped over to the other server.

99
00:04:48.410 --> 00:04:50.110
Well, that's the copy queue.

100
00:04:50.110 --> 00:04:53.560
And the more transaction
logs in the copy queue,

101
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:57.040
the further behind I am,
the busier your server is.

102
00:04:57.040 --> 00:05:00.960
A single transaction log file might
only have a few seconds worth of email.

103
00:05:00.960 --> 00:05:05.230
If you have a really slow email flow,
right, if you don't get a ton of email,

104
00:05:05.230 --> 00:05:07.820
one transaction log file might
have an hour's worth of emails, so

105
00:05:07.820 --> 00:05:11.620
it kind of varies how much is actually
in that transaction log file.

106
00:05:11.620 --> 00:05:13.380
But down here, this copy queue link.

107
00:05:13.380 --> 00:05:18.150
If you see it greater than zero for long
periods of time, it could mean that you

108
00:05:18.150 --> 00:05:21.650
don't have enough bandwidth between
your two servers to properly replicate.

109
00:05:21.650 --> 00:05:24.960
Or at a minimum it means you
need to be acceptant of the fact

110
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:27.130
that if you have a failure,
you might lose some data.

111
00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:29.850
There might be some data that just hadn't
had time to copy to the other side.

112
00:05:30.920 --> 00:05:34.920
Now I do have a little
complaint about this screen.

113
00:05:34.920 --> 00:05:38.640
And the complaint I have is when
I see copy queue length here,

114
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:40.960
this is a really generic thing.

115
00:05:40.960 --> 00:05:44.490
It's telling me I've have some
changes on the active server,

116
00:05:44.490 --> 00:05:46.380
they're waiting to be
sent to the other side.

117
00:05:46.380 --> 00:05:47.260
Okay.

118
00:05:47.260 --> 00:05:50.760
But they could actually already
be sent to the other side.

119
00:05:50.760 --> 00:05:52.410
They could already be
on the other side and

120
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:56.230
the other side just hasn't had time to
apply it to it's copy of the database.

121
00:05:56.230 --> 00:05:59.390
There might be some kind of problem
on the server on the other end.

122
00:05:59.390 --> 00:06:00.970
And this isn't gonna tell me that.

123
00:06:00.970 --> 00:06:02.970
If I see this number getting bigger and
bigger and

124
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:06.830
bigger, I know there's a problem, but
I don't really know what the problem is.

125
00:06:06.830 --> 00:06:08.280
It could be network connectivity.

126
00:06:08.280 --> 00:06:10.280
I can't even get to the other side.

127
00:06:10.280 --> 00:06:14.480
Or the server on the other side might
be under powered and it's just getting

128
00:06:14.480 --> 00:06:17.475
overwhelmed and it cannot keep up and
it is getting further and further behind.

129
00:06:17.475 --> 00:06:21.130
That's not a network issue at all,
that's CPU, disk IO.

130
00:06:21.130 --> 00:06:23.349
Right?
Things like that on that other server.

131
00:06:23.349 --> 00:06:26.718
So I do not get a whole heck of a lot of
data here and I will show you a way to get

132
00:06:26.718 --> 00:06:29.943
something more specific out of
the performance monitor in a moment.

133
00:06:29.943 --> 00:06:31.770
Now what you are seeing here.

134
00:06:31.770 --> 00:06:34.810
This is part of the diagnostic
health service and exchange.

135
00:06:34.810 --> 00:06:35.770
It's running in the background.

136
00:06:35.770 --> 00:06:38.410
It has a series of what iare
called probes that run and

137
00:06:38.410 --> 00:06:41.210
monitor all sorts of aspects
of your Exchange environment.

138
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:45.270
And so it's actively monitoring this
information and displaying it here.

139
00:06:45.270 --> 00:06:47.640
And that's why we have
things like view details.

140
00:06:47.640 --> 00:06:51.583
Because we can jump into that to see
additional information that's being

141
00:06:51.583 --> 00:06:53.090
monitored on the back end.

142
00:06:53.090 --> 00:06:55.940
And right here,
I can see the copy queue length and

143
00:06:55.940 --> 00:06:59.300
the replay queue length, all right,
the replay queue length.

144
00:06:59.300 --> 00:07:03.250
That says, this is data that has already
been copied to the other side, but

145
00:07:03.250 --> 00:07:06.590
it hasn't been applied yet,
it's waiting to be replayed.

146
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:08.420
And if we see those at zero like I've got,

147
00:07:08.420 --> 00:07:11.120
that means my two servers
are completely in sync.

148
00:07:11.120 --> 00:07:13.770
But if I see the number consistently
getting larger, and larger, and

149
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:17.270
larger that means the other
server is getting behind.

150
00:07:17.270 --> 00:07:20.440
And you can see a lot of other information
in here on the health of your system.

151
00:07:21.440 --> 00:07:24.160
Now if you have access to the GUI,
this is great.

152
00:07:24.160 --> 00:07:28.800
If you don't have access to the GUI well,
there's a few other ways we can get at it.

153
00:07:28.800 --> 00:07:31.562
And I like to use the PowerShell on this
because there's actually a really simple

154
00:07:31.562 --> 00:07:35.100
PowerShell command we can run that
will scan the health of the system.

155
00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:37.670
If we jump over to here,

156
00:07:37.670 --> 00:07:39.720
my other server that's got
the PowerShell already fired up.

157
00:07:39.720 --> 00:07:43.960
Now this is the Exchange Management Shell,
not just the normal PowerShell.

158
00:07:43.960 --> 00:07:49.340
There's a command, or a command lit,
called test Replication health.

159
00:07:49.340 --> 00:07:49.910
All right.

160
00:07:49.910 --> 00:07:53.851
The test replication health command that
lets you scan across all the replications

161
00:07:53.851 --> 00:07:56.728
on your system and
show you whether they're healthy or not.

162
00:07:56.728 --> 00:08:00.250
And it's pretty straightforward to run,
you just point it at a server.

163
00:08:00.250 --> 00:08:02.805
So I'll specify an identity and
I'll point this out loud.

164
00:08:02.805 --> 00:08:03.752
Castle one.

165
00:08:03.752 --> 00:08:04.930
Here, I'll do mailbox.

166
00:08:04.930 --> 00:08:06.510
Mailbox 01.

167
00:08:06.510 --> 00:08:07.180
All right.

168
00:08:07.180 --> 00:08:09.130
So it's going to check that server and

169
00:08:09.130 --> 00:08:10.690
give me information
about replication on it.

170
00:08:10.690 --> 00:08:12.490
And it's gonna lay it out right here.

171
00:08:12.490 --> 00:08:15.850
Notice how it's checking a lot more
than just the current que lane.

172
00:08:15.850 --> 00:08:18.960
Well those probes that are running in
the background are checking all this

173
00:08:18.960 --> 00:08:20.020
stuff already.

174
00:08:20.020 --> 00:08:24.330
It's just the GUI for
the Exchange Administration Center.

175
00:08:24.330 --> 00:08:26.080
It doesn't display all this.

176
00:08:26.080 --> 00:08:28.040
So from the commandlet here,
from the PowerShell,

177
00:08:28.040 --> 00:08:31.310
we can see it, the cluster service,
the replay service.

178
00:08:31.310 --> 00:08:35.240
So all these different services
that are a part of this database

179
00:08:35.240 --> 00:08:38.470
availability group structure,
they're all passing, they're all healthy.

180
00:08:38.470 --> 00:08:41.350
If one of them isn't, I'll have
an error here, and it'll tell me why.

181
00:08:41.350 --> 00:08:43.960
Maybe the service isn't started,
maybe there's access denied,

182
00:08:43.960 --> 00:08:45.680
maybe it's network unreachable.

183
00:08:45.680 --> 00:08:47.960
It'll tell me what that reason is.

184
00:08:47.960 --> 00:08:51.420
Now I do have some failures,
failures in some pretty important ones.

185
00:08:51.420 --> 00:08:54.180
Database redundancy,
database availability, they both failed.

186
00:08:55.220 --> 00:08:56.340
What's that all about?

187
00:08:56.340 --> 00:08:59.220
Well unfortunately, the way this
is laid out, I can't really tell,

188
00:08:59.220 --> 00:09:01.330
so I'm gonna re-run the command.

189
00:09:01.330 --> 00:09:05.960
And I'm just gonna drop that into
a Format List, or some other

190
00:09:05.960 --> 00:09:09.210
formatting if you want to change it
to be able to see what the deal is.

191
00:09:09.210 --> 00:09:11.530
And when this runs,
it's just gonna take this output,

192
00:09:11.530 --> 00:09:14.130
and there's more on the screen, it's not
showing up here, and it's just gonna lay

193
00:09:14.130 --> 00:09:17.290
it out in a list format, so
I can actually read what's going on.

194
00:09:17.290 --> 00:09:22.180
And if I run that, I'm gonna see all
those passes are gonna come across like

195
00:09:22.180 --> 00:09:24.640
you'll see here,
as we look down this list.

196
00:09:24.640 --> 00:09:26.040
Like here's where it checked for

197
00:09:27.080 --> 00:09:30.420
whether the database availability
group members are up.

198
00:09:30.420 --> 00:09:33.330
It checks whether there were
server locator services running.

199
00:09:33.330 --> 00:09:34.580
These all passed.

200
00:09:34.580 --> 00:09:38.500
But of I get down to the ones that failed,
so I'm just looking for that fail keyword.

201
00:09:38.500 --> 00:09:39.790
Here we go.

202
00:09:39.790 --> 00:09:42.190
I can see here that on
server lab-mailbox 01,

203
00:09:42.190 --> 00:09:45.260
I have database redundancy
shows as failed.

204
00:09:45.260 --> 00:09:47.580
And it tells me here what this check did.

205
00:09:47.580 --> 00:09:51.180
This check verified that databases
have sufficient redundancy.

206
00:09:51.180 --> 00:09:54.360
If the check fails, it means some
databases are at risk of losing data.

207
00:09:54.360 --> 00:09:56.980
In other words,
you've only got one copy of the database.

208
00:09:56.980 --> 00:10:00.720
Or at a minimum, you have one less
copy than you thought you did.

209
00:10:00.720 --> 00:10:01.790
Then it tells me why.

210
00:10:01.790 --> 00:10:04.950
It just tells me, hey there's certain
databases here that don't have redundancy.

211
00:10:04.950 --> 00:10:08.000
It's telling me mailbox database 009,
blah, blah,

212
00:10:08.000 --> 00:10:10.040
blah doesn't have a redundancy.

213
00:10:10.040 --> 00:10:14.600
All right, well I never configured a
redundancy for it, so I kinda expect that.

214
00:10:14.600 --> 00:10:18.523
I can figure redundancy for
the sales database, for sales db.

215
00:10:18.523 --> 00:10:21.720
I never did it for
this mailbox database, or the other one.

216
00:10:21.720 --> 00:10:23.050
And so
that's the one that's showing up next.

217
00:10:23.050 --> 00:10:26.710
This other mailbox database
is not showing as redundant.

218
00:10:26.710 --> 00:10:28.890
In the GUI, you can sort of see that.

219
00:10:28.890 --> 00:10:30.380
Just right here on the database list.

220
00:10:30.380 --> 00:10:34.280
See how when I look at sales db
it's got two servers listed?

221
00:10:34.280 --> 00:10:35.290
The other guys don't.

222
00:10:35.290 --> 00:10:37.100
The other guys just
have one server listed.

223
00:10:37.100 --> 00:10:38.630
They are not redundant.

224
00:10:38.630 --> 00:10:41.962
Even if I add that database to
the database availability group,

225
00:10:41.962 --> 00:10:43.390
it still only has one copy.

226
00:10:43.390 --> 00:10:46.036
It is not until I add a second copy
that it becomes redundant and so

227
00:10:46.036 --> 00:10:48.290
it is going to generate that failure.

228
00:10:48.290 --> 00:10:52.500
So be aware when you run
the test-replication health commandlet,

229
00:10:52.500 --> 00:10:56.220
sometimes you get fail messages back and
it is not a bad thing it is just

230
00:10:56.220 --> 00:10:58.960
some databases are redundant,
you haven't made them that way.

231
00:10:58.960 --> 00:11:01.150
You should go in and
configure them if you need that,

232
00:11:01.150 --> 00:11:02.500
if that's what you're trying to achieve.

233
00:11:04.110 --> 00:11:06.530
So that's one command
load that we can use, and

234
00:11:06.530 --> 00:11:08.650
there's a few other ones
that we can do too.

235
00:11:08.650 --> 00:11:13.820
For example, what I did here,
this test replication health command.

236
00:11:13.820 --> 00:11:16.740
That checked all the databases, but

237
00:11:16.740 --> 00:11:19.290
I might wanna look at
one particular database.

238
00:11:19.290 --> 00:11:22.020
I might wanna kinda dial in
on one that I'm targeting.

239
00:11:22.020 --> 00:11:28.240
And so for that, I can use this
Get-MailboxDatabaseCopy Status.

240
00:11:28.240 --> 00:11:30.375
This has got to be one
of the longer commands.

241
00:11:30.375 --> 00:11:36.610
So I'm gonna do
Get-MailboxDatabase Copy status.

242
00:11:36.610 --> 00:11:37.250
All right?

243
00:11:37.250 --> 00:11:39.810
I want to look at one of
my mailbox databases, and

244
00:11:39.810 --> 00:11:42.310
just see what the current
status of its replication is.

245
00:11:42.310 --> 00:11:44.200
What's it look like right now?

246
00:11:44.200 --> 00:11:47.740
And so, just like the other one,
I need to specify an identity.

247
00:11:47.740 --> 00:11:49.230
And then a name of the database.

248
00:11:49.230 --> 00:11:51.700
So mine is sales db.

249
00:11:51.700 --> 00:11:52.570
And I'll run that, and

250
00:11:52.570 --> 00:11:55.350
it's just going to give me something
dialed in on that one database.

251
00:11:55.350 --> 00:11:57.310
I can see I've got two copies.

252
00:11:57.310 --> 00:11:59.407
The main copy is here in our lab mailbox,

253
00:11:59.407 --> 00:12:02.005
I know it's the main copy
because it's mounted.

254
00:12:02.005 --> 00:12:06.710
It's active right now and then
the other one lab class 01 is healthy.

255
00:12:06.710 --> 00:12:10.680
It's not mounted, but it's healthy, it's
ready to take over at a moments notice if

256
00:12:10.680 --> 00:12:13.220
need be, and
I can see the copy que length and

257
00:12:13.220 --> 00:12:17.079
the replay que length right there it's got
the information I need and it's healthy.

258
00:12:19.240 --> 00:12:22.800
Some things you might notice in here
even on a healthy database, if you

259
00:12:22.800 --> 00:12:26.640
just re-booted one of these servers or if
you just built the database availability

260
00:12:26.640 --> 00:12:32.050
group, expect to see the context
index state as failed or unhealthy.

261
00:12:32.050 --> 00:12:34.250
I don't remember exactly
which error state it shows.

262
00:12:34.250 --> 00:12:36.550
But basically when new
servers are created or

263
00:12:36.550 --> 00:12:40.480
are added to a dag or when a server is
rebooted, is has to rebuild it's index.

264
00:12:40.480 --> 00:12:44.590
And the index takes time to reboot, so it
could take a good five or ten minutes, or

265
00:12:44.590 --> 00:12:48.690
even longer if it's a large database,
to correct that information and

266
00:12:48.690 --> 00:12:49.400
get it up to date.

267
00:12:49.400 --> 00:12:50.890
But you can see mine's
been running long enough,

268
00:12:50.890 --> 00:12:53.360
it's all healthy, and it's good to go.

269
00:12:53.360 --> 00:12:55.365
So quick and easy way to monitor
that from the PowerShell.

270
00:12:56.450 --> 00:13:00.820
Now everything that I'm looking at so
far Is real time data.

271
00:13:00.820 --> 00:13:03.410
I'm seeing the system as it is right now.

272
00:13:03.410 --> 00:13:07.040
So when I ran that command a moment ago,
my Copy Que Length was 0 and

273
00:13:07.040 --> 00:13:08.330
my Replay Que Length was 0.

274
00:13:08.330 --> 00:13:11.846
But what about now?

275
00:13:11.846 --> 00:13:12.860
What about now?
What about now, right?

276
00:13:12.860 --> 00:13:15.010
We might want to know
over a period of time.

277
00:13:15.010 --> 00:13:16.690
Sure, it might be caught up right now, but

278
00:13:16.690 --> 00:13:19.620
it might be lagging behind
at certain point in the day.

279
00:13:19.620 --> 00:13:23.640
So what we can do is we can use a script
that comes with Microsoft Exchange

280
00:13:23.640 --> 00:13:27.710
that allows us to monitor that replication
traffic over a certain period of time.

281
00:13:27.710 --> 00:13:28.990
And you can dictate it.

282
00:13:28.990 --> 00:13:31.750
When we run this script
the default is 30 seconds.

283
00:13:31.750 --> 00:13:35.600
But you can specify a start time and
an end time and so you can have it run for

284
00:13:35.600 --> 00:13:36.340
an hour, 24 hours.

285
00:13:36.340 --> 00:13:39.140
You can run it for
a whole week if you want to go crazy.

286
00:13:39.140 --> 00:13:42.500
It's a lot of data, but
it can gather that data for us and

287
00:13:42.500 --> 00:13:44.700
then put it out in a nice little report.

288
00:13:44.700 --> 00:13:46.580
Let me show you the command.

289
00:13:46.580 --> 00:13:48.390
First off we have to give it
to our scripts directory,

290
00:13:48.390 --> 00:13:50.635
which if you guys remember
is really buried in there.

291
00:13:50.635 --> 00:13:55.740
On any exchange server you
can jump into C:/program

292
00:13:55.740 --> 00:14:04.660
files/Microsoft/exchangeserver/V15/Scri-
pts.

293
00:14:04.660 --> 00:14:07.870
That's the full path to
that script directory.

294
00:14:07.870 --> 00:14:10.510
And in there, there's a bunch
of scripts that are in there.

295
00:14:10.510 --> 00:14:18.350
But the one that I'm looking for
is actually called Collectovermetrics.ps1.

296
00:14:18.350 --> 00:14:21.682
That guy right there,
Collectovermetrics.ps.1.

297
00:14:21.682 --> 00:14:26.990
And that's gonna basically gather this
replication data over a period of time,

298
00:14:26.990 --> 00:14:30.640
and then it aggregates it into
a report that I can view.

299
00:14:30.640 --> 00:14:34.430
So if I want to run that,
the way the script works is

300
00:14:34.430 --> 00:14:37.180
you really just call the script and
you point it at a server.

301
00:14:37.180 --> 00:14:38.720
The start time and end time are optional.

302
00:14:38.720 --> 00:14:41.650
If you don't specify it'll just run for
30 seconds, and that's what I want,

303
00:14:41.650 --> 00:14:43.260
I'm just gonna run it for 30 seconds.

304
00:14:43.260 --> 00:14:45.164
So, I'm gonna execute this script.

305
00:14:47.173 --> 00:14:51.573
And I'm gonna tell it which database
availability group that I want to query,

306
00:14:51.573 --> 00:14:56.107
right, and so I'm gonna be reaching out
to the only database availability group

307
00:14:56.107 --> 00:15:00.129
I have, but if you have more than one
you need to specify the right name.

308
00:15:00.129 --> 00:15:00.970
Mine's dag01.

309
00:15:02.010 --> 00:15:05.030
And then I need to tell
it a database to monitor.

310
00:15:05.030 --> 00:15:07.010
This is gonna monitor
a particular database.

311
00:15:07.010 --> 00:15:13.150
I'm gonna monitor the sales db and
then after that, if I just run it,

312
00:15:13.150 --> 00:15:18.150
I'm going to get this text data back,
and I want to get a nice, fancy report.

313
00:15:18.150 --> 00:15:20.560
So I'm going to say generate HTML report.

314
00:15:22.210 --> 00:15:25.110
If I just leave it there,
it's going to generate the HTML report and

315
00:15:25.110 --> 00:15:28.790
it's going to save it to a file or
as you can expect a file name, but

316
00:15:28.790 --> 00:15:33.520
you can add if this is like a one time
thing, you can add show HTML report, and

317
00:15:33.520 --> 00:15:37.030
when it's done it will just launch it for
us in browser so that we can see it.

318
00:15:37.030 --> 00:15:42.470
So the full command here is
collectovermetrics,PS1-databaseavailabili-

319
00:15:42.470 --> 00:15:43.360
tygroup and

320
00:15:43.360 --> 00:15:48.420
the name of the group, then -database: and
whatever the database name is.

321
00:15:48.420 --> 00:15:48.932
And be aware,

322
00:15:48.932 --> 00:15:51.857
if you have any spaces in your database
name you'll need to put quotes around it.

323
00:15:51.857 --> 00:15:55.844
In fact, it's not a bad idea to just
always put quotes around it to kinda

324
00:15:55.844 --> 00:15:57.250
get in the habit of that.

325
00:15:57.250 --> 00:16:00.456
And then I'm generating an HTML
report as opposed to plain text.

326
00:16:00.456 --> 00:16:02.507
And I wanna see that report.

327
00:16:02.507 --> 00:16:05.049
And when we run it,
it's gonna run for 30 seconds,

328
00:16:05.049 --> 00:16:07.255
it's collecting that replication data and,

329
00:16:07.255 --> 00:16:10.720
I don't know, maybe I can generate
some replication data of some sort.

330
00:16:10.720 --> 00:16:14.220
I don't know if I'll be fast enough
here to grab somebody's mailbox and

331
00:16:14.220 --> 00:16:17.920
maybe move them to
a different mailbox server.

332
00:16:17.920 --> 00:16:21.381
That's way down here, and
my timer is ticking, isn't it?

333
00:16:21.381 --> 00:16:24.700
[LAUGH] So we'll see, of course,

334
00:16:24.700 --> 00:16:28.370
it's gonna make me type things and
try and get this guy moved in.

335
00:16:28.370 --> 00:16:32.110
I think my 30 seconds might already be up,
but let's see if I can get it in there.

336
00:16:32.110 --> 00:16:33.115
Do it, go, run!

337
00:16:33.115 --> 00:16:35.530
[LAUGH] There we go, okay.

338
00:16:35.530 --> 00:16:41.060
So now I'm moving a mailbox from
another database into the Sales DB.

339
00:16:41.060 --> 00:16:44.811
So when that mailbox moves,
it's gonna move into, well,

340
00:16:44.811 --> 00:16:46.773
Sales DB on the active member.

341
00:16:46.773 --> 00:16:48.903
And the active member's
gonna start replicating that

342
00:16:48.903 --> 00:16:50.020
over to the standby member.

343
00:16:50.020 --> 00:16:52.472
So, I moved it,
it's gonna go to mailbox01.

344
00:16:52.472 --> 00:16:56.750
And then mailbox01 is gonna do
transaction log shipping over to cas01 so

345
00:16:56.750 --> 00:17:00.290
that cas01 can receive it and
replay those logs and

346
00:17:00.290 --> 00:17:02.780
have that mailbox be present
in that database too.

347
00:17:02.780 --> 00:17:06.360
So that's all happening in the background,
I can see that's syncing right now.

348
00:17:06.360 --> 00:17:09.302
Syncing means it's copying
the database between the two, and

349
00:17:09.302 --> 00:17:11.532
that's gonna kick off
that replication data.

350
00:17:11.532 --> 00:17:14.730
All right, so all that's happening
kind of in the background there.

351
00:17:14.730 --> 00:17:17.083
And if I jump over here,
my report already generated,

352
00:17:17.083 --> 00:17:20.000
so I might have a bunch of zeroes,
we'll see what happens.

353
00:17:20.000 --> 00:17:23.320
But I can see in the background that
I've got my web browser fired up.

354
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:27.230
And right here I can see my
database over summary statistics.

355
00:17:27.230 --> 00:17:32.020
And here it's just gonna lay things out so
I can see the total databases that I have,

356
00:17:32.020 --> 00:17:32.921
I've got two.

357
00:17:32.921 --> 00:17:36.447
The ones that are mounted and
started up, one that's mounted but

358
00:17:36.447 --> 00:17:37.740
not actually running.

359
00:17:37.740 --> 00:17:41.401
And you can see other statistical
information on them, right.

360
00:17:41.401 --> 00:17:44.225
Did we have any failures during
the time we were monitoring?

361
00:17:44.225 --> 00:17:47.673
How many responses back were under
30 seconds or over 30 seconds?

362
00:17:47.673 --> 00:17:51.381
What's my lossy amount,
did I lose any data during that time?

363
00:17:51.381 --> 00:17:54.771
And you can see mine,
no failed operations found in the data.

364
00:17:54.771 --> 00:17:56.917
Now, other data we see in here,

365
00:17:56.917 --> 00:18:02.258
if I had things that took more than 30
seconds it tries to lay out what that was.

366
00:18:02.258 --> 00:18:05.782
And you can see down here
just basic information, and

367
00:18:05.782 --> 00:18:07.514
it lays out a lot of stuff.

368
00:18:07.514 --> 00:18:10.470
Kind of what happened during that time,
and actually, mine was terrible,

369
00:18:10.470 --> 00:18:10.986
wasn't it?

370
00:18:10.986 --> 00:18:14.716
0 replayed logs, so that means [LAUGH]
during the 30 seconds I monitored,

371
00:18:14.716 --> 00:18:19.031
there actually wasn't even enough activity
to generate 1 transaction log moving, so

372
00:18:19.031 --> 00:18:21.444
of course I'm gonna see
really good stuff here.

373
00:18:21.444 --> 00:18:26.294
But it's just a nice graphical
representation that lets you spot whether

374
00:18:26.294 --> 00:18:28.430
things are healthy or not.

375
00:18:28.430 --> 00:18:32.490
And kind of isolating if there's
issues you need to deal with.

376
00:18:32.490 --> 00:18:35.250
So neat little command,
it's a script that's a part of Exchange,

377
00:18:35.250 --> 00:18:36.820
you don't have to write it or
download it or anything,

378
00:18:36.820 --> 00:18:40.105
it's a part of your
default Exchange install.

379
00:18:40.105 --> 00:18:43.870
All right, now these are all fine and
good, but all of these center

380
00:18:43.870 --> 00:18:48.260
around command line utilities and
me being present to run them.

381
00:18:48.260 --> 00:18:50.210
Well, a lot of times I'm
not present to run them,

382
00:18:50.210 --> 00:18:53.580
so I need something that can
kinda go on in the background.

383
00:18:53.580 --> 00:18:57.320
And one of the nice tools that's a part
of Windows that lets us do this,

384
00:18:57.320 --> 00:18:58.760
is the Performance Monitor.

385
00:18:58.760 --> 00:19:00.360
We can fire up the Performance Monitor and

386
00:19:00.360 --> 00:19:05.280
there's a number of performance counters
that specifically relate to replication.

387
00:19:05.280 --> 00:19:09.580
And you can set that up and
couple it with performance alerts, and

388
00:19:09.580 --> 00:19:13.040
now you can have it where the server
alerts you when there's a problem.

389
00:19:13.040 --> 00:19:14.360
So we don't have to go looking for

390
00:19:14.360 --> 00:19:18.200
a problem if we think it's occurring,
we get notified right away, all right?

391
00:19:18.200 --> 00:19:18.770
Let me show you that.

392
00:19:19.980 --> 00:19:23.730
So, let's see, what server do I
want to use, I'll use this one.

393
00:19:23.730 --> 00:19:26.110
So I'm gonna go ahead and
fire up my Performance Monitor.

394
00:19:27.780 --> 00:19:29.920
There we go, and
remember the Performance Monitor,

395
00:19:29.920 --> 00:19:32.800
it's a part of every Windows installation.

396
00:19:32.800 --> 00:19:38.130
But when you install Microsoft Exchange
on a server, it adds a lot more to it.

397
00:19:38.130 --> 00:19:40.990
So if you fired up the Performance Monitor
on your work station,

398
00:19:40.990 --> 00:19:44.170
it's really just got Windows
monitoring in it, not Exchange.

399
00:19:44.170 --> 00:19:47.670
But when you fire up Performance Monitor
on an Exchange Server,

400
00:19:47.670 --> 00:19:49.430
there is a lot more.

401
00:19:49.430 --> 00:19:50.470
So if I go in here and

402
00:19:50.470 --> 00:19:55.300
I go down to Performance Monitor,
you see it's monitoring %Processor Time,

403
00:19:55.300 --> 00:19:58.180
which is a great thing to monitor,
right, what's my CPU load?

404
00:19:58.180 --> 00:20:03.740
But we can hit this green + arrow, and
start to add more counters to it, right?

405
00:20:03.740 --> 00:20:07.040
And when you look at the counters, most of
this is stuff that's related to Windows,

406
00:20:07.040 --> 00:20:10.030
processor, memory,
disk I/O, things like that.

407
00:20:10.030 --> 00:20:11.320
But if you scroll around,

408
00:20:11.320 --> 00:20:16.740
you'll find in here MSExchange,
and look how many are in there.

409
00:20:16.740 --> 00:20:21.670
It's added over 200 counters
specifically related

410
00:20:21.670 --> 00:20:25.840
just to Exchange, and
there is a lot in there.

411
00:20:25.840 --> 00:20:28.400
You can monitor every single
aspect of Exchange right

412
00:20:28.400 --> 00:20:30.590
from inside the the Performance Monitor.

413
00:20:30.590 --> 00:20:31.870
Now, why is that important?

414
00:20:31.870 --> 00:20:37.713
Well, I can create several counters
that are monitoring for criteria.

415
00:20:37.713 --> 00:20:39.543
And then in the Performance Monitor,

416
00:20:39.543 --> 00:20:41.955
we can set up what are called
Data Collector Sets.

417
00:20:41.955 --> 00:20:44.220
A Data Collector Set
runs in the background.

418
00:20:44.220 --> 00:20:46.805
It runs and it collects data,
that's the name, right, so

419
00:20:46.805 --> 00:20:48.525
it can gather data about replication.

420
00:20:48.525 --> 00:20:53.663
But what's even better is that when
you define a Data Collector Set,

421
00:20:53.663 --> 00:20:58.070
you can also define alerts
that occur as a result of it.

422
00:20:58.070 --> 00:21:02.240
And so you can say, hey, if this threshold
exceeds a certain value, send me an alert.

423
00:21:02.240 --> 00:21:07.310
Send me an email or generate an event
log message, or do some kind of action.

424
00:21:07.310 --> 00:21:09.990
So now we can really get some
interactive monitoring out of this,

425
00:21:09.990 --> 00:21:11.560
it just takes setting it up.

426
00:21:11.560 --> 00:21:14.310
Now for replication, let me show
you the counters to watch out for.

427
00:21:14.310 --> 00:21:17.940
I'm gonna go under Performance Monitor,
and I'll hit that green + sign.

428
00:21:17.940 --> 00:21:23.110
And I'm gonna look for the section
called MS Exchange Replication.

429
00:21:23.110 --> 00:21:25.165
So it's in here somewhere.

430
00:21:27.266 --> 00:21:30.296
It gets a little confusing cuz
some of them are MSExchange,

431
00:21:30.296 --> 00:21:33.640
see how this one is MSExchangeRepl and
it's all one word?

432
00:21:33.640 --> 00:21:37.516
The one I'm looking for is MSExchange,
and then a space, and then Replication.

433
00:21:37.516 --> 00:21:41.560
So I've gotta find where that starts,
it's up here.

434
00:21:41.560 --> 00:21:45.330
It does make things confusing,
but we'll spot it.

435
00:21:45.330 --> 00:21:47.450
There it is, MSExchange Replication.

436
00:21:47.450 --> 00:21:50.770
And if I expand that,
underneath you'll see a bunch of counters,

437
00:21:50.770 --> 00:21:52.720
there's a ton of stuff here.

438
00:21:52.720 --> 00:21:54.950
And some of it's important,
some of it's not,

439
00:21:54.950 --> 00:21:58.110
some of it is used in really
special case scenarios.

440
00:21:58.110 --> 00:22:00.910
But some of the things that
we might want to monitor for?

441
00:22:00.910 --> 00:22:05.812
Well, you've got information in here
like average network reads per second.

442
00:22:05.812 --> 00:22:09.150
All right, or
other bandwidth type related issues,

443
00:22:09.150 --> 00:22:11.860
how much bandwidth is my
replication consuming?

444
00:22:11.860 --> 00:22:14.570
Well, we don't normally worry
about that too much cuz you've got

445
00:22:14.570 --> 00:22:17.580
a certain amount of bandwidth available
and email usually isn't that high.

446
00:22:17.580 --> 00:22:19.100
But in a high volume environment that

447
00:22:19.100 --> 00:22:20.860
might be something that
you want to monitor.

448
00:22:20.860 --> 00:22:24.000
You could also monitor your network
interfaces to see if they were over.

449
00:22:24.000 --> 00:22:27.990
But the ones I'm concerned about, well,
the first one is copy queue length, right?

450
00:22:27.990 --> 00:22:31.431
Copy queue length, we saw that in the GUI,
that was a pretty important one.

451
00:22:31.431 --> 00:22:35.570
I need to know how many transaction
logs are waiting to be processed.

452
00:22:35.570 --> 00:22:40.510
And down here I can pick if it's all
together or one particular database.

453
00:22:40.510 --> 00:22:44.960
Like I might just want to monitor
the Sales DB and that's it.

454
00:22:44.960 --> 00:22:48.090
And then I can do copy queue
length excluding inspection.

455
00:22:48.090 --> 00:22:49.610
What does that mean?

456
00:22:49.610 --> 00:22:52.380
Well, these are logs that have been
copied to the other servers but

457
00:22:52.380 --> 00:22:53.630
not applied yet, right?

458
00:22:53.630 --> 00:22:55.360
It's part of that replay queue.

459
00:22:55.360 --> 00:22:58.730
And so I can take that and
add that for Sales DB.

460
00:22:58.730 --> 00:23:01.350
So those are two good ones
to keep an eye out for.

461
00:23:01.350 --> 00:23:07.000
Another one, one you'll want to alert on,
is failed, right here, failed.

462
00:23:07.000 --> 00:23:09.920
That's one of those counters you
want to always show 0, right.

463
00:23:09.920 --> 00:23:13.150
If it ever shows 1 or higher, that means
you've got failed transaction logs and

464
00:23:13.150 --> 00:23:14.620
you need to find out why.

465
00:23:14.620 --> 00:23:18.530
And so I might wanna add that one,
all right now I've got a record of that.

466
00:23:18.530 --> 00:23:21.941
Some of the other ones, there's some neat
ones here where Microsoft's really thought

467
00:23:21.941 --> 00:23:23.108
of what we're going to need.

468
00:23:23.108 --> 00:23:26.496
Like log replay is not keeping up.

469
00:23:26.496 --> 00:23:31.720
Okay, any time the log replay on
the other side is getting behind,

470
00:23:31.720 --> 00:23:33.690
this will turn into a 1.

471
00:23:33.690 --> 00:23:34.670
Otherwise, it will be a 0.

472
00:23:34.670 --> 00:23:36.910
When it's a 0, you're healthy,
when it's a 1, you've got a problem.

473
00:23:36.910 --> 00:23:39.890
So, easy counter to monitor, all right?

474
00:23:40.890 --> 00:23:45.060
Along the same lines, we've got log
copying is not keeping up, okay?

475
00:23:45.060 --> 00:23:48.422
If it's log copying,
it's usually a network issue.

476
00:23:48.422 --> 00:23:52.184
If it's log replay,
it's normally a server issue.

477
00:23:52.184 --> 00:23:55.766
This helps us to kinda dial down where to
troubleshoot to find out why replication

478
00:23:55.766 --> 00:23:56.780
is behind.

479
00:23:56.780 --> 00:23:58.341
On the other side, all right?

480
00:23:58.341 --> 00:24:02.000
And then, one more I'd like
to add that's not in the GUI.

481
00:24:02.000 --> 00:24:03.660
We've got this copy queue length.

482
00:24:03.660 --> 00:24:06.120
There's a replay queue length also.

483
00:24:06.120 --> 00:24:09.720
And we can spot that in here and
add that one in.

484
00:24:09.720 --> 00:24:14.240
These are all great counters
to monitor for replication.

485
00:24:14.240 --> 00:24:16.430
And with the exception of
the copy queue length,

486
00:24:16.430 --> 00:24:18.910
I really do expect most of
these to be zero, right?

487
00:24:18.910 --> 00:24:22.070
We shouldn't have any giant delays,
but if it gets to one or

488
00:24:22.070 --> 00:24:24.220
two, that might be okay for some of them.

489
00:24:24.220 --> 00:24:28.650
If the copy queue length, or
the replay queue length gets to two,

490
00:24:28.650 --> 00:24:31.720
I'm okay with that, that's just two
megabytes of data that hasn't been rolled

491
00:24:31.720 --> 00:24:34.590
into the database yet,
it's not that giant of a deal.

492
00:24:34.590 --> 00:24:38.310
But, if I see something like
failed go to 1, that's a big deal,

493
00:24:38.310 --> 00:24:40.200
that means I've got an actual failure.

494
00:24:40.200 --> 00:24:45.100
Or log copying is not keeping up to date,
if that gets to a 1, that's too much.

495
00:24:45.100 --> 00:24:48.860
So we need to understand the values
of each, and if you ever forget

496
00:24:48.860 --> 00:24:52.550
you can highlight these things, and right
down here you can hit show description and

497
00:24:52.550 --> 00:24:54.280
it'll explain what it's monitoring.

498
00:24:54.280 --> 00:24:57.370
It'll tell you a little bit about it and
what to look for.

499
00:24:57.370 --> 00:24:59.460
And when I say okay,
it's gonna add all that together, and

500
00:24:59.460 --> 00:25:01.808
now I've got some great
counters here that are running.

501
00:25:01.808 --> 00:25:06.310
And I could fire this up when I need
it just on my own and monitor these, or

502
00:25:06.310 --> 00:25:10.400
I could create a data collector set that
had these, and I could set it to run.

503
00:25:10.400 --> 00:25:11.860
For an hour during peak time.

504
00:25:11.860 --> 00:25:13.100
I could set it run all the time.

505
00:25:13.100 --> 00:25:13.660
It's kind of up to me.

506
00:25:13.660 --> 00:25:17.660
I could set it up to run whenever I
needed it and just let it do it's job and

507
00:25:17.660 --> 00:25:18.700
that's that, right?

508
00:25:18.700 --> 00:25:21.640
So great counters are available for
us to get there.

509
00:25:21.640 --> 00:25:23.850
Now, I do want to mention one thing.

510
00:25:23.850 --> 00:25:28.140
If you've got Microsoft Systems
Center Operations Manager, SCOM.

511
00:25:28.140 --> 00:25:31.190
SCOM has an Exchange 2013 Management Pack.

512
00:25:31.190 --> 00:25:32.910
And it knows about all this stuff too.

513
00:25:32.910 --> 00:25:34.760
It knows about it automatically.

514
00:25:34.760 --> 00:25:37.790
Now, we can configure this ourselves
right here in performance monitor.

515
00:25:37.790 --> 00:25:39.200
It doesn't cost us a dime.

516
00:25:39.200 --> 00:25:40.600
SCOM costs money.

517
00:25:40.600 --> 00:25:42.900
So why would I want to go the SCOM route?

518
00:25:42.900 --> 00:25:45.110
Well, SCOM already has
the stuff to find it.

519
00:25:45.110 --> 00:25:48.050
Already knows what's good and what's bad,
so it knows when to throw an alert and

520
00:25:48.050 --> 00:25:49.050
when not to.

521
00:25:49.050 --> 00:25:52.310
And it can also monitor multiple servers.

522
00:25:52.310 --> 00:25:54.640
This, I'm just setting
this up on one server.

523
00:25:54.640 --> 00:25:56.520
Well, I've got three
exchange servers here.

524
00:25:56.520 --> 00:25:59.900
So I'll need to go to each exchange server
that I'm running replication on, and

525
00:25:59.900 --> 00:26:02.120
configure these same counters and
set up alerts.

526
00:26:02.120 --> 00:26:04.940
There's no way to centrally
manage the performance monitor.

527
00:26:04.940 --> 00:26:08.360
So instead, we can use SCOM and
it makes our life a lot easier.

528
00:26:08.360 --> 00:26:10.950
For large environments,
you'll probably want SCOM.

529
00:26:10.950 --> 00:26:12.030
For a small environment,

530
00:26:12.030 --> 00:26:14.270
a couple of exchange servers where
you don't mind doing it by hand?

531
00:26:14.270 --> 00:26:15.970
Well, you can use the performance monitor.

532
00:26:15.970 --> 00:26:18.110
It's right there,
you just have to know what to look for.

533
00:26:19.300 --> 00:26:23.380
All right, well those are the key
things to watch out for on replication.

534
00:26:23.380 --> 00:26:27.520
We're just keeping an eye on that copy
queue length and the replay queue length.

535
00:26:27.520 --> 00:26:29.010
And if they start to get bigger,

536
00:26:29.010 --> 00:26:30.930
then we've got some issues
we need to troubleshoot.

537
00:26:30.930 --> 00:26:32.400
Kind of isolate where that problem is.

538
00:26:32.400 --> 00:26:37.013
Usually boils down to network connectivity
and Disk I/O on the destination side, or

539
00:26:37.013 --> 00:26:38.790
maybe CPU on the other side.

540
00:26:38.790 --> 00:26:41.210
Just not being able to keep up
with the work that it's doing.

541
00:26:41.210 --> 00:26:42.195
So those are where we wanna target.

542
00:26:43.310 --> 00:26:47.060
Well, replication is really only one
aspect of our exchange environment.

543
00:26:47.060 --> 00:26:49.990
You've also got your mailbox servers and
your client access servers.

544
00:26:49.990 --> 00:26:52.190
We need to monitor performance on those.

545
00:26:52.190 --> 00:26:55.400
But I'm a little short on time on this
segment, so what we're gonna do is do

546
00:26:55.400 --> 00:26:59.660
a Part Two, where we'll start to take a
look at just our general servers are, our

547
00:26:59.660 --> 00:27:03.770
mailbox databases and our client access
servers, what we need to watch for them,

548
00:27:03.770 --> 00:27:07.690
how we kinda monitor and maintain them and
keep their performance up to snuff.

549
00:27:07.690 --> 00:27:12.160
So definitely stay tuned for Part Two but
in this episode, we got a chance to look

550
00:27:12.160 --> 00:27:17.000
at monitoring replication, how to spot
when there's a problem, and different ways

551
00:27:17.000 --> 00:27:20.110
that we can look to find that information
and make sure that our server was healthy.

552
00:27:20.110 --> 00:27:22.550
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

553
00:27:22.550 --> 00:27:27.285
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

554
00:27:27.285 --> 00:27:32.260
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses some of the various methods for monitoring the performance and health of Exchange 2013 Mailbox servers and Client Access Servers. He discusses several Performance Monitor counters and highlights how each can be used to monitor different aspects of Exchange performance. He wraps up the show by discussing the Exchange Best Practices Analyzer (BPA).
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintenance Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.837
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.837 --> 00:00:13.819
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:13.819 --> 00:00:15.966
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.966 --> 00:00:20.501
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again with
another episode of Microsoft Exchange.

5
00:00:20.501 --> 00:00:23.660
In fact,
this is Part 2 to the Monitoring and

6
00:00:23.660 --> 00:00:25.950
Maintenance episode that
we started filming earlier.

7
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:29.300
In our last episode we had a chance
to look at how to monitor replication

8
00:00:29.300 --> 00:00:32.080
on our system, and make sure that
our servers were communicating and

9
00:00:32.080 --> 00:00:35.920
that our database availability groups
are working the way their suppose to.

10
00:00:35.920 --> 00:00:37.840
Now I wanna switch gears, and

11
00:00:37.840 --> 00:00:41.010
we're gonna just take a look at
regular old Exchange Servers, right?

12
00:00:41.010 --> 00:00:44.220
Regardless of whether we're doing
replication or not, there's certain

13
00:00:44.220 --> 00:00:47.230
things that we need to monitor on our
servers to make sure that they're healthy.

14
00:00:47.230 --> 00:00:50.330
All right, now the first thing that I
wanna mention before we even get into

15
00:00:50.330 --> 00:00:55.980
monitoring anything, is how important
it is to have what's called a baseline.

16
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:59.150
All right,
a baseline is a collection of data, right,

17
00:00:59.150 --> 00:01:03.610
data about your servers when
everything's running fine.

18
00:01:03.610 --> 00:01:06.780
So you need to be sitting at your office
one day when all the exchange servers

19
00:01:06.780 --> 00:01:07.400
are working great.

20
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:10.530
You're not getting any support tickets,
things are running fine.

21
00:01:10.530 --> 00:01:13.890
And take a snapshot of your servers,
a performance snapshot,

22
00:01:13.890 --> 00:01:15.230
not like a disk snapshot.

23
00:01:15.230 --> 00:01:17.616
We [LAUGH] need a performance snapshot so

24
00:01:17.616 --> 00:01:20.736
we know what things look
like when things are good.

25
00:01:20.736 --> 00:01:23.744
Have you ever gotten the call
from somebody, and they say, man,

26
00:01:23.744 --> 00:01:26.890
my email is really slow,
what's going on over there?

27
00:01:26.890 --> 00:01:29.780
And you look at it, and
you're like, well it's fine for me,

28
00:01:29.780 --> 00:01:32.060
I don't see any problems, right?

29
00:01:32.060 --> 00:01:33.420
What is slow?

30
00:01:33.420 --> 00:01:35.880
Different people interpret
slow in different ways.

31
00:01:35.880 --> 00:01:39.240
And it could be their laptop, or
their desktop is what's slow.

32
00:01:39.240 --> 00:01:41.010
It could be the servers that are slow.

33
00:01:41.010 --> 00:01:45.180
It could be that things are running like
normal, and they just feel like it's slow.

34
00:01:45.180 --> 00:01:47.087
Maybe they're in a hurry,
right, that's how I get.

35
00:01:47.087 --> 00:01:50.410
If I want to print the document,
it prints at a certain speed, right?

36
00:01:50.410 --> 00:01:52.190
But if I'm in a hurry,
if I need to get out the door,

37
00:01:52.190 --> 00:01:54.380
that print job takes forever.

38
00:01:54.380 --> 00:01:56.330
It really takes the same time,
it's our own perception.

39
00:01:57.530 --> 00:01:59.970
We need something to
be able to compare to.

40
00:01:59.970 --> 00:02:04.640
So down the road when somebody calls and
says, man, email is really slow,

41
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:09.070
we can gather our performance data for
right now, compare it to our performance

42
00:02:09.070 --> 00:02:12.500
data from before, when things were good,
and see if they're different.

43
00:02:12.500 --> 00:02:15.780
If they're the same, we can tell the
person, hey, I'm sorry, I don't know your

44
00:02:15.780 --> 00:02:19.730
issue is, but the servers are running
at their normal operating parameters.

45
00:02:20.860 --> 00:02:24.350
Or we look at it and we see things are
different, we go wow, you're right, and

46
00:02:24.350 --> 00:02:25.530
it looks like a server issue.

47
00:02:25.530 --> 00:02:28.450
It's not your laptop or your desktop,
there's something going on on our end.

48
00:02:28.450 --> 00:02:30.390
Let me get in there and find it out.

49
00:02:30.390 --> 00:02:31.960
That's the advantage of having a baseline,

50
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:34.060
we need to know what things
are supposed to look like.

51
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:37.880
Now, you might ask yourself,
shouldn't Microsoft give us a baseline,

52
00:02:37.880 --> 00:02:40.180
like here's what an exchange
server should run like?

53
00:02:40.180 --> 00:02:43.470
Unfortunately everybody's implementation
is a little bit different, right?

54
00:02:43.470 --> 00:02:46.300
You might have different hard
drives than somebody else.

55
00:02:46.300 --> 00:02:47.710
Some hard drives are faster than others.

56
00:02:47.710 --> 00:02:51.380
Some people might have SCSI drives,
some people might have iSCSI or

57
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:52.840
Fiber Channel drives.

58
00:02:52.840 --> 00:02:55.110
And there's different
performance characteristics.

59
00:02:55.110 --> 00:02:58.350
So you might have different RAID levels,
right?

60
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:00.580
RAID 1 versus RAID 5, or whatever,

61
00:03:00.580 --> 00:03:03.290
each of those has different
read/write performance levels.

62
00:03:03.290 --> 00:03:08.349
Different CPUs, different quantity of
CPUs, these are all things that impact it.

63
00:03:08.349 --> 00:03:12.400
But one of the biggest things that impacts
it are the size of your mailboxes and

64
00:03:12.400 --> 00:03:14.190
how many mailboxes you have.

65
00:03:14.190 --> 00:03:17.013
That can really impact
performance on your system.

66
00:03:17.013 --> 00:03:19.913
And Microsoft doesn't know how many
mailboxes you're gonna have so

67
00:03:19.913 --> 00:03:21.670
they can't give you just a fixed number.

68
00:03:21.670 --> 00:03:24.885
That's why it's important that
you take your own baseline.

69
00:03:24.885 --> 00:03:28.595
What I'm gonna do this episode is I'm
gonna go through a number of performance

70
00:03:28.595 --> 00:03:31.100
counters that we need
to watch in our server.

71
00:03:31.100 --> 00:03:33.530
So that we have an idea
of what to look for.

72
00:03:33.530 --> 00:03:37.573
And then what you guys should do is take
this information and in real life land,

73
00:03:37.573 --> 00:03:41.190
build up a Performance Monitor that
collects all this data when things

74
00:03:41.190 --> 00:03:41.760
are good.

75
00:03:41.760 --> 00:03:45.087
And then just save it, stick it somewhere
on your hard drive and save it.

76
00:03:45.087 --> 00:03:47.557
And then down the road
when problems happen,

77
00:03:47.557 --> 00:03:50.850
you can rerun these same counters and
compare the two.

78
00:03:50.850 --> 00:03:54.190
And now you'll know if it's a server
problem, or a client problem, or

79
00:03:54.190 --> 00:03:55.550
if there's no problem at all, right?

80
00:03:55.550 --> 00:03:57.360
That's what we get from this.

81
00:03:57.360 --> 00:04:00.970
Now, there is a tool from Microsoft
that makes this a lot easier.

82
00:04:00.970 --> 00:04:04.915
There's a tool called the System
Center Operations Manager, SCOM.

83
00:04:04.915 --> 00:04:08.780
SCOM has a Microsoft Exchange
2013 management pack that

84
00:04:08.780 --> 00:04:10.010
you can install in it.

85
00:04:10.010 --> 00:04:13.150
And that lets it know all
the characteristics of Exchange.

86
00:04:13.150 --> 00:04:17.240
It can start monitoring your servers and
it'll see how many mailboxes you have and

87
00:04:17.240 --> 00:04:19.510
it'll know what the average
size of those mailboxes are and

88
00:04:19.510 --> 00:04:22.610
it'll know what your
performance should be.

89
00:04:22.610 --> 00:04:24.210
And then it can alert you.

90
00:04:24.210 --> 00:04:28.160
And so if you're running SCOM, it kinda
takes care of the baselines for you.

91
00:04:28.160 --> 00:04:31.050
And it takes care of watching for
errors, it takes care of all that.

92
00:04:31.050 --> 00:04:34.280
It's really a great product,
but it's kind of expensive.

93
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:36.450
And you don't have to have SCOM.

94
00:04:36.450 --> 00:04:39.110
SCOM's not really doing anything
that you couldn't do yourself with

95
00:04:39.110 --> 00:04:40.300
a Performance Monitor.

96
00:04:40.300 --> 00:04:42.990
It's just it takes a lot
of work to do it yourself.

97
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:45.470
You've gotta know exactly
which counters to use, right?

98
00:04:45.470 --> 00:04:47.280
So the first part is knowledge.

99
00:04:47.280 --> 00:04:50.230
Then you've gotta go and
configure it all on your servers, and

100
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:52.460
the more servers you have,
the more it's gonna take.

101
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:55.240
So, the other thing SCOM gives
us is centralized management.

102
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:59.190
And then lastly, you gotta set it up to be
able to alert you when a problem happens

103
00:04:59.190 --> 00:05:00.790
so you need to know what those alerts are.

104
00:05:00.790 --> 00:05:04.370
So the alerting threshold, that's kind
of the third piece that SCOM gives you.

105
00:05:04.370 --> 00:05:08.400
So if you already have SCOM, or
if it's in your budget to get it,

106
00:05:08.400 --> 00:05:10.450
it's a great utility for
monitoring Exchange.

107
00:05:11.650 --> 00:05:13.370
Like I said,
we don't actually have to have it,

108
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:16.190
you can do the monitoring right
in the Performance Monitor.

109
00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:18.760
So, let's walk through that process.

110
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:22.190
First off I'm gonna start with some kinda
general things, because you'll have

111
00:05:22.190 --> 00:05:25.530
different things you wanna monitor based
on whether it's a mailbox server or

112
00:05:25.530 --> 00:05:27.130
a client access server, right?

113
00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:28.570
Let's kinda start there.

114
00:05:28.570 --> 00:05:33.610
When we jump into our Performance Monitor,
we can go and set up Data Collector Sets.

115
00:05:33.610 --> 00:05:36.720
And Data Collector Sets can
collect all sorts of information.

116
00:05:36.720 --> 00:05:40.930
And when you install Exchange, it actually
creates a couple of these for you.

117
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:45.020
So you'll see Exchange Diagnostics
Daily Performance Log,

118
00:05:45.020 --> 00:05:47.350
and Exchange Diagnostics Performance Log.

119
00:05:47.350 --> 00:05:50.250
It's actually doing its own
diagnostics in the background, and

120
00:05:50.250 --> 00:05:52.098
it'll alert you to various things.

121
00:05:52.098 --> 00:05:55.620
It's not all-encompassing though, so
you don't want to rely on just that.

122
00:05:55.620 --> 00:05:59.300
But you can create your own
user-defined Data Collector Set, and

123
00:05:59.300 --> 00:06:02.020
define all the things I'm gonna
talk about in this episode.

124
00:06:02.020 --> 00:06:06.600
And then use those as a test to
be able to see how your server's

125
00:06:06.600 --> 00:06:08.590
doing at any given point, right?

126
00:06:08.590 --> 00:06:12.765
Now the server we monitor is gonna
make a difference, for example,

127
00:06:12.765 --> 00:06:14.825
if it's a client access server.

128
00:06:14.825 --> 00:06:17.340
We have to think what a client
access server does, right.

129
00:06:17.340 --> 00:06:23.320
End users browse to its web pages, or
they use POP3 and IMAP4 to go through it,

130
00:06:23.320 --> 00:06:27.320
or SMTP email is moved through
the queues on a client access server.

131
00:06:27.320 --> 00:06:30.780
But a client access server has
no mailboxes, zero mailboxes.

132
00:06:30.780 --> 00:06:35.110
It has no queues to speak of, so
email is not getting queued there.

133
00:06:35.110 --> 00:06:38.700
So disk I/O on a client access
server is almost nonexistent,

134
00:06:38.700 --> 00:06:41.080
it really doesn't do a lot of disk I/O.

135
00:06:41.080 --> 00:06:43.470
And it really doesn't
consume a lot of RAM either,

136
00:06:43.470 --> 00:06:45.650
stuff is just passing right through it.

137
00:06:45.650 --> 00:06:51.330
It's mostly CPU, and maybe some network,
but mostly CPU on a client access server.

138
00:06:51.330 --> 00:06:54.980
A mailbox server is very different though,
a mailbox server has a huge database.

139
00:06:54.980 --> 00:06:57.990
And the database is stored on the hard
drive and it's constantly reading and

140
00:06:57.990 --> 00:06:59.150
writing from that database.

141
00:06:59.150 --> 00:07:03.060
And it's got transaction logs and
other things, it's got email queues.

142
00:07:03.060 --> 00:07:06.590
All of that is gonna generate disk I/O.

143
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:09.280
And so we have something
different we want to focus on.

144
00:07:09.280 --> 00:07:13.960
And to try and alleviate the disk I/O, a
lot of the database gets cached into RAM,

145
00:07:13.960 --> 00:07:16.780
and so
mailbox servers consume a lot of RAM too.

146
00:07:16.780 --> 00:07:19.580
They do use some CPU, but
not like client access server.

147
00:07:19.580 --> 00:07:22.780
So, the performance profiles
of your different servers

148
00:07:22.780 --> 00:07:25.090
are actually gonna be
different based on their role.

149
00:07:25.090 --> 00:07:28.120
So keep that in mind,
I'll mention as we go through.

150
00:07:28.120 --> 00:07:30.290
But let's start with one that we need
to monitor pretty much everywhere,

151
00:07:30.290 --> 00:07:31.630
and that's processor.

152
00:07:31.630 --> 00:07:35.980
When you launch the Performance Monitor
it has one performance counter added by

153
00:07:35.980 --> 00:07:40.770
default which is CPU, and
it's percent processor time right?

154
00:07:40.770 --> 00:07:42.720
Now what percent processor time is,

155
00:07:42.720 --> 00:07:47.250
is the amount of time the CPU
spends actually doing something.

156
00:07:47.250 --> 00:07:49.610
A lot of times your CPU is idle, right?

157
00:07:49.610 --> 00:07:53.348
And even when it's busy it's
not 100% busy, it's 70% busy.

158
00:07:53.348 --> 00:07:57.130
Well, if it's 70% busy,
that means it's 30% idle.

159
00:07:57.130 --> 00:07:59.230
I've got available resources, right?

160
00:07:59.230 --> 00:08:02.146
So that's what percent
processor time measures,

161
00:08:02.146 --> 00:08:06.160
is how much time the processor is
actually occupied doing something.

162
00:08:06.160 --> 00:08:10.788
And if it's pegged out all of the time,
our server might be running slower than it

163
00:08:10.788 --> 00:08:14.000
should be because we've
exceeded what that CPU can do.

164
