00:08:14.000 --> 00:08:17.860
And you might need to go to multiple
CPUs or higher cores or faster CPUs,

165
00:08:17.860 --> 00:08:18.680
or whatever.

166
00:08:18.680 --> 00:08:21.790
But at a minimum,
you know that there is an issue.

167
00:08:21.790 --> 00:08:25.950
Now, we need to monitor the CPU on both
mailbox and client access servers, right?

168
00:08:25.950 --> 00:08:27.400
It's important on both sides.

169
00:08:27.400 --> 00:08:29.480
But on a client access server especially.

170
00:08:29.480 --> 00:08:32.420
That is where a lot of your
processor intensive work happens.

171
00:08:32.420 --> 00:08:35.520
So that's one that we definitely
want to keep track of.

172
00:08:35.520 --> 00:08:37.852
A few other things in addition to that.

173
00:08:37.852 --> 00:08:42.989
There's another counter called
the processor queue length.

174
00:08:42.989 --> 00:08:44.897
And the processor queue length,

175
00:08:44.897 --> 00:08:49.640
that is basically how many programs
are waiting in line to get to your CPU.

176
00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.890
Now modern CPUs are fast.

177
00:08:51.890 --> 00:08:53.930
They do millions of operations per second.

178
00:08:53.930 --> 00:08:56.720
They are really impressively fast.

179
00:08:56.720 --> 00:08:59.190
But they get busy and
sometimes you have to wait.

180
00:08:59.190 --> 00:09:01.210
And so, if I add in this other category.

181
00:09:01.210 --> 00:09:06.390
I'm just gonna go in to Add Counters and
I'm gonna find the Processor section.

182
00:09:07.460 --> 00:09:10.540
So I'm looking for
not Process but Processor.

183
00:09:10.540 --> 00:09:11.528
There we go.

184
00:09:11.528 --> 00:09:17.270
And inside a Processor we can find in
here the Processor Queue Length and

185
00:09:17.270 --> 00:09:19.820
oh sorry,
this one's actually not under processor.

186
00:09:19.820 --> 00:09:21.138
It's one of that they kind of moved off.

187
00:09:21.138 --> 00:09:22.690
I was wondering why it wasn't there.

188
00:09:22.690 --> 00:09:25.040
If we go and find system.

189
00:09:25.040 --> 00:09:25.870
There we go.

190
00:09:25.870 --> 00:09:29.110
If you're in the processor queue it means
you haven't gotten to the processor yet.

191
00:09:29.110 --> 00:09:31.482
So that's why it's not under
the processor section, and

192
00:09:31.482 --> 00:09:33.140
so we have to find it under system.

193
00:09:33.140 --> 00:09:37.140
It's not necessarily intuitive,
but it does make some sense.

194
00:09:37.140 --> 00:09:42.600
And if we go under system, we'll find that
processor queue length and there it is.

195
00:09:42.600 --> 00:09:43.730
Processor queue length.

196
00:09:43.730 --> 00:09:47.010
So this is how many programs are waiting
in line to get to the processor.

197
00:09:47.010 --> 00:09:51.520
Now remember, when I went to [LAUGH]
percent processor time, when we went

198
00:09:51.520 --> 00:09:56.980
there, it actually let me pick
individual cores if I wanted to, right?

199
00:09:56.980 --> 00:10:00.350
But here I can't and the reason is
these haven't made it to the CPU.

200
00:10:00.350 --> 00:10:02.040
They don't care what core they go to,
they're just waiting for

201
00:10:02.040 --> 00:10:04.980
some core to open up somewhere, right?

202
00:10:04.980 --> 00:10:07.030
And that's this processor queue length.

203
00:10:07.030 --> 00:10:11.530
As a rule of thumb, Microsoft says
this number should not be above 10 for

204
00:10:11.530 --> 00:10:12.570
any length of time.

205
00:10:12.570 --> 00:10:13.470
All right?

206
00:10:13.470 --> 00:10:15.010
Expect to see some pop in here.

207
00:10:15.010 --> 00:10:18.200
There's always gonna be programs waiting
for that chance to get to the CPU.

208
00:10:18.200 --> 00:10:21.700
But if it's over ten for
a consistent period of time

209
00:10:21.700 --> 00:10:24.380
that usually indicates that
your processor is saturated.

210
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:28.470
That you need more cores, or
you need more physical CPUs, or

211
00:10:28.470 --> 00:10:30.550
you need to just add more
client access servers and

212
00:10:30.550 --> 00:10:34.650
start distributing your load and take
some of the pressure off of this server.

213
00:10:34.650 --> 00:10:35.190
All right.

214
00:10:35.190 --> 00:10:37.940
On a client access server,
this is a really important one to watch.

215
00:10:37.940 --> 00:10:40.060
On a mailbox server, it's still important.

216
00:10:40.060 --> 00:10:41.350
Right, it's not unimportant.

217
00:10:41.350 --> 00:10:44.510
But it's less likely that you'll see
this thing pegged out, all right.

218
00:10:44.510 --> 00:10:46.200
So that's kind of the CPU side.

219
00:10:46.200 --> 00:10:49.720
And I'm working this from the angle of,
when you monitor a server,

220
00:10:49.720 --> 00:10:51.220
there's the big four, right.

221
00:10:51.220 --> 00:10:53.980
CPU, memory, disk, network, right.

222
00:10:53.980 --> 00:10:58.080
So on the CPU side, those are the two
counters that are really handy.

223
00:10:58.080 --> 00:11:00.190
On the memory side,

224
00:11:00.190 --> 00:11:03.290
we actually have quite a few different
counters that we can look for.

225
00:11:03.290 --> 00:11:05.740
On the memory side, I'm not really worried

226
00:11:05.740 --> 00:11:09.290
if my Exchange Server is running
at 100% memory consumption.

227
00:11:09.290 --> 00:11:11.000
A lot of people freak out about that,
right?

228
00:11:11.000 --> 00:11:17.360
If you have 32 gigs of RAM in your mailbox
server, and it's using 31 gigs of RAM.

229
00:11:17.360 --> 00:11:19.100
Is that freak out time?

230
00:11:19.100 --> 00:11:19.710
Maybe.

231
00:11:19.710 --> 00:11:21.690
For some people it is,
for some people it isn't.

232
00:11:21.690 --> 00:11:25.560
For me, I look at it and I say, wow,
that server's using its resources wisely.

233
00:11:25.560 --> 00:11:26.100
Right?

234
00:11:26.100 --> 00:11:29.380
Caches much data into RAM as you can so
you never have to go to the hard drive.

235
00:11:29.380 --> 00:11:30.140
I love it.

236
00:11:30.140 --> 00:11:30.880
All right.

237
00:11:30.880 --> 00:11:34.660
So the only time you really have
a problem is when you're using

238
00:11:34.660 --> 00:11:36.610
more memory than you have.

239
00:11:36.610 --> 00:11:39.130
I know I've got 32 gigs
of physical memory, and

240
00:11:39.130 --> 00:11:41.860
I'm using 36 gigs of memory, okay?

241
00:11:41.860 --> 00:11:45.070
How did it magically
create those four gigs?

242
00:11:45.070 --> 00:11:48.080
Well, it's not magic,
it's using your hard drive, right?

243
00:11:48.080 --> 00:11:51.220
It's swapping to a page
file on the hard drive.

244
00:11:51.220 --> 00:11:55.440
Unfortunately when you measure the speed
of memory you measure it in nanoseconds.

245
00:11:55.440 --> 00:11:58.210
When you measure the speed of hard
drives you measure it in milliseconds.

246
00:11:58.210 --> 00:12:01.200
Hard drives are significantly
slower than memory.

247
00:12:01.200 --> 00:12:02.780
And so that's a problem.

248
00:12:02.780 --> 00:12:06.770
That means when we're using the hard
drive as memory, we're using slow memory.

249
00:12:06.770 --> 00:12:09.870
So I don't necessarily care
how much memory I am using.

250
00:12:09.870 --> 00:12:12.440
What I care about is whether I'm paging or
not.

251
00:12:12.440 --> 00:12:15.800
I want to know if I am hitting a page
file, if I'm hitting the hard drive.

252
00:12:15.800 --> 00:12:17.840
If I'm hitting the hard
drive that's a problem.

253
00:12:17.840 --> 00:12:19.738
I need to add more memory, all right.

254
00:12:19.738 --> 00:12:23.910
But if I'm not using the hard drive and
I'm running it 95% memory utilization,

255
00:12:23.910 --> 00:12:27.890
I'm actually okay with that as long
as I'm not using the hard drive.

256
00:12:27.890 --> 00:12:30.070
Now if I'm anticipating
spikes down the road,

257
00:12:30.070 --> 00:12:32.040
I might want to go ahead
an upgrade anyway.

258
00:12:32.040 --> 00:12:35.660
But it's not like urgent red light,
let's get some memory right now.

259
00:12:35.660 --> 00:12:37.210
I can take my time.

260
00:12:37.210 --> 00:12:39.460
But we just want to make sure
we're not paging the hard drive.

261
00:12:39.460 --> 00:12:41.060
So that's really what
we want to watch for.

262
00:12:41.060 --> 00:12:44.320
And an easy way to spot that is
a neat little counter we can pull.

263
00:12:44.320 --> 00:12:45.490
It's under the memory section.

264
00:12:45.490 --> 00:12:48.490
Let me go here and find memory.

265
00:12:49.900 --> 00:12:50.680
And notice these.

266
00:12:50.680 --> 00:12:53.430
I'm not looking for
these under the exchange section.

267
00:12:53.430 --> 00:12:56.910
These are pretty standard across
any server implementation, right?

268
00:12:56.910 --> 00:12:58.400
So if you've got a file server,

269
00:12:58.400 --> 00:13:01.030
a domain controller, whatever,
a lot of these can be monitored too.

270
00:13:01.030 --> 00:13:06.310
The counter I'm looking for is page reads
and we'll find it in here somewhere.

271
00:13:06.310 --> 00:13:10.090
Which is, let's see Page.

272
00:13:12.220 --> 00:13:13.750
I will find it.

273
00:13:13.750 --> 00:13:15.750
There it is.
Page reads per second.

274
00:13:15.750 --> 00:13:18.060
What is a page read?

275
00:13:18.060 --> 00:13:21.660
A page read is when I look to RAM for
something and it wasn't there and

276
00:13:21.660 --> 00:13:24.310
I had to go to the hard drive for it.

277
00:13:24.310 --> 00:13:26.560
Having a page file is not a bad thing.

278
00:13:26.560 --> 00:13:29.090
Every server has a page file unless
you've turned it off yourself.

279
00:13:29.090 --> 00:13:30.400
Which is somewhat dangerous.

280
00:13:30.400 --> 00:13:32.170
Everybody's got a page file.

281
00:13:32.170 --> 00:13:33.940
But, it doesn't you're using it.

282
00:13:33.940 --> 00:13:37.850
But if you get reads on the page file,
that means you're using it,

283
00:13:37.850 --> 00:13:39.120
you're actually using it.

284
00:13:39.120 --> 00:13:42.230
This is a great way to see whether
you're paging the disk and

285
00:13:42.230 --> 00:13:45.900
if you see this counter registering
a high quantity of numbers for

286
00:13:45.900 --> 00:13:49.250
any period of time, that means you were
reading from a high drive that whole time

287
00:13:49.250 --> 00:13:51.900
and your server was running
slower than it should.

288
00:13:51.900 --> 00:13:53.770
So that's a great one to monitor.

289
00:13:53.770 --> 00:13:56.250
Definitely monitor this
one on a mailbox server.

290
00:13:56.250 --> 00:13:58.390
On a client access server,
it's not so important.

291
00:13:58.390 --> 00:14:00.590
Client access servers they
use a lot of CPU ram.

292
00:14:00.590 --> 00:14:03.290
They don't do too crazy on, but they can.

293
00:14:03.290 --> 00:14:04.900
Right?
They run IAS.

294
00:14:04.900 --> 00:14:06.980
And IAS creates these workerflows, for

295
00:14:06.980 --> 00:14:09.790
everybody that opens up sessions
through the client access server.

296
00:14:09.790 --> 00:14:17.370
So if the server gets overwhelmed, it can
create too many of these worker processes.

297
00:14:17.370 --> 00:14:21.160
And it ends up eating up the RAM, and
starting to write to hard drive and

298
00:14:21.160 --> 00:14:22.140
getting slow there too.

299
00:14:22.140 --> 00:14:24.930
And so you can add more client
access servers to alleviate that.

300
00:14:24.930 --> 00:14:26.960
But it's definitely important
on a mailbox server.

301
00:14:28.880 --> 00:14:30.300
All right, now I could stop there.

302
00:14:30.300 --> 00:14:31.560
That's usually the one that I look for.

303
00:14:31.560 --> 00:14:33.640
But we could jump for a few other things.

304
00:14:33.640 --> 00:14:37.740
For example, right here under
memory there's pages output.

305
00:14:37.740 --> 00:14:42.040
And pages output per second,
let's see if we can find that one.

306
00:14:42.040 --> 00:14:44.650
Pages output per second, there we go.

307
00:14:44.650 --> 00:14:49.790
That is when your system takes data from
RAM and writes it to the hard drive.

308
00:14:49.790 --> 00:14:52.590
So I've got some data in RAM
that hasn't been used for

309
00:14:52.590 --> 00:14:56.270
a few moments, but it's been used recent
enough that I still want it ready.

310
00:14:56.270 --> 00:14:57.822
So we write it to the page file.

311
00:14:57.822 --> 00:15:00.180
All right, this is when we put
things into the page file.

312
00:15:00.180 --> 00:15:04.230
Now, I'm not so worried about
putting things into the page file,

313
00:15:04.230 --> 00:15:07.130
because it's the system writing it,
the end users don't see that.

314
00:15:07.130 --> 00:15:09.930
I'm really worried about when I
retrieve data from the page file,

315
00:15:09.930 --> 00:15:11.430
that's when we see slowness.

316
00:15:11.430 --> 00:15:14.380
So, you don't necessarily need to monitor
both, but just remember this one's there.

317
00:15:14.380 --> 00:15:17.908
If you wanna catch when you're server
writes something to that page file,

318
00:15:17.908 --> 00:15:19.766
Page outputs per second's a good one.

319
00:15:19.766 --> 00:15:22.052
All right.

320
00:15:22.052 --> 00:15:24.340
Disk I/O.

321
00:15:24.340 --> 00:15:28.600
On a mailbox server, disk I/O is nine
times out of ten your bottleneck.

322
00:15:28.600 --> 00:15:31.020
Right?
If you look at a server, processor,

323
00:15:31.020 --> 00:15:32.960
memory, network, hard drive.

324
00:15:32.960 --> 00:15:36.590
Hard drive is typically the slowest
component in your system.

325
00:15:36.590 --> 00:15:39.640
SSDs are changing that, but
if you're on traditional spinning media,

326
00:15:39.640 --> 00:15:42.630
your hard drives are usually
the slowest device in your system.

327
00:15:42.630 --> 00:15:45.760
So when our exchange server
sees me running slow,

328
00:15:45.760 --> 00:15:47.690
it's not normally
the client access server.

329
00:15:47.690 --> 00:15:50.480
It could if the CPU is pegged
down on the client access server.

330
00:15:50.480 --> 00:15:53.079
But more often than not, the client
access server is just turning around and

331
00:15:53.079 --> 00:15:54.102
accessing a mailbox server.

332
00:15:54.102 --> 00:15:57.049
And if the mailbox server has
over saturated its' disks,

333
00:15:57.049 --> 00:16:00.961
if it's reaching across a scuzzy
controller or fiber channel controller and

334
00:16:00.961 --> 00:16:04.992
it's just used all of the available
bandwidth Then, it's gonna wait and now,

335
00:16:04.992 --> 00:16:06.884
it's taking time to get to the disk.

336
00:16:06.884 --> 00:16:09.330
And so, we've got a couple
of good counters for this.

337
00:16:09.330 --> 00:16:11.800
On a mailbox server,
these are really a must.

338
00:16:11.800 --> 00:16:15.020
The number one counter
that we need to watch for

339
00:16:15.020 --> 00:16:16.980
is what's called the disk queue length.

340
00:16:16.980 --> 00:16:19.810
I talk about the process of queue length
for programs that are waiting in line to

341
00:16:19.810 --> 00:16:22.460
get to the CPU,
disk queue length is the same thing.

342
00:16:22.460 --> 00:16:24.870
The number of programs waiting
in line to get to the disk.

343
00:16:24.870 --> 00:16:26.500
But this one is a little bit trickier,
right?

344
00:16:26.500 --> 00:16:29.160
I'm gonna go to the physical disk section.

345
00:16:29.160 --> 00:16:33.620
Let me just find that in
here probably in the ps.

346
00:16:33.620 --> 00:16:36.060
So I'll find physical disk.

347
00:16:36.060 --> 00:16:37.130
And under physical disk,

348
00:16:37.130 --> 00:16:40.700
I'll find that disk queue length
counter in it here somewhere.

349
00:16:42.840 --> 00:16:46.860
And it is, let's see,
it's average, disk queue length.

350
00:16:46.860 --> 00:16:48.850
Average disk queue length.

351
00:16:48.850 --> 00:16:53.620
If you just choose it and add it in, the
number it gives you is not very useful and

352
00:16:53.620 --> 00:16:56.150
that's because it's rolling
all your disks together.

353
00:16:56.150 --> 00:16:58.960
You really need to monitor
your disks individually,

354
00:16:58.960 --> 00:17:03.430
because you'll probably have an operating
system disk, a page file disk,

355
00:17:03.430 --> 00:17:06.560
a transaction log disk and
a mailbox database disk.

356
00:17:06.560 --> 00:17:08.670
Right?
You'll likely have four separate disks.

357
00:17:08.670 --> 00:17:12.070
And those disks might
actually be RAID arrays.

358
00:17:12.070 --> 00:17:14.860
So your operating system,
your page file and your transaction logs,

359
00:17:14.860 --> 00:17:17.300
those might all be RAID 1 mirrors.

360
00:17:17.300 --> 00:17:18.100
Right?

361
00:17:18.100 --> 00:17:23.180
But then your mailbox database might be
RAID 5 or RAID 10, different type of RAID.

362
00:17:23.180 --> 00:17:26.650
It just depends on how well you wanted
to tune the performance on the system.

363
00:17:26.650 --> 00:17:29.310
So when we monitor these,
the disk queue length is affected by that.

364
00:17:30.360 --> 00:17:32.960
The disk queue length is based on

365
00:17:32.960 --> 00:17:36.120
how many programs are waiting
to get to the hard drive, right?

366
00:17:36.120 --> 00:17:38.690
To write or read from the hard drive.

367
00:17:38.690 --> 00:17:43.380
A traditional spinning media has a little
mechanical arm that moves around on it.

368
00:17:43.380 --> 00:17:45.320
And the arm can only be
in one place at a time.

369
00:17:45.320 --> 00:17:47.130
So it can only do one thing at a time.

370
00:17:47.130 --> 00:17:51.680
If I've got a single drive, and it's doing
one operation, everybody else has to wait.

371
00:17:52.770 --> 00:17:55.570
But what if I have a RAID 5 array?

372
00:17:55.570 --> 00:17:58.190
And my RAID 5 array has 6 drives in it.

373
00:17:58.190 --> 00:18:00.690
Well, we'll chalk one of
those drives up to parody.

374
00:18:00.690 --> 00:18:03.390
And in the other five drives, technically,

375
00:18:03.390 --> 00:18:06.440
I have five heads that can all
be reading at the same time.

376
00:18:06.440 --> 00:18:08.660
I can be doing five things at once.

377
00:18:08.660 --> 00:18:10.100
It doesn't really work at that way.

378
00:18:10.100 --> 00:18:12.770
Because you take one operation,
and you spread it across all five.

379
00:18:12.770 --> 00:18:14.940
But it means they get
done five times faster.

380
00:18:14.940 --> 00:18:19.340
So, Microsoft's rule of thumb on this one,
when you're monitoring your disk queuing,

381
00:18:19.340 --> 00:18:23.700
monitor your disks individually, so
you might have a C, D, E, and F drive.

382
00:18:23.700 --> 00:18:25.740
Monitor them individually and

383
00:18:25.740 --> 00:18:29.620
then what you're looking for is the number
should really never be above 2.

384
00:18:29.620 --> 00:18:35.080
You never wanna see more than two programs
waiting in line, for a single disk.

385
00:18:35.080 --> 00:18:40.050
That means if it's a RAID five array with
six discs, take one out for parody right

386
00:18:40.050 --> 00:18:43.860
and so you've got five disks left,
you need to multiply five by two so ten.

387
00:18:43.860 --> 00:18:46.600
And the way Microsoft always phrases it is

388
00:18:46.600 --> 00:18:50.320
two times the number of
spindles in the disc.

389
00:18:50.320 --> 00:18:53.240
And this really applies to SSD
also although SSD can do some

390
00:18:53.240 --> 00:18:55.700
cool things where it can write to
more than one place at the same time.

391
00:18:55.700 --> 00:18:59.450
If you have dual channel stuff
it can really get kind of crazy.

392
00:18:59.450 --> 00:19:04.490
But, the basic rule of thumb, you don't
want to see this queue get above two for

393
00:19:04.490 --> 00:19:07.250
each individual physical
disc that you've got.

394
00:19:07.250 --> 00:19:11.200
So keep that in mind, this number is gonna
be a little bit different based on your

395
00:19:11.200 --> 00:19:12.839
physical architecture behind the scenes.

396
00:19:15.130 --> 00:19:17.460
Now that's the one I normally watch for.

397
00:19:17.460 --> 00:19:19.950
I'm not normally concerned
about how fast or

398
00:19:19.950 --> 00:19:23.120
how slow the disk is,
as long as I don't have rights piling up.

399
00:19:23.120 --> 00:19:25.470
And the disk queue length shows
you when things are piling up,

400
00:19:25.470 --> 00:19:27.310
that's when you know you've got a problem.

401
00:19:27.310 --> 00:19:29.710
But we might be concerned about speed,
right?

402
00:19:29.710 --> 00:19:32.020
I might want to know how
fast my reads are happening,

403
00:19:32.020 --> 00:19:33.200
how fast my writes are happening.

404
00:19:33.200 --> 00:19:36.150
And so we can spot that too, there's
performance counters buried in here.

405
00:19:36.150 --> 00:19:40.210
I'm gonna add this queue length and then
I'm gonna look for two other ones here.

406
00:19:40.210 --> 00:19:45.350
You'll find the average disk read and
average disk writes per second.

407
00:19:45.350 --> 00:19:47.280
They're up toward the top of this one.

408
00:19:48.510 --> 00:19:53.390
Average disk reads per second and
writes per second.

409
00:19:53.390 --> 00:19:54.600
These two guys right here.

410
00:19:54.600 --> 00:19:58.370
So if I want to see how much
activity is happening on the system.

411
00:19:58.370 --> 00:20:00.010
How many reads am I doing per second?

412
00:20:00.010 --> 00:20:01.730
How many writes am I doing per second?

413
00:20:01.730 --> 00:20:05.610
Now I can monitor how active those drives
are, and I can get a chance to see that.

414
00:20:05.610 --> 00:20:07.690
And you can monitor
the write queue length and

415
00:20:07.690 --> 00:20:10.540
the read queue length separately
if you wanna address it that way.

416
00:20:10.540 --> 00:20:12.430
I don't normally worry about that,
but you can.

417
00:20:12.430 --> 00:20:16.050
So you can really get into the nitty
gritty details of that system.

418
00:20:16.050 --> 00:20:17.400
On a client access server,

419
00:20:17.400 --> 00:20:19.910
you might choose to ignore
this performance altogether.

420
00:20:19.910 --> 00:20:23.320
But on a mailbox server, you really gotta
monitor this one, it's really important.

421
00:20:25.430 --> 00:20:29.550
All right, now if you see a high
queue length, what does it mean?

422
00:20:29.550 --> 00:20:32.100
I mentioned when you have the CPU,
the processor queue length,

423
00:20:32.100 --> 00:20:34.210
when it's really high,
you need more processors.

424
00:20:34.210 --> 00:20:36.770
Either more cores or more CPUs.

425
00:20:36.770 --> 00:20:40.290
Or you can roll out more servers and
spread your clients out.

426
00:20:40.290 --> 00:20:41.960
With a client access server, that's easy.

427
00:20:41.960 --> 00:20:43.570
Add more client access servers.

428
00:20:43.570 --> 00:20:45.310
On a mailbox server, it's a little harder.

429
00:20:45.310 --> 00:20:49.750
You need to add more mailbox databases and
spread your mailboxes out.

430
00:20:49.750 --> 00:20:51.330
What about disk queue length?

431
00:20:51.330 --> 00:20:55.330
Well, disk queue length, if it starts
to add up, it's gonna be one of.

432
00:20:55.330 --> 00:20:58.700
Well, it's a number of causes but
there's really only two solutions.

433
00:20:58.700 --> 00:21:01.300
Solution one is to add more discs.

434
00:21:01.300 --> 00:21:05.520
If it's a RAID five array with six discs,
I'll put up to ten discs.

435
00:21:05.520 --> 00:21:06.700
You're adding more spindles.

436
00:21:06.700 --> 00:21:09.280
More spindles means it can
do more operations at once.

437
00:21:09.280 --> 00:21:10.980
It can get more work done.

438
00:21:10.980 --> 00:21:12.900
The more discs in your array the better.

439
00:21:12.900 --> 00:21:17.470
A lot of people don't realize that, that
if you have a RAID five array with three,

440
00:21:17.470 --> 00:21:22.320
three terabyte drives versus a RAID
five well, three terabytes job, right?

441
00:21:22.320 --> 00:21:24.060
That's be what, nine terabytes.

442
00:21:24.060 --> 00:21:27.070
Or if I had five two terabyte drives.

443
00:21:27.070 --> 00:21:29.000
That would be ten terabytes.

444
00:21:29.000 --> 00:21:32.990
Well the five two terabyte drives will
actually perform better than the three

445
00:21:32.990 --> 00:21:36.360
three terabyte drives cuz I've got
five spindles as opposed to three.

446
00:21:36.360 --> 00:21:37.170
Better performance.

447
00:21:37.170 --> 00:21:37.930
Right?
These are things that we

448
00:21:37.930 --> 00:21:39.240
can kinda look for.

449
00:21:39.240 --> 00:21:40.460
So that's solution one.

450
00:21:40.460 --> 00:21:43.500
You throw more disks at it.

451
00:21:43.500 --> 00:21:47.480
Solution two is to either
upgrade our storage,

452
00:21:47.480 --> 00:21:53.490
go from scuzzy to fiber channel,
or to 10k drives to 15k drives.

453
00:21:53.490 --> 00:21:56.840
Whatever it is to get faster architecture.

454
00:21:56.840 --> 00:21:58.440
You'll see this with IScuzzy a lot.

455
00:21:58.440 --> 00:22:00.430
People think IScuzzy is great.

456
00:22:00.430 --> 00:22:02.990
Well, at the end of the day
IScuzzy really sucks, and

457
00:22:02.990 --> 00:22:05.430
it just doesn't give you good performance.

458
00:22:05.430 --> 00:22:09.105
So, IScuzzy is fine for
non critical things, but for

459
00:22:09.105 --> 00:22:12.330
a mailbox server IScuzzy
is throttling you.

460
00:22:12.330 --> 00:22:13.670
You end up with this bottleneck.

461
00:22:13.670 --> 00:22:14.340
It's really bad.

462
00:22:14.340 --> 00:22:19.240
And you'll see the queue length start
to go up for it because of just nature.

463
00:22:19.240 --> 00:22:23.290
But if you move to fiber channel,
you move to direct attached SCSI,

464
00:22:23.290 --> 00:22:26.580
you're gonna get a huge
performance increase over that.

465
00:22:26.580 --> 00:22:29.900
The other option would be to add more
than one mailbox database server,

466
00:22:29.900 --> 00:22:33.530
create more than one mailbox database,
and spread your mailboxes over it.

467
00:22:33.530 --> 00:22:36.580
Or you could even just have one server and
just add more storage that was separate.

468
00:22:36.580 --> 00:22:39.420
So you've got database one
on one set of drives and

469
00:22:39.420 --> 00:22:42.870
database two on a second set of
hard drives and spread your users.

470
00:22:42.870 --> 00:22:46.150
Be careful if you do that though,
because if you're using a shared storage

471
00:22:46.150 --> 00:22:48.580
controller you might
still have contention.

472
00:22:48.580 --> 00:22:51.853
So ideally you'd have two separate storage
controllers tied to these separate banks

473
00:22:51.853 --> 00:22:53.671
of drives, and
that starts to get expensive and

474
00:22:53.671 --> 00:22:55.635
you might as well add
another server at that point.

475
00:22:55.635 --> 00:22:57.180
It's kind of a tough decision.

476
00:22:58.780 --> 00:23:04.300
All right, let's see that was I gotta
keep track of this, CPU Memory Network.

477
00:23:04.300 --> 00:23:07.690
Well no, I left off network,
shoot, CPU Memory Disk,

478
00:23:07.690 --> 00:23:08.770
that's what we talked about so far.

479
00:23:08.770 --> 00:23:09.870
Let's talk about Network now right?

480
00:23:09.870 --> 00:23:14.210
Network's important, on the Network side
we usually just care about bandwidth it's

481
00:23:14.210 --> 00:23:17.140
really easy, you got a network adaptor in
your system you monitor it's bandwidth and

482
00:23:17.140 --> 00:23:18.160
you're done right?

483
00:23:18.160 --> 00:23:22.620
If I've got a gigabit card, and I see I'm
running at 100% utilization all the time,

484
00:23:22.620 --> 00:23:23.310
I've got a problem.

485
00:23:23.310 --> 00:23:27.340
I need to add more bandwidth, I could add
another gig card and bond them together or

486
00:23:27.340 --> 00:23:31.250
bump up to a ten gig card, go crazy,
all sorts of options that are out there.

487
00:23:31.250 --> 00:23:34.380
But we need to have a handle
on whether that's occurring.

488
00:23:34.380 --> 00:23:39.030
So you can jump to the network section,
so let me just find network in here

489
00:23:40.130 --> 00:23:45.310
And we can jump into our network adapter,
our network interface.

490
00:23:45.310 --> 00:23:47.930
Now, why two separate values, right?

491
00:23:47.930 --> 00:23:52.120
Well, usually a network adapter just
has one interface on it, right?

492
00:23:52.120 --> 00:23:54.770
But in most servers today
you get those dual mix,

493
00:23:54.770 --> 00:23:57.210
where you have two interfaces
on the same adapter.

494
00:23:57.210 --> 00:23:58.851
And so that's why we have
these separate entities.

495
00:23:58.851 --> 00:24:02.010
One's the adaptor itself,
where you've got like a PCI bus and

496
00:24:02.010 --> 00:24:04.511
a TCP offload engine that
you have to deal with.

497
00:24:04.511 --> 00:24:07.661
And then the other ones,
the actual interface itself.

498
00:24:07.661 --> 00:24:10.816
Now which one should we monitor,
cuz they have the same counters?

499
00:24:10.816 --> 00:24:12.858
It depends.

500
00:24:12.858 --> 00:24:15.220
If it's an expensive card,
which in a server,

501
00:24:15.220 --> 00:24:17.653
you are usually going to
use the expensive ones.

502
00:24:17.653 --> 00:24:19.197
You might have two interfaces and

503
00:24:19.197 --> 00:24:22.296
they have two completely separate
controllers on that one board.

504
00:24:22.296 --> 00:24:26.708
And so in that scenario,
you'd really wanna monitor the interface.

505
00:24:26.708 --> 00:24:30.350
But if it's a cheap dual interface card,
there's some companies that make them and

506
00:24:30.350 --> 00:24:31.388
they cost like $50.

507
00:24:31.388 --> 00:24:35.375
If you've got one of those,
there's probably only one controller for

508
00:24:35.375 --> 00:24:36.577
the two interfaces.

509
00:24:36.577 --> 00:24:38.919
And so
at that point if you monitor an interface,

510
00:24:38.919 --> 00:24:42.591
you're not getting real data,
you need to monitor the controller itself.

511
00:24:42.591 --> 00:24:44.351
So that's why we've got
those two entities and

512
00:24:44.351 --> 00:24:46.074
you need to make sure you
choose the right one.

513
00:24:46.074 --> 00:24:49.499
But if you've got like Intel mix or
Broadcom, they do a great job

514
00:24:49.499 --> 00:24:53.686
of providing optimized controllers for
each interface and so you'll wanna go

515
00:24:53.686 --> 00:24:57.949
with network interface and you can just
monitor bytes received and bytes sent.

516
00:24:57.949 --> 00:24:59.889
Those are really the two we wanna monitor.

517
00:24:59.889 --> 00:25:04.173
I know a lot of people monitor bytes
total, but if you've got a gig card,

518
00:25:04.173 --> 00:25:05.728
a gig card is full duplex.

519
00:25:05.728 --> 00:25:10.187
So you've got 1 gig in and
1 gig out simultaneous.

520
00:25:10.187 --> 00:25:12.009
So if you're monitoring bytes total,

521
00:25:12.009 --> 00:25:14.989
you might see that you're running
at a gigabyte of bandwidth and

522
00:25:14.989 --> 00:25:19.630
think that you're out of bandwidth when
in actuality you're only halfway there.

523
00:25:19.630 --> 00:25:23.631
So it's a better idea to monitor
them separately, received and sent.

524
00:25:23.631 --> 00:25:26.296
If you've got a gigabyte
card that's full duplex,

525
00:25:26.296 --> 00:25:29.627
you can receive a gig of data while
you're sending a gig of data and

526
00:25:29.627 --> 00:25:32.674
you'll be fine that gives you
a more clear understanding.

527
00:25:32.674 --> 00:25:34.636
It also helps you with
the troubleshooting.

528
00:25:34.636 --> 00:25:37.273
Am I receiving a gig of data?

529
00:25:37.273 --> 00:25:41.612
That's pretty difficult to do with email
to have a gigabyte of email coming in

530
00:25:41.612 --> 00:25:43.693
per second, that's pretty tough.

531
00:25:43.693 --> 00:25:49.172
I'm sorry, a gigabit let me use my right
term or no, actually, this is bytes shoot.

532
00:25:49.172 --> 00:25:51.332
So it is gigabytes, there we go.

533
00:25:51.332 --> 00:25:54.837
To have a gigabyte of data going
out though, that's not uncommon.

534
00:25:54.837 --> 00:25:57.660
If I have a bunch of clients connected and
they're all checking their email,

535
00:25:57.660 --> 00:26:00.757
they're all downloading attachments,
I could be pushing out all that bandwidth.

536
00:26:00.757 --> 00:26:02.847
So we wanna make sure we monitor those.

537
00:26:02.847 --> 00:26:06.092
Definitely a good one to kinda keep an eye
on and then down here at the bottom,

538
00:26:06.092 --> 00:26:08.189
you can choose the adapter
you're monitoring.

539
00:26:08.189 --> 00:26:14.456
So I'll monitor my Intel NIC And I'll add
those in, so I'm monitoring those too.

540
00:26:14.456 --> 00:26:17.485
Now everything that I've talked about so

541
00:26:17.485 --> 00:26:21.214
far, really could apply
to any Microsoft server.

542
00:26:21.214 --> 00:26:23.930
It could apply to a domain controller,
a file server, whatever.

543
00:26:23.930 --> 00:26:28.873
These are the big four, the things that we
need to monitor, but there's another set

544
00:26:28.873 --> 00:26:33.346
of counters that I like to monitor that
I call my client experience monitor.

545
00:26:33.346 --> 00:26:35.110
Client experience, what is that?

546
00:26:35.110 --> 00:26:38.806
If I fire up Outlook and I wanna open up
my email, it's gotta connect to a client

547
00:26:38.806 --> 00:26:42.502
access server, the client access server
has to connect to a mailbox server and

548
00:26:42.502 --> 00:26:45.000
then render my email and get it to me.

549
00:26:45.000 --> 00:26:46.253
How long does that take?

550
00:26:46.253 --> 00:26:47.776
That's client experience.

551
00:26:47.776 --> 00:26:50.038
And client experience,
in this case is a little bit unique.

552
00:26:50.038 --> 00:26:54.907
It's different than a file server or
a web server, an Active Directory domain

553
00:26:54.907 --> 00:26:59.554
controller, it's different than those
guys and so we have a special set of

554
00:26:59.554 --> 00:27:04.016
counters that are really useful to
monitor for just Exchange servers.

555
00:27:04.016 --> 00:27:07.497
But as far as everything else,
these guys right here.

556
00:27:07.497 --> 00:27:13.512
This is kind of our big four,
CPU, memory, disk, network.

557
00:27:13.512 --> 00:27:18.307
You wanna make sure you're monitoring
those and know what your good days are, so

558
00:27:18.307 --> 00:27:21.988
you can then compare those to
a bad day and see the difference.

559
00:27:21.988 --> 00:27:24.807
Well, I wanna tackle those
Exchange specific ones, but

560
00:27:24.807 --> 00:27:26.991
I'm a little short on
time on this segment.

561
00:27:26.991 --> 00:27:28.336
So why don't we do this?

562
00:27:28.336 --> 00:27:31.819
We're gonna to go for an unprecedented
part three for this episode and

563
00:27:31.819 --> 00:27:34.073
we'll jump back into Exchange monitoring.

564
00:27:34.073 --> 00:27:37.713
We'll get a chance to see those
specific counters and how they work and

565
00:27:37.713 --> 00:27:41.600
get us to that point where we can start
to take that baseline of our system and

566
00:27:41.600 --> 00:27:44.707
know that things are running
the way they're supposed to.

567
00:27:44.707 --> 00:27:48.851
So stay tuned, we've got part three
coming up as for this one though,

568
00:27:48.851 --> 00:27:50.407
signing off for ITProTV.

569
00:27:50.407 --> 00:27:52.915
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

570
00:27:52.915 --> 00:27:58.920
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don wraps up demonstrating how to monitor Microsoft Exchange 2013 Client Access and Mailbox servers. He shifts from the standard performance counters covered in part 2, to “customer experience” counters that better reflect the end-user experience when sending and receiving email. He discusses ways to detect resource limitations in OWA, Outlook and SMTP.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintenance Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.600
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.600 --> 00:00:13.068
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:13.068 --> 00:00:15.131
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.131 --> 00:00:19.590
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode Microsoft Exchange.

5
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:24.100
And in this episode we're continuing
on with our, well it was a two part

6
00:00:24.100 --> 00:00:28.150
series now three part series on monitoring
and maintaining exchange servers.

7
00:00:28.150 --> 00:00:30.700
Now if you haven't watched the other
episodes I definitely encourage you

8
00:00:30.700 --> 00:00:34.490
to do that, but in this episode we
are kind of taking a different angle

9
00:00:34.490 --> 00:00:38.570
in our last episode we saw some of the
performance counters we want to monitor.

10
00:00:38.570 --> 00:00:40.090
For really any Microsoft server.

11
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:43.430
Right?
Processor, memory, disk, and network.

12
00:00:43.430 --> 00:00:45.460
Right?
The utilization for each of those and

13
00:00:45.460 --> 00:00:47.250
what we expect them to look like.

14
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:49.670
What we need to watch out for
on those guys.

15
00:00:49.670 --> 00:00:55.670
But in this episode, I wanna look
at the exchange specific counters.

16
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:57.810
Things that are really important
to monitor on an exchange server.

17
00:00:57.810 --> 00:01:00.610
And I call this the client experience.

18
00:01:00.610 --> 00:01:03.130
So when an end user
connects to your server,

19
00:01:03.130 --> 00:01:06.930
their experiences are controlled by
a number of factors on the back end.

20
00:01:06.930 --> 00:01:10.907
Any one of which can cause their
experience to completely fail or

21
00:01:10.907 --> 00:01:15.707
be really slow, so when a user calls in
and says, hey my email is really slow.

22
00:01:15.707 --> 00:01:16.730
We need to know where to look.

23
00:01:16.730 --> 00:01:19.720
We need to know where our
potential problems could be.

24
00:01:19.720 --> 00:01:21.470
And those are the counters
we're gonna look at here.

25
00:01:22.540 --> 00:01:24.090
Well, if you didn't
watch the last episode,

26
00:01:24.090 --> 00:01:26.020
let me just kind of get
you back up to speed.

27
00:01:26.020 --> 00:01:27.500
These are the counters that
we were talking about.

28
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:28.610
We talked about some others too.

29
00:01:28.610 --> 00:01:32.860
But, you'll see where I've got some
memory, network, physical disc and

30
00:01:32.860 --> 00:01:36.400
CPU counters that are kind of added
in here in my performance monitor.

31
00:01:36.400 --> 00:01:39.520
And those are great just for
monitoring, really, any old server.

32
00:01:40.560 --> 00:01:43.770
But when it comes to
the client experience we have

33
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:46.880
some counters that are appropriate for
a mailbox database, and

34
00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:50.590
some counters that are appropriate for
a client access server.

35
00:01:50.590 --> 00:01:52.290
Let's start with the mailbox database.

36
00:01:52.290 --> 00:01:53.770
Because odds are in your network,

37
00:01:53.770 --> 00:01:56.460
if there's a bottleneck anywhere,
it's the mailbox database.

38
00:01:56.460 --> 00:01:57.690
Databases are big.

39
00:01:57.690 --> 00:01:59.940
They're complex, and
they're stored on disk.

40
00:01:59.940 --> 00:02:04.000
And disk is slow and as a result that's
usually where our bottleneck is.

41
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:05.110
But it would be nice to know that for

42
00:02:05.110 --> 00:02:09.550
a fact before we just go and
assume and turn out to be wrong.

43
00:02:09.550 --> 00:02:13.300
So let's start with counters that we
want to monitor on a mailbox database.

44
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:15.590
I'm gonna go into my performance monitor.

45
00:02:15.590 --> 00:02:18.350
And I'm just gonna hit my little green
plus here to add some more counters in,

46
00:02:18.350 --> 00:02:20.450
and we're gonna look for
some of these special counters.

47
00:02:20.450 --> 00:02:25.370
Now in the last episode, I stayed with
just standard Microsoft Windows ones.

48
00:02:25.370 --> 00:02:28.350
This time,
we're gonna do Microsoft Exchange ones.

49
00:02:28.350 --> 00:02:31.660
So, as you scroll around in the counters
here in the list you'll notice

50
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:35.390
a huge section where every
counter starts with MSExchange.

51
00:02:35.390 --> 00:02:37.690
These are the Exchange specific ones,
and that's where I wanna go.

52
00:02:37.690 --> 00:02:40.000
One of the key ones to look for

53
00:02:40.000 --> 00:02:44.990
on a database server are the counters
located as part of the information store.

54
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:47.410
So, if you scroll around in here and
look for

55
00:02:47.410 --> 00:02:51.930
the counter that's called
MS Exchange IS Store.

56
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:53.480
And I will find it right there.

57
00:02:53.480 --> 00:02:54.480
There we go.

58
00:02:54.480 --> 00:02:56.720
That's the information store service.

59
00:02:56.720 --> 00:02:59.790
And that's what's controlling your
database, your mailbox databases.

60
00:02:59.790 --> 00:03:05.360
So, if the performance here is bad,
performance on my databases are bad.

61
00:03:05.360 --> 00:03:08.530
And when you look, you can monitor
all sorts of crazy things, but

62
00:03:08.530 --> 00:03:13.820
there's one counter in here that I really
like, and it's called RPC Average Latency.

63
00:03:13.820 --> 00:03:17.900
So if I scroll down, I'll find it
probably down in the Rs somewhere.

64
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:19.930
It is very near, right there.

65
00:03:19.930 --> 00:03:21.930
RPC average latency, okay.

66
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:22.920
What is that?

67
00:03:22.920 --> 00:03:27.810
Well RPC is remote procedure call, when
somebody connects via Outlook, Outlook is

68
00:03:27.810 --> 00:03:31.420
connecting to the server via RPC over
http, it's doing a remote procedure call.

69
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:34.370
And when somebody logs
into Outlook web access,

70
00:03:34.370 --> 00:03:39.170
they hit the client access server via OWA
and the client access server proxies that

71
00:03:39.170 --> 00:03:42.310
to the back end as an RPC
call to the mailbox server.

72
00:03:42.310 --> 00:03:46.690
So our clients are typically
using RCP when they connect.

73
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:52.270
And if RPC is experiencing latency that's
gonna result in a slow experience for

74
00:03:52.270 --> 00:03:53.570
the end-user, right.

75
00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:56.820
This is a great way to monitor whether
end-users are having slow connectivity,

76
00:03:56.820 --> 00:03:59.170
because they might not notice themselves,
right.

77
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:00.030
A great example's if

78
00:04:00.030 --> 00:04:02.180
they're running Outlook they might
be running Outlook cache mode.

79
00:04:02.180 --> 00:04:03.400
It's the default.

80
00:04:03.400 --> 00:04:06.790
So they're accessing their mailbox
right there on their hard drive.

81
00:04:06.790 --> 00:04:08.720
When a new email comes in,

82
00:04:08.720 --> 00:04:10.935
they don't notice that
the server hasn't told them yet.

83
00:04:10.935 --> 00:04:12.210
Cuz they don't know the email exists yet.

84
00:04:12.210 --> 00:04:14.280
And then, all of a sudden,
they see the email come in.

85
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:16.420
They have no idea a delay happened.

86
00:04:16.420 --> 00:04:18.560
So they might not even realize it.

87
00:04:18.560 --> 00:04:19.220
Your OWA users.

88
00:04:19.220 --> 00:04:21.120
They're the ones who will
usually notice first.

89
00:04:21.120 --> 00:04:23.860
When they go to log into OWN, it takes
forever for their mailbox to load.

90
00:04:23.860 --> 00:04:25.960
Or it fails to load, and
they get a server error, right?

91
00:04:25.960 --> 00:04:30.330
Like a 500 error or some other message,
they'll know that there's a problem.

92
00:04:30.330 --> 00:04:33.990
But we can spot it early if we're
watching the RPC average latency.

93
00:04:35.240 --> 00:04:39.450
Now, if you go out and about on
the internet, Microsoft's tech net site,

94
00:04:39.450 --> 00:04:44.395
there's a number of different kind of
sides of what this value should be.

95
00:04:44.395 --> 00:04:48.555
I've seen some people say oh it should
always be under 30 milliseconds.

96
00:04:48.555 --> 00:04:51.495
So if I monitor the sales database
here I want the sales database

97
00:04:51.495 --> 00:04:53.665
to always respond within 30 milliseconds.

98
00:04:53.665 --> 00:04:56.075
There's other people that
say 50 milliseconds but

99
00:04:56.075 --> 00:04:58.605
the reality is it could
be significantly longer.

100
00:04:58.605 --> 00:05:01.860
It could be five or ten seconds and
your engineer probably won't notice.

101
00:05:01.860 --> 00:05:05.560
But if it gets really big then you're
gonna start having time outs on

102
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:07.480
the servers and
that's when you get errors.

103
00:05:07.480 --> 00:05:11.510
Or if it's just a little bit big,
the end users see a slow session and

104
00:05:11.510 --> 00:05:12.380
then they whine.

105
00:05:12.380 --> 00:05:14.750
I'm sorry,
they lodge a technical support ticket.

106
00:05:14.750 --> 00:05:18.770
So, either way it's something that we
could be watching ahead of time and

107
00:05:18.770 --> 00:05:22.470
if you see this number growing and growing
and growing it means one of two things.

108
00:05:22.470 --> 00:05:25.090
Number one there's a problem
somewhere on your server.

109
00:05:25.090 --> 00:05:28.530
Maybe you have a database
stored on a RAID 5 array and

110
00:05:28.530 --> 00:05:33.230
one drive has failed and now it's having
to recalculate the database from parody

111
00:05:33.230 --> 00:05:35.870
which slows down disk IO
an it slows down your server.

112
00:05:35.870 --> 00:05:37.820
Right?
Maybe that's it.

113
00:05:37.820 --> 00:05:40.170
Or maybe the server's running just fine.

114
00:05:40.170 --> 00:05:43.800
But when you specced out
the server you had 1,000 users.

115
00:05:43.800 --> 00:05:44.850
Now, you have 1,700 users.

116
00:05:44.850 --> 00:05:47.870
You've just grown your employees.

117
00:05:47.870 --> 00:05:49.020
Or grown your database.

118
00:05:49.020 --> 00:05:49.660
That happens, right?

119
00:05:49.660 --> 00:05:50.400
Databases grow.

120
00:05:50.400 --> 00:05:51.640
It's what works.

121
00:05:51.640 --> 00:05:54.550
If your company is successful,
your company is growing.

122
00:05:54.550 --> 00:05:57.170
So, you expect to see
performance degrade over time.

123
00:05:57.170 --> 00:05:59.990
And you need to expand your capacities for
that, right?

124
00:05:59.990 --> 00:06:03.940
So, this isn't necessarily
an indication of an unexpected failure.

125
00:06:03.940 --> 00:06:05.290
It might be an expected one, right?

126
00:06:05.290 --> 00:06:07.710
We just expected that to grow and
become more.

127
00:06:07.710 --> 00:06:10.080
So we wanna monitor that for two reasons.

128
00:06:10.080 --> 00:06:11.650
One so we know when there's a problem.

129
00:06:11.650 --> 00:06:14.120
And two, so
we can create trends over time.

130
00:06:14.120 --> 00:06:16.390
And we can say, each month,
we're adding employees.

131
00:06:16.390 --> 00:06:18.740
It's making this latency go up.

132
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:21.600
By five milliseconds a month, and

133
00:06:21.600 --> 00:06:26.010
so by this time next month it will be 50
milliseconds slower than it is today.

134
00:06:26.010 --> 00:06:27.250
Is that a problem?

135
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:32.310
It probably is and you need to plan for
your capacity to account for that.

136
00:06:32.310 --> 00:06:35.470
So that's a great one to monitor there's
a few others in here that you can find

137
00:06:35.470 --> 00:06:39.120
in here, theres a really weird
section In the performance counters.

138
00:06:39.120 --> 00:06:40.520
Let me show you guys this one.

139
00:06:40.520 --> 00:06:42.620
It's just called MS Exchange database.

140
00:06:42.620 --> 00:06:45.310
Now here it was MS Exchange IS store.

141
00:06:45.310 --> 00:06:47.090
That was the information store.

142
00:06:47.090 --> 00:06:50.260
But the one I'm looking for
is MS Exchange database.

143
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:53.500
So this one pertains to
a database specifically.

144
00:06:53.500 --> 00:06:55.080
If I can find it.

145
00:06:55.080 --> 00:06:58.820
So, let's see, MS Exchange database.

146
00:06:58.820 --> 00:07:00.810
Which you would think would be right here.

147
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:03.340
There might be a space on this one,
let's see.

148
00:07:03.340 --> 00:07:06.920
Sometimes there's a space after
MS Exchange, sometimes there isn't and

149
00:07:06.920 --> 00:07:09.880
so you have to kind of program,
there's a space on this one.

150
00:07:09.880 --> 00:07:15.580
So, MS exchange database equal equal
greater than instances, alright.

151
00:07:15.580 --> 00:07:19.070
This let's you dial in on particular
instances on the database.

152
00:07:19.070 --> 00:07:19.930
Now why is this important?

153
00:07:20.940 --> 00:07:23.880
If you have a database availability group

154
00:07:23.880 --> 00:07:28.260
then you might have more than one
instance of the same database.

155
00:07:28.260 --> 00:07:31.630
When I monitor that information store
counterage looking at one server,

156
00:07:31.630 --> 00:07:34.160
which means that one
copy of that database.

157
00:07:34.160 --> 00:07:37.030
But if I want to monitor more than one
copy of the same database I need to

158
00:07:37.030 --> 00:07:40.480
come here to instances to find it and
locate that database,

159
00:07:40.480 --> 00:07:43.680
and you'll see counters in here
that are similar to the other one.

160
00:07:43.680 --> 00:07:47.940
But the one that I like to watch
is this log threads waiting.

161
00:07:47.940 --> 00:07:52.180
So if you look around underneath it
here you'll find log threads waiting.

162
00:07:52.180 --> 00:07:56.317
Log threads waiting that's talking
about writing to the transactions logs.

163
00:07:56.317 --> 00:07:58.835
All right, when your sending
data into the transactions

164
00:07:58.835 --> 00:08:01.363
logs You have to write to them,
you have to write to disk.

165
00:08:01.363 --> 00:08:05.740
And if you have log threads waiting and
that number is growing,

166
00:08:05.740 --> 00:08:07.483
ideally it should be 0.

167
00:08:07.483 --> 00:08:10.010
Maybe a 1 or 2, it shouldn't be many.

168
00:08:10.010 --> 00:08:12.890
But if this number is growing, that
means your system is trying to write to

169
00:08:12.890 --> 00:08:15.690
the transaction logs and
for some reason it can't.

170
00:08:15.690 --> 00:08:17.440
It's having to wait too long.

171
00:08:17.440 --> 00:08:20.740
So maybe there's heavy disk I/O,
maybe there's disk contention.

172
00:08:20.740 --> 00:08:23.033
Your transaction logs might be
stored on the same hard drives as

173
00:08:23.033 --> 00:08:24.410
your Mailbox Database.

174
00:08:24.410 --> 00:08:26.820
This is a great warning sign to say,
move them off.

175
00:08:26.820 --> 00:08:29.160
Move your transaction logs
to dedicated hard drives.

176
00:08:29.160 --> 00:08:33.090
Cuz you need rights to occur as fast
as possible for those transaction logs.

177
00:08:33.090 --> 00:08:36.370
So this log threads waiting,
really a great one to monitor.

178
00:08:36.370 --> 00:08:39.450
And then down here you'll see
where I can pick the individual

179
00:08:39.450 --> 00:08:43.750
instances of the databases, so
I see SalesDB and Mailbox Database.

180
00:08:43.750 --> 00:08:47.680
Each of those guys listed down here,
and you can pick the one that you want.

181
00:08:47.680 --> 00:08:52.657
And notice how I've got Information
Store SalesDB, and right down here,

182
00:08:52.657 --> 00:08:57.087
I've got MS Exchange Replication SalesDB
passive in block mode.

183
00:08:57.087 --> 00:09:00.880
So it's showing each of
these different instances.

184
00:09:00.880 --> 00:09:03.629
But you might even just wanna
go all instances if you just

185
00:09:03.629 --> 00:09:05.744
have like one big database, or whatever.

186
00:09:05.744 --> 00:09:09.660
But we're trying to keep an eye on whether
our transaction logs are backing up.

187
00:09:09.660 --> 00:09:11.930
This is a great counter to monitor for
that.

188
00:09:11.930 --> 00:09:16.115
I'll just monitor my SalesDB and
throw that one in there.

189
00:09:16.115 --> 00:09:20.440
All right, while I'm in here, that's
usually the one I keep an eye out for, but

190
00:09:20.440 --> 00:09:24.829
there's another one, which is the, or
another two I guess, the I/O database,

191
00:09:24.829 --> 00:09:27.329
which is the input and
output on our database.

192
00:09:27.329 --> 00:09:29.400
We want to see how busy the databases are.

193
00:09:29.400 --> 00:09:34.230
And so you can find it in here where
you've got I/O Database Reads Average

194
00:09:34.230 --> 00:09:39.070
Latency and
I/O Database Writes Average Latency.

195
00:09:39.070 --> 00:09:44.350
And so you can keep track of how
long it's taking to read and write.

196
00:09:44.350 --> 00:09:49.190
When you buy a hard drive, it might say,
oh, this is a 15,000 RPM drive with

197
00:09:49.190 --> 00:09:53.207
one millisecond seek time on it or
something ridiculous like that.

198
00:09:53.207 --> 00:09:54.329
Well, that sounds great.

199
00:09:54.329 --> 00:09:57.358
It's got a one millisecond seek time,
so can I send data to it or

200
00:09:57.358 --> 00:09:59.200
get data out of it in one millisecond?

201
00:09:59.200 --> 00:10:00.380
Well, no.

202
00:10:00.380 --> 00:10:03.230
The seek time is how long it takes
the hard drive head to get into position.

203
00:10:03.230 --> 00:10:06.500
You still have to send data
across your controller.

204
00:10:06.500 --> 00:10:08.408
Does it work on the hard drive?

205
00:10:08.408 --> 00:10:11.110
You get data back on the controller and
then send it to the operating system.

206
00:10:11.110 --> 00:10:13.350
There's many components
that are in the mix.

207
00:10:13.350 --> 00:10:15.230
This measures the whole path.

208
00:10:15.230 --> 00:10:16.336
How long does it take me?

209
00:10:16.336 --> 00:10:20.019
If I wanna read something from the disk,
how long does it take me to go through

210
00:10:20.019 --> 00:10:24.223
the controller, get to the drive, retrieve
the data, put it back to the controller,

211
00:10:24.223 --> 00:10:26.090
send it into RAM, and then access it.

212
00:10:26.090 --> 00:10:31.170
And the longer that takes, the slower
the user experience is gonna be.

213
00:10:31.170 --> 00:10:34.550
And so this might mean I need to upgrade
my controllers, move to different storage,

214
00:10:34.550 --> 00:10:38.234
add, well, more drives aren't normally the
solution on this one, more controllers is.

215
00:10:38.234 --> 00:10:40.510
So a couple of different solutions there.

216
00:10:40.510 --> 00:10:42.352
But this is a good set
of counters to watch.

217
00:10:42.352 --> 00:10:46.887
The Log Threads Waiting is a great one
to watch, but I/O on the database,

218
00:10:46.887 --> 00:10:48.650
that's another one.

219
00:10:48.650 --> 00:10:51.650
Log threads is the transaction logs,
I/O on the database,

220
00:10:51.650 --> 00:10:55.915
that's the database itself, right, and
where the email's actually being stored.

221
00:10:55.915 --> 00:10:56.565
Okay?

222
00:10:56.565 --> 00:10:59.485
So those are a couple of ones that we
definitely want to monitor there, and

223
00:10:59.485 --> 00:11:03.745
on a mailbox server, those will give
you a pretty good indication, right?

224
00:11:03.745 --> 00:11:08.430
Those in combination with the counters we
talked about in part two of this episode,

225
00:11:08.430 --> 00:11:11.940
those will really give you a great
view of a mailbox server and

226
00:11:11.940 --> 00:11:13.480
what your end user's experience is like.

227
00:11:14.500 --> 00:11:17.110
A client access server is
a little bit different.

228
00:11:17.110 --> 00:11:19.035
A client access server, if you remember,

229
00:11:19.035 --> 00:11:22.570
it's really a web server that's running
like a POP3 proxy and an IMAP proxy.

230
00:11:22.570 --> 00:11:25.461
And it just pushes people through
to the mailbox server and

231
00:11:25.461 --> 00:11:27.150
it renders some webpages.

232
00:11:27.150 --> 00:11:30.392
So not a lot of disk I/O
on a client access server.

233
00:11:30.392 --> 00:11:34.240
And it's really just kinda CPU and
pushing people through.

234
00:11:34.240 --> 00:11:38.260
So on a client access server,
we wanna monitor CPU, memory,

235
00:11:38.260 --> 00:11:40.310
disk, network, just like normal.

236
00:11:40.310 --> 00:11:44.450
But there's a few other kind of experience
counters that we wanna watch out for.

237
00:11:44.450 --> 00:11:45.605
Let me show you those.

238
00:11:45.605 --> 00:11:49.060
So the key things we wanna look for,
I know I've said multiple

239
00:11:49.060 --> 00:11:53.786
times throughout the show that a client
access server doesn't really have queues.

240
00:11:53.786 --> 00:11:56.660
It's not really storing
anything on the hard drive.

241
00:11:56.660 --> 00:11:58.860
Well, it's not that it
doesn't have queues.

242
00:11:58.860 --> 00:12:01.160
It has queues, they're just in RAM.

243
00:12:01.160 --> 00:12:03.600
So data moves through them very,
very quickly and it doesn't stay.

244
00:12:03.600 --> 00:12:05.380
They're transient queues.

245
00:12:05.380 --> 00:12:09.450
It doesn't have queues on the hard drive
where data gets written and saved,

246
00:12:09.450 --> 00:12:12.201
like the transport role on
a mailbox server would.

247
00:12:12.201 --> 00:12:16.121
So, with a client access server,
disk I/O is not in the picture, so

248
00:12:16.121 --> 00:12:19.840
I don't necessarily need to monitor that,
but the queue in RAM,

249
00:12:19.840 --> 00:12:22.230
I might want to monitor that.

250
00:12:22.230 --> 00:12:24.330
If the queue in RAM starts to back up,

251
00:12:24.330 --> 00:12:26.800
it usually means your
mailbox servers are offline.

252
00:12:26.800 --> 00:12:29.390
It could mean a network issue, but it
typically means that the mailbox servers

253
00:12:29.390 --> 00:12:31.870
are offline, or
the mailbox databases are offline.

254
00:12:31.870 --> 00:12:34.460
But usually if it's mailbox
database that's offline

255
00:12:34.460 --> 00:12:36.799
the queues on the mailbox
server are still up, so

256
00:12:36.799 --> 00:12:40.650
the email moves right through the client
access server over the mailbox server and

257
00:12:40.650 --> 00:12:43.280
it's gone as far as the client
access server is concerned.

258
00:12:43.280 --> 00:12:46.290
But it doesn't hurt to monitor
those queues if you want to.

259
00:12:46.290 --> 00:12:53.800
So on a client access server you can go
in here to MSExchangeTransport Queues.

260
00:12:53.800 --> 00:12:59.170
And so if we find that in our list,
MSExchangeTransport Queues, right there.

261
00:12:59.170 --> 00:13:02.780
You'll see a number of different queues
that you can monitor different aspects

262
00:13:02.780 --> 00:13:03.890
about the queues.

263
00:13:03.890 --> 00:13:08.510
And the one that I like to look for
is Messages Queued For Delivery.

264
00:13:08.510 --> 00:13:12.620
And so if we hunt down and find that one,
Messages Queued For Delivery.

265
00:13:12.620 --> 00:13:13.900
Right there, okay.

266
00:13:13.900 --> 00:13:17.750
And you can monitor the messages, you
can monitor total across all the queues.

267
00:13:17.750 --> 00:13:21.770
See how if I pick for
delivery you can pick based on priority.

268
00:13:21.770 --> 00:13:25.160
But if you go down here to delivery
total it's the same thing,

269
00:13:25.160 --> 00:13:26.890
well what's the difference there?

270
00:13:26.890 --> 00:13:30.490
Well you have two different types
of queues that are in here.

271
00:13:30.490 --> 00:13:34.780
There's queues for email that's coming
in or going to the outside world.

272
00:13:34.780 --> 00:13:37.690
And then you have cues
that are emails going

273
00:13:37.690 --> 00:13:41.400
to a particular mailbox in your
organization, internal delivery type.

274
00:13:41.400 --> 00:13:46.360
And so, there's queues tied to a domain,
versus queues tied to a mailbox database,

275
00:13:46.360 --> 00:13:48.430
and so
that's why they kind of divide these up.

276
00:13:48.430 --> 00:13:51.927
But you can come through and
pick what it is that you monitor here.

277
00:13:51.927 --> 00:13:54.950
I usually just do Messages Queued For
Delivery, and that's the one I wanna see.

278
00:13:54.950 --> 00:13:56.537
And I grab it in total.

279
00:13:56.537 --> 00:13:58.100
You watch this.

280
00:13:58.100 --> 00:14:00.970
And you might have a big number all
the time, if you got a busy server,

281
00:14:00.970 --> 00:14:02.480
this number's gonna be big.

282
00:14:02.480 --> 00:14:06.320
But if you see it consistently growing,
that means your queue is stuck.

283
00:14:06.320 --> 00:14:10.290
That means email is piling up in
the queue, and you've got a problem.

284
00:14:10.290 --> 00:14:15.060
Could be a network issue,
could be your mailbox database is offline,

285
00:14:15.060 --> 00:14:17.140
could be no domain controllers available,
so

286
00:14:17.140 --> 00:14:19.710
the client access server can't figure
out where the mailbox server is.

287
00:14:19.710 --> 00:14:24.120
It's usually connectivity related, so we
can look for that and start to isolate it.

288
00:14:24.120 --> 00:14:25.898
That message queue.

289
00:14:25.898 --> 00:14:27.770
All right, other things.

290
00:14:27.770 --> 00:14:33.040
If we wanna see how busy our server is,
how much email is coming in and

291
00:14:33.040 --> 00:14:36.810
out of my system, well that's part
of the FrontEnd Transport roll.

292
00:14:36.810 --> 00:14:40.000
The FrontEnd Transport queue,
it's what's in RAM, and

293
00:14:40.000 --> 00:14:42.200
you can monitor the amount
of email flowing through it.

294
00:14:42.200 --> 00:14:44.370
It's not right here,
cuz that would make too much sense.

295
00:14:44.370 --> 00:14:47.320
It's actually in a different place,
inside of our counters.

296
00:14:47.320 --> 00:14:49.633
I need to look for
MS Exchange FrontEnd Transport.

297
00:14:49.633 --> 00:14:53.397
So I'm gonna kind of scroll and
try and find that.

298
00:14:53.397 --> 00:14:58.771
And you'll see there's a lot that you
can monitor on the FrontEnd Transport,

299
00:14:58.771 --> 00:15:04.030
and the one I'm looking for is Smtp,
here we go, SmtpReceive and Send.

300
00:15:04.030 --> 00:15:05.180
These two guys.

301
00:15:05.180 --> 00:15:09.220
For email coming in and out of my
organization it's going to be Smtp, right.

302
00:15:09.220 --> 00:15:11.200
Simple message transport protocol, and

303
00:15:11.200 --> 00:15:14.810
when you look in here you'll see
average bytes per connection and so on.

304
00:15:14.810 --> 00:15:16.780
You can monitor all sorts of aspects.

305
00:15:16.780 --> 00:15:20.250
The two that I like, Inbound Messages.

306
00:15:20.250 --> 00:15:24.560
You've got Inbound Message Bytes or you've
actually got Inbound Messages themselves

307
00:15:24.560 --> 00:15:30.490
and so you can spot that in here right
here, Inbound Messages Received/sec.

308
00:15:30.490 --> 00:15:34.190
So, how many emails are coming
into my organization per second?

309
00:15:34.190 --> 00:15:36.870
That's a great one to monitor or
you can limit it based on

310
00:15:36.870 --> 00:15:40.110
a particular client access server,
right here, if you just wanna watch.

311
00:15:40.110 --> 00:15:40.980
I'm gonna say, in total.

312
00:15:40.980 --> 00:15:43.220
I wanted them for my whole organization.

313
00:15:43.220 --> 00:15:43.940
And we can add that in.

314
00:15:43.940 --> 00:15:46.410
And then you can do the same thing for
outbound.

315
00:15:46.410 --> 00:15:47.730
So if I go to, whoops.

316
00:15:47.730 --> 00:15:49.700
I get a little crazy here and
scroll too far.

317
00:15:49.700 --> 00:15:57.107
If I go to my FrontEndTransport SmtpSend,
I can look for the total going out, right?

318
00:15:57.107 --> 00:16:01.860
So I gotta find my Messages
sent per second right here, and

319
00:16:01.860 --> 00:16:03.610
I can add that one in.

320
00:16:03.610 --> 00:16:06.930
And I can do this one based on which
outbound connector it's using, or

321
00:16:06.930 --> 00:16:08.350
I can just go total.

322
00:16:08.350 --> 00:16:12.320
And so now I have an idea of how much
email is flowing through my organization.

323
00:16:12.320 --> 00:16:14.555
Now, this is SMTP.

324
00:16:14.555 --> 00:16:18.780
SMTP does include internal email too,
when it moves between servers, so

325
00:16:18.780 --> 00:16:21.500
we can capture that and
get that same information alongside it.

326
00:16:23.010 --> 00:16:23.640
All right.

327
00:16:23.640 --> 00:16:25.110
What else do we wanna watch for?

328
00:16:25.110 --> 00:16:29.630
Well, as far as SMTP is concerned,
as far as the mail queues go,

329
00:16:29.630 --> 00:16:31.160
those are some good counters.

330
00:16:31.160 --> 00:16:33.250
What about Outlook web access?

331
00:16:33.250 --> 00:16:37.550
In the past, Outlook web access has
been notoriously difficult to monitor.

332
00:16:37.550 --> 00:16:39.930
Fortunately, we get some new counterS,
so it'd really help with that.

333
00:16:39.930 --> 00:16:43.405
There's a great counter buried away
in here, and this one is buried away.

334
00:16:43.405 --> 00:16:45.410
[LAUGH] We've gotta dig for it.

335
00:16:45.410 --> 00:16:50.290
It's under MS Exchange OWA, so
let me just find that in my list here.

336
00:16:50.290 --> 00:16:51.320
MS Exchange.

337
00:16:51.320 --> 00:16:56.740
It is, But
the hardest part is finding these things.

338
00:16:56.740 --> 00:16:59.290
You actually have a little search
field you can use down here.

339
00:16:59.290 --> 00:17:01.730
But normally we can scroll and
find it pretty quick.

340
00:17:03.620 --> 00:17:05.660
MS Exchange OWA.

341
00:17:05.660 --> 00:17:07.580
I should be close.

342
00:17:08.690 --> 00:17:10.410
There it went.

343
00:17:10.410 --> 00:17:11.040
Perfect.

344
00:17:11.040 --> 00:17:12.520
MS Exchange OWA.

345
00:17:12.520 --> 00:17:14.050
Inside of MS Exchange OWA,

346
00:17:14.050 --> 00:17:17.620
the counter that I'm looking for
is called Average Response Time.

347
00:17:17.620 --> 00:17:20.130
With a web server, the main component,

348
00:17:20.130 --> 00:17:22.270
the main thing I need to watch
is average response time.

349
00:17:22.270 --> 00:17:24.740
How long does it take OWA
to respond to a request?

350
00:17:24.740 --> 00:17:26.770
Okay.
If I send a search to OWA,

351
00:17:26.770 --> 00:17:31.410
how long does it take it to reach out
to a mailbox server, get the data,

352
00:17:31.410 --> 00:17:34.280
bring it back,
provide it to the end user, right.

353
00:17:34.280 --> 00:17:36.090
That's the end user experience.

354
00:17:36.090 --> 00:17:38.120
So I'm looking for
that average response time.

355
00:17:39.490 --> 00:17:41.610
And it's buried down in here, right here.

356
00:17:41.610 --> 00:17:43.600
And you actually have average
search times separately.

357
00:17:43.600 --> 00:17:46.340
I know I mentioned search a second ago,
but average response time for

358
00:17:46.340 --> 00:17:48.590
rendering anything else
providing that data.

359
00:17:48.590 --> 00:17:51.990
And now we can get an idea of
what our end users are seeing.

360
00:17:51.990 --> 00:17:54.300
This is really the face
that your end users see.

361
00:17:54.300 --> 00:17:56.210
They don't know about disk IO,
they don't know about network,

362
00:17:56.210 --> 00:17:57.310
they don't care about it.

363
00:17:57.310 --> 00:18:00.120
They just wanna know when they fire up
that web browser, why is it taking so

364
00:18:00.120 --> 00:18:01.920
long to open this email, right?

365
00:18:01.920 --> 00:18:05.560
And this is a great way for
us to monitor that ahead of time.

366
00:18:05.560 --> 00:18:09.090
Or, to say if somebody calls complaining
hey, it's taking forever for

367
00:18:09.090 --> 00:18:11.340
OWA to load,
we can look at this counter and say,

368
00:18:11.340 --> 00:18:14.850
well no it's actually taking just
as long as it ever has, right.

369
00:18:14.850 --> 00:18:16.740
It's just you're in a hurry, or

370
00:18:16.740 --> 00:18:20.170
you're experiencing this more differently
this time for whatever reason.

371
00:18:20.170 --> 00:18:21.495
Psychological disorder, who knows.

372
00:18:21.495 --> 00:18:25.150
[LAUGH] So these are the kind of things
that we need to be able to monitor so

373
00:18:25.150 --> 00:18:29.360
that we have tangible numbers
that we can provide to people.

374
00:18:29.360 --> 00:18:34.460
One last one I wanna throw in here,
if you're doing OWA.

375
00:18:34.460 --> 00:18:39.160
There's a special type of interface
with OWA for the free busy data, for

376
00:18:39.160 --> 00:18:40.280
the calendar data.

377
00:18:40.280 --> 00:18:40.900
All right?

378
00:18:40.900 --> 00:18:43.760
When you go an run like the meeting
minder, it's gotta reach out

379
00:18:43.760 --> 00:18:47.130
to Exchange and query other people's
free busy data and present that.

380
00:18:47.130 --> 00:18:49.750
That's actually not tracked
in the average response time.

381
00:18:49.750 --> 00:18:54.610
So if you want that one, that's actually,
you got another completely separate area.

382
00:18:54.610 --> 00:18:57.950
It's the MS exchange
availability services.

383
00:18:57.950 --> 00:19:01.260
And I know when I see availability
services I always think of redundancy.

384
00:19:01.260 --> 00:19:05.030
But it's availability as in
people's scheduled availability.

385
00:19:05.030 --> 00:19:07.280
And so if we find that in here,
I just passed it.

386
00:19:07.280 --> 00:19:08.660
There it is.

387
00:19:08.660 --> 00:19:11.310
Under availability service, you'll
actually see the same kind of thing.

388
00:19:11.310 --> 00:19:14.340
There's the average time to process.

389
00:19:14.340 --> 00:19:15.260
Here we go.

390
00:19:15.260 --> 00:19:18.080
And the one we really care
about is this guy right here.

391
00:19:18.080 --> 00:19:21.190
Average Time to Process
a Free Busy Request.

392
00:19:21.190 --> 00:19:24.770
So when somebody hits that OWA
server with a Free Busy Request or

393
00:19:24.770 --> 00:19:26.520
just a client accessor in general.

394
00:19:26.520 --> 00:19:29.520
How long does it take us to query that
data and provide it back to the user?

395
00:19:29.520 --> 00:19:31.840
This is another area where it'll
be the end-user experience,

396
00:19:31.840 --> 00:19:34.840
kinda what they feel
when they use the server.

397
00:19:34.840 --> 00:19:35.570
Right?

398
00:19:35.570 --> 00:19:38.530
If we monitor those,
we're in pretty good shape.

399
00:19:38.530 --> 00:19:44.620
Now we've got a handle on our servers, and
we take these, we take all of these and

400
00:19:44.620 --> 00:19:48.700
build them into a data collector set, and
we can collect that data whenever we want.

401
00:19:48.700 --> 00:19:53.750
So we collect it for an hour, a day, or
a week when our servers are running fine.

402
00:19:53.750 --> 00:19:56.160
And then when somebody complains,
we run these again and

403
00:19:56.160 --> 00:19:58.240
we collect it during the complaint time.

404
00:19:58.240 --> 00:19:59.660
And compare the numbers, right.

405
00:19:59.660 --> 00:20:00.890
Comparing the numbers is pretty easy.

406
00:20:00.890 --> 00:20:03.680
When you look at these charts,
you can choose any of 'em, and

407
00:20:03.680 --> 00:20:07.710
you get the average, the minimum,
the maximum, they're laid out right there.

408
00:20:07.710 --> 00:20:09.440
And I'm looking at this as a histogram,
but

409
00:20:09.440 --> 00:20:12.950
we can actually change that to a report.

410
00:20:12.950 --> 00:20:16.250
There, and
it just lays it out as flat numbers.

411
00:20:16.250 --> 00:20:19.870
And we can see it right here,
what are the average numbers?

412
00:20:19.870 --> 00:20:23.780
And now I can compare that to
what we took in the past and

413
00:20:23.780 --> 00:20:25.220
just see where we are comparatively.

414
00:20:25.220 --> 00:20:29.070
If they're the same, then there actually
isn't a problem, it's a perceived problem.

415
00:20:29.070 --> 00:20:32.840
But if they're different, I've got
an issue, and it might be a growth issue,

416
00:20:32.840 --> 00:20:33.560
a good issue.

417
00:20:33.560 --> 00:20:36.940
We just need to expand our capacity, or
it might be indicative of a real problem.

418
00:20:38.080 --> 00:20:39.320
All right.

419
00:20:39.320 --> 00:20:41.890
I do want to mention one
other set of counters.

420
00:20:41.890 --> 00:20:43.550
Active directory counters.

421
00:20:43.550 --> 00:20:46.480
Remember that Microsoft Exchange
stores its entire configuration in

422
00:20:46.480 --> 00:20:47.790
the Active Directory.

423
00:20:47.790 --> 00:20:51.270
So your exchange servers
are constantly querying the AD.

424
00:20:51.270 --> 00:20:53.970
If the AD is slow,

425
00:20:53.970 --> 00:20:56.860
then your exchange servers are gonna
be slow because they rely on it.

426
00:20:56.860 --> 00:20:59.400
So it's not a bad idea
to add a few counters to

427
00:20:59.400 --> 00:21:02.330
keep track of how your Active Directory
domain controls are performing.

428
00:21:03.350 --> 00:21:08.600
There's two counters in particular
that I like to watch, which, really,

429
00:21:08.600 --> 00:21:13.180
one is just my own information, which is
the average time that an LDAP query takes.

430
00:21:13.180 --> 00:21:14.650
Let me show you that one.

431
00:21:14.650 --> 00:21:18.280
So if I go back here, and
let me switch back to a histogram.

432
00:21:18.280 --> 00:21:19.990
Nope, not that one,
yeah line, there we go.

433
00:21:19.990 --> 00:21:22.460
I'm gonna go ahead and
add in another counter.

434
00:21:22.460 --> 00:21:28.720
And the one I'm looking for
is MS Exchange AD access.

435
00:21:28.720 --> 00:21:33.990
MS Exchange AD access,
way up here at the beginning, here we go.

436
00:21:33.990 --> 00:21:37.440
MS Exchange AD access domain controllers.

437
00:21:37.440 --> 00:21:40.120
And this is going to help us
measure the response time

438
00:21:40.120 --> 00:21:42.940
exchange servers are getting when they
reach out to domain controllers, and

439
00:21:42.940 --> 00:21:46.070
the counter that I like to look for
is the LDAP Search time.

440
00:21:48.000 --> 00:21:51.530
That's going to let you monitor
how much time it takes for

441
00:21:51.530 --> 00:21:53.310
your system to run an LDAP query.

442
00:21:53.310 --> 00:21:56.210
So if you've got a dynamic
distribution group and

443
00:21:56.210 --> 00:21:59.030
it includes everybody in a certain OU.

444
00:21:59.030 --> 00:22:01.800
Whenever an email comes in for that
distribution group, we've got do a query.

445
00:22:01.800 --> 00:22:03.150
Who's in that OU?

446
00:22:03.150 --> 00:22:05.220
How long does it take
the AD server to tell us?

447
00:22:05.220 --> 00:22:06.590
This counter will let us know.

448
00:22:06.590 --> 00:22:09.430
And you can monitor one domain
controller in particular, or

449
00:22:09.430 --> 00:22:10.590
you can monitor all of them.

450
00:22:10.590 --> 00:22:11.960
I've only got one here.

451
00:22:11.960 --> 00:22:13.820
So I'll put that one in and
I can monitor it.

452
00:22:13.820 --> 00:22:16.730
And now it's gonna let me know the type
of response time I'm getting off that DC,

453
00:22:16.730 --> 00:22:17.910
all right?

454
00:22:17.910 --> 00:22:20.750
This is one that we watch and
we have our own acceptable time.

455
00:22:20.750 --> 00:22:24.080
Now there is a timeout that
occurs if a query takes too long,

456
00:22:24.080 --> 00:22:25.700
eventually is a problem.

457
00:22:25.700 --> 00:22:28.440
Microsoft really considers anything
over 30 seconds to be a problem, but

458
00:22:28.440 --> 00:22:30.470
30 seconds is a really long time.

459
00:22:30.470 --> 00:22:33.220
So, what we think is a problem
might be much shorter.

460
00:22:33.220 --> 00:22:36.410
So, we need to come up with
what's our acceptable time and

461
00:22:36.410 --> 00:22:38.120
monitor this to make sure we don't see it.

462
00:22:39.540 --> 00:22:44.090
But if we hit Microsoft's threshold,
a failure will be generated.

463
00:22:44.090 --> 00:22:45.850
And that's another counter we can monitor.

464
00:22:45.850 --> 00:22:51.150
You'll see LDAP searches
time out per minute.

465
00:22:51.150 --> 00:22:53.160
Or time limit exceeded per minute.

466
00:22:53.160 --> 00:22:54.850
How many took too long?

467
00:22:54.850 --> 00:22:56.590
How many exceeded the time limit, or

468
00:22:56.590 --> 00:22:58.820
how many actually exceeded
the time limit and failed?

469
00:22:58.820 --> 00:22:59.770
That's even more.

470
00:22:59.770 --> 00:23:03.030
If this counter is one or
higher, any number,

471
00:23:03.030 --> 00:23:05.610
it's a problem,
something we need to address.

472
00:23:05.610 --> 00:23:09.700
You either need more domain controllers,
or maybe your exchange server is in

473
00:23:09.700 --> 00:23:11.710
one site, and
your domain controller is in another site.

474
00:23:11.710 --> 00:23:14.130
So we need a DC that is local
to the exchange server.

475
00:23:14.130 --> 00:23:17.980
We need to do something to alleviate
the pressure on the domain controllers.

476
00:23:19.440 --> 00:23:22.120
All right, now, that's a lot to take in.

477
00:23:22.120 --> 00:23:23.810
That's a lot of counters
that we can monitor,

478
00:23:23.810 --> 00:23:26.290
a lot of information that we can gather.

479
00:23:26.290 --> 00:23:28.470
If you have systems center operations
management handle those for

480
00:23:28.470 --> 00:23:31.010
you, problem solved, right?

481
00:23:31.010 --> 00:23:33.390
But, let's say we're
doing all this by hand,

482
00:23:33.390 --> 00:23:37.210
we get everything configured and
things are running great.

483
00:23:37.210 --> 00:23:39.900
Now, we just monitor it and
we're done, right?

484
00:23:39.900 --> 00:23:42.150
Well, there's one more
thing we want to remember.

485
00:23:42.150 --> 00:23:44.950
In addition to these performance counters,
Microsoft has what they call,

486
00:23:44.950 --> 00:23:46.970
their best practices.

487
00:23:46.970 --> 00:23:50.010
The best practices for
how you should configure Exchange.

488
00:23:50.010 --> 00:23:53.847
And oftentimes performance issues
in Exchange are caused because we

489
00:23:53.847 --> 00:23:55.443
misconfigured something.

490
00:23:55.443 --> 00:23:59.403
We configured something different than
the way that Microsoft wanted us to.

491
00:23:59.403 --> 00:24:01.940
So Microsoft has a really cool utility,

492
00:24:01.940 --> 00:24:05.680
called the Exchange Best
Practices Analyzer, the BPA.

493
00:24:05.680 --> 00:24:08.220
That can scan our exchange environment and

494
00:24:08.220 --> 00:24:11.750
let us know whether we're configured
to Microsoft standards or not.

495
00:24:11.750 --> 00:24:12.410
All right.

496
00:24:12.410 --> 00:24:15.150
Now there was a period of time when
Exchange 2013 first came out when the tool

497
00:24:15.150 --> 00:24:16.180
wasn't available.

498
00:24:16.180 --> 00:24:17.800
But the tool is available now.

499
00:24:17.800 --> 00:24:21.310
If you search on the Internet, you'll find
a lot of people saying it's not available.

500
00:24:21.310 --> 00:24:23.360
But it is.
Let me show you how you get at it.

501
00:24:23.360 --> 00:24:27.696
So if you're in your Exchange environment
all you have to do is jump into your

502
