00:24:27.696 --> 00:24:29.749
Exchange administration center.

503
00:24:29.749 --> 00:24:34.779
And if you go all the way down here to
Tools if your running Exchange Server

504
00:24:34.779 --> 00:24:40.130
2013 Service pack 1 or higher,
you'll see this guy right here.

505
00:24:40.130 --> 00:24:45.760
Check your on premise Exchange server with
the Office 365 best practices analyzer.

506
00:24:45.760 --> 00:24:50.340
Now that Office 365 part, that's the
reason why it wasn't available originally.

507
00:24:50.340 --> 00:24:55.347
Microsoft said our new best practice
is for you to use Office 365.

508
00:24:55.347 --> 00:24:58.710
And so in the beginning the BPA was
only available for Office 365 and

509
00:24:58.710 --> 00:25:01.310
a lot of people weren't
too happy about that.

510
00:25:01.310 --> 00:25:03.540
And so Microsoft said after fact,
okay, okay,

511
00:25:03.540 --> 00:25:06.820
it's okay if you just have all
your mail servers on premises.

512
00:25:06.820 --> 00:25:08.900
And so
now they made the tool available here, and

513
00:25:08.900 --> 00:25:10.580
you can run it on your on-premises server.

514
00:25:10.580 --> 00:25:13.240
Now when you click on that link,
it just goes to Microsoft's web page,

515
00:25:13.240 --> 00:25:14.850
where you can download the tool.

516
00:25:14.850 --> 00:25:17.620
So you actually don't have to go to
your administration center to do it.

517
00:25:17.620 --> 00:25:19.090
You can go to their website, and

518
00:25:19.090 --> 00:25:22.260
you can download it, and it's gonna
pull it down so you can install it.

519
00:25:22.260 --> 00:25:23.000
All right?
You

520
00:25:23.000 --> 00:25:24.970
can also just do a Google search,
it'll turn up.

521
00:25:24.970 --> 00:25:28.480
Just make sure you get the one for
Exchange 2013, cuz there's a different one

522
00:25:28.480 --> 00:25:32.330
for exchange 2010 and a different one for
2007 they released multiple versions.

523
00:25:33.850 --> 00:25:36.010
Now I've already got in
installed on this server here.

524
00:25:36.010 --> 00:25:40.100
Let me get out of my performance
monitor and I will fire it up.

525
00:25:40.100 --> 00:25:43.480
And when your running it looks like this,
it's a simple wizard that we pass through

526
00:25:43.480 --> 00:25:46.970
and as we complete the wizard
it'll scan our environment and

527
00:25:46.970 --> 00:25:47.960
let us know how things look.

528
00:25:47.960 --> 00:25:51.070
Now it does still expect
you to have Office 365 but

529
00:25:51.070 --> 00:25:53.440
it doesn't require you to have it.

530
00:25:53.440 --> 00:25:56.790
So, as I move forward,
I'm going to ignore some of that stuff.

531
00:25:56.790 --> 00:25:59.260
I'm going to choose to start my scan, and

532
00:25:59.260 --> 00:26:03.770
as it starts to scan, it's prompting
me for Office 365 credentials.

533
00:26:03.770 --> 00:26:05.780
If you've got them, put them in there,

534
00:26:05.780 --> 00:26:10.280
and then it will be able to scan your
Azure systems and your systems right here.

535
00:26:10.280 --> 00:26:12.530
It will scan them both and
let you know what's what.

536
00:26:12.530 --> 00:26:14.350
But if you don't, just hit Cancel.

537
00:26:14.350 --> 00:26:17.460
If you just cancel that, it'll go
through and run the rest of your scans.

538
00:26:17.460 --> 00:26:18.060
All right.

539
00:26:18.060 --> 00:26:20.760
And at the end, when we get on our report,
well, actually,

540
00:26:20.760 --> 00:26:23.220
I have a little warning that'll say,
Office 365 wasn't tested.

541
00:26:23.220 --> 00:26:24.690
You just ignore that warning.

542
00:26:24.690 --> 00:26:29.690
All the other stuff is still very accurate
and a great view of your system and

543
00:26:29.690 --> 00:26:31.490
whether or
not you're conforming to standards.

544
00:26:31.490 --> 00:26:34.440
Now, in my lab environment
I broke many rules.

545
00:26:34.440 --> 00:26:37.150
So, you'll see that I've got a bunch.

546
00:26:37.150 --> 00:26:37.980
I've got 19 failed checks.

547
00:26:37.980 --> 00:26:40.090
That's pretty bad, all right?

548
00:26:40.090 --> 00:26:44.400
I've got 22 warning checks,
a bunch of informational and 136 passed.

549
00:26:44.400 --> 00:26:47.190
Well, it's telling me
it found some problems.

550
00:26:47.190 --> 00:26:49.370
Those 19 failed checks,
I need to deal with those.

551
00:26:49.370 --> 00:26:53.810
Those are 19 things I need to get squared
away if I'm gonna put this in production.

552
00:26:53.810 --> 00:26:56.680
The 22 warnings,
those are ones I need to be aware of.

553
00:26:56.680 --> 00:27:01.990
I might need to correct them, or I might
have a reason why I didn't follow them.

554
00:27:01.990 --> 00:27:05.120
And if I have a reason,
it's okay to ignore the warning.

555
00:27:05.120 --> 00:27:07.780
But if I don't have a reason,
then I need to correct them.

556
00:27:07.780 --> 00:27:09.670
So, those are a little more subjective.

557
00:27:09.670 --> 00:27:11.520
Informational and passed,
I can ignore those.

558
00:27:11.520 --> 00:27:12.290
Those are good.

559
00:27:12.290 --> 00:27:13.870
I'm in good shape on those.

560
00:27:13.870 --> 00:27:16.070
If I take a look at failed checks,

561
00:27:16.070 --> 00:27:18.260
it's going to start telling me
some prompts, like this one.

562
00:27:18.260 --> 00:27:19.310
Active directory.

563
00:27:19.310 --> 00:27:22.480
Check if more than one global
catalog servers are configured.

564
00:27:22.480 --> 00:27:25.360
Well, I only have one domain controller,
so I've only got one global

565
00:27:25.360 --> 00:27:28.890
catalog server, so it's complaining
that I don't have a second one.

566
00:27:28.890 --> 00:27:29.680
Valid point.

567
00:27:29.680 --> 00:27:30.890
I need a second domain controller.

568
00:27:30.890 --> 00:27:31.750
So I need to correct that.

569
00:27:32.830 --> 00:27:35.610
Check whether your mailbox
databases are being backed up.

570
00:27:35.610 --> 00:27:39.200
Well, I kind of haven't run a backup on
these servers because it's just a lab.

571
00:27:39.200 --> 00:27:39.900
That's a problem.

572
00:27:39.900 --> 00:27:41.280
I need to start taking backups.

573
00:27:41.280 --> 00:27:43.560
So these are the things that it tells us.

574
00:27:43.560 --> 00:27:45.410
Some of them are really obvious.

575
00:27:45.410 --> 00:27:47.580
Some of them are a little more vague.

576
00:27:47.580 --> 00:27:53.130
Some of them, if you look in here,
how about this guy, the OWACTP monitor.

577
00:27:53.130 --> 00:27:55.350
All right, what is that?

578
00:27:56.885 --> 00:27:58.785
Well, it doesn't say.

579
00:27:58.785 --> 00:28:01.515
And if I double-click on it,
I don't get any information there.

580
00:28:01.515 --> 00:28:04.385
You can save the results and
it gives you a little bit more.

581
00:28:04.385 --> 00:28:06.945
If I view the details on this,
and I look for

582
00:28:06.945 --> 00:28:11.475
that CTP monitor in the results come out,
we can find it in here.

583
00:28:11.475 --> 00:28:15.020
And you get just a hair
more information on it.

584
00:28:15.020 --> 00:28:18.960
So here it's telling me that the OWACTP
monitor on Exchange Server lab

585
00:28:18.960 --> 00:28:20.820
castle one is unhealthy.

586
00:28:20.820 --> 00:28:22.740
That may cause a special unhealthy state,

587
00:28:22.740 --> 00:28:26.630
and then it's telling me how to check
it to use the get-serverhealth.

588
00:28:26.630 --> 00:28:30.320
So I get more information there and
I can start to look and try and

589
00:28:30.320 --> 00:28:31.040
find that problem.

590
00:28:31.040 --> 00:28:34.510
And if I know what to look for,
that helps.

591
00:28:34.510 --> 00:28:41.810
So I go fire up my PowerShell and
I can run Get-ServerHealth and

592
00:28:41.810 --> 00:28:43.370
pull that information up and
see what's up.

593
00:28:43.370 --> 00:28:46.470
Oh, I forgot to provide a server name,
it kinda needs that one, so

594
00:28:46.470 --> 00:28:47.980
maybe I'll check this guy.

595
00:28:47.980 --> 00:28:50.790
And it's gonna return all this
information back on the system,

596
00:28:50.790 --> 00:28:52.640
letting me know what's healthy and
what's not.

597
00:28:52.640 --> 00:28:56.500
So we can start to try and find that
problem and isolate where the issue is.

598
00:28:56.500 --> 00:28:59.930
This is a great way to
kinda find the information.

599
00:28:59.930 --> 00:29:01.330
The best practice is analyzer.

600
00:29:02.370 --> 00:29:03.420
It's not forced.

601
00:29:03.420 --> 00:29:05.910
You can have 19 failed checks on there and

602
00:29:05.910 --> 00:29:11.410
be okay; but, it means you've gone
against Microsoft's best practices.

603
00:29:11.410 --> 00:29:14.160
So you better have a reason for it,
and you better know what you're doing,

604
00:29:14.160 --> 00:29:17.510
because the guys at Microsoft, they wrote
this stuff, they kind of know what they're

605
00:29:17.510 --> 00:29:20.990
doing, so they have a very specific
reason for wanting it a certain way.

606
00:29:20.990 --> 00:29:24.620
You've gotta have a very specific
reason for not wanting it that way.

607
00:29:24.620 --> 00:29:29.030
And if you deviate too far, you can make
it where Microsoft won't support you.

608
00:29:29.030 --> 00:29:30.590
Where you call them on the phone,
and they're like look,

609
00:29:30.590 --> 00:29:34.160
we can't help you because you've done xyz,
and that's just not right.

610
00:29:34.160 --> 00:29:37.970
That's not the way this is intended to
be used, and you end up with no support.

611
00:29:37.970 --> 00:29:39.560
So we need to keep an eye on that.

612
00:29:39.560 --> 00:29:42.900
But using the best practices analyzer
is not something we just do once.

613
00:29:42.900 --> 00:29:46.380
You want to do it routinely, because you
might have set up the server perfect,

614
00:29:46.380 --> 00:29:48.990
just the right way or
your whole server farm.

615
00:29:48.990 --> 00:29:52.240
But over time, more servers get added,
other people work on it, and

616
00:29:52.240 --> 00:29:54.730
maybe you start to deviate
away from the best practices.

617
00:29:54.730 --> 00:29:57.580
And so we need to tweak that,
we need to change it and adjust it and

618
00:29:57.580 --> 00:29:58.800
get it to where things are squared away.

619
00:29:58.800 --> 00:30:00.530
So definitely make use of that utility.

620
00:30:00.530 --> 00:30:01.450
It's a great one.

621
00:30:01.450 --> 00:30:05.910
It's baked right in to the exchange,

622
00:30:05.910 --> 00:30:08.650
well the link is at least,
then we download it and install it.

623
00:30:08.650 --> 00:30:10.630
Then we can run that scan and
it checks our systems.

624
00:30:10.630 --> 00:30:13.890
It gives you a great bit of information
and it doesn't cost you a dime, right?

625
00:30:13.890 --> 00:30:17.210
That's analyzer it's available for free.

626
00:30:17.210 --> 00:30:20.930
All right, well what was supposed to be
a two part series ended up being a three

627
00:30:20.930 --> 00:30:24.770
part, but I can say, as of right now, you
guys have seen the typical monitoring and

628
00:30:24.770 --> 00:30:27.060
maintenance techniques we've got for
exchange.

629
00:30:27.060 --> 00:30:30.550
Obviously, the big takeaway here,
watch your servers, watch it.

630
00:30:30.550 --> 00:30:33.180
Watch them when they're good,
record those values.

631
00:30:33.180 --> 00:30:35.670
Watch them when they're bad and
compare the values, and

632
00:30:35.670 --> 00:30:38.860
now you'll know a better idea of
where that problem is coming from,

633
00:30:38.860 --> 00:30:41.200
where it originates, and
where to start your troubleshooting.

634
00:30:41.200 --> 00:30:45.870
There's a lot of stuff out there so it is
difficult sometimes to keep that straight

635
00:30:45.870 --> 00:30:47.520
and make sure that we
are working in the environment.

636
00:30:47.520 --> 00:30:50.110
That we are working where
the actual problem is and

637
00:30:50.110 --> 00:30:51.500
not just where some kind of symptom is.

638
00:30:51.500 --> 00:30:53.200
All right.

639
00:30:53.200 --> 00:30:57.480
But otherwise I think that is about it
from me for monitoring and maintenance.

640
00:30:57.480 --> 00:30:58.960
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

641
00:30:58.960 --> 00:31:02.233
Stay tuned we got more exchange
content coming down the road but for

642
00:31:02.233 --> 00:31:04.869
right now, signing off for
ITProTV, I am Don Pezet.

643
00:31:04.869 --> 00:31:06.129
And I'll see you next time.

644
00:31:06.129 --> 00:31:11.393
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to configure Database Availability Groups in Exchange 2013. He discusses the prerequisites and walks the viewers through the setup process.
episodes.title: Database Availability Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.005 --> 00:00:13.755
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.755 --> 00:00:16.297
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.297 --> 00:00:17.940
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.940 --> 00:00:21.296
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:21.296 --> 00:00:24.520
And in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at a pretty neat topic.

7
00:00:24.520 --> 00:00:26.910
We're gonna look at database
availability groups.

8
00:00:26.910 --> 00:00:30.070
Now, inside of Exchange we have a role,
the mailbox server role, and

9
00:00:30.070 --> 00:00:33.960
that's where all of our email gets stored,
and it's all stored in a big fat database.

10
00:00:33.960 --> 00:00:37.020
Well, what happens if that
database goes offline?

11
00:00:37.020 --> 00:00:38.680
Our users can't get to their email, right?

12
00:00:38.680 --> 00:00:39.890
That's pretty bad.

13
00:00:39.890 --> 00:00:40.610
In the past,

14
00:00:40.610 --> 00:00:45.310
in earlier versions of Exchange, the
solution to this was to set up a cluster.

15
00:00:45.310 --> 00:00:47.754
Well, the problem with
a cluster is it's complex.

16
00:00:47.754 --> 00:00:48.990
You have to have shared storage.

17
00:00:48.990 --> 00:00:51.087
You have to have expensive hardware.

18
00:00:51.087 --> 00:00:55.925
Ideally, you'll have a fiber attached SAN,
and that kind of stuff,

19
00:00:55.925 --> 00:00:58.796
it really is just complex and expensive.

20
00:00:58.796 --> 00:01:01.590
In Exchange 2013 and
even in Exchange 2010,

21
00:01:01.590 --> 00:01:05.950
we got database availability groups
that make things a heck of a lot easier.

22
00:01:05.950 --> 00:01:09.170
It uses some of the same
software as the regular failover

23
00:01:09.170 --> 00:01:10.970
cluster services in Windows.

24
00:01:10.970 --> 00:01:13.560
But it doesn't need all
the fancy hardware.

25
00:01:13.560 --> 00:01:16.513
What a database availability
group allows us to do,

26
00:01:16.513 --> 00:01:19.545
is to store an email database
on more than one server.

27
00:01:19.545 --> 00:01:22.280
In fact, you can store it on
up to 16 servers if you want.

28
00:01:22.280 --> 00:01:25.560
Now only one of those
servers is gonna be active.

29
00:01:25.560 --> 00:01:27.840
All the others are gonna be standby.

30
00:01:27.840 --> 00:01:32.504
And when one fails, the other
servers can automatically take over.

31
00:01:32.504 --> 00:01:34.786
It's automatic,
we don't have to do anything, and

32
00:01:34.786 --> 00:01:36.470
we don't have to have shared storage.

33
00:01:36.470 --> 00:01:38.504
Now, there's pros and cons to that, right?

34
00:01:38.504 --> 00:01:40.490
On the positive side,
we don't have to have shared storage.

35
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:43.840
That means all the hardware and
complexity is kind of out of this.

36
00:01:43.840 --> 00:01:48.587
On a negative side, it means we're
storing multiple copies of the database.

37
00:01:48.587 --> 00:01:52.942
So if our email database is 1 TB in size,
I'm gonna need a TB of storage on each of

38
00:01:52.942 --> 00:01:56.010
the nodes inside of that
database availability group.

39
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:57.916
Now, if you're just trying
to set up two nodes,

40
00:01:57.916 --> 00:01:59.462
that's not that big of a deal, right?

41
00:01:59.462 --> 00:02:00.540
You have that storage.

42
00:02:00.540 --> 00:02:04.340
But if you wanna set up more, it does
start to require extra storage there, so

43
00:02:04.340 --> 00:02:05.730
we have to be aware of that.

44
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:09.770
The other thing is when email comes in,
that email has to be

45
00:02:09.770 --> 00:02:13.470
replicated to the other copy of
the database to keep them in lockstep.

46
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:17.100
So there's gonna be replication
occurring between the database servers.

47
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:20.310
Fortunately, email is
really easy to replicate.

48
00:02:20.310 --> 00:02:22.890
You might remember from some of
the earlier episodes where I talked about

49
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:25.650
the mailbox database and
the files that build it up, and

50
00:02:25.650 --> 00:02:27.520
how we have transaction logs.

51
00:02:27.520 --> 00:02:31.320
And the transaction logs
are all 1 MB in size.

52
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:35.390
So when I talk about replicating,
it's really just copying these 1 MB files

53
00:02:35.390 --> 00:02:38.505
across to this other server to
maintain that database copy.

54
00:02:38.505 --> 00:02:39.980
It's not that big of a deal.

55
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:44.830
And as a result, database availability
groups have a real low barrier of entry.

56
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:47.600
Even small businesses can afford to
implement these cuz they're not that

57
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:50.812
complex, and
you don't need special hardware.

58
00:02:50.812 --> 00:02:53.110
All right, well,
let me show you how this works.

59
00:02:53.110 --> 00:02:55.850
So here I am, logged into my
Exchange Administration Center.

60
00:02:55.850 --> 00:02:59.550
And I've only got a couple of mailboxes,
right, nothing too special here.

61
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:03.086
And if I dive down to Servers, you'll
see I've got two servers that are in my

62
00:03:03.086 --> 00:03:07.010
environment, LAB-EXCHANGE server 1 and
LAB-EXCHANGE server 2.

63
00:03:07.010 --> 00:03:10.460
And both of those servers are mailbox and
client access servers.

64
00:03:10.460 --> 00:03:15.750
Now, database availability groups only
make an email database redundant.

65
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:18.280
They don't do anything for
the client access servers.

66
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:21.740
So when I talk about a database
availability group, that's redundancy for

67
00:03:21.740 --> 00:03:23.680
the mailbox server role.

68
00:03:23.680 --> 00:03:26.730
If I have a client access server,
I need something else for that, and

69
00:03:26.730 --> 00:03:30.240
we usually do network load balancing or
Windows load balancing services.

70
00:03:30.240 --> 00:03:32.520
That will make a client
access server redundant.

71
00:03:32.520 --> 00:03:34.150
We'll cover that in another episode.

72
00:03:34.150 --> 00:03:36.720
But right now we're gonna
focus on the mailbox database.

73
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:40.504
If you want to do a database availability
group, you're gonna have to have at least

74
00:03:40.504 --> 00:03:43.004
two servers that are running
the mailbox server role.

75
00:03:43.004 --> 00:03:46.690
So I've already got those two servers,
I'm ready to rock, all right.

76
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:49.550
I'm also going to need
a database to replicate.

77
00:03:49.550 --> 00:03:53.080
Now you can replicate as many databases
as you want, and when you created these

78
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:58.760
mailbox servers, well, they likely already
have a mailbox database created on them.

79
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:02.110
So if I go under my databases, I'll
see I've got those two kind of generic

80
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:05.060
mailbox databases that were
made during the install, which

81
00:04:05.060 --> 00:04:08.830
are just called Mailbox Database and then
some kind of random set of numbers, right.

82
00:04:08.830 --> 00:04:12.090
But you can make your own
mailbox databases redundant too.

83
00:04:12.090 --> 00:04:16.470
One key thing we have to remember is
whatever the file path is on the first

84
00:04:16.470 --> 00:04:19.720
server has to exist on the second server.

85
00:04:19.720 --> 00:04:23.967
So for example, if I chose to put my
game database on my E drive, right, so

86
00:04:23.967 --> 00:04:25.004
E:/ whatever.

87
00:04:25.004 --> 00:04:26.755
Maybe I'll get some extra RAID array.

88
00:04:26.755 --> 00:04:29.795
I would need to create an E
drive on the other system.

89
00:04:29.795 --> 00:04:31.762
It doesn't have to be the same
RAID array technology,

90
00:04:31.762 --> 00:04:33.921
it doesn't have to be on the same SAN or
anything like that.

91
00:04:33.921 --> 00:04:35.600
It just, there has to be an E drive.

92
00:04:35.600 --> 00:04:37.068
Because it's gonna replicate, and

93
00:04:37.068 --> 00:04:39.970
it's gonna expect those
file paths to be the same.

94
00:04:39.970 --> 00:04:42.421
So I'm gonna add in a quick database here.

95
00:04:42.421 --> 00:04:44.756
I'm just going to call this
my Sales mailbox database.

96
00:04:44.756 --> 00:04:47.970
So all my salespeople, they're
gonna have mailboxes right in here.

97
00:04:47.970 --> 00:04:50.410
And for the server I can just pick
which server I want it to reside on.

98
00:04:50.410 --> 00:04:53.547
I'll leave it here on EXCHANGESERV01.

99
00:04:53.547 --> 00:04:58.390
And the default path is to put it on the C
drive inside of the Exchange install.

100
00:04:58.390 --> 00:05:02.610
And I'm gonna leave it that way because
I know that path exists on both servers.

101
00:05:02.610 --> 00:05:04.130
But if I wanted to move it somewhere else,

102
00:05:04.130 --> 00:05:07.740
I would just need to make sure the path
existed in both places, all right?

103
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:11.390
I'll go ahead and save that, and
now I've got a database created.

104
00:05:11.390 --> 00:05:16.546
Now that database is only stored on
LAB-EXCHANGESERV01, and that's it, right?

105
00:05:16.546 --> 00:05:18.250
That's where I chose to create it.

106
00:05:18.250 --> 00:05:20.430
And if I start moving mailboxes into it,

107
00:05:20.430 --> 00:05:24.340
they're just gonna be right there
on that server in that one place.

108
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:26.120
And if that database goes offline?

109
00:05:26.120 --> 00:05:27.338
They don't have access to the mailbox.

110
00:05:27.338 --> 00:05:31.991
Now, just because the database is offline
doesn't mean that we lose access to that

111
00:05:31.991 --> 00:05:33.150
resource, right.

112
00:05:33.150 --> 00:05:34.830
We're not losing email.

113
00:05:34.830 --> 00:05:38.440
Email comes in, it just stays in the queue
until the mailbox database comes online.

114
00:05:38.440 --> 00:05:40.360
But the user can't get to their mailbox,
and so

115
00:05:40.360 --> 00:05:42.470
that's just as bad as losing email, right.

116
00:05:42.470 --> 00:05:44.240
They think they've lost everything.

117
00:05:44.240 --> 00:05:46.090
So we definitely wanna
make that redundant.

118
00:05:46.090 --> 00:05:48.720
But when you create one,
you'll see here SERVERS WITH COPIES.

119
00:05:48.720 --> 00:05:50.650
I've only got one server, that's it.

120
00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:53.360
So there's no redundancy
introduced by this

121
00:05:53.360 --> 00:05:54.840
outside of what your
hardware might provide.

122
00:05:56.270 --> 00:05:59.580
So my next step is gonna be to set
up the database availability group.

123
00:05:59.580 --> 00:06:03.088
Now, there's a couple of things that we
need to do before we just dive right in.

124
00:06:03.088 --> 00:06:05.716
Cuz you could just jump right over
to database availability groups,

125
00:06:05.716 --> 00:06:07.850
hit that plus sign, and get to work.

126
00:06:07.850 --> 00:06:08.650
But it's not gonna work.

127
00:06:08.650 --> 00:06:10.028
You're gonna have some problems.

128
00:06:10.028 --> 00:06:11.350
So I wanna go through and

129
00:06:11.350 --> 00:06:14.450
do a couple of extra things to
make sure that I'm set in place.

130
00:06:14.450 --> 00:06:18.820
First off, I need to make sure that
I have permission to do this, right?

131
00:06:18.820 --> 00:06:22.450
I need to have access to create
database availability groups.

132
00:06:22.450 --> 00:06:25.970
And so the way we do that is we use one of
the roles that's built here into Exchange.

133
00:06:25.970 --> 00:06:29.940
There's a role called organization
management, and we need to have that role.

134
00:06:29.940 --> 00:06:35.504
So over here in my admin center,
I'm just gonna browse down to permissions.

135
00:06:35.504 --> 00:06:37.879
And inside of permissions,
I've got my admin roles.

136
00:06:37.879 --> 00:06:41.060
And you can find organization
management right there, and

137
00:06:41.060 --> 00:06:44.610
this is gonna be a kind of a roll
up of various other roles.

138
00:06:44.610 --> 00:06:48.640
And I just need to make sure that
I have that permission, right.

139
00:06:48.640 --> 00:06:51.370
So, in the active directory there's
actually an Exchange organization

140
00:06:51.370 --> 00:06:53.650
administrators group, and
we can put ourselves in that group and

141
00:06:53.650 --> 00:06:55.070
have that permission.

142
00:06:55.070 --> 00:06:58.800
If I edit that organization management,
I can look in here and

143
00:06:58.800 --> 00:07:02.560
I can see not only what that role is,
but the roles that it possesses.

144
00:07:02.560 --> 00:07:06.810
And that's really the key piece is there's
two true roles that I really need.

145
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:09.000
If you look in here,
you can find them pretty easy.

146
00:07:09.000 --> 00:07:13.580
There's database availability groups and
database copies.

147
00:07:13.580 --> 00:07:14.740
Database availability groups,

148
00:07:14.740 --> 00:07:17.030
that's what gives you
the permission to create the DAG.

149
00:07:17.030 --> 00:07:19.270
And then database copies,

150
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:22.760
that's what gives you the permission to
clone the database and put that in place.

151
00:07:22.760 --> 00:07:27.506
So if I wanted to create a custom role
that allowed somebody to set up these DAGs

152
00:07:27.506 --> 00:07:31.463
well, I would need to add these
two roles to the role that I made.

153
00:07:31.463 --> 00:07:33.692
And then right down here,
I can see the members, and

154
00:07:33.692 --> 00:07:35.220
I can see that I am already a member.

155
00:07:35.220 --> 00:07:36.660
So Don Pezet, I'm in there.

156
00:07:36.660 --> 00:07:39.730
If I was doing this as a different user,
I'd need to add that to this list so

157
00:07:39.730 --> 00:07:40.760
that I could set up the DAGs.

158
00:07:42.280 --> 00:07:43.910
All right, so I'm good there.

159
00:07:43.910 --> 00:07:47.510
The other thing is I need to think
about my domain controllers, all right?

160
00:07:47.510 --> 00:07:53.231
If you're running Exchange on top of
Windows Server 2012, you're fine.

161
00:07:53.231 --> 00:07:55.170
You can go and create the DAGs right now.

162
00:07:55.170 --> 00:07:58.305
But if you're running Exchange on
top of Windows Server 2008, Or

163
00:07:58.305 --> 00:08:02.292
if it's on top of Windows Server 2012 and
you're domain controllers are 2008,

164
00:08:02.292 --> 00:08:05.236
then there's a little
extra work we have to do.

165
00:08:05.236 --> 00:08:06.990
When you create a DAG,

166
00:08:06.990 --> 00:08:11.980
it's actually creating a type of failover
cluster in the background, all right?

167
00:08:11.980 --> 00:08:16.160
So I've gotta make sure that
it is has a server object

168
00:08:16.160 --> 00:08:17.630
created in the active directory for that.

169
00:08:17.630 --> 00:08:20.470
And in 2012 it would've created
automatically, it's no big deal.

170
00:08:20.470 --> 00:08:22.430
But in 2008 it doesn't
create it automatically, so

171
00:08:22.430 --> 00:08:24.470
we're gonna have to create it, all right?

172
00:08:24.470 --> 00:08:27.320
Now when I say it's gonna
create a cluster server object,

173
00:08:27.320 --> 00:08:31.810
when you have a cluster, you have two or
more machines in a cluster and

174
00:08:31.810 --> 00:08:34.610
they create virtual server,
a fake server, right?

175
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:36.660
A server that doesn't really exist, but

176
00:08:36.660 --> 00:08:39.700
it's the server that you're
gonna point all your clients to.

177
00:08:39.700 --> 00:08:43.290
And if one node fails that virtual
server kinda hops over to another node.

178
00:08:43.290 --> 00:08:44.910
And if it fails it hops
over to another node.

179
00:08:44.910 --> 00:08:46.910
And it can do that across up to 16 nodes.

180
00:08:46.910 --> 00:08:47.690
So you can have many,

181
00:08:47.690 --> 00:08:51.440
many servers that are all able
to handle this virtual entity.

182
00:08:51.440 --> 00:08:53.790
So if I'm in 2012,
don't worry about that, right?

183
00:08:53.790 --> 00:08:55.270
Just put it out of your mind.

184
00:08:55.270 --> 00:08:59.430
But if I'm in 2008 I need to create
that virtual entity first, all right?

185
00:08:59.430 --> 00:09:02.750
And the easiest way to do that is to
jump over to a domain controller.

186
00:09:02.750 --> 00:09:05.310
So I'm gonna jump to my domain
controller and I'm on 2012, but

187
00:09:05.310 --> 00:09:07.860
I'm gonna go ahead and create this anyway.

188
00:09:07.860 --> 00:09:10.830
And so I'm gonna jump in here and I'm
gonna go into Active Directory Users and

189
00:09:10.830 --> 00:09:11.730
Computers.

190
00:09:11.730 --> 00:09:16.062
And what I need to do is I need to
create a computer object that is gonna

191
00:09:16.062 --> 00:09:18.197
represent this virtual server.

192
00:09:18.197 --> 00:09:21.218
And I need to assign some permissions
to that computer object so

193
00:09:21.218 --> 00:09:24.760
that Exchange will be allowed to work
with it and then I need to disable it.

194
00:09:24.760 --> 00:09:27.730
Its gotta be disabled so
the cluster can take it over.

195
00:09:27.730 --> 00:09:30.060
So, you can really go
into any OU you want.

196
00:09:30.060 --> 00:09:32.808
I'm gonna stick with my
default computer's container.

197
00:09:32.808 --> 00:09:36.930
And I'm gonna create a new computer,
and you want to give it a name.

198
00:09:36.930 --> 00:09:40.230
Now this is going to be the servers
that your end users see.

199
00:09:40.230 --> 00:09:42.480
The end users aren't going to see
the individual servers anymore,

200
00:09:42.480 --> 00:09:44.240
they're going to see this one entity.

201
00:09:44.240 --> 00:09:46.100
So think of a nice generic name.

202
00:09:46.100 --> 00:09:53.865
All of my servers, I've been naming
them LAB-EXCHSERV01 or 02 or 03.

203
00:09:53.865 --> 00:09:56.400
But users don't care about
how many servers I've got.

204
00:09:56.400 --> 00:09:58.040
They just wanna connect to Exchange.

205
00:09:58.040 --> 00:10:01.057
So I might call this LAB-EXCHANGE.

206
00:10:01.057 --> 00:10:03.020
And so now they know,
hey that's the Exchange server.

207
00:10:03.020 --> 00:10:06.330
That's what I need to point out for
my mailbox database or whatever, right.

208
00:10:06.330 --> 00:10:09.400
So you can give it a name,
whatever you want.

209
00:10:09.400 --> 00:10:11.362
I'll call mine LAB-MAILBOX.

210
00:10:11.362 --> 00:10:15.270
All right, so this is gonna be my
mailbox database cluster entity.

211
00:10:16.960 --> 00:10:18.100
All right, I'll go ahead and

212
00:10:18.100 --> 00:10:22.670
say OK to get that created, then I
need to adjust some permissions on it.

213
00:10:22.670 --> 00:10:24.570
Now, when you go into
Active Directory Users and

214
00:10:24.570 --> 00:10:28.810
Computers, the default view doesn't
actually show every thing that we need.

215
00:10:28.810 --> 00:10:31.670
So you need to make sure you go up
here to View and Advanced Features and

216
00:10:31.670 --> 00:10:32.290
turn that on.

217
00:10:32.290 --> 00:10:36.630
And when that's turned on, you can pull
up the properties for an object and

218
00:10:36.630 --> 00:10:39.240
you'll have your Security tab up here.

219
00:10:39.240 --> 00:10:41.910
And in Security, I need to add

220
00:10:41.910 --> 00:10:45.900
a special Exchange group to this to give
Exchange Server permission to manage this.

221
00:10:45.900 --> 00:10:52.329
So, I'm gonna hit Add, and I'm gonna
add in the Exchange Trusted Subsystem.

222
00:10:52.329 --> 00:10:54.825
I'll just do a Check Name to make
sure I typed it right there.

223
00:10:54.825 --> 00:10:55.775
You can browse and find it too.

224
00:10:55.775 --> 00:10:58.115
But it's called
Exchange Trusted Subsystem.

225
00:10:58.115 --> 00:11:01.043
And that's what's gonna give Exchange
the rights to manage this object.

226
00:11:01.043 --> 00:11:03.072
And I'll go go ahead and say OK to that.

227
00:11:04.172 --> 00:11:07.902
And so now I've got that computer,
that virtual server created,

228
00:11:07.902 --> 00:11:11.372
I've given Exchange permissions,
and now I need to disable it.

229
00:11:11.372 --> 00:11:13.072
I forget this step all the time,

230
00:11:13.072 --> 00:11:15.916
well I guess I remember it now because
I've forgotten gotten it so many times.

231
00:11:15.916 --> 00:11:17.706
The wizard will fail if it's enabled,

232
00:11:17.706 --> 00:11:20.166
because it assumes there's
a real computer attached to it.

233
00:11:20.166 --> 00:11:22.976
But if it's disabled, it knows that
it's available to be taken over.

234
00:11:22.976 --> 00:11:26.276
So, I'm just gonna right click on that and
choose to disable it.

235
00:11:26.276 --> 00:11:27.846
We'll disable that account.

236
00:11:27.846 --> 00:11:29.726
And so now I've got lab-mailbox and

237
00:11:29.726 --> 00:11:31.916
it's got a little down arrow on it,
it's disabled.

238
00:11:33.540 --> 00:11:37.420
Now, remember, if you're in
2012 you don't have to do this.

239
00:11:37.420 --> 00:11:40.850
But if you're on Windows Server 2008,
that's where you have to do this.

240
00:11:40.850 --> 00:11:45.053
If your domain controllers
are Windows Server 2008 you've

241
00:11:45.053 --> 00:11:48.280
got to pre-stage the cluster object.

242
00:11:48.280 --> 00:11:50.370
So now that I'm pre-staged,
I'm ready to go.

243
00:11:50.370 --> 00:11:54.060
Now I can actually go in and
create that database availability group.

244
00:11:54.060 --> 00:11:58.050
So here on my Exchange server,
I'm just going to go down to Servers, and

245
00:11:58.050 --> 00:12:01.360
Database Availability Groups,
and I'm going to create one.

246
00:12:01.360 --> 00:12:04.260
So I'll hit the plus sign
here to create the group.

247
00:12:04.260 --> 00:12:06.360
And when I create it,
I need to give it a name and

248
00:12:06.360 --> 00:12:09.740
the name is what's going to become
that virtual server object.

249
00:12:09.740 --> 00:12:13.286
So if I haven't created that object yet,
I can type whatever I want here.

250
00:12:13.286 --> 00:12:18.199
But if I've already pre-staged it, I've
gotta make sure I type in the same name,

251
00:12:18.199 --> 00:12:20.270
so I'm gonna type LAB-MAILBOX.

252
00:12:20.270 --> 00:12:21.880
And it's gonna look to
the active directory for

253
00:12:21.880 --> 00:12:25.550
that object to try and find it, and
if it's disabled, it'll use it.

254
00:12:25.550 --> 00:12:28.710
If it doesn't exist, it'll try and
create it, which will work in 2012, but

255
00:12:28.710 --> 00:12:31.790
will fail in 2008.

256
00:12:31.790 --> 00:12:33.580
All right,
then we need to specify a witness server.

257
00:12:33.580 --> 00:12:35.770
Now, what is a witness server?

258
00:12:35.770 --> 00:12:41.390
Well when you have a cluster, what happens
is you'll have one node that's active and

259
00:12:41.390 --> 00:12:43.470
all the other nodes are in standby.

260
00:12:43.470 --> 00:12:46.510
And the other nodes are sitting there and
they're waiting and they're saying hm.

261
00:12:46.510 --> 00:12:49.690
Let me wait and see if the active
guy fails, and then I'll take over.

262
00:12:49.690 --> 00:12:52.220
Well, how do they know
if the active guy fails?

263
00:12:52.220 --> 00:12:53.750
They can't see him anymore, right?

264
00:12:53.750 --> 00:12:55.590
They're sending these
little heart beat messages.

265
00:12:55.590 --> 00:12:56.830
They're kinda like pings.

266
00:12:56.830 --> 00:12:59.890
These little communicas that go back and
forth between the active server and

267
00:12:59.890 --> 00:13:01.310
all the standbys.

268
00:13:01.310 --> 00:13:03.700
And if those communicas
stop communicating,

269
00:13:03.700 --> 00:13:07.130
if it stops receiving them,
we assume the main server failed.

270
00:13:07.130 --> 00:13:09.520
And then it's time to take over.

271
00:13:09.520 --> 00:13:13.440
But what is a reason why we might not
be able to see that other server?

272
00:13:13.440 --> 00:13:14.690
It could be the server failed, right?

273
00:13:14.690 --> 00:13:17.200
It could be that it actually failed,
and yes, we need to take over.

274
00:13:17.200 --> 00:13:19.390
But it could be my problem.

275
00:13:19.390 --> 00:13:22.970
It could be, if I'm the standby node,
right, so there's an active node and

276
00:13:22.970 --> 00:13:26.510
I'm the standby node,
it could be that my network card failed.

277
00:13:26.510 --> 00:13:30.540
And I can't see the network and that's
why I can't talk to the active one, so

278
00:13:30.540 --> 00:13:33.680
I shouldn't go active because
I'm the one with the problem.

279
00:13:33.680 --> 00:13:37.770
So we need some way to get a consistent

280
00:13:37.770 --> 00:13:40.570
opinion of whether
the network is actually down.

281
00:13:40.570 --> 00:13:45.310
If you have an odd number of servers,
so like if I have three servers, and

282
00:13:45.310 --> 00:13:48.930
I think the main one went down,
I can ask the third server.

283
00:13:48.930 --> 00:13:51.880
I can say, hey,
does the main one look down for you too?

284
00:13:51.880 --> 00:13:54.990
And if the other one says oh yeah,
he's down, then you're both in agreement.

285
00:13:54.990 --> 00:13:56.570
You have what's called a quorum.

286
00:13:56.570 --> 00:13:58.470
A quorum is when you
basically take a vote and

287
00:13:58.470 --> 00:14:01.400
you guys agree that yes
the main server is down.

288
00:14:01.400 --> 00:14:04.150
And so, we can go ahead and
take action on that.

289
00:14:04.150 --> 00:14:05.810
But, if we reach out to
that other server and

290
00:14:05.810 --> 00:14:07.600
say hey is the main server down for
you to?

291
00:14:07.600 --> 00:14:11.180
And the other server says no it's up,
then I know it's my problem and

292
00:14:11.180 --> 00:14:12.620
I shouldn't go active.

293
00:14:12.620 --> 00:14:16.100
With an odd number of servers,
that works really well.

294
00:14:16.100 --> 00:14:18.860
But what if you have
an even number of servers?

295
00:14:18.860 --> 00:14:20.570
If you only have two servers, and

296
00:14:20.570 --> 00:14:23.980
the main one looks like it failed,
there's nobody else for me to talk to.

297
00:14:23.980 --> 00:14:25.970
I can't find out whether or
not that server is up.

298
00:14:25.970 --> 00:14:29.710
All right, if I have four servers,
or six servers, or

299
00:14:29.710 --> 00:14:32.850
eight servers,
there's the possibility I could get a tie.

300
00:14:32.850 --> 00:14:34.920
With an odd number of servers
there's never a tie, right?

301
00:14:34.920 --> 00:14:37.020
But with an even number of
servers you can have a tie.

302
00:14:37.020 --> 00:14:38.910
So we need something else.

303
00:14:38.910 --> 00:14:42.360
Something that can serve as that tie
breaker, or that I can vote against,

304
00:14:42.360 --> 00:14:45.320
even if I don't have another Exchange
server out there to talk to.

305
00:14:45.320 --> 00:14:46.840
And that's what a witness is.

306
00:14:46.840 --> 00:14:49.120
So a witness is that server
that'll act as a tie breaker.

307
00:14:49.120 --> 00:14:51.876
Now It can be any server.

308
00:14:51.876 --> 00:14:54.134
It can actually be a workstation,
but you really shouldn't do that.

309
00:14:54.134 --> 00:14:56.934
[LAUGH] It can be any server in
your environment that can share

310
00:14:56.934 --> 00:14:58.170
a folder, right?

311
00:14:58.170 --> 00:15:00.640
All the witness does is
it holds a shared folder.

312
00:15:00.640 --> 00:15:02.710
And those heartbeats that I mentioned,

313
00:15:02.710 --> 00:15:05.280
they're just these little timestamp files
that it rights to that heartbeat folder,

314
00:15:05.280 --> 00:15:07.425
to the folder that's going
on this witness server.

315
00:15:07.425 --> 00:15:09.500
And that witness serves as the tiebreaker.

316
00:15:09.500 --> 00:15:12.220
Now, if you have an odd number of servers,
the witness gets ignored,

317
00:15:12.220 --> 00:15:13.960
and it doesn't matter, right?

318
00:15:13.960 --> 00:15:17.100
But if you have an even number of servers,
that witness is really important, so

319
00:15:17.100 --> 00:15:19.260
Microsoft makes us put one in here,
all right?

320
00:15:19.260 --> 00:15:21.850
So I need to specify who that
witness server is gonna be.

321
00:15:21.850 --> 00:15:26.050
Now, it's really important that
it not be a mailbox server, okay?

322
00:15:26.050 --> 00:15:29.380
Do not specify another mailbox server
that might participate in the DAG.

323
00:15:29.380 --> 00:15:32.210
It's gotta be somebody outside of the DAG,
all right?

324
00:15:32.210 --> 00:15:34.580
So it should be,
it could be a client access server.

325
00:15:34.580 --> 00:15:37.200
That's usually what I do is just pick
a client access server and use it.

326
00:15:37.200 --> 00:15:38.870
Or it could be a domain controller.

327
00:15:38.870 --> 00:15:40.700
It could be another
server on your network.

328
00:15:40.700 --> 00:15:42.470
So you can kinda pick whatever you want.

329
00:15:42.470 --> 00:15:48.147
I've got another server sitting off here
to the sidelines which is LAB-EXCHSERV03,

330
00:15:48.147 --> 00:15:49.670
and I'll use that one.

331
00:15:49.670 --> 00:15:51.049
That's where I'm gonna put my witness.

332
00:15:51.049 --> 00:15:54.311
All right, now the witness really
is just a shared folder, so

333
00:15:54.311 --> 00:15:56.709
it gives me the option
to type in a directory.

334
00:15:56.709 --> 00:15:57.489
I'm not gonna do that.

335
00:15:57.489 --> 00:16:00.789
I'm gonna leave it blank And if you
leave it blank it just uses the default.

336
00:16:00.789 --> 00:16:04.700
On the C drive it'll create a folder,
it's called, I always forget the name.

337
00:16:04.700 --> 00:16:06.730
It's like D-A-G something.

338
00:16:06.730 --> 00:16:08.470
Well, we'll see it when it gets created.

339
00:16:08.470 --> 00:16:12.400
It's like D-A-G failover witness share or
something like that.

340
00:16:12.400 --> 00:16:15.500
But it's a folder and
it'll start writing timestamps to that.

341
00:16:15.500 --> 00:16:16.810
And I'm cool with the default.

342
00:16:16.810 --> 00:16:18.290
It's not like high disk IO or

343
00:16:18.290 --> 00:16:20.790
anything like that so we don't really
have to worry about it too much.

344
00:16:20.790 --> 00:16:23.950
All right, so I'm gonna have a virtual
server called Lab Dash Mailbox.

345
00:16:23.950 --> 00:16:27.300
The next thing they're gonna ask for
is an IP address for that server.

346
00:16:27.300 --> 00:16:30.070
If people wanna see the virtual server,
they have to have an IP to connect to it,

347
00:16:30.070 --> 00:16:32.390
so I need to give it an IP
address that's on my network.

348
00:16:32.390 --> 00:16:35.990
Now, you can really pick
just about any address, but

349
00:16:35.990 --> 00:16:40.930
it needs to be an address that's
reachable by every node in the cluster.

350
00:16:40.930 --> 00:16:45.770
So I'm gonna be adding Lab Exchange Server
1 and Lab Exchange Server 2

351
00:16:45.770 --> 00:16:50.612
into this cluster,
they both have 192.168.0 addresses, so

352
00:16:50.612 --> 00:16:54.725
I need to make sure that this
shared IP is in that range, and so

353
00:16:54.725 --> 00:16:57.730
I'll set this one to be, we'll do 222.

354
00:16:57.730 --> 00:17:01.614
This is what I forget, too, if you just
hit Save, it'll actually blank out the IP,

355
00:17:01.614 --> 00:17:03.500
and you won't end up with an IP address.

356
00:17:03.500 --> 00:17:06.130
You gotta make sure you actually hit
the plus sign to add it to this list,

357
00:17:06.130 --> 00:17:08.170
cuz you could add more
than one IP if you wanted.

358
00:17:08.170 --> 00:17:11.300
All right I'm gonna go ahead and
save that, and

359
00:17:11.300 --> 00:17:13.490
that's gonna create the database
availability group.

360
00:17:13.490 --> 00:17:15.580
Now I hit an error on mine, right?

361
00:17:15.580 --> 00:17:17.360
So I get it was unable to create it,

362
00:17:17.360 --> 00:17:22.139
unable to create the default witness
directory on LAB-EXCHSERV03.

363
00:17:22.139 --> 00:17:23.950
All right, now why is that?

364
00:17:23.950 --> 00:17:28.350
Well, the reason it failed, is that I
forgot a step, it's kind of important.

365
00:17:28.350 --> 00:17:32.010
I mentioned that LabExchangeServ03
that it has sitting on the sidelines,

366
00:17:32.010 --> 00:17:35.350
if it was an Exchange Server,
this would have worked just fine.

367
00:17:35.350 --> 00:17:38.300
But I haven't installed Exchange
on it yet, you might have noticed

368
00:17:38.300 --> 00:17:41.330
when I was back in my server list that
I had Lab Exchange Server zero one and

369
00:17:41.330 --> 00:17:42.552
zero two I didn't have zero three.

370
00:17:42.552 --> 00:17:45.600
All right and that's because
03 I have an install exchange.

371
00:17:45.600 --> 00:17:48.740
It's just a regular server
sitting right here.

372
00:17:48.740 --> 00:17:51.880
So here's that server,
whoops, which I just locked.

373
00:17:51.880 --> 00:17:55.040
So here's that server it's just sitting
here and it's not an Exchange Server.

374
00:17:55.040 --> 00:17:59.770
And as a result Exchange doesn't have
permission to set up the file share on it.

375
00:17:59.770 --> 00:18:01.690
So I need to make a quick
change to this server.

376
00:18:01.690 --> 00:18:05.270
I'm gonna go up here into Tools and
Computer Management.

377
00:18:05.270 --> 00:18:08.440
I'm in the Server Manager, so
I'll go to Tools and Computer Management.

378
00:18:08.440 --> 00:18:12.000
I'll go to Local Users and
Groups and Groups, and

379
00:18:12.000 --> 00:18:15.800
I'm gonna take the local administrator's
group on that server and

380
00:18:15.800 --> 00:18:19.930
I'm gonna add in the Exchange
trusted subsystem.

381
00:18:19.930 --> 00:18:21.600
You guys might remember that one.

382
00:18:21.600 --> 00:18:23.210
When you install Exchange,

383
00:18:23.210 --> 00:18:27.000
it automatically adds this to the local
administrators' group of that server,

384
00:18:27.000 --> 00:18:28.930
if I'd installed Exchange here,
that would have happened.

385
00:18:28.930 --> 00:18:31.870
But because this is just a member
server joined to the domain, and

386
00:18:31.870 --> 00:18:35.470
it's not running Exchange, I need to
give Exchange permission to manage it.

387
00:18:35.470 --> 00:18:37.530
So I'm gonna go ahead and do that.

388
00:18:37.530 --> 00:18:39.650
So I'll go ahead and set that value.

389
00:18:39.650 --> 00:18:42.810
So now Exchange has permission
to manage the server and

390
00:18:42.810 --> 00:18:47.230
if I go back to my wizard here,
I can try this again and I'll hit Save.

391
00:18:47.230 --> 00:18:49.910
And this time it should be able
to reach out to that server and

392
00:18:49.910 --> 00:18:51.030
create that witness folder.

393
00:18:51.030 --> 00:18:52.930
And there we go, I can see that it did.

394
00:18:52.930 --> 00:18:53.930
I can go verify, right?

395
00:18:53.930 --> 00:18:56.010
If I jump over to that server and

396
00:18:56.010 --> 00:19:00.490
I browse to it's C: Drive,
there it is, DAG file share witness.

397
00:19:00.490 --> 00:19:01.810
That's the folder that it just made.

398
00:19:01.810 --> 00:19:03.200
And it's probably empty.

399
00:19:03.200 --> 00:19:04.630
Yeah it's empty right now, and

400
00:19:04.630 --> 00:19:07.940
that's because I haven't added
any servers to the DAG yet.

401
00:19:07.940 --> 00:19:11.070
The DAG has no member servers.

402
00:19:11.070 --> 00:19:13.750
So now I just need to add
the servers to it, okay.

403
00:19:13.750 --> 00:19:16.900
So you can choose the DAG, and you've got
a button up here with a little gear on it,

404
00:19:16.900 --> 00:19:19.860
and that's what's gonna let
us manage the DAG membership.

405
00:19:19.860 --> 00:19:23.300
Here's where you can add servers
to the availability group.

406
00:19:23.300 --> 00:19:25.930
So I'm gonna choose that, and
I'm just gonna add in my servers.

407
00:19:25.930 --> 00:19:30.930
Now, In real life land, I'd pick all
my servers at once and add them in, but

408
00:19:30.930 --> 00:19:34.960
I'm in some virtual machines here, and
this process can be a little intensive, so

409
00:19:34.960 --> 00:19:35.880
I'm going to do them one at a time.

410
00:19:35.880 --> 00:19:39.380
And the reason it's intensive,
is when I add this server, so

411
00:19:39.380 --> 00:19:44.360
I'm adding Lab Exchange Server 01, when I
add that server, it's going to reach out

412
00:19:44.360 --> 00:19:49.800
to the server and it's going to install
the failover cluster feature, right?

413
00:19:49.800 --> 00:19:51.510
So it's got to install that
feature on the server,

414
00:19:51.510 --> 00:19:54.410
it's got to do a little bit of work
there to get that in place, and

415
00:19:54.410 --> 00:19:57.610
once it's done,
that system will join the cluster.

416
00:19:57.610 --> 00:19:59.500
Alright so I got an error here,
and if I take a look at it,

417
00:19:59.500 --> 00:20:00.480
let's see what it's telling me.

418
00:20:00.480 --> 00:20:04.250
It's on the create cluster errors may
result from incorrectly configured static

419
00:20:04.250 --> 00:20:07.590
addresses And then it says
the computer account, lab-mailbox,

420
00:20:07.590 --> 00:20:10.250
could not be validated, access was denied.

421
00:20:10.250 --> 00:20:14.800
Now, that's an odd error to get, because
we added the Exchange trusted subsystem to

422
00:20:14.800 --> 00:20:17.265
that account, but you know what,
I forgot something.

423
00:20:17.265 --> 00:20:20.260
We We added the account, but didn't
actually grant it any permissions, and

424
00:20:20.260 --> 00:20:21.650
that means that it got read-only.

425
00:20:21.650 --> 00:20:24.050
So I need to go and
fix the Active Directory permissions and

426
00:20:24.050 --> 00:20:25.080
that'll take care of this error.

427
00:20:25.080 --> 00:20:27.480
So let me just jump back over to my AD and

428
00:20:27.480 --> 00:20:30.180
I'm gonna take that lab dash mailbox
virtual server that we made.

429
00:20:30.180 --> 00:20:31.880
I'll pull up its properties.

430
00:20:31.880 --> 00:20:32.980
We'll go under security.

431
00:20:32.980 --> 00:20:36.080
And we'll find that exchange
trusted sub-system.

432
00:20:36.080 --> 00:20:37.260
It'll be in here.

433
00:20:37.260 --> 00:20:38.400
There it is.

434
00:20:38.400 --> 00:20:41.280
And notice under Exchange trusted
subsystem I granted access, but

435
00:20:41.280 --> 00:20:42.960
it's only got read only.

436
00:20:42.960 --> 00:20:45.070
I need to give it full
control of this object.

437
00:20:45.070 --> 00:20:47.250
It has to be able to take
control of this object and

438
00:20:47.250 --> 00:20:50.280
change things like its password, so
I'm gonna grant that permission,

439
00:20:50.280 --> 00:20:52.930
and that should take care
of our error right there.

440
00:20:52.930 --> 00:20:56.030
All right, so while that's running, and
instead of sitting here waiting and

441
00:20:56.030 --> 00:20:57.400
watching the little menu bars here.

442
00:20:57.400 --> 00:21:00.620
We'll let that churn along, and
I'll add that second server into the DAG.

443
00:21:00.620 --> 00:21:03.540
We still have more work to do,
we gotta add the databases in there, and

444
00:21:03.540 --> 00:21:04.750
build that redundancy.

445
00:21:04.750 --> 00:21:07.890
But I am short on time on this episode so
what we'll do is we'll go ahead and

446
00:21:07.890 --> 00:21:10.850
wrap it up here and
then stay tuned for part two.

447
00:21:10.850 --> 00:21:14.770
With part two both our servers will be
in that DAG and now we just need to

448
00:21:14.770 --> 00:21:19.370
move our database in there, verify
replication and test some failovers.

449
00:21:19.370 --> 00:21:23.440
There's still a lot more to go, but
in this episode, at least we got a chance

450
00:21:23.440 --> 00:21:28.290
to see how to do our pre-staging and some
of the pre-work to get ready for the DAG.

451
00:21:28.290 --> 00:21:31.950
We saw how to build the DAG and get it
in place and start to add servers to it,

452
00:21:31.950 --> 00:21:35.780
all the initial steps of setting up
that database availability group.

453
00:21:35.780 --> 00:21:37.690
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

454
00:21:37.690 --> 00:21:39.370
Stay tuned for part two.

455
00:21:39.370 --> 00:21:43.900
But for right now signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet, and I'll see you next time.

456
00:21:43.900 --> 00:21:49.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to Database Availability Groups. Now that the servers are configured, Don continues on with the configuration to create multiple database copies. He ends the episode by demonstrating how the database can failover during a failure.
episodes.title: Database Availability Groups Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.139
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.139 --> 00:00:13.001
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, good evening, and

3
00:00:13.001 --> 00:00:15.021
welcome back to another
episode of ITproTV.

4
00:00:15.021 --> 00:00:16.890
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:16.890 --> 00:00:19.852
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:19.852 --> 00:00:24.420
Now this is the exciting conclusion
to our two part series on database

7
00:00:24.420 --> 00:00:25.530
availability groups.

8
00:00:25.530 --> 00:00:28.160
If you haven't watched the other episode,
you definitely wanna start there,

9
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:31.990
because in that episode, we saw how to
create a database availability group, and

10
00:00:31.990 --> 00:00:34.270
some of the prerequisites
we had to take care of.

11
00:00:34.270 --> 00:00:37.430
And then we took two servers and
we joined them into that group.

12
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:41.550
Now, when we did that, it kicked off
a process where it was enabling those

13
00:00:41.550 --> 00:00:45.970
servers in the DAG, which is basically
installing the fail over cluster roll and

14
00:00:45.970 --> 00:00:48.370
setting them up,
attaching them to the file share witness.

15
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:49.800
But graphically,

16
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:52.550
it's just watching a little blue
bar crawling across the screen.

17
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:54.210
So we wrap that episode up.

18
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.400
And we're picking right
back up where we left off.

19
00:00:56.400 --> 00:00:58.270
So in the interim, those little blue bars?

20
00:00:58.270 --> 00:01:00.410
They made it to the other
side of the screen and so

21
00:01:00.410 --> 00:01:01.880
that's where we're at right now.

22
00:01:01.880 --> 00:01:05.030
Our two servers should now be
successfully in our DAG, but

23
00:01:05.030 --> 00:01:08.050
let's verify that just to make
sure it did complete successfully.

24
00:01:08.050 --> 00:01:11.330
So, let's take a look at my computer here
and if I go in my exchange admin center

25
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:15.470
and I jump down to servers and I see my
servers there, they're all happy, and

26
00:01:15.470 --> 00:01:19.200
then if I jump over to my database
availability groups, what I'm hoping to

27
00:01:19.200 --> 00:01:24.390
see is when I look at my DAG,
I should now have the two servers listed.

28
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:27.290
Or if you just added one and
you're kinda waiting on the other one,

29
00:01:27.290 --> 00:01:30.260
then you'll just see the one, but
I can see I've got Exchange Server 1 and

30
00:01:30.260 --> 00:01:32.320
Exchange Server 2 listed right there.

31
00:01:32.320 --> 00:01:34.300
So I've got them, they're in place.

32
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:37.810
I can see the witness server is listed
also there's Lab Exchange Server 03.

33
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:42.600
I've got a database available group,
so we're ready to rock right?

34
00:01:42.600 --> 00:01:46.640
Now I have a DAG, but
the DAG is currently empty.

35
00:01:46.640 --> 00:01:49.430
If I click on it, you'll see some
information over here that shows

36
00:01:49.430 --> 00:01:54.160
the member servers, the witness server,
information about the DAG network.

37
00:01:54.160 --> 00:01:57.960
It's there, I've got a DAG,
but nobody's using it.

38
00:01:57.960 --> 00:02:01.886
The next step is to actually take
a database and attach it to the DAG.

39
00:02:01.886 --> 00:02:07.070
Now, technically [LAUGH] technically,
any mailbox database that resides

40
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:11.770
on one of these two servers is technically
part of the DAG, but it's not redundant.

41
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:14.290
It's only on that one server,
and let me show you what I mean.

42
00:02:14.290 --> 00:02:18.110
If I go to databases,
I've got my sales database, and

43
00:02:18.110 --> 00:02:23.150
sales database resides on
the Lab Exchange Server 01.

44
00:02:23.150 --> 00:02:25.800
And Lab Exchange Server 01
one is part of the DAG, so

45
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:28.820
technically this database
is part of the DAG.

46
00:02:28.820 --> 00:02:33.070
But if I look at this servers with copy,
there's only server.

47
00:02:33.070 --> 00:02:35.500
There's only a copy of it
on Lab Exchange Server 01.

48
00:02:35.500 --> 00:02:38.760
So, just having the database
on the server in a DAG,

49
00:02:38.760 --> 00:02:42.780
I've got to add a copy before
its actually redundant.

50
00:02:42.780 --> 00:02:46.090
And that's my next step, is I'm going
to take a database like this one and

51
00:02:46.090 --> 00:02:49.930
I'll just highlight it,
I'll hit the ellipsis button up here and

52
00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:52.430
you'll have an add database copy option.

53
00:02:52.430 --> 00:02:52.970
All right?

54
00:02:52.970 --> 00:02:57.010
Now add database copy doesn't
work until you have a DAG, right?

55
00:02:57.010 --> 00:03:00.160
So you gotta create the DAG first
like we did in the last episode,

56
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:03.030
now we add the database to
it now the cool part here

57
00:03:03.030 --> 00:03:05.700
is we can do this while our
users are in the system.

58
00:03:05.700 --> 00:03:09.350
It doesn't effect them,
it's making a clone of the database.

59
00:03:09.350 --> 00:03:12.050
So what it actually does is in the
background it's gonna run volume shadow

60
00:03:12.050 --> 00:03:15.560
copy, it's gonna take a snapshot of
the database as it is right now and

61
00:03:15.560 --> 00:03:17.560
it's gonna send that
over to the other node.

62
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:20.640
Now if that database
is a terabyte in size,

63
00:03:20.640 --> 00:03:25.290
it's gonna copy a terabyte of data across
the network, it's gonna take a while.

64
00:03:25.290 --> 00:03:27.440
If it's 50 megs in size,
it's gonna happen really fast, so

65
00:03:27.440 --> 00:03:30.790
be aware that building up this
database while take a while.

66
00:03:30.790 --> 00:03:32.740
Once it sends that snap chat over,

67
00:03:32.740 --> 00:03:36.870
from then on,
it's just copying transaction log files.

68
00:03:36.870 --> 00:03:38.850
Remember that when we look
at the database, actually,

69
00:03:38.850 --> 00:03:42.250
let me get this one copying first before
I go off on transaction log files.

70
00:03:42.250 --> 00:03:45.630
So I'm gonna take that Sales Database and
I'll hit that three dots and I'll hit

71
00:03:45.630 --> 00:03:50.630
Add Database Copy And it's gonna come up,
and I can see here's my sales database.

72
00:03:50.630 --> 00:03:56.050
It currently has a copy on Exchange Server
01, and now I can specify another server.

73
00:03:56.050 --> 00:04:00.240
And if I browse,
I'll see the other servers in that DAG.

74
00:04:01.270 --> 00:04:04.750
And I can see the DAG name over here,
LAB-MAILBOX, right?

75
00:04:04.750 --> 00:04:07.790
Cuz you might have more than one DAG,
that is possible.

76
00:04:07.790 --> 00:04:09.890
So I'll go ahead and
choose this one and hit OK.

77
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:13.260
And there is another value we need to
specify here which is the Activation

78
00:04:13.260 --> 00:04:14.890
preference number.

79
00:04:14.890 --> 00:04:16.700
If we have a two-node cluster,

80
00:04:17.740 --> 00:04:21.550
I probably have one node that I
want to hold the database normally.

81
00:04:21.550 --> 00:04:23.690
And another node that acts as the backup.

82
00:04:23.690 --> 00:04:26.830
Maybe I have better hardware on one and
weaker hardware on the other, or

83
00:04:26.830 --> 00:04:29.270
maybe they're identical and I just have
a preference of one server, right?

84
00:04:29.270 --> 00:04:31.620
I always want it to go to
server one if I can, right?

85
00:04:31.620 --> 00:04:33.670
Because then I know it's there and
server two's the backup.

86
00:04:33.670 --> 00:04:35.280
I just wanna remember that.

87
00:04:35.280 --> 00:04:38.140
I've worked in cluster environments
where we didn't have preferences and

88
00:04:38.140 --> 00:04:40.960
it was kinda, [LAUGH] it was neat but
frustrating at the same time.

89
00:04:40.960 --> 00:04:43.900
So I'll give you guys
a real world example.

90
00:04:43.900 --> 00:04:47.870
I worked on a 16 node cluster for
Exchange.

91
00:04:47.870 --> 00:04:51.320
And it was frustrating because
nobody set preferences and so

92
00:04:51.320 --> 00:04:54.380
when you came in in the morning if
you wanted to work on a server.

93
00:04:54.380 --> 00:04:58.040
You could connect right to that server on
the network if it was no big deal, but

94
00:04:58.040 --> 00:05:02.280
if you wanted to find out where the actual
instance was running at that moment,

95
00:05:02.280 --> 00:05:04.670
it could have been any of
the 16 cluster nodes, so

96
00:05:04.670 --> 00:05:06.780
you had to go into the cluster manager,
and you had to look and

97
00:05:06.780 --> 00:05:08.940
see where that resource was attached,
and you had to find it.

98
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:11.360
It was like playing find
the server every morning.

99
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:14.330
So if you set a preference
like this you know

100
00:05:14.330 --> 00:05:16.750
what physical server
it's gonna be running on.

101
00:05:16.750 --> 00:05:19.700
The first server you make automatically
gets a preference of one.

102
00:05:19.700 --> 00:05:22.890
And then your additional servers
you can go through and change them.

103
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:26.740
If I pick one for this new server then
the other server will become two and

104
00:05:26.740 --> 00:05:29.640
you'll only see numbers for
the amount of nodes you have.

105
00:05:29.640 --> 00:05:31.870
I only have two nodes so
I see one and two.

106
00:05:31.870 --> 00:05:35.130
If you have 16 nodes,
you'll see 1 through 16, you can't have

107
00:05:35.130 --> 00:05:38.300
two servers with the same preference and
so you basically pick a number.

108
00:05:38.300 --> 00:05:40.800
I'm gonna make this guy number two,
he'll be the backup.

109
00:05:42.030 --> 00:05:46.620
If I choose number one, it's gonna
do all the replication first, and

110
00:05:46.620 --> 00:05:49.710
only when the replication is done will
it then fail over to number two and

111
00:05:49.710 --> 00:05:51.739
that one will become active
as part of this process.

112
00:05:53.430 --> 00:05:56.240
And there's a few other neat
options we can specify in here.

113
00:05:56.240 --> 00:06:00.710
If you go to more options down at the
bottom see how I can set replay lag time?

114
00:06:00.710 --> 00:06:06.570
Right, this we can use to set up a delay
between our main database and the backup.

115
00:06:06.570 --> 00:06:08.440
Now why would I want that?

116
00:06:08.440 --> 00:06:09.510
Normally we don't want a delay.

117
00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:12.180
If I have a failure, I want to be
able to jump over that unload to have

118
00:06:12.180 --> 00:06:15.140
all of my data right up to
the point of failure, okay?

119
00:06:15.140 --> 00:06:17.140
Well that's true, we normally want that.

120
00:06:17.140 --> 00:06:19.680
But there's times when we don't want that,

121
00:06:19.680 --> 00:06:22.440
we want to be able to go back
in time a little bit, all right?

122
00:06:22.440 --> 00:06:24.280
Now I can give you
a great example of this.

123
00:06:24.280 --> 00:06:26.710
Back in, it was probably in 2000,
it was 15 years ago.

124
00:06:26.710 --> 00:06:30.300
There was the Anna Kournikova virus,

125
00:06:30.300 --> 00:06:35.270
I think it was actually called Code Red,
that propagated out through email.

126
00:06:35.270 --> 00:06:38.040
And let's say that your system
got hit by that, and for

127
00:06:38.040 --> 00:06:41.190
whatever reason, your malware or
virus protection didn't catch it and so

128
00:06:41.190 --> 00:06:45.250
now the mailboxes on your server
are just riddled with viruses, okay?

129
00:06:45.250 --> 00:06:48.910
Well, you could go and restore
a backup from the night before, and

130
00:06:48.910 --> 00:06:54.260
you might lose some email, or
if you had a lagged copy of your database,

131
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:57.810
if you had a live backup that was just
an hour behind, or four hours behind,

132
00:06:57.810 --> 00:07:01.860
you could just flip over to it, and
now all those virus emails are gone.

133
00:07:01.860 --> 00:07:03.820
You flip over to the new one
that doesn't have them and

134
00:07:03.820 --> 00:07:06.290
obviously you take precautions to
make sure you don't get it again.

135
00:07:06.290 --> 00:07:10.070
So there are times where you
might wanna delay on that copy.

136
00:07:10.070 --> 00:07:15.280
Well, if I could have a three-node
cluster, where nodes one and

137
00:07:15.280 --> 00:07:19.800
two are all in real time and node three
has a delay, when I pick this delay,

138
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:23.370
this is just the delay for the server that
I'm adding right now, so you can actually

139
00:07:23.370 --> 00:07:26.080
mix and match this a little bit,
create some interesting things.

140
00:07:26.080 --> 00:07:29.640
Because each server is maintaining
their own copy of the data base,

141
00:07:29.640 --> 00:07:31.900
we can customize that setting,
its pretty neat.

142
00:07:31.900 --> 00:07:33.640
Now, I'm not gonna do a lag time on mine.

143
00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:36.630
I want mine to be real time if one fails,
I'll jump to the other.

144
00:07:36.630 --> 00:07:40.150
If I get blown out with a virus here,
I'll go to my back up tapes and

145
00:07:40.150 --> 00:07:40.810
restore from there.

146
00:07:40.810 --> 00:07:42.590
I'll sort it out.

147
00:07:42.590 --> 00:07:46.220
And we'll see in the restore episodes
where you can actually start to play

148
00:07:46.220 --> 00:07:49.840
forward your transaction logs and stop
at a certain point in time if you want.

149
00:07:49.840 --> 00:07:53.140
So you can get that same effect even
without doing a lag copy of your database.

150
00:07:53.140 --> 00:07:56.800
All right, so
I'm going to go ahead and save that.

151
00:07:56.800 --> 00:07:59.889
And what it's gonna do, it's gonna start
a sync operation in the background and

152
00:07:59.889 --> 00:08:01.078
that's gonna start running.

153
00:08:01.078 --> 00:08:04.846
But while it's doing its thing I
wanna show you guys real quick how

154
00:08:04.846 --> 00:08:06.090
the lag copies work.

155
00:08:06.090 --> 00:08:07.653
If I browse to my database, so

156
00:08:07.653 --> 00:08:11.290
I'm just gonna browse on the hard
drive where my database is stored.

157
00:08:12.770 --> 00:08:17.780
Each database has a main database file,
something.edb.

158
00:08:17.780 --> 00:08:21.940
So if I go into Sales,
I'll find sales.edb right here,

159
00:08:21.940 --> 00:08:25.580
but as we write data to the databases,
we start to make changes.

160
00:08:25.580 --> 00:08:29.740
The changes are all being written
to these transaction logs,

161
00:08:29.740 --> 00:08:32.990
these guys right here, this
E0100000000001, all the way through 9, and

162
00:08:32.990 --> 00:08:35.070
that's gonna keep going up, so
I probably have some more up here.

163
00:08:35.070 --> 00:08:35.790
Yeah.

164
00:08:35.790 --> 00:08:37.010
No, those are my reserves.

165
00:08:37.010 --> 00:08:40.010
Eventually, we'll get more,
and it'll start to climb up.

166
00:08:40.010 --> 00:08:42.080
But those are where the changes are going.

167
00:08:42.080 --> 00:08:44.930
So once the initial database
replication is done,

168
00:08:44.930 --> 00:08:47.040
this is what it's copying
between the servers.

169
00:08:47.040 --> 00:08:49.970
So when new email comes
in on the first server,

170
00:08:49.970 --> 00:08:52.460
it then just takes that transaction log,
sends it to the other server.

171
00:08:52.460 --> 00:08:54.510
And now the other server
has those transactions,

172
00:08:54.510 --> 00:08:56.740
it writes it to its own database,
and now it's up to date.

173
00:08:56.740 --> 00:09:00.430
And that's an ongoing thing that's
gonna keep happening in the background

174
00:09:00.430 --> 00:09:01.580
as our system runs.

175
00:09:01.580 --> 00:09:03.590
So that's what it's setting up.

176
00:09:03.590 --> 00:09:07.577
But the initial database copy, this,
it's doing a volume shadow copy of

177
00:09:07.577 --> 00:09:10.470
the database,
then cloning it to the other side and so

178
00:09:10.470 --> 00:09:13.131
this is the file that's
gonna take the longest.

179
00:09:13.131 --> 00:09:14.790
Mine's only 250 megs.

180
00:09:14.790 --> 00:09:16.180
Not gonna take long at all.

181
00:09:16.180 --> 00:09:19.730
But if yours is a terabyte,
it might take a day, who knows,

182
00:09:19.730 --> 00:09:23.170
depending on how slow your network
is to copy to the other side.

183
00:09:23.170 --> 00:09:25.374
Then the transaction log files copy and
it rolls them forward.

184
00:09:27.672 --> 00:09:29.770
All right, it looks like it's
completed my operation there.

185
00:09:29.770 --> 00:09:31.255
I'm gonna go ahead and close that.

186
00:09:31.255 --> 00:09:33.538
And now when I take
a look at my databases,

187
00:09:33.538 --> 00:09:37.326
see how the sales database shows up and
it says servers with copies and

188
00:09:37.326 --> 00:09:39.890
now there's more than
one server in the list.

189
00:09:39.890 --> 00:09:43.140
It's kinda hard to see because of
the way these columns are lined up.

190
00:09:43.140 --> 00:09:45.340
But if we expand this out,
you can see them.

191
00:09:45.340 --> 00:09:48.130
Or you can see them over
here in my details pane

192
00:09:48.130 --> 00:09:51.070
that it's got two servers in place.

193
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:54.220
Now when we start to look at these guys,
most of our databases,

194
00:09:54.220 --> 00:09:55.890
we've only got one copy of.

195
00:09:55.890 --> 00:10:01.320
But this one I can see LAB-EXCHSERV01,
LAB-EXCHSERV02 right there.

196
00:10:01.320 --> 00:10:03.370
So the two servers have the copies and

197
00:10:03.370 --> 00:10:06.230
I can see down here that it is active and
mounted.

198
00:10:06.230 --> 00:10:08.090
And this is the one we really
want to pay attention to.

199
00:10:08.090 --> 00:10:10.550
This right here, copy queue length.

200
00:10:10.550 --> 00:10:15.560
The copy queue, those are changes that are
waiting to be applied on the other server.

201
00:10:15.560 --> 00:10:19.460
All right, if you see a big number there
in your copy queue, that's a problem.

202
00:10:19.460 --> 00:10:22.770
That means the other side is
not up to date, all right?

203
00:10:22.770 --> 00:10:26.960
You should always see zero or
a really low number, one, five, ten,

204
00:10:26.960 --> 00:10:27.990
something like that right?

205
00:10:27.990 --> 00:10:30.490
When your server gets really busy,
there's always gonna be a queue, but

206
00:10:30.490 --> 00:10:32.280
it shouldn't be very large, right?

207
00:10:32.280 --> 00:10:33.380
In my case, it's a zero.

208
00:10:33.380 --> 00:10:34.855
That's exactly what we want.

209
00:10:34.855 --> 00:10:38.735
Content index state is healthy,
we're good, right?

210
00:10:38.735 --> 00:10:42.198
And this is LAB-EXCHSERV01,
if I keep scrolling down,

211
00:10:42.198 --> 00:10:44.839
I'll see LAB-EXCHSERV02, same thing.

212
00:10:44.839 --> 00:10:49.393
And on this one, the copy queue length,
of zero, it's the passive server and

213
00:10:49.393 --> 00:10:53.684
it's currently healthy, and
I've got a content index state of failed.

214
00:10:53.684 --> 00:10:54.745
Now, what does that mean?

215
00:10:54.745 --> 00:10:58.510
Well, it just got this database,
and so in the background,

216
00:10:58.510 --> 00:11:01.100
the index service is
having to run to index it.

217
00:11:01.100 --> 00:11:04.620
We've got an index here on our server,
it's building its own over there.

218
00:11:04.620 --> 00:11:07.620
And you might ask yourself,
why not just copy the index over?

219
00:11:07.620 --> 00:11:11.250
And the index, it actually has pointers
that reference where data is stored on

220
00:11:11.250 --> 00:11:13.980
the hard drive, and so
it's different for every server.

221
00:11:13.980 --> 00:11:17.110
We can't just copy the index, so
it has to rebuilt on the other side.

222
00:11:17.110 --> 00:11:20.340
I expect it to be failed for
awhile, right.

223
00:11:20.340 --> 00:11:23.180
The larger your database is, the longer
it'll take to rebuild that index.

224
00:11:23.180 --> 00:11:26.030
And I'm not worried about that
because it's passive right now.

225
00:11:26.030 --> 00:11:29.510
Right, it's not the active server,
so nobody is using that index.

226
00:11:29.510 --> 00:11:30.600
I've got time.

227
00:11:30.600 --> 00:11:34.340
And then once the index is rebuilt,
every time it applies transaction logs,

228
00:11:34.340 --> 00:11:36.250
it's going to be updating that index.

229
00:11:36.250 --> 00:11:38.470
And so it'll stay nice and healthy, and

230
00:11:38.470 --> 00:11:40.730
we've got a good database
copy right there.

231
00:11:40.730 --> 00:11:45.673
All right, now notice when we look
at EXCHSERV01 that it shows it's up,

232
00:11:45.673 --> 00:11:49.920
that it's active,
that it's mounted, and that's it.

233
00:11:49.920 --> 00:11:52.510
But on EXCHSERV02,
I have a few extra options, right?

234
00:11:52.510 --> 00:11:56.650
If we look down here,
let's see I can make that bigger or,

235
00:11:56.650 --> 00:11:57.800
oop, I'm making it smaller.

236
00:11:57.800 --> 00:11:59.695
That's exactly what I didn't want to do.

237
00:11:59.695 --> 00:12:04.250
[LAUGH] I was attempting to make it
a little bit larger so we could see.

238
00:12:05.300 --> 00:12:09.129
Well now that's going to be an all
new record for largeness, so

239
00:12:09.129 --> 00:12:12.741
you can see down there that we
got a couple of extra options,

240
00:12:12.741 --> 00:12:16.440
if I can stop messing with my zoom,
there we go.

241
00:12:16.440 --> 00:12:21.410
You can suspend, activate, or
remove that other node, okay?

242
00:12:21.410 --> 00:12:24.790
Nobody's using that other node right now
because I just brought it up, right?

243
00:12:24.790 --> 00:12:26.124
And we're not under failure, so

244
00:12:26.124 --> 00:12:29.390
I could remove it if I decided I didn't
want that part of the DAG anymore.

245
00:12:29.390 --> 00:12:30.020
All right?

246
00:12:30.020 --> 00:12:33.760
I could also activate it,
that's how we test failover, right?

247
00:12:33.760 --> 00:12:35.780
How do I know that other
server is working?

248
00:12:35.780 --> 00:12:40.310
Well, I could put somebody's mailbox
right here in Sales and access it.

249
00:12:40.310 --> 00:12:41.510
And then, I can come over here and

250
00:12:41.510 --> 00:12:46.400
activate, the other server will go active,
and that person will flip right over.

251
00:12:46.400 --> 00:12:48.750
Now your end users,
they don't even notice that happen, right?

252
00:12:48.750 --> 00:12:52.180
Microsoft Outlook, Outlook Web Access,
they all just automatically jump to

253
00:12:52.180 --> 00:12:55.340
the other server, cuz they're not actually
talking to the other server, are they?

254
00:12:55.340 --> 00:12:57.100
They're talking to a client access server.

255
00:12:57.100 --> 00:13:00.980
And the client access server is then
talking to the mailbox server for them.

256
00:13:00.980 --> 00:13:04.170
So when we fail this over, it's the client
access server that says all right,

257
00:13:04.170 --> 00:13:05.620
let me jump over to the other system.

258
00:13:05.620 --> 00:13:09.910
So even if we've got a POP3 or
an IMAP4 client, they failover, and

259
00:13:09.910 --> 00:13:11.000
it's seamless to them.

260
00:13:11.000 --> 00:13:11.950
They don't even see it happen.

261
00:13:11.950 --> 00:13:13.990
That's the best part about the DAG.

262
00:13:13.990 --> 00:13:16.810
I didn't need shared storage and
crazy cluster hardware.

263
00:13:16.810 --> 00:13:19.280
I can just have two servers,
seamless failover.

264
00:13:19.280 --> 00:13:20.790
It really does work well.

265
00:13:20.790 --> 00:13:22.960
And this is if I manually wanna test it.

266
00:13:22.960 --> 00:13:24.980
I can hit Activate and
it will manually flip over.

267
00:13:24.980 --> 00:13:26.290
It'll do that automatically too.

268
00:13:26.290 --> 00:13:29.001
If I were to cut the power to EXCHSERV01,

269
00:13:29.001 --> 00:13:33.340
EXCHSERV02 will say hm,
I think server one is dead.

270
00:13:33.340 --> 00:13:36.680
Let me check the file share witness,
is it dead on the file share witness too?

271
00:13:36.680 --> 00:13:37.820
Oh, it's dead there too.

272
00:13:37.820 --> 00:13:39.840
All right, I need to go ahead and
go active.

273
00:13:39.840 --> 00:13:42.890
And it'll go active, and your users
will connect, and off you go, right?

274
00:13:42.890 --> 00:13:44.790
So that's gonna be
happening automatically.

275
00:13:44.790 --> 00:13:47.015
You can also suspend the server.

276
00:13:47.015 --> 00:13:48.725
That just means, hey, let's take a break.

277
00:13:48.725 --> 00:13:52.125
Let's pause that server and
stop updating it.

278
00:13:52.125 --> 00:13:54.895
It still has the database, it still has
the indexes, it still has all that, but

279
00:13:54.895 --> 00:13:56.945
we're gonna stop sending
transaction logs to it.

280
00:13:56.945 --> 00:13:59.955
Now, there's not a whole lot
of reason why we'd do that.

281
00:13:59.955 --> 00:14:01.545
I can think of a couple examples.

282
00:14:01.545 --> 00:14:03.795
Maybe I'm about to do some
maintenance on that server, and so

283
00:14:03.795 --> 00:14:06.085
I know I'm gonna do some reboots and
other things, so

284
00:14:06.085 --> 00:14:09.230
I might wanna suspend replication,
so that I don't get a bunch of

285
00:14:09.230 --> 00:14:12.300
errors in my event log because
Exchange is trying to replicate to it.

286
00:14:12.300 --> 00:14:13.710
That's one example.

287
00:14:13.710 --> 00:14:18.026
Another example might be, I'm about to
do an upgrade on Exchange server 01, and

288
