00:14:18.026 --> 00:14:19.877
just in case something goes wrong,

289
00:14:19.877 --> 00:14:22.854
I want to have Exchange server
02 kinda frozen in time.

290
00:14:22.854 --> 00:14:26.285
So I could suspend it and start to
do my work on Exchange server 01 and

291
00:14:26.285 --> 00:14:30.011
if things go south, if things just
break I can just say forget server 01,

292
00:14:30.011 --> 00:14:31.690
let's flip over to server 02.

293
00:14:31.690 --> 00:14:33.940
And you can flip over to that one and
now you're in business.

294
00:14:33.940 --> 00:14:37.800
So, that would be an example of when
we might choose to suspend that.

295
00:14:37.800 --> 00:14:40.000
But if I want to activate it,
I just can just hit Activate and

296
00:14:40.000 --> 00:14:42.460
it's gonna tell it to
bring that server active.

297
00:14:42.460 --> 00:14:45.506
Right now, if somebody wants
to connect to that sales DB,

298
00:14:45.506 --> 00:14:47.819
they're gonna go to Exchange server 01.

299
00:14:47.819 --> 00:14:50.670
When I choose the other one to be active,
they'll go to server 02.

300
00:14:50.670 --> 00:14:53.860
Now remember,
they don't see server 01 and server 02.

301
00:14:53.860 --> 00:14:56.610
They see Lab-Mailbox.

302
00:14:56.610 --> 00:15:00.713
Remember when I created the DAG,
I named it Lab-Mailbox and

303
00:15:00.713 --> 00:15:05.070
I gave it a virtual IP
address of 192.168.0.222.

304
00:15:05.070 --> 00:15:08.010
So they see a server called Lab-Mailbox.

305
00:15:08.010 --> 00:15:09.880
They don't see the stuff behind it.

306
00:15:09.880 --> 00:15:12.585
They don't realize they're being sent
to one physical server or another.

307
00:15:12.585 --> 00:15:15.988
That's part of what makes this all so
seamless and easy.

308
00:15:15.988 --> 00:15:18.090
So I'm gonna take that sales database and
I'm gonna go ahead and

309
00:15:18.090 --> 00:15:21.312
activate the other node, and
we'll go ahead and tell it to activate.

310
00:15:21.312 --> 00:15:24.410
It's gonna reach out and it's gonna
tell that other system to go active.

311
00:15:24.410 --> 00:15:26.080
Now, I've got a little error here.

312
00:15:26.080 --> 00:15:26.780
Let's see what we've got.

313
00:15:26.780 --> 00:15:29.016
All right, so I'm gonna go ahead and
take that second node and

314
00:15:29.016 --> 00:15:29.920
I'm gonna activate it.

315
00:15:29.920 --> 00:15:34.229
Now when I activate it, it's gonna tell
it to bring that other node active and

316
00:15:34.229 --> 00:15:36.627
start sending people over to server 02.

317
00:15:36.627 --> 00:15:39.870
Now, well, I got an error, so
that didn't work out so well.

318
00:15:39.870 --> 00:15:42.370
Well, if we take a look at the error,
let's see what's going on.

319
00:15:42.370 --> 00:15:46.740
So if we kinda break this down, we see
Database copy Sales on Exchange Server 02

320
00:15:46.740 --> 00:15:51.010
has content index catalog files
in the following state, Failed.

321
00:15:51.010 --> 00:15:52.550
My index isn't active, all right?

322
00:15:52.550 --> 00:15:57.050
I can't fail over to that other node yet,
because it's not fully active.

323
00:15:57.050 --> 00:15:59.420
I've gotta wait for
it to finish building its index.

324
00:15:59.420 --> 00:16:03.465
When the index state goes to healthy Then
we'll be able to fail over to that node,

325
00:16:03.465 --> 00:16:06.690
and that's not uncommon for
a new cluster that we just built up.

326
00:16:06.690 --> 00:16:10.660
It takes time for it to build that index,
and so I can't fail over to it just yet.

327
00:16:10.660 --> 00:16:14.380
Now, we can monitor that replication
status a few different ways.

328
00:16:14.380 --> 00:16:18.060
Right here in the GUI, we don't
really get a whole lot of feedback,

329
00:16:18.060 --> 00:16:20.400
as far as how far it's replicated.

330
00:16:20.400 --> 00:16:22.236
If you choose a node and hit View Details,

331
00:16:22.236 --> 00:16:24.923
it will actually break down some
of the information for you.

332
00:16:24.923 --> 00:16:29.139
And you can see, right here where I'm
seeing that Content index status Failed,

333
00:16:29.139 --> 00:16:30.202
status is Healthy.

334
00:16:30.202 --> 00:16:32.461
And I can see my Copy queue length.

335
00:16:32.461 --> 00:16:34.880
You can start to see
some of that information.

336
00:16:34.880 --> 00:16:38.038
There's a Replay queue length, let me
explain the difference between those.

337
00:16:38.038 --> 00:16:41.710
The Copy queue length is just me copying
the changes to the other server.

338
00:16:41.710 --> 00:16:45.190
The Replay queue length is once
the server receives those changes,

339
00:16:45.190 --> 00:16:46.680
it has to apply them.

340
00:16:46.680 --> 00:16:48.870
So ideally, I see a zero on both of these.

341
00:16:48.870 --> 00:16:50.443
I've copied everything
to the other server, and

342
00:16:50.443 --> 00:16:51.651
the server's already applied them.

343
00:16:51.651 --> 00:16:56.070
But if I see one has a really high number,
then there's some kind of problem.

344
00:16:56.070 --> 00:16:57.602
I might need to address that, right.

345
00:16:57.602 --> 00:17:01.070
Now the other thing I can watch out for
is this field right here, Error messages.

346
00:17:01.070 --> 00:17:03.735
If there was actually a true
problem here for me to deal with,

347
00:17:03.735 --> 00:17:05.001
I'd have an error message.

348
00:17:05.001 --> 00:17:07.800
And I'd be able to look at that and
try to find out what the problem is.

349
00:17:07.800 --> 00:17:11.070
Mine's empty, and that's because
I don't have a real problem.

350
00:17:11.070 --> 00:17:14.117
It tells me my index failed, but it's
actually building that in the background,

351
00:17:14.117 --> 00:17:14.966
so I just need to wait.

352
00:17:14.966 --> 00:17:16.206
But you can see other information.

353
00:17:16.206 --> 00:17:19.799
Here's where you can manipulate that
preference number and lag time, too,

354
00:17:19.799 --> 00:17:23.520
if you wanna change that after the fact,
you can go in and kinda work with those.

355
00:17:23.520 --> 00:17:24.280
So we should be good there.

356
00:17:24.280 --> 00:17:26.281
You can also monitor a lot
of this from the PowerShell.

357
00:17:26.281 --> 00:17:29.931
Right, so if I were to fire up
my PowerShell on this system,

358
00:17:29.931 --> 00:17:32.780
let me get into my
Exchange Management Shell.

359
00:17:34.480 --> 00:17:36.651
We got a few different commands
that we can throw at it here.

360
00:17:36.651 --> 00:17:39.711
I'm just gonna bump up my font size so
you guys would be able to see this

361
00:17:43.711 --> 00:17:47.980
All right, and some of the commands
that we can run to see what's going on.

362
00:17:47.980 --> 00:17:52.050
We've got, for example,
Get-DatabaseAvailabilityGroup.

363
00:17:52.050 --> 00:17:54.541
That'll show us information about
our database availability group.

364
00:17:54.541 --> 00:17:58.148
And then we can do
Get-MailboxDatabaseCopyStatus, and so

365
00:17:58.148 --> 00:18:01.410
that will show us information
about where our copy is.

366
00:18:01.410 --> 00:18:06.384
So, I'm gonna do
a Get-DatabaseAvailabilityGroup,

367
00:18:06.384 --> 00:18:10.641
and that's just gonna list
the DAGs that I have.

368
00:18:10.641 --> 00:18:18.020
And then I can specify a particular one,
I can say Identity LAB-MAILBOX.

369
00:18:18.020 --> 00:18:20.890
And that'll give me the details
on that particular system,

370
00:18:20.890 --> 00:18:22.980
which is really not different
than what it gave me there.

371
00:18:22.980 --> 00:18:26.080
But I'm gonna add one more command
to that, which is -Status.

372
00:18:26.080 --> 00:18:29.770
And that's what's gonna let me see what
the current health of that information is,

373
00:18:29.770 --> 00:18:33.470
and the way it lists it here
is not terribly informative.

374
00:18:33.470 --> 00:18:36.248
I need to throw that into a format list so

375
00:18:36.248 --> 00:18:39.470
that I can actually see
the true status information.

376
00:18:39.470 --> 00:18:40.872
And now you can look in here and

377
00:18:40.872 --> 00:18:43.691
kinda see where things are at
as far as its communications.

378
00:18:43.691 --> 00:18:47.156
So, this is one way that we can view
settings, a little easier through the GUI,

379
00:18:47.156 --> 00:18:48.870
but you can view it here too.

380
00:18:48.870 --> 00:18:51.820
So, you can see things
like the ReplicationPort.

381
00:18:51.820 --> 00:18:55.290
If you find that replication is failing,
you can have Windows Firewall blocking it,

382
00:18:55.290 --> 00:18:57.600
and so that would be something
that we would need to open.

383
00:18:57.600 --> 00:19:00.520
But otherwise you can see some
basic information in here.

384
00:19:00.520 --> 00:19:07.300
And then there's
the Get-MailboxDatabaseCopyStatus.

385
00:19:07.300 --> 00:19:09.830
And for this one,
you can specify a particular mailbox.

386
00:19:09.830 --> 00:19:12.770
So I wanna look at that
sales mailbox database, and

387
00:19:12.770 --> 00:19:14.790
give me information about
its current status.

388
00:19:14.790 --> 00:19:15.771
And so it's gonna give me that list.

389
00:19:15.771 --> 00:19:17.891
And you'll see how it's
Mounted on EXCHSERV01.

390
00:19:17.891 --> 00:19:19.871
It's Healthy on SERV02.

391
00:19:19.871 --> 00:19:24.790
There's my queue length that are showing
up, and we can also see our index status.

392
00:19:24.790 --> 00:19:26.200
And actually looking here,

393
00:19:26.200 --> 00:19:29.240
it looks like my index state just
went Healthy on the other system.

394
00:19:29.240 --> 00:19:31.500
If you wait long enough,
then things do happen.

395
00:19:31.500 --> 00:19:34.218
There's more information in
there if you do a format list.

396
00:19:34.218 --> 00:19:37.420
You'll see there's actually quite a bit
tucked away inside of this one as

397
00:19:37.420 --> 00:19:38.670
far as status.

398
00:19:38.670 --> 00:19:41.691
But that initial output had
exactly what I needed to see.

399
00:19:41.691 --> 00:19:45.139
I'm gonna go back here to my GUI, and
I'm just gonna refresh this screen,

400
00:19:45.139 --> 00:19:47.490
make sure I've got the latest data.

401
00:19:47.490 --> 00:19:51.960
And now when I go in and
double-check my system, my LAB-EXCHSERV02,

402
00:19:51.960 --> 00:19:55.792
it's got Passive, Healthy,
Content index status Healthy.

403
00:19:55.792 --> 00:19:57.500
Looks like everything's healthy now.

404
00:19:57.500 --> 00:19:59.520
I should be to test that fail over.

405
00:19:59.520 --> 00:20:00.900
So we'll go ahead and test it.

406
00:20:00.900 --> 00:20:05.081
I'm gonna go come under here under
LAB-EXCHSERV02, and I'm gonna activate it.

407
00:20:05.081 --> 00:20:06.661
And we'll see what happens.

408
00:20:09.121 --> 00:20:10.020
All right, so there it goes.

409
00:20:10.020 --> 00:20:10.904
It's reaching out to the server node.

410
00:20:10.904 --> 00:20:13.830
The server's already got the database,
so it doesn't have to copy anything.

411
00:20:13.830 --> 00:20:18.060
It just has to say, take the main
database off, bring the other one active,

412
00:20:18.060 --> 00:20:20.580
clients will automatically jump over
to the other system when it's done.

413
00:20:20.580 --> 00:20:22.710
There we go,
you've completed the operation.

414
00:20:22.710 --> 00:20:26.210
When I hit close,
I still see my Sales database is up.

415
00:20:26.210 --> 00:20:28.320
Now look at my data over here.

416
00:20:28.320 --> 00:20:32.534
I can see that EXCHSERV01 is now Passive,
Healthy, and

417
00:20:32.534 --> 00:20:37.430
EXCHSERV02 is Active, Mounted,
and look at the index.

418
00:20:37.430 --> 00:20:40.680
The index state is Failed
on both of them right now.

419
00:20:40.680 --> 00:20:42.660
They're re-correcting their index.

420
00:20:42.660 --> 00:20:45.180
Now people are in there,
people are working with their email.

421
00:20:45.180 --> 00:20:47.729
But if they start doing
searches of the mailbox,

422
00:20:47.729 --> 00:20:51.161
the reason it says failed here is
the index is probably outdated.

423
00:20:51.161 --> 00:20:53.661
We're kind of replaying transaction
logs in the background.

424
00:20:53.661 --> 00:20:57.270
So the search will still work, but their
latest and greatest emails that have come

425
00:20:57.270 --> 00:21:01.001
in, anything that was in the queue during
the fail over, hasn't been indexed yet.

426
00:21:01.001 --> 00:21:03.242
And it usually doesn't take very long.

427
00:21:03.242 --> 00:21:06.410
You'd have to have an incredibly
busy server for it to take a while.

428
00:21:06.410 --> 00:21:07.380
So I'm just gonna refresh, and

429
00:21:07.380 --> 00:21:10.960
sure enough, I can see my index state
is now Healthy on both of them.

430
00:21:10.960 --> 00:21:15.060
So I'm healthy, I'm up, and
the second server is now the active node.

431
00:21:15.060 --> 00:21:17.311
Okay, now the second server
had a preference of two.

432
00:21:17.311 --> 00:21:19.520
The first server had a preference of one.

433
00:21:19.520 --> 00:21:23.110
The first server is healthy,
aren't we gonna fail back?

434
00:21:23.110 --> 00:21:26.705
Well, no,
because we made manually failed over

435
00:21:26.705 --> 00:21:31.545
it's not gonna do another fail over unless
an actual problem occurs, all right.

436
00:21:31.545 --> 00:21:34.875
You have in the cluster world,
you have what's call preemptive fail over.

437
00:21:34.875 --> 00:21:38.398
Preemptive fail over is when you fail
over even though there's not a problem.

438
00:21:38.398 --> 00:21:39.802
So whoever's preference one,

439
00:21:39.802 --> 00:21:42.610
they're gonna take over even
if there's not problem, right?

440
00:21:42.610 --> 00:21:44.210
That's preemptive fail over.

441
00:21:44.210 --> 00:21:47.850
Exchange database availability
groups are non-preemptive.

442
00:21:47.850 --> 00:21:50.520
In other words,
they only fail over if there's a problem.

443
00:21:50.520 --> 00:21:55.160
So if I leave it like this,
EXCHSERV02 has a preference of two.

444
00:21:55.160 --> 00:21:57.072
EXCHSERV01 has a preference of one.

445
00:21:57.072 --> 00:22:01.060
But EXCHSERV02 is gonna stay active
forever, until a problem happens.

446
00:22:01.060 --> 00:22:04.426
If I restart EXCHSERV02, if EXCHSERV02
goes offline or if I manually hit

447
00:22:04.426 --> 00:22:07.811
the deactivate server button on SERV01,
that'll trigger a fail-over.

448
00:22:07.811 --> 00:22:09.350
And It'll go back to SERV01.

449
00:22:09.350 --> 00:22:13.044
But if I don't do anything,
then SERV02 is gonna stay active,

450
00:22:13.044 --> 00:22:15.630
and that's gonna be the end of that,
right.

451
00:22:15.630 --> 00:22:21.120
So, for example, I could, let's say I
wanted to do a, just a simulation here.

452
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:23.461
We could take SERV02 and
shut it down, right.

453
00:22:23.461 --> 00:22:30.761
So I could do something like this.

454
00:22:30.761 --> 00:22:35.130
I'm gonna basically force
EXCHSERV02 to shut down.

455
00:22:36.340 --> 00:22:42.540
And when it shuts down, it's gonna go
offline, and SERV01 is gonna look at that.

456
00:22:42.540 --> 00:22:45.200
And it's gonna say,
wow, is SERV02 offline?

457
00:22:45.200 --> 00:22:46.330
I think it's offline.

458
00:22:46.330 --> 00:22:48.611
Let me go check with the file witness and
see if they agree.

459
00:22:48.611 --> 00:22:50.244
And it'll look at the file witness,

460
00:22:50.244 --> 00:22:53.940
and it'll see that SERV02 is not writing
files into that witness share anymore.

461
00:22:53.940 --> 00:22:57.000
And when it's not writing files there,
that means the witness thinks it's down.

462
00:22:57.000 --> 00:22:59.770
We think it's down,
we need to go active, okay?

463
00:22:59.770 --> 00:23:00.990
And that usually happens pretty quick.

464
00:23:00.990 --> 00:23:03.911
So I can see I can't ping SERV02 anymore.

465
00:23:03.911 --> 00:23:05.681
So SERV02 is offline.

466
00:23:05.681 --> 00:23:09.605
And if I come in here and refresh this,
I can watch the Sales database, and

467
00:23:09.605 --> 00:23:10.820
it does take a moment.

468
00:23:10.820 --> 00:23:14.283
Because it always assumes that, yeah,
maybe we're just dropping some packets,

469
00:23:14.283 --> 00:23:16.260
let's give it a moment and make sure.

470
00:23:16.260 --> 00:23:19.320
But when I come in here and refresh,
see how it's taking a while to load there?

471
00:23:19.320 --> 00:23:20.577
It's trying to figure out what's going on.

472
00:23:20.577 --> 00:23:22.043
And on the side here,

473
00:23:22.043 --> 00:23:27.150
I can see that LAB-EXCHSERV01
one is still Passive, Healthy.

474
00:23:27.150 --> 00:23:30.780
And SERV02 is Passive, ServiceDown.

475
00:23:30.780 --> 00:23:35.270
We see that SERV02 is down, what do I do?

476
00:23:35.270 --> 00:23:38.840
Well, it's making sure that it's really
down, that this isn't just a quick blip.

477
00:23:38.840 --> 00:23:41.690
And so in the next couple of seconds,
it's gonna recognize that this isn't

478
00:23:41.690 --> 00:23:45.040
just a quick blip, and
it's gonna go ahead and bring us active.

479
00:23:45.040 --> 00:23:46.560
And so we can give that a moment.

480
00:23:46.560 --> 00:23:49.216
If it doesn't happen in a reasonable time,
you could force it, but

481
00:23:49.216 --> 00:23:50.252
it will happen on its own.

482
00:23:50.252 --> 00:23:51.638
That's kind of the whole point of
this is that we shouldn't have to

483
00:23:51.638 --> 00:23:52.175
worry about it, right?

484
00:23:52.175 --> 00:23:55.855
You set it and forget it, and
it will take things over as needed.

485
00:23:55.855 --> 00:24:00.780
So, looking at my Sales database here,
it still says Active on SERV02,

486
00:24:00.780 --> 00:24:04.075
but it's status over here
is flagged as Unknown.

487
00:24:04.075 --> 00:24:07.761
And looking at the health information
over here, I can see that it is

488
00:24:07.761 --> 00:24:12.435
Passive Disconnected and Healthy for
SERV01, Passive ServiceDown on SERV02.

489
00:24:12.435 --> 00:24:15.998
So we can just keep refreshing, and
eventually it'll recognize that and

490
00:24:15.998 --> 00:24:17.370
flip it over.

491
00:24:17.370 --> 00:24:19.330
If I remember right,
it's a minute and a half is how long,

492
00:24:19.330 --> 00:24:21.190
it's like three 30-second intervals.

493
00:24:21.190 --> 00:24:23.960
So we'll just give it a second while
it kinda sorts through that and

494
00:24:23.960 --> 00:24:25.370
eventually goes active.

495
00:24:27.434 --> 00:24:30.460
All right, if you're in a giant hurry,
you could always come in here and

496
00:24:30.460 --> 00:24:34.220
take SERV01 and hit Activate, and
that'll bring it active right now.

497
00:24:34.220 --> 00:24:37.860
In my case, it is taking a while
to actually do that flip over.

498
00:24:39.480 --> 00:24:40.721
We're at risk of me becoming bored.

499
00:24:40.721 --> 00:24:43.581
That's always bad, and then I start
doing things and break the server.

500
00:24:43.581 --> 00:24:45.101
So, but we'll give it just a second here.

501
00:24:45.101 --> 00:24:46.746
If it doesn't become active,
I'll hit the Active button, and

502
00:24:46.746 --> 00:24:47.850
that'll take care of it.

503
00:24:47.850 --> 00:24:48.831
But it is automatic.

504
00:24:48.831 --> 00:24:51.672
It does kick that over, and
then it brings the server back up.

505
00:24:51.672 --> 00:24:53.391
Hopefully your end users don't know it.

506
00:24:53.391 --> 00:24:58.271
Really Outlook and Exchange,
they try and run in a cache mode anyway.

507
00:24:58.271 --> 00:25:00.280
So Outlook downloads their mailbox.

508
00:25:00.280 --> 00:25:05.080
A lot of users what they'll notice,
is they'll go to send an email, and

509
00:25:05.080 --> 00:25:08.380
the email will sit there in their
outbox instead of going to sent items.

510
00:25:08.380 --> 00:25:11.970
It'll just sit there kind of waiting,
and that's it, right?

511
00:25:11.970 --> 00:25:14.830
It's just kinda sitting and waiting for
those emails to move across.

512
00:25:14.830 --> 00:25:17.420
And then when the new server comes up,
the emails flow.

513
00:25:17.420 --> 00:25:23.060
So the end user, all they see is
just the email in the outbox, right?

514
00:25:23.060 --> 00:25:25.740
But then once the server is up,
it flows normal, and you're in business.

515
00:25:25.740 --> 00:25:27.990
I'm gonna go ahead and
force it to flip over, so here it is.

516
00:25:27.990 --> 00:25:30.940
Now it's gonna have to flush some
of the transaction logs out because

517
00:25:30.940 --> 00:25:34.068
of the unclean shut down on the other
system, but that shouldn't be a big deal.

518
00:25:34.068 --> 00:25:36.790
The new node will come active, and
our users will be back in business.

519
00:25:36.790 --> 00:25:40.510
So, database availability groups, there's
a couple of hoops we had to jump through

520
00:25:40.510 --> 00:25:41.470
to get them set up in the beginning.

521
00:25:41.470 --> 00:25:44.460
But once they're in place,
they're really easy to administer,

522
00:25:44.460 --> 00:25:46.630
and that's pretty much the end of it.

523
00:25:46.630 --> 00:25:51.400
So in this episode we got a chance to
see database availability groups in

524
00:25:51.400 --> 00:25:52.010
action, right?

525
00:25:52.010 --> 00:25:53.540
We created them in the last episode, but

526
00:25:53.540 --> 00:25:56.670
in this episode we moved
a database into the DAG.

527
00:25:56.670 --> 00:26:00.210
Then we got see failing it over to
another node and failing it back again,

528
00:26:00.210 --> 00:26:01.970
as well as how to monitor
it via PowerShell.

529
00:26:01.970 --> 00:26:04.581
So couple of different things
there that are all pretty useful.

530
00:26:04.581 --> 00:26:07.936
It's a great system, and it really does
take a lot of burden off of system

531
00:26:07.936 --> 00:26:11.980
administrators too if we're not having
to set up true hardware based clusters.

532
00:26:11.980 --> 00:26:14.652
Here it's just done right inside of
our systems, really works excellent.

533
00:26:14.652 --> 00:26:17.141
All right, well that's a great spot for
us to wrap this one up.

534
00:26:17.141 --> 00:26:19.461
So I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

535
00:26:19.461 --> 00:26:22.661
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

536
00:26:22.661 --> 00:26:28.920
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to properly backup and restore an Exchange mailbox database. He explains various backup strategies as well as some third party software that may be more appropriate in some situations.
episodes.title: Mailbox Database Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.603 --> 00:00:10.528
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.528 --> 00:00:12.989
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening!

3
00:00:12.989 --> 00:00:15.740
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.740 --> 00:00:17.270
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

5
00:00:17.270 --> 00:00:20.950
back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.950 --> 00:00:24.380
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at backing up and

7
00:00:24.380 --> 00:00:25.610
restoring Microsoft Exchange.

8
00:00:25.610 --> 00:00:28.870
Now, I know in all the episodes I
start off when I say things like, man,

9
00:00:28.870 --> 00:00:30.000
this is a really great feature.

10
00:00:30.000 --> 00:00:31.330
We're gonna talk about something exciting.

11
00:00:31.330 --> 00:00:35.216
But today we're going to be talking about
something that's just really really

12
00:00:35.216 --> 00:00:35.857
important.

13
00:00:35.857 --> 00:00:40.015
As an Exchange administrator, having
a reliable backup of your system and

14
00:00:40.015 --> 00:00:42.857
knowing how to restore it
is extremely essential.

15
00:00:42.857 --> 00:00:44.099
Because when a failure happens,

16
00:00:44.099 --> 00:00:46.370
you don't wanna be scrambling
trying to figure things out.

17
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:48.303
You wanna know exactly what to do and

18
00:00:48.303 --> 00:00:51.082
get that database back
online as fast as possible.

19
00:00:51.082 --> 00:00:55.177
So, this episode is actually gonna be
one of a series of episodes cuz there's

20
00:00:55.177 --> 00:00:58.337
several different ways to
backup Exchange and to restore.

21
00:00:58.337 --> 00:01:00.258
Really there's only a few
ways to back it up but

22
00:01:00.258 --> 00:01:03.730
there's several ways to restore it based
on what it is that we're trying achieve.

23
00:01:03.730 --> 00:01:07.270
And in this episode we're gonna be
tackling restoring the entire mailbox

24
00:01:07.270 --> 00:01:10.865
exchange or exchange mailbox database
in the event that we have a hard drive

25
00:01:10.865 --> 00:01:13.620
failure, server failures or
something of that nature.

26
00:01:13.620 --> 00:01:15.638
If you haven't watched it already,

27
00:01:15.638 --> 00:01:18.902
we did an episode on database
availability groups or DAGs.

28
00:01:18.902 --> 00:01:23.854
And with those, we can stop a failure from
being visible to the end user at all,

29
00:01:23.854 --> 00:01:24.600
right?

30
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:25.540
And that's pretty cool.

31
00:01:25.540 --> 00:01:28.510
When one server fails,
another server already takes over.

32
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:33.150
But we don't all have resources available
to do database availability groups.

33
00:01:33.150 --> 00:01:34.550
So for the next couple episodes,

34
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:38.790
I want to focus on technologies we can use
to back-up and restore individual servers.

35
00:01:38.790 --> 00:01:41.550
If they're not in a DAG, all right.

36
00:01:41.550 --> 00:01:44.910
So we're just gonna start off
with a plain old run of the mill

37
00:01:44.910 --> 00:01:49.370
how to I back up my mailbox database
restore or my mailbox database so

38
00:01:49.370 --> 00:01:52.310
that I can restore it in
the event of a failure, all right.

39
00:01:52.310 --> 00:01:54.670
Now when it comes to
planning your backups and

40
00:01:54.670 --> 00:01:57.460
recovery, there's a few things
we need to think about and

41
00:01:57.460 --> 00:02:02.040
the two big ones that you hear about
are the RPO and RTO, all right.

42
00:02:02.040 --> 00:02:05.680
Recovery time objective and
recovery point objective.

43
00:02:05.680 --> 00:02:10.380
The recovery time objective is,
how long can you be down for.

44
00:02:10.380 --> 00:02:13.890
If I have a failure, and
my server goes off-line, how much

45
00:02:13.890 --> 00:02:17.890
time do I have before I can restore
without my users feeling pain right?

46
00:02:17.890 --> 00:02:19.830
Before my company losing money?

47
00:02:19.830 --> 00:02:22.910
If I lose access to my mailbox for
an hour, that's not a big deal to me,

48
00:02:22.910 --> 00:02:23.860
I'm okay with that.

49
00:02:23.860 --> 00:02:24.540
It's just an hour.

50
00:02:24.540 --> 00:02:26.060
I'll check my email later.

51
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:29.300
But if I'm without email for
three days, that's a problem for me.

52
00:02:29.300 --> 00:02:33.110
I can't go days without email,
right, well that's me.

53
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:35.837
In your environment,
email might be mission critical.

54
00:02:35.837 --> 00:02:38.690
You might not be able to go
an hour without email, right?

55
00:02:38.690 --> 00:02:40.810
That could be a big deal for you.

56
00:02:40.810 --> 00:02:42.680
So, different companies
have different needs and

57
00:02:42.680 --> 00:02:45.250
you'll need to structure
your backup around that.

58
00:02:45.250 --> 00:02:48.980
Some solutions just will not work in
the amount of time that you have, and

59
00:02:48.980 --> 00:02:50.720
that's where database
availability groups are so

60
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:54.760
nice because they do instantaneous
recovery and that really works out well.

61
00:02:56.030 --> 00:02:58.512
The other part was recovery
point objective, RPO.

62
00:02:58.512 --> 00:03:02.110
And what RPO is stating is basically
how much data can I afford to lose?

63
00:03:02.110 --> 00:03:05.290
Let's say I do a backup
every night at midnight, but

64
00:03:05.290 --> 00:03:08.400
then I have a failure at 6 AM.

65
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:11.000
Well, if I go and
restore my backup from midnight,

66
00:03:11.000 --> 00:03:14.140
what happened to all my
email from midnight to 6 AM?

67
00:03:14.140 --> 00:03:15.140
It's gone.
I lost it.

68
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:16.110
All right.

69
00:03:16.110 --> 00:03:18.110
I lost six hours of email.

70
00:03:18.110 --> 00:03:19.480
Is that a big deal?

71
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:20.940
In your company that
might not be a big deal.

72
00:03:20.940 --> 00:03:23.240
You might just say whatever,
it's six hour, who cares?

73
00:03:23.240 --> 00:03:24.680
Right, at least I got
everything else back.

74
00:03:24.680 --> 00:03:26.660
And that may be fine.

75
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:29.810
But you might have a mission critical
environment where you can't afford to lose

76
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:31.970
even one single email and

77
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:36.120
in that environment using just a nightly
backup is not gonna do, right?

78
00:03:36.120 --> 00:03:37.604
Your recovery point
objective is much shorter.

79
00:03:37.604 --> 00:03:39.518
You don't wanna lose any e-mail, and

80
00:03:39.518 --> 00:03:42.600
database availability groups
are that solution, all right.

81
00:03:42.600 --> 00:03:46.350
So DAGs, that's really the number one
way to go to protect your server.

82
00:03:46.350 --> 00:03:49.030
You have a mailbox database
stored in more than one place.

83
00:03:49.030 --> 00:03:53.150
You have a database copies, right,
and that gives you that insulation.

84
00:03:53.150 --> 00:03:58.120
But one thing that DAGs don't give
us is long term retention, right?

85
00:03:58.120 --> 00:04:01.370
What if a mailbox was
deleted three months ago?

86
00:04:01.370 --> 00:04:03.540
Well, if I delete a mailbox and

87
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:08.010
it actually gets removed it gets removed
from the copies also, from the DAG copies.

88
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:12.780
So, DAGs are not a replacement for
backups, they're a supplement.

89
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:17.408
DAGs are designed to shrink your RPO and
RTO to get you online as fast as you can.

90
00:04:17.408 --> 00:04:22.212
But for long term data recovery,
we need traditional backups, all right.

91
00:04:22.212 --> 00:04:25.166
So you're normally gonna combine
these technologies together,

92
00:04:25.166 --> 00:04:26.650
not just go with one or the other.

93
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:28.480
You're gonna combine them, all right.

94
00:04:28.480 --> 00:04:29.930
So watch each of these episodes.

95
00:04:29.930 --> 00:04:31.390
See each of the different ways.

96
00:04:31.390 --> 00:04:33.850
And then figure out how to implement them
in your environment to meet the needs

97
00:04:33.850 --> 00:04:35.190
of your company.

98
00:04:35.190 --> 00:04:38.280
But a traditional backup you'll
find is actually pretty easy.

99
00:04:38.280 --> 00:04:42.010
One of the decisions we have to make
early on is do we want to use Microsoft's

100
00:04:42.010 --> 00:04:44.740
software or
do we want to use a third party, right.

101
00:04:44.740 --> 00:04:47.660
There's tons of companies out there that
make software that can backup Microsoft

102
00:04:47.660 --> 00:04:50.670
exchange and we just need to make
a decision as to which one we want, and

103
00:04:50.670 --> 00:04:52.840
there's pros and cons to each right?

104
00:04:52.840 --> 00:04:55.940
On the Microsoft side we
have Windows Server Backup.

105
00:04:55.940 --> 00:04:58.990
Windows Server Backup is built right
into Windows so it's free, right?

106
00:04:58.990 --> 00:04:59.580
Well, that's always nice.

107
00:04:59.580 --> 00:05:00.940
The price is right.

108
00:05:00.940 --> 00:05:03.489
Well, it's free because you've
already paid for the server so

109
00:05:03.489 --> 00:05:05.130
it's not completely free.

110
00:05:05.130 --> 00:05:09.320
But with that you can backup
your database and restore it.

111
00:05:09.320 --> 00:05:11.540
On a positive side, it does backups.

112
00:05:11.540 --> 00:05:14.740
On a negative side,
there's no centralized management for it.

113
00:05:14.740 --> 00:05:19.210
So if I have 50 servers, I'm having to set
up backups 50 times and if I'm monitoring

114
00:05:19.210 --> 00:05:21.820
those backups, I have to go to each of
the those 50 servers to monitor it.

115
00:05:21.820 --> 00:05:23.680
So you don't get centralized management.

116
00:05:23.680 --> 00:05:24.610
But it's cheap.

117
00:05:24.610 --> 00:05:27.020
So for small businesses,
even for some medium businesses,

118
00:05:27.020 --> 00:05:28.280
that works out really well.

119
00:05:28.280 --> 00:05:30.790
All right,
the other thing is Windows Server Backup

120
00:05:30.790 --> 00:05:33.420
doesn't do a great job of
maintaining multiple copies.

121
00:05:33.420 --> 00:05:37.360
So, if you're gonna have several backups,
spanning months or

122
00:05:37.360 --> 00:05:40.710
years even, Windows Server Backup
gets a little clunky.

123
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:44.150
So Microsoft has another product called
the System Center Data Protection Manager,

124
00:05:44.150 --> 00:05:45.700
SCDPM.

125
00:05:45.700 --> 00:05:48.460
SCDPM has centralized management and

126
00:05:48.460 --> 00:05:50.580
it can maintain copies
over the span of years.

127
00:05:50.580 --> 00:05:53.020
And it does data deduplication and
all that other stuff.

128
00:05:53.020 --> 00:05:57.130
It really does some impressive things and
that's all a part of SCDPM.

129
00:05:57.130 --> 00:05:58.430
Which is not free, right,

130
00:05:58.430 --> 00:06:02.100
it's basically a purchase product,
part of the system center suite.

131
00:06:02.100 --> 00:06:05.110
And you can back up your systems,
not just Exchange, but really any server.

132
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:06.820
So that's a great solution.

133
00:06:06.820 --> 00:06:12.120
A big advantage of the SCDPM is that if
you have a problem you call Microsoft.

134
00:06:12.120 --> 00:06:13.580
Microsoft wrote the SCDPM.

135
00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:14.580
They wrote your operating system.

136
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:15.750
They wrote Exchange.

137
00:06:15.750 --> 00:06:17.340
It's one person responsible for

138
00:06:17.340 --> 00:06:19.380
all those different entities
that make support easier.

139
00:06:20.420 --> 00:06:23.409
But it's not as feature rich as some
of the third party applications

140
00:06:23.409 --> 00:06:24.307
that are out there.

141
00:06:24.307 --> 00:06:28.909
Applications like Symantec Backup Exec,
Arc Serve, Com Vault,

142
00:06:28.909 --> 00:06:32.702
Acronis Advanced Backup for
Exchange, all of those.

143
00:06:32.702 --> 00:06:35.792
There's third party products that
can backup Exchange, and for

144
00:06:35.792 --> 00:06:39.880
the most part they're expensive,
you've got to buy them, right?

145
00:06:39.880 --> 00:06:44.240
They don't necessarily offer things
beyond with what you'd get with SCDPM or

146
00:06:44.240 --> 00:06:45.810
even Windows Server Backup.

147
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:49.450
But the big claim to fame that a lot
of those third party softwares have,

148
00:06:49.450 --> 00:06:54.770
is that they're very easy to use, and they
offer single item recovery, all right.

149
00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:58.560
In Exchange, if we use Windows Server
Backup or if we use the SCDPM,

150
00:06:58.560 --> 00:07:03.780
you can restore an entire mailbox
database, or you can restore

151
00:07:03.780 --> 00:07:09.580
an individual mailbox, but
you can't restore an individual email.

152
00:07:09.580 --> 00:07:12.450
Right.
If I just wanna get one email back,

153
00:07:12.450 --> 00:07:14.100
I've gotta restore the whole mailbox.

154
00:07:14.100 --> 00:07:16.260
Or I gotta restore
the whole mailbox database.

155
00:07:16.260 --> 00:07:18.232
I can't just restore that one email.

156
00:07:18.232 --> 00:07:21.038
So if I'm looking for individual item
restore, I probably wanna look at

157
00:07:21.038 --> 00:07:23.990
the third parties, if that something
that's important to me, all right.

158
00:07:23.990 --> 00:07:27.197
But other than that, if I just want
to be able to restore mailboxes or

159
00:07:27.197 --> 00:07:30.510
databases we can use the software
built right into windows.

160
00:07:30.510 --> 00:07:32.435
And let me show you, it's pretty easy.

161
00:07:32.435 --> 00:07:35.600
So the first thing we need
to do is to recognize

162
00:07:35.600 --> 00:07:38.232
that the backup software's not
actually installed by default.

163
00:07:38.232 --> 00:07:41.160
So we're going to have to get that
installed and it's a little bit quirky.

164
00:07:42.270 --> 00:07:46.100
For example, well here let's start off
right here, I am going to take my mailbox.

165
00:07:46.100 --> 00:07:48.580
So I'm logged into this server,
this is my mailbox.

166
00:07:48.580 --> 00:07:50.780
And I'm just gonna send myself an email.

167
00:07:50.780 --> 00:07:54.965
So I'm gonna be a little
schizophrenic today and email myself.

168
00:07:54.965 --> 00:08:00.816
And I'll just say email
sent prior to backup.

169
00:08:00.816 --> 00:08:01.930
All right.

170
00:08:01.930 --> 00:08:06.640
And I'll just say,
I sent this email prior to backing up.

171
00:08:08.390 --> 00:08:10.490
All right.
This way I'll have an email in my mailbox

172
00:08:10.490 --> 00:08:13.860
that I know was sent before
I did any kind of backup.

173
00:08:13.860 --> 00:08:15.450
And it'll take a second and it'll show up.

174
00:08:15.450 --> 00:08:16.520
So I'll have that.

175
00:08:16.520 --> 00:08:18.930
Next I need to set up
Windows Server Backup.

176
00:08:18.930 --> 00:08:21.680
Now, Windows Server Backup, you can
get to it through the Server Manager.

177
00:08:21.680 --> 00:08:22.790
If you go to the Server Manager and

178
00:08:22.790 --> 00:08:26.990
go up here to Tools, you'll see down here
at the bottom Windows Server Backup.

179
00:08:26.990 --> 00:08:27.550
All right.

180
00:08:27.550 --> 00:08:31.070
Now, on most servers like we'll
take this client access server.

181
00:08:31.070 --> 00:08:35.470
If I go to Tools and Windows Server
Backup, it's right here in my Tool menu

182
00:08:35.470 --> 00:08:38.550
but when I launch it,
it does this really annoying thing.

183
00:08:38.550 --> 00:08:42.440
The user interface,
the Admin Tools installed, but

184
00:08:42.440 --> 00:08:45.220
the actual backup software is not.

185
00:08:45.220 --> 00:08:46.650
So see how it's telling me here,

186
00:08:46.650 --> 00:08:50.870
I can't actually do my own Local Backup
because the software isn't installed.

187
00:08:50.870 --> 00:08:52.210
So I need to install it.

188
00:08:52.210 --> 00:08:55.080
And the way we do that is by going
back into our Server Manager.

189
00:08:55.080 --> 00:08:57.830
And going to Manage and
Add Remove Roles and Features.

190
00:08:57.830 --> 00:09:01.440
And the Windows Server Backup is
a feature, we just need to add that in.

191
00:09:01.440 --> 00:09:05.290
So if I move to the Wizard, I'll skip past
the Roles cuz I'm not messing with those.

192
00:09:05.290 --> 00:09:09.130
But here inside the Features,
I can find Windows Server Backup.

193
00:09:09.130 --> 00:09:11.270
I can check it and
I can move forward, all right.

194
00:09:11.270 --> 00:09:14.810
And that's gonna install
the actual backup software.

195
00:09:14.810 --> 00:09:17.680
And I've already done that
here on my mailbox server.

196
00:09:17.680 --> 00:09:21.500
So this is my mailbox server,
this other one is my client access server.

197
00:09:21.500 --> 00:09:25.550
But here in my mailbox, if I go to
Tools and Windows Server Backup.

198
00:09:26.610 --> 00:09:27.500
When I launch that and

199
00:09:27.500 --> 00:09:30.910
I go to my Local Backup,
instead of telling me I can't do a backup,

200
00:09:30.910 --> 00:09:34.630
it shows me what backups I already have
and gives me the ability to schedule it.

201
00:09:34.630 --> 00:09:38.370
So, first off, we just need to
get that installed, all right?

202
00:09:38.370 --> 00:09:41.050
Once that's done,
we're ready to start taking backups.

203
00:09:41.050 --> 00:09:45.170
Now, Windows Server Backup can backup
to a couple of different places.

204
00:09:45.170 --> 00:09:46.950
It can backup to a network share.

205
00:09:46.950 --> 00:09:47.860
And that's kinda nice.

206
00:09:47.860 --> 00:09:50.170
You can create a centralized network
share somewhere that you send all

207
00:09:50.170 --> 00:09:50.780
your backups to.

208
00:09:50.780 --> 00:09:56.250
But the problem with the backups to
a network, is it only supports one backup.

209
00:09:56.250 --> 00:09:59.420
So every night or every hour,
however often you run your backup,

210
00:09:59.420 --> 00:10:02.120
you're gonna be overwriting
the previous backup.

211
00:10:02.120 --> 00:10:04.960
So if you wanna maintain
like a backup history,

212
00:10:04.960 --> 00:10:07.160
you can't do that with a network share.

213
00:10:07.160 --> 00:10:09.280
So instead you could backup
to some kind of local media.

214
00:10:09.280 --> 00:10:12.350
Like I've added an extra hard drive to
this server, so I'll backup to that.

215
00:10:12.350 --> 00:10:15.660
And that will let you
backup multiple backups.

216
00:10:15.660 --> 00:10:19.230
Or you could back up to DVD or
tape if you've got removable media.

217
00:10:19.230 --> 00:10:20.880
Those are nice cuz you
could take them off-site.

218
00:10:20.880 --> 00:10:24.510
The hard drive I'm gonna back up to I
can't take off-site, it's in the server.

219
00:10:24.510 --> 00:10:27.540
But if you want removable media,
it certainly supports that too.

220
00:10:27.540 --> 00:10:30.050
You just have to remember to go and
change the media out each day.

221
00:10:31.070 --> 00:10:32.620
All right, so
I'm gonna take a backup of this server.

222
00:10:32.620 --> 00:10:36.500
Now, I could set up a Backup Schedule and
run backups every night,

223
00:10:36.500 --> 00:10:39.040
or however often it is I
needed to protect my data.

224
00:10:39.040 --> 00:10:40.580
Think about your RPO, right.

225
00:10:40.580 --> 00:10:42.240
Your Recovery Point Objective.

226
00:10:42.240 --> 00:10:46.340
How much data can you lose and
it still be okay?

227
00:10:46.340 --> 00:10:48.390
If your company has a six-hour RPO,

228
00:10:48.390 --> 00:10:51.800
then I'm probably need to run
a backup every six hours.

229
00:10:51.800 --> 00:10:52.860
So that when there's a failure,

230
00:10:52.860 --> 00:10:56.950
I know I have a backup within the last six
hours and I can hit my RPO, all right.

231
00:10:56.950 --> 00:10:59.965
But what happens if a backup fails?

232
00:10:59.965 --> 00:11:01.735
If a backup fails and
I'm running every 6 hours,

233
00:11:01.735 --> 00:11:04.005
I could go 12 hours without a backup now.

234
00:11:04.005 --> 00:11:06.705
And that would be a problem,
I'd break my RPO.

235
00:11:06.705 --> 00:11:09.341
So you might even wanna go
shorter than what your RPO is.

236
00:11:09.341 --> 00:11:13.165
If my RPO is every 6 hours, I might
set the backups to run every 3 hours.

237
00:11:13.165 --> 00:11:15.315
So if one fails, I can correct it.

238
00:11:15.315 --> 00:11:17.735
The next one runs and
I haven't gone beyond 6 hours, right?

239
00:11:17.735 --> 00:11:21.145
So, just be aware of little decisions like
that, that affect when our backups run.

240
00:11:22.190 --> 00:11:23.675
I'm gonna go and do a one-time back up,

241
00:11:23.675 --> 00:11:26.050
instead of a schedule cuz
it's just a lab server here.

242
00:11:26.050 --> 00:11:29.805
The first time you run it, it doesn't
have any previously scheduled options.

243
00:11:29.805 --> 00:11:32.190
So we have to define the options
of what we wanna back up and so

244
00:11:32.190 --> 00:11:34.690
I'll just choose Different Options and
tell what to backup.

245
00:11:34.690 --> 00:11:36.970
Now, when you do a backup,

246
00:11:36.970 --> 00:11:41.610
you can do a Custom backup and
just backup exchange if you want.

247
00:11:41.610 --> 00:11:42.840
But it's not recommended.

248
00:11:42.840 --> 00:11:45.260
Microsoft recommends doing
a full server backup.

249
00:11:45.260 --> 00:11:48.280
And the reason is,
it gives you the most flexibility.

250
00:11:48.280 --> 00:11:53.440
With the full server backup,
if your entire server gets destroyed.

251
00:11:53.440 --> 00:11:56.930
Well, you can restore the backup and
it will install Windows.

252
00:11:56.930 --> 00:11:58.172
It'll put Exchange back on it.

253
00:11:58.172 --> 00:12:01.698
It will put your mailbox database
to get you a bare metal recovery.

254
00:12:01.698 --> 00:12:04.642
You could bind an entirely new server and
have it backup and

255
00:12:04.642 --> 00:12:08.028
running in short order with a full backup,
right?

256
00:12:08.028 --> 00:12:10.140
Also with the full backup,
maybe my server's fine,

257
00:12:10.140 --> 00:12:11.570
it's just the database that's corrupt.

258
00:12:11.570 --> 00:12:15.170
I can restore just the database,
so I have that flexibility.

259
00:12:15.170 --> 00:12:19.830
If I go Custom, I start losing
the ability to restore certain things.

260
00:12:19.830 --> 00:12:22.370
So, we typically wanna
do a Full server backup.

261
00:12:24.320 --> 00:12:25.960
Then it's gonna ask where
I wanna back it up to.

262
00:12:25.960 --> 00:12:28.030
And I can back up to
a Remote shared folder.

263
00:12:28.030 --> 00:12:31.610
If I have a DVD drive or if I have
a tape drive, I can back up to those.

264
00:12:31.610 --> 00:12:34.910
But I'm gonna back up to an extra
hard drive that I've got and

265
00:12:34.910 --> 00:12:36.370
I'll just pick that hard drive right here.

266
00:12:36.370 --> 00:12:37.780
It's my E drive.

267
00:12:37.780 --> 00:12:41.290
Now, when you choose a full back up, by
default it's gonna backup all your drives.

268
00:12:41.290 --> 00:12:44.890
Which would include my E-drive, so it's
gonna ask me if I want to exclude that.

269
00:12:44.890 --> 00:12:49.120
Here we go and I'll go and say yes to
exclude it, don't back up the E drive.

270
00:12:49.120 --> 00:12:51.750
And so now I can see it's gonna
do a Bare metal recovery,

271
00:12:51.750 --> 00:12:53.400
backing up the whole server.

272
00:12:53.400 --> 00:12:57.160
It's gonna get the entire C drive and
it's gonna get my System state.

273
00:12:57.160 --> 00:12:59.780
The System state includes my registry,

274
00:12:59.780 --> 00:13:02.280
as well as some of
the Exchange configuration.

275
00:13:02.280 --> 00:13:05.270
The bulk of my Exchange configuration
is in the Active Directory though, so

276
00:13:05.270 --> 00:13:06.570
I don't actually have to back that up.

277
00:13:06.570 --> 00:13:08.570
It'll be replicated with the AD.

278
00:13:08.570 --> 00:13:11.490
It's the databases on the C
drive that I really care about.

279
00:13:12.660 --> 00:13:15.400
Now I'll go and hit Backup and
now it's gonna back my server up.

280
00:13:15.400 --> 00:13:18.650
Now, depending on the size of your server,
this can take a while, right?

281
00:13:18.650 --> 00:13:22.637
My server, I think is probably
around 23 or 24 gigs of data, so

282
00:13:22.637 --> 00:13:24.430
it's gonna run that backup.

283
00:13:24.430 --> 00:13:27.700
And it'll take it just a little while
to get that copied over and in-place.

284
00:13:27.700 --> 00:13:30.750
Now while that's running, let me talk
about what's happening in the background.

285
00:13:30.750 --> 00:13:33.280
In the background, the Volume
Shadow Copy Service is kicking in.

286
00:13:33.280 --> 00:13:37.350
And it's taking a snapshot of
my server as it is right now.

287
00:13:37.350 --> 00:13:39.750
So it's already done that, okay.

288
00:13:39.750 --> 00:13:44.120
Then when it starts to back up, it's
backing up that Volume Shadow Copy image.

289
00:13:44.120 --> 00:13:47.280
So if new email comes in right now, well,

290
00:13:47.280 --> 00:13:49.740
the Volume Shadow Copy
snapshot was already taken.

291
00:13:49.740 --> 00:13:54.440
So, if my backup's set to start at 6 PM,
it takes the snapshot at 6 PM and

292
00:13:54.440 --> 00:13:56.570
it backs up my server
exactly as it is at 6 PM.

293
00:13:56.570 --> 00:14:01.150
If the backup takes 30 minutes,
new email comes in between 6 pm and 6:30.

294
00:14:01.150 --> 00:14:05.950
But it's not a part of the backup, because
we're backing up that snapshot, all right?

295
00:14:05.950 --> 00:14:07.240
So that's all happening in the background.

296
00:14:07.240 --> 00:14:08.540
And we don't have to
get involved with that.

297
00:14:08.540 --> 00:14:13.240
That's all automatic and that's just
kind of occurring without us, all right.

298
00:14:13.240 --> 00:14:15.865
In the meantime,
it's writing this backup to the drive.

299
00:14:15.865 --> 00:14:20.090
And when it writes it to the drive, if I
browse to it here, we can kinda see it.

300
00:14:20.090 --> 00:14:23.940
It's creating this WindowsImageBackup
folder and it's giving the server name.

301
00:14:23.940 --> 00:14:27.330
Cuz you could actually store backups from
more than one server in the same location.

302
00:14:27.330 --> 00:14:28.770
So here's my LAB-MAILBOX01,

303
00:14:28.770 --> 00:14:33.240
and as I browse into that, we can
see the actual backup being created.

304
00:14:33.240 --> 00:14:36.070
Now, we can't really look at
the backup files cuz they're VHDs,

305
00:14:36.070 --> 00:14:38.640
they're virtual hard drives and
that's pretty awesome.

306
00:14:38.640 --> 00:14:40.680
Because it means when
I restore this server,

307
00:14:40.680 --> 00:14:43.920
I could restore it to a physical server or
a virtual server.

308
00:14:43.920 --> 00:14:47.130
You could restore this right into Hyper-V
to get back up and running pretty quickly.

309
00:14:47.130 --> 00:14:48.190
It's neat.
They support that.

310
00:14:49.540 --> 00:14:51.290
Now, other things we need to think about.

311
00:14:51.290 --> 00:14:53.200
I'm backing up a mailbox server, right?

312
00:14:53.200 --> 00:14:55.280
A mailbox server has
a mailbox database on it.

313
00:14:55.280 --> 00:14:57.280
It's got our email and
we know that's important.

314
00:14:57.280 --> 00:14:58.940
We know we need to back that up.

315
00:14:58.940 --> 00:15:00.340
So on a mailbox server,

316
00:15:00.340 --> 00:15:03.680
the key thing that I need to back
up is that mailbox database.

317
00:15:03.680 --> 00:15:07.270
But there's some other stuff on the
mailbox server that's important, right.

318
00:15:07.270 --> 00:15:08.940
Things that we kind of forget about.

319
00:15:08.940 --> 00:15:13.870
For example, on your mailbox server, you
might have your transport rules defined.

320
00:15:13.870 --> 00:15:16.470
Well the transport rules get partly
stored in the Active Directory, but

321
00:15:16.470 --> 00:15:18.430
then they get applied
on the server itself.

322
00:15:18.430 --> 00:15:21.370
And so, those are getting backed
up as a part of this too.

323
00:15:21.370 --> 00:15:25.060
Also, if we're using
the Unified Communications Management,

324
00:15:25.060 --> 00:15:27.278
we might have custom audio prompts.

325
00:15:27.278 --> 00:15:31.270
There's these default ones that come with
Microsoft's Unified Communication Solution

326
00:15:31.270 --> 00:15:32.260
with Lync.

327
00:15:32.260 --> 00:15:35.950
But if you record custom ones,
your own voice, your company's name.

328
00:15:35.950 --> 00:15:38.330
Those actually get stored on
your mailbox server where

329
00:15:38.330 --> 00:15:40.400
the Unified Communication Service
is running.

330
00:15:40.400 --> 00:15:42.490
And so when we run this backup,
we're backing those up too.

331
00:15:42.490 --> 00:15:43.330
And that's pretty important.

332
00:15:43.330 --> 00:15:44.660
We wanna make sure that we get those.

333
00:15:45.740 --> 00:15:49.442
[COUGH] Some of the other things,
if you've got message tracking turned on.

334
00:15:49.442 --> 00:15:51.496
Those log files are getting
stored on your servers, so

335
00:15:51.496 --> 00:15:52.981
we're backing up those logs, right?

336
00:15:52.981 --> 00:15:54.606
Those are all different things.

337
00:15:54.606 --> 00:15:56.633
But if you're not using
Unified Communications,

338
00:15:56.633 --> 00:15:58.528
if you don't have message
tracking turned on.

339
00:15:58.528 --> 00:16:01.139
Then it's the mailbox data,
this is what you really care about, and

340
00:16:01.139 --> 00:16:02.683
these are getting backed up right here.

341
00:16:02.683 --> 00:16:05.881
Now, the other server type that we
have is the client access server,

342
00:16:05.881 --> 00:16:07.994
we probably need to back that up too,
right?

343
00:16:07.994 --> 00:16:10.280
Well, not really.

344
00:16:10.280 --> 00:16:12.210
What's on your client access server?

345
00:16:12.210 --> 00:16:15.490
At the end of the day, your client
access server doesn't have mail queues.

346
00:16:15.490 --> 00:16:16.560
Right?
Cuz it runs the front end

347
00:16:16.560 --> 00:16:17.300
transport service.

348
00:16:17.300 --> 00:16:19.690
It doesn't run the hub
transport service anymore.

349
00:16:19.690 --> 00:16:21.210
So it doesn't have mail queues,

350
00:16:21.210 --> 00:16:25.530
it doesn't have mailboxes,
it just has the Outlook WebApp webpages.

351
00:16:25.530 --> 00:16:29.010
It's got the Exchange control panel,
the Exchange administration center.

352
00:16:29.010 --> 00:16:32.950
Those things, but those, you can get those
right off the install disk of Exchange.

353
00:16:32.950 --> 00:16:34.830
We don't need to back those up, do we?

354
00:16:34.830 --> 00:16:38.960
So really the only thing on a client
access server that's important to us

355
00:16:38.960 --> 00:16:40.400
is the certificate.

356
00:16:40.400 --> 00:16:44.350
If you've purchased a certificate from
an outside vendor, an SSL certificate, and

357
00:16:44.350 --> 00:16:46.140
you've got it attached to OWA and

358
00:16:46.140 --> 00:16:48.420
the other services that are there,
that's kind of important.

359
00:16:48.420 --> 00:16:49.950
We want that, right?

360
00:16:49.950 --> 00:16:53.160
But everything else in the client
access server is really not a big deal.

361
00:16:53.160 --> 00:16:54.920
You can easily just reinstall Exchange and

362
00:16:54.920 --> 00:16:58.190
have that back, attach your
certificate and you're in business.

363
00:16:58.190 --> 00:17:01.170
So your client access servers,
you might not even back those up.

364
00:17:01.170 --> 00:17:02.440
I know plenty of people don't.

365
00:17:02.440 --> 00:17:03.460
Plenty of people do.

366
00:17:03.460 --> 00:17:05.630
You can do a full metal backup
of your client access server and

367
00:17:05.630 --> 00:17:10.120
quickly recover from it, but
if your backup is a week, a month,

368
00:17:10.120 --> 00:17:12.560
even a year or old and
a client access server,

369
00:17:12.560 --> 00:17:15.750
the only thing you're gonna miss out
on are your Windows updates, right.

370
00:17:15.750 --> 00:17:17.910
And if you've issued a new certificate so

371
00:17:17.910 --> 00:17:20.540
your client access servers
are a lot less sensitive.

372
00:17:20.540 --> 00:17:23.430
That you don't have to back them up as
often as you do your mailbox server.

373
00:17:24.480 --> 00:17:27.380
All right, so my mailbox backup
just finished right there.

374
00:17:27.380 --> 00:17:30.835
So I go and hit close, so
I got a good backup taken off my database.

375
00:17:30.835 --> 00:17:34.700
Now what I can do is I can
jump back to my mailbox.

376
00:17:34.700 --> 00:17:37.540
And in my mailbox,
I'm gonna send myself another email.

377
00:17:37.540 --> 00:17:41.230
So I'll just fire off another email to me,
emailing myself today.

378
00:17:41.230 --> 00:17:45.460
And this one will be email
sent after the backup.

379
00:17:46.870 --> 00:17:47.700
All right?

380
00:17:47.700 --> 00:17:53.140
So, now I've got content in my
mailbox that was sent prior to and

381
00:17:53.140 --> 00:17:53.990
after the backup.

382
00:17:55.010 --> 00:17:57.950
And I can see that prior to email right
there and there's the one sent after.

383
00:17:57.950 --> 00:18:02.140
All right, so I'm in my mailbox,
things are running great.

384
00:18:02.140 --> 00:18:03.660
And then something happens.

385
00:18:03.660 --> 00:18:07.300
Something happens and it could be a little
problem, it could be a big problem.

386
00:18:07.300 --> 00:18:09.371
It could be my entire server is destroyed.

387
00:18:09.371 --> 00:18:13.011
If my entire server is destroyed,
I go in and buy a new server and

388
00:18:13.011 --> 00:18:15.141
I take this full back-up that I did,

389
00:18:15.141 --> 00:18:19.979
I boot off a Windows Server 2012 disc and
I tell it I want to do a restore, right?

390
00:18:19.979 --> 00:18:23.813
It's in the menu options of the installer
in Windows Server 2012 and you point it

391
00:18:23.813 --> 00:18:27.320
to this full back-up and it restores
my server and we're back in business.

392
00:18:27.320 --> 00:18:28.880
That's easy, we've seen that.

393
00:18:28.880 --> 00:18:32.510
If you've watched our Windows Server 2012
shows, we've shown that process before.

394
00:18:33.590 --> 00:18:35.910
But what if my server's okay?

395
00:18:35.910 --> 00:18:39.480
What if it's not the server that's failed,
but it's the database itself?

396
00:18:39.480 --> 00:18:42.730
Maybe the rate array the database
was sitting on got corrupted.

397
00:18:42.730 --> 00:18:47.080
Maybe an antivirus software quarantined
some of my transaction log files and

398
00:18:47.080 --> 00:18:48.710
really hosed things up that way.

399
00:18:48.710 --> 00:18:51.570
Maybe the database just got
corrupted somehow right?

400
00:18:51.570 --> 00:18:53.910
Maybe some virus has
spread throughout it and

401
00:18:53.910 --> 00:18:57.520
I just want to restore the database,
not the whole server right?

402
00:18:57.520 --> 00:19:00.240
Just the database, well we can do that.

403
00:19:00.240 --> 00:19:04.650
First off let me simulate a problem, I'm
gonna take our database and so I'll just

404
00:19:04.650 --> 00:19:09.360
go down here to servers and databases,
and I'm gonna dismount my database.

405
00:19:11.810 --> 00:19:13.310
And that's going to take it offline.

406
00:19:13.310 --> 00:19:15.110
So as soon as that database is offline,

407
00:19:15.110 --> 00:19:18.070
now users can't get to their
email anymore, all right?

408
00:19:18.070 --> 00:19:21.210
And then I'm gonna go and rename
the database file so that its missing.

409
00:19:21.210 --> 00:19:22.580
So that's dismounting in the background.

410
00:19:22.580 --> 00:19:26.840
And I'm going to browse in my hard
drive to where that database is.

411
00:19:26.840 --> 00:19:30.220
Buried 20 directories deep,
which I will get to eventually.

412
00:19:31.310 --> 00:19:33.220
And I'll find that mailbox database.

413
00:19:33.220 --> 00:19:33.920
There it is.

414
00:19:33.920 --> 00:19:36.990
So there's the mailbox database, and let
me just make sure it actually dismounted.

415
00:19:36.990 --> 00:19:40.030
It did.
And I'm just going to rename that file.

416
00:19:40.030 --> 00:19:43.090
Right?
So, I'll just stick like .old on the end.

417
00:19:43.090 --> 00:19:46.740
And that database is now gone as
far as the system is concerned.

418
00:19:46.740 --> 00:19:50.140
And gone, corrupted, failed,
whatever it doesn't matter.

419
00:19:50.140 --> 00:19:54.100
If the raid array failed, I need to go and
replace the hard drives and this

420
00:19:54.100 --> 00:19:57.310
was stored on, let's say it was stored
on my D drive or F drive or whatever.

421
00:19:57.310 --> 00:19:59.900
I would just need to make sure I
had a D or an F drive back again.

422
00:19:59.900 --> 00:20:01.760
Right?
You want to recreate that same path

423
00:20:01.760 --> 00:20:03.250
that you had before.

424
00:20:03.250 --> 00:20:05.210
And now we can run a restore.

425
00:20:05.210 --> 00:20:09.190
And when you run your restore you're
just gonna restore the database

426
00:20:09.190 --> 00:20:10.530
right back on to the server.

427
00:20:10.530 --> 00:20:11.210
Okay?

428
00:20:11.210 --> 00:20:14.190
So fortunately we don't
have to do a full restore.

429
00:20:14.190 --> 00:20:17.080
My backup was 21 gigs in size.

430
00:20:17.080 --> 00:20:20.070
But that mailbox database,
it's only 250 megs.

431
00:20:20.070 --> 00:20:24.830
So I don't want to restore 21 gigs of
data when I only need 10% of that.

432
00:20:24.830 --> 00:20:31.270
I need a much smaller sized amount of
data or not 10%, just 1% of that data.

433
00:20:31.270 --> 00:20:34.630
[LAUGH] Any how let me go in here and
I'm gonna restore just that database.

434
00:20:34.630 --> 00:20:39.080
So what we do is we jump back into
our Windows Server backup and,

435
00:20:39.080 --> 00:20:40.650
over on the right side
you can choose recover,

436
00:20:40.650 --> 00:20:44.310
and when you go to recover, it's asking
you what server you wanna recover.

437
00:20:44.310 --> 00:20:45.060
I'm recovering this one.

438
00:20:45.060 --> 00:20:47.700
And then it asks you to pick a date.

439
00:20:47.700 --> 00:20:49.480
If you've got more than one backup,

440
00:20:49.480 --> 00:20:51.900
you can choose what date
you wanna roll back to.

441
00:20:51.900 --> 00:20:54.660
Normally we want the newest
backup available and

442
00:20:54.660 --> 00:20:55.970
that's what it's gonna choose by default.

443
00:20:55.970 --> 00:20:59.120
So it's showing my newest
backup is today at 10:04 AM.

444
00:20:59.120 --> 00:21:00.580
That's the one that I'm gonna restore.

445
00:21:00.580 --> 00:21:01.170
All right.

446
00:21:01.170 --> 00:21:04.440
But I could go back in time if
that's what I was looking to do.

447
00:21:04.440 --> 00:21:07.450
And it'll have any date that has
the back up will be written in bold.

448
00:21:07.450 --> 00:21:10.680
See how that 19 is kinda bold but
the other numbers aren't?

449
00:21:10.680 --> 00:21:12.180
And that's letting me know
there's a backup on that date.

450
00:21:12.180 --> 00:21:16.030
All right, now's where things
get a little bit tricky.

451
00:21:16.030 --> 00:21:19.190
When you go to do the restore you
can restore entire hard drives,

452
00:21:19.190 --> 00:21:20.770
you can restore files and folders.

453
00:21:20.770 --> 00:21:23.810
What we want to restore is an application.

454
00:21:23.810 --> 00:21:26.890
You might be tempted to choose files and
folders, and

455
00:21:26.890 --> 00:21:29.880
if you do that you could go and you could
choose that EDB file and restore it.

456
00:21:29.880 --> 00:21:32.430
The problem is,
what about your transaction logs?

457
00:21:32.430 --> 00:21:36.200
What about the other things that
are associated with that database?

458
00:21:36.200 --> 00:21:38.210
Well those might be messed up too and so

459
00:21:38.210 --> 00:21:40.810
we might need to bring in
that whole database itself.

460
00:21:40.810 --> 00:21:43.350
So it's better to choose applications.

461
00:21:43.350 --> 00:21:45.930
When you choose applications
you can move forward and

462
00:21:45.930 --> 00:21:47.880
Microsoft Exchange will be
right there in the list.

463
00:21:47.880 --> 00:21:50.480
That was part of the system
state that was backed up.

464
00:21:50.480 --> 00:21:52.340
And so I've got that Exchange backup and

465
00:21:52.340 --> 00:21:57.040
if I view its details I can see
right here that it's got that

466
00:21:57.040 --> 00:22:00.680
mailbox backup right there and
that's got my Exchange databases in there.

467
00:22:00.680 --> 00:22:02.180
So that's the one that I want.

468
00:22:02.180 --> 00:22:04.500
Now I do have to make a decision.

469
00:22:04.500 --> 00:22:08.720
If I do full backups every night,
I'm gonna restore a full backup and

470
00:22:08.720 --> 00:22:11.200
my database will be back online and
that'll be great.

471
00:22:11.200 --> 00:22:12.110
All right?

472
00:22:12.110 --> 00:22:15.110
But what if I run a full
backup at midnight and

473
00:22:15.110 --> 00:22:19.220
then I run incremental backups
every day at, or every hour.

474
00:22:19.220 --> 00:22:21.700
We'll say every hour,
I run an incremental backup.

475
00:22:21.700 --> 00:22:25.830
Well, I would need to recover my full
backup, and then follow that up by doing

476
00:22:25.830 --> 00:22:28.640
all my incremental's to get
back to current, all right.

477
00:22:28.640 --> 00:22:32.590
Now if we're doing the back ups right
here in the Windows server back up and

478
00:22:32.590 --> 00:22:34.490
we're doing the back ups on disk or

479
00:22:34.490 --> 00:22:39.370
network share, well I don't have to worry
about that, it'll figure that out for me.

480
00:22:39.370 --> 00:22:41.100
But if I'm doing the back ups to tape or

481
00:22:41.100 --> 00:22:44.570
DVD, I"m gonna have to
restore the full one first.

482
00:22:44.570 --> 00:22:48.680
And then restore each of the incrementals
all the way back to the latest one to get

483
00:22:48.680 --> 00:22:49.520
back in business.

484
00:22:49.520 --> 00:22:52.532
So if I'm gonna have to do more than one
restore it's really important that I check

485
00:22:52.532 --> 00:22:53.570
this option here.

486
00:22:53.570 --> 00:22:56.930
Do not perform a roll four recovery
of the application database.

487
00:22:56.930 --> 00:22:58.070
All right.

488
00:22:58.070 --> 00:23:02.380
What happens is on your very last restore,
so let's say you have to do five,

489
00:23:02.380 --> 00:23:04.760
you have a full and
then four incrementals.

490
00:23:04.760 --> 00:23:08.680
On the very last one, you uncheck this,
and it'll restore the database and

491
00:23:08.680 --> 00:23:10.000
bring it live.

492
00:23:10.000 --> 00:23:12.770
But if you've got more backups to restore,
you check this, and

493
00:23:12.770 --> 00:23:16.770
that says, go ahead and restore the data,
but don't bring the database live yet.

494
00:23:16.770 --> 00:23:20.300
Hold it down so
we can continue doing more restores.

495
00:23:20.300 --> 00:23:24.040
And on the last one you'll uncheck that,
and then we'll be done.

496
00:23:24.040 --> 00:23:26.540
I just have one full back up,
so this is my last one.

497
00:23:26.540 --> 00:23:28.870
I'll leave that unchecked and
I'll move forward.

498
00:23:28.870 --> 00:23:30.820
And it's gonna restore.

499
00:23:30.820 --> 00:23:33.820
Now, if my database was corrupted,

500
00:23:33.820 --> 00:23:37.000
I just want to restore right
back to the original location.

501
00:23:37.000 --> 00:23:40.430
But that's gonna restore
the whole mailbox database.

502
00:23:40.430 --> 00:23:44.825
If I just want one person's mailbox,
I can recover to another location and

503
00:23:44.825 --> 00:23:46.091
lift it out of there.

504
00:23:46.091 --> 00:23:49.641
Or, if I'm trying to recover this,
and the hard drive isn't available and

505
00:23:49.641 --> 00:23:53.356
I have a different drive letter, I can
choose to recover to another location and

506
00:23:53.356 --> 00:23:54.648
send it to that other spot.

507
00:23:54.648 --> 00:23:56.365
So I got a couple of
different choices here.

508
00:23:56.365 --> 00:24:00.442
But typically we're just gonna recover to
the original location to get this database

509
00:24:00.442 --> 00:24:01.810
back online.

510
00:24:01.810 --> 00:24:04.250
And so when I move forward it's
got all the information it needs,

511
00:24:04.250 --> 00:24:07.610
it's gonna restore, and this will run
much faster than the backup because I'm

512
00:24:07.610 --> 00:24:11.150
just restoring my Exchange
data not the whole server.

513
00:24:11.150 --> 00:24:15.230
So it should be, I don't know,
somewhere in the 300 meg range.

514
00:24:15.230 --> 00:24:17.610
The database itself was 250 megs.

515
00:24:17.610 --> 00:24:20.300
But then you've got some other Exchange
files that it's gonna replace and

516
00:24:20.300 --> 00:24:21.490
put back, too.

517
00:24:21.490 --> 00:24:23.330
So that restore's gonna run.

518
00:24:23.330 --> 00:24:27.930
When it's done, my database will be
back because I unchecked the option in

519
00:24:27.930 --> 00:24:30.710
the menu there, it's gonna automatically
bring the database alive and

520
00:24:30.710 --> 00:24:33.930
my users should be able to get
back into their email again.

521
00:24:33.930 --> 00:24:34.610
Okay?

522
00:24:34.610 --> 00:24:36.160
So that's happening right now.

523
00:24:36.160 --> 00:24:38.100
See how it says preparing to recover?

524
00:24:38.100 --> 00:24:41.420
What it's doing is it's going through and
adjusting a few little settings for us.

525
00:24:41.420 --> 00:24:43.190
Some of the settings are ones
that we can't even adjust for

526
00:24:43.190 --> 00:24:45.850
ourselves, just getting
that database ready.

527
00:24:45.850 --> 00:24:49.410
If the database records are already
there and the database is mounted,

528
00:24:49.410 --> 00:24:52.440
it's gotta dismount the database to
be able to do this restore, and so

529
00:24:52.440 --> 00:24:54.300
it'll do that process in the background.

530
00:24:54.300 --> 00:24:57.540
So, there it goes actually running,
270 megs of data,

531
00:24:57.540 --> 00:24:59.870
so just under that 300 megs that I said.

532
00:24:59.870 --> 00:25:04.520
And see how it says it's done 100%
recovered, but it's still working?

533
00:25:04.520 --> 00:25:07.850
It's gotta roll forward the transaction
logs on the database, and

534
00:25:07.850 --> 00:25:08.950
then it's gotta bring it live.

535
00:25:08.950 --> 00:25:09.990
So it's doing that.

536
00:25:09.990 --> 00:25:12.730
And it's not until the database is
actually live that it'll say that it's

537
00:25:12.730 --> 00:25:14.270
finished, so we'll give it a moment.

538
00:25:14.270 --> 00:25:17.250
But if we look on the hard drive,
we can see what it's doing.

539
00:25:17.250 --> 00:25:19.360
See how it restored that EDB file?

540
00:25:19.360 --> 00:25:20.710
So it brought that back from the backup.

541
00:25:20.710 --> 00:25:22.940
There's the one that I renamed,
still sitting there.

542
00:25:22.940 --> 00:25:26.770
But that's the one that it just
restored and brought back online.

543
00:25:26.770 --> 00:25:28.710
All right.

544
00:25:28.710 --> 00:25:29.840
So now that it says that it's done,

545
00:25:29.840 --> 00:25:34.710
I should be able to log back into my
mailbox and let's see what we get, right?

546
00:25:34.710 --> 00:25:40.410
I'm gonna open up a new OWA window,
and we'll get connected into that.

547
00:25:41.470 --> 00:25:44.390
Now, if I try to log in while my database
was offline, I would have gotten

548
00:25:44.390 --> 00:25:48.850
an error message, saying that it couldn't
contact it, but I log in and here I am.

549
00:25:48.850 --> 00:25:51.300
I got logged in, I'm in my mailbox, and

550
00:25:51.300 --> 00:25:55.936
notice something,
here's my email sent prior to the backup,

551
00:25:55.936 --> 00:25:57.980
here's my email sent after the backup,
how do they get that?

552
00:25:57.980 --> 00:26:00.107
How do they get an email
sent after the backup?

553
00:26:00.107 --> 00:26:02.428
I renamed the database, right?

554
00:26:02.428 --> 00:26:04.912
So the database was completely deleted and

555
00:26:04.912 --> 00:26:08.987
somehow I magically got an email
that wasn't included in the backup.

556
00:26:08.987 --> 00:26:10.210
All right?

557
00:26:10.210 --> 00:26:13.610
How that worked is with transaction logs,
right?

558
00:26:13.610 --> 00:26:16.910
When you send a change
to an Exchange database,

559
00:26:16.910 --> 00:26:18.950
the change doesn't go
directly to the database.

560
00:26:18.950 --> 00:26:21.970
It goes to the transaction logs first.

561
00:26:21.970 --> 00:26:26.770
Once it's in the transaction logs,
then, it gets written to the database.

562
00:26:26.770 --> 00:26:29.340
Well, the change stays
in the transaction logs.

563
00:26:29.340 --> 00:26:31.660
It stays there until
you run another backup.

564
00:26:31.660 --> 00:26:33.100
I haven't run another backup.

565
00:26:33.100 --> 00:26:37.320
So, that new email was in
those transaction logs, and

566
00:26:37.320 --> 00:26:40.220
so exchange saw that and said hey,
I'm gonna put the database back but

567
00:26:40.220 --> 00:26:42.400
oh look, you've got some transaction logs.

568
00:26:42.400 --> 00:26:44.170
Let me roll those forward too, and

569
00:26:44.170 --> 00:26:47.830
that means I was able to recover
right to the point of failure.

570
00:26:47.830 --> 00:26:50.470
And I didn't loose one single email,

571
00:26:50.470 --> 00:26:53.550
my RPO here was zero,
my recovery point was zero.

572
00:26:53.550 --> 00:26:56.494
I didn't lose any data, that's perfect.

573
00:26:56.494 --> 00:27:00.471
If you can recover your transaction logs,
you can get right to the point of failure,

574
00:27:00.471 --> 00:27:01.450
all right?

575
00:27:01.450 --> 00:27:05.500
Instead if I had lost all of my data,
so if I go back here and

576
00:27:05.500 --> 00:27:10.190
I'll dismount that database, see,
I was mounted again, so I'll dismount it.

577
00:27:10.190 --> 00:27:12.643
And if I had been
a little more aggressive,

578
00:27:12.643 --> 00:27:15.234
instead of just deleting
the database file,

579
00:27:15.234 --> 00:27:20.225
if I had deleted the transaction logs too,
then I would have lost everything, right?

580
00:27:20.225 --> 00:27:22.050
Everything after the backup.

581
00:27:22.050 --> 00:27:26.270
So, now if I go in here, so I dismounted
the database, if I go into this folder and

582
00:27:26.270 --> 00:27:28.880
I take all this data, and
I'm just gonna delete it all, right?

583
00:27:28.880 --> 00:27:30.626
Look who's go crazy?

584
00:27:30.626 --> 00:27:33.302
Let's see.

585
00:27:33.302 --> 00:27:34.270
Folder's open somewhere.

586
00:27:34.270 --> 00:27:35.170
But I'll delete everything else.

587
00:27:35.170 --> 00:27:36.230
There we go.
All right, so

588
00:27:36.230 --> 00:27:37.780
I just deleted my transaction logs too.

589
00:27:37.780 --> 00:27:39.550
Let's say I lost it all.

590
00:27:39.550 --> 00:27:41.660
If you lose it all when
you do the restore,

591
00:27:41.660 --> 00:27:44.070
there's no transaction
logs to play forward.

592
00:27:44.070 --> 00:27:46.630
And so now,
just gonna recover what's in the backup.

593
00:27:46.630 --> 00:27:50.480
So, if I go back and redo that recovery,
I'll come back here and

594
00:27:50.480 --> 00:27:53.070
restore it, restoring that same back up.

595
00:27:53.070 --> 00:27:54.790
I'll choose applications.

596
00:27:54.790 --> 00:27:58.080
The only difference this time,
is there's no transaction logs for

597
00:27:58.080 --> 00:27:59.380
it to play forward.

598
00:27:59.380 --> 00:28:00.850
Since it can't play those forward,

599
00:28:00.850 --> 00:28:03.600
I'll lose that email that
came in after my back up.

600
00:28:03.600 --> 00:28:05.980
So, that's where it's important, right?

601
00:28:05.980 --> 00:28:08.990
If we had lost our entire server,
this is a question from the chat room,

602
00:28:08.990 --> 00:28:13.110
if we lost the whole server, then we
lost the transaction logs too, right?

603
00:28:13.110 --> 00:28:14.700
So when we went and did the restore,

604
00:28:14.700 --> 00:28:18.160
we would just have what was in the back
up, and so we wouldn't get that stuff.

605
00:28:18.160 --> 00:28:21.600
But, remember way back in
the beginning of this series where

606
00:28:21.600 --> 00:28:23.370
I talked about planning storage?

607
00:28:23.370 --> 00:28:26.010
If your transaction logs are on
one set of hard drives, and

608
00:28:26.010 --> 00:28:29.520
your database is on another set of hard
drives, and it's the hard drive your

609
00:28:29.520 --> 00:28:32.900
database is on that failed,
your transaction logs are still intact.

610
00:28:32.900 --> 00:28:37.120
And so you can restore just your
database and now you're back up and

611
00:28:37.120 --> 00:28:40.150
happy again and it rolls forward
those transaction logs, right?

612
00:28:40.150 --> 00:28:42.210
That's how we make sure
we don't lose any data.

613
00:28:42.210 --> 00:28:46.330
And that's another reason why you
wanna store your transaction logs on

614
00:28:46.330 --> 00:28:50.550
a separate hard drive from your database,
for recovery purposes, right?

615
00:28:50.550 --> 00:28:51.739
So this is gonna run the restore.

616
00:28:51.739 --> 00:28:54.283
It's gonna notice that I don't
have any transaction logs and so

617
00:28:54.283 --> 00:28:57.263
it's gonna create empty ones and
bring that database back up and running.

618
00:28:57.263 --> 00:29:00.008
So, all right.

619
00:29:00.008 --> 00:29:03.985
So once this is in place, we'll be back
in business and we should see that other

620
00:29:03.985 --> 00:29:07.605
email unless it found some other
magical way to get that missing email,

621
00:29:07.605 --> 00:29:08.470
it'll be gone.

622
00:29:08.470 --> 00:29:10.290
Now when I say other magical ways,

623
00:29:10.290 --> 00:29:12.600
there are actually some
magical ways that can do that.

624
00:29:12.600 --> 00:29:14.700
What if you have
a Database Availability Group?

625
00:29:14.700 --> 00:29:18.130
If you have a DAG, your database is
being copied to another server so

626
00:29:18.130 --> 00:29:20.940
when you reach toward this one,
the other servers got newer data,

627
00:29:20.940 --> 00:29:22.200
it will actually pull that back.

628
00:29:22.200 --> 00:29:23.460
And so we might get it from there.

629
00:29:23.460 --> 00:29:24.560
Right?
There are other places

630
00:29:24.560 --> 00:29:25.610
the email can come from.

631
00:29:25.610 --> 00:29:29.060
Exchange will automatically try to
get you to the newest, latest and

632
00:29:29.060 --> 00:29:32.672
greatest copy of your data through
whatever means that it can.

633
00:29:32.672 --> 00:29:35.600
All right my restore just finished,
I can see that it's completed.

634
00:29:35.600 --> 00:29:38.700
So if I jump back here and
let me get back into my mailbox.

635
00:29:38.700 --> 00:29:42.553
I'll just open up a new OWA window,
no sense trying to reuse one, and

636
00:29:42.553 --> 00:29:45.018
when I get logged in this time,
there we go.

637
00:29:45.018 --> 00:29:48.774
I'm back in my mailbox, I've got
the email sent prior to the backup, but

638
00:29:48.774 --> 00:29:51.089
I lost the one sent after the backup,
right?

639
00:29:51.089 --> 00:29:54.249
So, that's an example right there
of how important it is to try and

640
00:29:54.249 --> 00:29:56.680
recover our transaction
log files if we can.

641
00:29:56.680 --> 00:30:00.720
If we can save those transaction logs we
can get right to the point of failure and

642
00:30:00.720 --> 00:30:02.240
lose no email.

643
00:30:02.240 --> 00:30:03.370
That's the perfect solution.

644
00:30:03.370 --> 00:30:05.520
That's really when you know
you've done a great job.

645
00:30:06.800 --> 00:30:10.450
All right, well,
what we just saw in this episode,

646
00:30:10.450 --> 00:30:12.750
cuz that's really about all I've got for
standard back ups.

647
00:30:12.750 --> 00:30:15.970
So what we saw in this episode was
how to do a standard back up of

648
00:30:15.970 --> 00:30:19.390
an Exchange Server,
how to restore that and get us back up and

649
00:30:19.390 --> 00:30:22.130
running, and save the day, right?

650
00:30:22.130 --> 00:30:24.090
You saw that backup,
it did not take long to restore.

651
00:30:24.090 --> 00:30:25.960
Now my mailbox database is pretty small.

652
00:30:25.960 --> 00:30:29.980
If you've got a terabyte backup, it's
gonna take a while to restore that, right?

653
00:30:29.980 --> 00:30:32.540
And so that's recovery time objective,
