we've gotta be aware of it.

654
00:30:32.540 --> 00:30:35.830
But being able to quickly and
easily get that data right back in there,

655
00:30:35.830 --> 00:30:37.310
get it back in business?

656
00:30:37.310 --> 00:30:38.870
Well, it wasn't that hard.

657
00:30:38.870 --> 00:30:42.480
And we did it with software included
right here in Windows Server.

658
00:30:42.480 --> 00:30:45.160
There's third party options you
always wanna consider, right?

659
00:30:45.160 --> 00:30:47.430
Those have their pros and cons.

660
00:30:47.430 --> 00:30:50.680
But as far as simple, straightforward
backups, this one works really well and

661
00:30:50.680 --> 00:30:51.790
it's right there.

662
00:30:51.790 --> 00:30:55.530
Now, that's not the last that
I have to say on recovery.

663
00:30:55.530 --> 00:31:00.630
What I just gave you is a very typical
restore for a full server failure, right?

664
00:31:00.630 --> 00:31:03.800
But there's other types of recovery
that you might need to do.

665
00:31:03.800 --> 00:31:08.310
And if you have a gigantic database and
RPO is a problem, there's something

666
00:31:08.310 --> 00:31:12.220
called a dial tone recovery we can use to
shrink that RPO really, really small and

667
00:31:12.220 --> 00:31:12.810
really help out.

668
00:31:12.810 --> 00:31:17.030
So stay tuned for those episodes where
I show some alternative methods for

669
00:31:17.030 --> 00:31:18.890
backing up and recover.

670
00:31:18.890 --> 00:31:20.760
But for
this episode we'll wrap it up here.

671
00:31:20.760 --> 00:31:26.090
So, signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

672
00:31:26.090 --> 00:31:30.940
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates creating a Dial Tone database in Exchange. This is the quickest way to get a failed Mailbox Server online after a failure, but requires proper planning and execution.
episodes.title: Dial Tone Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.489
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.489 --> 00:00:11.395
All right.

3
00:00:11.395 --> 00:00:13.602
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening, and

4
00:00:13.602 --> 00:00:15.478
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.478 --> 00:00:16.896
I'm your host Don Pezet,

6
00:00:16.896 --> 00:00:20.513
back to you with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

7
00:00:20.513 --> 00:00:24.610
And in this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at how to do a dial tone recovery

8
00:00:24.610 --> 00:00:26.381
of an exchange mailbox database.

9
00:00:26.381 --> 00:00:28.494
Now, what is dial tone recovery?

10
00:00:28.494 --> 00:00:32.013
Well, in our previous episodes,
we talked about how to back-up and

11
00:00:32.013 --> 00:00:34.988
restore an exchange database,
and during that process,

12
00:00:34.988 --> 00:00:38.226
you assume that your database
has failed and has gone offline.

13
00:00:38.226 --> 00:00:40.102
And now we need to do the restore.

14
00:00:40.102 --> 00:00:43.408
And, while you're restoring
you're in what's called your RTO,

15
00:00:43.408 --> 00:00:44.974
your recovery time objective.

16
00:00:44.974 --> 00:00:48.440
It's the amount of time it takes you
to get the database back online.

17
00:00:48.440 --> 00:00:53.092
The bigger your database gets,
the longer it takes to get back online.

18
00:00:53.092 --> 00:00:57.223
So, if your database is a terabyte and
it's spread across five backup tapes,

19
00:00:57.223 --> 00:01:00.355
maybe you've got a full backup and
several incrementals,

20
00:01:00.355 --> 00:01:02.374
it can take a while to do that restore.

21
00:01:02.374 --> 00:01:05.131
So, if it takes you two
hours to do that restore,

22
00:01:05.131 --> 00:01:09.320
that's two hours that your fellow
employees can't access their email.

23
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:12.829
Now, new emails coming in, and it's
getting put into the mail queues on your

24
00:01:12.829 --> 00:01:16.292
client access server, or on your
mailbox server, if they're available.

25
00:01:16.292 --> 00:01:20.682
If they're not available,
then the mail's getting bounced, right?

26
00:01:20.682 --> 00:01:23.500
People are trying to do retries,
and if they're doing retries,

27
00:01:23.500 --> 00:01:26.842
you've only got 72 hours, before most
mail servers give up on that email.

28
00:01:26.842 --> 00:01:29.257
So, you have this kind of time limit.

29
00:01:29.257 --> 00:01:32.541
You need to get your mailbox database
back up as quickly as you can, but

30
00:01:32.541 --> 00:01:34.163
you wanna restore your user data.

31
00:01:34.163 --> 00:01:38.374
And the larger your mailbox database is,
the harder that becomes.

32
00:01:38.374 --> 00:01:42.222
So, a dial tone recovery
seeks to help us fix that.

33
00:01:42.222 --> 00:01:47.124
A dial tone recovery makes our recovery
time objective, our RTO, it makes it zero.

34
00:01:47.124 --> 00:01:50.639
It allows us to get a database back up and
running instantly.

35
00:01:50.639 --> 00:01:53.430
Now, there's pros and
cons to doing it this way, but

36
00:01:53.430 --> 00:01:56.861
the way that it works is it basically
brings up an empty database.

37
00:01:56.861 --> 00:01:58.692
It says okay, your database is lost.

38
00:01:58.692 --> 00:01:59.841
That really stinks.

39
00:01:59.841 --> 00:02:02.483
We don't want that but
we know you need to get around it.

40
00:02:02.483 --> 00:02:07.390
But for right now, let's bring up
an empty database and let users get in.

41
00:02:07.390 --> 00:02:11.249
Users will be able to get into
the mailbox, and it will be empty.

42
00:02:11.249 --> 00:02:16.444
But, they can send email and new email
coming in will come into their mailbox.

43
00:02:16.444 --> 00:02:18.531
So, they're able to work.

44
00:02:18.531 --> 00:02:20.714
They can get in, they can send email,
they can receive email.

45
00:02:20.714 --> 00:02:23.626
You're back and
online in a matter of moments.

46
00:02:23.626 --> 00:02:24.427
All right.

47
00:02:24.427 --> 00:02:26.342
But what about all your old email?

48
00:02:26.342 --> 00:02:27.682
Well, now that the server's online,

49
00:02:27.682 --> 00:02:29.518
you don't have to worry
about losing email anymore.

50
00:02:29.518 --> 00:02:32.906
Right, you can, [SOUND],
disaster averted, the system's up,

51
00:02:32.906 --> 00:02:35.439
people are able to get
into their email and work.

52
00:02:35.439 --> 00:02:39.989
But now, you can go back and restore all
the historical data and bring it back

53
00:02:39.989 --> 00:02:44.276
into the mailbox and so people are able
to get in there and start to work.

54
00:02:44.276 --> 00:02:47.257
So, that's really the whole
point of a dial tone recovery,

55
00:02:47.257 --> 00:02:49.601
is just to get people in
there as fast as you can.

56
00:02:49.601 --> 00:02:53.230
If email's a critical service for you,
and you're worried about losing email,

57
00:02:53.230 --> 00:02:56.225
we need to get a mailbox database up and
going, even an empty one, so

58
00:02:56.225 --> 00:02:59.486
that at least people can get in there and
start working with new stuff, and

59
00:02:59.486 --> 00:03:00.873
then we restore the old stuff.

60
00:03:00.873 --> 00:03:01.592
All right.

61
00:03:01.592 --> 00:03:03.921
The process, it's actually not that hard.

62
00:03:03.921 --> 00:03:06.108
It's a pretty easy process to go through.

63
00:03:06.108 --> 00:03:09.453
But there's some little confusing steps
in there that I wanna highlight and

64
00:03:09.453 --> 00:03:11.924
make sure you guys understand
why we do it a certain way.

65
00:03:11.924 --> 00:03:14.925
But the first part,
just getting a dial-tone database up and

66
00:03:14.925 --> 00:03:16.032
going is really easy.

67
00:03:16.032 --> 00:03:17.246
Let me show you.

68
00:03:17.246 --> 00:03:20.792
So, here, I'm logged into my mailbox and
I've taken a backup of my server.

69
00:03:20.792 --> 00:03:22.580
I took the backup prior to the show.

70
00:03:22.580 --> 00:03:24.055
And I sent a few emails.

71
00:03:24.055 --> 00:03:26.831
I got an email that I sent
myself prior to the backup and

72
00:03:26.831 --> 00:03:29.313
an email that I sent to
myself after the backup.

73
00:03:29.313 --> 00:03:30.961
Now, why did I do that?

74
00:03:30.961 --> 00:03:35.369
I did that because emails prior to the
backup are gonna be part of the backup.

75
00:03:35.369 --> 00:03:39.506
Emails that were sent after the backup
are gonna be in the transaction log, and

76
00:03:39.506 --> 00:03:43.095
they'll be in the database itself but
they won't be in the backup.

77
00:03:43.095 --> 00:03:46.226
And so, when I restore, there's
a possibility I might be able to recover

78
00:03:46.226 --> 00:03:49.562
those transaction log files if it's
just my database that's been damaged and

79
00:03:49.562 --> 00:03:50.741
not the transaction logs.

80
00:03:50.741 --> 00:03:51.683
There's a chance.

81
00:03:51.683 --> 00:03:53.703
With a dial tone recovery,
it doesn't normally happen though.

82
00:03:53.703 --> 00:03:56.983
So, normally, what we'll end up losing
those emails that were afterwards

83
00:03:56.983 --> 00:03:58.790
because they're not part of the backup.

84
00:03:58.790 --> 00:04:00.925
Well, let's see how this works.

85
00:04:00.925 --> 00:04:03.426
I'm going to go into my
exchange admin center and

86
00:04:03.426 --> 00:04:07.712
I'm just going to go down to servers and
databases, and find my mailbox database.

87
00:04:07.712 --> 00:04:10.290
And I'm gonna dismount it, now,
mine actually says dismounted.

88
00:04:10.290 --> 00:04:11.602
There we go, now it's mounted.

89
00:04:11.602 --> 00:04:14.212
[LAUGH] So, I'm gonna go ahead and
dismount mine and take it offline.

90
00:04:14.212 --> 00:04:17.459
And what I'm gonna do is, I'm just
gonna go and rename that database file.

91
00:04:17.459 --> 00:04:21.313
I'm gonna make it look like that database
file is gone, or we can just delete it.

92
00:04:21.313 --> 00:04:24.139
I'll browse on the hard drive
to where that database is.

93
00:04:24.139 --> 00:04:28.780
So, I'll just browse in here, and hunt
down where that database is stored, and

94
00:04:28.780 --> 00:04:32.356
I'm gonna simulate a failure
by deleting the database file.

95
00:04:32.356 --> 00:04:35.607
Okay, so, here's that mailbox
database file right here.

96
00:04:35.607 --> 00:04:36.656
I'm just gonna delete it.

97
00:04:36.656 --> 00:04:38.947
Now, you can't delete it while
the database is mounted,

98
00:04:38.947 --> 00:04:40.133
that's why I dismounted it.

99
00:04:40.133 --> 00:04:40.992
But now it's gone.

100
00:04:40.992 --> 00:04:41.955
Okay.

101
00:04:41.955 --> 00:04:44.883
So, now that the database is gone,
I've got a failure.

102
00:04:44.883 --> 00:04:48.381
If a user tries to log in right now,
what are they going to get?

103
00:04:48.381 --> 00:04:51.050
Well, let me refresh this screen and
we'll see.

104
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:54.242
I'm trying to log into my mailbox and
I get, something went wrong,

105
00:04:54.242 --> 00:04:56.260
we can't get that information right now.

106
00:04:56.260 --> 00:04:57.942
Exchange isn't able to access my mailbox.

107
00:04:57.942 --> 00:05:00.076
The database is offline.

108
00:05:00.076 --> 00:05:03.806
All right, if I go back to my
database screen, and I refresh it,

109
00:05:03.806 --> 00:05:06.793
here's my database,
it shows it's dismounted.

110
00:05:06.793 --> 00:05:08.901
It doesn't know there's a problem yet.

111
00:05:08.901 --> 00:05:10.876
It knows the database is dismounted, but

112
00:05:10.876 --> 00:05:13.201
it doesn't know the database
is actually gone.

113
00:05:13.201 --> 00:05:17.564
It's not until I remount it that it's
gonna notice there's a true problem.

114
00:05:17.564 --> 00:05:21.174
And when I go to mount it, it's gonna say,
oh, sure, I'll say yes, and

115
00:05:21.174 --> 00:05:25.282
now it's gonna go to mount it, and it's
gonna realize the database isn't there.

116
00:05:25.282 --> 00:05:26.084
It's missing.

117
00:05:26.084 --> 00:05:28.929
The EDB file is gone, okay?

118
00:05:28.929 --> 00:05:33.253
And when it's gone,
it now gives me two choices, right?

119
00:05:33.253 --> 00:05:36.014
Choice number one,
don't do anything, just give up.

120
00:05:36.014 --> 00:05:40.261
I can hit cancel here and it'll leave
the database off, and I can go and

121
00:05:40.261 --> 00:05:42.071
do a restore, or I can hit OK.

122
00:05:42.071 --> 00:05:45.926
If I hit OK,
it's gonna create an empty database.

123
00:05:45.926 --> 00:05:47.563
It's gonna create a dial tone database.

124
00:05:47.563 --> 00:05:51.984
It'll recreate that EDB file for
me, and get a database in there.

125
00:05:51.984 --> 00:05:55.858
And once that happens, users will be able
to get back into their mailbox, right?

126
00:05:55.858 --> 00:05:57.848
So, if I say okay to that,
that's what it's gonna do.

127
00:05:57.848 --> 00:05:59.162
It's gonna go and try and create one.

128
00:05:59.162 --> 00:06:02.153
Now, when it tried to create one,
it looked, and

129
00:06:02.153 --> 00:06:05.096
it saw those transaction log files,
all right?

130
00:06:05.096 --> 00:06:08.437
It hit those transaction log files and
that caused a problem.

131
00:06:08.437 --> 00:06:10.058
So, when we do a dial tone,

132
00:06:10.058 --> 00:06:14.365
it's typically not going to roll
forward those transaction log files.

133
00:06:14.365 --> 00:06:17.304
So, if I'm gonna get this in place,
I'm gonna need to go in there and

134
00:06:17.304 --> 00:06:19.293
clear those out to be able
to get it put back in.

135
00:06:19.293 --> 00:06:21.853
So, here, it's just warning me
that it's not able to do that.

136
00:06:21.853 --> 00:06:25.717
And I can just jump back to my files, and
if I want to try some other way to recover

137
00:06:25.717 --> 00:06:29.936
these or whatever, I can always take them,
and just move them off to another folder,

138
00:06:29.936 --> 00:06:33.014
but the odds are, I'm not gonna
be able to recover this data.

139
00:06:33.014 --> 00:06:36.058
But I'm gonna go ahead and
take these anyway, and

140
00:06:36.058 --> 00:06:38.099
I'll move them off to my C drive.

141
00:06:38.099 --> 00:06:42.589
And I'll just put them in like some kind
of temp folder just so I've got them, and

142
00:06:42.589 --> 00:06:45.912
maybe I can attempt some kind
of recovery of those later on.

143
00:06:45.912 --> 00:06:48.181
But for right now,
I'm gonna have to rely on my own backups.

144
00:06:48.181 --> 00:06:50.552
So, now that those files
are out of the way,

145
00:06:50.552 --> 00:06:54.464
if I go back to my database directory,
if I browse all the way into there,

146
00:06:54.464 --> 00:06:56.930
I should have saved the path,
but I didn't.

147
00:06:56.930 --> 00:07:00.693
So, we'll browse the long journey here
back into where that database is.

148
00:07:00.693 --> 00:07:02.572
I'll see if that folder
is basically empty.

149
00:07:02.572 --> 00:07:05.531
There's a little GUID file here,
it uses for some journaling.

150
00:07:05.531 --> 00:07:08.199
It, actually, won't let me remove that,
so I'll leave that be.

151
00:07:08.199 --> 00:07:12.212
Now, when I go through and try and
remount it ,it's gonna try and mount.

152
00:07:12.212 --> 00:07:13.954
It's gonna see the database is missing.

153
00:07:13.954 --> 00:07:17.074
It's gonna offer to create the dial
tone database and when it does,

154
00:07:17.074 --> 00:07:20.703
it'll have an empty database with nice,
new, empty transaction log files.

155
00:07:20.703 --> 00:07:21.944
So, there we go.

156
00:07:21.944 --> 00:07:23.686
Let it do that and then it'll be up.

157
00:07:23.686 --> 00:07:25.579
Now, when it's up, when users log in,

158
00:07:25.579 --> 00:07:28.698
your client access server looks
at the active directory and says,

159
00:07:28.698 --> 00:07:32.841
hey, where's this person's mailbox, and
it'll point them to this mailbox server.

160
00:07:32.841 --> 00:07:35.552
And it'll come to the mailbox and
it'll see that it's empty.

161
00:07:35.552 --> 00:07:38.512
And it'll just assume it's a new user,
like hey, this is somebody new.

162
00:07:38.512 --> 00:07:41.863
And so, it'll be like somebody
logging in for the first time.

163
00:07:41.863 --> 00:07:45.152
But they've got all their email addresses,
all their mailbox rules.

164
00:07:45.152 --> 00:07:47.185
All the stuff that they
had before is still there.

165
00:07:47.185 --> 00:07:48.661
It's just the email that are missing.

166
00:07:48.661 --> 00:07:51.238
And if they have a folder hierarchy,
those will be missing too.

167
00:07:51.238 --> 00:07:54.245
So, that stuff is part of
the mailbox database itself.

168
00:07:54.245 --> 00:07:57.830
But the fact that the mailbox exists is
actually stored in the active directory

169
00:07:57.830 --> 00:08:00.670
and so that's staying,
their configuration.

170
00:08:00.670 --> 00:08:05.180
So now that database is mounted and
if I browse back to that database path,

171
00:08:05.180 --> 00:08:07.604
which I really should have saved that.

172
00:08:07.604 --> 00:08:10.207
[LAUGH] But
if we browse back to the database path,

173
00:08:10.207 --> 00:08:14.589
we'll see where it's created a nice new
empty database in new transaction logs,

174
00:08:14.589 --> 00:08:17.653
right, so it's all right there and
it's new and shiny.

175
00:08:17.653 --> 00:08:21.044
And as a user,
if I go to login now, right,

176
00:08:21.044 --> 00:08:25.286
so I'll come in here and
try and get logged in to OWA and

177
00:08:25.286 --> 00:08:30.430
when we get in now,
it's not gonna give me an error this time.

178
00:08:30.430 --> 00:08:34.330
This time it succeeds and
here I am but my mailbox is empty.

179
00:08:34.330 --> 00:08:35.630
I'm missing data.

180
00:08:35.630 --> 00:08:38.340
But that's not the point,
the point is that my mailbox is working.

181
00:08:38.340 --> 00:08:42.210
And if I get any new emails, so
somebody writes an email to me and

182
00:08:44.750 --> 00:08:48.120
that doesn't seem to be happy with
my name, let's try that again.

183
00:08:50.400 --> 00:08:51.670
Let's see if it finds me.

184
00:08:51.670 --> 00:08:53.610
So, it's gonna let me draft that email.

185
00:08:53.610 --> 00:08:56.520
I can do a test email, this is a test.

186
00:08:56.520 --> 00:09:00.356
We'll fire that off and this is all
happening in this new empty database.

187
00:09:00.356 --> 00:09:03.731
So now my users are at least able
to send and receive email and

188
00:09:03.731 --> 00:09:05.359
they're in there, right.

189
00:09:05.359 --> 00:09:08.791
So now I can tell people, hey, it's safe
to get back into your mailboxes, but

190
00:09:08.791 --> 00:09:12.015
you're gonna be missing all your old
email, we'll get that back to you,

191
00:09:12.015 --> 00:09:12.535
all right.

192
00:09:12.535 --> 00:09:15.570
So now we're back up and
online as fast as we can.

193
00:09:15.570 --> 00:09:18.600
Now technically,
the dial tone part of this is done.

194
00:09:18.600 --> 00:09:22.110
We've got the dial tone database up,
we're in there and we're running.

195
00:09:22.110 --> 00:09:23.720
But now comes our work.

196
00:09:23.720 --> 00:09:27.640
As an admin, we've gotta get in and
restore the old data.

197
00:09:27.640 --> 00:09:31.370
Now, here's the challenge, we've actually
got two databases at this point.

198
00:09:31.370 --> 00:09:34.480
Because we were in a hurry,
we brought this one up and

199
00:09:34.480 --> 00:09:36.830
this is now accumulating new email.

200
00:09:36.830 --> 00:09:39.620
Meanwhile, I've got my database back up.

201
00:09:39.620 --> 00:09:42.860
If I just restore it on top of this,
I'm gonna lose all my new email.

202
00:09:42.860 --> 00:09:46.430
So what I've gotta do is restore
to what's called a recovery group.

203
00:09:46.430 --> 00:09:49.620
A recovery group is like
a special database that

204
00:09:49.620 --> 00:09:51.271
is allowed to have duplicate mailboxes,

205
00:09:51.271 --> 00:09:55.260
mailboxes that already exist in another
database, but not bring them online.

206
00:09:55.260 --> 00:09:59.970
So you use a recovery group to restore
your data to it and then pull it off and

207
00:09:59.970 --> 00:10:01.520
move it into another database.

208
00:10:01.520 --> 00:10:02.780
So that's what we're
gonna have to do here,

209
00:10:02.780 --> 00:10:06.000
we're gonna have to restore all of
our old data to a recovery group and

210
00:10:06.000 --> 00:10:09.640
then from there, move it back
into the dial tone, all right?

211
00:10:09.640 --> 00:10:13.340
So that's gonna be my next step and
I still haven't received my email,

212
00:10:13.340 --> 00:10:14.960
sometimes it can take a little while for

213
00:10:14.960 --> 00:10:19.010
the transport services to get updated
to be able to reflect the new database.

214
00:10:19.010 --> 00:10:23.550
But my new email will show up here
shortly, I'm not gonna wait for it though.

215
00:10:23.550 --> 00:10:25.700
In the meantime,
I need to get this other restore going, so

216
00:10:25.700 --> 00:10:26.650
I'm gonna jump in and do that.

217
00:10:26.650 --> 00:10:30.620
Now, unfortunately there is not
a great way to do this from the GUI.

218
00:10:30.620 --> 00:10:34.870
So, I'm gonna have to jump down
to my PowerShell to get in and

219

with mount dash database and

436
00:22:40.170 --> 00:22:44.350
then specify the name of that database,
and we'll see if it comes online.

437
00:22:44.350 --> 00:22:47.060
If I get an error here, then my database
is corrupt and that shouldn't happen.

438
00:22:48.320 --> 00:22:51.560
Once this is done,
I've got my live database.

439
00:22:51.560 --> 00:22:53.030
My live database,
the users are in it right now.

440
00:22:53.030 --> 00:22:54.655
It's got all the historical data and

441
00:22:54.655 --> 00:22:58.240
it's got new stuff now but
it's missing in the dial tone stuff.

442
00:22:58.240 --> 00:23:00.930
The dial tone stuff is in
the now in the recovery db.

443
00:23:00.930 --> 00:23:04.850
The last thing that I need to do is to
get the user email out of the recovery

444
00:23:04.850 --> 00:23:05.740
database and

445
00:23:05.740 --> 00:23:10.470
merge it into their live mailbox and
that's done with some PowerShell commands.

446
00:23:10.470 --> 00:23:14.540
The reason we do it with PowerShell, is
we could do it one by one in the EAC but

447
00:23:14.540 --> 00:23:16.935
if you've got 10,000 users,
you don't wanna do that.

448
00:23:16.935 --> 00:23:18.170
PowerShell can knock it out real fast.

449
00:23:18.170 --> 00:23:18.860
Let me show you how.

450
00:23:20.100 --> 00:23:23.365
We know we can use get dash mailbox to
pull up a list of all the mailboxes that

451
00:23:23.365 --> 00:23:26.577
we have on the server and we can point
it at the recovery database to get all

452
00:23:26.577 --> 00:23:29.227
the mailboxes in the recovery database,
too, if we want.

453
00:23:29.227 --> 00:23:33.267
But, what we can do is we can just get
dash mailbox to give us a list of users

454
00:23:33.267 --> 00:23:37.379
and we can pipe that into the mailbox
merge request to restore that data and

455
00:23:37.379 --> 00:23:38.960
get us back online.

456
00:23:38.960 --> 00:23:41.171
We can do it with just
a couple of quick commands.

457
00:23:41.171 --> 00:23:46.377
First off, I'm gonna create
a variable called mailboxes and

458
00:23:46.377 --> 00:23:49.890
I'm gonna set it equal to get-mailbox.

459
00:23:49.890 --> 00:23:51.897
I only have one database, so
I don't have to worry about it.

460
00:23:51.897 --> 00:23:53.797
But if you have more than one database,

461
00:23:53.797 --> 00:23:56.043
you'll want to make
sure you say -Database,

462
00:23:56.043 --> 00:23:59.861
and then whatever the name of the database
is, and this is your live database.

463
00:23:59.861 --> 00:24:03.241
Now my live database has that obnoxious
name that I copied earlier, so

464
00:24:03.241 --> 00:24:05.950
I'm just going to paste that one in.

465
00:24:05.950 --> 00:24:06.990
There we go.

466
00:24:06.990 --> 00:24:10.460
And so I'm basically getting a list of
all the mailboxes in that database.

467
00:24:10.460 --> 00:24:13.220
And storing them in a variable,
all right, so that runs.

468
00:24:13.220 --> 00:24:16.290
If I were to echo that variable,
you can see what's in there,

469
00:24:16.290 --> 00:24:18.160
it's just the list of mailboxes.

470
00:24:18.160 --> 00:24:18.970
Okay?

471
00:24:18.970 --> 00:24:23.830
Then, I can use that variable in my next
command, to go through and do a merge for

472
00:24:23.830 --> 00:24:27.960
every person whose mailbox is in there,
and the command goes like this.

473
00:24:27.960 --> 00:24:33.330
Basically, we, we run $mailboxes
to generate that list and

474
00:24:33.330 --> 00:24:38.530
then we pipe that into the new
mailbox restore request.

475
00:24:38.530 --> 00:24:42.170
The problem is, cuz you might ask
why don't I just run get-mailbox and

476
00:24:42.170 --> 00:24:43.230
pipe that in,

477
00:24:43.230 --> 00:24:48.650
the problem is treated as one big entity
when you run get-mailbox and pipe it.

478
00:24:48.650 --> 00:24:51.870
I need it to run this command once for
every single user.

479
00:24:51.870 --> 00:24:54.080
So I need to take action for
each individual step.

480
00:24:54.080 --> 00:24:57.230
In the Linux world we have the XR
command that would knock this out.

481
00:24:57.230 --> 00:25:01.570
In Powershell we have to do it through
some creative bracketing which we'll

482
00:25:01.570 --> 00:25:02.220
see right here.

483
00:25:02.220 --> 00:25:07.130
So instead of just piping this right
in to the new mailbox restore request

484
00:25:07.130 --> 00:25:12.060
I'm gonna do ${ and
that's letting it know that I'm gonna be

485
00:25:12.060 --> 00:25:15.110
running this entity basically like
once over and over and over again.

486
00:25:16.140 --> 00:25:19.460
And then in there I'll do
the new-mailboxRestoreRequest, not repair,

487
00:25:19.460 --> 00:25:26.014
restore request and
I'll tell it the -sourcestoremailbox,

488
00:25:26.014 --> 00:25:30.288
so where I'm getting my data from and
the source database, right.

489
00:25:30.288 --> 00:25:35.090
So the sourcestoremailbox, I can get that
right from my other command output and so

490
00:25:35.090 --> 00:25:39.980
we can just use $_, that means, look
to the output from this first command,

491
00:25:39.980 --> 00:25:42.820
and I'm gonna look for
a particular entity inside of there.

492
00:25:42.820 --> 00:25:50.410
I'm looking for ExchangeGuid and
then I can specify the source database.

493
00:25:52.970 --> 00:25:55.860
And the source database is
gonna be the RecoveryDB.

494
00:25:55.860 --> 00:25:59.540
That's where we're actually gonna get
this data from, the recovery database.

495
00:25:59.540 --> 00:26:03.154
And from there we can tell
it the -targetMailbox.

496
00:26:05.430 --> 00:26:07.650
Which it's gonna get right
from the other command.

497
00:26:07.650 --> 00:26:12.889
And then lastly, we can tell it,
this last little bit.

498
00:26:12.889 --> 00:26:14.927
Now this last little bit,
you'll see it all over the internet,

499
00:26:14.927 --> 00:26:15.921
not a lot of people explain it.

500
00:26:15.921 --> 00:26:20.748
They'll tell you that you
need to do a -skipMerging for

501
00:26:20.748 --> 00:26:24.557
the StorageProviderForSource like that.

502
00:26:24.557 --> 00:26:27.280
Now, that's a weird command.

503
00:26:27.280 --> 00:26:28.330
What's that all about?

504
00:26:28.330 --> 00:26:32.667
Well there's actually a bug in Exchange
2013, so if you're watching this show

505
00:26:32.667 --> 00:26:35.860
right now, you've got a live
install of Exchange 2013.

506
00:26:35.860 --> 00:26:37.056
You have this bug.

507
00:26:37.056 --> 00:26:40.830
Where the merge request'll fail when
it tries to restore the mailbox

508
00:26:40.830 --> 00:26:43.090
because the storage provider,
it stores some data for

509
00:26:43.090 --> 00:26:46.960
that, that isn't the same if you
just rebuilt your server, right?

510
00:26:46.960 --> 00:26:49.259
So we have to tell it to
skip that set of values for

511
00:26:49.259 --> 00:26:52.080
the storage provider in order for
the restore to proceed.

512
00:26:52.080 --> 00:26:54.690
If I leave that off my restore will fail,
right?

513
00:26:54.690 --> 00:26:56.532
So this is gonna make sure that happens.

514
00:26:56.532 --> 00:26:58.800
Now that'll probably go away, so

515
00:26:58.800 --> 00:27:01.910
if you're watching this show six
months from now or whatever,

516
00:27:01.910 --> 00:27:05.210
Microsoft will probably have fixed that,
but it doesn't hurt to leave this in.

517
00:27:05.210 --> 00:27:06.937
It's just telling it,
hey, when you restore,

518
00:27:06.937 --> 00:27:09.353
the storage provider might have
a slightly different identifier.

519
00:27:09.353 --> 00:27:12.920
If it has the same identifier,
it runs just fine if you skip it.

520
00:27:12.920 --> 00:27:16.430
So it's pretty safe to leave that in
there, and that'll take care of it.

521
00:27:16.430 --> 00:27:20.570
We're taking that output from get-mailbox,
and we're feeding it in

522
00:27:20.570 --> 00:27:25.650
a new-mailboxRestoreRequest, so it's
running a restore for each of these users.

523
00:27:25.650 --> 00:27:29.530
Now, when it does it this way,
it's a merge, not a replace.

524
00:27:29.530 --> 00:27:33.680
So their live mailbox has all
their historical data in it and

525
00:27:33.680 --> 00:27:37.860
now I'm just moving the dial tone stuff
in to get them back up and running.

526
00:27:39.830 --> 00:27:41.890
So, when I run that assuming
I don't have any typos which,

527
00:27:41.890 --> 00:27:44.490
that's a long command I could
probably have a typo in there.

528
00:27:44.490 --> 00:27:45.050
It's gonna run.

529
00:27:45.050 --> 00:27:47.010
It's gonna try and run for
each individual user.

530
00:27:47.010 --> 00:27:50.240
All right now,
I got some errors on mine and

531
00:27:50.240 --> 00:27:52.821
at first I thought I had some typos but
these are some normal errors.

532
00:27:52.821 --> 00:27:55.210
[LAUGH] I know, normal errors,
these are what we expect.

533
00:27:55.210 --> 00:27:55.990
But if you look at it,

534
00:27:55.990 --> 00:27:58.870
it's basically telling me that some
of the mailboxes don't exist, right?

535
00:27:58.870 --> 00:28:02.310
So it's telling me that this mailbox
with a GUID doesn't exist, and

536
00:28:02.310 --> 00:28:03.920
this other mailbox doesn't exist.

537
00:28:03.920 --> 00:28:04.750
What's that all about?

538
00:28:04.750 --> 00:28:09.480
Well each mailbox, each mailbox database
has certain mailboxes like these,

539
00:28:09.480 --> 00:28:13.650
the discovery search mailbox or
it's got the health mailbox.

540
00:28:13.650 --> 00:28:18.220
Those mailboxes are ones that
reside on the system that

541
00:28:18.220 --> 00:28:20.130
have a different GUID on new installs.

542
00:28:20.130 --> 00:28:23.330
So when I created a new database their
GUID changes so those weren't found.

543
00:28:23.330 --> 00:28:25.520
Fortunately, we don't care
about those mailboxes.

544
00:28:25.520 --> 00:28:27.540
The ones we care about are the ones
the users are tied to.

545
00:28:27.540 --> 00:28:31.399
So I see like, Don Pezet and
Jane Smith and if I scroll down here,

546
00:28:31.399 --> 00:28:33.273
I can see those were queued up.

547
00:28:33.273 --> 00:28:34.000
There's Don Pezet.

548
00:28:34.000 --> 00:28:34.940
There's Jane Smith.

549
00:28:34.940 --> 00:28:38.050
So it is actually queuing those up and
getting them in place.

550
00:28:38.050 --> 00:28:38.600
Right?

551
00:28:38.600 --> 00:28:40.760
Now, you do wanna keep and
eye on these, though.

552
00:28:40.760 --> 00:28:43.590
And when it does the mailbox merges, in
the background it's creating those merge

553
00:28:43.590 --> 00:28:46.680
requests, and we can go back and look
at the merge requests that are running.

554
00:28:46.680 --> 00:28:48.555
This doesn't actually do the merge.

555
00:28:48.555 --> 00:28:50.308
It does the merge request, and so

556
00:28:50.308 --> 00:28:53.700
in the background it's now added
to a queue and it's gonna run.

557
00:28:53.700 --> 00:28:58.496
And I can do a quick
Get-mailboxRestoreRequest to see a list

558
00:28:58.496 --> 00:29:01.040
any restores that are running.

559
00:29:01.040 --> 00:29:04.340
I can see Jane Smith and
Don Pezet are running right now.

560
00:29:04.340 --> 00:29:05.290
Actually they're not running.

561
00:29:05.290 --> 00:29:05.900
They're completed.

562
00:29:05.900 --> 00:29:07.490
I can see they're already done.

563
00:29:07.490 --> 00:29:08.630
Right?
We need to watch this,

564
00:29:08.630 --> 00:29:11.880
cuz if you're restoring 10,000 users,
you'll want to watch and

565
00:29:11.880 --> 00:29:14.160
make sure everybody gets
flagged as completed.

566
00:29:14.160 --> 00:29:16.550
And you can do a filter
to filter out completed,

567
00:29:16.550 --> 00:29:20.330
they'll say queued if they're waiting,
and then completed when they're done.

568
00:29:20.330 --> 00:29:22.930
So I can see that this is done,
and my mailbox, Jane's mailbox,

569
00:29:22.930 --> 00:29:25.970
we should be restored, and
we should be back in business, all right?

570
00:29:25.970 --> 00:29:27.562
Now how can we tell?

571
00:29:27.562 --> 00:29:30.274
Well, the end users can really tell,
they can log in and

572
00:29:30.274 --> 00:29:32.084
at this point they should have both.

573
00:29:32.084 --> 00:29:36.413
All their historical mail and the mail
that was in the dial tone recovery should

574
00:29:36.413 --> 00:29:39.310
all be present and
they should have that available.

575
00:29:39.310 --> 00:29:44.580
So if I go in here and
access OWA I'm gonna refresh my mailbox.

576
00:29:45.850 --> 00:29:49.510
And when I refresh it here's
my email prior to the back up.

577
00:29:49.510 --> 00:29:52.250
And here's my email from
the dial tone database.

578
00:29:52.250 --> 00:29:54.070
And now it's all in one place.

579
00:29:54.070 --> 00:29:56.750
As a user, my mailbox is now whole again.

580
00:29:56.750 --> 00:29:59.570
Right?
So I have all my mail back again.

581
00:29:59.570 --> 00:30:03.680
Now this was a much more involved
process than doing the standard restore

582
00:30:03.680 --> 00:30:05.300
like we did in the other episode.

583
00:30:05.300 --> 00:30:09.420
And that's because here, we're subjecting
ourself to something that's more difficult

584
00:30:09.420 --> 00:30:12.340
because we want our database
to be back online faster.

585
00:30:12.340 --> 00:30:15.219
So if speed is of the essence,
you do it this way.

586
00:30:15.219 --> 00:30:18.184
But if you wanna do it thoroughly,
not make mistakes,

587
00:30:18.184 --> 00:30:20.126
the other way is certainly easier.

588
00:30:20.126 --> 00:30:21.883
You just have a longer
downtime the other way,

589
00:30:21.883 --> 00:30:25.350
cuz you have to wait for the database to
fully restore before you bring it online.

590
00:30:25.350 --> 00:30:27.230
Here, we can bring the database
online right away,

591
00:30:27.230 --> 00:30:29.680
and not have to wait for that to restore.

592
00:30:29.680 --> 00:30:32.700
There is one more thing that we
need to do, if we're actually done,

593
00:30:32.700 --> 00:30:35.790
when all of our mailbox
restore requests are done,

594
00:30:35.790 --> 00:30:38.910
we can dismount the recovery database,
and delete it.

595
00:30:38.910 --> 00:30:44.400
So, once it's done, you basically come
in do a Dismount-Database RecoveryDB.

596
00:30:44.400 --> 00:30:45.600
That's what I called mine.

597
00:30:45.600 --> 00:30:48.850
So, I'm going to dismount it, take it
offline, and then you can remove it.

598
00:30:48.850 --> 00:30:54.675
And to remove it,
we can just do a Remove-mailboxDatabase

599
00:30:54.675 --> 00:31:00.290
-Identity RecoveryDB and
that'll remove it.

600
00:31:00.290 --> 00:31:02.330
It'll remove it but
it'll leave the files on the hard drive.

601
00:31:02.330 --> 00:31:03.930
And that's what it's
warning me about there.

602
00:31:03.930 --> 00:31:05.090
But I'm done.

603
00:31:05.090 --> 00:31:07.170
So now I can go in and
I can remove those files and

604
00:31:07.170 --> 00:31:09.620
get rid of them and
now I'm back to being live.

605
00:31:09.620 --> 00:31:10.720
All right?

606
00:31:10.720 --> 00:31:13.530
So a lot of stuff involved
there to go through.

607
00:31:13.530 --> 00:31:16.110
A lot of things that we have
to be aware of and get set.

608
00:31:16.110 --> 00:31:20.350
We had a comment in the chatroom that
we saw the mailbox for Don Pezet.

609
00:31:20.350 --> 00:31:22.160
We saw the mailbox for Jane Smith.

610
00:31:22.160 --> 00:31:24.260
We didn't see administrator, right?

611
00:31:24.260 --> 00:31:25.820
Why didn't we see administrator?

612
00:31:25.820 --> 00:31:29.860
Well, to be honest with you,
I've never logged in as administrator.

613
00:31:29.860 --> 00:31:34.110
If you've never logged in as a user, their
mailbox doesn't actually get created,

614
00:31:34.110 --> 00:31:36.720
their mailbox gets created
the first time they login.

615
00:31:36.720 --> 00:31:39.564
So if they've never logged in,
they have an e-mail address,

616
00:31:39.564 --> 00:31:42.472
they have a configuration, but
they don't have a mailbox yet.

617
00:31:42.472 --> 00:31:46.846
So when I went to do the restore,
it didn't find that mailbox and

618
00:31:46.846 --> 00:31:49.040
it didn't offer to restore it.

619
00:31:49.040 --> 00:31:51.710
Okay, I think there was another user,
was there another user in there?

620
00:31:51.710 --> 00:31:54.530
I don't think administrator
was the only one.

621
00:31:54.530 --> 00:31:56.700
Let's see if we had any other,
oh yeah, John Doe.

622
00:31:56.700 --> 00:31:59.820
So here's John Doe and I've never
logged in as John Doe either, and

623
00:31:59.820 --> 00:32:02.300
so when I looked down here,
it got me and Jane.

624
00:32:02.300 --> 00:32:05.390
It didn't get John Doe because
John doesn't have a mailbox.

625
00:32:05.390 --> 00:32:06.990
There's nothing to restore.

626
00:32:06.990 --> 00:32:09.150
So sometimes these errors
are indicating just that.

627
00:32:09.150 --> 00:32:10.240
The mailbox is empty.

628
00:32:10.240 --> 00:32:12.540
So you'll have to double check those and
make sure.

629
00:32:12.540 --> 00:32:14.920
But otherwise it's there.

630
00:32:14.920 --> 00:32:17.850
You could actually get even more
complex with that recover command to

631
00:32:17.850 --> 00:32:20.340
filter out mailboxes that
have never logged in.

632
00:32:20.340 --> 00:32:21.940
So there's ways to do that.

633
00:32:21.940 --> 00:32:24.499
But otherwise it does the recovery and
you're back in business.

634
00:32:25.630 --> 00:32:29.790
All right well, in this episode we got
a chance to see a dial tone restore.

635
00:32:29.790 --> 00:32:32.750
It was a lot more involved than
just a regular restore, but

636
00:32:32.750 --> 00:32:33.670
it serves its purpose.

637
00:32:33.670 --> 00:32:35.620
It gets our database back
online as fast as we can,

638
00:32:35.620 --> 00:32:38.790
and gets people back in their
email as quick as possible so

639
00:32:38.790 --> 00:32:42.280
definitely a great solution that's out
there and one that's available to you.

640
00:32:42.280 --> 00:32:44.259
All right well I hope you guys enjoyed it.

641
00:32:44.259 --> 00:32:48.539
That's all I've got for this episode, so
signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

642
00:32:48.539 --> 00:32:49.566
And I'll see you next time.

643
00:32:49.566 --> 00:32:55.280
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to restore a Public Folder environment in Exchange 2013. He describes how to restore the entire Public Folder mailbox, as well as how to restore individual folders. Finally, he demonstrates the process.
episodes.title: Public Folder Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.589
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.589 --> 00:00:14.021
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:14.021 --> 00:00:16.310
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.310 --> 00:00:17.201
I'm your host,

5
00:00:17.201 --> 00:00:20.690
Don Pezet, back again with another
episode of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:24.360
Now, in this episode,
we're gonna take a look at backing up and

7
00:00:24.360 --> 00:00:27.930
restoring public folders and
public folder data in Exchange 2013.

8
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:31.780
And I have to throw that little caveat
on the end there, it's in Exchange 2013,

9
00:00:31.780 --> 00:00:34.950
because every previous
version of Exchange did it

10
00:00:34.950 --> 00:00:36.940
differently than the way
we're about to do it now.

11
00:00:38.250 --> 00:00:38.880
Why is that?

12
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:42.000
Well remember in earlier
versions of Exchange,

13
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:44.430
public folders had their own database.

14
00:00:44.430 --> 00:00:46.670
You had a dedicated
public folder database.

15
00:00:46.670 --> 00:00:49.320
And so
it was different than a mailbox database.

16
00:00:49.320 --> 00:00:52.150
And that meant the way that you backed it
up and the way that you restored it was

17
00:00:52.150 --> 00:00:55.020
different, because it wasn't
a normal mailbox database.

18
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:56.220
But starting in Exchange 2013,

19
00:00:56.220 --> 00:00:59.770
your public folders are no longer
stored in a separate database.

20
00:00:59.770 --> 00:01:02.810
In fact, they're no longer stored
in a database all together,

21
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:04.750
they're stored in a mailbox.

22
00:01:04.750 --> 00:01:07.880
Your public folders are just another
mailbox right there on your server on

23
00:01:07.880 --> 00:01:08.940
the back end.

24
00:01:08.940 --> 00:01:12.710
So when we talk about backing up and
restoring public folders,

25
00:01:12.710 --> 00:01:17.970
it's really the same as backing up and
restoring an individual mailbox.

26
00:01:17.970 --> 00:01:20.690
So, that makes life a lot
easier on us as administrators.

27
00:01:20.690 --> 00:01:24.490
Because now we have one process to
remember instead of two separate things.

28
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:27.590
But, I do want to be thorough, so we're
going to spend this episode taking a look

29
00:01:27.590 --> 00:01:31.280
at this process and seeing how to
get those backed up and restored.

30
00:01:31.280 --> 00:01:34.050
But if you've watched the episode
on single mailbox recovery,

31
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.220
you'll see there's a lot of
common elements here, all right?

32
00:01:37.220 --> 00:01:40.470
Let's just start off with a basic public
folder hierarchy, kinda see what we have

33
00:01:40.470 --> 00:01:43.842
then we'll take a backup, and then we'll
get a chance to see how the restores work.

34
00:01:43.842 --> 00:01:46.290
All right, so
I'm logged into my server here and

35
00:01:46.290 --> 00:01:49.580
I mentioned how public folders
are now stored in a mailbox, right?

36
00:01:49.580 --> 00:01:50.640
Where do we see that?

37
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:55.240
Well, here in my Exchange Admin Center,
I can go down to my Public Folders.

38
00:01:55.240 --> 00:01:59.260
And inside of Public Folders,
I can go to Public Folder Mailboxes.

39
00:01:59.260 --> 00:02:02.460
Now if you're using public folders,
you're gonna have at least one mailbox.

40
00:02:02.460 --> 00:02:05.320
The first mailbox you create is
the one that has the readable and

41
00:02:05.320 --> 00:02:07.389
writeable copy of your public folders.

42
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:13.910
If you add more than one mailbox you can

43
00:02:13.910 --> 00:02:16.160
And that's nice because you can
have them in different areas.

44
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:17.990
So if your server fails,

45
00:02:17.990 --> 00:02:20.370
well your public folders are stored
on another server somewhere else.

46
00:02:20.370 --> 00:02:23.610
You just make that one writable and
off you go, right?

47
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:25.810
Or clone the data from that
mailbox back into your primary and

48
00:02:25.810 --> 00:02:27.130
you're back in business too.

49
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:31.090
So if you've got clones, you might not
need to go to your backup at all, right?

50
00:02:31.090 --> 00:02:32.940
So when do we need to go to our backup?

51
00:02:32.940 --> 00:02:36.650
Well, one, if we don't have clones, if we
don't have any other copies of our public

52
00:02:36.650 --> 00:02:40.690
folder database, or two,
if our public folders are online,

53
00:02:40.690 --> 00:02:43.980
we're just trying to recover
something old that was deleted.

54
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:45.395
Maybe I get a call from a user and

55
00:02:45.395 --> 00:02:48.827
they're like man I deleted something
two months ago and now I realize I need

56
00:02:48.827 --> 00:02:52.611
it it's really important I've got the
legal department asking me for it, okay?

57
00:02:52.611 --> 00:02:56.363
Well if you've got clones they're
deleted on the clones too, right, so

58
00:02:56.363 --> 00:02:58.680
that doesn't really help us much.

59
00:02:58.680 --> 00:03:02.120
But if we've got backup tapes,
right, or backup DVDs, or

60
00:03:02.120 --> 00:03:04.150
whatever it is that we backup to,
that's a different story.

61
00:03:04.150 --> 00:03:05.800
We might have backups from a year ago.

62
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:08.070
And so you can go and
get one of the older backups and

63
00:03:08.070 --> 00:03:09.240
restore that data and bring it back.

64
00:03:09.240 --> 00:03:10.820
And that's when it's really important.

65
00:03:10.820 --> 00:03:13.310
So I need to look here under
Public Folder Mailboxes,

66
00:03:13.310 --> 00:03:15.900
because this is what's gonna
tell me two things, right?

67
00:03:15.900 --> 00:03:17.700
One is gonna tell me
whether I have any copies.

68
00:03:17.700 --> 00:03:20.780
So I have copies, I can probably
go there for most of my needs.

69
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:23.260
And then two, it's gonna give
me the name of the mailbox.

70
00:03:23.260 --> 00:03:24.330
I need that name of the mailbox.

71
00:03:24.330 --> 00:03:25.480
That's gonna be important.

72
00:03:25.480 --> 00:03:27.963
It's not important for
the backup, but for the restore.

73
00:03:27.963 --> 00:03:31.470
Because when I do a restore,
I just wanna restore that one mailbox.

74
00:03:31.470 --> 00:03:33.920
I don't wanna restore

75
00:03:33.920 --> 00:03:36.490
because that's stored in a mailbox

76
00:03:36.490 --> 00:03:37.730
Or at least in mine it is.

77
00:03:37.730 --> 00:03:38.350
It doesn't have to be.

78
00:03:38.350 --> 00:03:41.400
You could have it in its own dedicated

79
00:03:41.400 --> 00:03:44.970
Some people do that because public

80
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:46.350
People read from them a lot.

81
00:03:46.350 --> 00:03:48.480
And they're not terribly

82
00:03:48.480 --> 00:03:50.780
when people do write they're

00:03:50.780 --> 00:03:52.040
And those files can be big.

00:03:52.040 --> 00:03:55.246
So you might choose to push those off

85
00:03:55.246 --> 00:03:55.906

00:03:55.906 --> 00:03:57.640
But either way, I just need his name.

87
00:03:57.640 --> 00:03:58.950
Public Folders is what I called mine.

88
00:03:58.950 --> 00:04:00.290
You could have called yours Bob,

89
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:02.340
or whatever it is that

00:04:02.340 --> 00:04:04.890
I called mine Public Folders
cuz it's easy to remember, but

91
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:06.980
I'm gonna need to know that for
the restore.

92
00:04:06.980 --> 00:04:10.650
And you can see on my Public Folders I've
got IT, Marketing, Sales.

00:04:10.650 --> 00:04:11.880
I've got a few different things.

94
00:04:11.880 --> 00:04:13.590
And if I were to fire
up Microsoft Outlook,

00:04:13.590 --> 00:04:15.900
I could connect right to those
public folders and get to it.

96
00:04:15.900 --> 00:04:18.800
Now, I'm on my server, and
I don't have Outlook installed, but

00:04:18.800 --> 00:04:20.480
you can get to it through OWA.

98
00:04:20.480 --> 00:04:25.320
If I fire up Outlook Web Access, you can
get to your public folders right here.

99
00:04:25.320 --> 00:04:29.530
It's kind of a hidden feature, Microsoft
doesn't go right out to call it out.

100
00:04:29.530 --> 00:04:32.190
If you wanna connect to a public
folder from OWA, all you

00:04:32.190 --> 00:04:35.770

00:04:35.770 --> 00:04:37.370
And you can add public

00:04:37.370 --> 00:04:39.570
That's the way that it's done in OWA and

104
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:44.470
So like I've got IT, but I could come in
here and add my other ones like Marketing,

105
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:45.840
and Sales, and

106
00:04:45.840 --> 00:04:51.230
now I'll have access to all of my public
folders, right here inside of OWA.

107
00:04:51.230 --> 00:04:54.600
But looking at the IT public folder,
I can see I've got a report, right.

00:04:54.600 --> 00:04:58.150
So there's a sample report that's sitting
there, it's a rich text document and

00:04:58.150 --> 00:05:00.670
if I go to open that up, there it is.

110
00:05:00.670 --> 00:05:03.760
Here's this document that I've

111
00:05:03.760 --> 00:05:05.910
So it's there and I know it's there but

00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:07.520
it's not safe because I

00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:09.570
So first off I need to take a backup.

00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:12.920
Fortunately, since the public folders are
just in a mailbox database like everything

00:05:12.920 --> 00:05:16.020
else we run the same backup we would for

116
00:05:16.020 --> 00:05:20.520
So, I'm gonna jump back here to my
Server Manager and I'm gonna run Tools and

00:05:20.520 --> 00:05:24.770
Windows Server Backup and
we'll take a backup of that.

118
00:05:24.770 --> 00:05:28.350
Now, actually you know what,
I'm gonna have a slight problem here.

00:05:28.350 --> 00:05:30.030
I'm on my client access server right.

00:05:30.030 --> 00:05:34.530
So this is LAB-CAS01 but mailbox database
isn't on my client access server.

121
00:05:34.530 --> 00:05:37.900
So I need to backup a database
on a different server.

122
00:05:37.900 --> 00:05:39.220
I need to go to my mailbox server.

123
00:05:39.220 --> 00:05:41.140
So I'm gonna jump over
to my mailbox server.

124
00:05:41.140 --> 00:05:43.000
Whoops, if I can remember where it is.

125
00:05:43.000 --> 00:05:44.060
Here it is.

126
00:05:44.060 --> 00:05:45.580
And I'm gonna do the backup here.

127
00:05:45.580 --> 00:05:48.500
Now remember, Windows Server Backup
is not installed by default so

00:05:48.500 --> 00:05:49.380
I need to get it installed.

00:05:49.380 --> 00:05:54.080
I'll just go over here to add,
remove roles and we'll find it.

00:05:54.080 --> 00:05:56.940
It's not a role,
I'm gonna skip past the role screen, but

00:05:56.940 --> 00:06:00.210
on this next screen where we get all of

00:06:00.210 --> 00:06:04.260
And if we scroll down we can find our
Windows Server Backup right there and

00:06:04.260 --> 00:06:05.460
I need to get it installed.

00:06:05.460 --> 00:06:09.090
It's kind of a tricky one because the icon

00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:13.230
If I go down to Tools, you'll see
Windows Server Backup already shows up.

00:06:13.230 --> 00:06:15.600
And that's the client from

00:06:15.600 --> 00:06:17.940
I could use that to connect to

00:06:17.940 --> 00:06:21.290
Windows Server Backup but
I couldn't run a backup itself, all right?

00:06:21.290 --> 00:06:23.310
So what what I'm installing
here is the back end,

140
00:06:23.310 --> 00:06:25.750
to actually get that backup
functionally running.

141
00:06:25.750 --> 00:06:27.350
Now I'm gonna take a backup.

142
00:06:27.350 --> 00:06:29.002
And once I've got
the backup I'm gonna go and

00:06:29.002 --> 00:06:30.580
delete that email out of my public folder.

00:06:30.580 --> 00:06:32.020
I'm just gonna remove it and

00:06:32.020 --> 00:06:34.970
we'll empty our recycle bin or

00:06:34.970 --> 00:06:38.049
We have to purge it cuz otherwise

00:06:38.049 --> 00:06:41.529
And deleted item retention last for
30 days so, well,

148
00:06:41.529 --> 00:06:45.240
it's 14 days on some systems by default,

00:06:45.240 --> 00:06:48.310
Depends on what service pack

00:06:48.310 --> 00:06:49.550
It's all customizable.

151
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:52.250
So users might be able to recover
right out of the recycle bin.

152
00:06:52.250 --> 00:06:55.310
But if it's really old,
if it's three months, six months,

153
00:06:55.310 --> 00:06:59.040
a year old, we're gonna have
to go to those backup tapes.

154
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:01.970
So now that it finished installing I can
go and launch my Windows Server Backup and

00:07:01.970 --> 00:07:04.510
I can take my first backup.

156
00:07:04.510 --> 00:07:07.970
Now, when I do a backup, remember,
I need to back up to a network location or

157
00:07:07.970 --> 00:07:10.460
I can do a backup to a local hard drive,

158
00:07:10.460 --> 00:07:13.150
if it's separate from the hard
drive where my data is, right?

159
00:07:13.150 --> 00:07:15.610
So I can attach a USB hard drive or
something.

160
00:07:15.610 --> 00:07:19.190
You can also backup to DVDs, we got
a couple of different options there.

161
00:07:19.190 --> 00:07:22.170
So in Windows Server Backup,
I'm just gonna go up here to Local Backup.

162
00:07:22.170 --> 00:07:24.240
And this is the first time
I'm running a backup, so

163
00:07:24.240 --> 00:07:25.880
I'm gonna have to set a few options here.

164
00:07:25.880 --> 00:07:28.708
It's looking to see if I have
any previous settings to load or

165
00:07:28.708 --> 00:07:30.047
a backup schedule in place.

166
00:07:30.047 --> 00:07:33.945
And of course I don't, so it's not gonna
find anything, and so it's gonna offer for

167
00:07:33.945 --> 00:07:36.620
me to set up my initial backup,
and I can set up a schedule.

168
00:07:36.620 --> 00:07:39.970
I'm just gonna do a one time backup here,
so I'll set this backup up.

169
00:07:39.970 --> 00:07:42.270
I'm gonna tell it to do
a full backup of my server.

170
00:07:42.270 --> 00:07:44.886
Now you can back up individual
pieces of the server, but

171
00:07:44.886 --> 00:07:47.736
Microsoft's recommendation is
always to do a full backup.

172
00:07:47.736 --> 00:07:50.957
And the reason is,
if you have that full complete backup,

173
00:07:50.957 --> 00:07:52.876
it includes bare metal recovery.

174
00:07:52.876 --> 00:07:55.441
And even if I lose the whole server,
I'll be able to recover that.

175
00:07:55.441 --> 00:07:57.279
So that's kind of a nice feature to have.

176
00:07:57.279 --> 00:07:58.650
So I'm gonna choose full server,

177
00:07:58.650 --> 00:08:01.550
and you'll see my backup's still
gonna be pretty small on this system.

178
00:08:01.550 --> 00:08:04.850
All right, so now it's asking
where I wanna back it up to.

179
00:08:04.850 --> 00:08:07.890
I'm gonna choose local drives, and I've
got an extra hard drive attached here,

180
00:08:07.890 --> 00:08:08.880
my E drive.

181
00:08:08.880 --> 00:08:10.840
Now, technically that's
part of the full backup, so

182
00:08:10.840 --> 00:08:13.370
I'm gonna get a warning here
about it wanting to exclude that.

183
00:08:13.370 --> 00:08:14.750
I'm okay with that, so I'll say okay.

184
00:08:14.750 --> 00:08:17.730
And now I can see bare metal recovery.

185
00:08:17.730 --> 00:08:20.450
It's backing up the C drive,
and the system state, and

186
00:08:20.450 --> 00:08:24.790
that's including the Exchange services and
the mailbox databases attached to it.

187
00:08:24.790 --> 00:08:27.760
So that's exactly what I want,
I'm going to start that back up.

188
00:08:27.760 --> 00:08:31.130
Now, the key take away here is
that when we do a backup for

189
00:08:31.130 --> 00:08:33.850
public folders, it's no different
than a backup for mailboxes.

190
00:08:33.850 --> 00:08:35.840
So its all one backup strategy.

191
00:08:35.840 --> 00:08:38.110
We don't need separate backup
strategies for different things,

192
00:08:38.110 --> 00:08:39.270
its all done one way.

193
00:08:39.270 --> 00:08:41.780
And when we go to restore,
it's kind of the same thing.

194
00:08:41.780 --> 00:08:45.730
If I wanna restore the whole mailbox
database, it'll include user mailboxes and

195
00:08:45.730 --> 00:08:47.280
public folder mailboxes.

196
00:08:47.280 --> 00:08:50.920
If I wanna restore just a user or
just a public folder, I can do that.

197
00:08:50.920 --> 00:08:51.770
It's done the same way.

198
00:08:51.770 --> 00:08:55.160
Right, everything is much more
simple under Exchange 2013.

199
00:08:55.160 --> 00:08:56.120
Now I say it's simple.

200
00:08:56.120 --> 00:08:59.090
We are still gonna have to jump to
the PowerShell as part of our restore, so

201
00:08:59.090 --> 00:09:02.810
it's not completely easy, but at least
it's easier than what it used to be.

202
00:09:02.810 --> 00:09:03.430
Right.

203
00:09:03.430 --> 00:09:05.830
So I'm gonna let that run and
the backup's kind of churning along there.

204
00:09:05.830 --> 00:09:07.120
It'll move fairly quick.

205
00:09:07.120 --> 00:09:10.290
The larger your mailbox database is, the
longer this backup will take to run, and

206
00:09:10.290 --> 00:09:13.070
if you're backing up over
a network it'll take even longer.

207
00:09:13.070 --> 00:09:15.120
All right, but
once it's done we'll be able to pick and

208
00:09:15.120 --> 00:09:17.720
choose the data out of it to
get recorded and get in place.

209
00:09:17.720 --> 00:09:20.860
Also keep in mind there are third party
software solutions out there that can

210
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:22.170
do this too.

211
00:09:22.170 --> 00:09:24.780
Things like Semantic Back Up Exec,
or Arcserve,

212
00:09:24.780 --> 00:09:30.120
Comvault, Acronis True Image, oh no,
Acronis Advanced Back Up for Exchange.

213
00:09:30.120 --> 00:09:32.580
There's a number of products
out there that'll do it.

214
00:09:32.580 --> 00:09:36.200
Most of them don't really offer you
anything you don't have right here in

215
00:09:36.200 --> 00:09:39.710
Windows Server Backup, but there's two
features that people really pay for.

216
00:09:39.710 --> 00:09:41.540
The first feature is
centralized management.

217
00:09:41.540 --> 00:09:43.380
If you're backing up more than one server,

218
00:09:43.380 --> 00:09:45.460
Windows Server Backup's
not really good for that.

219
00:09:45.460 --> 00:09:47.750
Microsoft has
the System Center Data Protection Manager.

220
00:09:47.750 --> 00:09:48.608
There's that one.

221
00:09:48.608 --> 00:09:51.640
The third party solutions can sometimes
integrate with other software better, so

222
00:09:51.640 --> 00:09:53.100
you might choose to go that route.

223
00:09:53.100 --> 00:09:56.130
The other feature,
single item recovery, right?

224
00:09:56.130 --> 00:09:57.855
If a user calls me and says, hey Don,

225
00:09:57.855 --> 00:10:01.900
I deleted this one document out of
a public folder, can you restore it?

226
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:05.390
I'll say yes, but the real answer is no,
I can't restore that one document,

227
00:10:05.390 --> 00:10:07.620
I have to restore that
whole public folder.

228
00:10:07.620 --> 00:10:12.340
So if I restore a backup from six months
ago, anything that's been deleted

229
00:10:12.340 --> 00:10:14.720
from that period six months
ago is gonna be back again.

230
00:10:14.720 --> 00:10:16.890
So I can't restore just one document.

231
00:10:16.890 --> 00:10:19.410
If you want that granular
level of restore,

232
00:10:19.410 --> 00:10:21.620
third party solutions are gonna
be the way that you want to go.

233
00:10:21.620 --> 00:10:24.930
All right,
now this backup is churning along, and

234
00:10:24.930 --> 00:10:26.670
it's already done a snapshot of my server.

235
00:10:26.670 --> 00:10:29.840
So if I start making changes now, things
aren't gonna become part of the backup,

236
00:10:29.840 --> 00:10:32.670
they'll actually be separate, because
of the way volume shadow copy works.

237
00:10:32.670 --> 00:10:36.820
Right, the volume shadow copy snapshot
right when the backup started, and

238
00:10:36.820 --> 00:10:39.210
now it's backing up that snapshot.

239
00:10:39.210 --> 00:10:41.180
So my database could be changing and
updating and

240
00:10:41.180 --> 00:10:42.740
that's not gonna get rolled back in here.

241
00:10:42.740 --> 00:10:46.730
That's a little bit of a difference too,

00:10:54.710 --> 00:10:56.660

00:18:20.510 --> 00:18:24.150

Then so what we have to do is

00:18:31.520 --> 00:18:32.540
