00:21:19.750 --> 00:21:22.890
Now, technically this is all I need and
I should be able to press enter,

469
00:21:22.890 --> 00:21:27.140
but there's a little bug in Exchange 2013
right now that hasn't been fixed yet, so

470
00:21:27.140 --> 00:21:30.460
I need to tell it to skip over
the storage provider configuration.

471
00:21:30.460 --> 00:21:34.750
Now, by the time you watch this, the bug
might be fixed, and if it is, you can

472
00:21:34.750 --> 00:21:38.610
leave this off, or leave this command in,
it'll be fine, it doesn't hurt anything,

473
00:21:38.610 --> 00:21:41.395
the storage configuration doesn't really
have a whole lot of bearing here.

474
00:21:41.395 --> 00:21:44.587
So I'm just gonna tell it to
skip a little bit of data here.

475
00:21:44.587 --> 00:21:46.845
All right, at this point there is one
little thing that we might need to add to

476
00:21:46.845 --> 00:21:50.495
our command line and that's because
public folders are very old technology,

477
00:21:50.495 --> 00:21:53.805
they've been around and so there might
be a value called a legacy DN or

478
00:21:53.805 --> 00:21:57.655
distinguished name attached to it, and I
have to allow for that DN to be present or

479
00:21:57.655 --> 00:22:01.185
not present because on the new server it
probably isn't present, so I'm gonna say,

480
00:22:01.185 --> 00:22:06.620
-Allowlegacydnmismatch.

481
00:22:06.620 --> 00:22:07.220
Okay.

482
00:22:07.220 --> 00:22:10.760
And what that says is if on this
new server, if it is a new server,

483
00:22:10.760 --> 00:22:13.730
if the DN is missing, the legacy DN,
don't worry about it.

484
00:22:13.730 --> 00:22:15.730
If the legacy DN doesn't match,
don't worry about it,

485
00:22:15.730 --> 00:22:17.600
let's just get this restored.

486
00:22:17.600 --> 00:22:20.280
You don't really know because it
all comes down to history, right.

487
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:21.700
How old is this public folder,

488
00:22:21.700 --> 00:22:23.970
was it migrated from previous
versions of Exchange.

489
00:22:23.970 --> 00:22:27.600
This is just gonna make sure that it goes
nice and smooth to get that connected.

490
00:22:27.600 --> 00:22:33.410
And then the very last thing,
I need to say include Folders.

491
00:22:33.410 --> 00:22:34.820
Oops, I forgot my dash there.

492
00:22:34.820 --> 00:22:38.060
I need to say -IncludeFolders.

493
00:22:38.060 --> 00:22:42.450
And here's where I can specify
the individual folders inside that I

494
00:22:42.450 --> 00:22:43.430
wanna restore.

495
00:22:43.430 --> 00:22:46.340
If I leave this off,
it's gonna restore the whole thing.

496
00:22:46.340 --> 00:22:48.680
Well I've got marketing and sales.

497
00:22:48.680 --> 00:22:49.870
They're not having a problem.

498
00:22:49.870 --> 00:22:51.500
It's the IT people.

499
00:22:51.500 --> 00:22:55.090
They're the ones calling and
telling me hey, you need to restore IT.

500
00:22:55.090 --> 00:23:00.840
And so I need to give it the path for
that folder, which would be slash IT.

501
00:23:00.840 --> 00:23:03.470
So that's what I want to restore back and
get in place.

502
00:23:03.470 --> 00:23:06.820
So the new mailbox restore request,
it's getting the data from the recovery

503
00:23:06.820 --> 00:23:11.390
database, from the public folders mailbox,
it's restoring it to the public folder's

504
00:23:11.390 --> 00:23:15.980
mailbox on the production database, and
it's getting that IT folder, right?

505
00:23:15.980 --> 00:23:18.020
That's what it's gonna grab and
it's gonna restore.

506
00:23:18.020 --> 00:23:20.790
All right, well it looks like I
got an error and if we look at it.

507
00:23:20.790 --> 00:23:21.930
Oh, I see what's going on here.

508
00:23:21.930 --> 00:23:26.540
We've got folder path \ IT contains
an invalid escaped character.

509
00:23:26.540 --> 00:23:30.440
I put the \ in because that's
the path to the folder.

510
00:23:30.440 --> 00:23:31.720
But I don't need the backslash.

511
00:23:31.720 --> 00:23:33.300
Here it's treating it
as an escape character.

512
00:23:33.300 --> 00:23:35.930
So if I just rerun that command and
leave that slash off,

513
00:23:35.930 --> 00:23:40.580
I'm including the folder IT and I can use
commas to add other folders in there, and

514
00:23:40.580 --> 00:23:44.530
so if I run that, there we go, it's gonna
create that mailbox restore request.

515
00:23:44.530 --> 00:23:46.820
And I can see that it's cued and

516
00:23:46.820 --> 00:23:52.000
if I start to monitor to that I
can run get-mailboxrestorerequest.

517
00:23:52.000 --> 00:23:54.020
And we can run that and
watch to see when it finishes.

518
00:23:54.020 --> 00:23:57.730
The larger the public folder is, the
longer it's gonna take to do that restore.

519
00:23:57.730 --> 00:24:02.040
Here I see this one has run several,
run pretty quick, and completed already.

520
00:24:02.040 --> 00:24:05.570
But we might have to run this several
times to actually see whether or

521
00:24:05.570 --> 00:24:07.700
not it has finished, all right?

522
00:24:07.700 --> 00:24:10.230
But once it's finished, that deleted mail?

523
00:24:10.230 --> 00:24:11.830
No, that should be back.

524
00:24:11.830 --> 00:24:15.260
Now, in my own experience, I've seen where
public folders can take a little while

525
00:24:15.260 --> 00:24:18.150
to show up though for the end user,
especially if you have copies.

526
00:24:18.150 --> 00:24:21.840
Because we just restored it to
the writable public folder.

527
00:24:21.840 --> 00:24:24.770
But if you've got copies of it,
it's now gonna replicate and

528
00:24:24.770 --> 00:24:27.000
it uses active directory application for
that.

529
00:24:27.000 --> 00:24:29.170
And so
it could happen in the next 15 minutes or

530
00:24:29.170 --> 00:24:32.060
it could take up to 90 minutes to
actually make it to the other side.

531
00:24:32.060 --> 00:24:33.980
So it can take a little while.

532
00:24:33.980 --> 00:24:35.600
In my case,
I've only got one server though, so

533
00:24:35.600 --> 00:24:37.160
it should show up pretty quickly.

534
00:24:37.160 --> 00:24:40.700
Let me jump back over here and see if I,

535
00:24:40.700 --> 00:24:44.190
do like a forced refresh on this,
if I can get it.

536
00:24:44.190 --> 00:24:47.190
Outlook Web App also takes a little
while to pick these things up.

537
00:24:47.190 --> 00:24:48.880
But if we take a look,
there it is, sure enough.

538
00:24:48.880 --> 00:24:52.010
There's my sample report back again,
restored from the backup, and

539
00:24:52.010 --> 00:24:52.810
the new stuff, right?

540
00:24:52.810 --> 00:24:56.490
This get stuff done,
I did that one after I took the backup.

541
00:24:56.490 --> 00:24:57.800
It doesn't wipe out new stuff.

542
00:24:57.800 --> 00:25:01.505
It just brings back the old stuff, and
now I've got my public folder back and

543
00:25:01.505 --> 00:25:03.155
I'm in business, okay.

544
00:25:03.155 --> 00:25:05.975
So the process is really, really,

545
00:25:05.975 --> 00:25:09.675
really similar to restoring a single user
mailbox, just a little bit different.

546
00:25:09.675 --> 00:25:12.395
We had the legacy DN stuff
we had to worry about, and

547
00:25:12.395 --> 00:25:15.770
we had to specify the individual
folders we wanted to restore.

548
00:25:15.770 --> 00:25:17.620
Instead of restoring the entire mailbox,

549
00:25:17.620 --> 00:25:19.060
although we could've
done the whole mailbox.

550
00:25:20.310 --> 00:25:23.460
All right, well that pretty much
wraps it up for this episode.

551
00:25:23.460 --> 00:25:27.350
So, in this episode we got a chance to see
how to back-up our public folder mailbox,

552
00:25:27.350 --> 00:25:28.710
which really wasn't a big deal.

553
00:25:28.710 --> 00:25:30.790
We saw how to restore the mailbox,

554
00:25:30.790 --> 00:25:34.690
get it mounted as a recovery database,
pick the data our of there and

555
00:25:34.690 --> 00:25:38.660
move it into our production database, and
get it back and available for our users.

556
00:25:38.660 --> 00:25:42.780
And the best part is this whole process
from backup to restore was done,

557
00:25:42.780 --> 00:25:44.220
while users can be in the database.

558
00:25:44.220 --> 00:25:46.990
We never actually had to kick
people out of the public folder.

559
00:25:46.990 --> 00:25:49.650
They could be in there working while
we were doing the whole process, so

560
00:25:49.650 --> 00:25:50.712
it's really not that bad.

561
00:25:50.712 --> 00:25:53.838
The PowerShell command's a little lengthy,
yet, that's kind of the tough one to

562
00:25:53.838 --> 00:25:55.998
remember but
the rest of it's pretty straight forward.

563
00:25:55.998 --> 00:25:59.506
So, all right, well that's a good spot for
us to wrap this one up, so

564
00:25:59.506 --> 00:26:03.498
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode,
signing off for ITProTV I'm Don Pizet and

565
00:26:03.498 --> 00:26:04.787
I'll see you next time.

566
00:26:04.787 --> 00:26:11.090
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use Microsoft Exchange Recovery Databases to restore a single user's mailbox. While complex, the process is preferable to a full restore as it does not disturb other user's mailboxes.
episodes.title: Single Mailbox Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.086 --> 00:00:13.570
All right good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.570 --> 00:00:15.800
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.800 --> 00:00:17.600
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17.600 --> 00:00:20.490
Back again with another episode
of Microsoft Exchange 2013.

6
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:26.110
In this episode, we're gonna take a look
at restoring a single user's mailbox.

7
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:30.500
Now in other episodes we've talked about
recovering our entire database server, but

8
00:00:30.500 --> 00:00:32.630
sometimes you just need one mailbox,
right?

9
00:00:32.630 --> 00:00:35.880
For example, a user might have
deleted a bunch of their stuff and

10
00:00:35.880 --> 00:00:36.870
they want it back.

11
00:00:36.870 --> 00:00:39.580
Well, you know, if they delete something,
it goes to the recycle bin.

12
00:00:39.580 --> 00:00:41.310
Maybe they emptied the recycle bin.

13
00:00:41.310 --> 00:00:45.370
Well, there's deleted item retention
that holds it for 30 more days, but

14
00:00:45.370 --> 00:00:48.640
maybe they need something from two months
ago or three months, or maybe a year ago,

15
00:00:48.640 --> 00:00:50.620
and it's been gone a long time.

16
00:00:50.620 --> 00:00:52.950
Well, it's beyond their
ability to restore it.

17
00:00:52.950 --> 00:00:54.000
And now it's up to us.

18
00:00:54.000 --> 00:00:58.120
We can go to our old back up tapes and
we can restore that user's mailbox.

19
00:00:58.120 --> 00:01:00.080
Just that one user.

20
00:01:00.080 --> 00:01:03.590
Now we can't restore individual email
items, not without third party software.

21
00:01:03.590 --> 00:01:05.110
But we can restore their mailbox.

22
00:01:05.110 --> 00:01:08.190
In other words, we could take
their mailbox from a year ago,

23
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:12.750
merge it into their Live mailbox and now
they'll have the missing data back again.

24
00:01:12.750 --> 00:01:15.730
They'll also have anything else they
deleted from a year ago back again too, so

25
00:01:15.730 --> 00:01:18.580
it's gonna be a little bit of work on
their part, but that's their own problem,

26
00:01:18.580 --> 00:01:20.670
because they should have deleted
stuff in the first place.

27
00:01:20.670 --> 00:01:21.880
But fortunately we can get to it, right?

28
00:01:21.880 --> 00:01:24.440
Another, let me give you
a more realistic example.

29
00:01:24.440 --> 00:01:26.290
Maybe you terminated an employee.

30
00:01:26.290 --> 00:01:30.390
They got fired and she deleted their
account, deleted their mailbox.

31
00:01:30.390 --> 00:01:34.330
Well, three months, six months later,
your legal department comes and says, ooh,

32
00:01:34.330 --> 00:01:35.210
we're under litigation.

33
00:01:35.210 --> 00:01:36.890
We need that user's mailbox, right.

34
00:01:36.890 --> 00:01:37.900
We need to recover the mailbox.

35
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:39.920
Well, it's gone from the server.

36
00:01:39.920 --> 00:01:43.060
The mailbox recovery,
the default period for it's 30 days,

37
00:01:43.060 --> 00:01:45.140
unless you have like
an in place hold on it.

38
00:01:45.140 --> 00:01:47.590
That data's gone, but
you go to your back up tapes.

39
00:01:47.590 --> 00:01:50.100
You can go and you can get it and
you can restore that data.

40
00:01:50.100 --> 00:01:53.540
So we can always get it bring it back and
restore that users mailbox.

41
00:01:53.540 --> 00:01:55.561
But we don't want to mess
with everybody on our server,

42
00:01:55.561 --> 00:01:58.020
we don't want to restore
the whole mailbox database.

43
00:01:58.020 --> 00:02:00.680
We just want that one mailbox, all right.

44
00:02:00.680 --> 00:02:03.850
Fortunately it's not that hard and
if you've watched our dial tone recovery

45
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:07.760
episode it's kind of similar to the dial
tone recovery, except a little bit easier.

46
00:02:07.760 --> 00:02:11.070
So let's take a look at the process,
and we'll see how to restore a user.

47
00:02:11.070 --> 00:02:15.345
All right, I'm gonna take a user like,
I've got Jane Smith here.

48
00:02:15.345 --> 00:02:19.220
Jane Smith; she's an email user in
my system, and she's got a mailbox,

49
00:02:19.220 --> 00:02:20.610
I'm actually logged into her OWA here.

50
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:24.240
She's got one email here from the
administrator, it was sent back on Sunday.

51
00:02:24.240 --> 00:02:26.540
And so she's got an email, very exciting.

52
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:27.260
Right?

53
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:30.740
Well maybe she's been terminated and
I removed her mailbox, or

54
00:02:30.740 --> 00:02:32.890
maybe she just deleted some stuff.

55
00:02:32.890 --> 00:02:36.200
If I removed her mailbox, step one,
I need to recreate her mailbox.

56
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:40.170
I can create a new active directory
user account and add a mailbox to it.

57
00:02:40.170 --> 00:02:42.370
The important part is that the mailbox
needs to have the same name,

58
00:02:42.370 --> 00:02:44.730
and the same email
address as it had before.

59
00:02:44.730 --> 00:02:49.010
So, if she was Jane Smith, and
her email was jsmith@itvprotv.net,

60
00:02:49.010 --> 00:02:52.650
I need to create a new account called
Jane Smith and jsmith@itprotv.net.

61
00:02:52.650 --> 00:02:56.290
And as long as the name is the same,
I can restore her data to it.

62
00:02:56.290 --> 00:02:57.140
Even if the name's different,

63
00:02:57.140 --> 00:03:00.740
you can actually get around that, but
by default it wants those to be the same.

64
00:03:00.740 --> 00:03:02.070
So I'm gonna stick with that.

65
00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:05.420
Now if they just had some deleted items,
the mailbox already exists.

66
00:03:05.420 --> 00:03:08.650
I'm just gonna be merging into it,
so there's no big deal there, right?

67
00:03:08.650 --> 00:03:13.340
So maybe she comes in and she deletes an
email, like I'll delete this admin email.

68
00:03:13.340 --> 00:03:16.350
And I can go to her deleted items and
there it still is, right.

69
00:03:16.350 --> 00:03:17.850
She can recover that.

70
00:03:17.850 --> 00:03:21.516
And then if she goes in here and
empties that out, now it's gone, right,

71
00:03:21.516 --> 00:03:23.220
it's gone forever.

72
00:03:23.220 --> 00:03:24.220
Well not really.

73
00:03:24.220 --> 00:03:25.750
Exchange is gonna keep it.

74
00:03:25.750 --> 00:03:29.790
And assuming I'm at like a default install
of Exchange, it's gonna hold that for

75
00:03:29.790 --> 00:03:30.560
30 days.

76
00:03:30.560 --> 00:03:33.970
So even 30 days from now she'll
be able to recover that.

77
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:38.050
And if you right click on a mailbox,
see how I can go to recover deleted items?

78
00:03:38.050 --> 00:03:40.207
And when we do that, oop,
it wants to do a pop up so

79
00:03:40.207 --> 00:03:42.320
I gotta approve the pop up real quick.

80
00:03:42.320 --> 00:03:45.910
But you can go to deleted items, you can
right click and do recover deleted items

81
00:03:45.910 --> 00:03:49.450
and in here, should be able to see,
there's the email still there.

82
00:03:49.450 --> 00:03:51.280
Right, so
you really do have a big window of time.

83
00:03:51.280 --> 00:03:53.670
This is not something we're
gonna be doing right away.

84
00:03:53.670 --> 00:03:57.250
But, I do have a nice little purge
option down here at the bottom, and

85
00:03:57.250 --> 00:03:58.490
I'm gonna purge this out.

86
00:03:58.490 --> 00:04:03.370
Now if I purge it in the default
configuration of Exchange,

87
00:04:03.370 --> 00:04:04.480
that's gone now, it's gone.

88
00:04:04.480 --> 00:04:07.690
If I have an in place hold or something
like that configured it's actually

89
00:04:07.690 --> 00:04:10.880
being retained on the back end as
part of our records management, but

90
00:04:10.880 --> 00:04:13.460
she wouldn't know that, she would
think that it's purged, all right.

91
00:04:13.460 --> 00:04:16.590
But that email's gone, and
it's gone, and she can't get to it.

92
00:04:16.590 --> 00:04:19.120
And then if she says, oh no,
I really needed that email!

93
00:04:19.120 --> 00:04:20.800
Let me call the help desk.

94
00:04:20.800 --> 00:04:23.430
All right she calls the help desk and
they send a ticket up to you as the email

95
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:27.650
admin, and you now need to recover her
mailbox to bring that back, all right.

96
00:04:27.650 --> 00:04:29.920
Now we can't pick and
choose one email, so we just ask her,

97
00:04:29.920 --> 00:04:31.760
hey, when did you delete it?

98
00:04:31.760 --> 00:04:34.220
And she says, well,
I deleted it last June.

99
00:04:34.220 --> 00:04:37.930
So we need to go and find a backup
from last June, from right before,

100
00:04:37.930 --> 00:04:40.780
as close as we can get to where
she deleted it, all right?

101
00:04:40.780 --> 00:04:44.150
And then we can restore the backup,
and merge that in.

102
00:04:44.150 --> 00:04:45.660
Now to restore the backup,

103
00:04:45.660 --> 00:04:49.410
I need to make sure that I don't
mess with my current users, right.

104
00:04:49.410 --> 00:04:51.360
I don't want to mess with
anybody else's database, so

105
00:04:51.360 --> 00:04:54.050
we're gonna have to be a little sensitive
to that as we go through and restore it.

106
00:04:54.050 --> 00:04:55.430
Let me show you the process.

107
00:04:55.430 --> 00:04:57.630
First off I'm gonna fire up
my Windows Server backup and

108
00:04:57.630 --> 00:04:59.510
I'm gonna restore a backup that I've got.

109
00:04:59.510 --> 00:05:03.100
So I'll go into my server manager, I'll
go to tools, and Windows Server backup.

110
00:05:03.100 --> 00:05:05.150
If you use third party software,
you'd go to it.

111
00:05:05.150 --> 00:05:07.060
I'm using Windows Server Backup.

112
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:09.449
And I need to find a backup,
so I'll do recover.

113
00:05:10.850 --> 00:05:14.160
And when I go to restore,
it's gonna ask me when I want to restore.

114
00:05:14.160 --> 00:05:16.200
And so I'll go back and
pick as close to the date,

115
00:05:16.200 --> 00:05:18.750
but prior to her deleting her content.

116
00:05:18.750 --> 00:05:21.090
Or prior to us deleting that mailbox,
right.

117
00:05:21.090 --> 00:05:22.680
I just need to go back
to that point in time.

118
00:05:24.260 --> 00:05:27.560
Then, I'm gonna choose to
restore an application, and

119
00:05:27.560 --> 00:05:31.290
I'm gonna be restoring Exchange, and
this is where it gets important.

120
00:05:31.290 --> 00:05:31.850
Alright?

121
00:05:31.850 --> 00:05:35.220
If I choose to recover to the original
location, it's going to restore

122
00:05:35.220 --> 00:05:37.960
everybody's mailbox and
I'm going to have a lot of angry users.

123
00:05:37.960 --> 00:05:38.910
